passage_content: ואראאלקיםאל משה ויאמר אליו אני ד'. דקדקו המפורשים מ"ט התחיל הכתוב בשםאלקיםמדה"דובלשון דיבור קשה, וסיים ויאמר אליו אני ד' שם של רחמים ואמירה לשון רכה, ורש"י ז"ל פי' דבר אתו משפט על שהקשה לדבר ולומר למההרעותהוגו' ויאמר אליו אני ד' נאמן לשלם שכר טוב וכו'וצ"בדלפי"זהמה ב' דברות סמוכיםזל"ז,וה"זמקרא קצר ולא נתבאר כוונת הדיבור והקישור בין שניהם,ובמד"ר(פ' ו' סי' א') נתבאר יותר לפי שאמר למההרעותהוגו' על דבר זה בקשהמדה"דלפגוע במשההה"דוידבראלקיםאל משה, ולפי שנסתכל הקב"ה שבשביל צער ישראל דבר כן חזר ונהג עמובמדתהרחמים,הה"דויאמר אליו אני ד' עכ"ד המדרש,וצ"בדהלאהבוי"תמסתכל בסוף דבר בקדמותו, ומעיקרא ידעדבשבילצערן של ישראל דיבר כך, ומהו זה שאמרו חזר ונהג עמובמדתהרחמים, ולא שייך חזרה לפניוית'.
translation: And God appeared to Moses and said to him, "I am the Lord." The commentators have noted that the verse begins with the name of God, which is a measure of strict judgment, and ends with "I am the Lord," a name of mercy and a gentle expression. Rashi, of blessed memory, explained that He spoke with him a judgment for having been difficult to speak and say, "Why have You done evil to this people?" and He said to him, "I am the Lord," faithful to reward good, etc. According to this, what is the connection between the two statements that are adjacent to each other? This is a brief verse, and the intent of the speech and the connection between them is not explained. In the Midrash (Parashat Va'eira, section 1), it is explained further, as it says, "Why have You done evil to this people?" Regarding this, the measure of strict judgment sought to confront Moses. And since the Holy One, blessed be He, saw that because of the suffering of Israel, He spoke this way, He returned and acted with them according to the measure of mercy, as it says, "And He said to him, 'I am the Lord.'" Thus far the Midrash. And it is difficult to understand why it looks at the end of the matter in its beginning, and initially, it is known that it was because of the suffering of Israel that He spoke this way. What does it mean that they said He returned and acted with them according to the measure of mercy, and it is not appropriate to say "returned" before Him?
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the dialogue between God and Moses highlights the duality of divine attributes, contrasting the strictness of "Elohim" with the compassion of "YHWH." The text emphasizes that God's initial harshness in addressing Moses was a response to the suffering of the Israelites, but ultimately, God returned to a mode of mercy. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the interplay between justice and compassion, illustrating that divine communication is influenced by the plight of the people. The passage underscores the importance of understanding God's actions in the context of human suffering and the divine promise of reward for faithfulness.

passage_content: ב)דרשובמד"ר(פ' ו' סי' ב') ר"יב"רחנינאאמראלקיםעל המצרים: אני ד' על ישראל, ופי'היפ"תאלקיםעל המצרים שיבוא בדין עליהם. אני ד' על ישראל לרחם עליהם כנגד מה שהרעו להם לישראל,וצ"בדמצרייםמאןדכרשמי', ולפי פשוטו נאמר דיבור זה למשה, גםלפי"זאין לו קישור לא לפרשה של מעלה למההרעותהוגו' ולא לפרשהשלאחרי'.
translation: In the Midrash (Parashat Va'era, Section 2), Rabbi Chaninah said: "God said to the Egyptians: I am the Lord over Israel, and I will bring judgment upon the Egyptians. I am the Lord over Israel to have mercy on them, in contrast to the evil they have done to Israel. And concerning the Egyptians, who is it that remembers My name? According to its simple meaning, this statement was said to Moses, and therefore it has no connection to the section above regarding the evil they have done, nor to the section that follows."
summary: The passage discusses the relationship between God and Israel, emphasizing God's compassion towards His people in contrast to the judgment that falls upon their oppressors, the Egyptians. It highlights the idea that God's mercy for Israel is a response to the suffering they endured, suggesting a deep connection between divine justice and mercy. Additionally, it notes that this message was conveyed to Moses, indicating a direct communication of God's intentions and the significance of His name in the context of Israel's redemption.

passage_content: ג)איתא (רמז קע"ו) וידבראלקיםאל משה וגו'זש"ה(תהלים נ') שמעה עמי ואדברה ישראל ואעידה בךאלקיםאלקיךאנכי,א"רפנחס הכהן ברחמאאמר הקב"ה למשה בשביל שקראתי אותךאלקיםשנא' ראהנתתיךאלקיםלפרעה,אלקיךאני ולכך נאמר וידבראלקיםאל משה עכ"ד המדרש,וצ"ב.
translation: 3) It is stated (Remez 196) "And God spoke to Moses, etc." as it is written (Psalms 50) "Hear, O My people, and I will speak; O Israel, and I will testify against you, I am God, your God." Rabbi Pinchas the priest said in mercy: The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "Because I have called you 'God,' as it is written, 'See, I have made you a god to Pharaoh,' I am your God, and therefore it is said, 'And God spoke to Moses.'" Thus far the Midrash, and it requires further explanation.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author highlights the profound relationship between God and Moses, emphasizing that God refers to Moses as "Elokim" (God) in recognition of his elevated spiritual status. This designation signifies Moses' role as a mediator between God and the Israelites, reflecting the deep connection and responsibility he bears. The text underscores the idea that divine communication is not merely a transmission of information but an intimate dialogue that elevates the recipient. Ultimately, it illustrates the concept of divine empowerment, where Moses is entrusted with the mission to lead and guide the people, embodying the divine presence among them.

passage_content: ויתבארבהקדםמ"שק"זהיש"מזלל"הבפ' שמות לפרש דבריהילקו"שבשלח (רמז רל"ד) והמים להם חומה, חמה כתיב שנתמלא עליהם הים חמה להטביעןוכו', מיד אותה חמה שנתמלא על ישראל החזירו על מצרים,הה"דוישבו המים ששבו מישראל על מצרים, ולכאורה תמוה וכי יעבידקוב"הדינאבלאדינאח"ו,דחימהשל ישראל יהי' על מצרים, הלא די להם בשלהםוק"לאמונה ואין עול, אבל יובן כפשוטועפי"דהמדרש שטען שר של מצרים מהנשתנואלו מאלו הללועוע"זוהללו עובדי ע"ז, והשיבית' וכי לדעתם עבדוה, והלא לא עבדוה אלא מתוך שעבוד ומתוך טירוף הדעת, ואתה דן שוגג כמזיד ואונס כרצוןוכו', וידועמ"שהשלה"קוירעו אותנו המצרים וגו' שעשו אותנו רעים וחטאים,ועפי"זיבוא על נכון המדרש הנ"ל,דאותהחמה החזיר על המצריים, כי הם הגורמים וישראל אנוסים עכת"דהק', ולכאורה עדיין ראוי להבין למה הי' הצורך להשתמשבחימהשל ישראל, וכי לא הי' מספיק בשלהם,ובל"סראויים היו המצרים למדת עונשם גם בשבילעוונותםשעבדו ע"ז ועוד הרבה רעות שעשו.
translation: And it will be explained in advance regarding what is written, "This is the sign of the Mazal" in Parashat Shemot, to explain the words of the Midrash in Beshalach (Remez 274) that "the waters were a wall for them," it is written that the sea was filled with heat to drown them, etc. Immediately, that heat which was filled upon Israel was returned upon Egypt, as it is said, "And the waters that returned from Israel upon Egypt." And at first glance, it is puzzling: how could the Holy One, blessed be He, act in judgment without judgment? That the heat of Israel should be upon Egypt? Surely they have enough of their own, and there is no burden, but it can be understood simply and according to the Midrash that claims that the Egyptians were not like these, but rather these are idol worshippers, and "I will return it," and did they serve it according to their understanding? They did not serve it except out of servitude and out of madness, and you judge a mistake as if it were intentional and coercion as if it were willful, etc. And it is known from what is written, "The Egyptians did evil to us," etc., that they made us wicked and sinful. And according to this, the aforementioned Midrash will come to be understood correctly, that the same heat was returned upon the Egyptians, for they are the cause, and Israel is coerced, thus far the quote. And at first glance, it is still necessary to understand why there was a need to use the heat of Israel; was it not enough with their own? And certainly, the Egyptians were deserving of their measure of punishment also for their sins of idol worship and many other evils they committed.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine justice, highlighting that the anger directed at the Egyptians during the Exodus was a reflection of the suffering endured by the Israelites. It emphasizes that the Egyptians' actions, rooted in idolatry and oppression, warranted their punishment, yet the use of Israel's anger in this divine retribution raises questions about the necessity of such a measure. The text suggests that the Israelites were coerced into sin by their oppressors, thus framing their suffering as a mitigating factor in the divine judgment against Egypt. Ultimately, it underscores the complexity of divine justice, where the motivations and circumstances of both the oppressed and the oppressors are taken into account.

passage_content: ואפשרלתרץעפימ"שבמתני' (סוטה דף כ' ע"א) יש זכות תולה ב' שנים. יש זכות תולה ג' שנים, ובגמ' שם רצו ללמדה מפסוקדכתיבגבי אדום (עמוס א') כה אמר ד' על שלשה פשעי אדום וגו', ומסיק דאין ראי' לדבר אלא זכר לדבר,דדלמאשאני עכו"ם דלא מפקידדינאעלייהועכ"דהגמ'ופרש"יאיןממהריןמן השמים לפקודעונותםעליהם בעוה"ז, אבל מישראלממהריןליפרעבעוה"זומדקדקיןאחריהם, ובזה יבואר דברי מדרש הנ"לדאותהחמה שנתמלא על ישראל החזירו על מצרים אע"פ שגם הם עבדו ע"ז וראויים היו לעונש, אבל עכו"ם לא מפקדדינאעלייהוואיןממהריןלהפרעמהם מידת ענשם, ואפשר הטעם כדי שיקבלו מדת שכרם עבור הטוב המגיע להם, וכשנתמלא סאתם הקב"ה פורע מהם, אבל לפי שהי' שליטת הדיןוהחימהעל ישראל, והמצריים היו הגורמים ומחטיאים אותם, ע"כ נמדד להםבמדתםשל ישראלשמדה"דממהרתלהפרעמהםומדקדקיןאחריהםכפרש"יז"ל.
translation: And it is possible to explain according to what is stated in the Mishnah (Sotah 20a) that there is a merit that is suspended for two years. There is a merit that is suspended for three years, and in the Gemara there, they wanted to learn it from the verse written regarding Edom (Amos 1): "Thus says the Lord: For three transgressions of Edom, and for four, I will not revoke it," and it concludes that this is not a proof to the matter but rather a reminder of the matter, for perhaps it is different with idolaters who do not have their judgment upon them, and thus the Gemara explains, and Rashi explains that they are not hastened from Heaven to exact their sins upon them in this world, but with Israel, they are hastened to exact in this world and are meticulous after them. And this will clarify the words of the aforementioned Midrash regarding the heat that was filled against Israel; it returned upon Egypt even though they also served idols and were deserving of punishment, but the idolaters do not have their judgment upon them, and they are not hastened to exact from them their measure of punishment. And perhaps the reason is so that they may receive their measure of reward for the good that is due to them, and when their measure is full, the Holy One, blessed be He, exacts from them. However, since the judgment and the heat were upon Israel, and the Egyptians were the causes and the ones who led them astray, therefore they were measured by the measure of Israel, which is that the judgment is hastened to exact from them and is meticulous after them, as Rashi, may his memory be blessed, explains.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine justice and the differing treatment of Israel and the nations regarding punishment for sins. It highlights that while the nations may not be immediately held accountable for their transgressions, Israel faces swift retribution due to their covenantal relationship with God. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the nature of divine mercy and justice, where Israel's suffering is seen as a consequence of their unique responsibilities and the influence of external forces, such as the Egyptians, on their spiritual state. Ultimately, it emphasizes the idea that God's judgment is measured and purposeful, allowing for the nations to receive their due reward before facing consequences.

passage_content: ומעתהיתבארו ב' המדרשים הנ"ל, ושניהם על קוטב א' נאמרו, והואדבקשהמדת הדין לפגוע במשה על שהקשה לומר למההרעותה, והגם שבשביל צערן של ישראל דבר כן, אבל לפי מידת גדלו וצדקתו הי' בזה פגם קצת ע"דוסביביונשערה מאוד, אולם לפי שהמצריים היו הגורמים לצערן של ישראל, והם אשר סובבולמדה"דשיחול, ע"כ בדין הוא שאותוהחימהומדה"דפגעה בהם במצרים, וזה לעומת זה נהג הקב"ה עם ישראלבמדתהרחמיםוז"שבמדרשאלקיםעל מצרים, אני ה' על ישראל, ומעתה א"ש קישור דרשתם ז"ל עה"פ וידבראלקיםאל משה.
translation: And from now on, the two aforementioned midrashim will be clarified, and both were said regarding one pole, which is that the attribute of judgment sought to strike Moses for questioning why He was causing harm, and although it was due to the suffering of Israel that this was said, according to the measure of his greatness and righteousness, there was a slight flaw in this, akin to a very strong whirlwind. However, since the Egyptians were the cause of Israel's suffering, and they were the ones who brought about the attribute of judgment to descend, therefore it is just that the heat and the attribute of judgment struck them in Egypt. Thus, the Holy One, Blessed be He, dealt with Israel with the attribute of mercy, as it is stated in the midrash regarding God’s relationship with Egypt, "I am the Lord concerning Israel." And from now on, I will explain the connection of their teaching regarding the verse "And God spoke to Moses."
summary: The passage discusses the tension between divine justice and mercy, particularly in the context of Moses questioning God about the suffering of the Israelites. It highlights that while Moses' inquiry reflects a slight imperfection due to his elevated status, the suffering of the Israelites is ultimately a result of the Egyptians' actions. Consequently, God's justice is manifested in punishing the Egyptians, while He extends mercy to the Israelites, illustrating the balance between these two divine attributes. This dynamic is further emphasized through the interpretation of the biblical verse where God speaks to Moses, reinforcing the connection between divine communication and the themes of justice and mercy.

passage_content: ועד"זיתבאר קישור הכתוב וידבראלקיםאל משה ויאמר אליו אני ד', שנתעוררמדה"דעל משה בשביל שאמר למההרעותהומקושר לפרשה שלמעלה הימנו אלא בשביל שהמצרים גרמו לזה ע"י שציערו את ישראל, ע"כ חזרהמדה"דעל המצריים ומדת הרחמים על ישראל, ובזה יתבאר דברי הילקוט הנ"ל אמר הקב"ה למשה בשביל שקראתי אותךאלהיםשנא' ראהנתתיךאלהיםלפרעה, ר"ל להמשיך מדת הדין על פרעה ועל מצרים, ע"כאלקיךאני שנא' וידבראלקיםאל משה, ונתעוררמדה"דעל משה כדי להחזירו על ראש מצרים, שהם היו הגורמים להחטיאם ומגיע להםמדינאכנ"ל.
translation: And similarly, it explains the connection of the verse "And God spoke to Moses and said to him, I am the Lord," that the attribute of judgment was aroused against Moses because he said, "Why have You done evil to this people?" This is connected to the section above it, but it is because the Egyptians caused this by oppressing Israel. Therefore, the attribute of judgment returned upon the Egyptians and the attribute of mercy upon Israel. In this, the words of the aforementioned Yalkut will be clarified: The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "Because I called you 'God,'" as it is said, "See, I have made you a god to Pharaoh," meaning to extend the attribute of judgment upon Pharaoh and upon Egypt. Therefore, "And God spoke to Moses," and the attribute of judgment was aroused against Moses in order to return it upon the head of Egypt, for they were the ones who caused them to sin, and they deserve the aforementioned judgment.
summary: The passage discusses the relationship between divine justice and mercy in the context of Moses' role in confronting Pharaoh. It emphasizes that God's communication with Moses is linked to the suffering of the Israelites caused by the Egyptians, which triggers divine judgment against them. The text highlights that Moses is called "God" to Pharaoh, symbolizing the imposition of divine justice upon the oppressors, while simultaneously reflecting God's compassion for the suffering Israelites. This interplay of attributes illustrates the complexity of divine governance in response to human actions.

passage_content: וידבראלקיםאל משה ויאמר אליו אני ה', פי' רש"י ז"ל דבר אתו משפט על שהקשה לדבר ולומר למההרעותהלעם הזה, לכאורה יש להפליא דהרי משה רבינו הי' מובחר היצורים ולגודל מדריגת קדושתו אין חקרוהי"לאימהופחד ורעדה מהקב"ה יותר מכל הברואים שבעולם, ואיך דיברמרע"הלפני הקב"ה דברים קשים כאלה, ואף לפני מלךב"ולא יאות לומר כןומכ"שלפניממ"ההקב"ה, גם צ"ב הקישור בשאלתו למה זה שלחתנילמ"שלמההרעותהלעם הזה.
translation: And God spoke to Moses and said to him, "I am the Lord." Rashi, may his memory be blessed, explains that He spoke to him a judgment for having the audacity to speak and say, "Why have You done evil to this people?" It is indeed astonishing, for our teacher Moses was the choicest of creations, and due to the greatness of his holiness, there is no end to the awe, fear, and trembling he had before the Holy One, blessed be He, more than all the creations in the world. How then did he speak such harsh words before the Holy One, blessed be He, and even before a king, where it is not fitting to say such things? Furthermore, the connection in his question, "Why have You sent me?" regarding "Why have You done evil to this people?" is also puzzling.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the dialogue between God and Moses highlights the tension between Moses' elevated spiritual status and his bold questioning of God's actions regarding the suffering of the Israelites. The text reflects on the paradox of a revered leader expressing doubt and concern before the Divine, emphasizing the complexity of faith and the human experience of grappling with divine justice. This interaction underscores key Hasidic themes of the relationship between the individual and God, where questioning can be seen as a form of deep engagement with the Divine. Ultimately, it invites contemplation on the nature of divine providence and the role of human agency in the face of suffering.

passage_content: ונל"פבהקדם מה שפירשתי (פ' לך עמוד של"ד)במאמה"כבמה אדע כיאירשנהוגו'פירש"ילא שאל לו אות על בשורת הזרע אבל על ירושת הארץ שאל לו אות ואמר לו במה אדע כיאירשנה, והקשה הרמב"ן ז"ל למה שאל אות בירושת הארץ ובנתינת זרע לא שאל אות עיי"ש תירוצו, עוד פי'רשיז"לד"א במה אדע לא שאל לו אות, אלא אמר לפניו הודיעני באיזה זכות יתקיימו בה, א"ל הקב"ה בזכותהקרבנות, ולכאורה קשה להעמיס זאת בלשון הכתוב במה אדע כיאירשנה. שמשמעותו מורה על הידיעה בעצם ההבטחה אם תתקיים ולא על הזכות במה יזכו, ופירשתי עפ"י המבואר בדבריחכז"לבכ"מכי א"י ניתן על תנאי אם ישמרו ישראל את התורה,כדאיתאבמכילתא פ' יתרו (הובא בילקוט מלכים רמז ק"ע) ג' דברים נתנו על תנאי ארץ ישראל בית המקדש ומלכות בית דוד עיי"ש, והכתוב עומד וצווחויתןלהם ארצות גוים וגו' בעבור ישמרוחקיווגו', ובזה יובן שעל בשורת הזרע לא שאל לו אות, מפני שההבטחההיתהמוחלטת ובלי תנאי,משא"כבשורת הארץ הי' על תנאי אם ישמרו את התורה,ועד"זהיתהשאלתו אם יזכו לירושת הארץ ובאיזה זכות יזכו אלי', והשיב לו הקב"ה בזכותהקרבנותעיין שם בדברינו ביאורהעניןבאריכות, ולכאורה עדיין ראוי להבין מדוע שאל על ידיעת הזכות, ויספיק שיתפלל אל הקב"ה שיזכובנ"ילהרבות מצותומע"טואזבודאייזכו לירושת הארץ.
translation: And it is possible to explain before what I have clarified (in Parashat Lech Lecha, page 34) regarding the matter: "How will I know that I will inherit it?" He did not ask for a sign regarding the promise of the seed, but he asked for a sign regarding the inheritance of the land, and he said, "How will I know that I will inherit it?" The Ramban, of blessed memory, asked why he asked for a sign regarding the inheritance of the land, but did not ask for a sign regarding the giving of the seed. There is a response there. Furthermore, Rabbi Shimon, of blessed memory, explained that "How will I know?" He did not ask for a sign, but rather he said before Him, "Make known to me by what merit they will be sustained in it." The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, "By the merit of the sacrifices." And at first glance, it is difficult to impose this on the language of the text, "How will I know that I will inherit it?" The meaning indicates knowledge of the essence of the promise if it will be fulfilled, and not about the merit by which they will merit it. I explained according to what is clarified in the words of our Sages, of blessed memory, everywhere that the Land of Israel is given conditionally if Israel will observe the Torah, as it is stated in the Mechilta, Parashat Yitro (brought in Yalkut Melachim, hint 490): "Three things were given conditionally: the Land of Israel, the Holy Temple, and the monarchy of the House of David," as it is stated there. And the text stands and cries, "And He gave them the lands of the nations..." because they will observe His commandments. And with this, it can be understood why he did not ask for a sign regarding the promise of the seed, because the promise was absolute and unconditional, whereas the promise of the land was conditional upon their observance of the Torah. Therefore, his question was whether they would merit the inheritance of the land and by what merit they would merit it. And the Holy One, blessed be He, answered him, "By the merit of the sacrifices." See there in our words explaining the matter at length. And at first glance, it is still appropriate to understand why he asked about knowing the merit, and it would suffice for him to pray to the Holy One, blessed be He, that He should merit him to increase in commandments and good deeds, and then he would surely merit the inheritance of the land.
summary: In the passage, the author discusses Abraham's inquiry about the inheritance of the land of Israel, contrasting it with the promise of offspring, which was unconditional. The Ramban's question about why Abraham sought a sign for the land but not for the seed is addressed by explaining that the land's promise was contingent upon Israel's adherence to the Torah. The text emphasizes that the fulfillment of the land's promise relies on the merit of sacrifices, highlighting the conditional nature of the land's inheritance compared to the absolute assurance of progeny. Ultimately, it suggests that Abraham's concern was about the specific merits required for the land, indicating a deeper understanding of the relationship between divine promises and human actions.

passage_content: אמנםידוע כי האבות הקדושים כל פעולתם הי' בשביל דורות העתידים, ועשו פועל דמיוני להכין ישועה לדורות לישראל, וכמושמצינובאאע"הכשבא לשכם הי' מתפלל על בני יעקב כשיבואולהלחםבשכם כפי' רש"יעה"כעד מקום שכם וגו'ועד"זיתבאר שאלת אאע"ה במה אדע באיזה זכות יזכו ישראלוכו', ותכלית ידיעה זו אליו כדי להכיןכחהשפעת זכות זה לבניו שיחזיקו בו, כי זה הי' כל עבודתוהק', וכמ"שכוידעתיו למען אשריצוהאת בניו ואת ביתו אחריו ושמרו דרך ה' וגו' ולזה רצה אאע"ה לידע באיזה זכות יזכו לירושת הארץ כדי להכין להםכחהשפעה זו.
translation: It is known that the holy patriarchs performed all their actions for the sake of future generations, and they created a spiritual impact to prepare salvation for the generations of Israel. As it is stated regarding our father Abraham, when he came to Shechem, he prayed for the children of Jacob when they would come to fight in Shechem, as explained in Rashi, "to the place of Shechem," etc. Similarly, it is explained in the question of our father Abraham, "By what merit will Israel be worthy?" The purpose of this knowledge was to prepare the power of the influence of this merit for his children, so that they would hold onto it, for this was the entirety of his service. As it is written, "For I have known him, in order that he may command his children and his household after him to keep the way of the Lord," etc. Therefore, our father Abraham wanted to know by what merit they would be worthy of inheriting the land, in order to prepare for them the power of this influence.
summary: The passage emphasizes that the patriarchs' actions were intended to benefit future generations of Israel, preparing a spiritual foundation for their redemption. It highlights Abraham's prayers and inquiries about the merits that would secure Israel's inheritance of the land, illustrating his commitment to ensuring that his descendants would have the necessary spiritual resources. This reflects a core Hasidic belief in the interconnectedness of past, present, and future, where the patriarchs actively shaped the spiritual legacy for their descendants. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of divine merit and the role of the patriarchs in facilitating the continuity of faith and tradition.

passage_content: ועד"זאפ"להכוונה גם במה שאמרמרע"הלהקב"ה למה הרעתה לעם הזה, שאינו כמתרעם ח"ו על דרכיוית', כי אם שאלה נכונה שאל באמרו למה הרעתה לעם הזה, ר"ל מהו הסיבה שגרם לזה שהרעתה לעם הזה ועל מה הגיע עליהם ככה, כי יש צורך בידיעה זו כדי לתקן החטא והפגם שבסיבתה בא עליהם הצרה הזאת, גם להמליץ זכות ולעורר רחמים עליהם, וכעיןשמצינובגמ' (יבמות ע"ח ע"ב) כתיב ויהי רעב בימי דוד ג' שנים שנה ראשונה אמר להם שמאעוע"זיש בכםוכו', בדקו ולא מצאו וכו' אמר אין הדבר תלוי אלא בי, מיד ויבקש דוד את פני ה', מאי היא אמר ר"ל ששאל באורים ותומיםוכו', ויאמר ה' אל שאול ואל בית הדמים וכו' עכ"דהגמ',ועד"זהי' שאלתמרע"הבאומרו למה הרעתה לעם הזה,ובעוה"רבדור הזה אין לנו מי שישאל ויחקור סיבת צרותינו לידע בשל מי הרעה הזאת ומה הגיע אלינו ככה, ותרופה אחת לנו שכולנו יחד נישא לבבינו אלאלבשמים, ונשוב אליו באמת ובלב שלם ונתקן אשר פגמנו עד שישוב וירחמנו.
translation: And similarly, the intention is also in what Moshe Rabbeinu said to the Holy One, Blessed be He, "Why have You afflicted this people?" This is not a complaint, Heaven forbid, about His ways, but rather a proper question he asked by saying, "Why have You afflicted this people?" In other words, what is the reason that caused You to afflict this people, and why has this come upon them? There is a need for this knowledge in order to rectify the sin and the flaw that caused this distress to come upon them, and also to advocate for them and awaken mercy upon them. And similarly, we find in the Gemara (Yevamot 78b) that it is written, "And there was a famine in the days of David for three years. In the first year, he said to them, 'Perhaps there is idolatry among you,' etc. They investigated and found nothing, etc. He said, 'The matter depends only on me.' Immediately, David sought the face of the Lord." What does this mean? It means that he asked through the Urim and Tumim, etc. And the Lord said to Shaul and to the house of blood, etc. Thus is the Gemara. And similarly, this is the question of Moshe Rabbeinu when he says, "Why have You afflicted this people?" And in our generation, woe to us, we have no one to ask and investigate the reason for our troubles to know who is responsible for this affliction and why this has come upon us. And there is one remedy for us: that we all together lift our hearts to Heaven, and return to Him truly and with a complete heart, and rectify that which we have blemished until He returns and has mercy upon us.
summary: The passage discusses the inquiry of Moshe Rabbeinu (Moses) to God regarding the suffering of the people, emphasizing the importance of understanding the reasons behind their afflictions in order to rectify their sins and invoke divine mercy. It draws a parallel to King David's search for the cause of a famine, highlighting the necessity of seeking answers to suffering. The text suggests that in the current generation, there is no one to question the reasons for their troubles, and the remedy lies in collective repentance and a sincere return to God to repair the damage caused by their transgressions.

passage_content: ולדרכינויתבאר הקישור למה הרעתה לעם הזה ולמה זה שלחתני,עפי"משפי' האר"יהק'עה"כלכה ואשלחך וגו' על כי בזה השליחות ששלח השי"תלמרע"ההי' בו טובה ורעה טובה לישראל ורעה למצרים, ומאתוית' לא תצא הרעה, להכי נגד הרעה שמגיע מהשליחות אמר לכה כלומר לך מדעתך, ונגד הטובה שמגיע ממנה אמר השי"ת ואשלחך אני משלח אותך עכת"דהק', וזה שטעןמרע"הקובל אני על ששלחתני,דהאממה שאמרת לי ואשלחך, נשמע שע"כ יצמח טובה לישראל מהשליחות, כי אם הקב"ה המשלח הרי מאתו לא תצא הרעה, ועדיין לא נתגלה בחי' הטוב שבשליחות, אדרבה ומאז באתי אל פרעה לדבר בשמך הרע לעם הזה והצל לא הצלת את עמך. ואין זה כבוד שמים שיתייחד השליחות בשמך על בחי' הרעה, ולכןמרע"הבגודל ענוותנותו תלההחסרוןבעצמו, כי הוא אשר מעל ח"ו בשליחות וע"ז הי' קובלמרע"ה, דהרי ראה כי הוכבד העבודה עלבנ"יוהוא מא' משתי הסיבות, או שחטא העם גרם לזאת ושאל למההרעותהלידע הסיבה ע"מ לתקנה, אושהחסרוןממנו על כי הוא הי' השליח לזה וכנ"ל, והשיב לו הקב"ה לסתור טענתו שאיןהחסרוןממנו ח"ו, אלא שכל זה הי' מן השמים, מפני שהי' צורך לאלו הדיבורים שיאמר משה רבינו למההרעותהוגו' כדי שיעורר על ידם רחמים על ישראל, ואחר שאמר למההרעותהא"ל הקב"ה עתה תראה וגו' כי כבר נשלם הרצון ונתעורר רחמים ע"י דיבורך.
translation: And in our way, it will be clarified the connection of why You have harmed this people and why You have sent me, according to the explanation of the holy Arizal, "And I will send you," etc. For in this mission that the Holy One, Blessed be He, sent to Moshe Rabbeinu, there was both good and bad: good for Israel and bad for Egypt. And from Him, evil will not come forth; therefore, against the evil that comes from the mission, He said, "Go," meaning go of your own accord. And against the good that comes from it, the Holy One, Blessed be He, said, "And I will send you," I am sending you, as it is written. And this is what Moshe Rabbeinu claimed: "I have a complaint about Your sending me," for the implication of what You said to me, "And I will send you," implies that therefore good will arise for Israel from the mission, for if the Holy One, Blessed be He, is the sender, then from Him evil will not come forth. Yet the good aspect of the mission has not yet been revealed; on the contrary, since I came to Pharaoh to speak in Your name, evil has befallen this people, and You have not saved Your people at all. And it is not fitting for the honor of Heaven that the mission should be associated with the aspect of evil. Therefore, Moshe Rabbeinu, in his great humility, attributed the shortcoming to himself, for he was the one who, Heaven forbid, failed in the mission, and this is what Moshe Rabbeinu was complaining about. For he saw that the work had become burdensome for the children of Israel, and this was for one of two reasons: either the sin of the people caused this, and he asked why You have harmed them to know the reason in order to rectify it, or the shortcoming was from him, for he was the messenger for this, as mentioned above. And the Holy One, Blessed be He, responded to him to refute his claim that the shortcoming was from him, Heaven forbid, but all of this was from Heaven, because there was a need for these words that Moshe Rabbeinu would say, "Why have You harmed," etc., in order to arouse mercy upon Israel. And after he said, "Why have You harmed," the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him, "Now you will see," etc., for the will has already been fulfilled, and mercy has been aroused through your words.
summary: The passage discusses the dual nature of Moses' mission, where his role as a messenger from God brings both good for Israel and suffering for Egypt. It emphasizes that any perceived negativity in the mission is not a reflection of Moses' shortcomings but rather a divine necessity to elicit compassion for the Israelites. Moses' humility leads him to question the suffering of his people, prompting God to clarify that the hardships serve a greater purpose in invoking mercy. Ultimately, the text highlights the interplay between divine will and human experience, illustrating how challenges can lead to spiritual elevation and redemption.

passage_content: ואפ"לשזהו הכוונה במאמר הכתוב וידבראלקיםאל משה זהמדה"ד, שדבר אתו משפט על שהקשה לדבר ולומר למההרעותה,דלמראיתעין הי' נחשב זאת לחטא, אבל אליבא דאמת הוכנו דיבורים אלו מן השמים וזה ירמוז ויאמר אליו אני ה'דמ"שמשה למההרעותהוגו' אני ה' אמרתי זאת, והשכינה מדברת מתוך גרונו של משה, והקב"ה סיבב כן שיהיו נאמרים דיבורים הללו מפי משה נביאו, כי הי' צורך לדיבורים הללו לעורר רחמים על ישראל, וכעיןשמצינובגמ' (יבמות קכ"א ע"ב) בבתו של ר'נחוניאחופרשיחיןשנפלה לבור וכו' והודיעולר"חב"ד וכו' א"ל לא נביא אנכי וכו' אלא דבר שהצדיק מתעסק בו יכשל בו זרעו,ואר"אאעפ"כ מת בנו בצמא וכו' ע"כ,ולכאו' מדוע לא הועיל זכותו גם לבנו שינצל בטענה זו דבר שהצדיק מתעסק בו יכשל בו זרעו, ובשיטה מקובצת (מס'ב"ק) כתב ולרבינונל"פאמרתי כלומר השמעתי דבר זה לפני הקב"ה וכו' והסכים הקב"ה לדברי, שכן דרכושל הקב"ה שמסכים לסברת הצדיקים שבדור, וכשמת בנו בצמא כבר מת ר'חנינאעכ"ד, וכן פי' בעץ יוסף על עין יעקב עיי"ש, הרי דאף אםהסבראאמיתית, מ"מ אם הקטרוג גדול יש צורך שצדיקגדול יאמר זה והקב"ה מסכים לסברת הצדיקים, וכן הי' כאן צורך גדול לאלו הדיבורים שיאמר משה רבינו למההרעותהלעם הזה כדי לעורר רחמים למעלה,ובעוה"רמה נענה אנן בדורותינו אלה בגודל השפלות אין מי יטעון בעדינו לעורר רחמי שמיא עלינו ורקהבוכ"עבעצמו למענוית' יעשה ולמען שם קדשו שלא יחולל בגוים.
translation: And even though this is the intention of the statement written, "And God spoke to Moses," this is the measure of judgment, that He spoke with him a judgment for having difficulty in speaking and saying, "Why have You done evil?" For in the eyes of the beholder, this would be considered a sin. But according to the truth, these words were prepared from Heaven, and this will hint and say to him, "I am the Lord," as if to say, "Moses, why have You done evil?" I, the Lord, said this, and the Shechinah speaks from the throat of Moses. And the Holy One, blessed be He, arranged it so that these words would be said from the mouth of Moses, His prophet, because there was a need for these words to awaken mercy upon Israel. And similar to what we find in the Gemara (Yevamot 121b) regarding the daughter of Rabbi Nechunya the excavator who fell into a pit, etc., and it was made known to Rabbi Chiya bar Abba, etc., he said to him, "I am not a prophet," etc., "but a matter that the righteous is engaged in, his offspring will fail in it." And Rabbi Elazar said, "Even so, his son died of thirst," etc. Therefore, it seems, why did his merit not also help his son to be saved with this claim, "A matter that the righteous is engaged in, his offspring will fail in it?" And in the Shita Mekubetzes (Baba Kamma), it is written, "And according to Rabbi Natan, I said," meaning, "I presented this matter before the Holy One, blessed be He," etc., and the Holy One, blessed be He, agreed with my words, for it is the way of the Holy One, blessed be He, to agree with the reasoning of the righteous of the generation. And when his son died of thirst, Rabbi Chaninah had already died, and thus it is explained in the Etz Yosef on Ein Yaakov, see there. Thus, even if the reasoning is true, nevertheless, if the accusation is great, there is a need for a great righteous person to say this, and the Holy One, blessed be He, agrees with the reasoning of the righteous. And here there was a great need for these words that Moses our teacher would say, "Why have You done evil to this people?" in order to awaken mercy above. And in our lowly generation, we are answered in our days with the great degradation; there is no one to argue on our behalf to awaken Heavenly mercy upon us, and the Holy One, blessed be He, Himself for His own sake will act and for the sake of His holy name, that it should not be profaned among the nations.
summary: The passage discusses the divine communication between God and Moses, emphasizing that Moses' questioning of God's actions was necessary to evoke mercy for the Israelites. It highlights the concept that even a righteous person's merit may not suffice in the face of severe accusations, necessitating a greater intercession. The text reflects on the importance of the righteous speaking on behalf of their people to elicit divine compassion, especially in times of great distress. Ultimately, it underscores the belief that God aligns with the reasoning of the righteous to bring about mercy and protection for the community.

passage_content: ואפ"לעודבמאמה"כויאמר אליו אני ה',דמ"שמשה למההרעותהוגו' זה אומר גם הקב"ה כביכול לטעון נגד מדת הדין, כי מלך במשפט יעמיד ארץומלכותאדרקיעכעיןמלכותאדארעא, וכשיש ח"ו התעוררות דין למעלה אז יגער ה' בך השטן והקב"ה טוען נגדו, אלא שיש צורךבאתערותאדלתתא, לזה צורך בדיבורים של צדיק אמת לעורר רחמים למעלה. והנה אז הי'מרע"המצער עצמו בצרתן של ישראל וטען בשבילם למההרעותהלעם הזהועי"כהי' מעורר רחמים עליהם, אמנם מה יעשו ישראל באותן הדורות שלא יהי' משה רבינו בעולם ומי יטעון בשבילם, כי מאז ראהמרע"השהגאולה אינו נצחי,ומה"טהי' מסרב בשליחותו כי רצונו הי' להמתין עד שיהי' גאולה נצחי, ולזה נחמו הקב"ה ויאמר אליו אני ד', דמה שאמרת למההרעותהוגו' אני ה' אמרתי זאת, ודיבורו יתברך נצחי לעולם וקיים לדורי דורות, ואנחנו צריכים לעורר רחמים על זה שהקדוש ברוך הוא יטעון בשבילנו למההרעותהלעם הזה וגו' שכבר סבלנו די והותר מחבלי משיח, ומעתה נזכה לעבוד השי"ת בהרחבה ובלי צרהועקתאונזכה במהרה לישועת השי"ת בהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו במהרה בימינו אמן.
translation: And even though it is said in the name of the Holy One, blessed be He, "I am the Lord," as it is stated, "Why have You afflicted this people?" This is also what the Holy One, blessed be He, so to speak, claims against the attribute of judgment, for a king establishes the land through justice, and the kingdom of heaven is like the kingdom of the earth. And when, Heaven forbid, there is an awakening of judgment above, then the Lord will rebuke the Satan, and the Holy One, blessed be He, will argue against him. However, there is a need for an awakening from below; for this, there is a need for the words of a true tzaddik to arouse mercy above. And behold, then Moses, our teacher, would humble himself in the suffering of Israel and argue for them, "Why have You afflicted this people?" and thus he would arouse mercy upon them. However, what will the Jews do in those generations when Moses our teacher will not be in the world, and who will argue for them? For since then, Moses our teacher saw that the redemption is not eternal, and he was reluctant in his mission because his desire was to wait until there would be an eternal redemption. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, comforted him and said to him, "I am the Lord," meaning that what you said, "Why have You afflicted this people?" I, the Lord, have said this. And His blessed word is eternal forever and established for generations upon generations. And we need to arouse mercy for the fact that the Holy One, blessed be He, will argue for us, "Why have You afflicted this people?" for we have already suffered enough from the birth pangs of the Messiah. From now on, may we merit to serve the Holy One, blessed be He, with abundance and without trouble, and may we merit speedily to the salvation of the Holy One, blessed be He, with the revelation of the glory of heaven upon us speedily in our days, Amen.
summary: The passage discusses the tension between divine justice and mercy, emphasizing that even God, in a sense, argues against the attribute of judgment on behalf of Israel. It highlights the role of righteous leaders, like Moses, who plead for the people during times of suffering, raising the question of who will advocate for Israel in future generations. The text reassures that God's promises are eternal and encourages the faithful to seek divine mercy, hoping for a future redemption and the revelation of God's glory. Ultimately, it expresses a longing for relief from suffering and a return to a state of spiritual abundance.

passage_content: וידבראלקיםאל משה ויאמר אליו אני ה',במד"ר(פ' ו' סי' א')הה"ד(קהלת ב') ופניתי אני לראות חכמה והוללות וסכלות כי מה האדם שיבוא אחרי המלך את אשר כבר עשהווכו', לפי שכבר הודיע הקב"ה שלא יניח אותם פרעה לילך שנא' וכו' ואני אחזק את לבו. ומשה לא שמר את הדבר הזה אלא בא להתחכם על גזירתו של הקב"ה והתחיל אומר ה' למההרעותהלעם הזה. וע"ז נאמר שאותה חכמה ודעת של משה של הוללות וסכלות הי' כי מה האדם שיבוא אחרי המלךוכו', ועל דבר זה בקשהמדה"דלפגוע במשההה"דוידבראלקיםאל משה, ולפי שנסתכל הקב"ה שבשביל צער ישראל דיבר כן חזר ונהג עמובמדה"רויאמר אליו אני ה' עכ"ד המדרש וכולו מוקשהדאיךיתכן לומר שמשה לא שמר את הדבר הזהדנראהכאילו שכח או עבר ח"ו על דברי השי"ת, ולא יתכן לחשוב כן עלמרע"המובחר היצורים אבי כל הנביאים. גם צ"ב מה שאמר שאותה חכמה ודעת של משה של הוללות וסכלות הי',דממנ"פאם הי' חכמה ודעת אין כאן הוללות וסכלות, ואם הוללות וסכלות אין כאן חכמה ודעת, והם ב' הפכים רחוקים מן הקצה אל הקצה.
translation: And God spoke to Moses and said to him, "I am the Lord," as it is written in the Midrash (Parashat Va'era, Section 1), "And I turned to see wisdom and folly and foolishness, for what is man that he should come after the king, that which has already been done." This is because the Holy One, blessed be He, had already informed that Pharaoh would not let them go, as it is written, "And I will harden his heart." And Moses did not keep this matter but came to outsmart the decree of the Holy One, blessed be He, and began to say, "O Lord, why have You done evil to this people?" And concerning this, it is said that that wisdom and knowledge of Moses was of folly and foolishness, for what is man that he should come after the king, etc. And for this matter, the Midrash sought to strike at Moses, as it is written, "And God spoke to Moses." And since the Holy One, blessed be He, saw that it was because of the suffering of Israel that he spoke this way, He returned and dealt with him in the Midrash and said to him, "I am the Lord." Thus concludes the Midrash. And all of this is difficult, for how can it be said that Moses did not keep this matter, which seems as if he forgot or transgressed, Heaven forbid, the words of the Holy One, blessed be He? It is not fitting to think this of Moses, the chosen of all creatures, the father of all prophets. It is also puzzling what it means that that wisdom and knowledge of Moses was of folly and foolishness, for if it was wisdom and knowledge, there is no folly and foolishness here, and if there is folly and foolishness, there is no wisdom and knowledge here, and they are two opposites, far from one another.
summary: The passage discusses a dialogue between God and Moses, highlighting the tension between divine decree and human understanding. It reflects on Moses' questioning of God's plan regarding the suffering of the Israelites, suggesting that his wisdom may have led him to challenge God's intentions. The text emphasizes the complexity of divine wisdom, where what appears as folly or ignorance from a human perspective may actually be a profound understanding of God's will. Ultimately, it illustrates the struggle between faith in divine providence and the human desire for clarity in the face of suffering.

passage_content: ב)במד"ר(פ' ו' סי' ב')הה"ד(קהלת ז') כי העושק יהולל חכם ויאבד את לב מתנה, כי העושק יהולל חכם זה משה, עשק שעשקו אותו דתן ואבירם יהולל חכםעירבבואותו, ויאבד את לב מתנה וכי תעלה על דעתך שהי' משה מתאבד, אלא הם שהקניטוהו ואמרו לו ירא ה' עליכם וישפוט, ואף הוא הקפיד ואמר ומאז באתי לדבר אל פרעהוכו', באותה שעה בקשהמדה"דלפגוע בו שנא' וידבראלקיםאל משה, א"ל הקב"ה וכי בשר ודם אניבמדותישאיני מרחםהה"דויאמר אליו אני ה',וצ"בשהקשה בעל המדרש וכי תעלה על דעתך שהי' משה מתאבד, ותירץ שהם הקניטו אותו ועל ידם הי' מתאבד כמ"ש ויאבד את לב מתנה, ולכאורה עדייןהקושיאבמקומה עומדת וכי תעלה על דעתך שהי' משה מתאבד, דגם אם הקניטוהו דתן ואבירם לא יתכן לומר שהי' משה מתאבד ח"ו. גם צ"ב הלשון ויאבד את לב מתנה שאין לו ביאור עפ"י פשוטו, ובידי משה פי' שחסר כאן בדברי המדרש וצריך להגיה מתונה כתיב, וכ"ההגירסאבמדרש קהלת על פסוק הזה, ויאבד את לב מתנה מתונה כתיב, אילו הי' משה מתון הי' ניצול אלא שהקניטוהו והקפידו אותו ואמר ומאז באתי לדבר אל פרעה וגו' עכ"ל. אמנם קשה לומר שבכל דפוסי המדרש חסרגירסאזו, גם בלשון הכתוב מתנה כתיב ולא מתונהוצ"ב.
translation: In the Midrash (Parashat Va'era, Section 2), it is stated: "For oppression will make a wise man mad and destroy the heart of a gift" (Ecclesiastes 7). The oppression that will make a wise man mad refers to Moses, who was oppressed by Datan and Aviram, which made him mad. And "destroy the heart of a gift" – do you think that Moses would have committed suicide? Rather, they provoked him and said to him, "Fear the Lord upon you and He will judge," and he too was upset and said, "And since I came to speak to Pharaoh..." At that moment, the attribute of judgment sought to strike him, as it is written, "And God spoke to Moses." The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, "Am I flesh and blood that I should have mercy?" It is written, "And He said to him, 'I am the Lord.'" The question posed by the author of the Midrash is, "Do you think that Moses would have committed suicide?" And it is answered that they provoked him, and through them he would have committed suicide, as it is written, "and destroy the heart of a gift." However, the question still stands: do you think that Moses would have committed suicide? Even if Datan and Aviram provoked him, it cannot be said that Moses would have committed suicide, Heaven forbid. Also, the wording "and destroy the heart of a gift" is difficult, as it does not have a clear explanation according to its simple meaning. In the hands of Moses, it is explained that something is missing here in the words of the Midrash and it should be corrected to "a calm heart is written." And so is the version in the Midrash Kohelet on this verse, "and destroy the heart of a gift" is written as "a calm heart." If Moses had been calm, he would have been saved, but they provoked him and upset him, and he said, "And since I came to speak to Pharaoh..." Thus far the text. However, it is difficult to say that in all versions of the Midrash this version is lacking, and also in the wording of the verse it is written "gift" and not "calm."
summary: The passage discusses the challenges faced by Moses, particularly the provocations from Datan and Aviram, which led to a moment of anger that could have caused him to lose his composure. It emphasizes the idea that even a great leader like Moses can be affected by external pressures, illustrating the human vulnerability inherent in spiritual leadership. The text also raises questions about the interpretation of "losing a gift" in the context of Moses' response, suggesting that a more measured approach could have prevented his distress. Ultimately, it highlights the tension between divine expectations and human emotions in the pursuit of righteousness.

passage_content: ונל"פבהקדם מ"ד בגמ' (תענית כ"ג ע"א) ת"ר פעם אחת יצא רוב אדר ולא ירדו גשמים שלחו לחוני המעגל התפלל ולא ירדו גשמים,עגעוגה ועמד בתוכה וכו' אמר לפניו רבש"ע נשבע אני בשמך הגדול שאיני זז מכאן עד שתרחם על בניך, התחילו גשמיםמנטפיןוכו' אמר לא כך שאלתי אלא גשמי בורותשיחיןומערות, ירדו בזעף וכו' אמר לפניו לא כך שאלתי אלא גשמי רצון ברכה ונדבהוכו', שלח לו שמעון בן שטח אלמלא חוני אתה גוזרני עליך נידויוכו', אבל מה אעשה לך שאתה מתחטא לפני המקום ועושה לך רצונך כבן שמתחטא על אביו ועושה לו רצונו,פרש"ימתחטא לשון חטא כלומר הולך וחוטא, עוד שם בגמ' (דף כ"ה ע"א) לוי גזרתעניתאולא אתאמיטראאמר לפניו רבש"ע עלית וישבת במרום ואין אתה מרחם על בניך אתאמיטראואיטלע,א"ראלעזר לעולם אל יטיח אדם דברים כלפי מעלה שהרי אדם גדול הטיח דברים כלפי מעלהואיטלעומנו לוי עכ"דהגמ', הרי מצינו בצדיקים וקדושים שהטיחו דברים כלפי מעלה בשביל טובת ישראל, אף שידעו שיחשב להם לחטא ופגם ויענשו על זה, מ"ממסרונפשייהולטובת ישראל ונתקבלה תפילתם להמשיך ישועה לישראל, וכמו"כמרע"השאמר למההרעותהבשביל צערן של ישראל. אף שידע בנפשי' כייענשעלי' מ"מ מסר נפשו לטובת ישראל.
translation: And it is explained in advance, as stated in the Gemara (Taanit 23a): Our Rabbis taught: Once, most of Adar had passed and no rain fell. They sent for Choni the Circle Maker, and he prayed, but no rain fell. He drew a circle and stood inside it, etc. He said before Him, Master of the Universe, I swear by Your great Name that I will not move from here until You have mercy on Your children. Then the rains began to drip, etc. He said, "Not like this did I ask, but rather for the rains of pits, ditches, and cisterns." They fell in a downpour, etc. He said before Him, "Not like this did I ask, but rather for the rains of goodwill, blessing, and generosity," etc. Shimon ben Shetach sent to him, "If not for you, Choni, I would decree upon you a ban," etc. But what can I do for you, since you are pleading before the Holy One, Blessed be He, and He fulfills your will like a son who pleads with his father and has his will fulfilled. The explanation is that "pleading" implies a language of sin, meaning he goes and sins. Furthermore, it is stated in the Gemara (25a) that Levi decreed a fast and did not rain. He said before Him, Master of the Universe, You have ascended and sat on high, and You do not have mercy on Your children. You have ascended and You have delayed. Rabbi Elazar said: A person should never throw words upward, for a great man threw words upward and was delayed. Thus, we find among the righteous and holy ones who threw words upward for the good of Israel, even though they knew it would be considered a sin and a blemish, and they would be punished for it. Nevertheless, they risked their lives for the good of Israel, and their prayers were accepted to bring salvation to Israel. Likewise, Moshe Rabbeinu said, "Why have You harmed Your people?" Even though he knew in his soul that he would be punished for it, he nevertheless risked his life for the good of Israel.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of intercessory prayer and the relationship between the righteous and God, highlighting the example of Choni HaMa'agal, who boldly demanded rain for the people despite the risk of being punished for his audacity. It emphasizes that even great figures like Moses and others have confronted God on behalf of Israel, demonstrating a willingness to bear personal consequences for the sake of the community's welfare. This reflects a deep theological insight into the nature of divine mercy and the power of sincere prayer, where the righteous can advocate for the needs of their people, even at the cost of their own standing. Ultimately, it illustrates the profound connection between human action and divine response in the context of communal suffering and redemption.

passage_content: ונקדיםדברי ק"ז הייטב לב זי"ע (פ' נח) לבאר אמרם ז"ל (זבחים קט"ז ע"א) נח איש צדיק תמים וגו' צדיק במעשיו תמים בדרכיו,פרש"יז"ל תמים עניו וסבלן,עפי"משפי'הגה"קמבארדיטשובזצ"להכ' שיש יתרון לחכמה מן הסכלות כיתרון האור מן החושך, כי אור משמעותי'יממאומשמעותי'אורתאכדאי'בפ"קדפסחים,משא"כחושך אין משמעותי' רק לילהוכו', זה עצמו ההבדל שבין חכמה לסכלות, כי החכם אם שהוא חכם לפעמים ישנה טעמו וריחו לפי הצורך ויעשה עצמו כסיל, ע"ד שעשה דוד בשנותו את טעמו לפני אבימלך,משא"כהכסיל אין בידו לעשות עצמו חכם בשום פעם ואופן עכ"ד, והוא נאותלענינינוכי זה גדר החכם להיות עניו ושפל, וכל גאה שוטה, אך לפעמים צריך להתלבש בלבוש הגאות לצורך הזמן לקנא קנאת ה' צבאות להשיב רבים מעון וכו' וגםלאפושיברחמים אבני דורו. וזהו גדר החכמה להשתמש בתרי אנפין גבר ענותן ושפל ולפעמים גאה וגאוןהכללפי שעה שמע לו וזהו ענין התחכמות וכו' ומי שמתנהג בדרך הנ"ל חכם מתקרי,משא"כמי שאינו בידו רק ע"ד אחד ומהנמנע אצלו להתלבש בלבוש הגאות ולחלף שמלותיו יקרא תם שאינו יודע לרמות, ולכן יקרא נח בשם תמים כי לא הי' לו ענין התחכמות לעשות פעם כך ופעם כך וכו'אתד"קיעיי"ש.
translation: And we will precede the words of K"Z, may his merit protect us (Parshat Noach), to explain their statement, of blessed memory (Zevachim 116a), "Noach was a righteous man, perfect in his generations," righteous in his deeds, perfect in his ways. The explanation of blessed memory is that "perfect" refers to one who is humble and patient. According to the words of the holy Rabbi from Berdichev, may his merit protect us, there is an advantage to wisdom over foolishness, like the advantage of light over darkness, for light has significance both by day and by night, as stated in the Passover Haggadah, whereas darkness has no significance except for night and so forth. This itself is the difference between wisdom and foolishness, for the wise man, even though he is wise, sometimes changes his taste and appearance according to the need and makes himself like a fool, as David did when he changed his appearance before Avimelech. However, the fool cannot make himself wise at any time or in any way. Thus, he is suitable for our discussion, for this is the definition of the wise man: to be humble and lowly, and every arrogant person is a fool. Yet sometimes it is necessary to don the garment of arrogance for the sake of the time, to be zealous for the zeal of the Lord of Hosts to bring back many from sin, and also to act with mercy towards the stones of his generation. And this is the definition of wisdom: to use two aspects, sometimes being humble and lowly, and sometimes being arrogant and proud, all according to the moment. This is the matter of cleverness, etc. And one who conducts himself in this manner is called wise, whereas one who is only capable of one way and cannot don the garment of arrogance and change his attire will be called "perfect," for he does not know how to deceive. Therefore, he is called Noach, which means "perfect," because he had no need for cleverness to act one way at one time and another way at another time, etc.
summary: The passage discusses the nature of wisdom and foolishness, emphasizing that true wisdom involves humility and the ability to adapt one's behavior according to circumstances, as exemplified by figures like David. It contrasts the wise, who can sometimes appear foolish for a greater purpose, with the fool, who lacks the capacity to change. The text highlights the importance of being "tameem" (innocent or simple) like Noah, who did not engage in cunning or manipulation, thus embodying a pure and straightforward faith. Ultimately, it illustrates that true wisdom is characterized by a balance of humility and the occasional necessity of assertiveness for the sake of divine service.

passage_content: והנהמרע"ההי' עניו מכל האדם אשר על פני האדמה כמו שהעידה עליוהתוה"ק, וכאן לבש לבוש הגאות להתפלל על ישראל ולדבר כלפי מעלה דברים שאינם מן המוסר לומר להקב"ה למההרעותה, וזה הי' לו מגודל מעלתחכמתושהי' בידו לשנות טעמו ולעשות דבר שנראה כהוללות וסכלות בשביל טובת ישראל, ובזה יובן דברי המדרש שאותה חכמה של משה של הוללות וסכלותהיתה, דמה שמשה לא שמר את הדבר ואמר למההרעותההי' בכוונה גדולה מאתו בשביל טובת ישראל, ואף שהי' עניו מכל אדם מ"מ לצורך השעה לבש לבוש הגאות ע"י גודלחכמתוועשה דבר שנראה כהוללות וסכלות בשביל טובת ישראל. והנה מדריגה זו שיוכל האדם להשתמש בתרי אנפין לשני הפכים זהו מתנה מהקב"ה, כי האדם מצד יגיעת עבודתו א"א להגיע לידי מדה זו שהיא למעלה מן הטבע, ורק הקב"ה שהוא כל יכול יש לו מדה זו שיכול לעשות שני הפכים בנושא אחד, אלא שהואיתב"שנותן מתנה זו לצדיקים אמיתיים העובדים אותו באמת שגם הם יוכלו להשתמשבמדהזו לעת הצורך.
translation: And behold, Moshe Rabbeinu was the most humble of all men who were on the face of the earth, as the Holy Torah testified about him. Yet here he donned the garment of pride to pray for Israel and to speak to the Holy One, Blessed be He, words that are not fitting to say, asking Him why He had done evil. This was due to the greatness of the wisdom that was in his hand, to change his nature and to do something that appeared to be arrogance and folly for the sake of the good of Israel. And in this, the words of the Midrash are understood, that this wisdom of Moshe was of arrogance and folly, for the fact that Moshe did not guard the matter and said, "Why have You done evil?" was with great intention on his part for the good of Israel. And even though he was the most humble of all men, nevertheless, for the sake of the moment, he donned the garment of pride through the greatness of his wisdom and did something that appeared to be arrogance and folly for the good of Israel. And behold, this level, where a person can use two faces for two opposites, is a gift from the Holy One, Blessed be He, for a person, through the toil of his service, cannot reach this measure, which is above nature. Only the Holy One, Blessed be He, who is all-powerful, has this measure, to do two opposites in one matter. However, He is good and gives this gift to true righteous ones who serve Him sincerely, so that they too can use this measure when necessary.
summary: The passage highlights the humility of Moses, who, despite being the most humble man, donned the "garment of pride" to advocate for Israel, demonstrating a profound wisdom that allowed him to act in ways that seemed foolish for the sake of the people's welfare. This ability to navigate opposites is presented as a divine gift from God, reserved for true righteous individuals who, through their genuine service, can access this extraordinary capacity. Ultimately, it emphasizes the idea that true spiritual elevation enables one to transcend natural limitations for the greater good.

passage_content: ובזהיתבאר דברי המדרש כי העושק יהולל חכם ויאבד את לב מתנה, ע"דשאמה"כארמי אובד אבי ודרשו רז"ל בקש לבן לעקור אתהכל, ואף שלא עלה בידו נחשב לו המחשבה כמעשה, וכמו"כ מה שדרשו רז"ל על עושק של דתן ואבירם ויאבד את לב מתנה, לפי שרצו לאבד נחשב להם כעשי',ומ"שאת לב מתנה פי' מתנה זו שנתן הקב"הלמרע"השיהי' בידו להשתמש בשני הפכים, ואף להפלגתענותנותויוכל להשתמש בלבוש הגאות ולהפציר בתפלתו על ישראל, מתנה זו רצו דתן ואבירם לאבדממרע"הע"י שהקניטוהו,וז"פויאבד את לב מתנה שרצו לאבדמלבושל משה המתנה שניתן לו מהקב"ה, ולזה הקשה המדרש וכי תעלה על דעתך שהי' משה מתאבד, ותירץ אלא שהקניטוהו ואמרו לו ירא ה' עליכם וישפוט ורצו לאבדמלבושל משה המתנה שקיבל מהקב"ה, אבל לא עלתה בידם הרצון ההוא,ומרע"הנשאר בגדולתו וקדושתו ואף הוא הקפיד וכו' ולבש לבוש הגאות בשביל טובתן של ישראל ונתקבלה תפלתו אצל הקב"ה, אולם אעפ"כ אמר הכתוב ויאבד עד"ש בלבן ארמי אובד אבי לצד הרצון שלו.
translation: And in this, the words of the Midrash are clarified, for the oppressor will praise the wise and will cause the heart of the gift to be lost, as it is said, "An Aramean was about to destroy my father," and our Sages interpreted that the son sought to uproot everything. And although he did not succeed, the thought is considered as an action. Likewise, what our Sages interpreted regarding the oppression of Datan and Aviram, and they caused the heart of the gift to be lost, for they wished to destroy it is considered as if they acted. And what is meant by "the heart of the gift" refers to the gift that the Holy One, blessed be He, gave to Moses, that he should have the ability to use two opposites, and even to express the greatness of humility, and he could don the garment of pride and plead in his prayer for Israel. This gift Datan and Aviram wished to destroy from Moses by provoking him. And this is the meaning of "and he lost the heart of the gift," which they wished to take away from the garment of Moses, the gift that was given to him by the Holy One, blessed be He. And therefore, the Midrash asks, "Could it enter your mind that Moses would be destroyed?" And it answers, "Rather, they provoked him and said to him, 'Fear the Lord upon you and He will judge,' and they wished to destroy the garment of Moses, the gift he received from the Holy One, blessed be He, but that desire did not succeed. And Moses remained in his greatness and holiness, and he too was particular, etc., and he wore the garment of pride for the sake of the goodness of Israel, and his prayer was accepted by the Holy One, blessed be He. However, nevertheless, the scripture states, 'And he lost' in connection with 'An Aramean was about to destroy my father' in accordance with his desire.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of intention versus action in the context of the biblical figures Datan and Aviram, who sought to undermine Moses by provoking him. It emphasizes that their desire to corrupt Moses's divine gift—his ability to embody both humility and authority—was considered as significant as an actual deed. Despite their attempts, Moses remained steadfast in his greatness and holiness, using his gifts for the benefit of Israel, and his prayers were accepted by God. Ultimately, the text illustrates the profound idea that one's intentions can carry weight in the spiritual realm, even if they do not manifest in action.

passage_content: עודנל"פאומרו ויאבד את לב מתנה,עפי"משפירשתימ"שישמח משה במתנת חלקו כי עבד נאמן קראת לו,דלכאו' צ"במ"שבמתנת חלקושהי"לבמתנה מה שנקרא עבד נאמן, והלאבודאייאות לו שם זה ע"ש עבודתו שהי' עבד נאמן להקב"ה ומסר נפשו בכל רגע על קדושת שמוית', ופירשתיעפי"מדאיתאבגמ' (ברכות ל"ד ע"ב) מעשה בר'חנינאבןדוסאשהלך ללמוד תורה אצלריב"זוחלה בנו שלריב"זא"לחנינאבני בקש עליו רחמים ויחי', הניח ראשו בין ברכיו ובקש עליו רחמים וחי',א"ריוחנן בן זכאי אלמלי הטיח בן זכאי את ראשו בין ברכיו כל היום כולו לא היו משגיחים עליו, אמרה לו אשתו וכיחנינאגדול ממך. אמר לה לאו אלא הוא דומה כעבד לפני המלך ואני דומה כשר לפני המלך,פרש"יכעבד בן בית נכנס ויוצא שלא ברשות, כשר לפני המלך שאינו רגיל לפניו ע"כ, מבואר שאע"פ שמעלת השר ודאי גדול יותר ממעלת העבד, מ"מלעניןליכנסלפני המלך גם בלי רשות גדלה מעלת העבד יותר שהוא יוצא ונכנס תמיד, והנהמרע"הלגודל מעלתו הי'בבחי' שר לפני המלך מלכי המלכים הקב"ה, אבל לטובת ישראל הי' צריך למעלת העבד להיות עייל בלא בר, ולפעול בתפלתו רחמים על ישראל, ונתן לו הקב"ה מעלה זו בתורת מתנה,וז"פישמח משה במתנת חלקו כי עבד נאמן קראת לו: אף שכליל תפארת בראשו נתת לו והי'בבחי' שר לפני המלך, מ"מ ניתן לו במתנה גם בחי' עבד להיות יוצא ונכנס תמיד להתפלל על ישראל, וזאת המעלה רצו דתן ואבירם לאבד ממנו ע"י שהקניטוהו ואמרו ומאז באתי וגו'וז"פכי העושק יהולל חכם ויאבד את לב מתנה שרצו לאבדמלבושל משה אותה המתנה שנתן לו הקב"ה להיות יוצא ונכנס ומתפלל על ישראל תמיד, אלא שלא עלתה בידם, מ"מ ע"ש הרצון אמר הכתוב ויאבד לב מתנה וכנ"ל.
translation: Still, it is said that he lost the heart of the gift, as it is explained that Moses rejoiced in the gift of his portion because he was called a faithful servant. For it is written, "A faithful servant" refers to the gift, and indeed, this title was given to him because of his service, as he was a faithful servant to the Holy One, blessed be He, and he gave his soul at every moment for the sanctity of His name. And it is explained that as it is written in the Gemara (Berakhot 34b), there was a story about Rabbi Chanina ben Dosa who went to learn Torah from Rabbi Yochanan ben Zakkai, and when Rabbi Yochanan's son fell ill, Rabbi Chanina prayed for him and he lived. Rabbi Yochanan ben Zakkai said that had he not placed his head between his knees all day long, they would not have paid attention to him. His wife said to him, "Is Chanina greater than you?" He replied, "No, but he is like a servant before the king, and I am like a minister before the king." It is explained that a servant of the household enters and exits without permission, while a minister before the king is not accustomed to being before him. Thus, it is clear that although the status of the minister is certainly greater than that of the servant, in terms of entering before the king even without permission, the status of the servant is greater because he is always entering and exiting. And behold, the greatness of his status was as a minister before the King of Kings, the Holy One, blessed be He, but for the benefit of Israel, he needed the status of a servant to enter without permission and to act in his prayers with mercy for Israel. And the Holy One, blessed be He, granted him this status as a gift, and thus it is said, "Moses rejoiced in the gift of his portion because he was called a faithful servant." Even though he was given the glory on his head and was in the status of a minister before the king, nonetheless, he was also given as a gift the status of a servant to always enter and exit to pray for Israel. And this status was what Datan and Aviram wanted to take away from him by provoking him and saying, "And since I came..." And thus it is said, "For the oppressor will praise the wise and will lose the heart of the gift," as they wanted to take away from Moses that gift which the Holy One, blessed be He, had given him to always enter and exit and pray for Israel. However, they did not succeed. Nevertheless, regarding their desire, the verse states, "And he lost the heart of the gift," as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the unique spiritual status of Moses, referred to as an "eved ne'eman" (faithful servant) of God, highlighting his dedication and self-sacrifice for the sanctity of God's name. It contrasts the roles of a servant and a minister before the king, emphasizing that while the minister holds a higher status, the servant's constant access to the king signifies a deeper connection. This access allows Moses to pray for the Jewish people, a gift from God that is described as a "matnat chelek" (gift of a portion). The text warns against the attempts of Datan and Aviram to undermine this gift, illustrating the importance of Moses' role in interceding for Israel.

translation: And God spoke to Moses and said to him, "I am the Lord," as it is opened in the Midrash, and God spoke and concludes, "I am the Lord," which is a name of mercy.
summary: In this passage, God speaks to Moses, identifying Himself as "I am the Lord," which signifies His essence as a source of mercy. The repetition of this phrase emphasizes the intimate relationship between God and His people, highlighting His compassionate nature. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of divine presence and the importance of recognizing God's mercy in the world. Ultimately, it underscores the theological insight that God's identity is deeply intertwined with His attributes of love and compassion towards humanity.

passage_content: ב)(פרשה ו' סי' א')הה"דופניתי אני וגו' כי מה האדם שיבא אחרי המלך את אשר כבר עשוהו (קהלת ב'), הפסוק הזה נאמר על שלמה ועל משה וכו' כיצד נאמר על משה, לפי שכבר הודיע הקב"ה למשה שלא יניח אותם פרעה לילך, שנא' ואני ידעתי כי לאיתןאתכם מלך מצרים להלוך ואני אחזק את לבו, ומשה לא שמר את הדבר הזה אלא בא להתחכם על גזירתו של הקב"ה והתחיל אומר ה' למההרעותהלעם הזה וכו' עכ"ד המדרשוצ"בהכוונהבמ"שאת אשר כבר עשוהו.
translation: In (Parashat Va'era, Section 1) it is stated: "I am the one who speaks," etc., for what is man that he should come after the king to that which has already been done (Ecclesiastes 2:), this verse is said about Solomon and about Moses, etc. How is it said about Moses? This is because the Holy One, Blessed be He, had already informed Moses that Pharaoh would not let them go, as it is said: "And I know that the king of Egypt will not let you go" (Exodus 3:19), "and I will harden his heart." And Moses did not heed this matter but came to outsmart the decree of the Holy One, Blessed be He, and began to say: "O Lord, why have You done evil to this people?" etc. Thus concludes the Midrash, with reference to "that which has already been done."
summary: The passage discusses the tension between divine foreknowledge and human action, using the example of Moses questioning God's decree regarding Pharaoh's refusal to let the Israelites go. It highlights the concept that despite God's prior knowledge of events, human beings, like Moses, may still attempt to challenge or understand divine will. This reflects a deeper Hasidic insight into the relationship between faith, free will, and the complexities of divine providence. Ultimately, it emphasizes the importance of aligning one's actions with divine intention, even in the face of apparent obstacles.

passage_content: ג)שםבמד"ר(פ' ו' סי' ב') א"ל הקב"ה חייך יש לך לידע שנאמר טוב אחרית דבר מראשיתו, טובה אחריתן של ישראל מראשית שנתתי להם במצריםוכו',וצ"ב.
translation: 3) (In the Midrash Rabbah, Parashat Vayikra, Section 6) The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him: "Rejoice, you should know that it is said, 'The end of a matter is better than its beginning.' The good end of Israel is better than the beginning that I gave them in Egypt, etc." And the question remains.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the Divine assurance emphasizes that the ultimate good for the Jewish people is predetermined from the very beginning of their journey, specifically from their time in Egypt. The phrase "טוב אחרית דבר מראשיתו" highlights the belief that the end result is inherently positive, reflecting a profound theological insight into the nature of divine providence and the unfolding of history. This underscores the idea that despite present challenges, there is a divine plan that ensures a favorable outcome for Israel. The passage reassures believers of the inherent goodness embedded in their destiny, reinforcing faith in God's overarching guidance.

passage_content: ד)הקמתי את בריתי אתם לתת להם את ארץ כנען וגו' דרשו רז"ל (סנהדרין צ' ע"ב) לכם לא נאמר אלא להם מכאן לתחיית המתים מן התורה, ראוי להבין כוונת דרשתם ז"ל מדוע רמז הכתוב להבטחת תחיית המתים בפרשה זודייקא.
translation: I established My covenant with them to give them the land of Canaan, etc. The sages of blessed memory expounded (Sanhedrin 90b) that it was not said "to you" but "to them," from here we learn about the resurrection of the dead from the Torah. It is fitting to understand the intent of their teaching, blessed be their memory, as to why the verse hints at the promise of the resurrection of the dead in this particular section.
summary: The passage discusses the divine promise of the land of Canaan and highlights a rabbinic interpretation that connects this promise to the concept of resurrection. The phrase "לכם לא נאמר אלא להם" suggests that the assurance of inheriting the land is linked to the future resurrection of the dead, indicating a deeper theological connection between the physical and spiritual realms. This interpretation emphasizes the enduring nature of God's covenant and the ultimate redemption of the Jewish people, reflecting key Hasidic themes of hope and the continuity of faith through generations.

passage_content: ונל"פעפי"מדאיתאבספה"קנועם אלימלך (פ' ויחי) לפרש אמרם ז"ל (ברכות ל"ד ע"ב) אמרו עליו על ר"ח בןדוסאכשהי' מתפלל על החולההי' אומר זה חיכו' אמרו לו מנין אתה יודע, אמר להם אם שגורה תפלתי בפי יודע אני שהוא מקובלוכו', לכאורה מלת שגורה בפי אינו מובן, הי' לו לומר אם תפלתי יוצא מפי בלי גמגום בידוע שהוא מקובל, אךהעניןהואדהנהלכאורה יש להבין הסיבה הזאת שהצדיק מתפלל על החולה והוא מתרפא, ונראה הדבר כמו השתנות חלילה אצל הבורא האחד הפשוט האמיתי וחלילה לחשוב ולומר כך, אךהעניןדהנהכל העולמות וכל הנבראים היו מתחילה קודם בריאת העולםבכחאין סוף ב"ה ואח"כ כשעלה ברצונו הפשוט לבוראם הוציאםמכחאל הפועל וכל מה שיהי' הוא שהי'בכחהאין סוף ב"ה וב"ש, ונמצא אין כאן שום השתנות כי כל זאת הי'בכחהא"סשזה יהי' חולה והצדיק יתפלל עליוויעתרבתפלתו וכו'עכלה"קלענינינועיי"ש, המורםמדבה"קדרק תפלה שהי'בכחהא"סב"המתחלתהבריאה מתקבלת ולא זולת, אמנם תפלה זו שהתפללמשרע"הלמההרעותהוגו' לאהיתהראוי' שתתקבל, כי הכבדת השעבוד הי' לטובתן של ישראל כמבוארבדרז"ל, ועוד טעמים כמבואר בדברנו להלן, נמצא תפלה זו לא הי'בכחהא"סב"ה מתחילת הבריאה, אלאשנסתבבלו מן השמיםבבחי' נורא עלילהועי"זנענש ולא נכנס לארץ, וכל זה הי' לתועלת הצלתן של ישראל כמבואר להלן,וז"פדברי המדרש כי מה האדם שיבא אחרי המלך את אשר כבר עשוהו ר"לבתחלתהבריאה, ולא יתכן בחי' השתנות אצלהבוי"תורק תפלה שהי'בכחהא"סב"ה מתקבלת, ומשה לא שמר את הדבר הזה אלא בא להתחכם על גזירתו של הקב"ה והתחיל אומר ה' למה הרעתהוכו', ותפלה זו לא הי' מוכנת ולאהיתהראוי' להתקבל,וז"פאידך דברי המדרש הי' לך לידע טוב אחרית דבר מראשיתו, היינו טוב אחרית דבר להתפלל תפלה שהוא מראשיתו מוכנתבכחהא"סב"המתחלתבריאת העולם, ולא כן תפלה זו שאמר למה הרעתה.
translation: And it is said in "Divrei Yoel" (Parashat Vayechi) to explain what our sages of blessed memory said (Berakhot 34b) about Rabbi Chiya ben Dosa, that when he would pray for the sick, he would say, "This one will live." They asked him, "How do you know?" He replied, "If my prayer is fluent in my mouth, I know that it is accepted." At first glance, the term "fluent in my mouth" is not clear; he should have said that if my prayer comes out of my mouth without stuttering, it is known that it is accepted. However, the matter is that one must understand the reason why the righteous prays for the sick and he is healed. It seems as if there is a change, Heaven forbid, in the One, the simple, true Creator, and it is forbidden to think or say such a thing. But the matter is that all the worlds and all creations were initially, before the creation of the world, in the potential of the Infinite Blessed Be He, and afterwards, when it arose in His simple will to create them, He brought them forth from potential to actual. Everything that will be is what was in the potential of the Infinite Blessed Be He, and thus there is no change here, for all of this was in the power of the Infinite, that this one will be sick and the righteous will pray for him and his prayer will be accepted, etc. As it is stated, the essence of prayer that is in the power of the Infinite Blessed Be He from the beginning of creation is accepted and nothing else. However, this prayer that Moshe prayed, "Why have You harmed Your servant?" was not worthy of being accepted, for the hardening of the servitude was for the benefit of Israel, as explained by our sages of blessed memory, and other reasons as explained in our discussion below. Thus, this prayer was not in the power of the Infinite Blessed Be He from the beginning of creation, but rather it was entangled from the heavens in a terrible accusation, and thus he was punished and did not enter the land. All of this was for the benefit of saving Israel, as explained below. And this is the meaning of the words of the Midrash, that what is man that he should come after the King with that which has already been done, meaning from the beginning of creation, and it is not possible for there to be a change in Him. Only a prayer that is in the power of the Infinite Blessed Be He is accepted. And Moshe did not guard this matter, but rather he came to be clever against the decree of the Holy One, Blessed Be He, and began to say, "O Lord, why have You harmed Your servant?" And this prayer was not prepared and was not worthy of being accepted. And this is the meaning of the other words of the Midrash, that you should know well the end of a matter from its beginning, meaning the good end of a matter is to pray a prayer that is from its beginning prepared in the power of the Infinite Blessed Be He from the beginning of the creation of the world, and not like this prayer that he said, "Why have You harmed?"
summary: The passage discusses the nature of prayer and its acceptance by God, emphasizing that a righteous person's prayer for healing is effective because it aligns with the divine will established at the beginning of creation. It highlights that all worlds and beings exist within the potential of the Infinite One, and thus, there is no real change in God when a prayer is answered. The text also critiques the notion of questioning God's decrees, as exemplified by Moses, suggesting that such prayers are not in harmony with the divine plan and therefore lack the necessary power to be accepted. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of praying in accordance with the original divine intention for one's prayers to be effective.

passage_content: ונקדיםדברי המדרש (איכה רבתי פ"ד סי' י"ד) מזמור לאסףאלקיםבאו גוים בנחלתך (תהלים ע"ט) לאהוהקרא צריךלמימראלא בכי לאסף נהי לאסף קינה לאסף, ומה אומר מזמור לאסף אלא משל למלך וכו' כך אמר להם מזמר אנו ששפך הקב"ה חמתו על עצים ואבנים ולא שפך חמתו על ישראלוכו', והנה אלמלי נכנסמרע"הלא"י הי' בונהביהמ"קולא היו האויבים יכולים לשלוט במעשה ידיוכאמרםז"ל (סוטה ט' ע"א), ואין מקום לתקנה של שפך חמתו על עצים ואבנים, וע"י שלא נכנסמשרע"הלא"י ניצולו ישראל מכלי' ששפך הקב"ה חמתו על עצים ואבנים.
translation: And we will precede with the words of the Midrash (Eicha Rabbah, Perek 4, Siman 14): A Psalm for Asaf, "God, the nations have come into Your inheritance" (Psalms 79). It is necessary to say that it is not a lament for Asaf, nor a wailing for Asaf, but a dirge for Asaf. And what does it mean, "A Psalm for Asaf"? Rather, it is a parable to a king, etc. Thus, he said to them, "We sing because the Holy One, blessed be He, poured out His wrath upon trees and stones and did not pour out His wrath upon Israel," etc. And behold, had Moshe entered the Land of Israel, he would have built the Holy Temple, and the enemies would not have been able to dominate the work of His hands, as our sages of blessed memory said (Sotah 9a). And there is no place for the remedy of His wrath being poured out upon trees and stones. And by the fact that Moshe did not enter the Land of Israel, Israel was saved from the destruction that the Holy One, blessed be He, poured out upon trees and stones.
summary: The passage discusses the idea that God's wrath was directed towards inanimate objects rather than the people of Israel, as expressed in the psalm attributed to Asaf. It emphasizes that had Moses entered the Land of Israel, he would have built the Holy Temple, preventing the enemies from having power over the Jewish people. This reflects a Hasidic belief in divine protection and the significance of the Temple as a central point of connection between God and Israel. Ultimately, it highlights the notion that Israel's suffering is mitigated by God's mercy, even in times of destruction.

passage_content: והנהאיתאבמד"ר(פ' ה' סי' כ"ג) ויאמר ה' אל משה עתה תראה וגו' מכאן אתה למד שנטל משה את הדין שלא יכנס לארץ, אמנם ע"י תוקף הדין שנגזר עליו שלא יכנס לא"ינסתבבאח"כ לישראל רחמים גדוליםשעי"זניצולו מכלי', וזה ירמוז הכתוב וידבראלקיםהיינובמדה"דשנטל משה את הדין שלא יכנס לארץ, ומזה נמשך מדת הרחמים לישראל ויאמר אליו אני ה' שם של רחמים שינצלועי"זמכלי'.
translation: And behold, it is written in the Midrash (Parashat Ha'azinu, Section 23) that the Lord said to Moses, "Now you shall see..." From here you learn that Moses accepted the decree that he would not enter the Land. However, through the strength of the decree that was imposed upon him not to enter, he later brought great mercy upon Israel, by which they were saved from calamities. This is hinted at in the verse, "And God spoke to him," which refers to the measure of judgment that Moses accepted regarding not entering the Land, and from this, the attribute of mercy was extended to Israel. And He said to him, "I am the Lord," a name of mercy, by which they will be saved from calamities.
summary: The passage discusses the moment when God informs Moses that he will not enter the Promised Land, highlighting the tension between divine judgment and mercy. It emphasizes that despite the strict decree against Moses, this very judgment leads to a greater outpouring of mercy for the Israelites, allowing them to be saved from destruction. The text illustrates the Hasidic concept that even in the face of harsh judgment, divine compassion can emerge, ultimately benefiting the community. The mention of God's name as a symbol of mercy reinforces the idea that mercy can transcend strict justice.
