translation: And the Lord said to Moses, saying, "Go speak to Pharaoh, king of Egypt, and send the Children of Israel out of his land." It is stated again, "Go speak to Pharaoh," indicating that it is more than once that He commanded to speak to Pharaoh.
summary: In this passage, the emphasis is on the divine command given to Moses to confront Pharaoh, highlighting the theme of divine authority and the necessity of obedience to God's will. The repetition of the command signifies the importance of persistence in the face of opposition, reflecting the Hasidic belief in the power of faith and action. This interaction illustrates the struggle between spiritual truth and worldly power, underscoring the idea that divine purpose will ultimately prevail. The passage invites reflection on the role of human agency in fulfilling divine intentions amidst challenges.

passage_content: ו)ה' אל משה ואל אהרן ויצום אלבנ"יואל פרעה וגו'פירש"יז"לצוהעליהם להנהיגם בנחת ולסבול אותם, ואל פרעה מלך מצרים צום עליו לחלוק לו כבוד בדבריהם,וצ"במדועדוקאבשליחות זוצוהאותם לחלוק כבוד לפרעה ולאצוהכן בשליחות אחרת.
translation: And the Lord spoke to Moses and to Aaron and commanded them to speak to the children of Israel and to Pharaoh, etc. It is explained that He commanded them to lead them gently and to bear with them, and to Pharaoh, king of Egypt, He commanded them to show him honor in their words. And it is necessary to understand the significance of this commandment, to show honor to Pharaoh, and also to command them in another mission.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the emphasis is on the divine command given to Moses and Aaron to lead the Israelites with gentleness and patience, reflecting a core Hasidic value of compassion in leadership. The instruction to show respect to Pharaoh, despite his oppressive rule, highlights the importance of honoring authority and the potential for spiritual elevation through humility. This duality of serving both the oppressed and the oppressor illustrates a profound theological insight into the nature of divine mission and the complexities of human relationships within the framework of faith. Ultimately, it underscores the significance of maintaining dignity and respect in all interactions, even in challenging circumstances.

passage_content: ז)משה לפרעה התפאר עלי למתי אעתיר לך ולעבדיך ולעמך להכרית הצפרדעים ממך ומבתיך רק ביאור תשארנה, ויאמר למחר ויאמר כדבריך למען תדע כי אין כה'אלקינו,יל"דשלא מצינו בא' מן המכות שביקשמרע"השיקצוב פרעה זמן להסירם ממנו, ולדברי רז"ל הי' זמן קצוב לכל המכותבשוה, לחד מ"ד ז' ימים ולחד מ"ד כ"ד יום, ומדוע נשתנה מכת הצפרדעים שתלהמרע"ההדבר בדעתו ורצונו של פרעה ושאלו למתי אעתיר לך, גם מה שהשיב לו למחר אינו מובן מדוע לא ביקש שיסורו היום ויפטר מן העונש מיד.
translation: 7) Moses boasted to Pharaoh, "I will pray for you, your servants, and your people to eradicate the frogs from you and your houses, but only the river will remain." And he said, "Tomorrow." He said, "As you have spoken, so that you may know that there is none like our God." It is taught that we do not find in any of the plagues that Pharaoh requested a specific time for their removal, and according to our sages, there was a set time for all the plagues, some for seven days and some for twenty-four days. Why was the plague of frogs different, that Moses left the matter to Pharaoh's will and desire and asked him, "When shall I pray for you?" Also, what he answered him, "Tomorrow," is not understood; why did he not ask for them to be removed today and be freed from the punishment immediately?
summary: In this passage, the dialogue between Moses and Pharaoh regarding the plague of frogs highlights the theme of divine sovereignty and human agency. Moses emphasizes that the timing of the plague's cessation is contingent upon Pharaoh's will, illustrating the tension between God's control and human choice. The unusual request for a delay until the next day raises questions about Pharaoh's hardened heart and his reluctance to fully submit to God's authority. This interaction serves to demonstrate the unique relationship between divine intervention and human response in the context of redemption and judgment.

passage_content: ח)צ"ב טעם שינוי הלשוןדפרעהאמרלמרע"ההעתירו אל ה' ויסר הצפרדעים וגו', וכן בתשובתמרע"הלפרעה כתיב וסרו הצפרדעים וגו' ובשאלתו לפרעה אמר למתי אעתיר וגו' להכרית הצפרדעים,וצ"בהכוונה בשנותו מלשון הסרה ללשון הכרתה.
translation: (8) The reason for the change in language: When Moshe Rabbeinu spoke to Pharaoh, he said, "I will pray to Hashem, and He will remove the frogs," etc. And similarly, in the response to Pharaoh, it is written, "And the frogs will depart," etc. But in his question to Pharaoh, he said, "When shall I pray," etc., to eradicate the frogs. It is necessary to understand why he changed from the language of removal to the language of eradication.
summary: In this passage, the change in language from "removal" to "eradication" in the context of Moses' plea to Pharaoh regarding the frogs signifies a deeper theological insight into the nature of divine intervention. The shift emphasizes the distinction between merely alleviating suffering and completely eliminating it, reflecting a Hasidic understanding of the transformative power of prayer. This highlights the importance of intention and the spiritual depth behind requests made to God, suggesting that true redemption requires a profound commitment to eradicating negativity rather than just alleviating it.

passage_content: ט)פרעה למשה ולאהרן ויאמר לכו זבחולאלקיכםבארץ, ויאמר משה לא נכון לעשות כן וגו' הן נזבח את תועבת מצרים לעיניהם ולא יסקלנו, לכאורה קשה דלפי דבריו הי' ראוי לחוש לסכנה פן יסקלום המצריים, א"כ מדוע אמר לא נכון לעשות כן,דמשמעותושאינו מן הנימוס הרי הי' סכנה ברורה בדבר.
translation: Pharaoh said to Moses and Aaron, "Go, sacrifice to your God in the land." And Moses said, "It is not right to do so... for we will sacrifice the abomination of Egypt before their eyes, and they will not stone us." It seems difficult, for according to his words, it would be appropriate to be concerned for the danger lest the Egyptians stone them. So why did he say it is not right to do so, since the implication is that it is not proper, yet there was a clear danger in the matter?
summary: In this passage, the dialogue between Pharaoh and Moses highlights the tension between the spiritual and physical realms. Moses asserts that sacrificing to God in Egypt would be inappropriate, as it would provoke the Egyptians, who view such acts as abominations. This reflects a deeper Hasidic concept of maintaining spiritual integrity and the importance of performing divine service in a manner that aligns with one's surroundings. The underlying theological insight emphasizes the need for discernment in how one expresses faith, particularly in a hostile environment.

passage_content: י)שלשת ימים נלך במדבר וזבחנו לה'אלקינוכאשר יאמר אלינו, לכאורה כאשר יאמר אלינו מיותר וכבר נזכר שכןצוההשי"ת.
translation: "On the third day we will go into the wilderness and we will sacrifice to Hashem our G-d as He will say to us; seemingly, the phrase 'as He will say to us' is superfluous, for it has already been commanded by the Blessed One."
summary: The passage discusses the command to journey into the desert for three days to offer sacrifices to God, highlighting the phrase "when He tells us" as seemingly redundant since God has already commanded it. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the dynamic relationship between divine command and human response, emphasizing the importance of spiritual readiness and the need for personal revelation in fulfilling God's will. The text suggests that true devotion requires not only adherence to commandments but also an active engagement with God's guidance. Ultimately, it underscores the significance of seeking a deeper connection with the divine through both action and intention.

passage_content: ונתחיללבאר דברי המדרש הנ"ל טוב אחרית דבר מראשיתו טובה אחריתן של ישראל מראשיתן שהי' להם במצרים,ואפ"לבדרך רמז מוסר עפ"י המבואר בספרן של צדיקיםדימיםאלו ימיהשובבי"םמסוגלים לתיקון חטא הידוע, וזה הי' תכלית פעולתם שלבנ"יבמצרים וע"כ הקדים יוסף הצדיק לבוא למצרים תחלה להכין בגודל קדושתוכחלבנ"ישיוכלו לעמודבנסיונותולהתגדרא"עבמידה זו כמבוארבמד"רפ' אמור (פ' ל"ב סי' ה') יוסף ירד למצרים וגדר עצמו מן הערוהונגדרוישראל בזכותו, ואיתאבזוה"קפ' שמות (דף ט"ו ע"א) כדחמאקוב"החדוותאסגיאהדהאיעלמאתתאהדאשתכללכגונאדלעילא, אמר דילמא ח"ויתערבוןבשאר עממיןוישתארפגימותאבכולהועלמין, מה עבדקוב"הטלטללכולהומהכאלהכאעדדנחתולמצרים למידרדיוריהוןבעם קשיקדלדמבזיןנימוסיהון,ומבזיןלהוןלאתחתנאבהוולאתערבאבהדייהווחשיבולהון עבדין, גוברין געלן בהוןנוקבתאגעלן בהון. עדדאשתכללכולאבזרעאקדישאוכו', וכד נפקונפקוזכאיןקדישיןדכתיבשבטי יה עדות לישראל עכ"דהזוה"קלענינינו, ולכאורהלפי"זהרי לא הי' בגדרנסיוןכלל שהרי המצרים מאסו בהם ומיאנו מלהתחתןולאתערבאבהדייהו,ובמקו"אאמרובזוה"ק(שמות ג' ע"ב)זכאיןאינון ישראלדאע"גדהוובגלותאדמצריםאסתמרומכל הניתלתאמנדה ובת אלנכרוכו'ובזכותאדא נפקו ישראלמגלותא, ולכאורהה"זנראה כסתירה לדבריהזוה"קהנ"ל, דאם המצריים מאסו בהםוגובריןונוקבתאגעלן בהון, א"כ נמנע הבחירה מהם,ואמאינחשב לזכותם של ישראל מה שנשמרו והובדלו מהם.
translation: And we will begin to explain the words of the aforementioned Midrash: Good is the end of a matter from its beginning; good is the end of Israel from their beginning, which they had in Egypt. And it can also be understood as a hint of moral teaching according to what is explained in the books of the righteous, that these days of Shovavim are suitable for the rectification of the known sin. And this was the purpose of the actions of Joseph in Egypt, and therefore Joseph the righteous was the first to come to Egypt to prepare with the greatness of his holiness the sons of Israel so that they could withstand the trials and be strengthened in this measure, as explained in the Midrash, Parashat Emor (Parashat 32, Section 5): Joseph descended to Egypt and guarded himself from immorality, and Israel was guarded by his merit. And it is found in the Zohar, Parashat Shemot (page 15, side A), that the Holy One, blessed be He, saw the joy that would arise from them, and He said, perhaps, Heaven forbid, they will intermingle with other nations and will be lost among them and all the worlds. What did the Holy One, blessed be He, do? He brought them down to Egypt to be in a place where their customs would be despised, and they would be despised by them, so that they would not intermingle with them and would not be influenced by them, and they would remain as they are. They would be strong in their essence and would be strong in their holiness. Until they would be included in the seed of the holy ones, and when they went out, they went out with the merit of the holy ones, as it is written, "The tribes of Yehudah are a testimony to Israel." Thus, the Zohar teaches us. And seemingly, according to this, there was no trial at all, since the Egyptians rejected them and refused to marry them and did not intermingle with them. And in another place, it is said in the Zohar (Shemot 3, side B) that the righteous are those who, despite being in exile in Egypt, were preserved from all that is attached to them, and the daughter of a foreigner was not mixed with them. And by this merit, Israel went out from exile. And seemingly, this appears to contradict the aforementioned words of the Zohar, for if the Egyptians rejected them and were strong and despised them, then their choice was prevented from them, and it cannot be considered a merit for Israel that they were preserved and distinguished from them.
summary: The passage discusses the divine providence and protection afforded to the Israelites during their time in Egypt, emphasizing that their suffering ultimately served a greater purpose in their spiritual rectification. It highlights the role of Joseph, whose righteousness prepared the way for the Israelites to withstand trials and maintain their identity amidst the challenges posed by the Egyptians. The text also reflects on the paradox of the Egyptians' rejection of the Israelites, suggesting that this very rejection was a means of preserving the Israelites' sanctity and distinctiveness, thus reinforcing the idea that their survival was a result of divine intervention rather than mere chance. Ultimately, it underscores the belief that even in exile, the Israelites were safeguarded by their inherent holiness and the merit of their ancestors.

passage_content: אולםבאמת כ"ז הי' לצד עצם בחירתם הטוב, שהרי הערב רב ורשעי ישראל על שהיומתדמיןבמעשיהםונתחברועם המצריים, היוחשוביןביניהם ועשו אותם פטרונים, ורקבנ"יהכשרים שלא רצו להתדמות אליהם, ולא שינו את שמם ולשונם ומלבושיהם, והתרחקו ממנהגיהם ונימוסיהם,עי"זהיו נמאסים בעיניהם והשתעבדו בהם בתוקף השעבוד, ואעפ"כ עמדובנסיונםוסבלו צרת השעבוד ולא רצו בקרבתם והתרחקו מהתחברותם, וזה הי' להם לחומה נשגבה שלא נכשלו בעריות על ידם,כאמרז"לבמד"ר(אמורפל"בס"ה) אחתהיתהופרסמה הכתוב, וא"ש שנחשב לזכותם של ישראל דמה שהיו המצרייםממאסיןבהם הי' לצד עצם בחירתם ומפני כשרותם וצדקתם, וכך הוטבע ממנוית' בטבע להיות הרשעיםממאסיןבצדיקים ולא יחפצו בקרבתם, וכמ"שבמד"ר(פ' חיי פ' ס' סי' ה') והנערה טובת מראה מאוד בתולה ואיש לא ידעה,א"ריוחנן ממשמע שנא' בתולה אין אנו יודעים ואיש לא ידעה, אלא אפי' אדם לא תבע בה על שם (תהלים קכ"ה) לא ינוח שבט הרשע על גורל הצדיקים, ופי'היפ"תדזהומשבח רבקה, כי האדם לא יאהב אלא בדומה לו, הרשע יאהב להתחבר עם רשעים כמותו והצדיק עם צדיקים כמותו,וז"שכי לא ינוח שבט הרשע וגו' כי שבט הרשע לא ימצא נחת על גורל הצדיקים יען כי לא ישלחו הצדיקים בעולתה ידיהם, והרשעיםמבקשיןרק עול ואון, ולכן לא תבע א' מהם לרבקה ולא חפץ להדבק בה כי המה היו רשעים והיאצדיקתעכ"ל, וכתב ק"זהיש"מזלה"ה(בפ' בלק) כי שומה מאת ה' ששנאה כבושה יש בין צדיק לרשע בטבע, אף אם איןמכיריןזה בזה היטב במעשיהם, כדי שלא יהי' להם התחברות וילמד ממנו וכו' ולפי גודל הטומאה של האיש ההוא כך הוא השנאה, כי השנאה הוא לפי ההתרחקות עיי"ש.
translation: However, in truth, this was due to the essence of their good choice, for the mixed multitude and the wicked of Israel, because they were striving to resemble the Egyptians, thought themselves to be among them and made them patrons. Only the righteous among them did not wish to resemble them, did not change their names, their language, or their clothing, and distanced themselves from their customs and manners. Because of this, they were despised in their eyes and were enslaved by them with the force of servitude. Nevertheless, they stood firm in their trials and endured the suffering of servitude, not wanting to be close to them and distancing themselves from their association. This was for them a lofty wall, so that they did not stumble into immorality through them, as our sages have said in Midrash (Emor, Parashat Behar, Section 5): "One was a woman." And it is clear that this is considered a merit for Israel, that the Egyptians despised them was due to the essence of their choice and because of their righteousness and justice. Thus, it was ingrained in nature that the wicked would despise the righteous and not desire to be close to them, as it is stated in the Midrash (Parashat Chayei Sarah, Section 5): "And the girl was very beautiful, a virgin, and no man knew her." Rabbi Yochanan interprets that since it is said "a virgin," we do not know "and no man knew her," but even a man did not desire her because, as it is written (Psalms 125), "The scepter of wickedness shall not rest upon the lot of the righteous." And this is the praise of Rivkah, for a person will only love that which is similar to him; the wicked will love to associate with wicked people like themselves, and the righteous with righteous people like themselves. And this is what is meant by "the scepter of wickedness shall not rest upon the lot of the righteous," for the scepter of wickedness will not find rest upon the lot of the righteous, because the righteous will not extend their hands to the wicked. The wicked seek only oppression and violence, and therefore none of them desired Rivkah or wished to cling to her, for they were wicked and she was righteous. Thus, it is written in the Zohar (Parashat Balak) that it is decreed by the Holy One, blessed be He, that there is a concealed hatred between the righteous and the wicked by nature, even if they do not know each other well in their deeds, so that they will not have association and learn from one another, etc. And according to the degree of the impurity of that person, so is the hatred, for hatred is according to the distance.
summary: The passage emphasizes the intrinsic separation between the righteous (tzadikim) and the wicked (resha'im), highlighting that the righteous maintain their identity and distance from the corrupt practices of the wicked, which serves as a protective barrier against moral corruption. It suggests that this natural aversion is divinely ordained, ensuring that the righteous do not associate with the wicked, as their values and desires are fundamentally incompatible. The text illustrates that the disdain of the wicked for the righteous is a reflection of the inherent purity and chosenness of the latter, reinforcing the idea that true righteousness cannot coexist with wickedness. Ultimately, this separation is seen as a safeguard for the integrity of the righteous, preventing them from being influenced by the moral decay of the wicked.

passage_content: ומעתהאין סתירה בדבריהזוה"קכלל, דאף מה שמאסו המצריים בהם הוא לצד זכותם וצדקתם, ועדיין הי' הבחירה בידם להתקרב אל המצריים כדרך שעשוהע"רורשעי ישראל, ואעפ"כ עמדובנסיונםולז"אזכאיןאינון ישראלדאסתמרומכל הני וכו' ואולי הי' הצורך לזה שימאסו המצריים בהם, מפנישעתידיןאומה"עלומר אם בגופן שלטו בנשותיהן לא כ"ש: כמ"שבמד"ר(שה"ש פר' ד' י"ב), שהיו האומות מונין את ישראל ואומרים (שמות א') ויעבידו מצרים את בני ישראל, אם בעשותן הןמכריחיןכל שכן בגופן ובנשותיהם, ולכן נתן הקב"ה בטבעם שימאסו בישראל גובריןונוקביןובזה נדחה ונתבטלהק"ושלהם.
translation: And from now on, there is no contradiction in the words of the Zohar in general, that even what the Egyptians rejected them was due to their merit and righteousness, and still, the choice was in their hands to draw close to the Egyptians, as the wicked ones of Israel did. And nevertheless, they stood in their trial, and thus it is said, "They are the righteous ones, who are preserved from all these," etc. And perhaps the need for this was that the Egyptians would reject them, because in the future a nation will arise, if they ruled over their bodies, how much more so over their women, as it is said in the Midrash (Song of Songs, chapter 4, verse 12), that the nations counted Israel and said (Exodus 1), "And the Egyptians made the children of Israel serve," if in their actions they are forcing, certainly in their bodies and their women. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, gave them a nature to reject Israel, both males and females, and in this, their power and dominion was nullified.
summary: The passage discusses the relationship between the Israelites and the Egyptians, emphasizing that the Egyptians' rejection of the Israelites was rooted in divine justice and the Israelites' inherent righteousness. It highlights the concept of free will, suggesting that despite the Egyptians' disdain, the Israelites had the choice to align with them, unlike the wicked among Israel. The text also reflects on the future significance of Israel as a nation, indicating that the Egyptians' aversion was part of a divine plan to protect the sanctity of the Jewish people. Ultimately, it underscores the idea that God's providence shapes the dynamics between nations, ensuring the preservation of Israel's identity.

passage_content: אמנםאעפי"כמפני שהיו ישראל בגלות מצרים ערות הארץ ומזוהמים מכל האומות, הי' להםנסיונותקשים בשמירת קדושת הברית, ואף אם מידי עריות ניצולו, אבל הי' להם עבודה גדולה במלחמת היצרלהמלטמן המחשבות והרהורים וחטא הידוע במקום מזוהם כזה, ובשעה שהגיעו סמוך לפרק הגאולה התגברו כוחות הטומאה עליהם יותר להחטיאם ר"ל, וע"ד שפי'בתויו"ט(אבות פ"ה מ"ה) ולא אירע קרילכה"גביוכ"פ, יש מי שהקשה ולמה יארע לו קרי אחר שהיומזרזיןאותו כל ז' הימים והוא בטהרה כל היום ההוא, וזקני העם כל הלילה לא יחשומלזרזו, והתשובה כייצה"טויצה"רמתקוטטים זה עם זה כשני אויבים וכשא' מהם קרוב להיות מנוצח, יתחזק על עמדו בראותו כי כלתה אליו הרעה וכו' ולזה הי' קרוב מאוד להיות הכהן בעל קרי עכ"ל,ועד"זלענינינוכשראה הס"מ שבאו משה ואהרן בשליחות השי"ת לגאול את ישראל, התגברבנסיונותיועליהם יותר, נמצא שאז הוצרכובנ"ילהתרחק ולהבדל מן המצרים יותר, כדי שיוכלו לעמודבנסיוןולא יכשלו בחטא, ולטעם זה סיבבהבוי"תשהכביד פרעה עול שעבודו עליהם בעת ההוא, כדי להגן על שמירתם,דע"יהעבדות והשעבוד נמאסו בעיני המצריים כמבוארבזוה"קהנ"ל, נמצא שנצמח לישראל טובה ותועלת מקושי השעבוד,ועי"זיצאו זכאים וכשרים וזכו לקבלת התורה כמ"שבזוה"ק(יתרו ע"ח ב')בההואזמנאדמטוישראללטוראדסיניכנישלהוקוב"הלזרעייןדישראלואשגחלי'בכלהו. ולא אשכחבכלהוזרעאדישראלפסלו, אלא כלהוזרעאקדישא כלהו בניקשוטוכו', וע"כ נתן להם התורה עיי"ש.
translation:
Indeed, despite this, because the Israelites were in the exile of Egypt, the land was bare and they were contaminated by all the nations, they faced difficult trials in maintaining the sanctity of the covenant. Even if they were saved from acts of immorality, they had a great struggle in the war against the evil inclination to escape from thoughts and reflections and the known sin in such a contaminated place. And at the time when they approached the moment of redemption, the forces of impurity intensified against them more to lead them astray, Heaven forbid. And as it is explained in the Tz'ror HaChaim (Ethics of the Fathers 5:5), "And it did not happen to him a 'keri' (a state of ritual impurity) all that day," there are those who ask why a 'keri' would occur to him after he is urged all seven days and he is in a state of purity all that day, and the elders of the people do not cease to urge him all night. The answer is that the evil inclination and the good inclination are in conflict with one another like two enemies, and when one of them is close to being defeated, it strengthens its position upon seeing that evil is approaching it, etc. Therefore, it was very close for the priest to be in a state of 'keri.' 

And regarding this, when the accuser saw that Moses and Aaron came on the mission of the Holy One, Blessed be He, to redeem Israel, he intensified the trials against them even more. It turns out that at that time they needed to distance themselves and separate from the Egyptians more, so that they could withstand the trial and not stumble into sin. For this reason, Pharaoh's oppression was intensified upon them at that time, to protect their observance, for the servitude and oppression were despised in the eyes of the Egyptians, as explained in the Zohar. Thus, it turns out that Israel derived goodness and benefit from the difficulty of the servitude, and through this, they emerged righteous and pure and were worthy of receiving the Torah, as it is written in the Zohar (Jethro 78b) that at that time when Israel came to receive the Torah, the Holy One, Blessed be He, looked upon all of Israel and did not find any of their seed unworthy, but all of their seed was holy, all of them in purity, etc. Therefore, He gave them the Torah, as stated there.
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual challenges faced by the Israelites during their enslavement in Egypt, emphasizing their struggle to maintain the sanctity of the covenant amidst the pervasive impurity of their surroundings. It highlights that as the time for redemption approached, the forces of impurity intensified their attempts to lead the Israelites astray, necessitating a greater effort to remain separate from the Egyptians. The text suggests that the hardships of slavery ultimately served a divine purpose, enabling the Israelites to emerge pure and worthy of receiving the Torah, as they were able to withstand these trials and maintain their spiritual integrity.

passage_content: ונקדיםדברי ק"זהיש"מזלה"ה(בפ' תבוא) לפרש הכתוב (איוב ח') והי' ראשיתך מצער ואחריתך ישגה מאוד,וזל"קכי הנה תמהתי על עיכוב הגלותכי רוב בני ישראל המה כשרים ומדוע בן דוד לא בא, וכאשר חקרתי נתוודע לי כי בבחרותם מרבין חבילות עבירות עד שדי להם על ימי חייהם, וע"ז איןעושיןתשובה כלל וזה הגורם, ולכך איןיכוליןשוב להדבקבבוראינוית"שוכו', והעיקר בבחרותו ונערותו כי התחלה יותר מןהכלוכו' וכן נ"ל לפרש והי' ראשיתך מצער עוונותמוצעריןאז ואחריתך ישגה מאוד, כיבעוה"רהמעשה נערות ובחרות יכלההכלומשחיתהכלעכדה"ק, ואנן מהנעניאבתרי'בדורינוזה שנתרבה השפלות עד מאוד, ובפרט בחטא זההנסיונותגדולים וקשים, ומפני שזהו יסוד ושורשהכל, ע"כ מתגבר השטןבעניןזה יותר, וידוע שכל התגברות קליפה השולטת בעולם משפיע על כל אדם במקצת, וכ"א צריך סייעתא דשמיאלהנצלממנה, ובדור הזה מתגבר הס"ס בב' פרטי עבירות ר"ל,ביצראדמינותבאופנים שונים,וזעיריןאינון הניצולים ממחשבת מינות לגמרי,ורובאדאינשינתפסים ה'ישמרינו,והב' מתגבר הס"מ להרסיסוד קדושתן של ישראל בפגם הברית ר"ל,בעוה"רעד כמה הגיע הירידה והשפלות בכל עניני הטהרה ושמירת היסוד, ואפי' באותן היודעים חומרהעוןמועטים המה הניצולים מן העבירה, וצריך לסייעתא דשמיא מרובים, כמושהי"ללישראל במצרים שהשגיחהבוית"שעל כאו"א מישראל בשמירה פרטיות שלא יכשלו בחטא,ובעוה"רבדורינוזה ההשגחה מסותרת, ומי שרוצה להיות יהודי נאמן לה' ולתורתו הקדושה, רואה את עצמו כשה אובד מחמת גודל ההסתרה, וקשה לשלוט על המחשבות ועל כל תנועה ותנועה, אבל באמת כ"ז אינו רק דמיון מחמת תוקף הגלות וכובדהנסיונות, וצריך לדעתשהבוית"שמשגיח בפרטיות על כאו"א מישראל, והעיקר רק לבקש דרך האמת וירצה להיות דבוקבבוכ"ע,ובעיניםצופיות נבקש מאתוית"ששירחם עלינו ויוציאנו מחשכות גדול הזה, ואז נראה בעינינו השגחתוית' בכל פרט ופרט.
translation: And I will precede the words of K"Z H"Y (in Parshat Ki Tavo) to explain the verse (Job 8:7) "And your beginning will be small, and your end will greatly increase." The interpretation is as follows: I am astonished by the delay of the exile, for most of the children of Israel are righteous, and why has the son of David not come? And as I investigated, it became known to me that in their youth they accumulate many bundles of sins until they are sufficient for their lifetime, and for this, they do not repent at all, and this is the cause. Therefore, they cannot return to cling to our Creator, blessed be He. The essence in their youth is that it is the beginning more than anything else. Thus, I believe it can be interpreted that "your beginning will be small" refers to the sins that are small then, "and your end will greatly increase," as it is written in the holy books regarding the actions of youth and young men, which can destroy everything. And we are from the lowly ones in this generation, where the degradation has increased greatly, especially in this sin of great and difficult trials. Because this is the foundation and root of everything, therefore the Satan is strengthened in this matter more. It is known that every strengthening of the impure forces that rule the world affects every person somewhat, and everyone needs divine assistance to be saved from it. In this generation, the evil inclination is strengthened in two specific sins, namely, heresy in various forms, and few are those who are completely saved from heretical thoughts, and most people are caught in it, may God protect us. The second is that the evil inclination is strengthened to destroy the sanctity of Israel through the blemish of the covenant, may God have mercy, to what extent has the descent and degradation reached in all matters of purity and the observance of the foundation. Even among those who know the severity of the sin, few are those who are saved from the transgression, and divine assistance is needed for many, as it was for Israel in Egypt, where He, blessed be He, watched over each one of Israel with private protection so that they would not stumble in sin. And in this generation, the divine supervision is concealed, and whoever wants to be a faithful Jew to God and His holy Torah sees himself as if he is lost because of the great concealment, and it is difficult to control thoughts and every movement. But in truth, all of this is only an illusion due to the severity of the exile and the weight of the trials. One must know that the Holy One, blessed be He, watches over each one of Israel in particular, and the main thing is to seek the path of truth and desire to be attached to Him, blessed be He. With watchful eyes, we will ask from Him, blessed be He, to have mercy on us and take us out of this great darkness, and then we will see with our own eyes His supervision in every detail.
summary: The passage discusses the delay of the Messiah's arrival, attributing it to the accumulation of sins among the youth, which prevents them from repenting and connecting with the Creator. It emphasizes the challenges faced in the current generation, particularly regarding the trials of heresy and the sanctity of the covenant, leading to a widespread spiritual decline. Despite the overwhelming nature of these challenges, the text reassures that Divine Providence is still present, urging individuals to seek truth and strive for a connection with God, which will ultimately reveal His guidance in their lives.

passage_content: הדרןלענינינולבאר דברי המדרש הנ"ל טוב אחרית דבר מראשיתווכו',עפימ"שרז"לבמד"ר(קהלת ז' ס"ח) טוב אחרית דבר, כשהוא טוב מראשיתו,דהעיקרהכלהוא היסוד והתחלה והכל בתר רישאגרירעיי"ש, האמנם דאף מי שלא זכה לראשית טוב בימי נערותו, עדיין יש לו תקנה להטיב מעשיו אף בימי זקנותו, וכמ"ש רז"ל (סוכה נ"ג ע"א) גבי שמחת בית השואבה, יש מהן אומרים אשריזקנתינושכפרה את ילדותינו אלו בעלי תשובה,ובמד"רקהלת הנ"ל דרשו ג"כ טוב אחרית דבר מראשיתו, יש לך אדם שעושה מעשים רעים בנערותו ובזקנותו עושה מעשים טובים, והאחרית טוב מהראשית, אמנם בחי' זו רבתהנסיונות, ולאו כל אנפין שווין להשיג תשובה ראוי' בזקנותו, אחרי שנשתרש בקרבוכחהרע מימי הנעורים, והדרך המשובח והמעולה להשגיח על הראשית שתהי' טובה, ואז ימשך מזה גם אחרית טוב, וזהו כלל בכלהמדותבעבדותהבוית"ש, ובפרטבעניןשמירת הברית שזהו יסודהכל, וכמ"ש ק"זזלה"הלפרש והי' ראשיתך מצער אז ואחריתך ישגה מאוד.
translation: We return to the matter discussed in the aforementioned Midrash, that "the end of a matter is better than its beginning" (Ecclesiastes 7:8), according to what our Sages said in the Midrash. The essence of the matter is that the foundation and beginning are all in the initial stages. Indeed, even one who did not merit a good beginning in his youth still has the opportunity to improve his deeds even in his old age, as our Sages said regarding the Simchat Beit HaShoeva, that some say, "When we grow old, we atone for our youth," and in the Midrash on Ecclesiastes, they also expounded that "the end of a matter is better than its beginning." There is a person who does evil deeds in his youth and does good deeds in his old age, and the end is better than the beginning. However, this aspect is filled with trials, and not all individuals are equal in achieving proper repentance in their old age, after having been entrenched in evil from their youth. The best and most excellent way is to ensure that the beginning is good, and then from this, a good end will also follow. This is a principle in all the attributes in the service of the Holy One, Blessed be He, and especially regarding the matter of guarding the covenant, which is its very foundation, as it is said, "And your beginning will be small, so your latter end will greatly increase" (Job 8:7).
summary: The passage emphasizes the Hasidic concept that while the end of a person's life can be good even if their youth was marked by wrongdoing, it is ideal for one's beginning to be good to ensure a positive outcome. It highlights the importance of striving for righteousness from an early age, particularly in the context of maintaining moral integrity, as this foundation influences one's later actions. The text also acknowledges the challenges of repentance in old age, suggesting that a strong commitment to good deeds and spiritual growth from youth is essential for achieving a truly positive end. Ultimately, it underscores the significance of the initial choices in shaping one's spiritual journey and destiny.

passage_content: ובזהיתבאר דברי המדרש הנ"ל, א"ל הקב"ה למשה חייך יש לך לידע שנא' טוב אחרית דבר מראשיתו, טובה אחריתן של ישראל מראשיתן שנתתי להם במצרים, וזהו תשובה על מה שנצטערמשרע"העל קושי השעבוד ואמר למההרעותה, והשיב לו הקב"ה שנצמח מזה תועלת וטובה גדולה לישראל,דעי"זנשמרו מפגם הברית וזכו להיות גם ראשיתן טובה, ומזה נמשך אחרית טוב לכל דורות ישראלדעי"זזכו לקבלת התורה,וכחזה עומד לנו להתגבר עלנסיונותהקשים, והאחרית בגאולה העתידה תהי'בבחי' גדולה מהראשית של מצרים, וכ"ז נמשך מהראשית,דהכלבתר השורש אזיל כידוע, ובזהיל"פמאמה"כוגם אני שמעתי את נאקתבנ"יאשר מצרים מעבידים אותם ואזכור את בריתי, ר"ל שמעתי כבר צעקתם מקושי השעבוד, אבל ואזכור את בריתיתקוןהברית שיצמח מזה לכל דורות ישראל, ע"כאלקיםחשבה לטובה והי' הכרח לזה בשביל תועלת והצלת הדורות.
translation: And in this, the words of the aforementioned Midrash are clarified: The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "By your life, you should know that it is said, 'Good is the end of a matter from its beginning.' The goodness of the end of Israel is greater than the goodness of their beginning that I gave them in Egypt. This is a response to what Moses was distressed about regarding the difficulty of the servitude and said, 'Why have You done evil to Your people?' And the Holy One, Blessed be He, answered him that from this will arise great benefit and goodness for Israel. Know that through this they were preserved from the blemish of the covenant and merited to have their beginning also be good. From this, a good end extends to all generations of Israel, for through this they merited the receiving of the Torah, and thus we have the strength to overcome the difficult trials. The end in the future redemption will be greater than the beginning in Egypt, and all this extends from the beginning, for everything follows the root, as is known. And in this, it is said, 'And I have also heard the cry of the children of Israel whom Egypt is enslaving, and I will remember My covenant.' This means I have already heard their cry from the difficulty of the servitude, but I will remember My covenant, the rectification of the covenant that will arise from this for all generations of Israel. Therefore, God thought for good, and it was necessary for this for the benefit and salvation of the generations.
summary: הקטע מדגיש את הרעיון שהקב"ה גילה למשה כי כל קושי שעברו ישראל במצרים נועד להביא לתועלת גדולה, שהיא שמירה על ברית הקודש וזכייה בטוב ראשוני ואחריתי. השעבוד, על אף הקשיים שבו, היה הכרחי כדי להבטיח את קבלת התורה ולחזק את כוחם של ישראל להתמודד עם ניסיונות עתידיים. בסופו של דבר, הגאולה העתידה תהיה גדולה יותר מהראשית, והכל נמשך מהשורש של הקשיים שעברו. הקב"ה ראה את צעקת ישראל והכין להם תיקון שיביא תועלת לדורות.

passage_content: ואפ"לעוד דברי המדרש הנ"ל טוב אחרית דבר מראשיתו,עפי"מדאיתאבגמ' (מנחות נ"ג ע"ב) אר"י בשעה שחרבביהמ"קמצאו הקב"ה לאברהם שהי' עומדבביהמ"קאמר לו מה לידידיבביתי, א"ל עלעיסקיבני באתי, א"ל בניך חטאו וגלו וכו' א"ל הי' לך לזכור ברית מילה א"ל (ירמי' י"א) ובשר קודש יעברו מעליך, א"ל שמא אם המתנת להם היוחוזריןבתשובה, א"ל (שם) כירעתכיאז תעלזי, (פרש"יבשעת עליצותםמחזיקיןיותר בדעתם ולאחוזריןבהן) מיד הניח ידיו על ראשו והי' צועק ובוכה ואמר לו שמא ח"ו אין להם תקנה,יצתהב"קואמרה לו זית רענן יפה פרי תואר קרא ה' שמך. מה זית זה אחריתו בסופו אף ישראל אחריתן בסופן, ופי'המהרש"אבח"אדר"לאחריתו הוא תכליתו אינו אלא בסופו,דהזיתגופי' אין לו שום מעלה עד תכליתו שנעשה שמןוכו', שהזית קשה לשכחה והשמן יפהלזכרוןוכו', כך ישראל אין אחריתו ותכליתו בעוה"ז אלא בסופו דהיינו לימות המשיח אחר שיחזרו בתשובה ע"ייסוריןכמו השמן שלא בא אלא ע"י כתישה עכ"ד.
translation: And furthermore, the words of the aforementioned Midrash are good: the end of a matter is better than its beginning, as it is stated in the Gemara (Menachot 53b) that Rabbi Yochanan said, at the time when the Holy Temple was destroyed, the Holy One, Blessed be He, found Abraham standing in the Temple and said to him, "What is your friend doing in My house?" He replied, "I have come to engage in business." He said to him, "Your children have sinned and have been exiled," etc. He said to Him, "You should remember the covenant of circumcision." He replied (Jeremiah 11), "And the holy flesh will pass over you." He said, "Perhaps if You wait for them, they will return in repentance." He said (there), "As you have feared, so you will rejoice." (The explanation is that at the time of their joy, they hold more firmly to their understanding and do not return to it.) Immediately, he placed his hands on his head and was crying and weeping, saying, "Perhaps, Heaven forbid, they have no remedy." The Holy One, Blessed be He, came out and said to him, "A green olive tree, beautiful in fruit and form, the Lord has called your name." Just as this olive has a good end in its outcome, so too Israel has a good end in their outcome. And the explanation of the Maharsha is that the end is its purpose, which is only in its conclusion, for the olive itself has no merit until its end when it becomes oil, etc. The olive is hard to forget, and the oil brings forth remembrance, etc. So too, Israel's end and purpose in this world is not until its conclusion, which is in the days of the Messiah, after they return in repentance through suffering, just as the oil only comes through crushing. Thus is the matter concluded.
summary: The passage discusses the relationship between God and Abraham during the destruction of the Temple, emphasizing the hope for Israel's eventual redemption despite their sins. It highlights the concept that, like the olive which only reaches its purpose through pressing to produce oil, Israel's ultimate fulfillment and redemption will come at the end of days, particularly through repentance following suffering. This reflects a core Hasidic belief in the transformative power of hardship leading to spiritual elevation and the eventual restoration of the Jewish people. The imagery of the olive tree symbolizes resilience and the promise of a brighter future, reinforcing the idea that true purpose is realized in the culmination of one's journey.

passage_content: והנהלכאורה ראוי להבין שאמר אאע"ה הי' לך לזכור ברית מילה והשיב לו השי"ת ובשר קודש יעברו, ולא יתכן לחלוק על המציאות וא"כ אאע"ה מעיקרא מאיקסברובוודאי ידע והשיגהכל, ואיך המליץ בעדם הי' לך לזכור ברית מילה, גם צ"ב הלשון ובשר קודש יעברו הרי אם לא קיימו מצות מילה אין זה בשר קודשוהול"להפרו ברית מילה,ונל"פדבאמתקיימו ישראל מצות מילה, אולם יתפרש הכוונהעפימ"דבגמ' (עירובין י"ט ע"א) שהפוגם בריתו משכהערלתוודומה כמי שאינו נימול עיי"ש דברירשיז"ל, ואיתאבזוה"קששם הקודששריאעל האי ברית וחלילה אםפוגמיןאותומעביריןממנו שם הקודשושריאהס"מ במקומה,וז"פהגמרא שאמר אאע"ה הי' לך לזכור ברית מילה לפי שקיימו באמת מצות מילה, השיב לו הקב"ה אמת שקיימו אותה אבל בשר קודש יעברו ע"י שפגמו בקדושת הברית, שקודם הפגם נקראת המילה בשר קודשושריאעלי' שמא קדישא, וע"י הפגםמעביריןהקדושה מעליו ושורה במקומה הס"מוז"שובשר קודש יעברו, אמר אאע"ה עוד לפני הקב"ה שמא אם המתנת להם היוחוזריןבתשובה, א"ל הקב"ה שהיו שמחין עם העבירות ואין מרגישים בפגם החטא ואיך יעשו תשובה,ובעוה"רגם עכשיו שמחים במינות וכפירה ואומרים שהוא נסים ונפלאות מהקב"ה, אין לך מינות וכפירה גדולה מזה, וכיון ששמחים עמהם איך יבואו לידי תשובה, וכן הוא בפרטיות בכל אחד מישראל אם מכיר את מצבו וכואב לבו על הפגם שעשה, אז יש לצפות שיעשה עוד תשובה ויתקן פגמו, אבל אלושמצדיקיןאת מעשיהם ולבם בריא כאולם ואומרים כוחי ועוצם ידי עשה לי, איך אפשר לצפות עליהם שישובו ובפרט במינות שעלי' נאמר כל באי' לאישובון, ואפילו בשאר חטאיםבכה"גאמרו בגמ' שאיןחוזריןבתשובה, וע"ז אמר אאע"ה לפני הקב"ה שמא ח"ו אין להם תקנה,יצתהב"קואמרה לו וכו' מה זית זה אחריתו בסופו אף ישראל אחריתן בסופן. שהסוף יהי' לישראל אחריתטובה לימות המשיחכשיהי' התרוממות קרן התורה וישראל וישועה שלימה, רק מי יודע מי יזכה לה אם חלילה לא נהי' ח"ו נדחים ע"י רוב עונות, השי"ת יעזור שנזכה לראות בישועה שלימה ובאחרית הטובה שיהי' אז לישראל.
translation:
And it seems appropriate to understand that our forefather Abraham was told, "You should remember the covenant of circumcision," and the Holy One, Blessed be He, responded to him, "And the holy flesh will pass." It is not possible to dispute reality, and therefore our forefather Abraham certainly knew from the beginning and understood everything. How could he advocate for them, saying, "You should remember the covenant of circumcision"? The language is also puzzling: "And the holy flesh will pass," for if they did not fulfill the commandment of circumcision, it is not holy flesh, and thus it would be possible to nullify the covenant of circumcision. 

However, it is true that Israel fulfills the commandment of circumcision. Yet, the intention can be explained according to the teaching in the Gemara (Eruvin 19a) that one who damages his covenant is like one who is uncircumcised, as is stated there by Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish. And it is known that the holy name rests upon this covenant, and God forbid, if they damage it, they remove the holy name from him, and the evil inclination rests in its place. 

Thus, the Gemara states that our forefather Abraham said, "You should remember the covenant of circumcision" because they truly fulfilled the commandment of circumcision. The Holy One, Blessed be He, replied to him, "True, they have fulfilled it, but the holy flesh will pass due to their blemishing the sanctity of the covenant." Before the blemish, the circumcision is called holy flesh, and the holy name rests upon it, but through the blemish, they remove the sanctity from it, and it rests in the place of the evil inclination. 

And our forefather Abraham said further before the Holy One, Blessed be He, "Perhaps if you wait for them, they will return in repentance." The Holy One, Blessed be He, told him that they were rejoicing in their transgressions and do not feel the blemish of sin, and how will they repent? And in this generation, they are also now rejoicing in heresy and denial, claiming that it is miracles and wonders from the Holy One, Blessed be He. There is no greater heresy and denial than this, and since they rejoice in it, how can they come to repentance? 

And so it is in particular with each one of Israel: if he recognizes his state and his heart aches for the blemish he has caused, then one can expect that he will repent and rectify his blemish. But if he justifies his actions and his heart is healthy as a rock, saying, "My strength and the might of my hand have made this for me," how can one expect that they will return, especially in heresy, concerning which it is said, "All who come to her will not return"? And even regarding other sins, in such cases, the Gemara states that they do not return in repentance. 

To this, our forefather Abraham said before the Holy One, Blessed be He, "Perhaps, God forbid, they have no remedy." The Holy One, Blessed be He, responded to him, "Just as this olive has an end, so too Israel will have an end." The end will be for Israel a good end in the days of the Messiah when there will be an elevation of the crown of the Torah and Israel and complete salvation. Only who knows who will merit it if, God forbid, we are not cast away due to the majority of our sins. May the Holy One, Blessed be He, help us to merit to see complete salvation and the good end that will be for Israel then.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the covenant of circumcision (Brit Milah) and its connection to holiness in the Jewish people. It emphasizes that while the Jewish people may have fulfilled the commandment of circumcision, any blemish or violation of its sanctity can lead to a loss of divine presence and holiness. The text reflects on the challenges of repentance, particularly in the face of complacency and denial of sin, suggesting that true return to God requires recognition of one's failings. Ultimately, it expresses hope for redemption and a positive future for Israel, especially in the Messianic era, despite current spiritual challenges.

passage_content: שובראיתי בפי'הרי"ףבע"יכעי"זובשר קודש יעברו שהיו מושכיםבערלתםעיי"ש, ועכ"פ יוצא לנו מדבריהגמ' הנ"ל קצת בחי' נחמה שהרי טען אאע"ה לפני הקב"ה שמא אם המתנת להם היוחוזריןבתשובה, הרי מבואר דאף על חטא פגם הברית מועיל תשובה, ועודחזינןשהבטיח הקב"הלאאע"השיהיו אחריתן של ישראל טובה לימות המשיח, ע"י שיעשו כל ישראל תשובה שלימה ויתוקן פגם החטא, וכמ"ש הרמב"ם ז"ל שלפני ביאת המשיח יבוא אלי' להחזיר כל ישראל בתשובה כמ"ש והשיב לב אבות על בנים ולב בנים עלאבותם, ומפורשבפדר"א(פרק מ"ג) דאין ישראל נגאלים אלא בתשובה עיי"ש, אמנם צריך להתחיל מיד ולעשות איזה בחי' של תשובה כפי יכולתנו, והתשובה האמיתית בשלימות יעשו ישראל לימות המשיח שיערה ה' עליהם רוח טהרה וקדושה, והתשובה של עכשיו ה"הבבחי' הכנה והכשר שנזכה על ידה להגיע לתשובה שלימה לימות המשיח בב"א.
translation: I have seen again in the words of the Rif, may his merit protect us, and in the holy writings that they were drawing upon their foreskin, as mentioned there. Nevertheless, we derive from the words of the aforementioned Gemara a certain aspect of comfort, for he, our forefather Abraham, argued before the Holy One, Blessed be He, perhaps if You wait for them, they will return in repentance. It is clear that even for the sin of the breach of the covenant, repentance is effective. Furthermore, we see that the Holy One, Blessed be He, promised our forefather Abraham that the descendants of Israel will have goodness in the days of the Messiah, through the fact that all of Israel will do complete repentance and the flaw of the sin will be rectified. As the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, wrote that before the coming of the Messiah, Elijah will come to return all of Israel in repentance, as it is written, "and he will turn the hearts of the fathers to the children and the hearts of the children to their fathers." It is explicitly stated in Pirkei DeRabbi Eliezer (Chapter 43) that Israel will not be redeemed except through repentance, as mentioned there. However, one must begin immediately and perform some aspect of repentance according to our ability, and the true repentance in completeness will be done by Israel in the days of the Messiah, when the Lord will pour upon them a spirit of purity and holiness. The repentance of now is indeed a preparatory stage and a means by which we will merit to reach complete repentance in the days of the Messiah, may it be soon.
summary: הקטע מדגיש את חשיבות התשובה כדרך לתקן את חטא פגם הברית, ומבצע חיבור בין התשובה של היום לבין הגאולה העתידית. הוא מציין שהקב"ה הבטיח לאברהם אבינו שעם ישראל יחזור בתשובה שלמה לפני ביאת המשיח, וכי התשובה הנוכחית היא הכנה לתשובה המושלמת שתתרחש אז. כמו כן, יש להדגיש את הצורך להתחיל בתשובה מיד, בהתאם ליכולתנו, כדי לזכות לרוח טהרה וקדושה שתוביל לגאולה.

passage_content: וז"פדברי המדרש הנ"ל דלפי שנצטער על קושי השעבוד וכאב לו מאוד צערן של ישראל ולזהאמר למההרעותהוגו', ניחם אותו הקב"ה במה שניחם את אאע"ה בשעת חורבןביהמ"ק, מה זית זה אחריתו בסופו ע"י כתישה,ועד"זהשיבלמרע"ההי' לך לידע טוב אחרית דבר מראשיתו, שהאחרית של ישראל יהי' טוב ע"י ראשיתן במצרים שיחזרו בתשובה ע"ייסוריהגלות, ע"כ תראה את האחרית שלהם ולא תצטער על מצבם של עכשיושהכלהוא לתועלתם וטובתם.
translation: And according to the words of the aforementioned Midrash, since he was distressed by the difficulty of the servitude and greatly pained by the suffering of Israel, he said, "Why have You done evil to Your people?" The Holy One, blessed be He, comforted him as He comforted our forefather Abraham at the time of the destruction of the Holy Temple. Just as this olive, its end is through crushing, so too you should know that the end of a matter is known from its beginning. The end of Israel will be good through their beginning in Egypt, as they will return in repentance through the sufferings of the exile. Therefore, you will see their end and not mourn for their current state, for all of it is for their benefit and goodness.
summary: The passage discusses the suffering of the Jewish people during their enslavement in Egypt and God's reassurance to Moses by drawing a parallel to the comfort given to Abraham during the destruction of the Temple. It emphasizes that just as the olive, which is crushed, ultimately yields oil, the hardships faced by the Israelites will lead to their eventual redemption and spiritual return through repentance. The text highlights the importance of recognizing the ultimate good that will arise from current suffering, suggesting that the end result for Israel will be positive despite present difficulties.

passage_content: ולבארהעניןאיך נשתנה בחינתם של ישראל כ"כ בזמן קצר,דמתחלהכתיב ויאמן העם וגו' ואח"כ ולא שמעו אל משה עיין לעיל קושיא ג')דהנההבטיחנוהבוי"תבתוה"ק שע"י קיום התורה ומצות יבואו עלינו השפעות טובות וברכות, וע"י מעשה העבירות יגיעו עונשין על שונאי ישראל והרמב"ןהק' כתב (סוף פ' בא) דמי שאינו מאמין בזה אין לו חלק בתורת משה, אמנםהיצה"רמסמא עיני האדם ומראה פנים להיפך שדרך הרשעים צלחה והצדיקים הם בעינוי ובעוני, ומצינו בירמי' הנביא (ירמי' מ"ד י"ח) שהוכיח את ישראל על שעבדו ע"ז השיבו לו נשים הארורות מעת חדלנו לקטר למלכת השמים וגו' חסרנו כל, וירמי' הנביא הוכיחםדמפנישעבדו ע"ז חסרו את כל וטעותם נמשך ע"י סמיותעיניםשלכחהיצה"ר, עד שנדמה להם כאלו בחנו בחוששהע"זהביאה להם השפעות טובות, ומעת שחדלו לקטר למלכת שמים חסרו כל,ובעוה"רבדורינוהנסיונותגדולים מאודשרואיןדרך רשעים צלחה בחנוהאלקיםוימלטוועי"זמאשרים זדים ומשבחים מינים ואפיקורסים.
translation: And to explain the matter of how the state of Israel changed so much in such a short time, for at first it is written, "And the people believed" etc., and afterwards, "But they did not listen to Moses" (see above question 3). Behold, we have been promised in the Holy Torah that through the observance of the Torah and commandments, good influences and blessings will come upon us, and through the transgressions, punishments will come upon the enemies of Israel. And the holy Ramban wrote (at the end of Parashat Bo) that one who does not believe in this has no part in the Torah of Moses. However, the evil inclination blinds a person’s eyes and shows a face to the contrary, that the way of the wicked is prosperous and the righteous are in suffering and poverty. And we find in the prophet Jeremiah (Jeremiah 44:18) that he rebuked Israel for serving idols, and the cursed women responded to him, "Since we ceased to offer to the queen of heaven, we have lacked everything." And the prophet Jeremiah rebuked them that because they served idols, they lacked everything, and their error was prolonged by the blindness of their eyes caused by the evil inclination, until it seemed to them as if they had tested with their senses that this idolatry brought them good influences, and since they ceased to offer to the queen of heaven, they lacked everything. And in our generation, we see very great trials, that the way of the wicked is prosperous, and they are emboldened, and through this, the wicked are made secure and the heretics and apostates are praised.
summary: The passage discusses the rapid change in the spiritual state of the Jewish people, highlighting their initial faith followed by a lack of belief in Moses. It emphasizes the promise of divine blessings through the observance of Torah and commandments, contrasting this with the consequences of sin, which lead to suffering. The text illustrates how the evil inclination can blind individuals to the truth, causing them to mistakenly perceive that the wicked prosper while the righteous suffer. Ultimately, it warns against the dangers of idolatry and the misinterpretation of divine justice in times of trial.

passage_content: ועד"זיתבארלענינינודבבשורההראשונה כתיב ויאמן העם וישמעו וגו' שמשה ואהרן בגודל קדושתם השפיעו עליהם בחי' קדושה ופרשו עצמם מדרכי ע"ז, ועכ"פ נתעלה בחינתם במקצת אף שלא הי' עדיין בשלימות, והאמינו לשלוחי ה' בשורת הגאולה, אמנם כאשר ראושנתוסףקושי השעבוד עליהם אחר שבאו משה ואהרן אל פרעה, ורשעי ישראל דרכם צלחה וחשובים בעיני המצריים, ורק אותן ששמעו לקולמרע"הוהלכו בדרכיונתוסףצרתם, ע"כ מאז נתגדל אצלם בחי'הנסיוןונחלשכחהאמונה וע"כ לא שמעו אל משה, והטעם מפני קוצר רוח ועבודה קשה לפי שנתגדל השעבודונתוסףצרתם מאז באו משה ואהרן לפרעה, ולא יקשה עודקושיתהמכילתא (עי' קושיא ב') וכי יש לך אדם שמתבשר בשורה ואינו שמח, דהרי ראו היפך הבשורה שמאז הכביד עולו עליהם יותר, והשעבוד הי' סיבה שלא שמעו למשה, ובזה יובן שהפשט והדרש הא בהא תליין, שע"כ הי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז, מחמת העבודה הקשה שהכביד פרעה עליהם,ועי"זנתגדל אצלם בחי'הנסיוןונחלשכחהאמונה ולא רצו עוד לשמוע לדברי תוכחתו, כי חשבו שהוא גרם להם קושי השעבוד.
translation: And similarly, it is explained regarding the matter of the first announcement, it is written, "And the people believed and they heard," etc. Moses and Aaron, in the greatness of their holiness, influenced them with a level of holiness and distanced themselves from the ways of idolatry. Nevertheless, their level was elevated somewhat, even though it was not yet complete, and they believed in the messengers of Hashem regarding the tidings of redemption. However, when the difficulty of the servitude increased upon them after Moses and Aaron came to Pharaoh, and the wicked among Israel prospered and were esteemed in the eyes of the Egyptians, and only those who listened to the voice of Moses and followed his ways had their troubles increased, therefore, from then on, the aspect of trial grew among them, and their faith weakened. Thus, they did not listen to Moses, and the reason was due to shortness of spirit and hard labor, for the servitude had intensified and their troubles increased since Moses and Aaron came to Pharaoh. And it will not be difficult to answer the question of the Mechilta (see question 2), "Is there a person who receives good news and is not happy?" For they saw the opposite of the tidings, since from then on, his yoke became heavier upon them, and the servitude was the reason they did not listen to Moses. In this, it is understood that the simple meaning and the deeper meaning are interconnected, for it was difficult for them to distance themselves from idolatry because of the hard labor that Pharaoh imposed upon them, and through this, the aspect of trial grew among them, and their faith weakened, and they no longer wanted to listen to his words of rebuke, for they thought he was the cause of their difficulty in servitude.
summary: In this passage, the author discusses the initial faith of the Israelites in Moses and Aaron, who inspired them with holiness and a belief in redemption despite their incomplete spiritual state. However, as the burdens of slavery intensified after Moses and Aaron approached Pharaoh, the people's faith weakened due to their suffering and the allure of the oppressors. This struggle illustrates the profound challenge of maintaining faith in the face of adversity, highlighting the interplay between spiritual aspiration and the harsh realities of life, which can lead to a decline in belief and a reluctance to heed prophetic guidance.

passage_content: ואפ"לעוד מדוע בבשורה ראשונה כתיב ויאמן העם וישמעו וגו', ובבשורה השני' ולא שמעו אל משהדהנההבדל גדול יש בין אופן ב' הבשורות,דבבשורההראשונה (בפ' שמות) כתיב לך ואספת את זקני ישראל ואמרת אליהם וגו' אעלה אתכם מעני מצרים אל ארץ הכנעני וגו' אל ארץ זבת חלב ודבש, חשבו ישראל שיצאו ממצרים וירשו את הארץ בליעכובושהי' כלל, ע"כ ויאמן העם וישמעו וגו' ויקדו וישתחוו ושמחו על בשורה הטובה, אמנם בבשורה זו השני' הטיל תנאי בדבר, גם הודיעם שיהי' ישועתם בהדרגה עד שיתעלוממדריגהלמדריגהויהיו ראויים לירושת הארץ, וזה אומרו והוצאתי אתכם מתחת סבלות מצרים והצלתי אתכם מעבודתם שיפסק מעליהם עול שעבודם של מצריםואח"זוגאלתי אתכם וגו', ולקחתי אתכם לו לעם במתן תורה, וידעתם כי אני ה'אלקיכםהמוציא אתכם וגו' שע"י קבלת התורה נתאמת לישראל שהקב"ה הוא המוציא אתכםמאמ"צ, וכמ"ש רז"ל (ברכות ל"ח ע"א) כדמפיקנאלכועבידנאלכו מילתא כיהיכאדידעיתודאנאהואדאפיקתיתכון ממצרים וזהו מתן תורה, ואחר כל זה והבאתי אתכם אל הארץ וגו', והרי זה תנאי באופן הבשורה, שלא יזכו לירושת הארץ כ"א אחר מתן תורה, ועוד תנאי וידעתם כי אני ה' המוציא אתכם וגו' הגם שידעו והאמינו במציאותהבוית"שגם במצרים, אבל ידיעה ברורה לא נתוודע להם עדמ"ת, כמ"ש הרמב"ם ז"ל (בפ"חמה'יסוה"ת) שבמתן תורה נתאמת להםלישראל אמיתת נביאתו שלמשרע"ה, ושכל האותות שעשה היו מפי ה' ובשליחותו עיי"ש.
translation: And furthermore, why in the first announcement it is written, "And the people believed and they heard," etc., while in the second announcement it is written, "And they did not listen to Moses"? There is a great difference between the two ways of the announcements. In the first announcement (in Parashat Shemot), it is written, "And you shall gather the elders of Israel and say to them," etc., "I will bring you up from the affliction of Egypt to the land of the Canaanite," etc., "to a land flowing with milk and honey." The Israelites thought that they would leave Egypt and inherit the land without any delay whatsoever. Therefore, "And the people believed and they heard," etc., and they bowed down and worshipped and rejoiced over the good tidings. However, in this second announcement, a condition was placed upon the matter; it was also made known to them that their salvation would be gradual, until they would ascend from level to level and become worthy of inheriting the land. This is indicated by the phrase, "And I will bring you out from under the burdens of Egypt and I will save you from their work," that the yoke of their servitude would be lifted from them. And afterwards, "And I will take you to Me as a people" at the giving of the Torah, "and you shall know that I am the Lord your God who brings you out," etc. Through the acceptance of the Torah, it was confirmed to Israel that the Holy One, Blessed be He, is the One who brings you out from Egypt, as our Sages of blessed memory said (Berakhot 38a), "As we go out, we go out with a word, for when they knew that He is the One who brought them out from Egypt, this is the giving of the Torah." And after all this, "And I brought you to the land," etc., and this is a condition in the manner of the announcement, that they would not merit to inherit the land except after the giving of the Torah. Moreover, there is another condition: "And you shall know that I am the Lord who brings you out," etc. Even though they knew and believed in His existence, blessed be He, even in Egypt, a clear knowledge was not revealed to them until the giving of the Torah, as the Rambam of blessed memory wrote (in the eighth chapter of the laws of the Torah), that at the giving of the Torah, the truth of the prophecy of Moshe Rabbeinu was confirmed to Israel, and that all the signs he performed were by the mouth of the Lord and by His agency, as stated there.
summary: The passage discusses the difference between two messages delivered to the Israelites regarding their redemption from Egypt. In the first message, the people believe and rejoice in the promise of immediate liberation and inheritance of the land, while the second message introduces conditions, emphasizing that their salvation will occur gradually and contingent upon their acceptance of the Torah. This highlights the theological concept that true understanding of God's presence and authority is only fully realized through the giving of the Torah, which confirms the authenticity of Moses' prophecy and the divine nature of their redemption. Ultimately, the Israelites' entitlement to the Promised Land is linked to their commitment to the covenant established at Sinai.

passage_content: ולכןולא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה, לפי שהי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז כדרשת חז"ל, ע"כ השיגו כי לא יזכו לירושת הארץבבחי'המדריגהשעומדים בה, אבל יצטרכו לזיכוך אחר זיכוך ולפרוש מטומאת מצרים לגמרי עד שיזכו לקבלת התורה וידיעתהבוי"תואמיתותו, ולכן לא קבלו בשורה זו השני' בשמחה כמו הראשונה, כינתעצבומהשגת ידיעה זו שלא יגיעו לירושת הארץ בניקל ובמהירות כמו שחשבובתחלה, ואולי הטעם שלאהודיעםהבוי"תזאת בבשורה ראשונה,אפ"לעפימ"שהרמב"ם ז"ל (בסוף ה' תשובה ה"ה)כשמלמדיןאת הקטנים ועמי הארץ, איןמלמדיןאותן אלא לעבוד מיראה וכדי לקבל שכר, עד שתרבה דעתן ויעבדוהו מאהבה עכ"לוכעי"זכתב בס' הישר המיוחסלר"תז"ל דאםרוציןלקרב בנ"א אל הקדושה ירגילוהו לפי דעתו והשגתו במצות קלות שיקל עולם עליהם לקבלו, ואח"כ מעט מעט יותר עד שיתקרב ויקבל עליו אף החמורות עכת"ד,ועד"זלענינינולפי שהיו ישראל משוקעים בטומאת מצרים מאוד, ע"כבתחלתהתקרבותם הודיעםהבוי"תהקלות ואח"כ החמורות, ולפי פשוטו מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה שלא יכלו לסבול קושי השעבוד שהכביד פרעה עולו עליהם, כמו שפי' בת"אמפולחנאדהוה קשיעליהוןוה"זנתינת טעם למה שלא שמעו אל משה,דהי' תשוקתם וציפויםלהגאלמיד כאשר נתבשרו בבשורה הראשונה, וע"כנתעצבוכאשר שמעו בבשורה השני' כי עוד יתארכו הימים ולא יצאו ממצרים מיד, ולא יזכו לירושת הארץ כ"א אחר שיתקיים התנאי כנ"ל.
translation: And they did not listen to Moses because of shortness of spirit and hard work, for it was difficult for them to separate from idolatry, as the Sages have taught. Therefore, they realized that they would not merit the inheritance of the land at the level of the spiritual state they were in, but would need further purification and to completely separate from the impurity of Egypt until they would merit receiving the Torah and knowing its truth. Therefore, they did not accept this second message with joy like the first, as they were saddened by the realization that they would not reach the inheritance of the land easily and quickly as they had initially thought. And perhaps the reason that the Holy One Blessed Be He did not inform them of this in the first message, even though the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, teaches (at the end of Hilchot Teshuvah, Halacha 5) that when teaching children and the common people, one should teach them only to serve out of fear and to receive reward, until their understanding increases and they serve Him out of love. Thus, it is written in the Sefer HaYashar attributed to Rabbi Tzaddok, that if one wishes to draw people closer to holiness, one should accustom them according to their understanding and comprehension with lighter commandments that will be easier for them to accept, and then gradually more until they come closer and accept even the heavier ones. And so, regarding our matter, since the Israelites were very immersed in the impurity of Egypt, therefore at the beginning of their approach, the Holy One Blessed Be He informed them of the lighter commandments and afterwards the heavier ones. And according to the simple meaning, due to shortness of spirit and hard work, they could not bear the difficulty of the servitude that Pharaoh had imposed upon them, as it is explained in the Talmud. And this gives reason for why they did not listen to Moses, for their desire and hope was to be redeemed immediately when they were informed in the first message. Therefore, they were saddened when they heard in the second message that the days would still be prolonged and they would not leave Egypt immediately, and they would not merit the inheritance of the land until the condition mentioned above was fulfilled.
summary: The passage discusses the Israelites' struggle to accept Moses' message due to their deep entrenchment in the impurities of Egypt and the burdens of slavery. Their initial joy at the promise of redemption turned to sadness upon realizing that they would not inherit the land immediately, as they needed to undergo further purification and spiritual elevation. This reflects the Hasidic teaching that spiritual growth often requires gradual steps, starting with easier commandments before progressing to more challenging ones, emphasizing the importance of patience and gradual ascent in one's relationship with the Divine. Ultimately, the delay in redemption serves as a necessary process for the Israelites to fully prepare for receiving the Torah and its truths.

passage_content: ומצינובנבואתישעי' (כ"ח ט"ז) כשהתנבא על הגאולה אמר המאמין לא יחיש, שמאמין האמיתי לאימהרנהאלא ימתין ויצפה שבא יבוא בזמנו הראוי, אולם לא היו ישראל עדיין במעלה השלימות קודם מתן תורה, ורצו שיהי' היציאה מיד ע"כ לא רצו לשמוע ולקבל בשורה השני', ובאמת שאפי' רגע אחת קודם הזמן אסור לצאת מן הגלות, ובלילה האחרונה הזהיר אותם הקב"ה אל יצא איש מפתח ביתו עד בוקר, ואחר שהיו כבר בא"י באותה הלילה, כמ"ש בתרגוםיוב"עשהעננים הוליכו אותם למקום המקדש, מ"מ החזירום למצרים כדי להשלים זמן הגלות עד רגע האחרונה, אבל הי' קשה להם לסבול עוד עול הגליות,שמתחלתהפקידה עד היציאה הי' כמעט שנה שלימה, והם רצו לצאת מיד ע"י גודל הצרות שסבלו שם, ע"כ לא קשהקושיתהמכילתא וכי יש לך אדם שמתבשר בשורה ואינו שמח,דאדרבהרצו שיתקיים מיד ועדיין לא הי' זמנו, וזה הי'החסרוןשרצו אותו קודם הזמן. וע"כ אמרמרע"ההןבנ"ילא שמעו אלי ואיך ישמעני פרעה, שע"י שישראלדוחקיןאת הקץ לפני הזמן.עי"זנתוסףכחלפרעה שלא ישמע אלי לשחרר את ישראל,דאפי' רגע אחת אםממהריןלדחוק את הקץ מעכב ח"ו גאולתם של ישראל, וכמושרואיןבעוה"רבדורינואלה שנתעכב הגאולה ע"יסט"אזו של דחיקת קץ הגאולה,וז"שהןבנ"ילא שמעו אליועי"זלא ישמע אלי פרעה.
translation: And in the prophecy of Isaiah (28:16), when he prophesied about the redemption, he said, "The believer will not hasten," for the true believer does not rush but rather waits and anticipates that it will come at the appropriate time. However, the Israelites were not yet at the level of perfection before the giving of the Torah, and they wanted the redemption to happen immediately; therefore, they did not want to hear and accept the second message. In truth, even a moment before the time, it is forbidden to leave the exile, and on that last night, the Holy One, blessed be He, warned them not to let any man leave his house until morning. And after they were already in the Land of Israel that night, as it is said in the Targum, "The clouds led them to the place of the Temple," nevertheless, He brought them back to Egypt to complete the time of the exile until the last moment. But it was difficult for them to bear the yoke of the exiles any longer, for from the time of the decree until the departure was almost a full year, and they wanted to leave immediately due to the great troubles they suffered there. Therefore, it is not difficult to ask the question of the Mekilta: Is there a person who receives good news and is not happy? On the contrary, they wanted it to be fulfilled immediately, and yet it was not yet their time, and this was the shortcoming that they desired it before the time. And therefore, Moses said, "Behold, the children of Israel did not listen to me, and how will Pharaoh listen to me?" because the Israelites were pushing the end before the time. Through this, it was added to Pharaoh that he would not listen to me to free the Israelites, for even a moment if they hasten to push the end, it delays, Heaven forbid, the redemption of Israel. And as we see in our generation, the redemption has been delayed due to this matter of hastening the end of the redemption, and this is why "the children of Israel did not listen to me, and therefore Pharaoh will not listen to me."
summary: The passage discusses the concept of waiting for redemption at the appropriate time, emphasizing that true faith involves patience and trust in God's timing. It highlights that the Israelites, prior to receiving the Torah, were not yet spiritually ready for immediate redemption and struggled with the prolonged suffering of exile. The text illustrates that hastening the redemption can lead to setbacks, as seen in the relationship between Moses and Pharaoh, where the Israelites' impatience delayed their liberation. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of aligning one's expectations with divine timing to facilitate genuine redemption.

passage_content: ובזהיתיישבבמאמה"כוידבר ה' אל משהלאמרבא דבר אל פרעה וגו' וישלח אתבנ"ימארצו,דמלתלאמרמיותר (עיין לעיל קושיא ה')דלמייאמר אם לפרעה הרי כבר הזהירו בא דבר אל פרעה, ולדרכינואפ"להכוונהשצוהוהקב"הלאמרלישראל ולהזהירם על ככה, שא"א שיצאו מהגלות על דעת עצמם כ"א ע"ימשרע"השהוא מוכן לשליחות זו לגאול את ישראל, וז"אלאמרבא דבר אל פרעה וגו' וישלח אתבנ"ימארצו, ללמדם על כךשמשרע"היהי' המדבר ועל ידו יצאו ישראל ממצרים ורק בזמנו הראוי ולא קודם לכך, ובזה יובן קישורמאמה"כויצום אל בני ישראל ואל פרעה מלך מצריםפירש"יצום לחלוק לו כבוד. וטעם הציווי לפי שלא שמעו אל משהונתעצבומאיחור זמן הגאולה, ע"כ הזהירם שלא ימרדו בפרעה ולא ירצו לצאת לפני זמנו, אלא ינהגו בו כבוד כל זמן שלא נתמלא קיצם להיגאלועי"זיוכל להוציא אתבנ"ימאמ"צ,משא"כבאם ח"ו ידחקו את הקץ יתארך גלותם עוד, כמ"ש הרמב"ןדבעוןבני אפרים שיצאו קודם זמנם נתארך גלותם של ישראל עוד שלשים שנה עיי"ש.
translation: And in this, it is established that the Holy One, Blessed be He, spoke to Moses saying, "Speak to Pharaoh," etc., and He sent His sons to their land. The phrase "saying" is superfluous (see above the question 5) because if it is for Pharaoh, he has already been warned with "Speak to Pharaoh." And according to our way, it is to direct that the Holy One, Blessed be He, commanded to say to Israel and to warn them about this, that it is impossible for them to leave the exile on their own accord except through Moses, who is prepared for this mission to redeem Israel. And this is the meaning of "saying" to speak to Pharaoh, etc., and He sent His sons to their land, to teach them that Moses was the one who spoke, and through him Israel would leave Egypt, and only at the appropriate time, not before that. And in this, the connection is understood from the verse "And He commanded the children of Israel and Pharaoh, king of Egypt," explaining that "He commanded to honor him." And the reason for the command is that they did not listen to Moses and were saddened by the delay of the redemption. Therefore, He warned them not to rebel against Pharaoh and not to wish to leave before their time, but to treat him with honor as long as their time for redemption had not yet been fulfilled. And thus, he would be able to bring His sons out of Egypt, for if, Heaven forbid, they would hasten the end, their exile would be prolonged even more, as the Ramban writes that because of the sin of the children of Ephraim who left before their time, the exile of Israel was prolonged by another thirty years, as stated there.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of divine timing in the redemption of the Jewish people from Egypt, highlighting that they cannot escape slavery on their own accord but must do so through Moses, who is divinely appointed for this mission. It teaches that the Israelites are instructed to show respect to Pharaoh until the appointed time for their liberation arrives, as premature attempts to leave could lead to prolonged exile. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of aligning human actions with divine will and the significance of patience in the face of suffering. The text warns against the dangers of rushing the redemption process, as illustrated by the historical example of the Ephraimites, whose premature exodus resulted in extended suffering for the entire nation.

passage_content: ונבואלבאר הדקדוקים הנ"לבעניןהצפרדעים (עיין לעיל קושיא ז' ח')דהנהיש עוד שינוי בפסוקיםדבדברימשה אל פרעה נאמר וסרו הצפרדעים ממך וגו' רק ביאור תשארנה, ואח"כ כתיב ויעש ה' כדבר משה וימותו הצפרדעים וגו', ולכאורה אין זה כדברימשרע"הבשליחות ה' וסרו הצפרדעים ממך רק ביאור תשארנה ולא אמר וימותו או ויכרתו, ויתבאר בהקדם דבריהגמ' (פסחים נ"ג ע"ב) מה ראו חנני'מישאלועזרי' שמסרו עצמן על קדושת השם לתוך כבשן האש, נשאו ק"ו בעצמם מצפרדעים, ומה צפרדעים שאיןמצוויןעל קדושת השם, כתיב בהו ועלו ובאו בביתך וגו' ובתנוריך ובמשארותיך, אימתי משארת מצוי' אצל התנור בשעה שהתנור חם, אנושמצוויןעלקה"שעאכו"כ, וכתבוהתוס' פי' הקונטרס מה ראו שלא דרשו וחי בהם ולא שימות בהם, וקשהדהאבפרהסיאהוהומסקינןבסנהדרין (דף ע"ד ע"א)דלכו"עבפרהסיאחייב למסור עצמו אפילו על מצוה קלהוכו',ור"ימפרש מה ראו שלא ברחו, שהרי קודם המעשה היו יכולים לברוח כמו שעשה דניאלכדאמרבחלק (סנהדרין צ"ג ע"א) ג' היו באותה עצה עכ"דהתוס'.
translation:
And we will elaborate on the aforementioned nuances regarding the frogs (see above, question 7, section 8) that behold, there is another change in the verses. Concerning what was said by Moshe to Pharaoh, "And the frogs shall depart from you," etc., it only states, "And the rest shall remain," and afterwards it is written, "And the Lord did according to the word of Moshe, and the frogs died," etc. At first glance, this is not in accordance with what Moshe said in the name of the Lord, "And the frogs shall depart from you," only "the rest shall remain," and he did not say "and they shall die" or "and they shall be cut off." 

It will be explained by first bringing the words of the Gemara (Pesachim 53b), "What did Chananiah, Mishael, and Azariah see that they gave themselves over for the sanctification of the Name into the fiery furnace? They reasoned a fortiori for themselves from the frogs. And what frogs, which are not commanded regarding the sanctification of the Name, it is written about them, 'And they went and came into your house,' etc., 'and into your ovens and into your kneading troughs.' When is the kneading trough found near the oven? When the oven is hot. Humans are commanded regarding the sanctification of the Name, how much more so!" 

And the Tosafot wrote, the explanation of the pamphlet, "What did they see that they did not demand 'and you shall live by them' and not 'you shall die by them'?" And it is difficult, for we have concluded in Sanhedrin (Daf 74a) that all agree that in public matters one is obligated to give oneself over even for a light commandment, etc. And Rashi explains, "What did they see that they did not flee?" For before the act, they could have fled, as Daniel did, as it is said in the section (Sanhedrin 93a), "There were three in that counsel," etc., thus the Tosafot.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction in the biblical account of the frogs' plague, highlighting the difference between Moses' command to Pharaoh and the subsequent divine action. It draws a parallel between the frogs, which are not commanded to sanctify God's name, and the bravery of Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah, who willingly faced death for their faith. The text emphasizes the concept of self-sacrifice for the sanctification of God's name, suggesting that even creatures like frogs, which are not obligated to do so, demonstrate a form of obedience. This leads to a deeper understanding of the expectations placed upon humans regarding their commitment to faith and divine commandments.

passage_content: ובשו"תשבות יעקב (חלק ב' תשובה ק"ו) שאלה בעיר אחת גזרו עליהם העברת הדת ר"ל באופן שעפ"ידינאיהרגואל יעבור, ומקצתם יכולים לברוח אימחוייביןלברוח כדי להציל את נפשם, דלא יהיו כמאבדא"עלדעת, אונימאדלא יפרשו מן הציבורומחוייביםלמסור נפשם עלקה"ש, והביא ראי' מדבריהתוס' אלו שיותר טוב למסור נפשו להריגה,דכמושחמ"ויכלו לברוחואעפי"כמסרו נפשם עלקה"ש, ואח"כ הביא ראיות הרבהדהיכאדאפשרלקיים וחי בהם וגם שלא לעבור על מצות ה' ב"ה, עדיף יותר דאז מקיים שניהם, אבללפי"זיקשה על פי'הר"ישהיויכוליןחמ"ולברוח ומדוע לא ברחו לקיים שניהם, ותירץ שם וז"ל: וכדי לתרץ דעת ר"יבלא"הצריכיןאנו לפרש דבריו, דלפי פשוטו מה ק"ו הוא זה,דשאניצפרדעים שנגזר עליהם בגזירת השם שיבואו באש,משא"כחמ"ושלא נצטוו על כך. כיון שאפשר להם לברוח, אלא צ"לדס"ללר"ישגםחמ"ונצטוו על כך,כדאיתאבסוטה (דף י' ע"ב)שיצתהב"קואמרה אתה הצלת תמר ושני בני' מן האש, חייך שאני מציל שלשה בניך מן האש מאןנינהוחמ"ו, לכך לא ברחולהמלטעל נפשם, ואין למדין מהם למקום אחר,דוודאיגדול הצלת נפשות אם יכוליםלברוח עכ"ל, ותירוצו צ"ב דאין הכרח מזהשמחוייביןלהפיל עצמם לכבשן האש,דאולימה שהבטיח הקב"ה ליהודה שיציל את בניו מן האש הי' על תנאי, וכמושאמרז"לבגמרא (ע"ז דף ה' ע"א)למימראדאי לא חטאו לא הוומייתיוהכתיב פרשת יבמות ופרשות נחלות, ותירצו על תנאי, א"כ גם כאןאפ"לשהבטיח השי"ת שאם ימסרו עצמם למיתה ינצלו, אבל אינו מוכרח שנצטוו בזה למסור נפשם למיתה, ותו דאם היו מצוויםמהשי"תא"כ הדראקושיתהתוס'לדוכתי' על מה שפי'רשיז"למה ראו שלא דרשו וחי בהם ולא שימות בהם, הרי היומחוייביםלמסור נפשם מצד ציווי הקב"ה אליהם בפרטיות,
translation: In the responsa of Shevet Yaakov (Part 2, Responsum 106), a question arose in a certain city where they decreed upon them the transfer of the religion, God forbid, in a manner that according to their law, one would be obligated to transgress, and some of them could escape; they are obligated to flee in order to save their lives, so that they would not be like those who lose their lives on account of their beliefs, and they are indeed obligated to give their lives for the sanctification of the Name. He brought proof from the words of the Tosafot that it is better to give one's life to be killed, for as it is written, "and they could flee," and nevertheless, they gave their lives for the sanctification of the Name. Afterwards, he brought many proofs that where it is possible to uphold "and you shall live by them" and also not to transgress the commandments of the Holy One, blessed be He, it is preferable to do so, for then one fulfills both. However, according to this, he questioned the explanation of the Rosh, that they could flee, and why did they not flee to fulfill both. He answered there, and I quote: "And to explain the opinion of the Rosh, we need to interpret his words, for according to the simple meaning, what kind of a fortiori is this, that since they were decreed upon by the decree of the Name to come into the fire, unlike those who were not commanded regarding this. Since it is possible for them to flee, it must be that the Rosh holds that they were also commanded regarding this, as it is stated in the Sota (Daf 10b) that she went out and said, 'You saved Tamar and her two sons from the fire; by your life, I will save your three sons from the fire.' Who is the one who argues with this? Therefore, they did not flee to save their lives, and one cannot learn from them to another place, for there is a great obligation to save lives if they can flee." Thus far his words. His answer is difficult, for it is not necessary to conclude from this that they are obligated to throw themselves into the furnace, for perhaps the promise that the Holy One, blessed be He, made to Yehuda to save his sons from the fire was conditional, as it is stated by our Sages in the Gemara (Avodah Zarah 5a) that if they did not sin, they would not be delivered, as it is written in the sections of Yevamot and the sections of inheritances, and they answered that it was conditional. Therefore, here too, one could say that the Holy One, blessed be He, promised that if they would give themselves to death, they would be saved, but it is not necessary that they were commanded regarding this to give their lives for death. Furthermore, if they were commanded by the Holy One, blessed be He, then the question returns to the Tosafot regarding what the Rosh explained, why did they not demand "and you shall live by them" and not die by them, for they would be obligated to give their lives based on the command of the Holy One, blessed be He, to them specifically.
summary: In the passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the discussion revolves around the obligation to sacrifice one's life for the sanctification of God's name versus the permissibility of fleeing to save oneself. It highlights the tension between the duty to uphold religious commandments and the instinct for self-preservation, referencing Talmudic sources to illustrate that while some may be commanded to face death, others may be permitted to escape. The text emphasizes the importance of understanding divine commandments and the conditions under which one is obligated to act, suggesting that the preservation of life can sometimes take precedence over martyrdom. Ultimately, it reflects on the complexities of faith, duty, and divine promise in the face of persecution.
