passage_content: אמנםמעיקראל"קקושיתוהראשונה, שהרי הוא עצמו סיים בסוף דבריו אבל מ"מ אם רוצה להחמיר על עצמו ולמסור נפשו לקדש השם ברבים שממנו ילמדו אחרים לעשות זכור לטוב, וודאי לא מקרי מאבד עצמו לדעת עכ"ל, ומביא ראי' מגמ' עיי"ש, וכן כתבוהב"יוד"מז"ל (יו"ד סי' קנ"ז)דחסידויר"ש ורואה שהדור פרוץ בכך רשאי לקדש השם ולמסור עצמו אפי' על מצוה קלה עיי"ש, א"כ אין קושיא עלחמ"ו, דאף אם מצד הדין החיוב לברוח, מ"מ הם ראו שיש צורך לדור שמהם ילמדו לקדשש"שברבים, וע"כ מסרו נפשם עלקה"שאע"פ שלא היומחוייביןעפ"י הדין, אמנםהקושיאשהקשה דלפי פי'הר"יאין כאן ק"ודשאניהצפרדעים שהיו מצווים מפי הקב"ה שיבואו באש,משא"כחמ"ושלא היו מצווים על כך והיו יכולים לברוח עדיין קשה.
translation: Indeed, initially, it is difficult to understand the first question, for he himself concluded at the end of his words. However, if one wishes to be stringent upon himself and to sacrifice his life to sanctify the Name in public, from which others will learn to do so, it is certainly not considered as one who is losing his life intentionally. Thus, he brings a proof from the Gemara, as mentioned there. Similarly, the Beit Yosef writes (Yoreh De'ah, Siman 157) that a pious person who sees that the generation is lax in this matter is permitted to sanctify the Name and to give himself up even for a light commandment, as mentioned there. Therefore, there is no difficulty on the part of the Chassidim, for even if, according to the law, the obligation is to flee, they saw that there was a need for the generation to learn from them to sanctify the Holy Name in public. Thus, they sacrificed their lives for the sanctification of the Name, even though they were not halachically obligated to do so. However, the question that was raised is that according to the explanation of the R'iya, there is no comparison to the frogs that were commanded by the Holy One, Blessed be He, to come into the fire, whereas the Chassidim were not commanded to do so and could have fled. Still, it remains difficult.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of self-sacrifice for the sanctification of God's name, emphasizing that even if one is not legally obligated to do so, the act can serve as a powerful example for others. It references the idea that righteous individuals may choose to endure suffering or even death to inspire others to uphold their faith, particularly in a morally lax generation. The text contrasts this with the biblical frogs, which were commanded to enter the fire, highlighting the distinction between divine command and voluntary sacrifice. Ultimately, it underscores the value of personal commitment to faith and the impact of such actions on the community.

passage_content: ואפ"לדלא קשה מידי, שהרי בוודאי לא נצטוו כל א' מן הצפרדעים בפרטיות, שזה ילך בתנור וזה בחצר וזה בביתוכו', רק הציווי הי' על המין בכללו שילכו באלו המקומות, וגם אותם הצפרדעים שהלכו למקום שאינו סכנה קיימו ג"כ מצותהבוב"ה, נמצא כל א' הי' לו ברירה לילך למקום שאין בוסכנה,ולפי"זלא היו הצפרדעים מצווים למסור נפשםוליכנסלתוך התנור, כמו"כ חנני'מישאלועזרי' הי' בידם לברוח, וגם אז היומקיימיןרצון השי"ת במה שסירבו להשתחוות לצלם, ואעפ"כ מסרו נפשם ולמדו ק"ו מן הצפרדעים, שלא נצטוו על קידוש השם ואעפ"כ מסרו נפשם, אנו שמצווים עלקידה"שעאכו"כ ושפיר הוי ק"ו, ומצינו שקיבלו הצפרדעים שכר על בחירתם הטובה למסור נפשם עלקה"שכמבואר במדרש ילקוט (רמז קפ"ב) ומה פרע להם הקב"ה שכל הצפרדעים מתו ואותן שירדו לתנור לא מתו מפני שמסרו עצמן לשריפה ע"כ, ולכאורה מדוע מתו השאר ולא חזרו ליאור ומה חטאו בזה שלא נכנסו לתנור, והרי במה שהלכו לשאר מקומות קיימו ג"כ רצוןהבוי"תומצינו במכת ארבה שחזרו כולם אל היםדכתיבויהפוך ה' רוח חזק מאודוישאאת הארבה ויתקעהו ימה סוף, וכמו"כ מדוע לא חזרו הצפרדעים, ואפשר דלפי שמנעו עצמם מלקדשש"שע"כ וימותו כולם חוץ מאלו, ומזה למדוחמ"ולמסור עצמם עלקה"ש.
translation: And although it is not too difficult, for certainly not every one of the frogs was commanded individually, that this one should go into the oven, and this one into the courtyard, and this one into your house, rather the command was upon the species as a whole to go into these places, and also those frogs that went to a place that was not dangerous fulfilled their command from the Holy One, Blessed be He. It turns out that each one had the choice to go to a place where there was no danger, and according to this, the frogs were not commanded to give up their lives and enter the oven. Likewise, Chananiah, Mishael, and Azariah had the ability to flee, and even then they were fulfilling the will of the Holy One, Blessed be He, by refusing to bow down to the idol. Nevertheless, they gave up their lives and learned a fortiori from the frogs, who were not commanded on sanctifying the Name, and yet they gave up their lives. We, who are commanded on sanctification of the Name, how much more so, and it is indeed a fortiori. And we find that the frogs received reward for their good choice to give up their lives for the sanctification of the Name, as explained in the Midrash Yalkut (Remez 122). And what did the Holy One, Blessed be He, repay them? That all the frogs died, and those that went into the oven did not die because they gave themselves to the fire. Therefore, at first glance, why did the others die and not return to the Nile, and what sin did they commit by not entering the oven? And behold, in that they went to other places, they also fulfilled the will of the Creator. And we find in the plague of locusts that they all returned to the sea, as it is written, "And the Lord turned a very strong wind and it lifted the locusts and drove them into the Red Sea." Likewise, why did the frogs not return? It is possible that since they prevented themselves from sanctifying the Name, therefore they all died except for those, and from this we learn to give ourselves for the sanctification of the Name.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of free will in the context of the frogs during the plagues of Egypt, emphasizing that they were not individually commanded to enter dangerous places but rather as a species. It draws a parallel to the story of Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah, who chose to sacrifice themselves rather than bow to an idol, highlighting the idea that even without a direct command, the frogs demonstrated self-sacrifice for the sanctification of God's name. The text suggests that the frogs received a reward for their choice, as those who entered the furnace were spared, while others perished for not fully committing to the act of sanctification. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of willingly embracing the call to holiness, even in the face of danger.

passage_content: והנהפליגי רז"ל במדרש (פ' ט' סי' י"ב ובילקוט רמז קפ"ב) כמה זמן שימשה כל מכה. איכא למ"ד שההתראה הי' כ"ד יום והמכה שימשה ז' ימים, ואיכאדס"לשהמכה שימשה כ"ד יום ולכאורה קשה איך אמר משה רבינו לפרעה התפאר עלי למתי אעתיר לך וגו',ממנ"פאם לא נשלמה עדיין זמן המוגבל ומה אם יאמר פרעה שיסורו מיד, ומסתמא הי' צורך בדבר שישמש כל מכה במידה וזמן קצוב בערך מדת עונשם, ואם הי' אחר השלמת הזמן הי' ראוי שיסור מאליו ומיד, אמנם נראהדעלגוף המכה לא שאלמרע"הלמתי אעתיר,דזההי' לו זמן קצובדכלהמכות באו מדה כנגד מדה בחשבוןמדוייקכמבואר כל זה במדרשיחכז"ל, גם פרעה לא הי' בוחר להמתין עד למחר לסבול צרתו יותר מן ההכרח,ועכ"חמוכרח שלא על עצם המכה שאלו משה רבינו, ובזה יובנו שינוי הלשונות שפרעה אמר ויסר הצפרדעים,ומשרע"השאלו למתי אעתיר וגו' להכרית הצפרדעים:דהנהאותם שנשארו בחיים ע"י שנכנסו לתנורים לא יתכן עליהם לשון הכרתה, שהרי חזרו ליאור במקום שהם מתענגים ויוצדק בהם לשון הסרה, ע"כ ניחאדהסרתהצפרדעים רצה פרעה שיהי' מיד, וכבר נשלם ימי שימושה של מכה זו באותה שעה ולא רצה לסבול עוד עד למחר, רק שאלתמשרע"ההיתהעל אותם הצפרדעים שלא נכנסו לתנורים אימתי יכרתו, ולפי שע"יהכרתתםנתגדל כבוד שמים, ונתגלה פעולתם הטוב של אותן שמסרו נפשם עלקה"שונשארו בחיים, ע"כ השיב פרעה למחר כיון שדבר זה מביא כבוד שמים יותר טוב שיתאחר עד למחר,דאלמלינתגלה הכבוד שמים מיד אפשר שהי' מכריח בחירתו להוציא את ישראל, שעדיין הי' לבו נשבר בקרבו מהרגשת המכה,משא"כעד למחר יוכל להיות לו הכבדת הלב, או אפשר שחשב פרעהשההכרתההוא מפאת מערכת השמים, וכשידחה עד למחר לא יתקיים כלל ולא רצה שיתקדשש"שע"י המכות וע"כ ביקש על למחר,ומרע"ההשיב לו שיתקיים למחר כדבריך למען תדע כי אין כה'אלקינוויתקדשש"שעל ידם, ואפשר שע"כ הסכים משה רבינו שיהי' למחר מפני שאז יתגדל כבוד שמים יותר, שיתברר לכל שאינובכחמערכת השמים כ"אמאלקיהיכולת.
translation:
And behold, our sages have elaborated in the Midrash (Parashat Va'era, section 12, and in Yalkut, Remez 182) on how long each plague lasted. There is an opinion that the warning lasted 24 days and the plague lasted 7 days, and there is another opinion that the plague lasted 24 days. At first glance, it is difficult to understand how Moshe Rabbeinu said to Pharaoh, "Boast about me, when shall I pray for you," etc. If the time had not yet been completed, what if Pharaoh were to say that they should be removed immediately? It is certain that there was a need for each plague to last a specific measure of time in relation to the measure of their punishment. If the time had been completed, it would have been appropriate for it to cease on its own and immediately. However, it seems that regarding the essence of the plague, Moshe Rabbeinu did not ask, "When shall I pray," for that would have been a fixed time for all the plagues, which came measure for measure in precise calculation, as is explained in the Midrash. Also, Pharaoh would not choose to wait until tomorrow to suffer his affliction more than necessary. Therefore, it is necessary to understand that Moshe Rabbeinu did not ask about the essence of the plague. 

In this, we can understand the change in language when Pharaoh said, "And the frogs departed," and when Moshe Rabbeinu asked him, "When shall I pray to eradicate the frogs?" For those that remained alive by entering the ovens, it is not fitting to use the term "eradication" regarding them, since they returned to the Nile where they enjoy themselves, and it would be appropriate to use the term "removal." Therefore, Pharaoh wanted the frogs to be removed immediately, and the days of the plague's duration had already been completed at that time, and he did not want to suffer until tomorrow. Rather, Moshe Rabbeinu's question was about those frogs that did not enter the ovens—when would they be eradicated? And since their eradication would increase the honor of Heaven, and the good deeds of those who sacrificed themselves for the Holy One, blessed be He, and remained alive would be revealed, therefore Pharaoh answered, "Tomorrow," because this matter brings more honor to Heaven, it is better that it be delayed until tomorrow. For if the honor of Heaven were to be revealed immediately, it might compel his choice to release Israel, as his heart was still broken from the feeling of the plague. However, until tomorrow, it could be that his heart would be hardened, or perhaps Pharaoh thought that the eradication was due to the celestial system, and when it is delayed until tomorrow, it would not be fulfilled at all, and he did not want it to be sanctified through the plagues. Therefore, he requested for it to be tomorrow. 

And Moshe Rabbeinu responded to him that it would indeed be fulfilled tomorrow, as you have said, so that you may know that there is none like our God, and it will be sanctified through them. And perhaps for this reason, Moshe Rabbeinu agreed that it would be tomorrow, because then the honor of Heaven would be greater, as it would be clarified to all that it is not by the power of the celestial system, but rather by the power of our God.
summary: The passage discusses the timing and significance of the plagues in Egypt, emphasizing that each plague served a specific purpose and duration as a measure of divine justice. It highlights the dialogue between Moses and Pharaoh, illustrating that Pharaoh's request for the removal of the frogs was not merely about alleviating suffering but also about the potential for greater sanctification of God's name. The text suggests that delaying the removal of the plagues could enhance the glory of God, as it would demonstrate His sovereignty over nature and the heavens, ultimately reinforcing the idea that divine intervention is not bound by natural laws. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the interplay between divine providence and human choice, showcasing the importance of timing in the unfolding of God's plan.

passage_content: מכלהעניןהזה יש לנו ללמוד עד היכן צריך האדם למסור נפשו בשביל כבוד שמים, ובירושלמי דרשו עה"פ עת לעשות לה' הפרו תורתך,דבדורשל מפירי תורה עת לעשות לה', וכל דבר שאפשר לעשות עבור כבוד שמים וכבוד התורה וכבוד הצדיקים, ולהגדילכחהאמונה ודרך הקדושהמחוייביםלעשות במסירת נפש ממש, ובמקום שאין אנשים השתדל להיות איש, ולא לסמוך על אחרים שיעשו,וה"זנלמודמהצפרדעים שלא סמכו על האחרים שיקיימו ציווי השי"ת למסור עצמם למיתה והם ילכו במקומות שאין בו סכנה, ומהם למדוחמ"וק"ו למסור עצמם עלקה"ש, ונזכה שיתקדשש"שעל ידינו ולמסור את נפשינו בשביל כבוד שמו יתברך וזה יהי' תיקון גמור על כל חטאינו, כמ"שבספה"קדברי חיים (פ' נח)וזל"ק: והנה ידועדעלהכלמועיל תשובה ועל חטא זה של מ"ז אינומועיל תשובה כאשר חכמים הגידו בספריהם, אך הלא באמת הגידו לנו חז"ל באמרתם הקדושה שגם על חטא זה יש מקום לשובוכו', ופשר הדברדבקושימועיל תשובה כמבוארבספה"ק, וטעם הדבר מבואר בספריםדהחטאפוגם האדםבמדותיווכו', ובכל חטא פוגם אותו האבר שפגם בו, ולכן בעשותו תשובה מביא חיות חדש משורשו אל האבר והצינור שנחלשוכו', אך בחטא החמור הנ"ל ר"ל הוא כמסיר שורשו לגמרי, ולכן כמעט אין לו תרופה, מפני שהחטא בכל האברים מכף רגל ועד ראש, נמצא שצריך לעשות כנגדה מצוה כזה שהוא ג"כ בכל האברים, ואין לך מצוה אחרת שיעשה אותה האדם בכל גופו, רק במה שמוסר נפשו להקב"ה ומקבל על עצמו באמת, זה הוא מצוה שעושה האדם בכל גופו, והוא וודאי תיקון לחטא הידוע עכת"ד ז"ל, ובאמת בשפלות המצב וכובדהנסיונותשלדורינוא"א להיות שומרתומ"צזולת אם מוכנים בכל עת ובכל רגע למסירות נפשוהשי"תיעזור לנו לשמור ולעשות כל דבריהתוה"קומצותי' במסירת נפש, וזה יהי' לנו לתיקון על גודל הפגם שנגרם בעונותינו.
translation: From this matter, we learn how far a person must be willing to give up his life for the honor of Heaven. In the Jerusalem Talmud, they expounded on the verse "It is time to act for the Lord; they have made void Your Torah," that in the generation of those who violate the Torah, it is a time to act for the Lord. Everything that can be done for the honor of Heaven, the honor of the Torah, and the honor of the righteous, and to strengthen faith and the path of holiness, one is obligated to do with true self-sacrifice. And in a place where there are no people, one should strive to be a person, and not rely on others to act. And we learn from the frogs, who did not rely on others to fulfill the command of the Holy One, Blessed be He, to give themselves to death while they went to places where there was no danger. From them, we learn how much more so to give themselves for the sanctification of the Name. May we merit that the Holy Name be sanctified through us, and to give our souls for the honor of His Blessed Name, and this will be a complete rectification for all our sins, as it is written in the book "Divrei Chaim" (Parashat Noach) and it is said: "And behold, there is a promise for all who repent, and for this sin of M'Z, repentance is not effective, as the sages have stated in their books." However, indeed, our sages have told us in their holy words that even for this sin there is a place to return, and the explanation of the matter is that repentance is effective, as explained in the holy books. The reason is explained in the books that the sin damages a person in his character traits, etc. And in every sin, it damages that particular limb that was blemished. Therefore, when he repents, he brings new life from its root to the limb and the channel that has weakened. However, in the serious sin mentioned, it is as if he removes his root entirely, and therefore he has almost no remedy, because the sin affects all the limbs from the soles of the feet to the head. It follows that he must perform a commandment that also encompasses all the limbs, and there is no other commandment that a person can perform with his entire body, except by giving his soul to the Holy One, Blessed be He, and truly accepting upon himself. This is a commandment that a person performs with his whole body, and it is certainly a rectification for the known sin, as stated. And indeed, in the lowliness of the situation and the weight of the trials of our generation, it is impossible to be a guardian of the commandments unless one is prepared at all times and every moment for self-sacrifice. May the Holy One, Blessed be He, help us to guard and do all the words of the Torah with self-sacrifice, and this will be a rectification for the great blemish caused by our sins.
summary: The passage emphasizes the profound commitment required from individuals to sacrifice themselves for the honor of God, the Torah, and the righteous. It draws on the example of the frogs in Egypt, who did not rely on others to fulfill God's command, highlighting the necessity of personal responsibility in spiritual matters. The text discusses the concept of repentance, particularly in relation to severe sins, asserting that true atonement can only be achieved through self-sacrifice, which engages the entire being in the service of God. Ultimately, it calls for a readiness to uphold the commandments with utmost dedication, viewing such commitment as a remedy for the spiritual failings of the generation.

passage_content: ונבואלבאר הדקדוקים הנ"לבמאמה"כלא נכון לעשות כן וגו' הן נזבח את תועבת מצרים לעיניהם ולא יסקלנו (עיין לעיל קושיא ט'),דלכאורהלא יעלה על הדעת שימנעומרע"הוישראל מלזבוח לה' מחשש יראת המצריים שלא יסקלום, ואין זה אפי' בגדר התנצלות לפרעה, כי כבר ראה פרעה וידע שלא נמנעמשרע"המלקיים צווי השי"ת בשליחותו מיראת המלכות, ונכנס לתוך פלטין המלך והתרה בו קשות ולא נמנע מיראת המלכות, ונכנס ויוצא שלא ברשות ולא יכלו לעשות לו דבר,ואמרז"לבמד"ר(פ' בא ט"ז ג') א"ל הקב"ה למשה חייך אין ישראליוצאיןמכאן עד שישחטו אתאלהימצרים לעיניהם. שאודיע להם שאיןאלהיהםכלום וכו' ובו בלילה שחטו ישראל פסחיהן ואכלו והיו המצריםרואיןבכוריהם הרוגיםואלהיהןשחוטיןולא היו יכולים לעשות כלום וכו' הוי יבושו כל עובדי פסל, עכ"ד המדרש, ואםהבוי"תצוהלזבוחאלהיהםלעיניהם. וודאי שאין מקום ליראה מפניהם כלל,וצ"בטעם התנצלות זה שאינו מספיק להתקבל על לב פרעה.
translation: And we will elaborate on the aforementioned nuances, for it is certainly not correct to do so, etc. They sacrificed the abomination of Egypt before their eyes, and they were not stoned (see above, question 9). It seems inconceivable that Moshe Rabbeinu would prevent Israel from sacrificing to Hashem out of fear of the Egyptians that they would stone them, and this is not even within the realm of an excuse to Pharaoh, for Pharaoh had already seen and knew that Moshe Rabbeinu did not refrain from fulfilling the command of the Holy One, Blessed be He, at His behest out of fear of the monarchy. He entered the king's palace and rebuked him harshly, and he did not refrain out of fear of the monarchy, and he entered and exited without permission, and they could do nothing to him. And our sages of blessed memory said in the Midrash (Parshat Bo 16:3) that the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moshe, "By your life, Israel will not leave here until they slaughter the gods of Egypt before their eyes," to inform them that their gods are nothing, etc. And that night, Israel slaughtered their Paschal lambs and ate, and the Egyptians saw their firstborns slain and their gods slaughtered, and they could do nothing, etc. Let all idol worshippers be ashamed. Thus is the teaching of the Midrash, and if the Holy One, Blessed be He, commands to sacrifice to their gods before their eyes, there is certainly no place for fear of them at all, and this excuse is certainly not sufficient to be accepted in Pharaoh's heart.
summary: The passage discusses the theological implications of the Israelites' sacrificial practices in the presence of the Egyptians, emphasizing that their fear of reprisal from Pharaoh was unfounded. It highlights that God commanded Moses to ensure the Israelites would sacrifice to Him openly, demonstrating that the Egyptian gods were powerless. The act of slaughtering the Passover lamb, a symbol of Egyptian deities, served to humiliate the Egyptians and affirm the sovereignty of the God of Israel. Ultimately, the text underscores the importance of faith and divine authority over earthly powers.

passage_content: אמנםביאורהעניןדאה"נבליל יציאתם כששחטו ישראלאלהיהםשל מצרים לעיניהם לא יכלו לעשות דבר, מפני שהי'מצותוית' בכך ובזמנו הראוי', אבל קודם הזמן לא נכון לעשות כן להתגרות באומות, וציווי השי"ת הי' לשחטו בליל יציאתםדוקא, וקודם לכן לא נכון לזבוח תועבת מצרים לעיניהם שלא להתגרות ולמרוד באומות, וע"ד שפירשנו לעילמ"שרש"י ז"ל עה"פ ויצום אלבנ"יואל פרעה מלך מצרים צום לחלוק לו כבודוכו', והוא לטעם שלא הגיע עדיין קץ הגאולה בעת ההוא, ונצטוו ישראל שלא ימרדו בו טרם הגיעה עת גאולתם,ולז"אלומשרע"הדרך שלשת ימים נלך במדבר וזבחנו לה'אלקינוכאשר יאמר אלינו,דלכאורהכאשר יאמר אלינו מיותר (עיין לעיל קושיא י') אבל יש בזה נתינת טעםדא"אלנו לעשות דבר כ"א עפ"י צווי השי"ת ובזמנו הראוי כאשר יאמר אלינו, וזהו טעם מספיק לדחות דברי פרעה כי לא נוכל לזבוח בארץ כי אם כאשר יאמר ה' אלינו, וע"כ לא נכון לעשות כן וגו', ולא מטעם יראתם של מצרים, אלא לצד איסורדרביעעלה, הן נזבח את תועבת מצרים לעיניהם ולא יסקלנווה"זהתגרות ומרידה באומות ולא נכון לנו לעשות כן.
translation: Indeed, the explanation of the matter is that on the night of their departure, when Israel slaughtered the gods of Egypt before their eyes, they could not do anything, because it was commanded to them in this manner and at the appropriate time. However, before the time, it was not right to provoke the nations, and the command of the Holy One, blessed be He, was to slaughter it specifically on the night of their departure. Prior to that, it was not appropriate to sacrifice the abomination of Egypt before their eyes, so as not to provoke and rebel against the nations. This is in accordance with what we explained above regarding Rashi's commentary on the verse "And Pharaoh, king of Egypt, commanded the children of Israel to fast to honor him," which is for the reason that the end of the redemption had not yet arrived at that time, and Israel was commanded not to rebel against him before the time of their redemption arrived. And therefore, Moshe said, "We will go three days' journey into the wilderness and we will sacrifice to the Lord our God as He will say to us," for seemingly "as He will say to us" is superfluous (see above question 10). But there is a reason here that we are to do nothing except according to the command of the Holy One, blessed be He, and at the appropriate time as He will say to us. This is a sufficient reason to reject Pharaoh's words, for we cannot sacrifice in the land except when the Lord says to us. Therefore, it is not right to do so, etc., and not because of the fear of the Egyptians, but rather due to the prohibition against rebellion, for indeed we would be sacrificing the abomination of Egypt before their eyes, and they would not stone us, and this would be provoking and rebelling against the nations, and it is not right for us to do so.
summary: The passage discusses the timing and divine command regarding the sacrifice of the Egyptian gods by the Israelites during their exodus. It emphasizes that the act of sacrifice was to be performed specifically at the appointed time, as commanded by God, to avoid provoking the Egyptians and to adhere to the divine plan for redemption. The text highlights the importance of following God's instructions and the concept of not rebelling against nations until the proper time for redemption has arrived. Ultimately, it underscores the significance of divine timing and obedience in the context of the Israelites' liberation.

passage_content: ואפשרלהסביר עפ"י פשטות מדוע בשליחות הראשון כתיב ויאמן העם וישמעו וגו' ועכשיו ולא שמעו אל משה (עי' קושיא ג') בהקדם דברי האר"י ז"ל עה"פ ולא יכלו להתמהמה שאם היושוהיןשם עוד רגע היו נופלים לשער הנו"ן שבטומאה ולא היו יכולים לצאת משם לעולם, ולכאורה קשה להביןדמצינושהי' לישראל במצרים מדות תרומיות שלא שינו לשונם ושמם ומלבושם ולא הי' בהםדלטוריןולא הי' ביניהם אחדדקטילזרעי' במעיאמו, וב' דברים בלבד נכשלו בהםעוןע"ז והפרו ברית מילה, ולפני יציאתם תקנו גם זה שבשעה שהקריבו את קרבן פסח נימולו כולם כמבואר במדרש רבה עה"פ זאתחקתהפסח. ומשכו ידיהם מע"ז קודם הקרבת קרבן פסח,ואמרז"לבשעה שהמצריים היו טרודים עם בכוריהם עסקו ישראל בשירות ותשבחות להקב"ה באמירת הלל באהבה נפלאה, והלכו לא"י למקום המקדש ע"י עננים להקריב קרבן הפסח ואח"כ חזרו למצרים, ואיךיצוייראחר כל זה שאם היושוהיןשם עוד רגע אחת היומשוקעיןבשער הנו"ן של טומאה, ואחר שראו כל הנסים ופרשו מע"ז איךנשתקעובטומאת מצרים יותר, שהרי אחר זה כתיב ולא יכלו להתמהמה והוא פליאה.
translation: It is possible to explain simply why in the first mission it is written, "And the people believed and heard," etc., and now "they did not listen to Moses" (see question 3). In advance of the words of the Ari, may his merit protect us, on the verse "And they could not delay," for if they had remained there even for a moment longer, they would have fallen into the gate of the Nun of impurity and would not have been able to escape from there forever. At first glance, it is difficult to understand how it could be that the Israelites in Egypt had elevated qualities, for they did not change their language, their names, or their clothing, and there were no informers among them, nor was there one who was a murderer of his own children. And they only stumbled in two matters: the sin of idolatry and the breach of the covenant of circumcision. Before their departure, they also rectified this, for at the time they offered the Passover sacrifice, they all were circumcised, as explained in the Midrash Rabbah on the verse "This is the statute of the Passover." They withdrew their hands from idolatry before the offering of the Passover sacrifice, and our sages say that when the Egyptians were preoccupied with their firstborns, the Israelites engaged in service and praises to the Holy One, blessed be He, by reciting Hallel with wonderful love, and they went to the Land of Israel to the place of the Temple by way of clouds to offer the Passover sacrifice, and afterwards they returned to Egypt. And how can it be imagined that if they had remained there for just one more moment, they would have been immersed in the gate of the Nun of impurity? After they saw all the miracles and distanced themselves from idolatry, how could they have sunk deeper into the impurity of Egypt? For it is written afterwards, "And they could not delay," and this is indeed a wonder.
summary: The passage discusses the paradox of the Israelites' faith and actions during their exodus from Egypt, highlighting their initial belief in Moses contrasted with their later reluctance to listen to him. It emphasizes the spiritual danger they faced if they lingered in Egypt, risking falling into the depths of impurity. Despite their previous adherence to certain commandments and their eventual commitment to the Passover sacrifice, the text questions how they could still be susceptible to spiritual decline after witnessing divine miracles. This reflects a deeper Hasidic insight into the struggle between faith, spiritual elevation, and the ever-present threat of moral and spiritual degradation.

passage_content: אכןנוכל ללמוד מזה מוסר השכלשיצויירעשות כל הדברים האלה למול ולהקריב קרבן פסח ולשיר שירות ותשבחותלהשי"תואחר כל זה יתגברו כוחות הטומאה יותר וכן הי' לבני ישראל במצרים, ויתבארעפימ"שבספה"קנועם אלימלך (פ' פנחס) עה"פ צרור אתהמדיניםוהכיתם אותם כי צוררים הםבנכליהם,דיל"דמה שאמר כי צוררים הם לכם בלשוןהוהעל דבר העברונתהוהכבר, ותירץ וז"ל והכלל בזה הוא שבכל עבירה נברא קליפה ר"ל, וכ"ז שהקליפה בעולם אזי נופלים מחשבות רעות לאדם מאותה העבירה, וצריך אדם השב לבער הקליפה מן הארץ, וגםבנ"דכ"ז שהיו אותם הרשעיםהמדיניםבעולם, אז היו עדיין הרהורידפעורשולטים בישראל לבלבל להם המחשבה, ולכךנצטוהמרע"הלנקום בהם נקמת ה', וזהו כי צוררים לכם בהוה, ומפרש הכתוב במהבנכליהםאשר נכלו לכם ע"ד פעור, פי' באותן המחשבות הרעותהמתהויםלכם בדברכם במעשהדפעור, ולכך תבערו אותם מן הארץ ותהיו טהורים וקדושים וכו'עכלה"ק, וכעין זה פי'האוהחה"קעיי"ש, וזההעניןעםבנ"יבמצריםדכ"זשהמצריים היו בעולם, הי' שורש טומאת מצרים שולטים בהם והתגברו עליהם, ע"כ כל זמן שהיו בזה המקום שעבדו שם ע"ז מלפנים, השפיעה עליהם הטומאה הזאת אף אחר שפירשו ממנה, ומה שפירשומןהע"זהי' ג"כ בדרך נס שהרי ממינות א"א לפרוש,דעלי' נאמר כל באי' לאישובון, נמצא שמה שיכלו לפרוש מדרכי ע"ז לא הי' בדרך הטבע כלל, ואחר כל זה הי' בהם עדיין שורש הטומאה עד שלא יכלו להתמהמה, ולא תיקני אותה בשלימות עד שעתמ"ת, וע"ד שפירשתיבמאמה"כאו הנסהאלקיםלבוא לקחת לו גוי מקרב גוי,דלכאורהצ"ב אומרו מקרב גוי, ונראה פירושו דלפי שהיו ישראל משוקעים בטומאת מצרים, נשאר בקרבם מדרכיהגויםאפילו אחר שיצאו משם, וע"דשאמרז"לגיורי עד עשרה דרי לא תבזיארמאהבאפי', דאף אחר שפירש מהם עדיין דרכי הגוי ודרכי העבירה טמון בפנימיות לבו, ולזה עשה הקב"ה נס לישראל והוציא מלבם דרכיהגויםאשר הי' עמון בקרב לבם,וז"פאו הנסהאלקיםלבוא לקחת לו גוי "מקרב" גוי, היינו שלקח והוציא מקרבםומפנימותםדרכיהגוים.
translation: Indeed, we can learn from this a moral lesson that it is conceivable to do all these things, to circumcise and to offer the Passover sacrifice, and to sing songs and praises to the Blessed One. And after all this, the forces of impurity will strengthen even more, just as it was for the Children of Israel in Egypt. This is explained in the holy book Noam Elimelech (Parashat Pinchas) on the verse "You shall utterly destroy the Midianites and strike them, for they are adversaries to you in their schemes." The interpretation is that although it is stated that they are adversaries to you in the present tense, it refers to past actions. He explains, and I quote: "The general principle here is that with every transgression, a shell (klipah) is created, so long as the shell exists in the world, evil thoughts from that transgression will fall upon a person. A person must strive to eradicate the shell from the earth. And in our case, as long as those wicked Midianites were in the world, the evil thoughts of Peor still ruled over Israel to confuse their minds. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, commanded to take vengeance on them, and this is because they are adversaries to you in the present. The verse clarifies this with the phrase 'in their schemes,' which refers to those evil thoughts that arise for you when you engage in the actions of Peor. Therefore, you must eradicate them from the land and be pure and holy, etc. This is all in the holy language. Similarly, it is stated in the holy book of the Baal Shem Tov, as mentioned there. This matter is also true for the Children of Israel in Egypt, for as long as the Egyptians were in the world, the root of the impurity of Egypt ruled over them and strengthened against them. Thus, as long as they were in that place where they previously served idols, this impurity influenced them even after they distanced themselves from it. And the fact that they distanced themselves from idol worship was also through a miracle, for it is impossible to separate from heresy naturally, as it is said, 'All who come to the settlement.' It turns out that what they could separate from the ways of idol worship was not through natural means at all. And after all this, the root of impurity still remained within them, so they could not delay, and they did not rectify it completely until the time of the giving of the Torah. This is in accordance with what is explained in the verse, 'For God tested to take for Himself a nation from the midst of a nation,' for at first glance, it is puzzling why it says 'from the midst of a nation.' The explanation seems to be that since the Israelites were immersed in the impurity of Egypt, remnants of the ways of the nations remained among them even after they left there. This is in accordance with what our sages said regarding converts, that until ten generations, they should not be embarrassed in their presence, for even after they have distanced themselves, the ways of the nations and the ways of transgression are hidden in the depths of their hearts. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, performed a miracle for Israel and removed from their hearts the ways of the nations that were hidden within them. And this is the meaning of 'For God tested to take for Himself a nation "from the midst" of a nation,' meaning that He took and removed from within them and from their innermost being the ways of the nations.
summary: The passage discusses the struggle against spiritual impurities and the influence of negative thoughts stemming from past transgressions, particularly in the context of the Israelites in Egypt. It emphasizes that even after leaving Egypt, remnants of idolatrous practices and their associated impurities lingered within the Israelites, necessitating divine intervention to cleanse them. The text highlights the importance of purging these negative influences to achieve holiness and purity, illustrating the ongoing battle between the forces of holiness and the remnants of impurity. Ultimately, it underscores the need for divine assistance in overcoming the spiritual challenges that arise from past sins.

passage_content: וכןהואבדורינוהאחרון שכדילהנצלמדעות כוזבות צריך להיות נסים ממש, וכמו שכתבהרה"קמרוזיןזי"ע בהסכמתו לספר באר הגולהבזה"ל: ובגלות האחרוןבעיקבתאדמשיחאיהי' נפתח שער הנו"ן שבטומאה שהיא מינות ואפיקורסותרח"לוכו', ע"כ הבטיחנו הבוראית"שע"י נביאו, שכל מי שירצה להחזיק באמונה המורשה לאבותינו יתחזק, ומן השמים יסייעוהו אחר התאמצותו שיתאמץ בכל כוחו להציל עצמו מפח יקשם, ויראה לנו נפלאות להצילנו מידם כמו הנפלאות שעשה לנו במצרים וכו'עכלה"ק, ובדורות הקודמים לא היו אפשר לצייר את המצב הזה,ובדורינורואיןאותו בחושבעוה"רשאם אדם ניצול ממחשבת מינות הוא ממש נס גדול כניסייצי"מ, ובזה ניחאדכלזמן שהיו ישראל במצרים באותו המקום שחטאו, זה עצמו גרם להם שישתקעו בטומאה יותר, ולטעם זה לא יכלו להתמהמה שם אפי' עוד רגע,ויכוליןללמוד מזה מוסר השכלדאעפ"ישעשו וקיימו כל המצוותאעפי"ככתיב בהם ולא יכלו להתמהמה, ואין אתנו יודע עד מה ובאיזה מדריגה אנו עומדים,דאפשרלהיות גם בין בני ישראלוהולכיןבכל יום להתפלל בכוונה וללמוד ולעשות מצותומעש"טולפעמים נאנח על עוונותיו ואחר כל זהיכוליןלהיות משוקע בטומאה, וכמושרואיןשהי' כן בישראל במצרים שאחר כל עבודתם הגדולה כתיב ולא יכלו להתמהמה, אלאשהשי"תריחם עליהם והוציאם משם ולקח אותם גוי מקרב גוי שלקח מהם את כוחות הטומאה ונשארו נקיים, כן גם אנחנו מצפים כיון שעכ"פ רצוננו לילך בדרך האמתולהשמרמדיעותנפסדות ועבירה והרהורים רעים, אעפ"י שא"א להיות כ"כ בשלימות, הבורא כל עולמים יעזור לנו ויוציאנו מעמקי הטומאה ויתעוררו הנסים של יציאת מצרים, ואלו הזמנים של ימיהשובבי"םמסוגלים לתיקון חטא הידוע כמ"שבספה"ק.
translation: And so it is that in the last exile, in order to be saved from false beliefs, there must be real miracles, as the holy Rabbi of Karazin, may his merit protect us, wrote in his approbation to the book "Be'er HaGolah": In the last exile, in the footsteps of the Messiah, the gate of the Nun of impurity, which is heresy and apostasy, will be opened. Therefore, the Creator has promised us through His prophet that anyone who wishes to hold on to the faith passed down to our forefathers will be strengthened, and from Heaven they will assist him after he makes an effort with all his might to save himself from the traps of the wicked, and He will show us wonders to save us from their hands, just as the wonders He did for us in Egypt, etc. In previous generations, it was not possible to envision this situation, and in our generation, we see it with our senses. If a person is saved from heretical thoughts, it is truly a great miracle like the miracles of the Exodus. And this is evident from the fact that all the time the Israelites were in Egypt, in the very place where they sinned, this itself caused them to sink deeper into impurity. For this reason, they could not delay there even for a moment, and we can learn from this a moral lesson that even though they did all the commandments, still it is written about them that they could not delay. And no one knows until what point and at what level we stand, for it is possible that even among the children of Israel, they go every day to pray with intention and to learn and to perform commandments, and at times they sigh over their sins, and after all this, they can still be immersed in impurity. And as we see that it was so with Israel in Egypt, that after all their great service, it is written that they could not delay, except that the Holy One, blessed be He, had mercy on them and took them out from there and took them as a nation from among the nations, removing from them the forces of impurity, and they remained clean. So too, we hope that since we at least desire to walk in the path of truth and to guard ourselves from false beliefs and transgressions and evil thoughts, even though it is impossible to be so complete, the Creator of all worlds will help us and take us out from the depths of impurity, and the miracles of the Exodus will be awakened, and these times of the days of Shovavim are suitable for the rectification of the known sin, as it is written in the holy books.
summary: The passage emphasizes the necessity of divine miracles for salvation from false beliefs and spiritual impurities in the current era, likening it to the miraculous redemption from Egypt. It reassures that those who strive to uphold the faith passed down from ancestors will receive heavenly assistance, even amidst struggles with doubt and sin. The text reflects on the historical context of Israel's suffering in Egypt, highlighting that despite their efforts, they were unable to escape their spiritual state without God's intervention. Ultimately, it expresses hope for redemption and the revival of miracles akin to the Exodus, particularly during the spiritually potent times known as "Shovavim."

passage_content: ובזהיובן בפשטות מהשבתחלההאמינו למשה ואח"כ כתיב ולא שמעו אל משה, שבזמן האחרון טרם יציאתםנתגברועליהם כוחות הטומאה יותר עד שאם היו שם עוד רגע היונופליןבשער הנו"ן, ואין מקום לתמי' מה שהאמינובתחלהואח"כ לא רצו לשמוע עוד,ורואיןתמי' כזו גםבדורינואצל הרבה אנשים שביום הקדום היו מוחזקים לאנשים כשרים, ופתאוםנתהפכוונשמעו אחר פגעי הזמן, הבורא כל עולמים יעזור וכימי צאתנו ממצרים יראנו נפלאות, שהשפלותבדורינוגדול הוא מאוד,דבמצריםהי' להם לישראל נביאי אמת משה ואהרן, אבל היום אין לנו דבר כי אם האמונה בבורא עולם, ואין ישראל נגאלים אלא בזכות האמונה, ובזכות זה אנו חייםונזוניםכאמרז"ל, הבורא עולם יעזור שנוכל להתגבר ולהכניע כל כוחות היצר וכוחות הטומאה, ולהיות דבוק בדרך האמתוכחהקדושה, ונזכה לחיות ולראות פני משיח צדקינו ואליהו הנביא ומשה רבינו וכל דור המדבר יבואו עמו, ולא נהי' חלילהמהנדחיםע"יעוונינוהרבים,דכלאחד יודע בעצמו עד היכן הוא משוקע בעוונות ופשעים ובאיזה פנים נתראה לפני צדיקי אמת, השי"ת ירחם עלינו לעמוד בכלהנסיונותולהתגבר על כל המניעות ולהיות דבוק בבורא כל עולמים, ירחם השי"ת עלינו ובמהרה נזכה לישועה שלימה בהתרוממות קרן התורה וישראל בנחת ובשמחה, ונזכה לקבל פני משיח צדקינובאנפיןנהירין, יהי כבוד ה' לעולם ישמח ה' במעשיו, ונזכה לשמחה האמיתית ולהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו במהרה בימינו אמן.
translation: And this is understood simply from the beginning: they believed in Moses, and afterwards it is written, "But they did not listen to Moses," for in the last moments, just before their departure, the forces of impurity became stronger against them, to the point that if they had remained there for another moment, they would have fallen at the gate of the Nun. There is no place for wonder as to why they believed at first and then did not want to listen anymore. Such wonder is also seen in our generation among many people who were once regarded as righteous individuals, and suddenly they turned and listened to the influences of the times. May the Creator of the worlds help us, and as in the days of our exodus from Egypt, may He show us wonders, for the lowliness in our generation is very great. In Egypt, the Israelites had true prophets, Moses and Aaron, but today we have nothing but faith in the Creator of the world, and Israel is redeemed only through the merit of faith. And because of this, we live and are sustained, as our sages have said. May the Creator of the world help us to overcome and subdue all the forces of the evil inclination and the forces of impurity, and to be attached to the path of truth and holiness. May we merit to live and see the face of our righteous Messiah, Elijah the prophet, and Moses our teacher, and all the generation of the wilderness will come with him, and may we not, Heaven forbid, be among those cast away due to our sins and the many transgressions, for each one knows for himself how deep he is sunk in sins and transgressions, and in what manner he will appear before the true righteous ones. May the Holy One, blessed be He, have mercy on us to stand firm in all the trials and to overcome all the obstacles and to be attached to the Creator of all worlds. May the Holy One, blessed be He, have mercy on us, and may we soon merit complete salvation with the upliftment of the banner of the Torah and Israel in peace and joy, and may we merit to receive the face of our righteous Messiah with shining faces. May the glory of the Lord be forever; may the Lord rejoice in His works, and may we merit true joy and the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us speedily in our days. Amen.
summary: The passage reflects on the fluctuating faith of the Jewish people, contrasting their initial belief in Moses with their later refusal to listen to him, highlighting the increasing influence of impurity in the world. It emphasizes that in contemporary times, faith in God is the sole source of redemption, as there are no longer true prophets like Moses and Aaron. The text calls for divine assistance to overcome the challenges posed by the evil inclination and to remain steadfast in faith, ultimately expressing hope for the coming of the Messiah and the restoration of spiritual joy and connection to God. It concludes with a prayer for a complete redemption and the revelation of divine glory in the world.

passage_content: במסיבהאלקיםאל משה וגו' ושמי ד' לא נודעתי להם וגו' ברש"י ז"ל ורבותינו דרשוהו וכו' א"ל הקב"ה יש לי להתאונן על מיתת האבות, הרבה פעמים נגליתי עליהם באל שדי ולא אמרו לי מה שמךוכו', ואין המדרש מתיישב אחר המקרא וכו' וא"ת לא הודיעם שכך שמו, הרי תחלה כשנגלהלאאע"הבין הבתרים נאמר אני ד' אשר הוצאתיך מאור כשדים, עכ"ד רש"י ז"ל, ובאמת מפורש כןבתנחומא(ר"פ זו) תדע לך שלא גלה אותו לאבות העולם ולמה גלה אותולמשרע"העל שהלך לגאול את ישראל, ואיתא ג"כ באותיותדר"ע(אלף) אפי' אברהם יצחק ויעקב שהם גדולים ממלאכי השרת והקב"ה אהבם אהבה גמורה, לא גילה להם שם המפורש אלא למשה בלבד ע"כ, וגם זה צ"בדנשגבהמעלתהאבוה"קעד אין חקר, ומבוארבמד"רעה"פ המכסה אני מאברהם וגו' שלא העלים הקב"ה ממנו דבר, ואף מה שנתחדש הלכהבב"דשל מעלה בכל יום גילה לו הקב"ה, וטעמא בעי מדוע שם המפורש לא גילה להם, ואיתא במדרש תהלים (צ"א)אשגבהוכי ידע שמי,דלע"ליודיע הקב"ה שם המפורש לישראל עיי"ש, ואיך יתכן שלא הגיע מדריגתן שלהאבוה"קאל מה שיזכו כל ישראללע"ל.
translation: In the assembly, God said to Moses, etc., and My name, the Lord, was not made known to them, etc. Rashi, may his memory be blessed, and our Rabbis expounded it, etc. The Holy One, blessed be He, said, "I have reason to complain about the death of the Patriarchs. Many times I revealed Myself to them as El Shaddai, and they did not ask Me what My name is," etc. And the Midrash does not align with the verse, etc. And if you say He did not inform them that this is His name, behold, initially when He revealed Himself to Abraham at the covenant of the pieces, it is stated, "I am the Lord who brought you out of Ur of the Chaldeans," thus concludes Rashi, may his memory be blessed. And indeed, it is explicitly stated so in Tanchuma (in this section), "Know that He did not reveal it to the Patriarchs, and why did He reveal it to Moses? Because he went to redeem Israel." It is also stated in the letters of the Midrash (Aleph) that even Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, who are greater than the ministering angels, and the Holy One, blessed be He, loved them with a complete love, did not reveal to them the Ineffable Name, but only to Moses, therefore. And this is also a question of why the Holy One, blessed be He, did not reveal the Ineffable Name to them, and it is stated in the Midrash Tehillim (91) "Because he knows My name," that the Holy One, blessed be He, did not want to reveal the Ineffable Name to Israel, see there. And how is it possible that they did not reach the level of the Patriarchs, and what will all of Israel merit in the World to Come?
summary: The passage discusses the theological significance of God's revelation of His name to Moses, while withholding it from the patriarchs Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. It emphasizes that despite their greatness, the patriarchs did not receive the full revelation of God's name, which was reserved for Moses due to his unique role in redeeming Israel. This highlights the idea that certain divine truths are revealed in accordance with the specific mission and spiritual elevation of individuals, suggesting a deeper connection between revelation and the responsibilities of leadership in the Jewish tradition. The text reflects on the profound love God has for the patriarchs, yet underscores the distinct privilege granted to Moses in the context of Israel's redemption.

passage_content: ב)דר"א(פ"מ) אמר משה לפני הקב"הרבוןכל עולמים הודיעני שמך הגדול והקדוש וכו' והודיעווכו', וראו העליונים שמסר הקב"ה סוד שם המפורש וענו ברוך אתה ה' חונן הדעת ע"כ, וראוי להבין מדועדוקאבכאןברכו חונן הדעת, והרי כל התורה וכל חזי החכמה מסר לוית'.
translation: Moses said before the Holy One, Blessed be He, "Master of all worlds, make Your great and holy name known to me," etc., and He made it known to him, etc. And the heavenly beings saw that the Holy One, Blessed be He, entrusted the secret of the Ineffable Name, and they responded, "Blessed are You, Lord, who grants wisdom." Therefore, it is fitting to understand why here it is blessed, "who grants wisdom," when all the Torah and all the visions of wisdom were entrusted to him.
summary: In this passage, Moses requests to know the great and holy name of God, leading to a revelation of the secret of the ineffable name, which elicits a response of praise from the heavenly beings. The phrase "חונן הדעת" (He grants knowledge) emphasizes the divine gift of understanding, suggesting that all Torah and wisdom are bestowed upon humanity through God's grace. This highlights the Hasidic belief in the intimate connection between divine revelation and human comprehension, underscoring the importance of divine assistance in grasping spiritual truths.

passage_content: ג)לכן אמור לבני ישראל אני ד', לכן אמור הנני נותן לו את בריתי שלו'וצ"ב.
translation: Therefore, say to the children of Israel, I am the Lord; therefore, say, behold, I am giving him his covenant.
summary: In this passage, the declaration "אני ד'" emphasizes God's unique and singular nature as the ultimate authority. The phrase "הנני נותן לו את בריתי שלו" signifies the intimate relationship between God and the Jewish people, highlighting the covenant as a profound gift that establishes a deep spiritual connection. This reflects key Hasidic concepts of divine love and the importance of faithfulness to the covenant, illustrating how the relationship with God is both personal and communal. Ultimately, it underscores the idea that God's presence and promises are ever-present and accessible to those who seek Him.

passage_content: ד)אתכם מתחת סבלות מצרים וגו'פרש"יז"ל כי כן הבטחתיו ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול עכ"ל,וק"זהייטב לבזלה"הדקדק מדוע הביא רש"י ז"ל גם סיפאדקראברכוש גדול, ואין מזה ראי' על מאמר והוצאתי אתכם.
translation: d) "I will take you out from under the burdens of Egypt," etc. The explanation of the holy Rabbi, may his merit protect us, is that thus I promised him, and afterwards they went out with great wealth, thus far. And the question is, why did Rashi, may his memory be blessed, also bring the end of the verse regarding "great wealth," and does this not serve as a proof for the statement "and I will take you out"?
summary: הקטע מדגיש את ההבטחה האלוהית לשחרור ממצרים, תוך התמקדות במושג "ברכוש גדול" כסימן לגאולה מלאה. רש"י מתייחס לכך שההוצאה ממצרים לא הייתה רק פיזית אלא גם רוחנית, כאשר ה' מבטיח לא רק חירות אלא גם שפע. ההדגשה על "ברכוש גדול" מצביעה על כך שהגאולה כוללת גם את ההיבט הכלכלי והחברתי, מה שמחזק את האמונה בהשגחה הפרטית של ה' על עם ישראל. בסופו של דבר, יש כאן קריאה להבין את הגאולה כהליך כוללני שמקיף את כל תחומי החיים.

passage_content: והנל"פבהקדם דברי קודשהנוע"אזלה"ה(בפ' קרח) עה"פ לא חמור א' מהם נשאתי וגו',דהנהכן הוא המהנה ת"ח וצדיקים מנכסיו, אז ההנאה הזאת תביאהו שלא במהרה הוא חוטא להיות רשע גמור לכפור בתורה חלילהוכו',וז"שלא חמור א' מהם נשאתי, כלומר אני גרמתי להם זאת, שע"י שלא לקחתי מהם, זה גרמה להם שחטאו, שאםנהנתימהם הי'מגיןעליהם זאת לבלתי יחטאועכלה"קוידוע שכן הוא דרך הצדיקים לתלותהחסרוןבעצמם, וללמד זכות על ישראל, אמנם ראוילהבין מדוע באמת שללמשרע"ההנאתו מכל ישראל, אם הי' זה לטובתנפשותםלהגין עליהם לבלתי יחטאו. והרי כל השתדלותו ורצון נפשו הי' אך ורק לטובת ישראלולש"ש.
translation: And this is what is meant by the words of the holy Zohar (in Parashat Korach) regarding the verse "I have not taken even one donkey from them," for behold, here are the Tzaddikim and Torah scholars from His possessions. This enjoyment will lead him not to sin quickly and become a complete wicked person, G-d forbid, to deny the Torah, etc. And this is what is meant by "I have not taken even one donkey from them," meaning I caused them this, that by not taking from them, it caused them to sin, for if I had enjoyed from them, it would have protected them from sinning. And it is known that this is indeed the way of the Tzaddikim to attribute the shortcoming to themselves and to speak favorably of Israel. However, one must understand why Moshe Rabbeinu was indeed denied enjoyment from all of Israel, if it was for the benefit of their souls to protect them from sinning. For all his efforts and the desire of his soul was solely for the benefit of Israel and for the sake of Heaven.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the relationship between the righteous (Tzadikim) and their influence on the community, emphasizing that the Tzadik's selflessness in not taking from others serves as a protective measure against sin. The text highlights the idea that the Tzadik bears the responsibility for the shortcomings of the people, teaching a lesson of merit on behalf of Israel. It questions why Moses refrained from benefiting from the people, suggesting that his ultimate desire was their spiritual welfare. This reflects a deep Hasidic concept of self-sacrifice and the interconnectedness of the Tzadik and the community's spiritual state.

passage_content: ואפ"לעפימ"דבירושלמידקדושין, א"ל ר'יוסאלר' בון תא ואמסור לך שמאדמפורש, א"ל לית אנא יכיל בגיןדאנאאכיל מעשר, ומאןדידעלי', לית לי'לאתהנוי' משל אחרים,וק"זזלה"הבתפלה למשה (ט') פי' בזה ויבטחו בך יודעי שמך, בךדייקאולאיהנומשל אחרים, יודעי שמך היינו שם המפורש עכ"ל, והנהלמשרע"הגילה הקב"ה סוד שם המפורש שהי' מוכרח אליו ידיעה זו לצורך הגאולה, כמ"שבתנחומאהנ"ל ולמה גילה אותו למשה על שהלך לגאול את ישראל, ואפשרדמה"טלא הי' אפשר לולאתהנויימשל אחרים: אמנםהאבוה"קלא הוצרכו להשתמש בידיעת שם המפורש לצורך הגאולה, והי' רצוןהבוי"תשיהי' להם התקשרות עם בנ"א להחזירם למוטב ולהגין בזכותם עליהם שלא יחטאו, ואלמלי ידעו בסוד שם המפורש לא הי' אפשר להםלאתהנויימשל אחרים ולהגין עליהם ע"כ לא הודיעם הקב"ה שם המפורשבבחי'דלעתיד.
translation: And even though it is written in the holy teachings of the Kabbalists, Rabbi Yosala said to Rabbi Bon Ta, "I will tell you the name that is very explicit." He replied, "I cannot because I eat tithes, and whoever is dependent on me, I do not have the pleasure of others." And this is what is said in the prayer of Moses (9): "And they trusted in You, those who know Your name," specifically, and not the pleasure of others. "Those who know Your name" refers to the explicit name. Thus, it is known that the Holy One, blessed be He, revealed the secret of the explicit name, which was necessary for this knowledge for the purpose of redemption, as it is stated in the Tanchuma mentioned above. And why did He reveal it to Moses? Because he went to redeem Israel. It is possible that for this reason it would not have been possible without the pleasure of others. However, the holy fathers needed to use the knowledge of the explicit name for the purpose of redemption, and it was the will of the Blessed One that they should have a connection with people to return them to good and to protect them in their merit so that they would not sin. And had they known the secret of the explicit name, it would not have been possible for them to have the pleasure of others and to protect them. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, did not inform them of the explicit name in the aspect of "not for the future."
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the significance of the Divine Name and its connection to redemption. It emphasizes that knowledge of the Name is essential for the redemption process, as it allows for a unique relationship between God and humanity, enabling divine protection and guidance. The text highlights that this knowledge was revealed to Moses specifically because of his mission to redeem the Israelites, underscoring the importance of human agency in the divine plan. Ultimately, it suggests that without this sacred knowledge, the connection necessary for redemption and protection would not be possible.

passage_content: עודיתבאר בהקדם דברינו לעיל (ח"א עמוד ש"ז:), פ' לךבמאמה"כלמען ייטב לי בעבורך וחיתה נפשי בגללך,ופרש"יז"ל למען ייטב לי בעבורך יתנו לי מתנות, ותמהו המפורשים הכי הי' אאע"ה משתוקק למתנתם, גם מ"ט הקדים לקיחת המתנות לוחיתה נפשי שהוא העיקר, ופירשנועפימ"דבמד"ר(פר' מ' ס"ו) כל מה שכתוב באברהם כתיב בבניו וכו' באברהם כתיב ואברם כבד מאוד במקנה בכסף ובזהב. ובישראל כתיב ויוציאם בכסף וזהב וגו' והרמב"ן ז"ל (ר"פ לך) האריך בזה כי כל מעשההאבוה"קהי' להכין ולכבוש דרך לבניהם, וע"כ עשו פועל דמיוני במעשיהם כדי שתהא מתקיימת עכ"פ עיי"ש מבוארמדרז"לדע"יהמתנות שלקח אאע"ה זכו ישראל לרכוש מצרים, והי' זה להצלתנפשותםלפדותא"עמגזירת השמד בדורות הבאים שלא יפגעוהאומה"עבנפשותםכמבואר בזרע קודש (נעתק בדברינו שם), ע"כ הקדים אאע"ה לקיחת המתנות שהוא סיבה לוחיתה נפשיעייש"דבאריכות.
translation: In advance of our earlier discussion (Part 1, page 67), it is stated, "For my sake, may it be good for me because of you, and my soul shall live because of you." The explanation is that for my sake, they will give me gifts. The commentators were astonished: how could our forefather Abraham be so eager for their gifts? Also, why did he prioritize receiving the gifts over "and my soul shall live," which is the main point? It is explained in the Midrash (Parashat M, Section 66) that everything written about Abraham is also written about his children, etc. It is written about Abraham, "And Abram was very wealthy in cattle, silver, and gold." And regarding Israel, it is written, "And He brought them out with silver and gold," etc. The Ramban, may his memory be blessed (in Parashat Lech), elaborated on this, for all the actions of the father were to prepare and pave the way for his children. Therefore, he made a figurative effort in his actions so that it would be established. It is explained there that the gifts that our forefather Abraham received were a merit for Israel to acquire Egypt, and this was for the salvation of their souls to redeem them from the decree of destruction in future generations, so that the nations would not harm their souls, as explained in Zera Kodesh (quoted in our discussion there). Therefore, our forefather Abraham prioritized receiving the gifts, which is a cause for "and my soul shall live," as explained in detail.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Abraham's desire for gifts, emphasizing that his primary concern was the well-being of his descendants. It highlights the idea that the actions of the patriarchs were intended to prepare and secure a path for their children, ensuring their survival and prosperity. The gifts Abraham received are seen as a means to protect future generations from potential threats, illustrating a deep connection between the patriarch's actions and the fate of the Jewish people. This reflects a broader Hasidic theme of divine providence and the importance of spiritual legacy.

passage_content: ואפ"לעוד בזהעפי"דהפרשת דרכים ז"ל (דרך המצפה דרוש כ"ו)דלכאורהאיך דן הקב"ה את המצריים במיתה וממון, והאקיי"לדאין אדם מת ומשלם, ותירץעפימ"שהתוס' (כתובות ל' ע"ב ד"ה זר)דגזה"כהוא בהקדש ותרומה דלא אמרי' קם לי'בדרבהמיני'וכו', ומעתה כיוןדישראלנקראו קודש וראשית תבואתו של הקב"ה, ע"כמדינאחייבים המצרים להיותלוקיןומשלמיןעל ידיהם, ופי' בזה הכתוב קודש ישראל לד' ראשית תבואתו, ע"כ אוכליו יאשמו פי' חייבים לשלם מלשון ואת אשמו ישוב בראשו, וגם רעה תבוא עליהם שיענשו בידי שמים עכת"ד ז"ל, והנה היו ישראל במצרים בסכנה גדולה שלאיטמעובאומות,כאמרז"לשהיוהאומה"עמבזיןאותם ואומרים סבורים הם שלא שלטו המצריים באמותיהם, אם בגופם היו מושלים בנשותיהם לא כ"ש,וקיי"לדעכו"םועבד הבא על בת ישראל הולד פגום, אמנם מהרכוש הי' ראי' ברורה שנשארו בקדושתן ונקראו קודש לד', ובזה שלקח אאע"ה המתנות עשה פועל דמיוני כדי שיתקיים הבטחת הרכוש לבניו כמבואר במדרש הנ"לוז"שלמען ייטב לי בעבורך יתנו לי מתנותועי"זיזכו לרכוש מצרים ויתברר שנשארו ישראל קדושים ולא נטמעו באומות,ועי"כוחיתה נפשי בגללךדכלהמניח בן כמותו כאלו לא מת.
translation: And even further, in the words of the holy Zohar (in the section of the paths, Drush 26), it seems at first glance how the Holy One, blessed be He, judged the Egyptians with death and monetary loss, and we have a principle that a person dies and pays. And it was explained according to what Tosafot says (Kiddushin 30b, s.v. Zar) that in the case of sacred items and terumah, we do not say that it is established for the other kinds, etc. Therefore, since Israel is called holy and the first of the produce of the Holy One, blessed be He, according to the law, the Egyptians are obligated to be struck and to pay through their hands. And the verse explains this: "Holy is Israel to the Lord, the first of His produce," therefore, those who eat of it will be guilty, meaning they are obligated to pay, from the language of "and his guilt shall return upon his head," and also evil will come upon them that they will be punished by the hands of Heaven, thus said the holy one, blessed be He. And behold, the Israelites in Egypt were in great danger of being assimilated among the nations, as our sages have said that the nation was oppressing them and saying they thought that the Egyptians did not rule over their women, if they ruled over their bodies, how much more so over their wives. And we have a principle that a gentile and a slave who has relations with a Jewish woman, the offspring is blemished. However, from the property, there was clear evidence that they remained in their sanctity and were called holy to the Lord. And in this that our father Abraham took the gifts, he made a fictitious act so that the promise of the property would be fulfilled for his sons, as explained in the aforementioned Midrash, "so that it may be good for me because of you, they will give me gifts," and through this, they merited the property of Egypt, and it would be clarified that Israel remained holy and did not assimilate among the nations. And thus, "my soul lives because of you," for anyone who leaves a son like him is as if he did not die.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the divine judgment of the Egyptians, emphasizing that since the Israelites are considered holy and the first fruits of God, the Egyptians are obligated to pay for their actions against them. The text highlights the danger the Israelites faced in Egypt, suggesting that their preservation of holiness amidst potential assimilation was crucial. The taking of gifts by Abraham is seen as a symbolic act ensuring the sanctity and future prosperity of the Israelites, reinforcing their identity as a chosen people. Ultimately, the passage underscores the theological concept of divine justice and the enduring sanctity of Israel despite external threats.

passage_content: היוצאלנו מזה שהי' מוכרח אאע"ה לקבל המתנות בשביל לעשות פועל דמיוני לבניו שיזכו לרכוש מצרים, ואוליעד"זגם ביצחק ויעקב שעשו ג"כ במעשיהם פועל דמיוני לטובת הצלת דורות ישראל,ומה"טלא גילה להם הקב"ה שם המפורשבבחי'דלעתיד, אבל גילה אותולמשרע"העל שהלך לגאול את ישראל,ומה"טלא הי' רשאי ליהנות משל אחריםולע"לכל ישראל ידעו את השם, כי לא יצטרכו ישראל זה לזה ליהנות משל אחרים,וז"שבמדרש (תנחומאישן) ושמי ד' לא נודעתי להם ולך גליתי אותו, שאתה הולך לגאול את ישראל כדי שתצליח, אמר הקב"ה בעוה"ז ליחידים גליתי שמי, אבל לעוה"ב לכל ישראל אני מודיע שמו שנא' לכן ידע עמי שמי וגו'.
translation: The reason we were compelled, blessed be His Name, to receive the gifts was in order to create a fictitious effect for His sons so that they would merit to acquire Egypt. And similarly, with Isaac and Jacob, who also acted in their deeds to create a fictitious effect for the benefit of saving the generations of Israel. For this reason, the Holy One, blessed be He, revealed to them the Ineffable Name in the aspect of the future, but He revealed it to Moses, who went to redeem Israel. For this reason, he was permitted to benefit from others, and in the future, all of Israel will know the Name, for Israel will not need to benefit from others. And this is what is said in the Midrash (Tanchuma Yashan), "And My Name, the Lord, was not known to them, but to you I have revealed it," that you are going to redeem Israel so that you will succeed. The Holy One, blessed be He, said that in this world, to individuals, I revealed My Name, but in the World to Come, I will make My Name known to all of Israel, as it is said, "Therefore My people shall know My Name," etc.
summary: The passage discusses the necessity for the patriarchs, particularly Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, to engage in actions that would create a spiritual merit for their descendants, enabling them to acquire Egypt. It emphasizes that God revealed the ineffable name to Moses as he was chosen to redeem Israel, indicating that while individuals may receive divine knowledge in this world, in the world to come, all of Israel will know God's name. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of collective redemption and the ultimate spiritual elevation of the Jewish people.

passage_content: נחזורלעניןהפרשהדהנהבסוף פרשה שלמעלה כתיב ויפגעו את משה ואת אהרן נצביםלקראתם בצאתם מאת פרעה, ויאמרואלהםירא ד' עליכם וישפוט אשר הבאשתם את ריחנו וגו'פרש"ירבותינו דרשו כלנציםונצבים דתן ואבירם היו וכו'ומשרע"ההי' מצטער מאוד בראותו כי פנו עורף לשלוחי ד' וממאנים בגאולתוית', וחשש פן ילמדו מהם בני ישראל, ולזה אמר למההרעותהלעם הזה וגו', ע"ד שפי' ק"ז הייטב לבזלה"השהכוונה על הערב רב שנקראו עם, שמאז באתי בשליחותך נעשו רעים וחטאים יותר, ופן ילמדו ישראל מהםויחלשאמונתם, ותלה כלהחסרוןבעצמו שאינו מסוגל להחזירם בתשובה ולהגין עליהם, מפני שמעולם לא נהנה מהם, וע"ד שפי'בנוע"אלא חמור א' מהם וגו',ולז"אלמה זה שלחתני, כי זה גרם הקלקול מפני שהייתי אני השליח, וע"כ ניחמו השי"ת כי כ"ז הי' הכרח וא"א שתהי' שליחות הזה כ"א על ידך,ומה"טלך גליתי שם המפורש ולא לאחרים ומעתה א"א לךלאתהנויימשל אחרים, ואעפ"כ תצליח בשליחותי להחזיר את ישראל בתשובה ולהפרישם מהערב רב.
translation: We will return to the matter of the portion. Behold, at the end of the portion above it is written, "And they encountered Moses and Aaron, standing to meet them as they came out from Pharaoh," and they said to them, "May the Lord look upon you and judge, for you have made our scent stink," etc. Our sages explained that the "standing" refers to Datan and Aviram, etc. And Moses was very distressed to see that they turned their backs on the messengers of the Lord and refused His redemption, and he feared that the children of Israel would learn from them. Therefore, he said, "Why have You harmed this people?" etc., as explained in the Zohar that it is good to disgrace them, referring to the mixed multitude who are called a people, that since I came with Your mission, they have become more wicked and sinful, and lest the Israelites learn from them and weaken their faith. He attributed the entire shortcoming to himself, that he is not capable of bringing them to repentance and protecting them, because he has never benefited from them. And as explained in the Midrash, "But one donkey of theirs," etc., and to this he said, "Why have You sent me?" for this caused the corruption because I was the messenger. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, comforted him, for all this was necessary, and it is impossible for this mission to be fulfilled except through you. And from this, I revealed there the explicit name and not to others, and from now on you cannot benefit from others, and nevertheless, you will succeed in your mission to bring Israel to repentance and separate them from the mixed multitude.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the challenges faced by Moses and Aaron as they confront the Israelites' resistance to redemption, particularly influenced by the mixed multitude (Erev Rav). Moses expresses deep concern that the people's negative behavior will weaken the faith of the Israelites. He attributes the failure to his own inadequacy as a messenger of God, yet ultimately, he is reassured that his mission is divinely ordained and that he will succeed in guiding the Israelites back to repentance, despite the obstacles posed by the Erev Rav. This reflects key Hasidic themes of divine providence, the struggle between faith and doubt, and the transformative power of repentance.

passage_content: ולז"אוידבראלקיםאל משהוכפרש"יז"ל דבר אתו משפט על שהקשה לדבר ולומר למההרעותה, ויאמר אליו אני ד', שגילה לוית' סוד שם המפורש וזה לך אות שתצליח בשליחותי, וכמ"ש במדרש הנ"ל ושמי ד' לא נודעתי להם ולך גליתי אותו שאתה הולך לגאול את ישראל כדי שתצליח, ומה שלא גליתי להם הי' ג"כ לצורך הגאולה כדי שיעשו פועל דמיוני ללקיחת הרכוש, ויתברר לכל כי קודש ישראל לד' ונתקיים הבטחתי בזרעם ולאיטמעובאומות, ובזה יתבאר קישור הפסוקים ושמי ד' לא נודעתי להם. וכ"ז כדי לקיים הבטחתי שנשבעתי לאבות הראשונים, לכן אמורלבנ"יוהוצאתי אתכם וגו',וז"שרש"י ז"ל שכן הבטחתיו ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול, שע"י הרכוש נתקיים הבטחתי בזרעם המתייחסים אחריהם.
translation: And to explain, G-d spoke to Moses and said, "I am the Lord," revealing to him the secret of the Ineffable Name. This is a sign for you that you will succeed in My mission, as it is stated in the aforementioned Midrash: "And My Name, the Lord, was not known to them, but to you I have revealed it, for you are going to redeem Israel so that you will succeed." The reason I did not reveal it to them was also for the purpose of redemption, so that they would perform an imaginary act of taking the possessions, and it would be made clear to all that the holiness of Israel belongs to the Lord, and My promise to their descendants would be fulfilled, and they would not be assimilated among the nations. In this, the connection of the verses will be clarified: "And My Name, the Lord, was not known to them." All this is to fulfill the promise that I swore to the forefathers. Therefore, say to the children of Israel, "I have taken you out," etc., as Rashi, of blessed memory, explains, that I promised them, and afterwards they will go out with great wealth, for through the wealth, My promise to their descendants, who are related to them, will be fulfilled.
summary: הקטע עוסק בגילוי שם ה' למשה, המצביע על הצלחתו בשליחותו לגאול את ישראל. ההסתרה של השם מהאבות נועדה לשרת את הגאולה, כדי שהעם יפעל באופן דמיוני ויתברר כי ישראל שייכים לקודש. בכך מתקיים הבטחת ה' לאבות, והיציאה ממצרים עם רכוש גדול משקפת את הקשר בין הגאולה לבין ההבטחה שניתנה לזרע האבות.

passage_content: ונקדיםעוד מה שפרשתי לעיל (בפ' שמות) עה"פ ויאמר משה אלהאלקיםהנה אנכי בא אלבנ"יוגו' ואמרו לו מה שמו מה אומר אליהם, ויאמראלקיםאל משה אקי' אשר אקי' וגו', ודרשו רז"ל במדרש שגילה לוית' סוד שם המפורש, וכ"כ הרמב"ןוהראב"עוכל המפורשים ז"ל, ומיד אח"כ כתיב ויאמר כה תאמר לבני ישראל אקי' שלחני אליכם, ופי'האוהחה"קהגם שגילה אל משה עבדו סוד השםוכו', חזר לומר שאינו באמור אלא הזכרת השםוכו', אבל מה שהוספתי לגלות לך אשר אקי' הוא בבל תאמר עכ"ל,וכעי"זברש"י במוסגר שמאז הי' דעתו באומרוית' אקי' אשר אקי' למשה לבדו הגיד ולא שיגיד לישראל, אמנם תמהו המפורשים דהרימשרע"השאל מהקב"ה מה אומר אליהם, וא"כ תשובתוית' הראשונה במאמר אקי' אשר אקי' אינו מענין השאלהדלמשהלבדו הגיד כן ולאשיאמרנהלישראל.
translation: And I will precede what I explained above (in Parashat Shemot) regarding the verse "And Moses said to God, 'Here I am, I am going to the children of Israel, and they will say to me, What is His name? What shall I say to them?'" And God said to Moses, "I will be that I will be," etc. The sages expounded in the Midrash that He revealed to him the secret of the Ineffable Name, and so too wrote the Ramban and the Ra'avad and all the commentators, and immediately afterward it is written, "And you shall say to the children of Israel, 'I will be has sent me to you.'" And the explanation is that even though He revealed to Moses, His servant, the secret of the Name, He returned to say that it is only the mention of the Name, etc. But what I added to reveal to you that "I will be" is not to be said, thus it is concluded. And similarly, Rashi wrote in a parenthesis that since then it was His intention in saying "I will be that I will be" to reveal it only to Moses and not to say it to Israel. However, the commentators wondered why Moses asked the Holy One, Blessed be He, what he should say to them, and if so, His first response in the statement "I will be that I will be" is not relevant to the question, for He revealed it only to Moses and not to say it to Israel.
summary: בקטע זה מדבר רבי יואל על השיחה בין משה לקב"ה, שבה גילה לו את סוד שם המפורש "אֶהְיֶה אֲשֶׁר אֶהְיֶה". הוא מסביר כי השם הזה נועד להיות ידוע רק למשה ולא לישראל, מה שמעורר שאלות על משמעות השם בהקשר של שליחותו של משה. המדרש והפרשנים מדגישים את החשיבות של השם בהבנת הקשר בין הקב"ה לעם ישראל, ואת המורכבות שבמסירת המידע הזה. בסופו של דבר, יש כאן הדגשה על הקשר האישי והייחודי בין משה לאלוהים, ועל כך שהמסר לעם ישראל הוא שונה מההבנה העמוקה שניתנה למשה.

passage_content: ופירשתיעפ"י אמרם ז"לבזוה"קכימשרע"ההוא הגואל אשר גאל את אבותינו והוא יהי' הגואל גם לעתיד, (עיין בדבריהאוהחה"קבפ' ויחי עה"פ אסרי לגפן עיי"ש,) גם אמרו רז"ל שהי'משרע"המצפה שיהי'תקוןהשלם וגאולה נצחית מיד, ע"כ כששאל ואמרו לו מה שמו מה אומר אליהם,היתהכוונת שאלתו סובב עלהבחי' שיזכו ישראל בעת גאולה העתידה, וע"ז השיב לו הקב"ה אקי' אשר אקי' וגילה לו סוד שם המפורש, ע"ד שימסרנו לישראל בגאולה העתידה, כמ"שבתנחומאהנ"לדלעתידלכל ישראל אני מודיע שמי, ועוד אמר אליוית' כה תאמרלבנ"יאקי' שלחני אליכם, ופי' כה עכשיו, ע"דשאמה"כוהנה לא שמעת עד כה, והודיעוית' שלא הגיע עדיין הזמן לגלות להםדבעוה"זהעלימהו כתיב (עיי"ש בדברינו לעיל ביתר ביאור).
translation: And it is explained according to what they said, may their memory be blessed, in the Zohar that Moshe Rabbeinu is the Redeemer who redeemed our forefathers, and he will be the Redeemer also in the future (see in the words of the holy Baal HaTanya in Parshat Vayechi on the verse "Bind the vine"), and our sages also said that Moshe Rabbeinu was anticipating that there would be a complete rectification and eternal redemption immediately. Therefore, when he asked and they said to him, "What is His name? What shall I say to them?" his question was focused on the aspect that Israel should merit at the time of the future redemption. And to this, the Holy One, blessed be He, answered him, "Ehyeh Asher Ehyeh," and revealed to him the secret of the Ineffable Name, in the manner that it will be given to Israel in the future redemption, as it is said in the Tanchuma that in the future I will inform all of Israel of My Name. And He also said to him, "Thus shall you say to the children of Israel, 'Ehyeh has sent me to you,'" and it means "thus now," in the manner that it is written, "And behold, you have not heard until now," and He informed him that the time has not yet come to reveal to them this matter, as it is written (see there in our words above with more explanation).
summary: The passage discusses the connection between Moses as the redeemer of the Jewish people and the future redemption, emphasizing that the same divine presence that redeemed the ancestors will also redeem them in the future. It highlights the anticipation of a complete and eternal redemption, with Moses's inquiry about God's name reflecting a deeper concern for the spiritual readiness of the Israelites for this future redemption. God's response, revealing the ineffable name, signifies a promise of eventual revelation and connection to the divine, indicating that the time for this revelation has not yet arrived. This underscores the Hasidic belief in the unfolding of divine plans and the importance of spiritual preparation for redemption.

passage_content: ובזהיתבאר דברי המסורה לכן אמור לבני ישראל אני ד', לכן אמור הנני נותן לו את בריתי שלו'עפי"דהתרגוםיוב"עשםדקאיעל בחי' גאולה העתידה, ופי' הכתובואעבדיני' מלאך קיימאוייחילחיי עלמא למבשרהגאולתאבסוףיומיאעיי"ש,וז"פהמסורה לכן אמורלבנ"יאני ד', ולפי בחינתם של עכשיו הכוונהלאמרלהם הזכרת השם בלבד,ובבחי' העלימהו כמ"שהאוהחה"ק, ויש בו עוד כוונה נוספת על בחי' העתיד, לכן אמור לבני ישראל אני ד' לגלות להם סוד שם המפורש, אלא שעדיין לא הגיע זמנה באותה שעה ואימתי יזכו ישראללזה לכן אמור הנני נותן לו את בריתי שלו', כשיבוא אלי' לבשר הגאולה בסוףיומיאומלאה הארץ דעה את ד', אז יתקיים לכן אמור לבני ישראל אני ד' על בחי' הרוממה, ולכל ישראל יודיע השי"ת סוד שם המפורש, ובזה יתבאר דברי הפרקידר"אהנ"ל (בקושיאב') כשראו העליונים שמסר הקב"ה סוד המפורשלמשרע"ה, ענו ואמרו בא"י חונן הדעת, שהשיגומה"ששבחי' זו נמסרהלמשרע"הע"מ לגלותו לישראל לעתידכשיהי' מלאה הארץדיעהוכל ישראל יהיו ראויים להשגה זו, וע"כ ענו ואמרו בא"י חונן הדעת, על אותההבחי' שיתרבה הדעת ולא ילמדו עוד איש את רעהו, כי כולם ידעו את ד'כמאמה"כ.
translation: And in this it will be clarified the words of the Masorah, therefore say to the children of Israel, I am the Lord. Therefore say, behold, I am giving him his covenant, according to the translation of "I will place my name upon the children of Israel" regarding the aspect of the future redemption. And the explanation of the verse, "And they shall serve me," is that the angel exists, and I will hope for the life of the world to announce the redemption at the end of days. And this is the Masorah, therefore say to the children of Israel, I am the Lord. And according to their current state, the intention is to tell them the mention of the name alone, and in the aspect of concealment, as is known in the holy teachings. And there is another intention regarding the aspect of the future, therefore say to the children of Israel, I am the Lord, to reveal to them the secret of the explicit name, but the time for this has not yet arrived. And when will Israel merit this? Therefore say, behold, I am giving him his covenant, when he comes to announce the redemption at the end of days, and the earth will be filled with the knowledge of the Lord. Then it will be fulfilled, therefore say to the children of Israel, I am the Lord, in the aspect of the exalted. And the Holy One, blessed be He, will inform all of Israel of the secret of the explicit name. And in this, the words of the aforementioned chapter will be clarified, as when the higher realms saw that the Holy One, blessed be He, entrusted the secret of the explicit name to Moshe Rabbeinu, they responded and said, "Blessed are You, who grants knowledge," for he attained that this aspect was given to Moshe Rabbeinu in order to reveal it to Israel in the future when the earth will be filled with the knowledge of the Lord, and all Israel will be worthy of this attainment. Therefore, they responded and said, "Blessed are You, who grants knowledge," regarding that aspect that knowledge will increase and they will no longer teach each man his neighbor, for they will all know the Lord, as it is written.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine revelation and the future redemption of Israel, emphasizing the importance of the Name of God and the secret of the Tetragrammaton. It highlights that while the full understanding of this sacred name has not yet been revealed, it will be granted to Israel in the future when they are worthy, leading to a universal knowledge of God. The text reflects on the connection between the present state of Israel and their future potential, suggesting that the ultimate revelation will coincide with the fulfillment of God's covenant. The acknowledgment of God's wisdom and the promise of a time when all will know Him underscores the transformative nature of this future redemption.

passage_content: ויתבארעוד בהקדם דבריהגמ' (ב"ב דף ט' ע"א)א"ראלעזר גדול המעשה יותר מן העושה שנאמר (ישעי' ל"ב) והי' מעשה הצדקה שלו' ועבודת הצדקה השקט ובטח עד עולם,פרש"ימעשה הצדקה, טורח המעשים את חבריהםמדלאכתיבוהיתההצדקה שלו' עכ"ל רש"י ז"ל, ובעין יעקב הביאו בשםהריטב"אז"לדהשקטובטח הוא הרווחה קצת, אבל השלו' הוא דבר של טובה גמור עכ"ל, אמנם עדיין צ"ב לבאר ההבדל ביניהם, וגם השקט ובטח הוא בחי' של שלו', ומהו רבותי'דהשלו' שנתברך בו המעשה יתר על העושה, גם הקשו המפרשים ממ"ד בסנהדרין (דף צ"ט ע"ב)א"ראבהו כל המעשה אתחבירולדבר מצוה מעלה עליו הכתוב כאלועשאה, שנא' ומטך אשר הכית וגו', וכי משה הכהו והלא אהרן הכהן, אלא לומר לך כל המעשה אתחבירווגו' כאלועשאה, הרי מבואר שםדשוויןהם, וכאן אמרודהמעשהגדול יותר מן העושה.
translation: And it will be further explained in advance the words of the Gemara (Baba Batra 9a) that "Rabbi Eliezer said: The deed is greater than the doer, as it is said (Isaiah 32:17) 'And the work of righteousness shall be peace, and the effect of righteousness quietness and assurance forever.' Rashi explains 'the work of righteousness' refers to the effort of the deeds for their companions, as it does not say 'and the righteousness shall be peace.' Thus far Rashi, may his memory be blessed. And in Ein Yaakov, it is brought in the name of the Ritva, may his memory be blessed, that 'quietness and assurance' is a certain degree of relief, but 'peace' is a matter of complete goodness. Thus far. However, it is still necessary to clarify the difference between them, and also 'quietness and assurance' is a form of 'peace.' What is the meaning, my masters, of the 'peace' with which the deed is blessed more than the doer? The commentators also question from the statement in Sanhedrin (99b) that 'Rabbi Abba said: All the deeds of a friend for a matter of mitzvah, the verse considers it as if he did it himself,' as it is said, 'And your rod, with which you struck...' But did Moses strike him? Was it not Aaron the priest? Rather, it is to tell you that all the deeds of a friend are considered as if he did it himself. It is clear there that they are equal, and here it is said that the deed is greater than the doer.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between the act of charity (מעשה צדקה) and the individual performing it, emphasizing that the act itself holds greater significance than the doer. It references the Talmud and various commentaries to illustrate that while both the act and the actor are valued, the essence of the act embodies a deeper spiritual quality, represented by the concepts of peace (שלו') and security (שקט ובטח). The text invites reflection on the nature of actions and intentions in the realm of divine service, suggesting that the merit of the act transcends the individual.
