passage_content: ואפ"לעפי"דהגמ' (ב"מל"ב ע"ב) אוהב לפרוק ושונא לטעון מצוה בשונא כדילכוףאת יצרו, ואי ס"ד צער בע"ח דאורייתא הא עדיף לי', ותירצודאפ"הכדילכוףאת יצרו עדיף עכ"דהגמ', מבואר דאףדפריקהמצוותה גדולהדצערבע"ח דאורייתא, מ"מ טעינה לשונא עדיף מיני', כדילכוףאת יצרו,ומכ"שבב' מצות שבחינתןשוה, ובא' מהםאיתבי' כפיית היצר טפי האעדיפא, והנה כאו"א יש לויצה"רלפי בחינתו,ואמרז"לכל הגדולמחבירויצרוגדול הימנו. אמנם העושה מצוה לעצמו אין לו רק התנגדותמיצה"רשלו, אבל המעשה אתחבירולדבר מצוה יש לו התנגדות מב' יצרים,יצה"רשלומנגדוומסיתו לחדול ולמנוע מזה, ואם כבר נתגבר עליצה"רשלו, אז נפגע בהתנגדותיצה"רשלחבירווע"כ גדול המעשה יותר מן העושה,דיצראתקיף לי' טפיואכפיאליצראטפי עדיף, ומתורץ סתירתהגמ' הנ"ל,דמ"דבסנהדריןדהמעשהאתחבירולדבר מצוה מעלה עליו הכתוב כאלועשאה, היינודבעצםפעולתהמצוהשווין הם המעשה והעושה, ואף שהמעשה לא קיימה בפועל רק גורם להביא אתחבירולידי קיוםהמצוה, מעלה עליו הכתוב כאלועשאהונחשב לו כאלו קייםהמצוהבפועל המעשה, אמנם אף שבעצם הפעולות שווין הם, מ"מאכפיאליצראטפי עדיף ובזה גדול המעשה על העושה דאית בי' כפיית היצר טפי.
translation: And even though the Gemara (in "Malachim Bet" 2:2) states that one who loves to unload and hates to load is fulfilling a mitzvah by opposing his evil inclination, and if it were to be understood that causing pain to an animal is a Torah prohibition, it would be preferable to me, and it is explained that in order to subdue his evil inclination, it is indeed preferable. The Gemara clarifies that even though unloading is a great mitzvah compared to causing pain to an animal, nonetheless, loading for a hater is preferable, as it serves to subdue his evil inclination. Moreover, in two mitzvot where their essence is equal, and in one of them the subjugation of the inclination is more pronounced, that one is preferable. And behold, each person has an evil inclination according to his level, and our sages have said that the greater one is than his friend, the greater his evil inclination is against him. However, one who performs a mitzvah for himself only faces the opposition of his own evil inclination, but one who performs an act for a friend in the name of a mitzvah faces opposition from both inclinations: his own evil inclination that opposes him and incites him to cease and refrain from this. And if he has already overcome his own evil inclination, then he is affected by the opposition of his friend's evil inclination, and thus the act is greater than the doer, for the evil inclination is stronger against him, and to subdue the evil inclination is indeed preferable. This resolves the contradiction in the aforementioned Gemara, that one who performs an act for a friend in the name of a mitzvah is considered as if he has done it himself, meaning that in essence, the act and the doer are equal; and even though the act has not been fulfilled in practice, it causes the friend to fulfill the mitzvah, and the verse considers it as if he has fulfilled the mitzvah in practice. However, even though in essence the actions are equal, the subjugation of the evil inclination is indeed preferable, and in this way, the act is greater than the doer, as it contains a greater subjugation of the inclination.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of performing mitzvot (commandments) in the context of overcoming one's evil inclination (yetzer hara). It emphasizes that while both the act of fulfilling a commandment and the intention behind it are important, the struggle against the yetzer hara, especially when it involves influencing others to perform mitzvot, elevates the act. The text highlights that the greater the challenge posed by the yetzer hara, the more valuable the action becomes, suggesting that the collective effort to fulfill commandments, even indirectly, is considered as if one has performed the mitzvah themselves. Ultimately, it underscores the idea that the spiritual weight of an action is enhanced by the resistance faced in its execution.

passage_content: והנהאמרו רז"ל זבחים (ק"א ע"ב) לאנתכהןפנחס עד ששם שלו' בין השבטיםוכו',ואפ"להכוונה בזהדהנהכשהרג פנחס לזמרי נתעורר עליו שנאה גדולהכאמרז"ל(סוטה מ"ג) שהיו השבטיםמבזיןאותו הראיתם בןפוטיזהוכו', ודרך הטבע כך הואדהמוכיחומקנא בעושי רע יש לו התנגדות גדול מאנשים שאינם מהוגנים, וממשיכים לדעתם גם כשרים להצטרף עמהם,משא"כמי שאינו מוכיח ומוחה בעושי רעה יש לו מנוחה והשקטכאמרז"לכתובות (ק"ה ע"ב) אמראבייהאי צורבאמרבנןדמרחמיןלי' בני מתא לאו משוםדמעלוטפי אלא משום דלא מוכח להו במילי דשמיא, ורגיל אני לפרשבמאמה"כ(משלי כ"ח) מוכיח אדם אחרי חן ימצא וגו',דלכאורהמהו ימצא ואם זהו שכרושיתןהקב"ה חנו בעיני בנ"א,הול"לחן ישיגהו, אמנם מי שאינו מוכיח יש לו חן גם בדרך הטבע והכלנוחיןממנו,משא"כהמוכיח והמוחה, והנה מציאה הוא מה שבא בהיסח הדעת ולא עלה על הדעת להשיגו,וז"שהכ' מוכיח אדם אחרי חן ימצא, שלבסוף תשיגהו החןבבחי' מציאה והיפך הטבע, ע"ישהבוי"תיתןחנו בעיני בנ"א ויכירו כי לטובתםנתכוין,ועד"זהי' בפנחס כשעשה מעשה הקנאותנתגרועליו כל השבטים,ודנוהוכמחרחר ריב ובעל מחלוקת, ע"כ נתן הקב"ה מדת שכרו הנני נותן לו את בריתי שלו', שיכירו כל ישראל שהוא איש שלו', ועשה שלו' בין ישראל לאביהם שבשמים, ובימי יהושע עשה שלו' בין השבטיםכפרש"יבגמ'דזבחיםהנ"ל,דבניגד ובני ראובן בנו את המזבח בעבר הירדן ובקשו שאר השבטים לעלות עליהם לצבא ושלחו את פנחס לדבר עמהם, ואז הכירו כל ישראל שהוא בעל השלו'.
translation: And behold, our Sages of blessed memory said in Zevachim (101b) regarding Pinchas, that he was appointed a priest only after he brought peace among the tribes, etc. And even so, when Pinchas killed Zimri, a great hatred arose against him, as our Sages said (Sotah 43b) that the tribes were belittling him, saying, "You have seen the son of Puti," etc. And it is natural that one who rebukes and is zealous against evildoers faces great opposition from those who are not upright, and even the righteous join in their opinion. However, one who does not rebuke and protest against wrongdoing has peace and quiet, as our Sages said in Ketubot (105b), that Rabbi Abba said, "This scholar, who is merciful to the people of the town, is not because he is more righteous, but because he does not rebuke them in matters of Heaven." And I am accustomed to explain with the verse (Proverbs 28) "A man who rebukes will find favor," etc. At first glance, what does "will find" mean? If this is the reward that the Holy One, blessed be He, grants him favor in the eyes of people, it should have said, "Favor will be given to him." However, one who does not rebuke has favor also by nature, and everyone is at ease with him. In contrast, the one who rebukes and protests, and behold, finding favor is what comes unexpectedly and was not thought of to be attained. And this is what is written, "A man who rebukes will find favor," that in the end, favor will come to him in the manner of a finding, which is contrary to nature, as it is written, "And He will give you favor in the eyes of people," and they will recognize that he intends for their good. And so it was with Pinchas; when he acted with zeal, all the tribes rose against him, and he was judged as a stirrer of strife and a bearer of controversy. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, granted him the measure of reward, "Behold, I give him My covenant of peace," so that all of Israel would recognize that he is a man of peace, and he made peace between Israel and their Father in Heaven. And in the days of Joshua, he made peace among the tribes, as explained in the aforementioned Gemara in Zevachim, that when the children of Reuben built the altar across the Jordan, the other tribes sought to go to war against them and sent Pinchas to speak with them. Then all of Israel recognized that he was the one who brought peace.
summary: The passage discusses the challenges faced by those who rebuke wrongdoing, exemplified by Pinchas, who faced significant opposition from the tribes after his zealous act against Zimri. It highlights the natural resistance that arises against those who call out evil, contrasting it with the relative peace enjoyed by those who remain silent. The text emphasizes that true merit and recognition come to the one who rebukes, as God rewards Pinchas with a covenant of peace, affirming his role as a peacemaker among the tribes of Israel. Ultimately, it illustrates the divine acknowledgment of those who act for the sake of righteousness, even amidst societal backlash.

passage_content: ובזהיתבארמאמה"כ(ישעי' ל"ב) והי' מעשה הצדקה שלו' ועבודת הצדקה השקט ובטח,דהנההעושה צדקה בעצמו ואינו מעשה את אחרים יש לו השקט ובטח גם בדרך הטבע, ואין בנ"א מתנגדים למעשיו אםיתןמכספו והונו, אבל המעשה אתחבירולדבר מצוהוכופהועל הצדקה, לזה יש לו התנגדות גדול בדרך הטבע, וע"כ הוצרך לברכת השלו' והבטיחוהבוי"תוהי' מעשה הצדקה שלו', שלבסוף תשיגהו השלו' וחן ימצא בעיני בנ"א,ולז"ארז"ל גדול המעשה יותר מן העושה שנא' והי' מעשה הצדקה שלו' ועבודת הצדקה השקט ובטח וגו', ואפשרדהשקטובטח ג"כ הוא בחי' שלו', אבל זו הוא בדרך הטבע, וגדול המעשה שניתנה לו השלו' במתת השי"ת למעלה מן הטבע ואין לו גבולדכלפעולותיוית' נצחיים ובלי תכלית.
translation: And this is explained in the verse (Isaiah 32:17) "And the work of righteousness shall be peace, and the service of righteousness, quietness and assurance." Behold, one who does charity by himself and does not involve others has peace and assurance even in a natural way, and people do not oppose his actions if he gives of his money and wealth. However, one who involves others in the mitzvah and compels them towards charity faces great opposition in a natural way. Therefore, he needs the blessing of peace, and it is promised that "the work of righteousness shall be his," so that in the end, peace will reach him, and he will find favor in the eyes of people. And as our sages said, "The work is greater than the doer," as it is stated, "And the work of righteousness shall be peace, and the service of righteousness, quietness and assurance," etc. It is possible that the quietness and assurance also represent a form of peace, but this is in a natural way. And the greatness of the work is that he is granted peace as a gift from the Blessed Creator, above nature, and he has no limit to all his actions, which are eternal and without end.
summary: The passage emphasizes the significance of performing acts of charity (tzedakah) both personally and collectively, highlighting that individual acts bring peace and security in a natural sense, while communal efforts face greater opposition. It suggests that true fulfillment and divine blessing come from the collective act of charity, which transcends natural limitations. The text underscores the idea that the act of charity itself holds greater value than the individual performing it, and that divine peace and favor are bestowed upon those who engage in such acts, elevating them beyond the confines of the natural world. Ultimately, it conveys that the impact of these charitable deeds is eternal and limitless.

passage_content: ויתבארלדרכנו דברי המסורה לכן אמורלבנ"יאני ד' לכן אמור הנני נותן לו את בריתי שלו'דהנהמשרע"הבא אלבנ"יוהוכיחם לעשות תשובה ולהפריש מע"ז, אמנם ראה התנגדות גדול לעומתו מהערב רב שאמרו לו ירא ד' עליכם וישפוט וגו' וגםבנ"ילא שמעו אליו כמ"ש ולא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה, ע"כ התמרמרמשרע"הואמר למה זה שלחתני, מה יהי' תכלית השליחות אם לא יצליח להחזיר את ישראל למוטב, ע"כ הבטיחוהבוי"תשלבסוף ימצאו דבריו חן בעיניהם ויעשו תשובה,וז"שלכן אמור לבני ישראל אני ד', שתכריז ותאמר שיש בורא עולם משגיח על כל מעשה בנ"א, ותוכיחם להפריש מע"ז ותועבת מצרים. וא"ת מה תועלת והןבנ"ילא שמעו אלי,כאמרז"לשהי' קשה בעיניהם להפריש מןהע"ז, ע"ז אמר לכן אמור הנני נותן לו את בריתי שלו', שזו ברכה כוללת לכל המעשה אתחבירולדבר מצוה,שהבוי"תנותן לו ברכת השלו' למעלה מן הטבע ולבסוף יתקרבו בנ"א לדעתו ויכירו בטובתו, וכדרך שנתברך פנחס במתנה זו, וזה הי' בחי' נחמה ותשובהלמשרע"השלבסוף ישמעו אליובנ"יויעשו תשובה, ובזכות זה יגאלו מן הגלות.
translation: And it will be clarified through our path the words of the tradition, therefore say to the children of Israel, I am the Lord. Therefore say, behold, I am giving him his covenant. Behold, Moshe Rabbeinu came to the children of Israel and admonished them to repent and to separate from idolatry. However, he saw great opposition against him from the mixed multitude who said to him, "Fear the Lord upon you and He will judge," etc., and also the children of Israel did not listen to him, as it is said, "and they did not listen to Moshe because of shortness of spirit and hard work." Therefore, Moshe Rabbeinu was distressed and said, "Why have You sent me? What will be the purpose of the mission if I do not succeed in bringing Israel back to the right path?" Therefore, they promised him that in the end, his words would find favor in their eyes and they would repent. And this is why He said to the children of Israel, "I am the Lord," to proclaim and say that there is a Creator of the world who oversees all the actions of man, and to admonish them to separate from idolatry and the abominations of Egypt. And you might ask, what benefit is there if the children of Israel do not listen to me, as our sages have said that it was difficult in their eyes to separate from idolatry? To this, He said, "Therefore say, behold, I am giving him his covenant," which is a blessing that encompasses all actions of the community and the performance of a commandment, that the Holy One, Blessed be He, will grant him the blessing of peace above nature, and in the end, people will draw near to His knowledge and recognize His goodness, in the way that Pinchas was blessed with this gift. And this was a form of comfort and repentance for Moshe Rabbeinu, that in the end, they will listen to me and the children of Israel will repent, and through this merit, they will be redeemed from the exile.
summary: The passage emphasizes the struggle of Moses in his mission to lead the Israelites away from idolatry and towards repentance, despite facing significant opposition from the mixed multitude and the Israelites' own hardships. It highlights the assurance from the Divine that ultimately, Moses' words will find favor and lead the people to return to God. The text underscores the importance of proclaiming God's sovereignty and the promise of a covenant that brings blessings beyond natural limitations, ultimately leading to redemption from exile. This reflects a deep theological insight into the relationship between divine guidance, human agency, and the transformative power of repentance.

passage_content: עודאפ"לאמרם ז"ל גדול המעשה יותר מן העושה,דלכאורהטעמא בעי,וממנ"פאםמייריכשהמעשה נתינתו גדולה מן העושה, הרי תנינןהכללפי רוב המעשה,ובכה"גגם העושה פעולתו גדולה, גםאמרז"לא' המרבה וא' הממעיט ובלבדשיכויןלבו לשמים ולמה יוגדל המעשה על העושה, ואםמייריבשנתינתןשווים א"כ מדוע יגרע פעולתו של העושה מהמעשה, וראוי להיות שניהם שווין, ויתבארעפי"דהגמ'ב"מ(נ"ח ע"ב) גדול אונאת דברים מאונאת ממון, שזה בגופו וזה בממונו, הרידצעראדגופאקשהמצעראדממונו,וקיי"לדלפי צערא אגרא, ולזה גדול המעשה יותר מן העושה שזה בגופו וזה בממונו. נוסף לזה שהמעשה אחרים לדבר מצוה סובל גם מאונאת דברים, וימצא רבים הקמים עליו לקנטרו בדברים ולהעליל עליו עלילות וחשדים, והוא סובל כ"ז עבור פעולתהמצוה, ע"כ גדול המעשה יותר מן העושה, כיאיתבי' גם אונאת דבריםוצעראדגופא,ובעוה"רעכשיו גם העושה סובל מאונאת דברים, והנותן צדקה להחזקת ת"ת על טהרת הקודש וברוח ישראל סבא, אין דעת העולם נוחה הימנו, וכמ"ש ות"ת "כנגד" כולם,שבעוה"רזהו בהתנגדות כולם, אעפ"כ המעשה יגיע לו אונאת דברים יותר וע"כ גדול המעשה על העושה, השי"ת יעזור לנו בדור הזהשהנסיונותגדולים מאוד, שנוכל להרבות פעלים עבור קיוםהתוה"ק, ולכל המשתתפים בפעולה זו העושים והמעשיםיתןלהםהבוכ"עשפע ברכה והצלחה, ונזכה להרבותכבוד שמים ותורה וטהרה וקדושה בישראל, ובמהרה נינצל מכל צרה וצוקה ונזכה כולנו יחד לראות בישועת ישראל ושמחתן ולקבל פני משיח צדקינו בקדושה ובטהרה בשמחה ובנחת בהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו בב"א.
translation:
Furthermore, it is said by our sages, of blessed memory, that the deed is greater than the doer. This requires explanation, for if the act of giving is greater than the doer, then we have a principle according to the majority of the deed, and in such a case, the doer's action is also significant. It is also stated that one who increases and one who decreases, provided their heart is directed towards Heaven, and why should the deed be greater than the doer? If we argue that their giving is equal, then why should the doer's action be diminished compared to the deed? It would be appropriate for both to be equal. 

This can be clarified according to the Gemara in Bava Metzia (58b), which states that the pain of verbal abuse is greater than the pain of monetary loss, for one affects the body and the other affects one's money. We hold that according to the pain, there is a reward. Therefore, the deed is greater than the doer, as one affects the body and the other affects money. 

In addition to this, the act of others for the sake of a mitzvah also suffers from verbal abuse, and many rise against him to provoke him with words and to slander him with accusations and suspicions, and he endures all this for the sake of the mitzvah's action. Thus, the deed is greater than the doer, for it is established that there is also verbal abuse and bodily pain, and in our evil times, the doer also suffers from verbal abuse. 

And one who gives charity to support a Torah institution in purity and in the spirit of our forefathers, the opinion of the world is not favorable towards him, as it is said that Torah study is "against" all of them. In this evil time, this is in opposition to all, yet the deed will bring upon him greater verbal abuse, and therefore the deed is greater than the doer. May the Holy One, blessed be He, help us in this generation where the trials are very great, that we may increase our actions for the preservation of the Holy Torah. 

And to all those participating in this action, both the doers and the deeds, may they be granted abundant blessing and success. May we merit to increase the honor of Heaven, Torah, purity, and holiness in Israel, and may we quickly be saved from all trouble and distress, and may we all together merit to see the salvation of Israel and their joy, and to greet our righteous Messiah in holiness and purity, with joy and tranquility, with the revelation of the honor of Heaven upon us, speedily and in our days.
summary: The passage emphasizes the Hasidic teaching that the act of performing a mitzvah (commandment) holds greater significance than the individual performing it, highlighting the intrinsic value of the deed itself. It discusses the concept of suffering and challenges faced by those who engage in good deeds, particularly in the face of verbal slander and societal opposition. The text underscores that despite the hardships, the merit of the action outweighs the personal struggles of the doer, and it calls for divine assistance to strengthen the commitment to Torah and mitzvot in a time of great trials. Ultimately, it expresses hope for collective redemption and the coming of the Messiah, emphasizing the importance of unity and spiritual elevation in the Jewish community.

passage_content: וידבראלקיםאל משה ויאמר אליו אני ה' דקדקו המפרשים שהתחיל הכתוב וידבר לשון קשות ובשםאלקיםשהוא מדת הדין, וסיים ויאמר אמירה רכה ובשם הוי' שהוא רחמים.
translation: And God spoke to Moses and said to him, "I am the Lord." The commentators noted that the verse begins with "And God spoke," which is a language of severity and is in the name of God as Elokim, which represents the attribute of judgment, and it concludes with "and said," which is a gentle expression and is in the name of Havayah, which represents mercy.
summary: The passage highlights the contrast between the divine names used in God's communication with Moses, emphasizing the transition from the name "Elohim," associated with strict judgment, to "Hashem," representing mercy. This shift illustrates the balance between justice and compassion in divine interactions. The use of harsh language at the beginning and a gentle tone at the end reflects the complexity of God's relationship with humanity, where both attributes coexist and are essential for understanding divine will. Ultimately, it underscores the Hasidic belief in the importance of mercy prevailing over judgment.

summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, God addresses an individual, highlighting the importance of humility and the consequences of being overly concerned with words. This reflects a key Hasidic concept that despite present challenges, the divine plan ensures a favorable conclusion for Israel, rooted in faith and trust in God's overarching goodness.

passage_content: ג)פרשת שמות ויאמר ה' אל משה עתה תראה אשר אעשה לפרעה וגו',פירש"ימדברי רז"ל העשוי לפרעה תראה ולא העשוי למלכי ז' אומות כשאביאם לארץובמד"ר(פ' ה' סי' כ"ג) מכאן אתה למד שנטל משה עכשיו את הדין שלא יכנס לארץ, וקשה הלא מפורש בתורה שעבור חטא מי מריבה נגזר עליו שלא יכנס לארץ, ומבואר במדרשי חז"ל שאף חטא זהנסתבבלובבחי' נורא עלילה, ולפי האמת הי' מוכרחשמרע"הישארבמדבר לסיבת עוד טעמים אחרים, ועכ"פ מפורש בתורה שחטא מי מריבההיתהסיבה לגזירה ההוא,וצ"באומרם ז"ל מכאן נטל משה את הדין שלא יכנס לארץ.
translation: 3) In the portion of Shemot, and the Lord said to Moses, "Now you will see what I will do to Pharaoh," etc. The sages explained: "What is prepared for Pharaoh you will see, but not what is prepared for the kings of the seven nations when I bring them to the land." And in the Midrash (Parashat Ha'azinu, section 23) it is learned from here that Moses now took upon himself the decree that he would not enter the land. And it is difficult, for it is explicitly stated in the Torah that because of the sin of the waters of Meribah it was decreed upon him that he would not enter the land. And it is clarified in the Midrashim of our sages that even this sin was entangled in a terrible accusation. And in truth, it would have been appropriate for Moses to remain in the wilderness for other reasons as well. Nevertheless, it is explicitly stated in the Torah that the sin of the waters of Meribah was the reason for that decree. And it is necessary to understand their saying that from here Moses took upon himself the decree that he would not enter the land.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the divine decree against Moses entering the Promised Land, emphasizing that it was not solely due to the sin of the waters of Meribah, but also connected to a broader understanding of divine justice and the unique role of Moses. The text highlights that while Moses was chosen to confront Pharaoh, he was also burdened with the weight of judgment, reflecting the complexity of leadership and the consequences of actions. The Hasidic insight suggests that even great leaders like Moses are subject to divine will and the intricate interplay of sin and redemption. Ultimately, the passage underscores the profound theological theme of accountability and the multifaceted nature of divine decrees.

passage_content: ד)אני שמעתי את נאקתבנ"יאשר מצרים מעבידים אותם ואזכור את בריתי,יל"דאומרו ואזכור בלשון עתיד. וכל הפרשה נאמרה בלשון עבר וגםהקימותיוגו' וגם אני שמעתי וגו' וכמו"כהול"לוזכרתי את בריתי,ובספה"קאגראדכלהדקדק דהרי זכירת הבריתהיתההסיבה ששמע הקב"ה את נאקתם, א"כ טרם שמע את נאקתם כבר זכר את הבריתוהול"לזכרתי את בריתי.
translation: I heard the groaning of the children of Israel in Egypt, who are being enslaved, and I will remember My covenant. It is said in the future tense. And the entire section is stated in the past tense, including "and I have established" and "and I have heard," and similarly, it should have said "I remembered My covenant." And in the holy books, it is emphasized that the remembrance of the covenant was the reason that the Holy One, blessed be He, heard their groaning. Therefore, before He heard their groaning, He had already remembered the covenant, and it should have said "I remembered My covenant."
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the significance of God's remembrance of the covenant in relation to the suffering of the Israelites in Egypt. The use of the future tense "וזכור" (and I will remember) suggests a proactive divine engagement, indicating that God's remembrance of the covenant is the reason He hears their cries. This highlights the Hasidic concept of God's ongoing relationship with His people, emphasizing that divine intervention is rooted in the eternal bond established through the covenant. The passage underscores the idea that God's awareness and response to suffering are intrinsically linked to His commitment to the covenant.

passage_content: ונל"פבהקדם דברי ק"ז הייטב לבזלה"ה(פ' תולדות) לבאר אמרם ז"ל (יבמות ס"ד ע"א) מפני מה הי' אבותינו עקורים מפני שהקב"המתאוהלתפלתן של צדיקים,עפימ"שהזוה"קוז"ל כ' שניןאשתהייצחק עםאתתי' ולאאולידתעדדצליצלותי', בגיןדקוב"האתרעיבצלותהוןדצדיקייא, מאי טעמא (פי' המקדש מלך מ"ט לאיקוייםבהם והי' טרם יקראו ואני אענה, ע"ז אמר) בגיןדיתרביויתוסף רבותקודשאמאןדאצטרךבצלותהוןדצדיקייאעכ"ד, (ופי'המקד"משמרויחיםבזה שמתרבה השפע גם לזולתם, למי שצריך לאותו ענין שהם מתפללים עיי"ש) למה זה דומה לצינור שנסתם, ואם יבוא אחד ויפתחנו וינקנו שוב הוא פתוח לכל, ומי שצריך למי הישועה ישאב בששון מאותו הצינור,וכעניןדכתיבושאבתם וגו'ממעיניהישועה, וביארו המפורשים כי ישועת צדיקים הוא כמו מעיין הנובע ישועה לכל מיד ולדורות, ולכן הקב"המתאוהלתפלתן כדי שע"י תפלתן יפתח הצינור והמעיין לכל מי שצריך לאותו דבר עכ"ל ק"ז הייטב לבזלה"ה.
translation: And it is explained in the beginning of the words of K.Z. that it is good to mention the name of the Holy One, blessed be He (Parashat Toldot) to clarify what our Sages, of blessed memory, said (Yevamot 64a) regarding why our forefathers were barren: because the Holy One, blessed be He, desires the prayers of the righteous. As the Zohar states, "For seven years, Rivka was with Yitzchak and did not give birth until he prayed," because the Holy One, blessed be He, is eager for the prayers of the righteous. What is the reason? (As explained in the Mikdash Melech, that it is for the fulfillment of the verse, "Before they call, I will answer," and regarding this it is said) because through their prayers, the Holy One, blessed be He, increases the holiness of the righteous, as it is written, "And you shall draw water with joy from the wells of salvation." The commentators explain that the salvation of the righteous is like a spring that flows forth salvation for all, immediately and for generations. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, desires their prayers so that through their prayers, the pipe and the spring will be opened for all who need that matter. Thus, it is good to mention the name of the Holy One, blessed be He.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that God desires the prayers of the righteous, as their supplications can open channels of divine blessing for others. It references the idea that the prayers of the righteous act like a blocked pipe that, when cleared, allows for the flow of salvation and blessings to all in need. This is likened to a spring of water that provides sustenance and healing, emphasizing the communal impact of individual prayers. Ultimately, the text highlights the importance of the righteous in facilitating divine mercy and abundance for the broader community.

passage_content: ועד"זכל מעשה האבות וגלגולי סיבותיהם שסבלו צרותויסוריןוהתפללולהשי"תוהושיעם נפתח על ידיהם צינור הישועה לכל הזמנים, וכן מה שסבלו ישראל במצרים שעבוד קשה וצעקולהשי"תבתפלה וריחם הקב"ה עליהם. נפתח על ידם צינור השפעת ישועה לכל ימי גלותם שינצלו תמיד מיד המצירים אותם, ומקור הישועה לדורות נמשך מגאולת מצרים, וכמו שאמר המגיד אילו לא הוציא הקב"ה את אבותינו ממצרים הרי אנו ובנינו משועבדים היינו לפרעה במצרים, וכמו"כ גאולה העתידה ב"ב נמשך מגאולת מצרים שהוא המקור והשורש לכל הגאולות.
translation: And similarly, all the deeds of the Patriarchs and the cycles of their causes, who suffered troubles and afflictions and prayed to the Holy One, blessed be He, and He saved them, opened through them a channel of salvation for all times. Likewise, what Israel suffered in Egypt, hard servitude and their cries to the Holy One, blessed be He, in prayer, and the Holy One, blessed be He, had compassion on them. Through them, a channel of the flow of salvation was opened for all the days of their exile, that they would always be saved from those who oppress them, and the source of salvation for generations is drawn from the redemption of Egypt. As the Maggid said, if the Holy One, blessed be He, had not taken our forefathers out of Egypt, we and our children would be enslaved to Pharaoh in Egypt. Similarly, the future redemption, may it come speedily, is drawn from the redemption of Egypt, which is the source and root of all redemptions.
summary: The passage emphasizes the significance of the suffering and prayers of the patriarchs and the Israelites in Egypt, which opened a channel of salvation for all generations. It highlights that the hardships endured by the ancestors and their cries to God led to divine compassion and the establishment of a source of redemption that continues to benefit the Jewish people throughout their exiles. The text asserts that the future redemption is intrinsically linked to the redemption from Egypt, which serves as the foundational root for all subsequent salvations.

passage_content: ובזהפירשתי אמרינו הן גאלתי אתכם אחרית כראשית,דלכאורההריאמרז"למי נתלה במי קטן נתלה בגדול, וגאולה העתידה תהי' בחינתה גדולה ויתירה על כל הגאולות הקודמים, ואיך יתלו גאולה העתידה בראשונים לומר אחרית כראשית, אך מפני שגאולת מצריםהיתההשורש גם לגאולה העתידה,ובכחהתפלות שהתחננו ישראל להקב"ה בעת צרתם במצרים פתחו מעיין ישועה לגאולה העתידה, אף שתהי' גדולה במעלתה מ"מ תולה אותה בראשית מחמת שהוא הגורמת והשורש לגאולה העתידה,דלוליגאולת מצרים לא היויכוליןלזכותגם לגאולה העתידה, וזה שהשיב לו הקב"ה למשה על אומרו למה הרעתה לעם הזה, א"ל הקב"ה חייך יש לך לידע שנאמר טוב אחרית דבר מראשיתו, טובה אחריתן של ישראל ע"י הראשית שהי' להם במצרים, ויצמח מזה טובה וישועה לישראל בכל הדורות.
translation: In this explanation, I have stated that I redeemed you at the end as at the beginning. For it seems that the sages said, "Whoever is dependent on a small one is dependent on a great one," and the future redemption will be of a greater nature than all previous redemptions. How can the future redemption be compared to the earlier ones, saying "the end as the beginning"? However, because the redemption from Egypt was the root of the future redemption, and through the power of the prayers that the Israelites pleaded to the Holy One, Blessed be He, during their distress in Egypt, they opened a fountain of salvation for the future redemption. Even though it will be greater in its stature, it is still connected to the beginning because it is the cause and root of the future redemption. Without the redemption from Egypt, they would not have been able to merit the future redemption. This is what the Holy One, Blessed be He, replied to Moses when he said, "Why have You made this evil for this people?" The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him, "By your life, you should know that it is said, 'Better is the end of a matter than its beginning.' The goodness of the end for Israel comes through the beginning that they had in Egypt, and from this will sprout goodness and salvation for Israel in all generations.
summary: The passage emphasizes the connection between the redemption from Egypt and the future redemption, asserting that the former serves as the root for the latter. It highlights the idea that the prayers and supplications of the Israelites during their suffering in Egypt opened the wellspring of future salvation. Although the future redemption will be greater in its essence, it is intrinsically linked to the initial redemption, illustrating the principle that the end is rooted in the beginning. Ultimately, this reflects the belief that the goodness of the future is derived from the foundational experiences of the past.

passage_content: והנהאלמלי נכנסמשרע"הלארץ ישראל לא הי' עוד חורבן וגלות, ולא הי' צורך לפתיחת הצינורמבחי' ישועה זו בשביל דורות העתידים,ולפי"זלא הי' הכרח בקישוי השעבוד גם להם, אך לפי שנגזר עלמשרע"השלא יכנס לארץ וראה הקב"ה שיהיו עודחרבנותוגליות ויהיו צריכים ישראללבחי' ישועה והצלה זו, ע"כ הי' צורך בקישוי השעבוד כדי שיפתח הצינור לדורות, וזה שאמר הקב"ה למשה עתה תראה וגו' שנטל משה את הדין שלא יכנס לארץ. ואין הכוונה שבשביל שאמר למה הרעתה נגזר עליו הגזירהדא"אלומר כן וכנ"ל (עיין קושיא ג') אך הכוונה שהראה לו הקב"ה בנבואה שעתיד להיות נגזר עליו שלא יכנס לארץ, ויהי' עוד חורבן וגליות לישראל, וזה הי' לו תירוץ מספיק על קישוי השעבוד, שהי' בו צורך בשביל שיפתח הצינור לדורות העתידים, אךמרע"הלפי דעתו שלאהסכים גם על הגזירה שלא יכנס לארץ, והפציר בתפלה כמ"ש ואתחנן אל ה' בעת ההוא וגו' ע"כ התרעם על קישוי השעבוד ואמר למה הרעתה.
translation: And behold, had Moshe not entered the Land of Israel, there would have been no further destruction and exile, and there would have been no need to open the channel of this type of salvation for future generations. Therefore, there was no necessity for the tightening of the servitude for them as well. However, since it was decreed upon Moshe that he would not enter the Land, and the Holy One, blessed be He, saw that there would be further destructions and exiles, and that Israel would need this type of salvation and rescue, therefore there was a need for the tightening of the servitude so that the channel would be opened for future generations. This is what the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moshe: "Now you shall see," etc., that Moshe accepted the judgment of not entering the Land. And the intention is not that because he said, "Why have You done evil to Your servant?" the decree was pronounced upon him, as mentioned (see Question 3), but rather that the Holy One, blessed be He, showed him in prophecy that it was destined to be decreed upon him that he would not enter the Land, and that there would be further destruction and exiles for Israel. This was a sufficient excuse for the tightening of the servitude, which was necessary in order to open the channel for future generations. However, Moshe, according to his opinion, did not agree to the decree of not entering the Land, and he pleaded in prayer, as it is written, "And I pleaded with the Lord at that time," etc. Therefore, he was upset about the tightening of the servitude and said, "Why have You done evil?"
summary: The passage discusses the necessity of Moses not entering the Land of Israel, which was divinely decreed to ensure that future generations of Israel would have access to a channel of salvation and redemption. This decree was a response to the foreseen future of further destructions and exiles that the Jewish people would face. Although Moses pleaded with God to change this decree, the need for the suffering and bondage was ultimately justified as a means to open the pathway for future deliverance. The text highlights the interplay between divine justice and mercy, emphasizing that hardships can serve a greater purpose in the unfolding of redemption.

passage_content: ובזהיתבאר הפסוק וגם אני שמעתי את נאקתבנ"יאשר מצרים מעבידים אותם ואזכור את בריתי לשון עתיד (עיין קושיא ד')דר"לתמיד ובכל הדורות אזכור אותו הברית והישועה שנעשה לישראל במצרים, ונמשך מאז צינור ישועה לכל הדורות, ובזה יתבאר קישור דברי המסורה לכן אמורלבנ"יאני ה', לכן אמור הנני נותן לו את בריתי שלום,עפי"משפי' בתרגום יונתן וז"ל ויחי לעלמאלמבשראגאולתאבסוףיומיא, ונרמז בזה שמקור ושורש גאולה העתידה נמשך מגאולת מצרים שהוא צינור ומקור הישועות לכל הדורות, ובזה א"ש הפסוקשבתחלתהפרשה וידבראלקיםאל משה שהיא בחי' דין הנרמז בשםאלקיםודיבור הוא לשון קשות, ומאותו דין יוצמח רחמים גדולים לכל הדורות, כנרמזבויאמראליו אני ה' שם הרחמים, שע"י קישוי השעבוד במצרים שבא מתוקף הדין נצמח לכל הדורות רחמים וישועות טובות לישראל.
translation: And this will clarify the verse: "And I have also heard the groaning of the children of Israel, whom the Egyptians are enslaving, and I will remember My covenant," in the future tense (see the question of the fourth chapter). The Holy One, Blessed be He, will always and in all generations remember that covenant and the salvation that was done for Israel in Egypt, and since then a channel of salvation has been drawn for all generations. This clarifies the connection of the words of the tradition; therefore, say to the children of Israel, "I am the Lord," therefore say, "Behold, I give him My covenant of peace," as explained in the translation of Jonathan, and it is written, "And he will live forever from the tidings of redemption at the end of days." It is hinted here that the source and root of the future redemption is drawn from the redemption of Egypt, which is the channel and source of salvations for all generations. And thus the verse is understood at the beginning of the portion: "And God spoke to Moses," which is the aspect of judgment hinted at by the name Elokim, and speech is a term of difficulty. And from that judgment, great mercies will sprout for all generations, as hinted at in "And He said to him, 'I am the Lord,'" there is the mercy, that through the intensity of the servitude in Egypt, which came from the force of judgment, great mercies and good salvations for Israel will sprout for all generations.
summary: The passage emphasizes the enduring significance of the covenant made with Israel during their enslavement in Egypt, highlighting that this event serves as a source of redemption for all generations. It suggests that the future redemption is intrinsically linked to the past, with the suffering in Egypt giving rise to divine mercy and salvation. The text also contrasts the harshness of divine judgment, represented by the name "Elokim," with the ultimate outpouring of compassion and blessings that emerge from it, illustrating a profound theological connection between suffering and redemption.

passage_content: עודירמוזבמאמה"כואזכור את בריתי בלשון עתיד,עפימ"שבספה"קעלהקושיאהמפורסמת הלא הרבה צדיקיםאמתייםהתפללו על הגאולה, והורידו כנחל דמעות ולא נתקבלה תפילותיהם שלא הי' עדיין זמנה, ולא יעלה על הדעת שיהיו כל תפילותיהם לריק ח"ו ונאבדו מבלי זכר למו, אבל באמת כל התפלות ההם עומדים לפני השי"ת, וכשיבוא זמן הגאולה יתגלו לעין כל ויראו עין בעין איך שהיומסייעיןאל הגאולה, וכן במצרים כל אותן השנים שנמשך השעבוד התפללו ישראל הרבה תפלות וצעקות ולא הועילה לשעתו, ע"כ אמר הקב"ה אל תחשבו שלא שמעתי כל אותן התפלות, אלא וגם אני שמעתי מכבר את נאקתבנ"יוראיתי שברון לבם, אלא שלא הגיע עדיין הזמן. וכשיבוא הזמן לצאת מן הגלות יתברר שכל התפלות לא היו לריק ולבטלה.וז"פהפסוק וגם אני שמעתי את נאקתבנ"יר"ל שמעתי כבר כל אותן השנים, ואזכור את בריתי בשעה שאזכור את בריתי ואגאלם מן השעבוד והגלות אז יתברר ויתגלה להם תכליתו, וע"כ אמר בלשון עתיד ע"ש שלא בא לידי התגלות עדיין ורק אחר הגאולהיוודעתועלתם.
translation: And I will remember My covenant in the future tense, as it is explained in the holy writings regarding the well-known question: many true righteous ones have prayed for the redemption, and they poured out their tears like a river, yet their prayers were not accepted because the time had not yet come. It cannot be conceived that all their prayers would be in vain, Heaven forbid, and lost without a trace. But in truth, all those prayers stand before the Holy One, Blessed be He, and when the time of redemption comes, they will be revealed to all eyes, and they will see clearly how they were assisting the redemption. Similarly, in Egypt, during all those years of servitude, the Israelites prayed many prayers and cries, yet it did not help at that time. Therefore, the Holy One, Blessed be He, said: Do not think that I did not hear all those prayers; rather, I have already heard the groaning of the children of Israel and I have seen the brokenness of their hearts, but the time had not yet arrived. And when the time comes to leave the exile, it will be clarified that all the prayers were not in vain or for naught. And this is the meaning of the verse: "And I have heard the groaning of the children of Israel," meaning I have already heard all those years, and I will remember My covenant at the time when I remember My covenant and redeem them from servitude and exile; then it will be clarified and revealed to them its purpose. Therefore, it is said in the future tense, because it has not yet come to revelation, and only after the redemption will it be known and elevated.
summary: The passage emphasizes that all prayers for redemption, even if seemingly unanswered, are preserved before God and will be revealed in the time of the ultimate redemption. It reflects the belief that the suffering and cries of the Jewish people are heard by God, who acknowledges their pain but waits for the appropriate time to act. The future redemption will demonstrate that these prayers were not in vain, and the fulfillment of God's covenant will become evident. Thus, the language of the future in the promise of redemption signifies that its realization is yet to come, highlighting the importance of faith and patience in the face of suffering.

passage_content: באופןאחראפ"לע"ד רמז מוסרבמאמה"כוגם אני שמעתי את נאקתבנ"יאשר מצרים מעבידים אותם ואזכור את בריתי,דהנהמבוארבספה"קדפרשיותאלו שקורין בהםיצ"מהם ימיהשובבי"םומסוגלים ביותר לתיקון חטא הידוע,דזההי' עיקר בחי' הגלות במצרים שהיו ישראל משועבדים לשפלים ומזוהמים שבאומות והתגברות כחות הטומאה הי' קשה עליהם עד מאוד, אלא שע"יכחושל יוסף הצדיק שכבש לפניהם הדרך ניצולו מעריות בפועלכאמרז"לאחתהיתהופירסמההכתוב, אבל מ"מ א"א להיות נקי מהרהור עבירה במקום מזוהם וטמאכמצרים, גם שהשר של מצרים התגבר עליהם להביא אותם לידי תאוה רעה זו, וכמ"שבספה"קמאור ושמש (פ' מסעי) עה"פ כי אתם באים אל ארץ כנען וגו' ששרי המדינות שלמעלה הם המביאים לכל תאוותויצה"רשבעולם וכו' ובפרט לאיש הישראלי כל מגמתם לנתק אותם מעבודתו עבודת השי"ת, וכו' וכל שר של מדינה מושך בני מדינתובתאוהאחרתוכו', וידוע שמעשה הכנענים מקולקלים מכל האומות,כפרש"יז"ל (בפ' אחרי) בפסוק כמעשה ארץ מצרים וגו' וכמעשה ארץ כנען וגו' ששרים של מעלה הביאו אותם לידי תאוות גדולותעכדה"קלעניננועיי"ש, ועל זה היו ישראל מצטערים מאוד כי מי יוכל לעמוד ולהתגבר נגד שרי מעלה.
translation: In a responsible manner, I have heard the lamentation of the children of Israel, who are enslaved by Egypt, and I will remember My covenant. Behold, it is explained in the holy books regarding these sections that they are called "the days of Shovavim," which are especially capable of rectifying the known sin. This was the essence of the state of exile in Egypt, where the Israelites were enslaved to the lowly and defiled among the nations, and the strengthening of the forces of impurity was very difficult for them. However, through the merit of Joseph the Righteous, who paved the way for them, they were saved from actual immorality, as it is hinted in the verse. Nevertheless, it is impossible to be free from the thoughts of sin in a defiled and impure place like Egypt, especially since the angel of Egypt strengthened himself against them to bring them to this evil desire. As it is written in the holy book "Or and Shemesh" (Parashat Masei) regarding the verse "For you are coming to the land of Canaan," that the ministers of the nations above are the ones who bring forth all desires and the evil inclination in the world, etc., and especially for the Jewish man, their entire intention is to disconnect them from the service of the Blessed Creator, etc. And every minister of a nation pulls the people of that nation towards another desire. It is known that the deeds of the Canaanites are corrupted more than all the nations, as explained by our holy Rabbi (in Parashat Acharei) in the verse "like the deeds of the land of Egypt" and "like the deeds of the land of Canaan," that the ministers above brought them to great desires. And concerning this, the Israelites were very distressed, for who could stand and overcome against the ministers above?
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual struggles of the Israelites during their enslavement in Egypt, emphasizing the overwhelming influence of impurity and temptation from the surrounding nations. It highlights the role of divine providence, particularly through the merit of Joseph, in helping the Israelites resist immoral desires. The text underscores the challenge posed by the celestial powers that incite sinful inclinations, particularly for the Jewish people, and reflects on the deep sorrow of the Israelites as they confront these formidable spiritual adversaries. Ultimately, it conveys a message of hope for redemption through awareness and connection to their covenant with God.

passage_content: וז"פהפסוק וגם אני שמעתי את נאקתבנ"יאשר מצרים מעבידים אותם, והכוונה בזה על שר של מצרים, וע"דשפרש"יז"לבפ' בשלח עה"פ והנה מצרים נוסע אחריהם, ראו שר של מצרים נוסע מן השמים לעזור למצרים, ואף הכא יתפרש אשר מצרים מעבידים אותם על שר של מצרים, שהשיגו והרגישו ישראל שהשר של מצרים מתגבר עליהם בכל תקפו להביאם לידי תאוה רעה של עבירה,ולז"אמעבידים אותם בלשון כבד ולשון מפעיל שמכריחם בעל כרחם, ולזה צעקו ישראל אל ד' להושיעם מידווהבוי"תשמע את נאקתם כמ"ש וגם אני שמעתי את נאקתבנ"יאשר מצרים מעבידים אותם, שזה הי' עיקר צעקתם ולא על כבדות העבודה והשעבוד.
translation: And I also heard the groaning of the children of Israel, which the Egyptians are forcing upon them, and the intention here is regarding the minister of Egypt. As it is explained by the holy Rabbi in Parshat Beshalach on the verse, "And behold, the Egyptians are pursuing them," it is seen that the minister of Egypt travels from the heavens to assist the Egyptians. And here too, it can be interpreted that "the Egyptians are forcing them" refers to the minister of Egypt, whom the Israelites perceived and felt was overpowering them with all his might to lead them to a bad desire of sin. Therefore, it says "they are forcing them" in a heavy and active language, as if compelling them against their will. For this reason, the Israelites cried out to the Holy One, blessed be He, to save them from the hand of the oppressor, "I have heard the groaning of the children of Israel," which was the essence of their cry, and not merely about the heaviness of the labor and servitude.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author emphasizes the spiritual struggle of the Israelites under Egyptian oppression, interpreting their cries not merely as a response to physical labor but as a plea against the spiritual forces represented by the "ser of Egypt." The text highlights the notion that the Israelites felt the overwhelming influence of this celestial adversary, which sought to lead them into sin and moral degradation. Their call to God for salvation was rooted in a deep awareness of this spiritual battle, reflecting a key Hasidic concept of divine intervention in the face of existential threats. Ultimately, their cries were directed towards liberation from both physical and spiritual bondage.

passage_content: וזהובחי' נחמה גם לנו בגלות המר הזה, שלגודלהנסיונותבכל ארצותפזורנומי יוכל לומר זכיתי לבי טהרתי מחטאי,ובעוה"רבדורנו כל הארצותמקולקליןביצראדעריותותאותרעות, כמו שהי' ארץ מצרים וכנען מלפנים בדור ההוא, ושרי המדינות שלמעלה מתגברים ביותר על ישראל לנתק אותם משורשם כמ"שבספה"קמאור ושמש הנ"ל,והבוי"תיושיענו ויצילנו מידם כמו במצרים, והנה דרשו רז"ל בגמ' (נדה י"ג ע"ב)אר"אמאידכתיב(ישעי' א') ידיכם דמים מלאו אלו המנאפים בידפרש"ימוציא זרע לבעלה, וכתבהמהרש"אז"לדבהאיקרא כתיב גם כי תרבו תפלה אינני שומע, ולפי פשוטושמייריבשפיכות דמים ממש, למה תלה בו גם כי תרבו תפלה אינני שומע יותר מבשאר עבירות, אבל הרהור עבירה היא ודאי ביטול תפלה וביותר במוציא שז"ל עכ"דהמהרש"אז"ל, ועיין בדברנו (פ' שמות)תוס' ביאור עלדבה"קעפי"דהגמ' שם כל המביא עצמו לידי הרהור איןמכניסיןאותו במחיצתו של הקב"ה, כתיב הכא וירע בעיני ה' וכתיב התם כי לא ק"ל חפץ רשע אתה לאיגורךרע עכ"דהגמ',ומה"טגם תפלתו נדחית ר"ל, גם שע"י חטא הנוראוהמזיקיןהנבראים על ידו נעשה מסך המבדיל ומונעיםומעכבים ר"ל את תפלתו מלעלות, והנה כל ישראל צריכים לרחמי שמים בכל עת ורגע, ולהתחנן ולהרבות בתפלות ובקשות לפניהבוי"תשנוכל לעמוד ולהתגברבנסיונותהעצומים,ולפי"דרז"ל הנ"ל שמי שחטא בחטא הנורא הידוע ואף המביא עצמו לידי הרהור נדחה תפלתו ר"ל, א"כ איהאיפואתקותנובדור השפל הזה שאף אין אתנו יודע מה הוא תפלה.
translation: And this is our consolation even in this bitter exile, that due to the great trials in all the lands of our dispersion, no one can say, "I have merited to purify my heart from my sins." And in our generation, all the lands are corrupted by the evil inclination and its wickedness, just as the land of Egypt and Canaan were in that generation. And the rulers of the nations above are greatly strengthening themselves against Israel to sever them from their root, as it is written in the holy book "Maor v'Shemesh" mentioned above. And may the Holy One, blessed be He, save us and rescue us from their hands, just as in Egypt. And behold, our sages have expounded in the Gemara (Niddah 13b), as Rabbi said: "From where is it derived (Isaiah 1) 'Your hands are full of blood'? These are the adulterers who cause their seed to be brought forth to their husbands." And the Maharsha wrote that in this context it is also written, "Even if you multiply prayer, I do not listen." And according to the simple understanding, it refers to actual bloodshed. Why is it mentioned here, "Even if you multiply prayer, I do not listen," more than other transgressions? But certainly, the thought of sin is indeed a nullification of prayer, especially in the case of one who causes seed to be brought forth, as the Maharsha wrote. And see our discussion (Parashat Shemot) in the Tosafot's explanation on this matter, that anyone who brings himself to thoughts of sin is not allowed to enter into the Divine Presence. It is written here, "And it was evil in the eyes of the Lord," and it is written there, "For You do not desire wickedness; You cannot dwell with evil." Therefore, also his prayer is rejected, so to speak. Also, due to the terrible sin, the harmful beings created by it create a barrier that separates and prevents his prayer from ascending. And behold, all of Israel needs the mercy of Heaven at all times and moments, and to plead and increase in prayers and requests before the Holy One, blessed be He, so that we can stand and overcome the immense trials. And according to the aforementioned teaching of our sages, that one who has sinned with the known terrible sin, and even one who brings himself to thoughts of sin, his prayer is rejected, so where then is our hope in this lowly generation, where no one knows what prayer is?
summary: The passage reflects on the spiritual challenges faced by the Jewish people in exile, likening their struggles to those experienced in Egypt. It emphasizes the importance of sincere prayer and repentance, highlighting that sins, particularly those leading to harmful thoughts, can obstruct one's prayers from reaching God. The text underscores the need for divine mercy and the collective responsibility of the Jewish community to engage in heartfelt supplication to overcome the overwhelming trials of their time. Ultimately, it questions the hope for redemption in a generation where the true nature of prayer is often obscured.

passage_content: אמנםמצינו רמז נחמהעפימ"דבס' חסידים (רמזתתשנ"ז) שומע תפלה עדיך כל בשר יבואו, שומע תפלות אינו אומר אלא שומע תפלה זו תפלה של מלאך מזלו של אדם, שהוא מתפלל על האדם שישמע הקב"ה תפלתו של אדםוכו', וזהו וגם אני שמעתי את נאקת בני ישראל, וגם לרבות מלאכי מזלם, ולרשע מקבלים מיד תפלתו במילידצריךלו, רק שלא יהא הדבר רע לעולםוכו', דומה לעבד שמבקש פרס מרבו ואומר תנו לו ולא אשמע עוד קולוכדאיתאבמס' תענית עכ"לספ"ח, הרי שאף תפלת הרשע שאין הקב"ה חפץ בקילוסו מ"מ מתקבלת תפלתו,וק"ובמי שרוצה להטיב מעשיו ולעשות תשובה על חטאיו, ומתחנן בתפלתו לפניהבוית"ששיעזרהו להתגבר על יצרו ולתקן את מעשיו,בודאיהבוי"תמקבל תפלתו, וע"דמ"שבספה"קאגראדכלה(פ' לך)עמ"דבמד"רולישמעאל שמעתיך וגו' ר' אבא בר כהנא אמר מכאן אתה למד בן הגבירה מבן האמה, הנה ברכתי אותו זה ישמעאל וכו' ק"ו ואת בריתי אקים את יצחק עכ"ד המדרש, ולכאורהלמ"לק"ו כיוןדמקראמפורש הבטחתהבוי"תליצחק,אמנם זהו מחסדיהבוי"ת,דמכחהק"ויומשךחסד וטובה לישראל, אפי' אם ח"ו לא יהי' להם זכות, מגיע להם עפ"י מדת ק"ו הניתן לדרוש עפ"י התורה היינו ק"ו מהצלחת ישמעאל וגדולתו שאין להם שום זכות כלל וכו'ומכ"ששמגיע לזרע יצחק עכת"ד ז"ל.
translation: Indeed, we find a hint of comfort in the words of the "Sefer Hasidim" (hinting at the year 5757) that "He hears the prayer of all flesh," meaning that He hears prayers, but it is said that He hears this prayer, which is the prayer of the angel of a person's fortune, who prays for the person that the Holy One, blessed be He, should hear the prayer of the person, etc. This is also reflected in the verse, "And I have also heard the groaning of the children of Israel," which includes the angels of their fortune, and for the wicked, their prayer is accepted immediately in the manner they need, provided that it does not bring harm to the world, etc. It is similar to a servant who requests a reward from his master and says, "Give it to him, and I will not hear any more sound," as it is stated in the "Masechet Ta'anit," etc. Thus, even the prayer of the wicked, of whom the Holy One, blessed be He, does not desire their praise, is nevertheless accepted. And concerning one who wishes to improve his deeds and repent for his sins, and pleads in his prayer before the Holy One, blessed be He, that He should help him overcome his evil inclination and rectify his deeds, certainly his prayer is accepted. This is in line with what is stated in the holy writings of the "Agarat Kalla" (Parashat Lech Lecha) in the Midrash, "And I have heard you, O Ishmael," etc. Rabbi Abba bar Kahana said, "From here you learn the son of the noblewoman is preferred over the son of the maidservant; behold, I have blessed him, this is Ishmael, etc., and certainly, I will establish My covenant with Isaac." Thus, the Midrash concludes. And seemingly, this is not a mere a priori argument since the verse explicitly promises to Isaac. However, this is from the kindness of the Holy One, blessed be He, that from this, He will extend kindness and goodness to Israel, even if, Heaven forbid, they do not have merit. They are deserving according to the principle of a priori reasoning that can be derived according to the Torah, meaning a priori from the success of Ishmael and his greatness, who have no merit at all, etc., how much more so is it fitting for the seed of Isaac. Thus concludes his words, may his memory be blessed.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine mercy and the acceptance of prayers, emphasizing that even the prayers of the wicked can be heard by God, akin to a servant requesting a reward from his master. It highlights that the prayers of those who seek to repent and improve their actions are certainly accepted, reflecting God's compassion. The text also draws a comparison between the fates of Ishmael and Isaac, illustrating that despite the lack of merit, God's kindness extends to all, particularly to the descendants of Isaac, reinforcing the idea of divine grace and the importance of sincere repentance.

passage_content: ועד"זיתבארלעניננואףדכתיבגם כי תרבו תפלה אינני שומע ידיכם דמים מלאו: מ"מ צריך להרבות בתפלה ותחנונים לפניהבוי"תובמסתרים תבכה נפשינו שלא נטבע ח"ו במצולות הזדונים, וע"ז בעצמו יתפלל ויתחנן שלא יהי'מהנידחיןשל גם תרבו תפלה אינני שומע,והבוי"תברוב חסדיו שומע תפלת כל פה ק"ו מתפלת הרשע שמתקבלת, ואמרו חז"ל (בב"רפנ"גסי"ד) וישמעאלקיםאל קול הנער באשר הוא שם בזכות עצמו, יפה תפלת החולה לעצמו יותר מכל, ופי'היפ"תכי הוא מתפלל מתוך צרתו וקרוב ד' לנשברי לב עכ"ל, ואם תפלת ישמעאל נתקבלהמה"טק"ו שיתקבל תפלתנו לרחמים ולרצון ובדורותהקודמיןהי' לנוביהמ"קוכהנים וצדיקים קדושי עליונים שהתפללו על ישראל,ובכחקדושתם הגדולה היו בוקעים רקיעים ומבטלים כלהמקטריגיםוהמסכים המבדילים,ובעוה"רבדורנו השפל נשאר לנו רק סגולה זו יפה תפלת החולה לעצמו, וכל אחד ישפוך נפשו לד' ויהי' לבו נשבר בקרבו וקרוב ד' לנשברי לב לכל אשר יקראוהו באמת.
translation: And similarly, it is explained regarding this matter that it is also written, "When you multiply prayer, I do not hear; your hands are full of blood." Nevertheless, one must increase in prayer and supplications before the Blessed One, and in secret, let our souls weep that we should not be drowned, Heaven forbid, in the depths of wickedness. And for this very thing, one should pray and plead that he should not be among those who are cast away, for even when you multiply prayer, I do not hear. Yet, the Blessed One, in His abundant kindness, hears the prayer of every mouth, certainly more so than the prayer of the wicked, which is accepted. And our Sages said (in Bereishit Rabbah 53:9), "And God heard the voice of the lad where he was," in his own merit. The prayer of the sick person is more beautiful for himself than for anyone else, for he prays out of his distress, and the Blessed One is close to the brokenhearted. If the prayer of Ishmael was accepted for this reason, how much more so will our prayer be accepted for mercy and favor. In previous generations, there were the prophets, the Temple, the priests, and the holy righteous ones who prayed for Israel, and through their great holiness, they would break the heavens and nullify all the accusers and the barriers that separate. And in our lowly generation, we are left with only this merit: the prayer of the sick person is beautiful for himself. Each one should pour out his soul to the Blessed One, and let his heart be broken within him, for the Blessed One is close to the brokenhearted, to all who call upon Him in truth.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of heartfelt prayer and supplication, even in times when it seems that God is not listening due to the sins of the people. It highlights that sincere prayers, especially from those in distress, are particularly powerful and can be accepted by God. The text draws on the merit of past righteous individuals whose prayers were effective, suggesting that in the current lowly state of the world, the personal and earnest prayers of individuals remain a vital means of connecting with the Divine. Ultimately, it reassures that God is close to the brokenhearted and hears those who call out to Him sincerely.

passage_content: ולדרכנויתבאר בדבריהגמ' שבת (נ"ה ע"א) שמואל אמר תמה זכות אבות וכתבוהתוס' אומר ר"תדזכותאבות תמה אבל ברית אבות לא תמהדהאכתיב וזכרתי את בריתי אף לאחר גלות ואנן אין אנומזכיריןזכות אבות אלא הברית עכ"דהתוס', וכבר נאמרו פירושים שונים לבאר החילוק בין זכות אבות לברית אבות, ובדברנובכ"מנתבאר בפנים שונים (עיין פ' ויחי עמוד תקפ"ג), והנ"ללעניננודבריתאבות היינו הבטחת ואת בריתי אקים את יצחק הנסמך אל ולישמעאל שמעתיך, ודרשו רז"לבמד"רמכאן אתה למד בן הגבירה מבן האמה, הנה ברכתי אותו זה ישמעאל ק"ו ואת בריתי אקים את יצחק, וכמ"שבספה"קאגראדכלהדאף אם ח"ו לא יהי' להם זכות, מגיע להם עפ"י מדת ק"ו מהצלחת ישמעאל וגדולתו שאין להם שום זכות כלל, וע"כ אף לאחר שתמה זכות אבותדצריךלזה להיותאוחזיןמעשה אבותיהם בידיהם, ואם לא יהיו ישראל ח"ובבחי' זו, מ"מ ברית אבות לעולם קיימת, ק"ו מהצלחתהאומה"עשאין להם שום זכות.
translation: And it is explained in the words of the Gemara in Shabbat (55a) that Shmuel said, "The merit of the forefathers is in question," and Tosafot writes that R"T says the merit of the forefathers is in question, but the covenant of the forefathers is not in question, as it is written, "And I will remember My covenant even after the exile," and we do not mention the merit of the forefathers except for the covenant. Thus says Tosafot. And various interpretations have been given to explain the distinction between the merit of the forefathers and the covenant of the forefathers, and in this matter, it is explained in different contexts (see Parashat Vayechi, page 823). And the aforementioned regarding the covenant of the forefathers refers to the promise, "And I will establish My covenant with Isaac," which is connected to Ishmael, as you have heard from me. And our sages expounded in Midrash that from here you learn the son of the noblewoman is from the son of the maidservant; behold, I have blessed him, this is Ishmael, all the more so, "And I will establish My covenant with Isaac." And as it is written in the holy book, "Even if, Heaven forbid, they do not have merit, they are entitled, according to the principle of a fortiori, from the success of Ishmael and his greatness, for they have no merit at all." Therefore, even after the merit of the forefathers is in question, it is necessary for this to hold onto the deeds of their forefathers in their hands, and if the Jews are not in this aspect, nevertheless, the covenant of the forefathers is eternally established, all the more so from the success of the nation, for they have no merit at all.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between the merit of the Patriarchs (Zchut Avot) and the covenant of the Patriarchs (Brit Avot), emphasizing that while the merit may wane, the covenant remains eternal. It highlights that even without the merit of the Patriarchs, the descendants of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob are assured of their covenantal relationship with God, as illustrated by the example of Ishmael's success despite lacking such merit. The text underscores the importance of holding onto the deeds of the ancestors while affirming that the covenant is a lasting promise that sustains the Jewish people, regardless of their current spiritual state.

passage_content: ואפשרלפרש בזהמאמה"כואראאל אברהם ואל יצחק ואל יעקב וגו' וגםהקימותיאת בריתי וגו', ואזכור את בריתי,דהנהישראל במצרים עדיין הי' להם זכות אבות (דמ"שרז"ל תמה זכות אבות על הדורות שאחר החורבן אמרו כן כמבואר בגמ' שם), וה"ה כאילוהאבוה"קבעצמם היו שם,דזכותושל אדם הוא ממש שיעור קומתו, כמ"שבספה"קבני יששכר (חודש סיון מאמר ב' ס"ב) לפרש דברי המדרש (שמו"ר פ' כ"ח סי' א') בקשומלה"שלפגוע במשה, עשה הקב"הקלסטוריןפניו של משה דומה לאברהם, א"ל הקב"ה אי אתםמתביישיןהימנו לא זהו שירדתם אצלו ואכלתם בתוך ביתו, אמר הקב"ה למשה לא ניתנה לך תורה אלא בזכות אברהםוכו', הנה מהראוי להתבונןהאיךס"ד שיאמר הקב"ה למלאכים שזהו אברהם וזה הי' משה וכו' ונ"לדהנהנעמי כשנתנה עצה לרות וירדת הגורן דרשו חז"ל זכותי תרד עמךוכו',דהכתיבהוא וירדתי והקרי וירדת,ותרווייהוקשוטכי זכות של נעמי הלך עמהוהוהכמו שיעור קומתה ממשוכו',ולפי"זיונח גםבכאןכיון שזכות אברהם עלה עם משה, הנה הי' שם קומת אברהם ממש, וד'אלקיםאמת אמר לא זהו שאכלתם אצלועכדה"ק, וכמו"כ בגלות מצרים היוהאבוה"קבעצמם שם, ובזכותם נתקבל תפלתם של ישראל ונושעו מצרתם.
translation: And it is possible to explain this based on what is written: "And I will remember the covenant with Abraham, with Isaac, and with Jacob, etc., and I will remember my covenant." Behold, Israel in Egypt still had the merit of the Patriarchs (as our Sages wondered about the merit of the Patriarchs for the generations after the destruction, as explained in the Gemara there), and so too, as if the Patriarchs themselves were there, for the merit of a person is truly a measure of his stature, as it is written in the holy book of Bnei Yissachar (month of Sivan, article 2, section 2) to explain the words of the Midrash (Shemot Rabbah, Parashat 28, section 1) that when the ministering angels sought to harm Moses, the Holy One, blessed be He, made Moses' face resemble that of Abraham. The Holy One, blessed be He, said to them, "Are you not ashamed of him? Is this not the one you descended to and ate in his house?" The Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses, "The Torah was not given to you except in the merit of Abraham," etc. Therefore, it is appropriate to contemplate how it is conceivable that the Holy One, blessed be He, would say to the angels, "This is Abraham, and this was Moses," etc. And I think that when Naomi gave advice to Ruth and said, "Go down to the threshing floor," our Sages expounded, "Your merit will go down with you," etc. The writing is "And I have come down," and the reading is "And you went down," and both are correct, for the merit of Naomi went with her, and it was as if her stature was truly with her. According to this, it can also be understood here that since the merit of Abraham ascended with Moses, there was truly the stature of Abraham there, and the Holy One, blessed be He, said, "Is this not what you ate at the altar of the Holy One, blessed be He?" Likewise, in the exile of Egypt, the Patriarchs themselves were there, and in their merit, the prayers of Israel were accepted, and they were saved from their distress.
summary: The passage discusses the enduring merit of the Patriarchs—Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob—who are seen as present in the spiritual essence of the Jewish people, even during their suffering in Egypt. It emphasizes that their righteousness serves as a protective force, allowing the Israelites to maintain a connection to their ancestors and receive divine assistance. The text highlights the idea that the spiritual stature of the Patriarchs is intrinsically linked to the identity and salvation of the Jewish people, illustrating the profound theological concept of intergenerational merit and the continuity of divine favor through the lineage of the Patriarchs.

passage_content: ואפשרשירמוז הכתובואראאל אברהם ואל יצחק ואל יעקב וגו' הכוונה בו עלההוה, כי היו שםהאבוה"קבעצמם ובזכותם שמע הקב"ה נאקתם של ישראל,וז"שרש"י ז"לואראאל האבות שזכות האבות סייע להם, והבטיח הקב"ה להם וגםהקימותיאת בריתי אתם, ר"ל על אותם הזמנים שלא יהי' עוד זכות אבות אושיע את ישראלבכחברית אבות,וז"שוגם אני שמעתי את נאקת בני ישראל בעבר, שהי' להם במצרים זכות אבות ובזכותם שמעתי תפלתםשל ישראל, ואזכור את בריתי בכל הדורות אף לאחר שתמה זכות אבות אזכור להם ברית אבות.
translation: And it is possible that the verse hints at "And I appeared to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob," meaning in the present, for the holy fathers were there in their essence, and by their merit, the Holy One, blessed be He, heard the cries of Israel. And this is what Rashi, of blessed memory, says: "And I appeared to the fathers," that the merit of the fathers assisted them, and the Holy One, blessed be He, promised them, "And I will establish My covenant with them," meaning in those times when there will no longer be the merit of the fathers, I will save Israel by the strength of the covenant of the fathers. And this is what is said: "And I have also heard the groaning of the children of Israel in Egypt," for they had the merit of the fathers, and by their merit, I heard the prayers of Israel. And I will remember My covenant in all generations, even after the merit of the fathers has ceased, I will remember the covenant of the fathers for them.
summary: The passage emphasizes the significance of the patriarchs—Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob—as intercessors for the Jewish people, highlighting that their merit allows God to hear the cries of Israel. It suggests that even when the merit of the patriarchs diminishes, God's covenant with them ensures His continued remembrance of Israel's plight. The text underscores the enduring nature of the covenant, indicating that God's commitment to Israel transcends the temporal merits of the ancestors, ensuring divine support throughout generations.

passage_content: וידבראלקיםאל משה ויאמר אליו אני ד', דקדקו המפרשיםדהתחילהכתוב בשםאלקיםמדת הדין, וסיים אני ד' שם הרחמים, גם שהתחיל וידבר דיבור קשה ומסיים ויאמר אמירה רכה.
translation: And G-d spoke to Moses and said to him, "I am the L-rd." The commentators note that it begins with the name of G-d, the attribute of judgment, and concludes with "I am the L-rd," the name of mercy. Also, it starts with "And He spoke," a harsh utterance, and ends with "and He said," a gentle expression.
summary: In this passage, the transition from the name "Elokim," representing the attribute of judgment, to "Ani Hashem," signifying the attribute of mercy, highlights the duality of divine interaction. The initial harshness of "וידבר" contrasts with the gentleness of "ויאמר," illustrating how God communicates with humanity through both sternness and compassion. This reflects a fundamental Hasidic teaching on the balance between justice and mercy in the divine relationship with the world. Ultimately, it emphasizes that even in moments of strict judgment, God's underlying intention is one of love and redemption.

This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the importance of lineage and the spiritual legacy passed down through the ages.

passage_content: ג)ד' לא נודעתי להם,פרש"ילא נכרתי להםבמדתאמיתית שלי שעלי' נקרא שמי ד' נאמן לאמת דברי, שהרי הבטחתים ולא קיימתיוכו', הקשו המפרשים הרי מעיקרא הי' ההבטחה ודור רביעי ישובו הנה, ועדיין לא הגיע זמנה להבטחת ירושת הארץ שתתקיים, ושאר ההבטחות שהבטיחם הקב"ה על הזרע ושמירה מאויבים כולן נתקיימו, ואין מקום לתרעומת כלל.
translation: 3) "And I did not make Myself known to them," meaning "I did not reveal Myself to them in the true measure of My essence, by which My name is called 'Faithful to Truth'—for I had promised them and did not fulfill it, etc." The commentators ask, how could it be that the promise was initially made, and that in the fourth generation they would return here, and yet the time for the promise of inheriting the land has not yet come to be fulfilled? And all the other promises that the Holy One, blessed be He, made regarding the seed and protection from enemies have all been fulfilled, and there is no place for complaint at all.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the concept of God's name being associated with truth and faithfulness, emphasizing that despite the apparent delay in fulfilling certain promises to the Jewish people, such as the inheritance of the land, God's assurances remain valid. The text addresses the tension between divine promises and their timing, asserting that while some promises have not yet been realized, others regarding protection and continuity have been fulfilled. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the nature of faith and the understanding of divine timing in relation to human expectations.

passage_content: ד)כתב רש"י ז"ל רבותינו דרשוהולעניןשל מעלה שאמר משה למההרעותה, א"ל הקב"ה חבל עלדאבדיןוכו' יש לי להתאונן על מיתת האבות, הרבה פעמים נגליתי עליהם בשם שי"ן דל"ת יו"ד, ולא אמרו לי מה שמך, ואתה אמרת מה שמו מה אומר אליהם, ואין המדרש מתיישב אחר המקרא מפני כמה דברים, שלא נאמר ושמי ד' לא שאלו לי. וא"ת לא הודיעם שכך שמו והריכ"פדבר אליהם בשם הוי' בברית בין הבתרים ובפרשת המילה, ועוד קשה לדבריהם איך נמשך מאמר הזה לפסוקים שלאחריו וגם אני שמעתי וגו' לכן אמורלבנ"יוגו' לכך אני אומר יתיישב המקרא על פשוטו וכו' עכ"ל רש"י ז"לוהראב"עוהרמב"ן ז"ל מתרצים דרשת רבותינו ז"ל,דהכוונהדבבחינתשם הוי' לא נגלה הקב"ה לאבות הקדושים לברוא להם חדשות בשנוי התולדות, ולעשות להם נסים חוץ לדרך הטבע אבל נגלה להםבבחי' השם שי"ן דל"ת יו"ד שהוא מנצח מערכות השמים, לעשות עמם נסים גדולים שלא נתבטל בהם נוהג העולם, ברעב פדה אותם ממות, ובמלחמה מידי חרב וכו' עיי"ש, אולם עדיין אינו מתורץ לפי דבריהם מה שהקשה רש"י,דאיךנמשך המאמר הזה לפסוקים שלאחריו וגם אני שמעתי וגו'וצ"ב.
translation: 4) Rashi, may his memory be blessed, wrote that our sages interpreted regarding the matter of the upper realm, that Moses said, "Why have You harmed Your servant?" The Holy One, blessed be He, replied, "Woe to that which is lost..." I have reason to complain about the death of the patriarchs; many times I revealed Myself to them with the name Shindaleth-Yud, and they did not ask Me, "What is Your name?" And you asked, "What is His name? What shall I say to them?" And the Midrash does not align with the verse for several reasons, as it was not said, "And My name, the Lord, they did not ask Me." And if you say that He did not inform them that this is His name, and He spoke to them in the name of the Lord in the covenant between the pieces and in the section of circumcision, it is also difficult according to their words how this statement connects to the verses that follow, "And I have also heard..." Therefore, say to the children of Israel... For this reason, I say that the verse should be understood in its simple meaning, etc. Thus far is the text of Rashi, may his memory be blessed. And the Ra'avad and the Ramban, may their memories be blessed, explain our sages' interpretation, that in terms of the name of the Lord, the Holy One, blessed be He, did not reveal Himself to the holy patriarchs to create new things by changing the natural order, but He revealed Himself to them in the aspect of the name Shindaleth-Yud, which conquers the hosts of heaven, to perform great miracles with them without nullifying the ways of the world, redeeming them from death in famine, and from the sword in war, etc. However, it is still not resolved according to their words what Rashi questioned, how this statement connects to the verses that follow, "And I have also heard..." etc.
summary: The passage discusses the theological implications of God's revelation to the patriarchs, emphasizing that while He appeared to them using the name associated with natural order (שין דלת יו"ד), He did not disclose the Tetragrammaton (י-ה-ו-ה) which signifies a deeper, transformative relationship. This distinction highlights that the patriarchs experienced divine intervention within the natural world rather than through miraculous changes to it. The text also addresses the tension between traditional interpretations and the literal understanding of scripture, suggesting that God's name and nature were revealed progressively, with implications for the relationship between the divine and the Jewish people.

passage_content: ה)(פ"רו' ס"ב) א"ל הקב"ה למשה אני הכתבתי עליך שאתה עניו, ואתה מקפיד על דברי, חייך יש לך לידע, שנא' טוב אחרית דבר מראשיתו. טובה אחריתן של ישראל מראשית שנתתי להם במצרים, עכ"ד המדרש, וראוי להבין מה ענין ענו'להכא, ומהו כוונת התשובה טוב אחרית דברוצ"ב.
translation: The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses: "I have written about you that you are humble, and you are particular about My words. By your life, you should know that it is stated, 'The end of a matter is better than its beginning.' The good end of Israel is better than the beginning that I gave them in Egypt." Thus concludes the Midrash. It is fitting to understand what the matter of humility is here, and what the intention of the response 'the end of a matter' is.
summary: In this passage, God tells Moses that He has written about his humility, yet Moses is concerned about His words. The phrase "good is the end of a matter from its beginning" suggests that the ultimate outcome for the Jewish people, starting from their time in Egypt, is positive. This highlights the Hasidic concept that despite initial struggles, the final redemption and spiritual elevation of Israel is assured, emphasizing the importance of faith and trust in divine providence. The connection between humility and the unfolding of divine plans underscores the theological insight that true greatness lies in recognizing one's place within God's overarching narrative.

This reflects a core Hasidic belief in the transformative power of faith and the importance of maintaining a connection with God to achieve inner tranquility and fulfillment. The reference to the covenant underscores the enduring nature of God's commitment to His followers, reinforcing the idea of divine grace in the spiritual journey.

passage_content: ז)בפ' וידבר משה כן אלבנ"יולא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה,יל"דדהול"לולא שמעו אליו.דכברנזכר בפסוק שמשה הי' המדבר, ולמה אמר עוד ולא שמעו אל משה.
translation: In Parashat Va'era, it is written that Moses spoke thus to the Children of Israel, but they did not listen to Moses because of shortness of spirit and hard work. It is said, "If they had not listened to him." It has already been mentioned in the verse that Moses was the one speaking, so why does it say again, "and they did not listen to Moses"?
summary: In this passage, the text highlights the struggle of the Israelites to listen to Moses due to their suffering and oppression, emphasizing the concept of "shortness of spirit" caused by their harsh labor. The repetition of the phrase "and they did not listen" underscores the profound disconnect between the leader and the people, reflecting a deeper spiritual malaise. This situation illustrates the Hasidic idea that external hardships can hinder one's ability to connect with divine guidance, suggesting that true listening requires inner freedom and spiritual openness. Ultimately, it points to the necessity of overcoming physical and emotional burdens to attain a higher spiritual awareness.

passage_content: ח)מ"שמקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה, נתינת טעם זה צ"ב,דאדרבהמכחטעם זההי"ללשמוע, כמ"ש לעילבפ' שמות ויאמן העם וישמעו כי פקד ד' אתבנ"יוכי ראה את ענים ויקדו וישתחוו. ובמכילתא הקשו כן, וכי יש לך אדם שמתבשר בשורה ואינו שמחוכו', א"כ מה ת"ל ולא שמעו אל משה, אלא שצום לפרוש מע"ז, והי' קשה בעיניהם לפרוש מע"ז עכ"ל המכילתא, ועדיין צ"ב מה נשתנה דעתם,דמתחלהשמחו בבשורת הגאולהכמשה"כויקדו וישתחוו, ועכשיו לא שמעו אל משהוצ"ב.
translation: (8) "Regarding the statement that due to shortness of spirit and hard work, this reasoning is questionable, for on the contrary, because of this reasoning they should have listened, as it is written above in Parashat Shemot, 'And the people believed, and they heard that the Lord had visited the children of Israel, and that He had seen their affliction, and they bowed their heads and prostrated themselves.' And in the Mekilta they posed a similar question: 'Is there a person who receives good tidings and does not rejoice?' If so, what does it mean when it says, 'But they did not listen to Moses'? Rather, it was difficult for them to separate from idolatry, and it was hard in their eyes to separate from idolatry, thus said the Mekilta. Yet it is still questionable why their mindset changed, for initially they rejoiced at the tidings of redemption, as it is written, 'and they bowed their heads and prostrated themselves,' and now they did not listen to Moses, and this is a question."
summary: The passage discusses the paradox of the Israelites' initial joy upon hearing the news of redemption contrasted with their later refusal to listen to Moses. It highlights the struggle between spiritual aspiration and the burdens of oppression, suggesting that the weight of their suffering made it difficult for them to embrace the message of salvation. The text reflects on the Hasidic theme of the tension between faith and despair, emphasizing the need for a deeper understanding of divine intervention amidst hardship. Ultimately, it raises questions about the nature of belief and the challenges of maintaining hope in the face of adversity.

passage_content: ט)בפרשה הן בני ישראל לא שמעו אלי ואיך ישמעני פרעה ואני ערל שפתים,פרש"יז"ל בשם המדרש זה א' מעשרה ק"ו שבתורה והקשו המפורשיםדק"ופריכאהוא. דמה שלא שמעו ישראל הי' מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה כמפורש בכתוב,משא"כפרעה שלאהי"לקוצר רוח ולא עבודה קשה, ולא ראוי זה כראוי זה.
translation: In the section, "Behold, the children of Israel did not listen to me; how then shall Pharaoh listen to me, for I am of uncircumcised lips," the explanation is given in the name of the Midrash that this is one of the ten a fortiori arguments in the Torah. The commentators have questioned this, saying, "And what is the difficulty?" For the reason that the children of Israel did not listen was due to shortness of spirit and hard work, as is explicitly stated in the text. In contrast, Pharaoh did not have the shortness of spirit nor the hard work, and this is not fitting to compare one to the other.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the contrasting responses of the Israelites and Pharaoh to divine communication. The Israelites, burdened by hard labor and shortness of spirit, struggle to hear God's message, while Pharaoh, who is not subjected to such hardships, is also resistant. This highlights a key Hasidic concept: the idea that spiritual receptivity can be hindered by external pressures and suffering. The text emphasizes the theological insight that divine communication is not solely dependent on the recipient's circumstances but also on their inner state and openness to receive.
