passage_content: י)צ"במ"שואני ערל שפתים,דעלטענה זו כבר השיב לו השי"ת מי שם פה לאדם, גם צירף עמו את אהרן שיהי' לו לפה ולמליץ, ולמה חזרמרע"העוד הפעם על טענתו הקודמת.
translation: I) It is written: "I am of uncircumcised lips." To this, the Holy One, Blessed be He, already responded to him, "Who made man's mouth?" He also joined with him Aaron, to be his mouth and advocate. And why did Moshe Rabbeinu return once again to his previous claim?
summary: In this passage, the author reflects on Moses' reluctance to speak due to his speech impediment, emphasizing that God reassured him by appointing Aaron as his spokesperson. This highlights the theme of divine support and partnership in fulfilling one's mission. The repetition of Moses' objection underscores the struggle between human limitations and divine empowerment, illustrating a key Hasidic concept of relying on God's assistance in overcoming personal challenges. Ultimately, it conveys the message that even the most humble and flawed individuals can be chosen for significant roles through divine intervention.

passage_content: יא)בפרשה כי ידבר אלכם פרעהלאמרתנו לכם מופת, ואמרת אל אהרן קח את מטך וגו',במד"ר(פ' ט' סי' א') ר"פ הכהןבר"חפתח, (ישעי' מ"ו) מגיד מראשית אחרית וגו' שהגיד הקב"ה למשה מראשית אחרית, אם ידבר אלכם פרעהאכ"כ, אלא כי ידבר, עתיד הוא לומר לכם כן עכ"ד המדרש,וצ"בוכי צריך ראי'ודרשאללמוד זה שהקב"ה מגיד מראשית אחרית: ומהו כוונת דרשתם ז"ל בזה.
translation: 11) In the portion "When Pharaoh speaks to you saying, 'Show us a miracle,'" and you shall say to Aaron, "Take your staff," etc. (Midrash Rabbah, Parashat Va'era, Section 1) Rabbi Pinchas the Kohen opened with (Isaiah 46) "Declaring the end from the beginning," that the Holy One, Blessed be He, revealed to Moses the end from the beginning. If Pharaoh speaks to you, then afterward, he will say to you thus. This is the conclusion of the Midrash, and it is puzzling why there is a need for a proof and a teaching that the Holy One, Blessed be He, reveals the end from the beginning: and what is the intention of their teaching in this matter.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the concept of divine foreknowledge as expressed in the Midrash, highlighting that God reveals to Moses the future events that will unfold, specifically Pharaoh's eventual demands. This underscores the Hasidic belief in God's omniscience and the idea that the unfolding of history is part of a divine plan. The passage emphasizes the importance of understanding that God's communication is not just about immediate events but encompasses the entirety of the past, present, and future, reflecting a deep theological insight into the nature of prophecy and divine guidance.

passage_content: יבפרעה לחכמים ולמכשפים ויעשו גם הםחרטמימצרים בלהטיהם כן,אמרז"לבמדרש רבה (פ' ט' סי' ו') באותה שעה התחיל פרעה משחק עליהם ומקרקר אחריהם כתרנגולת, ואמר להם כך אותותיו של הקב"הוכו', שלח והביא תינוקות מןאסכולישלהם, ועשו אף הם כך וכו' שנא' ויעשו גם הם: מהו גם שאפי' תינוקות של ד' וה' שנים קרא ועשו כן, ולכאורה קשה, הרי הקב"ה מגיד מראשית אחרית, ולמה צו' למשה ואהרן לעשות אות המטהשעי"זהתלוצצו עליהם, והרי תכלית האותות כדי שיאמין לשלוחי השי"ת, ואדרבהעי"זנתפקר עוד יותר.
translation: Pharaoh turned to the wise men and the magicians, and they too performed their enchantments with their secret arts. Thus, our sages said in Midrash Rabbah (Parashat Va'era, Section 6): At that moment, Pharaoh began to mock them and clucked after them like a hen, saying to them: "These are the signs of the Holy One, blessed be He." He sent and brought children from their schools, and they too did likewise, as it is said, "And they did the same." What does "also" mean? Even the children of four and five years old were called and did so. At first glance, this is difficult: the Holy One, blessed be He, reveals the end from the beginning, so why did He command Moses and Aaron to perform the sign of the staff, which was to be a challenge to them? The purpose of the signs is for them to believe in the emissaries of the Holy One, blessed be He, and on the contrary, this caused them to become even more obstinate.
summary: In this passage, the author discusses the challenge posed by Pharaoh and his magicians, who replicate the miracles performed by Moses and Aaron, even using young children to do so. This raises a theological question about the purpose of the signs and wonders, as they seem to lead to greater disbelief rather than faith in God’s messengers. The text highlights the tension between divine foreknowledge and human free will, suggesting that even in the face of miraculous signs, the hardened heart of Pharaoh exemplifies the struggle against divine truth. Ultimately, it reflects on the complexity of faith and the resistance to divine authority, even when confronted with undeniable evidence.

passage_content: יג(רמז קפ"א) כי ידבר אלכם פרעהלאמרתנו לכם מופת, אמר להם למחר אני מוציאם ממצרים, ואני נותן להם את התורה שנא' בה כי יקום בקרבך נביא ונתן אליך אות או מופת עכ"ד הילקוט,וצ"באיךשייכאמצות הנביא שעתיד להתחדש במתן תורה, אל מה שישאל פרעה מופת, הרי ודאי לא במצות התורה ישאל כן.
translation: 13 (Remez 151) For Pharaoh will speak to you, saying, "We have given you a sign." He told them, "Tomorrow I will take them out of Egypt, and I will give them the Torah," as it is stated, "If a prophet arises among you and gives you a sign or a wonder." Thus far the Yalkut. And how does this relate to the commandments of the prophet that will be renewed with the giving of the Torah? As for what Pharaoh will ask for a sign, it is certainly not in the commandments of the Torah that he will ask this.
summary: In this passage, the author discusses Pharaoh's request for a sign as a precondition for the Israelites' liberation from Egypt, highlighting the connection between miracles and the future giving of the Torah. The text emphasizes that the miracles performed by Moses serve as a precursor to the revelation of the Torah, suggesting that the true purpose of the signs is to prepare the people for their covenantal relationship with God. This reflects a key Hasidic concept that the miraculous is intertwined with divine revelation, underscoring the transformative power of the Torah in the spiritual journey of the Jewish people.

passage_content: יד)במכת ברד כתיב, ויאמר ד' אל משה השכם בבקרוהתיצבלפני פרעה וגו',במד"ר(פ' י"ב סי' י"א)הה"ד(איוב ל"ו) הן ק"לישגיבבכחומי כמוהו מורה,א"רברכי' הקב"ה מעציםכחהצדיקים לעשות רצונו, מי כמוהו מורה, שהוא מורה דרך לעשות תשובהוכו', שלא חפץ לשלוח המכה עד שיזהירנו לעשות תשובה, שכ"כ השכם בבקרוהתיצבלפני פרעה עכ"ד המדרש, וראוי להבין מה נשתנה מכת ברד שדרשו בו חז"ל כן, והרי גם בשאר המכות לא הכה בהם עד שהתרה בם, ובה' מכות הראשונות הי' בהם התראה לדבריהכלומפורש כן בפסוקים, ואיכא למ"דדבכלהמכות הי' התראה, אפי' באלו שאין ההתראה מפורש בהם,וצ"בהכוונה שדרשו כן במכת ברדדוקא.
translation: In the plague of hail, it is written, "And the Lord said to Moses, 'Get up early in the morning and stand before Pharaoh...'" (Midrash Rabbah, Parashat Yud-Bet, Section 11). This is as it is stated (Job 36:32), "Behold, He is mighty in strength and wisdom." Rabbi Berachiah said: The Holy One, blessed be He, empowers the righteous to fulfill His will. Who is like Him, the Teacher, who teaches the way to do repentance, etc.? He did not wish to send the plague until He warned them to repent, as it is written, "Get up early in the morning and stand before Pharaoh." Thus far the Midrash. It is appropriate to understand what was different about the plague of hail that our Sages expounded this way, for in all the other plagues, He did not strike them until He warned them. And in the first five plagues, there was a warning, as is explicitly stated in the verses. And there is an opinion that in all the plagues there was a warning, even in those where the warning is not explicitly mentioned. And it is necessary to understand why they specifically expounded this regarding the plague of hail.
summary: In the passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author highlights the significance of divine warning before punishment, particularly in the context of the plague of hail. It emphasizes that God empowers the righteous to guide others towards repentance, as seen in the instruction to Moses to confront Pharaoh early in the morning. The unique focus on the hail plague suggests a deeper theological insight into the necessity of repentance and the role of divine mercy, indicating that even in judgment, God desires to offer opportunities for return and correction. This reflects a core Hasidic belief in the interplay between divine justice and compassion.

passage_content: טו)בפעם הזאת אני שולח את כל מגפתי אללבךוגו'פרש"ילמדנו שמכת בכורות שקולה כנגד כל המכות, הקשההרא"םז"ל מכת בכורות מאןדכרשמי', ולמה לא יתפרש על מכת ברד שמדבר בה הכתוב, ותירץ בשם ר"תמאורליינו"ששהגירסאצ"ל בכורות, והוא הברד שנלקה בו האביב הממהרלהתבכר,כמשה"ככי השעורה אביב, והכוונה ללמדנו על מכת ברד שהוא שקולה כנגד כל המכות, והקשה ע"זהגו"אזלל"הדלעיל (בפ' שמות) עה"פ הנה אנכי הורג את בנך בכורך,פרש"ישמכת בכורות קשה מכולם, ואם נפרש כאן דברי רש"י על מכת ברד, א"כ יהיו דבריוסותריןזא"ז.
translation: 15) This time I send all my plagues upon your heart, and it teaches us that the plague of the firstborn is equivalent to all the plagues. The Ra'ah"m asks why the plague of the firstborn is mentioned specifically, and why it should not be interpreted as referring to the plague of hail that the verse speaks of. He answers in the name of R"T that the text indeed refers to the firstborn, and it is the hail that struck the spring, hastening it to blossom, as it is written, "for the barley is in the ear." The intention is to teach us that the plague of hail is equivalent to all the plagues. He questions this based on the earlier statement (in Parshat Shemot) regarding the verse, "Behold, I will kill your firstborn," where it is explained that the plague of the firstborn is the hardest of all. If we interpret Rashi's words here as referring to the plague of hail, then the statements would contradict each other.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the significance of the Plague of the Firstborn, emphasizing that it is considered equivalent to all the other plagues combined. The text references the interpretation of Rashi, who highlights the severity of the Firstborn plague, suggesting that it embodies a unique intensity that surpasses the others. The connection to the plague of hail is explored, indicating that both plagues serve as profound lessons about divine judgment and the consequences of disobedience. Ultimately, the passage underscores the theological concept of God's omnipotence and the weight of His decrees in the context of the Exodus narrative.

passage_content: טזקשה על תירוצו ממה שדרשו חז"ל והנה לא שמעת עד כה, עד שתשמע ממני מכת בכורות שאפתח בכה שנא' כה אמר ד' בחצות לילה, ואיך יתכן שהביא עליו מכת ברד ששקולה כנגד כל המכות ולא נכנע, ואח"כ יביא עליו מכה שהוא יותר קלה ובזהיכנעלבבו ויניחם לצאת.
translation: You have questioned his explanation based on what our Sages have taught, and behold, you have not heard until now, until you hear from me about the plague of the firstborn, as it is said, "Thus says the Lord, at midnight." And how is it possible that He brought upon him the plague of hail, which is equivalent to all the plagues, and he did not relent, and afterwards He would bring upon him a plague that is lighter, and in this way, he would be offended and allow them to go out.
summary: The passage discusses the paradox of divine punishment, highlighting how Pharaoh endured the severe plague of hail, which is equal to all the plagues, yet remained unyielding. In contrast, he succumbed to the seemingly lighter plague of the firstborn, illustrating the complexity of human resistance to divine will. This reflects a deeper Hasidic insight into the nature of spiritual awakening and the transformative power of humility in the face of divine intervention. Ultimately, it emphasizes the idea that true submission to God often comes through profound experiences of suffering and revelation.

passage_content: יזיונתן פי' עה"פ בפעם הזאת אני שולח את כל מגפתי אללבך, אריבזמנאהדאאנא שלחמחתאלך מן שמיא,ותתיביתכל מחתי וכו' דמן קדמי הווןמשתלחיןולא מןחרשיותאוכו' וכ"כהאוהחה"קכי בכל המכות עד הנה, לא הי' פרעה מחליטבלבוכי הםמאלקיהיכולת, והי' תולה במכשפות ומעשה שדיםוכו', ע"כ א"ל ד' כי בפעם הזאת אני שולח את כל מגפתי שכבר באו עליך, אללבךשתדע בכולם כי לא מעשה כשפים המה אלא מעשהאלקיםעכ"ד ז"ל. אמנם צ"ב איךנתבררלוע"י מכת ברד יותר מבשאר המכות, הגם שדרשו חז"ל הביאו רש"י בשם מדרש אגדה שהגביהו הקב"ה למשה למעלה מן השמים בשעה שהביא עליהם הברד, ואיתאבמד"רנתן הקב"ה למשה רשות לשלוט במעשה שמים, שנא' נטה את ידך על השמים וגו' אבל איך הבחין פרעה בכל זה, וכמו שאמר בשאר המכות כולן שמעשה כשפים הם, כמו"כ הי' אפשר שיאמר גם במכת ברד כן.
translation: Jonathan explains the verse: "At this time I will send all My plagues upon your heart," that the Holy One, blessed be He, sent them from Heaven, and you will know all My plagues, etc., that from the beginning they were sent and not from sorcery, etc. And so it is with all the plagues until now, Pharaoh did not decide in his heart that they were from the Almighty's power, and he attributed them to sorcery and the work of demons, etc. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, "For at this time I will send all My plagues that have already come upon you, upon your heart, so that you will know in all of them that they are not the work of sorcery but the work of God," thus far his words. However, it is difficult to understand how it was clarified through the plague of hail more than through the other plagues, even though our Sages have explained, and Rashi brought in the name of the Midrash Aggadah that the Holy One, blessed be He, raised Moses above the heavens when He brought the hail upon them, and it is stated in the Midrash that the Holy One, blessed be He, gave Moses permission to control the acts of Heaven, as it is said, "Stretch out your hand toward heaven," etc. But how did Pharaoh distinguish all this, just as he said regarding all the other plagues that they were acts of sorcery, so too it would have been possible for him to say the same regarding the plague of hail.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author emphasizes that the plagues sent to Pharaoh were direct acts of God, rather than the result of sorcery or witchcraft, highlighting God's sovereignty over nature. The specific mention of the hail plague serves to illustrate how even in this instance, Pharaoh's recognition of divine intervention was crucial, as God elevated Moses to a position of authority over the heavens. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of divine providence and the importance of recognizing God's hand in all events, reinforcing the idea that true power lies with the Almighty rather than with human or supernatural forces.

passage_content: יחברד ואש מתלקחת בתוך הברד,פרש"יבשם המדרש נס בתוך נס. האש והברדמעורביןוהברד מים הוא, ולעשות רצון קונם עשו שלו' ביניהם. ולכאורה צ"ב דלא מצינו מבואר למה הי' צורך לנס זה, ולפי משמעות הכתוב הברד לבדו הכה בהם ולא האש שנא'ויךהברד וגו', וכתיב הנשארת לכם מן הברד, אשר הותיר הברד,ובכ"מנזכר הברד לבד, והמכה נקראת ע"ש הברד ולא ע"ש האש, ואם הי' רצונוית' לשלוח עליהם גם אש ממרומיו, אבל לאיזה תכלית הי' הנס שיהיומעורביןזב"ז,וכללאהוא דלא עבידקוב"הניסאלמגנא.
translation: The hail and the fire were mixed together in the hail; the Midrash explains that it was a miracle within a miracle. The fire and the hail are intertwined, and the hail is water, and to fulfill the will of their Creator, they made peace between them. However, it seems difficult to understand why this miracle was necessary, and according to the meaning of the verse, the hail alone struck them, as it is said, "And the hail struck," and it is written, "The remnants that remain from the hail," which the hail left behind. In every instance, the hail is mentioned alone, and the plague is named after the hail and not after the fire. If it was His will to send fire upon them from on high, what purpose was there in the miracle that they should be mixed together? The general principle is that the Holy One, blessed be He, does not perform miracles for no reason.
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous combination of fire and hail during the plagues in Egypt, highlighting the concept of "a miracle within a miracle." It emphasizes that while hail alone was sufficient to inflict damage, the intertwining of fire and hail serves a deeper purpose in fulfilling God's will. The text raises questions about the necessity of this combined miracle, suggesting that it reflects God's intricate design in executing divine justice and protection. Ultimately, it illustrates the complexity of divine intervention and the multifaceted nature of God's actions in the world.

translation: In the book of Shemot, it is said that Pharaoh said, "Who is the Lord that I should heed His voice to let Israel go? I do not know the Lord, and I will not let Israel go." We must understand the word "and" (וגם) – what is its purpose here? It indicates that he does not know the Lord, and what is the implication of this addition?
summary: In this passage, Pharaoh's refusal to recognize God and his insistence on not releasing the Israelites highlights the theme of divine authority versus human arrogance. The use of the word "גם" (also) suggests a deeper understanding of the interconnectedness of God's identity and the fate of the Israelites, emphasizing that true recognition of God leads to liberation. This reflects a key Hasidic concept that awareness of the divine is essential for spiritual and communal redemption. Ultimately, the text illustrates the struggle between faith and resistance, underscoring the transformative power of acknowledging God's presence.

passage_content: כ)אלהםמלך מצרים למה משה ואהרן תפריעו את העם ממעשיו לכו לסבלותיכם,פרש"ילכו למלאכתכם שיש לכם בבתיכם, אבל מלאכת שעבוד מצרים לאהיתהעל שבטו של לוי, ותדע לך שהרי משה ואהרן יוצאים ובאים שלא ברשות עכ"ל,וצ"בדלמההזהירם פרעה על כך שיחזרו למלאכתם שבבית, ומאינפק"מלדידי' אם יחזרו אלי' או יהיו בטלים ממלאכה לגמרי, ועיקר כוונת אמירתוהיתהשלא להפריע את העם ממלאכה, וכבר מילתו אמורה למה משה ואהרן תפריעו וגו' ודי בזה, ומאמר לכו לסבלותיכם מיותר ומחוסר הבנה.
translation: (20) The king of Egypt said, "Why do Moses and Aaron disturb the people from their work? Go to your burdens." This means "Go to your work that you have in your homes," but the work of the servitude of Egypt was not upon the tribe of Levi. And you should know that Moses and Aaron were coming and going without permission. Therefore, why did Pharaoh warn them about this, that they should return to their work at home? And it is not clear to me whether they would return to it or be completely idle from work. The main intention of his statement was not to disturb the people from their work, and his words are already stated: "Why do Moses and Aaron disturb..." and this is sufficient. The statement "Go to your burdens" is superfluous and lacks understanding.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the Pharaoh's admonition to Moses and Aaron highlights the tension between spiritual leadership and the demands of physical labor. The insistence that they should not disrupt the people's work reflects a deeper understanding of the struggle between divine purpose and earthly obligations. The mention of the tribe of Levi, who were not subjected to the same labor, underscores the idea that spiritual elevation often requires separation from mundane tasks. Ultimately, the text emphasizes the importance of maintaining focus on spiritual pursuits, even amidst the pressures of worldly responsibilities.

passage_content: כאקשהדרש"יז"ל פי'בפ'ואראסבלות מצרים, טורח משא מצרים, ובת"א פי' דחוק פולחןמצראי, מבוארדמלתסבלות ביאורו משא כבידה שטורח לסובלו, ואיך יתפרש כאן לסבלותיכם למלאכתכם שבבית, ואין זה טורח משא, ולאיפוללשון סבלות במה שהאדם עושה מלאכת עצמו לרצונו, עודיל"דדעלמלאכת העם אמר תפריעו את העם ממעשיו, והואהיתהעבודה קשה וטורח משא,כמשה"כוימררו את חייהם בעבודה קשה וגו' את כל עבודתם אשר עבדו בהם בפרך,ופרש"יבעבודה קשה המפרכת את הגוףומשברתו, וע"ז יוצדק מילתסבלותם, ולמה הפך סדר הלשונות,והול"לאיפכא למה תפריעו את העםמסבלותםלכו למעשיכם.
translation: As it is explained in the Midrash, "May His Name be remembered," in the portion of "And the burdens of Egypt," the toil of the burdens of Egypt, and in the Targum it is explained as the oppression of the Egyptian worship. It is clarified that the term "burdens" refers to a heavy load that one struggles to bear, and how it can be interpreted here as "your burdens" in the context of your work at home, and this is not a burden of toil, nor does it apply to the term "burdens" in what a person does for his own will. Furthermore, regarding the work of the people, it is said, "You shall disrupt the people from their deeds," and this became hard work and a burden, as it is written, "And they made their lives bitter with hard work... all their work which they did with rigor," and it is explained that "with hard work that crushes the body and breaks it." And for this, the term "their burdens" is justified, and why the order of the terms is reversed, and it is said, "Why do you disrupt the people from their burdens? Go to your deeds."
summary: The passage discusses the concept of "suffering" in the context of the Israelites' labor in Egypt, contrasting the burdensome nature of their work with the notion of personal fulfillment in one's own labor. It highlights that the term "suffering" (סבלות) is used to describe the oppressive work that breaks the body, as opposed to the natural toil of one's own endeavors. The text questions the inversion of language regarding the people's suffering and their work, emphasizing the distinction between imposed hardship and voluntary labor. Ultimately, it reflects on the theological implications of divine justice and the human experience of labor and suffering.

passage_content: כבקשהמ"שלמה משה ואהרן תפריעו וגו' ומה מקום לשאלת למה, הרי אמרו לו שהם שלוחי ד', אלא שלא הי' רצונו לשמוע בדבר ד', וכבר אמר לא ידעתי את ד' וגם את ישראל לא אשלח, ומה הוסיף כאן בשאלתו למה משה ואהרן תפריעו, ואין בזה דברי טעם, וגםבלא"האין מקום לתמי' זו כלל, כי אחרי שראו בדחוק פולחן ועבודת משא מצרים על ישראל, באו לבקש ממנו להקל מעליהם עול השעבוד, ומה זה שאמר למה משה ואהרן תפריעו, וכי לא ידע למה.
translation: As the request of Moshe and Aharon, "You shall not disturb," and what place is there for the question of why, for they told him that they are messengers of Hashem, but he did not wish to listen to the word of Hashem. And he already said, "I do not know Hashem," and "I will not send Israel." And what does he add here in his question, "Why do Moshe and Aharon disturb?" There is no reasoning in this, and even without that, there is no place for this wonder at all, for after they saw the difficult service and labor of Egypt upon Israel, they came to ask him to lighten the yoke of servitude from upon them. And what is this that he said, "Why do Moshe and Aharon disturb?" Does he not know why?
summary: בקטע זה נדונה השאלה מדוע פרעה שואל את משה ואהרן "למה תפריעו", כאשר ברור לו שהם שליחי ה'. הכותב מציין שפרעה לא רצה להכיר בכוחו של ה' ובשליחותו, והדבר מעיד על חוסר הבנה רוחנית מצידו. השאלה מדגישה את המתח בין ההכרה האלוהית לבין ההתנגדות האנושית, ומצביעה על כך שפרעה היה מודע לעול השעבוד שהוטל על ישראל, אך עדיין בחר להתנגד לשחרורם.

passage_content: כגלמה הזכיר את שמותם, ואין זה מדרך הלשון, שהרי דבראלהםלנוכח, וכבר כתיב ויאמראלהם,והול"ללמה תפריעו את העם,ומ"שלמה משה ואהרן מיותר.
translation: As a metaphor, he mentioned their names, and this is not the way of language, for He spoke to them directly, and it is already written, "And He said to them," and it should have said, "Why do you disturb the people?" and "Why Moses and Aaron" is superfluous.
summary: הקטע מדגיש את החשיבות של שמות והזכרתם בהקשר של תקשורת עם העם. השימוש בשמותיהם של משה ואהרן מצביע על הקשר האישי והעמוק בין המנהיגים לעם, ומעורר שאלות על הדרך שבה יש להעביר מסרים רוחניים. יש כאן הבנה שהשיח עם העם אינו רק טכני, אלא נוגע לנשמה ולזהות של כל פרט ופרט. המילים נושאות משקל רוחני, והזכרת השמות מחזקת את הקשר בין המנהיגים לעם ואת תפקידם הרוחני.

passage_content: כד)ראוי להבין תכלית כוונתובמ"שלמה משה ואהרן תפריעו, וכי הי' בידם להפריע את העם ממעשיו, הלא פרעה הי' בידו שבט המושל, ולא הניחםבלא"השיפריעו את העם,כמשה"כויצו פרעה את הנוגשים בעם וגו' תכבד העבודה על האנשים וגו',ובודאילא זה הי' כוונתו להזהירם שלא יפריעו את העם כי לא הוצרך לכך,וצ"בהכוונה בזה.
translation: It is fitting to understand the ultimate intention in the words of Shlomo, Moshe, and Aharon: "You shall not disturb the people." Did they have the power to prevent the people from their actions? Was it not Pharaoh who held the scepter of governance, and he did not allow them to disturb the people? As it is written, "And Pharaoh commanded the taskmasters over the people, saying, 'You shall make the work harder for the men...'" Indeed, his intention was to warn them not to disturb the people, for there was no need for that. And this requires clarification in the intention behind it.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine providence and the role of leaders in guiding their people. It emphasizes that although Moses and Aaron had the potential to influence the Israelites, it was ultimately Pharaoh's oppressive authority that prevented them from doing so. The text suggests that Pharaoh's command to intensify the labor of the Israelites was a deliberate attempt to discourage any interference from Moses and Aaron, highlighting the tension between divine will and human authority. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the struggle between spiritual leadership and worldly power.

translation: "Why do you disturb Moshe and Aharon, what does 'why' mean? He said to them, 'You, why, and your words, why.'"
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author addresses the questioning of Moses and Aaron, emphasizing the significance of their inquiries. The term "למה" (why) reflects a deeper search for understanding and connection to divine purpose. This highlights a key Hasidic concept that questioning and seeking answers are essential for spiritual growth and engagement with God. Ultimately, it suggests that such inquiries can lead to a more profound relationship with the divine and a clearer understanding of one's role in the world.

passage_content: ולבארהעניןנ"ל עוד כוונה נוסף על פשוטו בוויכוח שבין משה ואהרן עם פרעה,דהנהמשה ואהרן כשבאו בשליחות השי"ת אל ישראל, וראו שאין להם לישראל דיזכותיםלהגאל, הגם שהי' להם מידות טובות כמ"שבזוה"קדאסתמרוישראל מנדה ובת אלנכר, ואיתא בגמ' בשביל ד' דברים נגאלו אבותינו ממצרים שלא שינו את שמם ואת לשונםוכו', אעפ"כ היו משוקעים בע"ז ובמ"ט שערי טומאה, והי' תנאי לגאולתם שיקדים לה בחי' התשובה, כמאמרם ז"ל (במד"רפ' ט"ז סי' ב') משכו ידיכם מע"ז וקחו לכם צאן של מצו'. ע"כ משה ואהרן עוררו אותם אל התשובה, כמבואר בדברי המכילתא הנ"ל מה ת"ל ולא שמעו אל משה, אלא שצום לפרוש מע"ז, ומצינו בכתוב (יחזקאל כ') שאהרן התנבאאלהםאיש שקוצי עיניו השליכו וגו', והי' אז הזמן מסוגל לתשובה, כי רצה הקב"ה להוציא את ישראל מתחת טומאת מצרים, ולא הי' בכוחם לפרוש ממנה, כי היו משוקעים. במ"ט שערי טומאה, ולולי עזראלקילא היו יוצאים משם לעולם, ועשה השי"ת פלאות להפרישם מטומאת מצרים, כמו שפירשנו בדברנוכ"פמאה"כ, הנסהאלקיםלקחת לו גוי מקרב גוי, שהוציא הקב"ה מקרבם טומאת מצרים, והי' הזמן מסוגל לבירורהניצה"ק, שתקנו ישראל והוציאו משם כלהניצה"קכמ"ש וינצלו את מצרים, וע"כ מסוגלים ימי השובבים לתיקון חטא הידוע, והם ימים מסוגלים לתשובה, כי הקריאה מעורר סגולת הזמן, הגםדכלהשנה כולה אין לך דבר שעומד בפני התשובה, אבל סגולת הימים אלו מסייעים שיתעורר האדם בהם לשוב אל בוראו יתברך.
translation: To further explain the aforementioned matter, there is an additional intention beyond its simple meaning in the debate between Moses and Aaron with Pharaoh. Behold, when Moses and Aaron came on the mission of the Holy One, Blessed be He, to Israel, and saw that the Israelites had no merits to be redeemed, even though they had good traits, as it is stated in the Zohar that Israel was preserved from the curse and the daughter of the foreigner, and it is stated in the Gemara that for four things our ancestors were redeemed from Egypt: they did not change their names, nor their language, etc. Nevertheless, they were sunk in idolatry and in the forty-nine gates of impurity, and the condition for their redemption was that they should first engage in the aspect of repentance, as our sages of blessed memory said (Midrash Rabbah, Parashat 16, Section 2), "Withdraw your hands from idolatry and take for yourselves sheep for the commandments." Therefore, Moses and Aaron urged them towards repentance, as explained in the words of the aforementioned Mekilta, "What does it mean that they did not listen to Moses?" It means that they should fast to separate from idolatry. And we find in the scripture (Ezekiel 20) that Aaron prophesied to them, "Each man cast away the abominations of his eyes," etc. At that time, it was a favorable moment for repentance, for the Holy One, Blessed be He, wanted to take Israel out from under the impurity of Egypt, and they were unable to separate from it because they were sunk in the forty-nine gates of impurity. Had it not been for Ezra, they would have remained there forever, and the Holy One, Blessed be He, performed wonders to separate them from the impurity of Egypt, as we explained in the words of the verse, "Has God attempted to take for Himself a nation from the midst of a nation," that the Holy One, Blessed be He, removed the impurity of Egypt from among them. And it was a time suitable for the purification of the holy sparks, which Israel rectified and extracted from there all the holy sparks, as it is said, "And they plundered Egypt." Therefore, the days of the Shovavim are suitable for the rectification of the known sin, and they are days suitable for repentance, for the reading awakens the merit of the time, even though throughout the entire year there is nothing that stands before repentance, but the merit of these days assists a person to awaken to return to his Creator, Blessed be He.
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual struggle of the Israelites in Egypt, emphasizing that despite their good qualities, they were deeply entrenched in idolatry and impurity. Moses and Aaron's mission was to awaken them to repentance, as their redemption required a prior return to God. The text highlights the significance of specific times, such as the "Shovavim" period, which are particularly conducive to repentance and spiritual rectification, illustrating that while repentance is always possible, certain times enhance the ability to return to God. Ultimately, it underscores the divine intervention that facilitated their separation from the impurities of Egypt, allowing for their eventual redemption.

passage_content: וכתבהשלה"קדפרעההי' חכם להרע, וידע כי תקנתם וגאולתם של ישראל תלוי בתשובה, ע"כ רצה למנוע מהם דרכי התשובה ולהחטיאם, כי ידעשעי"זיעכב גאולתם ויאריך עת גלותם, ופי' בזהמ"שוירעו אותנו המצרים, שעשו אותנו רעים וחטאים, וכתב הרמב"ן ז"לבפ' בא שנתארך להם זמן הגלות ל' שנים, כי לא הי' הגזרה רק ועבדום וענו אותם ארבע מאות שנה, ולבסוף יצאולת"לשנים מגזירת ברית בין הבתרים, לפי שגרם החטא להתארך גלותם,כמשה"כאיש שקוצי עיניו לא השליכו ואת גילולי מצרים לא עזבו (יחזקאל כ'), וע"כ השקיעו פרעה ומצרים כלכוחותםלהחטיא את ישראל ולמנעם מתשובה, כי ידעו שגאולתם תלוי בתשובה, ואיכא למ"ד במס' סנהדרין (קי"א) שלא יצאו אלא ב' מס'רבוא, והשאר מתו בג' ימי אפילה שלא היו רוצים לצאת, וכ"ז הי' ע"י גודל התגברות טומאת מצרים עליהם, כמבואר במדרש ילקוט (רמז רל"ד) שאמר הקב"ה לס"מ שלא עבדו ישראל לע"ז אלא מתוך שעבוד וטירוף הדעת שגרמו להם המצריים.
translation: And it is written, "For Pharaoh was wise to do evil, and he knew that the rectification and redemption of Israel depended on repentance. Therefore, he wanted to prevent them from the ways of repentance and to cause them to sin, for he knew that through this their redemption would be delayed and the duration of their exile would be prolonged." And he explained this with the verse, "And the Egyptians treated us harshly" (Exodus 1:13), that they made us wicked and sinful. And the Ramban, of blessed memory, wrote in Parashat Bo that the duration of their exile was extended by thirty years, for the decree was only "And they shall serve them and they shall afflict them for four hundred years," and in the end, they left only after two years from the decree of the covenant between the pieces, because sin caused their exile to be prolonged, as it is written, "A man whose eyes are not cast aside and whose idols of Egypt they did not forsake" (Ezekiel 20:8). Therefore, Pharaoh and the Egyptians invested all their efforts to cause Israel to sin and to prevent them from repentance, for they knew that their redemption depended on repentance. And there is a teaching in the tractate Sanhedrin (111) that they did not leave except for two out of six hundred thousand, and the rest died in three days of darkness because they did not want to leave. And all this was due to the great intensification of the impurity of Egypt upon them, as explained in the Midrash Yalkut (Remez 234) that the Holy One, blessed be He, said to the Satan that Israel did not serve idols except out of servitude and madness that the Egyptians caused them.
summary: The passage discusses the idea that Pharaoh, aware that the redemption of the Israelites depended on their repentance, sought to prevent them from returning to God and thus prolong their exile. It emphasizes that the Israelites' sins, influenced by the Egyptians' oppression and idolatry, led to an extended period of suffering beyond the original decree. The text highlights the struggle between the forces of impurity and the potential for repentance, illustrating how the Egyptians aimed to keep the Israelites trapped in sin to hinder their redemption. Ultimately, it reflects on the profound connection between repentance and divine salvation in the context of the Israelite experience in Egypt.

passage_content: והנהפשטות הכתוב מורה שהסיבה שלא שמעו אל משה הי' מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה, אבל חז"ל דרשו שהי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז, ר"ל שהי' התגברות כוחות היצר כבד עליהם מאוד והיו משוקעים כ"כ בטומאת מצרים עד שהי' קשה להם להתגבר ולפרוש מע"ז.ואפ"לדהאבהאתליא, והדרש והפשט א' הם, ויובןעפימ"שבס' הישרלר"תשיש ב'מדריגותבעבודת השי"ת:דהאדםשנחלשו כוחות נפשו, יעשההמצוהוהמדותטובות שאין עליהם התנגדות היצר כ"כ וניקל עליו לעשותם, אבל באלו שניגוד היצר קשה בהם, ונפשו של אדם מחמדתן, אין בוכחלעמוד נגד יצרו ולהתגבר עליו, וכאשר יזדמנו לו מניעות וסיבות המעכבים, ימנעו אותו מעבודתוית', אבל לצדיק אמת כל המניעות שבעולם לא יקשו בעיניו מלהתגבר עליהם, ולבו כלב הארי ללחום עם יצרו עד שיתגבר עליו, וכמו"כ ישראל במצרים שמשה רבינו לימד אותם דעת לעבודת השי"ת, והורה להם הדרך שיפרשו מכל מידה רעה ותולדה של ע"ז, וכמ"ש חז"ל (שבת דף ק"ה ע"ב) ולא יהי' בך אל זר איזהו אל זר שבגופו של אדם זהיצה"ר, היום אומר לו עשה כך וכו' עד שאומר לו לך ועבוד ע"ז והוא הולך ועובד, וגם מע"ז ממש צום לפרוש ממנו, ואילולי היו משוקעים כל כך בעבודה קשה, ואילו הי' להם פנאי ודעת מיושבת להתבונן בדברי תוכחה הנאמרים אליהם מפימשרע"ה, לא הי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז, אבל לפי שהי' להם קוצר רוח מעבודה קשה של מצרים, לא הי' בהם דעת להתבונן, וע"כ בצירוף ההתגברות הגדול הי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז, ונמצא כי שני הטעמים א' הם והא בהא תליין
translation: And the simple interpretation of the text indicates that the reason they did not listen to Moses was due to shortness of spirit and hard labor. However, our Sages expounded that it was difficult for them to separate from idolatry, meaning that the forces of the evil inclination were very strong upon them, and they were so immersed in the impurity of Egypt that it was hard for them to overcome and separate from idolatry. And perhaps this is the essence of the matter, and the interpretation and the simple meaning are one. It can be understood according to what is stated in the book "Yashar" regarding the two levels in the service of the Blessed One: that a person whose spiritual powers have weakened should perform the commandments and good traits that do not have such strong opposition from the evil inclination, and it is easier for him to do them. But in those matters where the opposition of the evil inclination is strong, and a person's soul desires them, it is difficult for him to stand against his inclination and overcome it. And when obstacles and reasons that hinder him arise, they will prevent him from his service, etc. But for a true righteous person, all the obstacles in the world will not seem difficult to him to overcome, and his heart is like that of a lion to fight with his inclination until he overcomes it. Likewise, Israel in Egypt, whom Moses our teacher taught the knowledge of serving the Blessed One, and showed them the way to separate from every evil trait and the offspring of idolatry, as our Sages said (Shabbat 105b), "And there shall not be in you a foreign god," what is a foreign god in a person's body? This is the evil inclination, which today tells him to do thus and so, until it tells him, "Go and serve idolatry," and he goes and serves. And even from idolatry itself, he should fast to separate from it. Had they not been so immersed in hard labor, and had they had the leisure and settled mind to contemplate the words of rebuke spoken to them by Moses, it would not have been difficult for them to separate from idolatry. But since they had shortness of spirit from the hard labor of Egypt, they did not have the mind to contemplate, and therefore, combined with the great struggle, it was difficult for them to separate from idolatry. It turns out that both reasons are one, and one depends on the other.
summary: The passage discusses the reasons why the Israelites in Egypt struggled to heed Moses' call to abandon idolatry, attributing their difficulty to both their intense labor and the overwhelming influence of the yetzer hara (evil inclination). It emphasizes that while some individuals can easily perform good deeds when the opposition is minimal, true tzaddikim (righteous individuals) can overcome any obstacles in their spiritual path. The text highlights the interconnectedness of external pressures and internal struggles, suggesting that had the Israelites not been so burdened, they would have found it easier to reject idolatry. Ultimately, it conveys a profound understanding of the challenges faced in spiritual growth and the necessity of inner strength to overcome them.

passage_content: אמנםאעפ"כ לגודל צדקתם של משה ואהרן לא ימלט שלא הכניסובלבםהרהורי תשובה, וכמ"שהבינה לעתים (דרוש ס"ו) לפרשמשה"כעל מלך המשיח ושפט בצדק דלים,דלכאורהמהו רבותי' בהא, וכיצריכאלמימרשלא יעשה עול במשפט, הרי מדה זו מצוי בהכרח אצל כל אדם בינוני, אמנם אמר הנביא שלא יצטרך לשפוט באמירת פיו, אלא שהוא בעצמו בכל פעולותיו ובכל מעשיו יעשה הצדק המוחלט, ובאותו צדק הנמצא בו, יעשה רושם חזק בלב כל אדם, ויתרחקו מעשות דבר מעוקל, ולא יצטרכו להתקרב למשפט, ונמצא המשפט נעשה מאליו ע"י צדקתו,וז"שושפט בצדק ר"ל ע"י צדקתווכו'.וק"זהייטב לבזלל"הכתבבפ' מעות בשם הארי' דבי עילאיזלל"הלפרש הפסוק ומבןחמשיםשנה ישוב מצבא העבודה, שבן לוי נפסל בשנים, ולא יעבוד עוד בפועל ממש, אבל ושרת את אחיו לשמור משמרת לעורר הלבבות, הגם שעבודה לא יעבוד עוד, אבל בכל פעולותיהם ומעשיהם יכניסו רושם התעוררות לתשובה בלב ישראל, עכ"ד, ועל אחת כמה וכמה שמשה ואהרן בגודל צדקתם ועל ידי פעולותיהם ומעשיהם הטובים ובדיבורי תוכחתם הכניסו רושם הרהורי תשובה בלבבות בני ישראל, ואף עלפי שלא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה, והי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז לגמרי. אבל אעפ"כ הפריעו את העם ממעשיהם, ונתגרה בקרבם מלחמה בין כוחותהמנגדיםהיצ"טוהיצה"ר,ונתרפומע"ז ומטומאת מצרים, כמ"שבספה"קזכרוןזאתמההצה"קמלובלין זי"עבפ' קרח, עה"פ ונלחמו אתך ולא יוכלו לך כי אני ד' אתך להצילך,דלכאורההול"לולחמו אתך,דנלחמומשמע שנפעלים ע"י אחרים, אמנם הכוונהדע"כהרשעים שונאים הצדיקים ורוצים להרע להם,דע"יעבודתם של הצדיקים נכנס בהם השפעה של יר"ש,ועי"זמתגרה מלחמהבפנימותםובקרבם,היצ"טעםהיצה"ר, ואינם רוצים בכך, וע"כ הם שונאים לצדיקים,וז"שונלחמו אתך, שעל ידך הם נפעלים למלחמה, אבל לא יוכלו להרע לך כי ד' אתך להצילך עכ"ל.
translation:
Indeed, despite this, due to the great righteousness of Moses and Aaron, they could not avoid having in their hearts thoughts of repentance, as the explanation is given at times (in Drush S"V) to interpret the verse regarding the King Messiah, "and he shall judge the poor with righteousness." At first glance, what is the significance of this, my masters? And just as it is necessary for him to not commit injustice in judgment, this quality is necessarily found in every average person. However, the prophet said that he will not need to judge by the utterance of his mouth, but rather he himself, in all his actions and deeds, will perform absolute justice, and with that justice found within him, he will make a strong impression on the heart of every person, and they will distance themselves from doing anything crooked, and they will not need to approach judgment, and thus judgment will occur by itself through his righteousness. This is what is meant by "and he shall judge with righteousness," meaning through his righteousness, etc. 

And this is good to explain, as written in Parshat Ma'ot in the name of the Ari, that to explain the verse "and from the age of fifty he shall return from the service of work," that a Levite is disqualified by age, and he will not work in actual service anymore, but he will serve his brothers to guard the watch to awaken the hearts, even though he will not work anymore, but in all their actions and deeds, they will instill an impression of awakening for repentance in the hearts of Israel. Thus far. And all the more so, Moses and Aaron, due to their great righteousness and through their good actions and their words of reproof, instilled an impression of thoughts of repentance in the hearts of the children of Israel, even though they did not listen to Moses due to shortness of spirit and hard work, and it was difficult for them to completely separate from idolatry. However, despite this, they disturbed the people from their actions, and a war was stirred up among them between the forces of the opposing side, the good inclination and the evil inclination, and they were healed from idolatry and from the impurity of Egypt, as it is written in the holy book "Zikaron Zot" from the holy Rabbi of Lublin, may his merit protect us, in Parshat Korach, on the verse "and they will fight against you, and they will not be able to harm you, for I am the Lord with you to save you." At first glance, it should have said "and they will fight with you," for "fighting" implies being acted upon by others. However, the intention is that the wicked hate the righteous and want to harm them, and through the work of the righteous, an influence of fear of Heaven enters them, and thus a war is stirred up within them and among them, between the good inclination and the evil inclination, and they do not want this, and therefore they hate the righteous. This is what is meant by "and they will fight against you," that through you they are acted upon for war, but they will not be able to harm you, for the Lord is with you to save you. Thus far.
summary: The passage emphasizes the profound righteousness of Moses and Aaron, suggesting that their actions and teachings instilled a sense of repentance in the hearts of the Israelites, even amidst their struggles with idolatry and oppression. It highlights the concept that true justice, as exemplified by the Messiah, transcends mere verbal judgment and manifests through righteous deeds that inspire others to turn towards repentance. Furthermore, it illustrates the internal spiritual conflict between the good inclination and the evil inclination, asserting that the presence of righteous individuals can provoke this struggle within others, ultimately leading to divine protection and salvation.

passage_content: ופרעההרשע רצה למנועבנ"ימלעשות תשובה, כי ידע כי בנפשו הוא,שעי"זיזכו ישראל לצאת ממצרים, וע"כ אמר למה משה ואהרן תפריעו את העם ממעשיו, ולא הי' כוונתו עלסבלותם, כי ע"ז הי' לו עצה ע"י הנוגשים והשוטרים, שלא יניחו אותם לפרוע מעבודתם, אבל כוונתו הי' שלא להפריע אותם "ממעשיהם שבבית", כי עד שלא באו משה ואהרן היו עושים מתועבת מצרים, ועכשיו הפריעו אותם ממעשיהם, וע"כ לא אמרסבלותםכי לאהיתהכוונתו על סבלות משא. וטענתו של פרעההיתהשבלא"הלא יעשו ישראל תשובה גמורה, ואין בכוחכם לבטלם מע"ז לגמרי שכבר הם משוקעים בטומאה כ"כ, ואין זה אלא הפרעה לשעה, וכל עבודתכם ללא תועלת, וכיון שכן מצו' שלא לומר להם, כיבודאילא ישמעו לדבריכם, וכמ"ש חז"ל במס' יבמות (ס"ה ע"ב) כשם שמצו' לומר דבר הנשמע, כך מצו' שלא לומר דבר שאינו נשמע, רבי אבא אמר חובה הוא שנא' אל תוכח לץ פן ישנאך, והטעם פן ישנאך כי השנאה תעורר בו ההיפך, ויהי' גרוע עוד יותר ויוסיף רעה על רעתו, וע"כ חובה שלא להוכיחו כלהיכאשברור שלא ישמע,וז"שלמה משה ואהרן תפריעו וגו' כי אין זה לטובתם אלא לרעתם,שעי"זיהיו מקולקלים יותרובלא"הלא ישמעו לכםומ"שלכו לסבלותיכם הכוונה למלאכתכם שבבית כמושפרש"יז"ל, ומה הי' מלאכתם של משה ואהרן עבודת השי"ת, כמ"ש הרמב"ן ז"לדמנהגכל עם להיות להם חכמים מורי תורתם, ולכן הניח פרעה להם שבט לוי שיהיו חכמיהם וזקניהם, והי' כ"ז סיבה מאת ד' עכ"ד ז"ל. והנה ידע פרעה שלא יעלה בידולהמנעקדושים אלו מעבודת השי"ת, אלא שלא רצה שיפריעו גם את העם ממעשיהם הרעים, ולעוררם אל התשובה ע"כ אמר לכו לסבלותיכם אל עבודתכם שבבית, ובין תנור לכיריים תעבדו עבודת ד' לעצמכם, ואל תפריעו את העם ממעשיו, כיבלא"הלא יועיל אלא יזיק.ועד"זהי' כוונת אמירתו הרעה אל משה ואהרן.
translation: And the wicked Pharaoh wanted to prevent Bnei Yisrael from repenting, for he knew that it was in his soul, that through this they would merit to leave Egypt. Therefore, he said, "Why do Moses and Aaron disturb the people from their work?" His intention was not regarding their suffering, for he had advice from the taskmasters and officers, that they should not be allowed to cease from their labor. Rather, his intention was not to disturb them "from their actions at home," for before Moses and Aaron came, they were engaged in the abominations of Egypt, and now they disturbed them from their actions. Therefore, he did not mention their suffering, for his intention was not regarding the burden of labor. And Pharaoh's claim was that without a doubt, Bnei Yisrael would not do complete repentance, and you do not have the power to completely nullify their idolatry, for they are already so deeply entrenched in impurity. This is only a temporary disturbance, and all your work is without benefit. Since this is the case, it is a commandment not to speak to them, for they will not listen to your words, as our Sages said in Yevamot (65b), "Just as it is a commandment to say something that is heard, so it is a commandment not to say something that is not heard." Rabbi Abba said it is an obligation to say, "Do not reprove a scorner, lest he hate you," and the reason is that hatred will awaken the opposite in him, and he will become even worse and add evil to his evil. Therefore, it is an obligation not to reprove him at all when it is clear that he will not listen. And this is what he meant when he said, "Why do Moses and Aaron disturb..." for this is not for their good but for their detriment, as through this they will become more corrupted, and without a doubt, they will not listen to you. And "go to your burdens" means to your work at home, as it is explained. And what was the work of Moses and Aaron? The service of the Holy One, Blessed be He, as the Ramban, may his memory be blessed, wrote about the custom of every nation to have wise men who teach them their Torah. Therefore, Pharaoh allowed them the tribe of Levi to be their wise men and elders, and all this was a reason from God, may He be blessed. And behold, Pharaoh knew that he would not succeed in preventing these holy ones from the service of the Holy One, Blessed be He, but he did not want them to also disturb the people from their evil deeds and to awaken them to repentance. Therefore, he said, "Go to your burdens, to your work at home," and between the oven and the stove, serve the work of God for yourselves, and do not disturb the people from their actions, for without a doubt, it will not help but will harm. And this was the intention of his evil statement to Moses and Aaron.
summary: In this passage, the author discusses Pharaoh's intention to prevent the Israelites from repenting and turning away from their sinful practices, as he understood that their redemption from Egypt depended on their ability to do so. Pharaoh's objection to Moses and Aaron was not about their physical suffering but rather about disrupting their immoral behaviors, which he believed would lead to greater corruption. The text emphasizes the idea that true spiritual work and connection to God must not be hindered by engaging in sinful actions, and it highlights the importance of guiding the people towards repentance rather than allowing them to remain entrenched in their wrongdoing. Ultimately, Pharaoh's resistance reflects a deeper struggle against the divine call for redemption and transformation.

passage_content: וא"שמה שקרא עבודת ישראל בשם מעשיו, ועל עבודת משה ואהרן אמר לשוןסבלותם,דעבודתהשי"ת הי' נחשב בעיניו לסבלות וטורח משא, כמו שדרך הרשעים ששמירת התורה והמצות הם בעיניהם לטורח ולמשא כבידה, ובאמת אמרו בגמ' מצות לאו להנות נתנו אלא לעול עלצאווריהםניתנו, ועבודה קשה הוא להשיג אף תנועה קלה של אמת, ולהתגבר נגדהיצה"רהוא חוץ לדרך הטבע, כמ"ש ז"ל (קידושין דף ל' ע"ב)דאלמלאהקב"ה עזרו אינו יכול לו,אלא שאינה טורח וסבלות בעיני הצדיקים, אדרבה כל מאוים וחשקתם ותשוקתם לקיים רצונוית', אף שקשה מאודולפוםצערא אגרא, אבל בעיני הרשעים נחשב העול הזה לטורח וסבלות, וע"כ קרא פרעה לעבודת משה ואהרן בשם סבלות, וא"ל לכו לסבלותיכם. ומעשיהם של ישראל שהיועושיןבביתםמבחי' ע"ז ומבחינת מעשיהם של מצרים, זה קרא בשם מעשים, כי אלו לא הי' סבלות וטורח משא בעיניו, שהיו ערבים וטובים בעיניו כמ"ש ז"ל עליצה"רשתחלתומתוק וסופו מר,וז"שלמה משה ואהרן תפריעו את העם ממעשיו שבבית, לכו לסבלותיכם שאתם תעבדו העבודה קשה בעבודת השי"ת, ואצלםבלא"הלא תפעלו כלום.
translation: And I heard that the work of Israel is called by the name of their deeds, and regarding the work of Moshe and Aharon, he used the term "their burdens." For the service of the Holy One, Blessed be He, was considered by him as a burden and toil, just as it is the way of the wicked that the observance of the Torah and the commandments is seen by them as a burden and a heavy load. And indeed, it is said in the Gemara that the commandments were not given for enjoyment but to place a yoke upon their necks. And it is a hard work to achieve even a slight movement of truth, and to overcome the evil inclination is outside the natural way, as our sages have said (Kiddushin 30b) that if not for the Holy One, Blessed be He, helping him, he cannot succeed. However, it is not a burden and toil in the eyes of the righteous; on the contrary, all their fears and desires and longings are to fulfill His will, even though it is very difficult and according to the pain is the reward. But in the eyes of the wicked, this yoke is considered a burden and toil. Therefore, Pharaoh called the work of Moshe and Aharon by the name of burdens, and he said to them, "Go to your burdens." And the deeds of Israel, which they were doing in their homes, from the aspect of idolatry and from the aspect of the deeds of Egypt, this he called by the name of deeds, for these were not burdens and toil in his eyes, as they were pleasing and good in his sight, as our sages have said about the evil inclination that its beginning is sweet and its end is bitter. And thus, he said, "Moshe and Aharon, you disturb the people from their deeds in the house; go to your burdens, for you will work the hard work in the service of the Holy One, Blessed be He, and with them, without a doubt, you will accomplish nothing.
summary: The passage discusses the contrasting perceptions of spiritual labor between the righteous and the wicked. It highlights that for the righteous, serving God is a source of joy and fulfillment, despite its inherent difficulties, while for the wicked, it is viewed as a burden and toil. The reference to Pharaoh's labeling of the work of Moses and Aaron as "suffering" underscores this dichotomy, illustrating how the righteous find meaning in their devotion, whereas the wicked see it as a heavy yoke. Ultimately, the text emphasizes that true spiritual fulfillment transcends the challenges faced in serving God.

passage_content: וז"שחז"ל במדרששא"לפרעה אתם למה ודבריכם למה, שהי' פרעה הרשע מהביל את כוחם של משה ואהרן. שלא יוכל לפעול אצל ישראל לעוררם אל התשובה, לאבכחעבודתם ולא ע"י דיבורי תוכחה ומוסר, כמ"ש לעילדהצדיקבכחעבודתו ומעשיו הטובים, יוכל להאיר בלבבותבנ"יולהחזירם בתשובה, וכמו"כ ע"י דיבורי תוכחה, אבל פרעה אמר להם שלא יועילו אצל ישראל, כי כבר הם משוקעים בטומאת מצרים, וטוב שלא לומר דבר שאינו נשמע,וז"שאתם למה, לא יועיל עצמיות שלכם לעשות רושם עליהם לטובה, ודבריכם למה, גם דבריכם לא יועילו, ובחנם כל טרחכם, ע"כ לכו לסבלותיכם והניחו את ישראל לעשות כחפצם וכרצונם.
translation: And this is what our Sages said in the Midrash: Pharaoh said to them, "Why are you here, and what is the purpose of your words?" For Pharaoh, the wicked one, was trying to diminish the strength of Moshe and Aharon, so that he would not be able to influence the Israelites to awaken them to repentance, neither through their labor nor through words of rebuke and moral instruction. As mentioned above, the righteous, through their work and good deeds, can illuminate the hearts of the Jewish people and bring them back to repentance, and likewise through words of rebuke. But Pharaoh told them that they would not be effective with the Israelites, for they were already sunk in the impurity of Egypt, and it is better not to say something that will not be heard. Therefore, he said, "Why are you here?" Your very essence will not make a positive impression on them, and "What is the purpose of your words?" Even your words will not be effective, and all your efforts are in vain. Therefore, go to your burdens and leave the Israelites to do as they please and according to their will.
summary: In this passage, the Hasidic text discusses Pharaoh's attempt to undermine the spiritual influence of Moses and Aaron over the Israelites, asserting that their efforts to inspire repentance and moral awakening would be futile due to the deep entrenchment of the Israelites in the impurities of Egypt. Pharaoh dismisses the potential impact of their righteous actions and words, suggesting that the Israelites are too far gone to respond positively. This highlights the struggle between divine influence and the pervasive power of spiritual exile, emphasizing the challenge of awakening the soul amidst overwhelming negativity. Ultimately, it reflects on the limitations of human effort in the face of deep-seated spiritual disconnection.

passage_content: ומ"שלמה משה ואהרן תפריעו וגו' ולכאורה למה הזכיר שמותם, ואין זה מדרך הלשון שהרי דבר עמהם לנוכח, אמנםג"זהי' מעין הטענה, ויובןעפימ"שק"ז הייטב לב בשםהאו"י, שאין תוכחת מוסר מועיל לזולתו, בלתי ממי שהוא דומה לו, ואם יוכיחנו מי שלא טעםטעםחטא מעולם, יאמרבלבושזה אינו יודע כמה קשה לפרוש מזה ולשוב, וע"כ לא יקבל ממנו תוכחה, אבל אם יוכיחנו מי שחטא ושב, ה"ה יודע טעמו של חטאוהנסיוןלפרוש ממנו, ע"כ יכנסו דיבוריובלבויותר, ופי' בזהמאה"כטוב לשמוע גערת חכם מאיש שומע שיר כסילים, ר"ל מאיש כזה שכבר שמע שיר כסילים ופירש הימנה ועשה תשובה עיי"ש.וז"שפרעה למה משה ואהרן צדיקים כמותכם תפריעו את העם ממעשיו,שבלא"הלא יקבלו ישראל מכם, כי איךיקחוראי' מדרך עבודתכם לעזוב דרכם הרעה ולשוב, כי יאמרו אתם לא חטאתם מעולם לפיכך אין אתם יודעים כמה קשה הוא לפרוש ממנה, וע"כ חדלו מהם כיבלא"הלא יועילו דבריכם ומעשיכם כלום.
translation: "And 'Why do you, Moses and Aaron, disturb the people from their works?' And at first glance, why did he mention their names? It is not the way of language, for he spoke to them directly. However, this is a kind of accusation, and it will be understood according to what is written in the holy books, that no rebuke of moral conduct is effective for another, except from someone who is similar to him. If someone who has never tasted the flavor of sin rebukes us, he will say in his heart that he does not know how difficult it is to separate from it and return, and therefore he will not accept rebuke from him. But if someone who has sinned and repented rebukes us, he knows the taste of sin and the struggle to separate from it, and thus his words will penetrate our hearts more deeply. And it is explained in the holy writings that it is good to hear the rebuke of a wise man than the song of fools, meaning from a person who has already heard the song of fools and separated from it and repented, as explained there. And this is what Pharaoh meant: 'Why do you, righteous ones like you, disturb the people from their works?' For without a doubt, Israel will not accept from you, for how can they take a sign from your way of service to abandon their evil path and return? For they will say, 'You have never sinned, therefore you do not know how difficult it is to separate from it,' and therefore they ceased from them, for without a doubt your words and actions will not help at all."
summary: In this passage, the author emphasizes the importance of relatable authority in moral guidance, suggesting that only those who have experienced sin and repentance can effectively admonish others. The mention of Moses and Aaron serves to illustrate that their righteousness may hinder their ability to connect with the Israelites, who might perceive them as lacking understanding of the struggles involved in overcoming sin. Thus, the text highlights the necessity of empathy and shared experience in the process of repentance and moral instruction.

passage_content: ובזהאפ"למ"שהכתוב ולא שמעו אל משה,דהול"לולא שמעו אליו שהרי מוזכר בפסוק שמשה הי' המדבר אליהם, אמנם גם זה הי' טעם הסיבה שלא שמעו אליו, לצד שמשה הי' המדבר ולצד גדולתו וצדקתו, לפי שהי'ההבדל ביניהם רב, ורחוק מאוד מדריגתוממדריגתם, ע"כ לא לקחו ראי' מגדולתו וצדקתו, כי חשבו שאין כוחם ככוחו בעבודת השי"ת, וכמ"ש לעיל דאין תוכחת המוכיח מוצלחת כ"א כשיוכיח רעהו הדומה לו.
translation: And in this, it is explained that the verse states, "And they did not listen to Moses," for it could have said, "If they did not listen to him," since it is mentioned in the verse that Moses was the one speaking to them. However, this was also the reason why they did not listen to him, because Moses was speaking and due to his greatness and righteousness, for the difference between them was great and very far from their level. Therefore, they did not take evidence from his greatness and righteousness, as they thought that their strength was not like his in the service of the Blessed One, as mentioned above, that the reproof of the one who reproves is only successful when he reproves a peer.
summary: In this passage, the author reflects on the reasons why the Israelites did not listen to Moses, despite his greatness and righteousness. The key insight is that the vast difference in spiritual stature between Moses and the people led them to feel inadequate and disconnected from his authority. This highlights the Hasidic concept that effective rebuke or guidance must come from someone who is relatable and similar in spiritual standing to the one being addressed. Thus, the lack of connection prevented them from recognizing the power of Moses' words and teachings.

passage_content: ובפשטותאפשר לתרץ מה שלא שמעו אל משה עכשיו, ולעיל כתיבבפ' שמות ויאמן העם וישמעו כי פקד ד' אתבנ"יוכי ראה את ענים וגו', הרי ששמעו אליו אע"פ שהיו ג"כ בקוצר רוח מעבודה קשה, ומה נשתנה עכשיו שלא שמעו אליו, אולם אפשר לחלקדשםלא נתבשרו רק בבשורת הגאולה לבד, ע"כ שמעו אליו, וכמ"ש במדרש וכי יש לך אדם שמתבשר בשורה טובה ואינו שמח בתמי'. אבל עכשיו נתבשרו גם על קבלת התורהשא"למשה מאמר השי"ת ולקחתי אתכם לי לעם והייתי לכםלאלקיםוגו', וכתבהראב"עוהרמב"ן ז"ל,דבישרלהם על מעמד הר סיני וקבלת התורה, כי שם נאמר והייתם לי סגולה מכל העמים, וגם אמר להם לפרוש מע"ז שנא' והייתי לכםלאלקיםוגו' ע"כ ולא שמעו אל משה עכשיו, שהי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז, לצד שהיו משוקעים בטומאת מצרים כ"כ, ולגודל התגברות כוחות מצרים עליהם, ונראה כי זה הי' עיקר הסיבה שלא שמעו אליו שהרי במדרש לא הזכירו רק סיבה זו, שהי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז לצד שהיו משוקעים במ"ט שערי טומאה.ומ"שהכתוב טעם הסיבה מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה, זהו טעם מצורף לזכותן של ישראל,דמצריםגרמו להם כל זאת ע"י שעבוד וטרוף הדעת,וע"כ לא הי' להם דעת מיושבת להתבונן בדברי משה רבינו,ואלוליהעבודה קשה היו מתגברים על כוחות הטומאה לפרוש מע"ז כנ"ל.
translation: And simply, it is possible to explain why they did not listen to Moses now, whereas earlier it is written in Parashat Shemot, "And the people believed, and they heard that the Lord had visited the children of Israel and had seen their affliction," thus they listened to him even though they were also short of spirit from hard work. What has changed now that they did not listen to him? However, it is possible to divide that they were only informed of the good tidings of redemption, therefore they listened to him, as it is said in the Midrash, "Is there a person who is informed of good news and does not rejoice in it?" But now they were also informed about the acceptance of the Torah, as the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "And I took you to be My people, and I will be your God," and as the Rabbi Avraham Ibn Ezra and the Ramban, may their memory be blessed, wrote, that He informed them about the event at Mount Sinai and the acceptance of the Torah, for there it was said, "And you shall be to Me a treasured people among all the nations," and He also told them to separate from idolatry, as it is written, "And I will be your God," therefore they did not listen to Moses now, as it was difficult for them to separate from idolatry, because they were so deeply immersed in the impurity of Egypt, and due to the great overpowering of the forces of Egypt over them. It seems that this was the main reason they did not listen to him, for in the Midrash, only this reason is mentioned, that it was difficult for them to separate from idolatry because they were immersed in the forty-nine gates of impurity. And when the verse gives the reason as "because of shortness of spirit and hard work," this is an additional reason in favor of Israel, that Egypt caused them all this through servitude and confusion of mind, and therefore they did not have settled minds to contemplate the words of our teacher Moses, and had it not been for the hard work, they would have overcome the forces of impurity to separate from idolatry, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the reasons why the Israelites initially did not listen to Moses, contrasting their earlier acceptance of the good news of redemption with their reluctance to embrace the call to receive the Torah. It suggests that their inability to respond was primarily due to their deep entanglement in the impurities of Egypt and the overwhelming influence of idolatry, which made it difficult for them to detach from their past. The text emphasizes that their suffering and hard labor in Egypt contributed to a state of mental distraction, preventing them from fully grasping Moses' message. Ultimately, it highlights the struggle between the forces of impurity and the divine call to holiness, illustrating the challenges faced by the Israelites in their journey towards spiritual elevation.

passage_content: ועתהא"ש מה שטען משה רבינו לפני השי"ת הןבנ"ילא שמעו אלי, ואיך ישמעני פרעה,ול"קקושיתהמפרשיםדק"ופריכאכנ"ל, ואפשרדסברתפרעההיתהדהסיבהשלא שמעו אליו ישראל, לצד שהם משוקעים בטומאה וקשה להם לפרוש מע"ז, וכמו שפירשנו לעיל שזוהיתהטענת פרעה למשהבמ"שלמה משה ואהרן תפריעו וגו', כיבלא"הלא ישמעו אליכם בני ישראל, ועתה אם יראה פרעה שישראל לא שמעו אלי, איך ישמעני פרעה, שסבה זו שייך אצלו יותר, שהוא שורש הטומאה ההוא ומרכבה לטומאת מצרים,ובודאיימאן מלשמוע בדבר ד'. גם אפשר שילמד מישראל ועוד יעשה ק"ו לבלתי שמוע, וכמו שמפרשיםמאה"כויתערבו בגוים וילמדו ממעשיהם, שאם ח"ו יתערבו בגוים ויפרצו מעשיהם,הגויםילמדו ממעשיהם, לפישהיצה"רמתגבר על ישראל יותר כמ"ש ז"ל (סוכה דף נ"ב ע"א) מניח כל האומות ואינו מתגרה אלא בישראל, ויוכל להיותשהגויםילמדו ממעשיהם, וכמו"כ כאן טען משה רבינו שפרעה ילמד מהםובודאילא ישמע לי.
translation: And at that time, what Moshe Rabbeinu argued before the Holy One, Blessed be He, was: "They will not listen to me," and how will Pharaoh listen to me? This is not a question that the commentators have asked, and it is possible that Pharaoh's reasoning was the reason that Israel did not listen to him, because they were immersed in impurity and it was difficult for them to separate from idolatry. As we explained above, this was Pharaoh's argument to Moshe: "Why do you disturb the people?" For he said, "Surely they will not listen to you, the children of Israel." And now, if Pharaoh sees that Israel did not listen to me, how will Pharaoh listen to me? This reason is more relevant to him, as he is the root of that impurity and the chariot of the impurity of Egypt. And certainly, he will not listen to the word of G-d. It is also possible that he will learn from Israel and will make a fortiori argument not to listen, as it is explained that they will mix with the nations and learn from their deeds. For if, Heaven forbid, they mix with the nations and break through their deeds, the nations will learn from their actions, because the evil inclination overcomes Israel more, as our sages of blessed memory said (Sukkah 52a) that it leaves all the nations and only provokes Israel. And it could be that the nations will learn from their deeds. Likewise, here Moshe Rabbeinu argued that Pharaoh would learn from them and certainly would not listen to me.
summary: In this passage, Moshe Rabbeinu expresses his concern to Hashem about the Israelites' lack of faith and their entanglement in impurity, which hinders their ability to heed his call. He argues that if the Israelites do not listen to him, it will be even more unlikely for Pharaoh to listen, as Pharaoh embodies the root of impurity and is influenced by the Israelites' spiritual state. The text highlights the interconnectedness of spiritual influence, suggesting that the behavior of the Israelites can affect not only their own fate but also that of the nations around them, emphasizing the struggle against the Yetzer Hara that particularly targets the Jewish people.

passage_content: ומהשישפירכאעל ק"ו זו, דהרי ישראל לא שמעו מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה,משא"כפרעה שאין לו קוצר רוח. אבל טעןמשרע"הדפרעהלא יחשבולפירכא,דבאמתלזכותן של ישראל כתבה תוה"ק כן כנ"ל, ופרעהבודאישאינו בגדר ללמד זכות על ישראל, ויסבור שעיקר הסיבה על שהם משוקעים בטומאת מצרים, וטעם זה שייך אצלו יותרובודאישלא ישמע הוא. ועודאפ"לדבלא"האין זופירכא,דכמודישראללא שמעו אליו מקוצר רוח ולצדנסיוןהעוני,וק"ושלא ישמע פרעה לצדנסיוןהעושר, כי הוא גדולמנסיוןהעוני.
translation: And from this reasoning, it is clear that Israel did not listen due to shortness of spirit and hard work, unlike Pharaoh who does not have shortness of spirit. However, Moshe Rabbeinu argued that Pharaoh would not be considered a valid reason, for in truth, the Torah was written to justify Israel as mentioned above, and Pharaoh, being an idolater, is not in a position to defend Israel, and he would think that the main reason is that they are immersed in the impurity of Egypt, and this reason applies to him more, and certainly he will not listen. Furthermore, one could say that without this, there is no valid reasoning, for just as Israel did not listen to him due to shortness of spirit and the trial of poverty, so too Pharaoh will not listen due to the trial of wealth, for he is greater than the trial of poverty.
summary: The passage discusses the contrasting spiritual states of the Israelites and Pharaoh, emphasizing that the Israelites, burdened by oppression, could not hear the divine message due to their suffering, while Pharaoh, who lacks such constraints, fails to recognize their merit. It highlights that Pharaoh's perspective is flawed, as he attributes the Israelites' plight to their own shortcomings rather than acknowledging their inherent sanctity. The text underscores the idea that true understanding and compassion come from recognizing the struggles of others, particularly in the context of divine justice and mercy. Ultimately, it reflects on the deeper spiritual trials faced by both the oppressed and the oppressor.

passage_content: ומהשהקשו המפרשיםדלמהחזר משה לבוא בטענת ואני ערל שפתים, ועל טענה זו כבר השיב לו הקב"ה מי שם פה לאדם וגו' ואנכיאהי' עם פיךוהוריתיךאשר תדבר.אפ"לעפימ"שהרמב"ן ז"ל (בפ' שמות) עה"פ מי שם פה לאדם, שלא רצה השי"ת להסיר ממנו כובד הפה, בעבור שהי' בו ממעשה הנס שאירע לו עם פרעה כמ"ש רבותינו ז"ל, ומטעם זה נשאר ערל שפתים, אלא שהקב"ה הבטיחו שבעת שידבר אל ישראל יהיו דיבוריו נכונים, והואמ"שלו ואנכיאהי' עם פיךוהוריתיךאשר תדבר, וע"כ יכנסו דבריך ויעשו רושם בלבבותבנ"י, וכמ"ש ז"ל דברים היוצאים מבחינת הלב נכנסים אל הלב אע"פ שלא הטעימן המדבר בשפתיו, והאמת כן הי' שלבסוף שמעו אליובנ"יומשכו ידיהם מע"ז ועשו תשובה כמ"ש ז"ל, וע"כ עכשיו שראה משה רבינושבנ"ילא שמעו אליו ולא נכנסו דבריו באזניהם, ואפשר שחשב משה לצדענותנותוהגדולה שלא זכה למעלה זו שדיבוריו יעשו רושם בלבבותבנ"י, או שלא הועילו מעלת הדיבורים לצד שהי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז, יהי' מאיזה טעם שיהי', עכ"פ אם מעלת הדיבורים לא הועילו, א"כ חזרה טענתו הקודמת ואני ערל שפתים,דמצדהמדברבודאישלא יעשו דברי רושם באזני פרעה, כי אני ערל שפתים.
translation: And regarding the question of the commentators as to why Moses returned with the claim "I am of uncircumcised lips," to which the Holy One, Blessed be He, had already responded, "Who has made man's mouth..." and "I will be with your mouth and will teach you what you shall speak." Even though the Ramban, of blessed memory, explains (in Parashat Shemot) on the verse "Who has made man's mouth," that the Holy One did not want to remove from him the heaviness of the mouth, because it contained within it a miracle that occurred to him with Pharaoh, as our sages of blessed memory have said, and for this reason he remained of uncircumcised lips. However, the Holy One, Blessed be He, assured him that when he would speak to Israel, his words would be effective, and this is what He meant by "I will be with your mouth and will teach you what you shall speak." Therefore, your words will enter and make an impression in the hearts of the children of Israel, as our sages have said, "Words that come from the heart enter the heart," even if the speaker did not flavor them with his lips. And indeed, it was true that in the end they listened to him, and the children of Israel withdrew their hands from idolatry and repented, as our sages have said. And now, since Moses our teacher saw that the children of Israel did not listen to him and his words did not enter their ears, he may have thought that due to his humility and greatness, he was not worthy of this elevation that his words would make an impression in the hearts of the children of Israel, or that the merit of speech was ineffective because it was difficult for them to separate from idolatry. Whatever the reason may be, in any case, if the merit of speech was ineffective, then his previous claim returned, "I am of uncircumcised lips," for from the perspective of the speaker, it is certain that the words would not make an impression in the ears of Pharaoh, because I am of uncircumcised lips.
summary: In this passage, the author explores Moses' reluctance to speak due to his perceived speech impediment, "I am of uncircumcised lips." The Divine response emphasizes that God equips individuals for their mission, assuring Moses that His presence will empower his words to resonate with the hearts of the Israelites. Despite this, Moses doubts the effectiveness of his speech, especially in light of the Israelites' resistance to leaving idolatry, reflecting a deeper struggle between divine empowerment and human limitations. Ultimately, the text highlights the profound connection between heartfelt speech and its impact on the listener's heart, illustrating the transformative power of sincere communication in spiritual leadership.

passage_content: ועתהנבאר דברי המדרש הנ"ל כי ידבר אלכם פרעה וגו' מגיד מראשית אחרית, שהגיד הקב"ה למשה מראשית אחריתוכו', ויתורץ ג"כ מה שהקשינו לעיל למה צו' ד' לעשות אות המטה,ועי"זנתפקר עוד יותר כמ"ש במדרש שהתלוצץ עליו ואמר מעשה כשפים הוא, והביא תינוקות ועשו כן, והנה הבאנו לעיל דברי התרגוםיוב"עודבריהאוהחה"קדבמכתברדנתבררלפרעה שכל המכות המה מעשהאלקים, ובכל מכה ומכה שהביא הקב"ה עליו עד הנה, הי' תולה בכשפים ולא האמין לשליחי ד', ולכאורה צ"ב הרי הקב"ה מגיד מראשית אחרית, וידע שלא יאמין בהם ויתלה במעשה כשפים, ואין זה מכבוד שמים, שהם באו לפניו בשליחות השם להתרות בו שישלח ד' בהם המכות האלה, והוא הכחישם בפניהם באמרו שמעשה כשפים, וחיזק דבריו במה שגם חרטומי מצרים עשו כן, וא"כ מה הי' תועלתן של המכות האלו, אחרי שלא הודה בהן שהןמאלקיהיכולת, ואם בשביל להכביד את לבבו באו אליו המכות באופן שיטעה בהן ולא יכירבאמותותן, עדיין אין טעם זה מספיק, דאף אם יהי' בהם כדי הכרה,וידע פרעה שמעשהאלקיםהם, יש בידוית' להכביד את לבבו, והרי גם במכת ברד שאמר הכתוב כי בפעם הזאת אני שולח את כלמגפותיאללבך, והכיר שבאו אליו מאת ד' ולא מעשה כשפים, ואמר חטאתי הפעם ד' הצדיק וגו'ואעפ"כ ויחזק לב פרעה ולא שלח את העם, וכמו"כ לכאורה למה לא באו כל המכות באופן שיהא בהם כדי הכרה שהם מעשהאלקים, ובדרך זה ראויליענשיותר אם לא ישמע.
translation: And now we will explain the words of the aforementioned Midrash, that Pharaoh will speak to you, etc., indicating that the Holy One, Blessed be He, revealed to Moses from the beginning of the end, and it will also be clarified what we questioned above regarding why God commanded to perform the sign of the staff. And thus it became even more evident, as stated in the Midrash, that he mocked him and said it was an act of sorcery, and he brought children and did likewise. And behold, we have brought above the words of the translation, "And the words of the love of the Holy One," in the letter of the plague, which clarified to Pharaoh that all the plagues are acts of God. And in every plague that the Holy One, Blessed be He, brought upon him until now, he attributed it to sorcery and did not believe the messengers of God. And at first glance, it is difficult to understand: since the Holy One, Blessed be He, reveals from the beginning of the end, He knew that he would not believe them and would attribute it to acts of sorcery, and this is not fitting for the honor of Heaven, that they came before him in the name of God to warn him that God would bring upon him these plagues, and he denied them in their presence by saying it was an act of sorcery, and he strengthened his words by saying that the magicians of Egypt did likewise. And if so, what was the benefit of these plagues, after he did not acknowledge them as acts of God? And if they came to harden his heart in such a way that he would be misled by them and not recognize their truth, this reason is still insufficient, for even if there were enough for recognition, and Pharaoh would know that they are acts of God, he still has the ability to harden his heart. And behold, even in the plague of hail, as the scripture states, "For this time I will send all My plagues upon your heart," he recognized that they came to him from God and not from acts of sorcery, and he said, "I have sinned this time; the Lord is righteous," etc. And yet, Pharaoh's heart was hardened, and he did not send the people. Likewise, at first glance, why did not all the plagues come in a way that would provide enough recognition that they are acts of God? And in this way, it would seem that he would be punished more if he did not listen.
summary: The passage discusses the paradox of Pharaoh's refusal to acknowledge the divine origin of the plagues, despite God's foreknowledge of his hardened heart. It highlights the tension between divine signs and human disbelief, emphasizing that even when confronted with clear evidence of God's power, Pharaoh attributed the miracles to sorcery. This raises questions about the purpose of the plagues if they did not lead to Pharaoh's recognition of God's authority, suggesting a deeper exploration of free will and divine justice in the face of obstinacy.

passage_content: ולבארכלהעניןנקדיםמ"שהרמב"ן ז"ל (בפ' יתרו) עה"פ ברוך ד' אשר הציל אתכם מיד פרעה וגו' אשר הציל את העם מתחת יד מצרים, דשני הצלות האמורות כאן, הראשונה על משה ואהרן שעשה השי"ת להם נס גדול שלא הרגו אותם פרעה,וז"שאשר הציל אתכם מיד מצרים ומיד פרעה, והנס השני אשר הציל את העם מתחת יד מצרים עכ"ל, מבוארדע"ינס ניצולו משה ואהרן מידם, ואופן הנס הי' ששלח הקב"ה עליו פחד ומורא, ויראו מלנגוע בהם לרעה, כמ"ש ז"ל במדרש (פ' ט' סי' ז') עה"פ ויבלע מטה אהרן אתמטותם, כשראה פרעה כן תמה ואמר, ומה אם יאמר למטה בלע לפרעהולכסאועכשיו הוא בולע אותו, וע"כ נפל עליו פחד ממשה ואהרן, וכ"כ הרמב"ן ז"ל עה"פ והנה לא שמעת עד כה, כי ממופת התנין ואילך לא הי' גוער בהם, רק שומע דבריהם ושותק כי יפחד מהמכות עיי"ש. ואף שתלה מעשיהם בכשפים מ"מ פחד מהם אולי לצד שחשב שכוחם גדול בכישוף יותר מכל חרטומי מצרים, כמ"שהאוהחה"קשלא האמין פרעה לחרטומי מצריםמ"שאצבעאלקיםבמכת כנים, אבל ידמה כי חרטומי מצרים לא השיגו השגת משה ואהרן במכשפות, וע"כ תולים מכה זו במעשהאלקיםעיי"ש.
translation: To explain the matter, we will precede with what the Ramban, may his memory be blessed, states (in Parashat Yitro) regarding the verse "Blessed is the Lord who has saved you from the hand of Pharaoh... who has saved the people from under the hand of Egypt." The two salvations mentioned here are, the first concerning Moses and Aaron, for the Holy One, blessed be He, performed a great miracle for them that Pharaoh did not kill them, and this is what is meant by "who has saved you from the hand of Egypt and from the hand of Pharaoh." The second miracle is "who has saved the people from under the hand of Egypt." It is explained that the miracle was that Moses and Aaron were saved from them, and the manner of the miracle was that the Holy One, blessed be He, sent fear and dread upon them, and they were afraid to harm them, as our sages have said in the Midrash (Parashat Tetzaveh, section 7) regarding the verse "And the staff of Aaron swallowed their staffs." When Pharaoh saw this, he was astonished and said, "What if the staff swallows Pharaoh and the throne, and now it is swallowing him?" Therefore, fear fell upon him from Moses and Aaron. The Ramban, may his memory be blessed, also states regarding the verse "And behold, you have not listened until now," that from the miracle of the serpent onward, he did not rebuke them, but only listened to their words and remained silent because he feared the plagues, as mentioned there. And although he attributed their actions to sorcery, nonetheless, he feared them, perhaps because he thought that their power in sorcery was greater than that of all the magicians of Egypt, as Pharaoh did not believe the magicians of Egypt regarding "the finger of God" in the plague of lice, but he thought that the magicians of Egypt did not attain the level of Moses and Aaron in sorcery, and therefore he attributed this plague to the actions of God, as mentioned there.
summary: The passage discusses the dual salvations experienced by Moses and Aaron, as described by the Ramban, highlighting God's miraculous protection over them from Pharaoh and the Egyptians. It emphasizes that God instilled fear in Pharaoh, preventing him from harming Moses and Aaron, which illustrates the theme of divine intervention in human affairs. The text also reflects on the limitations of Pharaoh's sorcerers compared to the power of God, suggesting that even when Pharaoh attributed the plagues to magic, he recognized the superiority of Moses and Aaron's abilities. This underscores the Hasidic belief in the profound influence of divine presence and the importance of faith in God's protection.
