passage_content: ולבארהעניןנקדים דבריהמד"ר(בפ' שמות פ' ה' סי' ט"ז) ויאמראלהםמלך מצרים למה משה ואהרן תפריעו את העם וגו', מהו למה, אמר להם אתם למה ודבריכם למהוצ"בהכוונה (וכברפירשנוהו לעיל בדברנו פ' שמות). וכעת נ"ל באופן אחר בהקדם דבריהמד"ר(שמות פ"גסט"ז) ויאמר שלח נא ביד תשלח,א"רחייאהגדול אמר לפניו רבש"ע איזה חביב לאדם בן אחיו או בן בנו הוי אומר בן בנו, כשבקשת להציל את לוט בן אחי אברהם, ביד המלאכים שלחת להצילו, בניו של אברהם שהם ס'רבואבידי אתה משלח להצילם, שלח נא ביד המלאכים שאתה רגיל לשלח עכ"ד המדרש. והקשה בס'תוס' חן ממ"ד במס' ב"ב (דף קכ"ח ע"א) שלח לי' ר' אבאלר' יוסף ברחמא, הלכה שלישי בשני כשר להעידוכו', מר בר רב אשיאכשרבאבאדאבא, ולית הלכתא כמר בר רב אשי, ופי'הרשב"םאכשרבאבאדאבאשיעיד הבן לאבי אביווכו', ולית הלכתא כוותי'דבניבנים ובני בני בנים עד אלף דורות לא יעידו לאבותיהם,דבןירך אביו הוא, וכתבוהתוס' ואין נראהלר"יכיוןדאתפלגדראכ"כ עכ"ל, וכן כתבוהתוס' הךסבראבסנהדרין (דף כ"ח ע"א) עיי"ש,ולפי"זלכאורה לא קשהקושיתמשרע"הכלל,דלוטשהי' בן אחיו של אברהם הי' שני בראשון, והוא קרבות הפסול לעדות, אבל ישראל כבראפלוגדראמאברהם. והנה מדברי המדרש הנ"ל מוכח כדבריהרשב"םז"ל דבבנו וב"ב עד סוף כל הדורות לא אמרי'אפלוגדרא, משוםדבןירך אביו הוא. אבל באמת לית הלכתא כדבריהרשב"ם,והתוס'והרא"שוכל הפוסקים חולקים עליו,ובש"עלא הובא דעתהרשב"םכלל,ופסקינןהלכתאדדוררביעי כשר לעדותדכבראפלוגדרא, וא"כ מה הי'קושיתושלמשרע"ה, והרי ישראל במצרים כבר היו אחר כמה דורות, ולא דמי לבן אחיו שהוא שני בראשוןוצ"ב.
translation:
To clarify the matter, we will precede with the words of the Midrash (in Parashat Shemot, section 5, sign 16): "And the king of Egypt said to them, 'Why do you Moses and Aaron disturb the people?' What does 'why' mean? He said to them, 'You, why, and your words, why?' This is in reference to the intention (and we have already explained this above in our discussion of Parashat Shemot). And now it seems to me in another way, by prefacing the words of the Midrash (Shemot 3:16): 'And he said, please send by the hand of whom you will send.' Rabbi Chiya the Great said before Him, 'Master of the Universe, which is more beloved to a person, the son of his brother or the son of his son?' You would say, the son of his son. When you sought to save Lot, the son of Abraham's brother, you sent him by the hands of the angels to save him. The sons of Abraham, who are sixty myriads, you send to save them by your own hand. 'Please send by the hands of the angels that you are accustomed to send.' Thus is the teaching of the Midrash. 

And the Tosafot in the book 'Chen' from Rabbi Abba and Rabbi Yosef in Bava Batra (page 128a) asked: 'Send to him, Rabbi Abba and Rabbi Yosef, in mercy, the third law in the second is valid to testify for him.' Mar Bar Rav Ashi is valid, but the law is not like Mar Bar Rav Ashi. And the explanation of the Rashbam is that it is valid for a father to testify for his son, etc. But the law is not like him, for in the case of sons and the sons of sons up to a thousand generations, they do not testify for their ancestors, for a son is like the thigh of his father. And the Tosafot wrote, 'And it does not seem to me that it is like the Rashbam, for it contradicts the law.' Thus far the text. 

And so the Tosafot wrote this reasoning in Sanhedrin (page 28a), see there. And according to this, it seems that the question of Moshe Rabbeinu is not difficult, for Lot, who was the son of Abraham's brother, was second in the first degree, and he is disqualified for testimony. But Israel, on the other hand, is like a generation from Abraham. And behold, from the words of the aforementioned Midrash, it is proven like the words of the Rashbam, that in the case of a son and a grandson until the end of all generations, we do not say 'disqualified,' because a son is like the thigh of his father. But in truth, the law is not like the words of the Rashbam, and the Tosafot and the Rosh, all the poskim disagree with him. And in Shulchan Aruch, the opinion of the Rashbam was brought as a general rule, and we have ruled that a fourth generation is valid for testimony, for he is already a generation from the first. And if so, what was the question of Moshe Rabbeinu? And behold, Israel in Egypt had already been after several generations, and it is not comparable to the son of a brother who is second in the first degree, etc."
summary: The passage discusses the dialogue between Moses and Pharaoh regarding the liberation of the Israelites, emphasizing the significance of familial relationships in the context of divine intervention. It highlights the idea that while Moses sought to save the Israelites, who are descendants of Abraham, the Torah's teachings on lineage and testimony reflect a deeper connection to God's covenant with His people. The text contrasts the status of Abraham's descendants with that of Lot, illustrating the unique spiritual bond and responsibility that exists within the Jewish lineage. Ultimately, it underscores the theological principle that God's chosen people, despite their historical struggles, maintain a special status in His eyes, warranting divine assistance.

passage_content: ויתבארעפימ"שק"זהיש"מזלל"ה(בפ' תולדות) הטעם על שהיו אבותינו אברהם ויצחק עקרים דאי משום שהקב"המתאוו' לתפילתן של צדיקיםכאמרםז"ל, הי' מספיקבאמהותעקרות והבן, ועוד יעקב בחיר שבאבות מ"ט לא הי' עקר משום טעם זה והי' די ברחל. ואמרתי הטעםדצפההקב"ה שמאברהם ויצחק יצאו גם ישמעאל ועשו הרשעים, ורצה השי"ת שלא יגן עליהם זכותן, וענין זכות אבות הוא כי כל תולדותיו הם אצלובכח, וא"כ כל מה שמסגל מצותומע"טתולדותיומסגליןעמו, וע"כ יש להם מזכות מצותומע"טשל האבות. ולכך היו אבותינו עקרים בטבע, ואם כן לא הי' בהם התולדותבכחהגוף כלל, רק כרגע נעשה להם נס והולידו,ומה"טאין להם לעשו וישמעאל זכות אבות כלל, דלא היו בהםבכחלא בגוף ולא בנפש אבל ישראל היובכחנשמתן כנודעדאברהםויצחק הם מקור נשמת ישראל, ומעתה יובן מה שהיו אבותינו אברהם ויצחק עקרים ויעקב לא הוצרך לזה שלא הי' פסול בזרעו והבן, עכת"ד ק"זזלל"ה.
translation: And it is explained in the name of the "K" that this is the "Mazal" (in Parashat Toldot) the reason why our forefathers Abraham and Isaac were barren, for if it were because the Holy One, blessed be He, desires the prayers of the righteous, as our sages have said, it would have been sufficient with the barren mothers, and understand, furthermore, Jacob, the chosen of the forefathers, was not barren for this reason, and it was enough with Rachel. And I said the reason is that the Holy One, blessed be He, foresaw that from Abraham and Isaac would come also Ishmael and Esau, the wicked, and the Holy One, blessed be He, wanted that their merit should not protect them. And the matter of the merit of the forefathers is that all their descendants are with them in strength, and therefore all that they acquire through commandments and good deeds, their descendants acquire with them. And thus our forefathers were naturally barren, and therefore they did not have offspring in the strength of the body at all, but at that moment a miracle occurred for them and they gave birth. And for this reason, Ishmael and Esau have no merit of the forefathers at all, for they did not have it in strength, neither in body nor in soul, but Israel has it in the strength of their soul, as is known from Abraham and Isaac, who are the source of the soul of Israel. And from now on, it will be understood why our forefathers Abraham and Isaac were barren, and Jacob did not need this, for there was no flaw in his offspring, and understand this. Thus is the conclusion, may their merit protect us.
summary: The passage discusses the barrenness of the patriarchs Abraham and Isaac, suggesting that it was a divine strategy to prevent the emergence of negative descendants like Ishmael and Esau, thereby protecting the sanctity of their lineage. It emphasizes the concept of "Zchut Avot" (merit of the ancestors), indicating that the spiritual legacy of the patriarchs is transmitted through their righteous actions, which are not inherent in their physical descendants who are not aligned with their values. Jacob, being free from such concerns, did not experience barrenness, as his lineage was pure and untainted. Ultimately, the text highlights the unique spiritual connection between the Jewish people and their patriarchs, rooted in the divine will and the merit of their righteous deeds.

passage_content: ומעתהא"שקושיתמשרע"הכיוןדקרבותישראל אל האבות הקדושים מצד שורש נשמתם שהיו כלולים בהםבכח, ולא מצד הגופים, ע"כ לא שייך אצלם סברתאיפלוגדרא, כי קרבתם במקור עליון באילן הנשמות, ואין שם פירוד ולא הפלגה, וע"כ ישראל נחשבים בניםלאבוה"קעד סוף כל הדורות ואין לומר בהםאיפלוגדרא, וא"ש טענתו שלמשרע"האיזה חביב בן אחיו או בן בנו כנ"ל בדברי המדרש רבה.
translation: And from this, the question of Moshe Rabbeinu arises regarding the closeness of Israel to the holy forefathers from the root of their souls, which were included in them in potential, and not from their bodies. Therefore, the concept of division does not apply to them, for their closeness is in the supreme source in the tree of souls, where there is no separation or division. Thus, Israel is considered children of the Holy Father until the end of all generations, and one cannot say about them that there is division. And this clarifies the argument of Moshe Rabbeinu regarding which is the beloved son, whether of his brother or of his son, as mentioned in the words of Midrash Rabbah.
summary: The passage emphasizes the intrinsic connection between the Jewish people and the holy patriarchs, rooted in the spiritual essence of their souls rather than their physical forms. This unity implies that there is no division or separation among them, as they are all part of a higher source within the tree of souls. Consequently, the Jewish people are regarded as eternal children of the Holy Father, transcending generational divides. This concept reinforces the idea that their bond is unbreakable and reflects a profound theological insight into the nature of spiritual lineage and connection.

passage_content: ובזהיתבאר דבריהמד"רהנ"ל למה משה ואהרן וגו' אמר להם פרעה אתם למה ודבריכם למה,דפרעההקשה להם ג"כ קושיא הנ"ל, איזה חביב לאדם בן אחיו או בן בנו, וא"כ למה שלח הקב"ה אתכם להציל את ישראל, ולמה לא שלח מלאכים כאשר שלח להציל את לוט גם לצד שבן בנו חביב יותר ובן ירך אביו הוא, ראוי הי' שהקב"ה בעצמו יגאל את ישראל ולא ע"י שלוחים,כדאיתאבמד"ר(פ' ג' סי' ד') שטעןמשרע"הכן ואמררבוןהעולמים כשירד יעקב למצרים, לא כך אמרת לו אנכי ארד עמך מצרימה ואנכי אעלך גם עלה, ועכשיו אתה אומר לי לכה ואשלחך אל פרעה, לא אנכי הוא שאמרת ואנכי אעלך גם עלה,וז"שמי אנכי כי אלך וגו' לא אנכי אני שהבטחת לאבותיהם עכ"ד המדרש. וכמו"כ פרעה הקשה קושיא זו למשה ואהרן, כי לצד קרבות של האבותדבןירך אביו הוא, הי' ראוי שהקב"ה בעצמו יגאל אתכם, אלא ע"כדכבראיפלוגדראוא"כ בטלה זכות אבות, וכיון שכן אין לכם זכות להיותכם נגאלים, כמבוארבמד"רפ' בא (פט"וס"ד) אמר הקב"ה אם אני מסתכל במעשיהםשל ישראל אינם נגאלים לעולם, אלא למי אני מסתכל לאבותיהם הקדושים ובזכותאבותםאני גואלם, לכך כתיב מדלג על ההרים ואין הרים אלא אבותוכו', וכן דרשו ז"ל במס' ר"ה (דף י"א ע"א) ומבואר כן במדרשי חז"ל בהרבה מקומותדהגאולההי' רק בזכות אבות.דאל"הלא הי' הזמן עדיין שיצאו ממצרים. גם לא הי' זכותם מספיק. ומעתה טען פרעהממנ"פאתם למה, ר"ל למה באתם אתם להיות המדרש רבה, ופרעה הי' חכם גדול בטומאה והשיג את כל אלה, אלא שלא ידע שקרבת ישראל לאבות הקדושים מצד שורש נשמותיהם, ולא שייך בהםאיפלוגדרא. ומה שלא גאלם הקב"ה בעצמו אלא ע"י שליחות משה ואהרן לפי שלא הי' עדיין גאולה נצחיות, והטעם לפי שלא נשלם עדיין בירור כלהניצה"קכמבואר בדבריהאריז"ל, והוצרכו ישראל להשלים זאת בשאר גליות, ולעתיד הקב"ה בעצמו יגאלנו, ואז יהי' גאולה נצחי שאין אחרי' גלות עוד. כמ"ש ז"ל ופדויי ד'ישובון(ישעי'נ"א) אין אומר ופדויי משה ואהרן אלא ופדויי ד', שגאולה העתידה יהי' ע"י הקב"ה בעצמו, ואיתא בילקוט (רמז תקע"ז) אמר הקב"ה בעוה"ז הייתם נושעים ע"י בנ"א, במצרים ע"י משה ואהרן בימי סיסרא ע"י דבורה וברקוכו', ולפי שהיו ע"י בשר ודם הייתם חוזרים ומשתעבדים, אבללע"לאני בעצמי גואל אתכם ועוד יותר אין אתם משתעבדים שנא' ישראל נושע בד' תשועת עולמים ע"כ.
translation:
And in this, the explanation of the aforementioned Midrash is clarified: Why did Pharaoh say to Moses and Aaron, "You, why have you come, and what are your words?" For Pharaoh also posed them the above question: Which is more beloved to a person, a son of his brother or a son of his son? If so, why did the Holy One, blessed be He, send you to save Israel, and why did He not send angels as He sent to save Lot? After all, a son of his son is more beloved, and he is a descendant of his father. It would have been fitting for the Holy One, blessed be He, to redeem Israel Himself and not through messengers, as it is stated in the Midrash (Parashat Shemot, section 4) that Moses argued and said to the Master of the Universe, "When Jacob descended to Egypt, did You not say to him, 'I will go down with you to Egypt, and I will also bring you up'?" And now You say to me, "Go and I will send you to Pharaoh"? Is it not I who You promised, "I will also bring you up"? And this is what is meant by "Who am I that I should go..." I am not the one You promised to their forefathers, thus concludes the Midrash. 

Similarly, Pharaoh posed this question to Moses and Aaron, for due to the closeness of the forefathers, being a descendant of his father, it would have been fitting for the Holy One, blessed be He, to redeem you Himself. However, since there is already a dispute, the merit of the forefathers is nullified, and since that is the case, you have no merit to be redeemed, as explained in the Midrash, Parashat Bo (section 4). The Holy One, blessed be He, said, "If I look at the deeds of Israel, they will never be redeemed, but whom do I look at? To their holy forefathers, and in the merit of their forefathers, I will redeem them." Therefore, it is written, "leaping over the mountains," and mountains refer to the forefathers, etc. And so our sages taught in Tractate Rosh Hashanah (11a), and it is explained in many places in the Midrashim of our sages that the redemption was only in the merit of the forefathers. For otherwise, the time had not yet come for them to leave Egypt, and their merit was not sufficient. 

From now on, Pharaoh argued with them: "Why have you come to be the redeemers?" It would have been fitting for the Holy One, blessed be He, to redeem them Himself due to the closeness of the son, for a son is more beloved. However, since there is a dispute, they have no merit of the forefathers, and therefore your words will not help to bring out Israel, for without the merit of the forefathers, they will never be redeemed, as stated above in the words of the Midrash. And Pharaoh was a great wise man in impurity and understood all these things, except that he did not know that the closeness of Israel to the holy forefathers is due to the root of their souls, and the dispute does not apply to them. 

And the reason the Holy One, blessed be He, did not redeem them Himself but through the agency of Moses and Aaron is because the eternal redemption had not yet been completed, and the reason is that the complete clarification of all the sparks of holiness had not yet been fulfilled, as explained in the words of the Arizal. The Israelites needed to complete this in the other exiles, and in the future, the Holy One, blessed be He, will redeem us Himself, and then there will be an eternal redemption with no subsequent exile. As our sages said, "And the redeemed of the Lord shall return" (Isaiah 51), it does not say "and the redeemed of Moses and Aaron," but "and the redeemed of the Lord," for the future redemption will be by the Holy One, blessed be He Himself. And it is stated in the Yalkut (Remez 817), "The Holy One, blessed be He, said, 'In this world, you were saved by human beings, in Egypt by Moses and Aaron, in the days of Sisera by Deborah and Barak,' etc. And because it was through flesh and blood, you would return and be enslaved again. But in the future, I will redeem you Myself, and even more so, you will not be enslaved, as it is said, 'Israel is saved by the Lord, a salvation of worlds.'"
summary: The passage discusses the theological reasoning behind God's choice to send Moses and Aaron as messengers to redeem the Israelites from Egypt, rather than redeeming them directly. It emphasizes the importance of the merit of the patriarchs, suggesting that the redemption is rooted in their righteousness rather than the current state of the Israelites. Pharaoh's challenge highlights the belief that without the merit of the ancestors, the Israelites would not be worthy of redemption. Ultimately, it conveys the idea that future redemption will be direct from God, leading to an eternal salvation without subsequent exile.

passage_content: ולדרכנויבוארמאמה"כולא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח וגו' והדקדוקים הנ"ל (בקושיאז'), ואפשר על כי ראו ישראל שהוכבד עליהם עול השעבוד, כמאמרמשרע"הומאז באתי אל פרעה וגו' הרע לעם הזה והצל לא הצלת את עמך, ע"כ חששו שאין להם הגנת זכות אבות עוד,דכבראיפלוגדרא, ובלי זכות אבות א"א שיהיו נגאלים כדברי המדרש הנ"ל, והי' להם ראי' ע"זדאיפלוגדראדאל"כלא הי' משה רבינו השליח,דאיזהמהם חביב בן אחיו או בן בנו כטענתמשרע"הלפני הקב"ה,וז"שהכתוב ולא שמעו אל משה ר"ל לפי שמשה רבינו הי' השליח, ע"כ חששודכבראיפלוגדראואין מספיק זכותם להיות נגאלים, וזכות אבות כבר נפסקה, והראי' מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה שהוכבד פרעה עולו עליהם ולא הגין עליהם זכות אבות כנ"ל.
translation: "And they did not listen to Moses because of shortness of spirit and hard work, etc., and the aforementioned nuances (in the question), and it is possible that Israel saw that the yoke of servitude had become heavy upon them, as it is said, 'And now I have come to Pharaoh, etc., he has done evil to this people and you have not rescued your people.' Therefore, they feared that they no longer had the protection of the merit of the ancestors, for the merit had already been diminished, and without the merit of the ancestors, it is impossible for them to be redeemed, as stated in the aforementioned Midrash. And they had a proof for this, that the merit had already been diminished; otherwise, Moses our teacher would not have been the messenger, for which of them is more beloved, a son of his brother or a son of his son, as Moses our teacher argued before the Holy One, Blessed be He. And this is what the verse means, 'And they did not listen to Moses,' meaning that since Moses our teacher was the messenger, they feared that the merit had already been diminished and there was not enough merit for them to be redeemed, and the merit of the ancestors had already ceased, and the proof is from the shortness of spirit and from the hard work, that Pharaoh had laid his yoke heavily upon them and did not protect them with the merit of the ancestors, as mentioned."
summary: The passage discusses the despair of the Israelites under Egyptian bondage, highlighting their fear that the merit of their ancestors no longer protected them from suffering. It reflects on the idea that their suffering, characterized by "shortness of spirit" and "hard labor," led them to doubt the effectiveness of their ancestral merit for redemption. The text emphasizes that without the merit of their forefathers, the Israelites felt unworthy of salvation, questioning the legitimacy of Moses as their messenger from God. Ultimately, it illustrates a profound theological concern regarding the relationship between divine protection, ancestral merit, and the challenges faced by the oppressed.

passage_content: וכמו"כעד"זיתפרש דברי המכילתא שהי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז,ומה"טחששו שאינם ראויים שיגן עליהם זכות אבות, מפני שאינםאוחזיןמעשה אבותיהם בידיהם, וע"כ לא שמעו אל משה להאמין בבשורת הגאולה שיהי' מיד, כי עכשיו נוכחו לדעת שאינם ראויים לזהדכבראיפלוגדראופסקה זכות אבות. ומתורץ קושיא (ז') הנ"ל דאףדמתחילההאמינודכתיבויאמן העם וישמעו כי פקד ד' אתבנ"יוגו', אבל עכשיו ראו שהורע מצבם והכביד פרעה עולו עליהם גם שהי' קשה עליהם לפרוש מע"ז ע"כ חששודאיפלוגדראולאיגיןעליהם זכות אבות ובזכות עצמם א"א שיהיו נגאלים לעולם כמבואר בדברי המדרש הנ"ל, וע"כ לא שמעו אל משה.
translation: And similarly, the words of the Mechilta are explained that it was difficult for them to separate from idolatry, and for this reason they feared that they were not worthy of the merit of the Patriarchs to protect them, because they did not hold the deeds of their forefathers in their hands. Therefore, they did not listen to Moses to believe in the tidings of redemption that would come immediately, for now they realized that they were not worthy of it, as the merit of the Patriarchs had already been diminished. This resolves the question (7) above that even though initially they believed, as it is written, "And the people believed, and they heard that the Lord had visited the children of Israel," but now they saw that their situation had worsened and Pharaoh had increased his burden upon them, and it was also difficult for them to separate from idolatry. Therefore, they feared that the merit of the Patriarchs would not protect them, and that by their own merit they could not be redeemed at all, as explained in the words of the aforementioned Midrash. Therefore, they did not listen to Moses.
summary: The passage discusses the Israelites' struggle to detach from idolatry and their fear that they were unworthy of the merit of their ancestors due to their lack of adherence to the patriarchs' deeds. This led them to doubt Moses' message of imminent redemption, as they perceived their worsening situation and the intensification of Pharaoh's oppression. The text emphasizes the theological concept that reliance solely on ancestral merit is insufficient for redemption, highlighting the need for personal righteousness and faith in God's promise. Ultimately, their disbelief stemmed from a sense of disconnection from both their heritage and divine favor.

passage_content: ובזהיובןהק"והןבנ"ילא שמעו אלי ואיך ישמעני פרעה, ולא קשהקושיתהמפרשיםדק"ופריכאהואדקוצררוח ועבודה קשה לא הי' בפרעה כנ"ל, (קושיא ט') אמנם לדרכנו טעם הכתוב מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה,דמזהשפטו ישראל לומרדכבראיפלוגדראכנ"ל, וא"כמכ"שוק"ושלא ישמעני פרעה,דכברטען כן אתם למה ודבריכם למה כנ"ל, ולא הודה באחדות שורש נשמותיהם של ישראל, שהם כלולים באבות הקדושים באילן הנשמות כענף עם השורש, אבל חשב שכל קרבתם אינה אלא מצד הגופים וכבראיפלוגדרא, ואםבנ"ילא שמעו בזה ק"ו שלא ישמעני פרעה, וא"שכחהק"ו.
translation: And in this is understood the verse "And they did not listen to me," and how will Pharaoh listen to me? And the difficulty of the commentators is not difficult, for it is said that it is due to "shortness of spirit and hard work," which was not the case with Pharaoh as mentioned above. (Difficulty 9) However, according to our path, the reason for the verse is due to "shortness of spirit and hard work," from which the Israelites judged to say that they were already in a state of division, as mentioned above. And if so, how much more so will Pharaoh not listen to me, for they have already claimed, "Why should we listen to you?" And your words are as mentioned above, and he did not acknowledge the unity of the root of the souls of Israel, which are included in the holy ancestors in the tree of souls, like a branch with the root. Rather, he thought that all their closeness was only from the bodies and already in a state of division. And if they did not listen to this, how much more so will Pharaoh not listen to me? And this is understood as a strong inference.
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual disconnect between the Israelites and Pharaoh, emphasizing that Pharaoh's inability to hear the Israelites stems from his lack of recognition of their divine essence, which is rooted in the patriarchs. The text highlights the concept of the unity of souls, suggesting that the Israelites are intrinsically linked to their ancestors, yet Pharaoh perceives them only in a physical sense. This misunderstanding leads to a deeper theological insight about the importance of recognizing the spiritual lineage and unity of the Jewish people, which is essential for true communication and understanding. Ultimately, the passage illustrates the struggle between spiritual awareness and physical perception in the context of redemption.

passage_content: ולדרכנויתורץקושיתהמפרשיםמ"שמשרע"הוהן לא יאמינו לי ולא ישמעו בקולי, ולכאורה הרי כבר הבטיחוית' ושמעו לקולך וגו', (עיין לעיל קושיא ז') והרמב"ןהק'והאוהחה"קתירצו שלא נתרגש משה לטעון טענה זו והן לא יאמינו, אלא לצד שאמר לו ד' דבר חדש מה שלא שמע מקודם, והואאומרוית' אליו ואני ידעתי כי לאיתןאתכם מלך מצרים להלוך וגו', וע"כ חששמשרע"הכי אחרי ראותם בני ישראל שלא ישמע פרעה בקולי, יאמרוה"זראי' ברורה כי לא נראה אליך ד', שאלו היית שליח השם לא ימרה פרעה את דבריוית' עכת"ד ז"ל.ועד"זאפ"ללדרכנו כי לא נסתפק משה רבינו ע"ה בהבטחתוית' ושמעו לקולך, וכן הי' כשבאו בשליחות ראשונה אל ישראל כתיב ויאמן העם וישמעו וגו', אמנם אחר שהודיע לוית' עוד ואני ידעתי כי לאיתןאתכם מלך מצרים להלוך, מעתה חששמשרע"השאחר שיקשה לב פרעה ולא יאבה שלוח, ועוד יכביד עולו עליהם, מאזיפגלבם של ישראל ויסתפקו בשליחותו, ויחששו כיון דלא הועילה להם זכות אבות להקל מעליהם עול השעבודבודאיאפלוגדרא, וא"כ אין זכותם מספיק שיגאלו מיד.
translation: And according to our way, the question of the commentators on what is written, "And they will not believe me and will not listen to my voice," seems to be that they already promised, "And they will listen to your voice," (see above question 7). And the holy Ramban and the holy Ohr HaChaim explained that Moshe was not disturbed to argue this claim, for they will not believe, but rather because Hashem told him a new thing that he had not heard before, which is His saying, "And I know that the king of Egypt will not give you permission to go," and therefore Moshe felt that after seeing the children of Israel that Pharaoh would not listen to his voice, they would say, "This is clear evidence that Hashem did not appear to you," for if you were a messenger of Hashem, Pharaoh would not defy his words. Thus far his words, may his memory be blessed. And similarly, we can say according to our way that Moshe Rabbeinu, peace be upon him, did not doubt the promise, "And they will listen to your voice," and so it was when they first came on the mission to Israel, it is written, "And the people believed and listened," etc. However, after he was informed, "And I know that the king of Egypt will not give you permission to go," from then on Moshe felt that after Pharaoh's heart would be hardened and he would not agree to send them, and he would further burden them, then the hearts of Israel would weaken and they would doubt his mission, and they would be concerned that since the merit of the forefathers did not help to lighten the yoke of servitude, it would not be sufficient for them to be redeemed immediately.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author addresses the tension between Moses' mission to free the Israelites and their potential disbelief in his divine appointment, particularly in light of Pharaoh's resistance. The text emphasizes that Moses, upon receiving the revelation that Pharaoh would not heed his words, feared that the Israelites might doubt their redemption due to the intensified oppression they would face. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the struggle of faith amidst adversity, highlighting the importance of divine assurance and the challenges of maintaining belief in the face of seemingly insurmountable obstacles. Ultimately, it underscores the complexity of faith and the reliance on God's promises in times of trial.

passage_content: וז"שמשה רבינו ע"ה והן לא יאמינו לי, ר"ל שיהי' הצדק אתם שלא יאמינו לי, ובאמת גםמשרע"הטען למההרעותהלעם הזה ולמה זה שלחתני,דבשבילכך לא האמין פרעה לפי שאני הייתי השליח וע"כ הרע לעם הזה, וכמו שפירשנו לעיל אתם למה ודבריכם למה, שטען פרעה שאלמלי הגיע זמן גאולתם של ישראל, הי' מן הראוי שיהי' גאולתם ע"י שליחות המלאכים או ע"יהבוי"תבעצמו כנ"ל. ולצד ב' טענות אלויחלשאמונתם של ישראל בשליחות, וכמו שכן הי' באמתכמאמה"כולא שמעו אל משה לצד שמשה הי' השליח, וגם מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה לפי שהוכבד עליהם עול השעבוד, ומזה ראי'דכבראיפלוגדראכמו שפירשנו לעיל,וז"שוהן לא יאמינו לי שיהי' אתם טענה הנשמעת שלא יאמינו לי, כי יאמרו לא נראה אליך ד' ר"ל בשם המפורש,כדאיתאבתנחומא(פ'וארא) שלא גילה הקב"ה אותה לאבות העולם ולמה גילה אותו למשה על שהלך לגאול את ישראל, מבואר מזהדבחי' שם הוי'ית' הוא שם הגאולה, וגילה אותוית'למשרע"העל שהלך לגאול את ישראלוז"שוהן לא יאמינו לי כי יאמרו לא נראה אליך ד' בשם המפורש, להיות שליח לגאולתן של ישראל.
translation: And thus said Moshe Rabbeinu, peace be upon him, "And they will not believe me," meaning that the truth will be with them that they will not believe me. In truth, Moshe Rabbeinu also argued, "Why have You harmed this people, and why have You sent me?" For this reason, Pharaoh did not believe, since I was the messenger, and therefore he harmed this people. As we explained above, "You" and "your words" refer to Pharaoh's claim that if the time of Israel's redemption had arrived, it would have been appropriate for their redemption to be through the agency of angels or through the Holy One Himself, as mentioned. And due to these two arguments, he weakened the faith of Israel in the mission, as it was indeed true that all heard Moshe because Moshe was the messenger, and also due to the shortness of spirit and hard work, for the yoke of servitude was heavy upon them. And from this, there is proof that there was already a dispute, as we explained above. And thus, "And they will not believe me" is a claim that is heard, that they will not believe me, for they will say, "We have not seen the Lord," meaning the Ineffable Name, as it is stated in the Tanchuma (Parashat Va'era) that the Holy One, blessed be He, did not reveal it to the forefathers of the world, and why did He reveal it to Moshe? Because he went to redeem Israel. It is clear from this that the name of the Lord is the name of redemption, and He revealed it to Moshe because he went to redeem Israel. And thus, "And they will not believe me" because they will say, "We have not seen the Lord," with the Ineffable Name, to be a messenger for their redemption of Israel.
summary: In this passage, the author discusses Moses' concerns about the Israelites' disbelief in his mission as their deliverer, emphasizing that their skepticism stems from their suffering and the lack of divine revelation. The text highlights the significance of God's name, which represents redemption, and notes that it was revealed to Moses specifically because of his commitment to liberate the Israelites. The passage reflects on the tension between divine authority and human doubt, illustrating the challenges faced by a messenger of God in the context of suffering and expectation of redemption. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of faith in the face of adversity and the role of divine intervention in the process of salvation.

passage_content: ובזהיבואר דברי הספרי וידבר משה לפני ד'לאמרהןבנ"ילא שמעו אלי וגו' מה ת"ללאמר, אמר לו רבש"ע הודיעני אם אתה גואלם אם לאו, ולכאורה כבר הבטיחוית' על הגאולהכ"פוע"ד כן שלחו, והודעה זו מה צורך בו (עיין לעיל קושיא ח'). אמנם לדרכנו כל טענתו שלמשרע"ההיתהדזההגורם מה שלא שמע פרעה ולא שמעו בני ישראל, לפי שאני השליח, ומן הראוישהבוי"תבעצמו יגאלם,דאיזהמהם חביב בן אחיו או בן בנו כדברי המדרש הנ"ל,וז"שלאמרהשיבני אם אתה גואלם, ר"ל אתה בעצמך ולא ע"י שליח, ולפי שידעמשרע"השאם הוא יהי' השליח, לא יהיה גאולת עולם, כמבואר בילקוט הנ"לדגאולותהקודמות לפי שהיו ע"י שלוחי בשר ודם הייתם חוזרים ומשתעבדים, ולעתיד יהי' ישראל נושע בד' ואז יהי' תשועת עולמים.מה"טלא רצהמשרע"הלהיות השליח, ולטובתן של ישראלנתכויןשהבוי"תבעצמו יגאלם ויהי' גאולה נצחי,ועד"זיובנו כל טענותיו שלמשרע"המה שסירב ומיאן ולא רצה להיות השליח, והמכוון בהם אחד הוא שמסר נפשו לטובת ישראל וכל דיבוריו היו תפילות ותחנונים לפני הקב"ה לעורר רחמים על ישראל שיגאלםהבוי"תגאולת עולם מיד.
translation: And in this, the words of the Sefarim are clarified, and Moses spoke before the Holy One, Blessed be He, saying: "They will not listen to me," etc. What does it mean to say? He said to Him, Master of the Universe, inform me if You are redeeming them or not. And seemingly, He had already promised them regarding the redemption, as it is written, "So shall you say to the children of Israel," and this information is unnecessary (see above, question 8). However, according to our approach, all of Moses' arguments were that this was the reason why Pharaoh did not listen and the children of Israel did not listen, for I am the messenger, and from the outset, He Himself will redeem them, as some of them are beloved, either a son of his brother or a son of his son, as the aforementioned Midrash states. And this is what "to say" means: He answered me if You are redeeming them, meaning You Yourself and not through a messenger. And since Moses knew that if he would be the messenger, it would not be a redemption for eternity, as explained in the aforementioned Yalkut regarding the previous redemptions, for they were through human messengers, you would return and be enslaved. In the future, Israel will be saved by the Holy One, Blessed be He, and then there will be an eternal salvation. For this reason, Moses did not want to be the messenger, and for the benefit of Israel, he intended that the Holy One, Blessed be He, Himself should redeem them, and it would be an eternal redemption. And thus we understand all of Moses' arguments for which he refused and declined to be the messenger, and the intention behind them is one: he gave his soul for the benefit of Israel, and all his words were prayers and supplications before the Holy One, Blessed be He, to arouse mercy upon Israel that they should be redeemed by the Holy One, Blessed be He, with an eternal redemption immediately.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author explores Moses' reluctance to be the messenger of redemption for the Israelites, emphasizing that true redemption must come directly from God rather than through a human intermediary. Moses expresses a deep concern that if he were to be the agent of redemption, it would not lead to an everlasting salvation, as previous redemptions were temporary and resulted in subsequent enslavement. His insistence on divine intervention reflects a profound understanding of the nature of redemption, highlighting the need for a direct and eternal deliverance from God for the Jewish people. Ultimately, Moses' prayers and pleas are aimed at invoking God's mercy to ensure a lasting and complete redemption for Israel.

passage_content: ועתהנבוא לבאר דברי המדרש הנ"ל (בקושיאו')הה"דופניתי אני לראות חכמה והוללות וסכלות וגו', נאמר עלמשרע"העל שאמר למההרעותהוכו', שאותה חכמה ודעת של משה של הוללות וסכלות היווכו',וצ"בכי איך אפשר שיהיו שני הפכים בנושא א' חכמה ודעת והוללות וסכלות עייןקושיתנולעיל. ויבואר עפ"י דבריהגמ' עירובין (דף נ"ד ע"ב) אילת אהבים ויעלת חן באהבתה תשגה תמיד (משלי ה') כגון ר' אלעזר בןפדת, אמרו עליו על ר"א שהי' יושב ועוסק בתורה בשוק התחתון של ציפורי, וסדינו מוטל בשוק העליון של ציפוריוכו',פרש"יבאהבתה תשגה תמיד בשביל אהבתה של תורה תעשה עצמך שוגה ופתי להניח עסקיך ולרוץ לדבר הלכה עכ"ל, עכ"פ מצינו בחי' זו אצל צדיקים וחכמים גדולים, שלגודל אהבתם בלימודהתוה"קואהבתהבוי"ת, עשו דברים שהיומשתולליןבהם על הבריות, אבל תוכן ופנימיות מעשיהם הי' בהשכל ודעת ובחכמה נפלאה מאהבת והדביקות בוית'ובחכמתהתוה"ק, אלא שהחכמההיתהמסותרת ומכוסה וטמיר, וע"כ הי'נראה כלפי הרואים כהוללות וסכלות. וכמו"כלעניננובמאמרמשרע"השאמר למה הרעות וגו' מסר נפשו לתועלת ישראל כמ"ש לעיל, והי' בזה חכמה גדולה, שפעל בדיבוריו הצלה לישראל להקל מעליהם עול השעבוד.
translation:
And now let us explain the words of the aforementioned Midrash (in his question) "I see wisdom and folly, etc." This is said regarding Moshe Rabbeinu, who asked, "Why have You done evil to Your people?" For that wisdom and knowledge of Moshe were considered folly and foolishness. And the question arises: how is it possible for there to be two opposites in one subject, wisdom and knowledge, and folly and foolishness? Refer to the question posed above. 

It can be explained according to the words of the Gemara in Eruvin (54b): "The doe of love and the gazelle of grace, in her love she will always err" (Proverbs 5). For example, regarding Rabbi Elazar ben P'dat, it was said about him that he would sit and engage in Torah in the lower marketplace of Tzipori, while his cloak was lying in the upper marketplace of Tzipori, etc. The explanation is that "in her love she will always err" means that for the love of Torah, one should make oneself foolish and simple to leave one's business and run to discuss halacha. 

In any case, we find this quality among the righteous and great sages, that due to their immense love for the study of the Holy Torah and the love of the Blessed One, they did things that seemed to be foolishness in the eyes of others. However, the essence and inner nature of their actions were with understanding, knowledge, and wondrous wisdom stemming from love and attachment to the Blessed One and the wisdom of the Holy Torah. It was just that the wisdom was hidden and concealed and mysterious, and therefore it appeared to those who saw it as folly and foolishness. 

And similarly, regarding the matter of Moshe Rabbeinu, who said, "Why have You done evil, etc.," he risked his life for the benefit of Israel, as mentioned above, and in this there was great wisdom, for he acted with his words to bring salvation to Israel and to lighten the yoke of servitude from upon them.
summary: The passage discusses the apparent contradiction between wisdom and folly as exemplified by Moses, who questioned why he was treated harshly despite his profound understanding. It highlights that true wisdom can sometimes appear as foolishness to the untrained eye, particularly when driven by a deep love for Torah and a commitment to the welfare of others. The actions of great sages, like Rabbi Elazar ben P'dat, demonstrate that their seemingly reckless behavior stems from a hidden, profound wisdom rooted in their devotion to God and the Torah. Ultimately, this reflects the idea that genuine spiritual insight may be misinterpreted as folly, yet serves a higher purpose in the divine plan.

passage_content: ויובןעפ"י מ"ד בגמ'ב"ק(דף נ' ע"א) מעשה בבתו שלנחוניאחופרשיחיןשנפלה לבור גדול, באו והודיעו את ר'חנינאבןדוסא, שעה ראשונה אמר להם שלו'וכו', שלישית אמר להם עלתה וכו' א"ל נביא אתה, אמר להם לא נביא אנכי וכו' אלא כך אמרתי דבר שנצטער בו אותו צדיק יכשל בו זרעו,א"ראחא אעפ"כ מת בנו בצמא, שנא'וסביביונשערה מאוד מלמד שהקב"ה מדקדק עםסביביואפי' כחוט השערה והקשובתוס'אכתימנ"ל הא מת בנו בצמא, ותירצודמ"מבאותו דבר עצמו לא הי' ראויליכשלעיי"ש. ובשיטה מקובצת כתב ולרבינו נראה לפרשמ"שרחב"דאמרתי דבר שנצטער בו אותו צדיק יכשל בו זרעו, כלומר השמעתי דבר זה לפני הקב"ה, והסכים הקב"ה לדברי שכן דרכו של הקב"ה שמסכים לסברת הצדיקים שבדור, וכשמת בנו בצמא כבר מת ר'חנינאוכו' עיי"ש. ובזה יבואר דברי המדרש הנ"ל שביקשה מדת הדין לפגוע במשה, לפי שכלפי חוץ היו נראים הדיבורים כהוללות וסכלות, כמבואר בדברי המדרש שכבר הודיע הקב"ה למשה שלא יניח אותם פרעה לילך וכו' ומשה לא שמר את הדבר ובא להתחכם וכו' והתחיל אומר למה הרעות, והמלאכיםמב"דשל מעלה לא הבינו החכמה המסותרת בדבריו, וע"כ ביקשה מדת הדין לפגוע במשהוז"שוידבראלקיםאל משהבמדה"ד, ולפי שנסתכל הקב"ה שבשביל צערן של ישראל דיבר כך, חזר ונהג עמובמדתהרחמים שנא' ויאמר אליו אני ד',דהבוי"תיודע הנסתרות וכוונה הפנימיות שבדיבוריו, שהי' בזה התחכמות נפלאה והועיל הרבה להצלת ישראל להקל מעליהם עול השעבוד, והקב"ה מסכים לסברת הצדיקים כנ"ל.
translation: And it is understood according to what is stated in the Gemara Bava Kamma (page 50a), a story about the daughter of Nachuniah the digger of wells who fell into a deep pit. They came and informed Rabbi Chanina ben Dosa. At first, he said to them, "She is well," etc. On the third time, he said to them, "She has risen," etc. They said to him, "You are a prophet." He replied to them, "I am not a prophet," etc., but I said that a righteous person who suffers from something, his offspring will stumble in that matter. However, despite this, his son died of thirst, as it is stated, "And around me there was a very great storm," which teaches that the Holy One, blessed be He, is meticulous with the surroundings, even as a hair's breadth. And the question arises, how did his son die of thirst? And the answer is that nevertheless, from that very matter, it was not fitting for him to stumble. And in the Shita Mekubetzes, it is written that our Rabbi seems to explain that I said a thing that a righteous person suffers from, his offspring will stumble in it, meaning I presented this matter before the Holy One, blessed be He, and the Holy One, blessed be He, agreed with my words, for it is the way of the Holy One, blessed be He, to agree with the reasoning of the righteous of the generation. And when his son died of thirst, Rabbi Chanina had already died, etc. There, it will be clarified the words of the aforementioned Midrash that the attribute of justice sought to strike Moses, for outwardly, the words seemed like folly and foolishness, as explained in the words of the Midrash that the Holy One, blessed be He, had already informed Moses that Pharaoh would not let them go, etc., and Moses did not heed the matter and came to be clever, etc., and began to say, "Why have You done evil?" And the angels from the heavenly court did not understand the hidden wisdom in his words. Therefore, the attribute of justice sought to strike Moses, as it is said, "And God spoke to Moses in the attribute of justice." And since the Holy One, blessed be He, saw that because of the suffering of Israel, he spoke thus, He returned and acted with him in the attribute of mercy, as it is said, "And He said to him, 'I am the Lord,'" to make known the hidden matters and the inner intention in his words, that there was a wonderful cleverness in this and it greatly benefited the salvation of Israel to lighten the yoke of servitude from them, and the Holy One, blessed be He, agrees with the reasoning of the righteous, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that God aligns with the reasoning of the righteous, as illustrated by the story of Rabbi Chanina ben Dosa and the tragic fate of his son. It emphasizes that even when the words of the righteous may seem foolish or misguided, God understands the deeper intentions behind them, particularly when they stem from a place of suffering for the Jewish people. This reflects a broader theological insight that God's mercy can override strict judgment, especially in response to the pain of the righteous and their communities. Ultimately, it highlights the dynamic relationship between divine justice and mercy, as well as the significance of the righteous in influencing God's actions.

passage_content: ולפיהנ"ל אנהיר לן עיינין להבין קצת דברי רש"י ז"ל עה"פ ויאמר אליו אני ד' נאמן לשלם שכר טוב וכו' ולא לחנם שלחתיך כ"א לקיים דברי אשר דברתי לאבות הראשונים וכו' (עיין הדקדוקים לעיל קושיא ב') אמנם כל טענתו שלמשרע"השלא רצה להיות השליח, לפי שידעדבאופןזה א"א שיה' הגאולה נצחי,ועתידיןישראל להיותחוזריןומשתעבדים בשאר גליות, כמבואר בדברי חז"לדכלהישועות שהיו ע"י שלוחי בשר ודם לא היו נצחיים, וא"כ מה בצע בגאולתם אם יצטרכו לסבול עוד עול הגליות, וע"כ ביקש והתפלל והפצירשהבוי"תבעצמו יגאלם ויהי' גאולת עולם שאין אחרי' שעבוד עוד. וע"ז השיב לוית' אני ד' נאמן לשלם שכר וכו' ולא לחנם שלחתיךוכו',דבאמתלא הגיע הזמן עדיין לגאולה נצחי, כי לא נשלם בירורהניצה"קכמבואר בכתביהאריז"ל, אבל אעפ"כ יש צורך והכרח לגאולה זו שהוא רק לפי שעה, ולא לחנם שלחתיך שאין שליחותך בחנם, אלא שיש בזה הכנה ושורש לגאולה העתידה, וע"ד שכתב ק"זהיש"מזלל"ה(בפ'תצו') לפרש הפסוקתבאמוותטעמו בהר נחלתך מכון לשבתך וגו',דהמקדשותשנחרבובעוה"רלא הי'בנינםפועל ריק ח"ו, אלא שהיו הכנה ע"י קדושת עבודה מעשההקרבנותויתר עבודת הקודש אשר עשו שם, להכיןכחרוחני וקדושה נפלאה אל הבית השלישי שיהי' קיום נצחי ובית עולמים עיי"ש באריכות.
translation: According to the above, it is clear to us to understand somewhat the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, on the verse "And He said to him, I am the Lord, faithful to pay good reward, etc., and I did not send you for naught, but to fulfill the words that I spoke to the forefathers, etc." (see the grammatical points above, question 2). However, all of his argument was that Moshe Rabbeinu did not want to be the messenger, because in this way it is impossible for the redemption to be eternal, and the future of Israel would be to return and be enslaved in other exiles, as explained in the words of our Sages that all salvations that were through messengers of flesh and blood were not eternal. Therefore, what benefit is there in their redemption if they will have to endure the yoke of exiles again? And thus he requested and prayed and urged that the Holy One, Blessed be He, Himself should redeem them, and that it should be an eternal redemption with no further enslavement. To this, He replied, "I am the Lord, faithful to pay good reward, etc., and I did not send you for naught," meaning that in truth, the time for an eternal redemption had not yet arrived, for the selection of the holy sparks had not been completed, as explained in the writings of the Arizal. Nevertheless, there is a need and necessity for this redemption, which is only temporary, and it is not for naught that I sent you, for your mission is not in vain, but there is a preparation and root for the future redemption. This is in accordance with what the Kabbalists wrote (in Parshat Tetzaveh) to explain the verse "And in death, its taste is in the mountain of Your inheritance, the place for Your dwelling, etc.," that the sanctuaries that were destroyed in the destruction of the Temple were not a futile construction, Heaven forbid, but they were a preparation through the sanctity of the service of the offerings and other holy work that was done there, to prepare a wonderful spiritual and holy atmosphere for the third Temple, which will have eternal existence and be a house of worlds, as explained there at length.
summary: The passage discusses the reluctance of Moses to be the messenger for the redemption of the Israelites, as he feared it would not lead to a permanent salvation, but rather a temporary one, with future exiles. God reassures Moses that his mission is not in vain, as it serves as a necessary preparation for the ultimate, eternal redemption, even if the time for complete salvation has not yet arrived. The text emphasizes that past redemptions, while not everlasting, were essential for establishing a foundation for the future, highlighting the interconnectedness of historical and future salvations in the divine plan.

passage_content: וכמוכןלעניננוכלהנסיונותשעמדו בהם ישראל, והאמינו בנבואתו של משה רבינו ע"ה, והלכו אחריו במדבר בארץ לא זרועה, כל זההיתההכנה לגאולה העתידה, ובזכותה יבואו ויחזרו לעתיד,כאמרםז"ל בסנהדרין (דף ק' ע"ב)דאחריםבאין בזכותם עיי"ש, ולעתיד כשהקב"ה בעצמו יבוא ויגאלנו, יהי' התגלות האור כ"כ גדול ונורא, עד שלא יהי' במציאותנסיוןכלל, וכמ"ש ז"ל במס' שבת (קנ"א ע"ב) הגיעו שנים אשר תאמר אין לי בהם חפץ (קהלת י"ב) אלו ימי המשיח, שאין בהם לא זכות ולא חובה, ולא יהיונסיונותולא קיבול שכר, אבל בגאולת מצרים הגם שעשה השי"ת מופתים גדולים ונוראים, אבל לא הי'בבחי' התגלות כמו שיהי' לעתיד, ובמה שהוקשה ד' את לב פרעה והכביד עולו על ישראל,והעיזפניו נגד משה ואהרן שלוחי ד', כל זה הי' בגדרנסיונותלישראל, ואעפ"כ האמינו ויצאו למדבר ארץ לא זרועה, וע"כ שכרם אתם להיות נגאלים לעתיד בזכות זה, כדבריהגמ' אחרים באיםבזכותם הן עצמן לא כ"ש,וז"שלוית' אני ד' נאמן לשלם שכר טוב למתהלכים לפני ולא לחנם שלחתיך כ"א לקיים דברי שדברתי לאבות הראשונים, ובזה השיב לוהבוי"תעל חששתו הנ"ל, דלא שייך אצל ישראלאיפלוגדראלפי שקרבתם אל האבות הקדושים משורש נשמותיהם, ועדיין זכות האבות קיימת, ומוכרח אני לגאלם לפי שעה, אע"פ שלא יהי' עדיין גאולה נצחיות, אבל הצורך בשליחותך לקיים דברי שהבטחתי לאבות הראשונים.
translation: And likewise, regarding all the trials that Israel faced, and their belief in the prophecy of our teacher Moses, peace be upon him, and their following him in the wilderness, in a land that was not sown, all of this was a preparation for the future redemption. And through it, they will come and return in the future, as our sages, may their memory be blessed, said in Sanhedrin (page 100b) that others come in their merit, as stated there. And in the future, when the Holy One, blessed be He, Himself will come and redeem us, the revelation of the light will be so great and awesome that there will not be any trials at all, as it is written by our sages in the tractate Shabbat (101b): "There will come years when you will say, 'I have no desire in them' (Ecclesiastes 12), these are the days of the Messiah, in which there will be neither merit nor obligation, and there will be no trials nor reward." However, in the redemption from Egypt, even though the Holy One, blessed be He, performed great and awesome miracles, it was not in the aspect of revelation as it will be in the future. And regarding the hardening of Pharaoh's heart and the burden he placed upon Israel, and his defiance against Moses and Aaron, the messengers of the Holy One, all of this was within the framework of trials for Israel. Nevertheless, they believed and went out to the wilderness, a land that was not sown. Therefore, their reward is to be redeemed in the future because of this, as the Gemara states that others come in their own merit, how much more so. And this is what He said: "I, the Lord, am faithful to pay good reward to those who walk before Me, and I did not send you for naught, but to fulfill the words I spoke to the forefathers." And with this, He answered the aforementioned concern of the one who was worried, that it is not applicable to Israel to be divided according to their distance from the holy forefathers, from the root of their souls, and the merit of the forefathers still exists. I must redeem them for the time being, even though there will not yet be an eternal redemption, but the necessity of your mission is to fulfill the words I promised to the forefathers.
summary: The passage emphasizes that the trials faced by the Israelites in the desert, along with their faith in Moses' prophecy, were essential preparations for the future redemption. It highlights that in the Messianic era, there will be no trials or obligations, contrasting it with the earlier redemption from Egypt, which involved significant challenges. The text reassures that God's promise to redeem the Israelites is rooted in the merit of the patriarchs, ensuring their eventual salvation despite the current lack of a permanent redemption. Ultimately, it underscores God's faithfulness in fulfilling His promises to the ancestors.

passage_content: וע"כהסמיך הכתוב לומרואראאל אברהם אל יצחק ואל יעקב וגו' וגםהקימותיאת בריתי לתת להם את ארץ כנען וגו' לכן אמורלבנ"יאני ד' והוצאתי אתכם וגו' לקיים אותה הבטחה והשבועה שנשבעתי לאבות הראשונים. ואפשרדזהוכוונת רש"י ז"ל שפי'ואראאל האבות והבטחתים הבטחותוכו', ולכאורה מה הוסיף רש"י ז"ל בביאורו, אבל לדרכנו תוכן וכוונת אמרוית' למשה הי' להסירמלבוהחששא,דכבראיפלוגדראופסקה זכות אבות,דאל"ההי' ראוי שיהי' השליחות ע"י מלאכים אוהבוי"תבעצמו יגאלם, כדברי המדרש הנ"ל ששאל איזה מהם חביב בן אחיו או בן בנו, וע"כ להסיר תלונה זומלבוהזכיר לוהבוי"תזכות והבטחת האבות שעדיין קיימת, והצורך בשליחותך לקיים הבטחתי שהבטחתי לאבות הראשונים.
translation: And therefore the scripture is close to saying, "And I appeared to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob, etc." and also "And I established My covenant to give them the land of Canaan, etc." Therefore, say to the children of Israel, "I am the Lord, and I have brought you out, etc." to fulfill that promise and the oath that I swore to the forefathers. And it is possible that this is the intention of Rashi, of blessed memory, who explained "And I appeared to the forefathers and I promised them promises, etc." At first glance, what did Rashi, of blessed memory, add in his explanation? But according to our path, the content and intention of his words to Moses was to remove the concern from his heart, that perhaps the merit of the forefathers had ceased, for otherwise it would have been fitting for the redemption to be through angels, or He Himself would redeem them, as stated in the aforementioned Midrash, which asked which of them is more beloved, a son of a brother or a son of a son. And therefore, to remove the complaint, he mentioned the merit and the promise of the forefathers that still exists, and the need for your mission is to fulfill the promise that I promised to the forefathers.
summary: The passage emphasizes the continuity of God's covenant with the patriarchs Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, highlighting the importance of their merit in the redemption of their descendants. It suggests that God's promise to deliver the Israelites from Egypt is rooted in the oaths made to the ancestors, thus reinforcing the significance of their righteousness. The reference to Moses' mission underscores the necessity of acknowledging the patriarchs' enduring merit, which serves to alleviate any doubts regarding the divine plan for redemption. Ultimately, it illustrates the deep connection between the past and present in the unfolding of God's promises to His people.

passage_content: ואפ"לעוד בחי' בפסוקים הנ"ל,דהנהמתנאי הגאולה שיקדים אלי' התשובה כמאמרם ז"ל (מדרששוח"טק"ו ט') אין ישראל נגאלים אלא בתשובה, ומשה ואהרן עוררו אותם אל התשובה, כמבואר בדברי המכילתא מה ת"ל ולא שמעו אל משה אלא שצום לפרוש מע"ז, וכל ישראל הרהרו תשובהבלבםכמבוארבמד"רשמות (סו"פא') עה"פ ויראאלקיםאת בני ישראל וידעאלקים, רבנן אמרי ויראאלקיםשעשו תשובה הבינונים, וגם הרשעים הרהרו לעשות תשובהוכו', וידעאלקיםשאפי' א'בחבירולא הי' יודע אלא הקב"ה לבדו, וזה מכוון את לבו וזה מכוון את לבוועושיןתשובה, ואע"פ שעשו תשובה לא יצאו משם לעולם אלמלא זכות האבות וכו' עכ"ד המדרש, אולם לא הי' בחי' תשובתם שלימהובאתגליא, וכנראה שלא בא לכלל מעשה אלא בהרהורי לבבם בלבד עשו תשובה, דהרי מבוארבדרז"לדעדייןהיו משוקעים במ"ט שערי טומאה, אבלהבוי"תבחסדו הגדול ובזכות האבות הקדושים קיבל בחי' תשובתם אף שלא הי' בגדר השלימות, אבל חשבםית' לפי ערךהנסיונותובערך גודל התגברות כוחות טומאת מצרים עליהם, וכמו שפירשנו לעיל (פ' שמות)במאמה"כואת צעקתם שמעתי מפנינוגשיו, שלצד גודל התגברות כוחות הטומאה של מצרים עליהם, עשו כל החטאיםבבחי' כפי' ואונס עיי"ש. והכלל הואשהבוכ"עדן את ישראל בערך מצב הדור, וכמ"ש דודהמע"הראה עניי ועמלי ושא לכל חטאתי,כשהבוי"תרואה עניי ועמלי וגודלהנסיונותראוי שיסלח לכל חטאתי וכמו"כ ישראל במצרים אף שלא הי' בידם אלא הרהורי תשובה בלבד, אעפ"כ קיבלםהבוי"תבצירוף זכות האבות, וסייע בידם להוציאם ולהפרישם מטומאת מצרים לגמרי, אבל עכ"פ הי' מוכרח שתקדים לגאולתם איזה בחי' של תשובה כמאמרם ז"ל, וכל בחי' של תשובה ואפי' הרהורי תשובה לבד מביא תיקון קצת להתקרב אלהבוי"ת,ויכוליןלהגיעעי"זלתיקון האמיתי והשלימות בחסדהבוי"ת.
translation: And even further, regarding the verses mentioned above, behold, the condition for redemption is that repentance precedes it, as our sages of blessed memory said (Midrash Shochar Tov 26:9), "Israel is not redeemed except through repentance." And Moses and Aaron aroused them to repentance, as explained in the words of the Mekilta: "What does it mean that they did not listen to Moses? It means they fasted to distance themselves from idolatry." And all of Israel contemplated repentance in their hearts, as explained in Midrash Shemot (1:5) on the verse "And God saw the children of Israel, and God knew," the Rabbis say that God saw that they repented, the average ones, and even the wicked contemplated doing repentance, etc. And God knew that even one among them did not know, except for the Holy One, blessed be He alone. This one directs his heart, and that one directs his heart, and they do repentance. And although they repented, they would not have left there forever were it not for the merit of the patriarchs, etc., thus concludes the Midrash. However, their repentance was not complete and revealed, and it seems that they did not reach the level of action but only had thoughts of the heart, for it is clear from the words of our sages that they were still immersed in the forty-nine gates of impurity. But the Holy One, blessed be He, in His great mercy and in the merit of the holy patriarchs accepted their form of repentance even though it was not in the realm of completeness, but He considered them according to the value of their trials and according to the great strength of the forces of the impurity of Egypt against them, as we explained above (in Parashat Shemot) in the verse "And I have heard their cry because of their taskmasters," that due to the great strength of the forces of impurity of Egypt against them, they committed all the sins in a state of coercion, as mentioned there. And the principle is that the Holy One, blessed be He, judges Israel according to the state of the generation, as it is written, "When the Holy One, blessed be He, sees the poor and the laborers and the great trials, He is worthy to forgive all their sins." Likewise, Israel in Egypt, even though they had only thoughts of repentance, nevertheless, the Holy One, blessed be He, accepted them in conjunction with the merit of the patriarchs and assisted them to take them out and completely separate them from the impurity of Egypt. However, it was necessary that some form of repentance precede their redemption, as our sages of blessed memory said, and any form of repentance, even just thoughts of repentance alone, brings some rectification to draw closer to the Holy One, blessed be He, and they can reach true rectification and completeness through the grace of the Holy One, blessed be He.
summary: The passage discusses the essential role of repentance (teshuva) in the redemption of the Jewish people, emphasizing that they can only be redeemed through sincere return to God. It highlights that even the Israelites' incomplete repentance, characterized by mere thoughts of return while still immersed in impurity, was accepted by God due to the merit of the patriarchs. The text underscores that God's compassion considers the struggles and challenges faced by the people, allowing for a process of gradual spiritual elevation, ultimately leading to complete redemption through divine grace.

passage_content: ועד"זיובנו התכת וקישור הפסוקים ולא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח וגו' שהי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז כדרשת המכילתא, ולא עלה בידם של משה ואהרן להביאם אל התשובה גמורה ושלימה, ומעתה דאג משה רבינודאיךיהי' אפשר לגאלם, והרי מתנאי הגאולה שתקדים אלי' התשובה כמאמרם ז"ל,וז"שהןבנ"ילא שמעו אלי ואיך ישמעני פרעה ואני ערל שפתים, כי לא יהיו דברי נשמעים אליו ולא יאבה לשלוח ולהוציא את ישראל, כיון שלא שמעו אלי בני ישראל לעשות תשובה גמורה ושלימה, ותשובתוית' מבוארת בפסוקשלאח"זוידבר ד' אל משה ואהרן ויצום אלבנ"יואל פרעה מלך מצרים להוציא אתבנ"ימאמ"צויתורץ מה שהקשההאוהחה"קדאינו מבואר מהציוםאל בני ישראל, ומאמר להוציא אתבנ"ימאמ"צ, ציווי זו שייך אל פרעה ולא לישראל, ולדרכנוהיתהבזה תשובה מספקת להשקיט רוחו של משה רבינו, שהי' דואג ומתמרמר שלא עלהבידו להביאם לידי תשובה גמורה ועדיין הי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז ולסיבה זו הי' דואג שלא ישמע גם פרעה כנ"ל, וע"ז הי' דבר ד' אליו ויצום אל בני ישראל להחזירם בתשובה, ואל פרעה מלך מצרים שישלחם ויפעלו הדיבורים להוציא אתבנ"ימארץ מצרים, כיהבוי"תיסייע בידם לעשות תשובה, וגם יקבל בחי' תשובתם בערךהנסיונותושפלות מצבם כנ"ל, והבטיחוית' כי יעלה בידו להוציא את ישראל ממצרים.
translation: And similarly, we will explain the connection and linkage of the verses, and they did not listen to Moses due to shortness of spirit, etc., for it was difficult for them to separate from idolatry, as the Mechilta interprets. And Moses and Aaron were unable to bring them to complete and true repentance. From now on, Moses our teacher was worried about how it would be possible to redeem them, for it is a condition of redemption that repentance precedes it, as our sages of blessed memory said. And thus, "They did not listen to me, and how will Pharaoh listen to me, for I am of uncircumcised lips?" For his words would not be heard by him, and he would not be willing to send and release Israel, since the children of Israel did not listen to me to achieve complete and true repentance. And his response is clarified in the verse that follows: "And the Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron and commanded them to speak to the children of Israel and to Pharaoh, king of Egypt, to bring the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt." This clarifies what was difficult for the Holy One, blessed be He, for it is not clear from the command to the children of Israel, and the statement to bring the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt. This command pertains to Pharaoh and not to Israel. And in this, there was a sufficient response to calm the spirit of Moses our teacher, who was worried and distressed that he had not succeeded in bringing them to true repentance, and it was still difficult for them to separate from idolatry. For this reason, he was concerned that Pharaoh would not listen as mentioned above. And to this, the Lord spoke to him and commanded him to return them to repentance, and to Pharaoh, king of Egypt, to send them, and the words would work to bring the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt, for He would assist them in achieving repentance, and He would also accept their repentance in relation to their trials and the lowliness of their situation, as mentioned above, and He assured him that he would succeed in bringing Israel out of Egypt.
summary: The passage discusses the challenges faced by Moses and Aaron in leading the Israelites to complete repentance, as their attachment to idolatry made it difficult for them to heed Moses' call. This concern led Moses to worry about the feasibility of their redemption, given that true repentance is a prerequisite for salvation. God reassures Moses by commanding him to instruct both the Israelites and Pharaoh, indicating that the Israelites' struggles and their eventual repentance would be acknowledged and supported by divine intervention, ultimately ensuring their liberation from Egypt. The text highlights the interplay between human effort in seeking repentance and the necessity of divine assistance in achieving redemption.

passage_content: והנהמבוארבספה"קדימי השובבים המה מסוגלים מאוד לתקן חטא הידוע ר"ל, האמנם מבוארבזוה"קפ' ויחי דלא מהני תשובה כלל על חטא זה,ובמקו"אאיתאדהנימילי כד לא עבדתיובתאשלימתא,תיובתאדאיהואתחזיאלחפייאעל כלעובדוי, מבוארדעכ"פצריך תשובה גדולה על זה,ובעוה"ררחוקים אנו מאודמבחי' זו, וא"כ איפו' יש לנותקו' ונחמה, ואיך נוכל להתקרב לפניוית' ולשוב על חטא הנורא הזו. וכבר דברנו מזה פעמים אין מספר ועלה בידינו למצוא בדברי רז"ל המלצת זכות באופנים שונים, שבערך דור חלש כדורנו קשה להשיג אפי' בחי' קטנה של תשובה, וע"כ ראוישהבוי"תיקבלתשובתינואף שאינוע"צהשלימות, וכעת נ"ל לומר עודעפי"משהבאתי בספרי ויואל משה (מאמר א' סי' מ') מדברי הרמב"ם ז"ל בפי' המשנה בפרק חלק, בפלוגתת החכמים אם עשרת השבטים עתידים לחזור לעוה"ב, וכתב שם וז"ל כבר זכרתי לך פעמים רבות, שכל מחלוקת שיהי' בין החכמים שאינו בא לידי מעשה, אלא שהוא אמונת דבר בלבד, אין צד לפסוק הלכה כא' מהם, וכן כתב עוד בפי' המשנה במס' סוטה פרק הי' נוטל,לעניןפלוגתאדמתנונתוהולכתיעיי"ש,וק"זהיש"מזלל"הבפ'תשאכתבדמבוארכן בכל הספריםדכלכללי הלכות אינם אלא בדיניםהנהוגיןבינינו והלכות הניתנים לנו אבל לא בדיני שמים בדבר שביד הקב"ה לעשותו, אין לנו ע"ז שום כללי הלכה להכריע בפלוגתת חז"לבעניניםכאלו עכ"ד ז"ל.
translation: And behold, it is explained in the holy book "Kadimi" that the weeks of the "Shovavim" are very capable of rectifying the known sin, may G-d have mercy. Indeed, it is explained in the Zohar, Parashat Vayechi, that repentance does not help at all for this sin, and in other places it is stated that if one did not act and completed the matter, the repentance is a proof that he is seen as if he worked. It is explained that, nevertheless, a great repentance is required for this, and in our generation, we are very far from this level. And if so, where is there to be found a remedy and comfort, and how can we draw close before Him, blessed be He, and return from this terrible sin? We have already spoken about this countless times and have managed to find in the words of our Sages various merits, that in a weak generation like ours it is difficult to achieve even a small level of repentance. Therefore, they saw fit to accept our repentance even if it is not complete. And now it seems to me to say further, according to what I brought in my book "Yoel Moshe" (Article 1, Section 40) from the words of the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, in his commentary on the Mishnah in Chapter Chelek, regarding the dispute among the sages whether the Ten Tribes are destined to return to the World to Come. He wrote there, and I quote: "I have already mentioned to you many times that any dispute that exists among the sages which does not come to action, but is merely a matter of belief, there is no basis to rule halacha like one of them." He also wrote further in his commentary on the Mishnah in Masechet Sotah, Chapter 7, regarding the dispute of the Tannaim and the way it is conducted, see there. And this is what the holy Rabbi said in Parashat Tazria, that it is explained in all the books that all general halachot are only in the laws that are practiced among us and the halachot given to us, but not in heavenly laws regarding matters that are in the hands of the Holy One, blessed be He, to do, we have no general halachic principles to decide in the disputes of our Sages regarding such matters. Thus is the word of the blessed one.
summary: The passage discusses the difficulty of achieving true repentance for severe sins, particularly in the context of the current generation's spiritual challenges. It references the Zohar, which suggests that certain sins cannot be rectified through repentance alone, highlighting the need for a profound level of atonement. Despite this, the author finds solace in the teachings of the sages, who indicate that even minimal repentance can be accepted, especially in a weakened generation. The text emphasizes the complexity of divine judgment and the limitations of human understanding in matters of heavenly decrees.

passage_content: והסברהעניןדאלוההלכותהנהוגיןלבנ"אלעשותם, א"א שיפול בהם השתנות, וכבר נמסרה בידינו כללי ההלכה מפי התלמוד והפוסקים, ועליו אין להוסיף וממנו אין לגרוע,דהתוה"קניצחי ולאיפולבה שינוי וגרעון ותוספת, אמנם בהלכות הנהוגים בהקב"ה לעשותם, א"א לנו להכריע בהם עפ"י כללי ההלכה,דהבוי"תמתנהג עם עולמו כפיהמדות, וא"א לנו לידע איזה מידה אשר ישלוט אז, וכפי המידה ההיא יכריע השי"ת להתנהג עם בריותיו.ומבוארכעניןהזהבספה"קדגל מ"א (פרשה זו) עה"פ וגם אני שמעתי את נאקתבנ"יוגו'ותו"דדהתורהניתנה תמידלידרשלפי ענין ראשי הדור ובחינתם ומדריגתם, כמו שראיתי באיזה ספר וכו' ששם המפורש היא נמסר לדרוש בו בכל דור לפי אותו הדורוכו', וידועדכלהתורה כולה שמותיו של הקב"ה, נמצאבודאיג"כ נדרשת בכל דור ודור לפי דורשיו ולפי נשמת אותו הדור, והביא שפסוק הנ"ל הי' נדרש בימיבעש"טזלל"הוגם אני שמעתי את נאקת בני ישראל, שצועקים עבור השכינה כביכול לקרב השכינה הקדושהוכו', כך הי' נדרש בימיהבעש"טזלל"הואנשי דורו, שהיובמדריגהגדולה כזו שלא להתפלל כלל על חסרון עצמי רק על חסרון השכינה כביכול. ועתה לפי דורותינו נדרש הפסוק וגם אני שמעתי את נאקת בני ישראל, אפי' אם הם צועקים עבור עצמם אשר מצרים מעבידים אותם, אעפ"כ לגודל רחמיו וחסדיוית' מקבל אפי' תפלה וצעקה שהוא עבור עצמם עכת"ד ז"ל. וברורדמ"שז"לדהתוה"קנדרשת בכל דור ודור לפי דורשיו ולפי נשמת אותו הדור, אין הכוונה על הלכות ודינים הנהוגים לישראל לעשותם, כי א"א שיפול בהם שינוי או מגרעת,והתוה"קלא ישתנה לעולם, אלא הכוונה עלהעניניםשהבורא ב"ה מתנהג בהם כפי התורה, ובהם נדרשתהתוה"קבכל דור ודור כפי מצב הדור ובחינתו, וכמו שמפרש אח"כדבדורושלהבעשטה"קהי' פשט הפסוק באופן אחר, ואח"כ שנחלשו מצב הדורותהבוי"תשומע לקולשועתםגם אםמתפלליןעבור עצמם,והתוה"קנדרשת באופן אחר.
translation: And the explanation of the matter is that the laws practiced by the sons of Israel to perform them cannot undergo change. We have already received the principles of halacha from the Talmud and the poskim, and upon them, one should not add or subtract, for the Torah is eternal and cannot be subject to change, reduction, or addition. However, regarding the laws that are practiced in relation to the Holy One, Blessed be He, we cannot decide them according to the principles of halacha, for the Holy One, Blessed be He, conducts His world according to the attributes, and we cannot know which attribute will prevail at that time, and according to that attribute, the Holy One, Blessed be He, will decide how to conduct Himself with His creations. This matter is clarified in the holy book "Kedushat Levi" (in this section) on the verse "And I also heard the groaning of the children of Israel," and it is explained that the Torah is always given to the leaders according to the essence of the generation and their qualities and levels, as I have seen in some book, etc., where it is explicitly stated that it is given to be interpreted in every generation according to that generation, and it is known that the entire Torah is the names of the Holy One, Blessed be He. Therefore, it is certainly required in every generation according to its interpreters and according to the soul of that generation. It is brought that the above verse was interpreted in the days of the Baal Shem Tov, may his memory be blessed, as "And I also heard the groaning of the children of Israel," who cry out for the Shechinah, as it were, to bring closer the holy Shechinah, etc. Thus, it was interpreted in the days of the Baal Shem Tov, may his memory be blessed, and the people of his generation, who were at such a high level that they did not pray at all for their own deficiencies, only for the deficiency of the Shechinah, as it were. And now, according to our generations, the verse "And I also heard the groaning of the children of Israel" is interpreted even if they are crying out for themselves because the Egyptians are enslaving them; nevertheless, due to His great mercy and kindness, He accepts even a prayer and cry that is for themselves, thus said he, may his memory be blessed. And it is clear from the words of the holy Rabbi, may his memory be blessed, that the Torah is interpreted in every generation according to its interpreters and according to the soul of that generation; this does not refer to the laws and statutes that are practiced by Israel to perform them, for they cannot undergo change or reduction, and the Torah will never change. Rather, it refers to the matters by which the Creator, Blessed be He, conducts Himself according to the Torah, and in them, the Torah is interpreted in every generation according to the state of the generation and its qualities, as he later explains that in the generation of the Baal Shem Tov, the verse was interpreted in a different way, and afterwards, as the state of the generations weakened, the Holy One, Blessed be He, listens to the voice of their cries even if they pray for themselves, and the Torah is interpreted in a different way.
summary: The passage emphasizes that while the laws of the Torah are eternal and unchangeable, the way God interacts with the world can vary according to the spiritual state of each generation. It highlights that the Torah is interpreted in each era based on the needs and spiritual level of the people, allowing for a dynamic relationship between divine providence and human experience. The Baal Shem Tov's teachings illustrate that even prayers for personal needs are accepted by God, reflecting His compassion, especially in times of spiritual decline. Ultimately, the text underscores the importance of understanding the Torah's teachings in the context of the current generation's spiritual condition.

passage_content: וכעי"זכתב רבינו יונהזלה"הלפרש עת לעשות לד' הפרותורתיך, שבדור שפל כשהפרותורתיך, אז הוא עת לעשות לד',דחשובמאוד כל מהשעושיןלכבוד השי"ת, עכ"פ מבואר מכל הליןדהבוי"תדן ומתנהג עם ישראל כפי הערך מצב הדור, והגם שהחמירובזוה"קדלא מהני תשובה על חטא הידוע רקבתיובתאשלימתאוכו', אבל בערךנסיונותהעצומים של דורנו בכל תנועה ופסיעה, וגודל ההסתרה השורה בימינו, קשה להשיג אפי' נקודה קלה של תשובה, וע"כ אפי' הרהור תשובה בלבד ג"כ חשובה לפני הקב"ה, וא"א לומר הלכה ברורה דלא מהני תשובה על חטא הידוע, אלא צריך לבקש רחמים ותחנונים שנזכה לעשות תשובה אמיתיות ולהתקרב להקב"ה, ואם נעשה כל מהשביכולתינו,בודאיהבוי"תיקבלתשובתינוכפי ערך שפלות מצב הדור, וע"כ הימים האלו מסוגלים יותר שיתקבל בחי'תשובתינו,דהקריאהמעורר הזמן, ובמצרים הי' ג"כ על בחי' זו שנתקבל לפניהבוי"תמה שהרהרו תשובהבלבם, אף שלא זכו לתשובה שלימה,שדנםית' לפי המצבורבויכובדהנסיונותכנ"ל.והשי"תיזכנו לשוב בתשובה שלימה, ולעשות נחת רוח לפניוית', ונזכה לגאולה שלימה בקרוב בהתרוממות קרן התורה וישראל, ובהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו במהרה בימינו אמן.
translation: And similarly, our teacher Yonah, may his memory be blessed, wrote to explain the time to act for the Lord is when the Torah is in a low state. In a lowly generation, when the Torah is in a low state, then it is a time to act for the Lord, for it is very important that all we do is for the honor of the Holy One, Blessed be He. It is clear from all of this that the Holy One, Blessed be He, judges and conducts Himself with Israel according to the value of the state of the generation. And although it is strict in the Zohar that repentance does not help for a known sin, only for a hidden one, in relation to the immense trials of our generation in every movement and step, and the great concealment that prevails in our days, it is difficult to attain even a slight point of repentance. Therefore, even a mere thought of repentance is also important before the Holy One, Blessed be He. One cannot say a clear halacha that repentance does not help for a known sin; rather, one must seek mercy and supplications that we merit to make true repentance and draw close to the Holy One, Blessed be He. If we do all that is within our ability, surely the Holy One, Blessed be He, will accept our repentance according to the value of the lowly state of the generation. Therefore, these days are more capable of having our repentance accepted, for the call awakens the time. And in Egypt, it was also in this manner that they were accepted for the thoughts of repentance in their hearts, even though they did not merit complete repentance, as they were judged according to the collective and the great trials mentioned above. May the Holy One, Blessed be He, grant us to return with complete repentance, and to bring Him satisfaction, and may we merit complete redemption soon with the elevation of the banner of the Torah and Israel, and with the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us speedily in our days, Amen.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of sincere repentance, especially in a time of spiritual decline, where even a mere thought of repentance is valued by God. It acknowledges the challenges of achieving true repentance due to the overwhelming trials and concealment of divine presence in the current generation. The text encourages seeking mercy and striving to connect with God, suggesting that genuine efforts, even in difficult circumstances, can lead to acceptance of repentance. Ultimately, it expresses hope for complete redemption and the elevation of Torah and Israel in the near future.

translation: In the gathering, to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob, etc., Rashi explains that He appeared to the Patriarchs. The commentators have scrutinized what Rashi, may his memory be blessed, added in his commentary beyond what is clear in the verse, and it is known that Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob are the Patriarchs, blessed be He. We have already elaborated on this and more in the words of God.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the patriarchs Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob in the context of their relationship with God, emphasizing their roles as foundational figures in Jewish theology. It highlights the unique attributes and spiritual contributions of each patriarch, suggesting that their lives and actions serve as a model for understanding divine interaction with humanity. The reference to Rashi's commentary indicates a deeper exploration of the text, inviting readers to reflect on the nuances of the patriarchs' legacy and their ongoing relevance in the Jewish faith. Overall, it underscores the importance of the patriarchs in establishing a covenantal relationship with God.

passage_content: ב)ה' לא נודעתי להםפירש"ילא נכרתי להםבמדתאמיתית שלי וכו' שהרי הבטחתים ולא קיימתי, ומהו ההבטחה וגםהקמותיאת בריתי אתם לתת להם את ארץ כנען וגו', והקשו המפורשים הרי עדיין לא הי' זמנה להבטחה זו שתתקיים, ומעיקראהיתהההבטחה ודור רביעי ישובו הנה ואין מקום לתרעומת כלל, גם איך יתקשר כל זה אל סיום המאמר וגם אני שמעתי את נאקתבנ"יוגו', ואלמ"שמשרע"הלמההרעותהלעם הזה, ואיך יתנחם בזה מה שלא נתקיים עדיין הבטחת ירושת הארץ לאבות.
translation: B) "I did not make Myself known to them" - I did not reveal Myself to them in My true measure, etc., for I had promised them and did not fulfill it. And what is the promise? "And I will establish My covenant with them to give them the land of Canaan," etc. The commentators have questioned that the time for this promise to be fulfilled had not yet arrived, and indeed the promise was that "the fourth generation shall return here," and there is no room for complaint at all. Also, how does all this connect to the conclusion of the statement, and I have also heard the groaning of the children of Israel, etc., and why does it say, "Why have You done evil to this people?" And how can they find comfort in that which has not yet been fulfilled, the promise of inheriting the land to the forefathers?
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author reflects on the divine promise to the Jewish people regarding the land of Canaan, emphasizing the tension between God's assurances and their fulfillment. He addresses the apparent delay in the realization of this promise, suggesting that the timing of its fulfillment was not yet appropriate. The text also grapples with the suffering of the Jewish people and their cries for redemption, questioning how they can find solace in unfulfilled promises. Ultimately, it highlights the enduring faith in God's covenant despite present hardships.

passage_content: ג)הקמותיאת בריתי אתם לתת להם את ארץ כנען וגו', ודרשו רז"ל בגמ' (סנהדרין צ' ע"ב) לכם לא נאמר אלא להם מכאן לתחיית המתים מן התורה עכ"דהגמ',וצ"בקישור דרשתם ז"ללהכאומה ענין הבטחת תחיית המתים אלמ"שמשרע"הלמההרעותה.
translation: 3) "I will establish My covenant with you to give them the land of Canaan, etc." And our Sages, of blessed memory, expounded in the Gemara (Sanhedrin 90b) that it does not say "to you" but "to them," from here is a source for the resurrection of the dead from the Torah, as the Gemara concludes. And the connection of their exposition, of blessed memory, to this is the matter of the promise of the resurrection of the dead, as it is stated in the verse.
summary: The passage discusses the promise of the land of Canaan as a covenant with the Jewish people, highlighting the phrase "to them" rather than "to you," which the sages interpret as a reference to the resurrection of the dead. This connection emphasizes the theological concept that the promise of the land is intrinsically linked to the future redemption and revival of the Jewish people. The text reflects a deep belief in the continuity of the Jewish soul and the ultimate fulfillment of divine promises, reinforcing the hope for resurrection as a fundamental aspect of faith.
