passage_content: ולבארהעניןנ"ל עפ"י המבוארבדרז"לדלזכותלירושת הארץ צריך להיות דור זכאי וראוי לכך וכתבהראב"דז"ל (פ"בדעדיותמ"ט) על דברי ר"ע (במתני' שם) ובמספר הדורות והוא הקץ שנא' קורא הדורות מראשוכו', ופי' הוא ז"ל כלומר אע"פ שנותן קץ לגלויות ישראל ולשעבוד שלהם בשנים, מ"מלעניןהטובות והנחמות האמורות להם, במספר השנים הוא תולה, לפי שהוא רואה את הדור שהוא זכאי, ומתגלגל עמהם עד שמגיע לאותו הדור, וכן הי' בשעבוד מצרים אע"פ שנגאלו בסוף ד' מאות שנה לא שבו לשבת בארץ עד דורו של יהושע וכו' וכן לימות המשיח לא יכנסו לא"י מיד, אבל יוליך אותם למדבר העמים כמפורש בנבואת יחזקאל כ' עכ"ל, ומפורש כןבמד"ר(במדברפי"אס"ב) עיי"ש.
translation: To explain the aforementioned matter according to what is clarified in the teachings of our Sages, that in order to merit the inheritance of the land, there must be a generation that is worthy and deserving of it. And the Rabbi, of blessed memory, wrote (in the tractate of Ediyot 49) regarding the words of Rabbi Akiva (in the Mishnah there) and concerning the number of generations, and this is the end that is said, "He calls the generations from the beginning," etc. And his explanation is, blessed be his memory, that although He sets a limit to the exiles of Israel and their subjugation in years, regarding the good and comforting matters that are said to them, He ties it to the number of years, for He sees the generation that is worthy and rolls along with them until He reaches that generation. And so it was with the Egyptian bondage; although they were redeemed at the end of four hundred years, they did not return to dwell in the land until the generation of Joshua, etc. And likewise, in the days of the Messiah, they will not enter the Land of Israel immediately, but He will lead them to the wilderness of the nations, as explicitly stated in the prophecy of Ezekiel 20. Thus is it explicitly stated in the Midrash (in Bamidbar, chapter 11, section 2), see there.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that the merit to inherit the Land of Israel requires a generation that is deemed worthy. It references the teachings of Rabbi Akiva and the idea that the redemption of Israel from exile is contingent upon the righteousness of the generation at that time. The text emphasizes that even though there is a predetermined timeline for the exiles, the actual realization of redemption is linked to the moral state of the people, as seen in historical contexts like the Exodus from Egypt and the future redemption in the Messianic era.

passage_content: והנהמבואר בדברי רז"ל שקושי השעבוד הי' לתועלתן וטובתן של ישראל,דעי"זנשלם זמנם מהר ויצאו לסוףרד"ושנה, ולולא כן הי' הגזירה להשלים ד' מאות שנה, ואלמלי היו מתמהמהים במצרים כ"כ שנים היו משתקעים ח"ובנ' שערי טומאה ולא היו יכולים לזכות לירושת הארץ כלל, שא"א כ"א לדור זכאי כשרים וצדיקים, ונקדים עודמ"שהרמב"ן ז"ל (בפ' בא) עה"פ ויהי מקץ שלשים שנה וארבע מאות שנה וגו' יצאו כל צבאות ה'מאמ"צ,ותו"דז"ל כי הגזירה הי' על ת' שנה מן היום ההוא שנגזר עליהם ברית בין הבתרים,והשלשיםשנה הם תוספת עליהם בעבורעוןהדור ההוא וכו' שאין שום הבטחה שלא יגרום החטא לבטלהוכו', ומן הידוע שהיו ישראל במצרים רעים וחטאים מאודוכו', וע"כ ארך גלותם ל' שנהוכו', ולא נתקיים להם ודור רביעי ישובו הנהוכו', אבל החטאים גרמוהכלע"כ מקצת לשונו עיי"ש,וז"שרש"י ז"ל שהרי הבטחתים ולא קיימתי, שנתאחר ונדחה זמנו של קיום ההבטחה לסיבת גרמת החטא כמ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל, ולטעם המבואר בדבריהראב"דז"ל שגלגל הקב"ה עמהם עד שמגיע לדור זכאי הראויים לירושת הארץ, וכל זה הי' תשובת נחמהלמשרע"השהי' מיצר ומצטער בצרתן של ישראל בקושי השעבוד והקשה לומר למההרעותהוגו', והשיב לו הקב"ה כי כ"ז הכרח לטובתן של ישראל, כדי שיזכו לירושת הארץ,ולז"אלו ושמי ה' לא נודעתי להם לא נכרתי להםבמדתאמיתית שלי וכו' שהרי הבטחתים ולא קיימתי, ונדחה ונתאחר קיום הבטחתי מסיבת גרמת חטאם, ולולא קושי השעבוד הי' ראוי להתאחר יותרונשתקעוח"ו שם לעולם,ולז"אוגם אני שמעתי את נאקתבנ"יאשר מצרים מעבידים אותם ואזכור את בריתי, היינו הבטחת ירושת הארץ שהבטחתי להם,דע"ישמצרים מכבידים עליהם השעבוד, יזכו לקיום ההבטחה ולא יתאחר עוד.
translation: And behold, it is explained in the words of our Sages that the difficulty of the servitude was for the benefit and good of Israel, for by this their time was completed quickly and they left at the end of four hundred years. Had it not been so, the decree would have been to complete four hundred years, and had they delayed in Egypt for so many years, they would have sunk into the fifty gates of impurity and would not have been able to merit the inheritance of the land at all, for it is impossible for any generation to be worthy, righteous, and just. And we further precede with what the Ramban, of blessed memory, states (in Parashat Bo) regarding the verse "And it came to pass at the end of four hundred and thirty years," that all the hosts of the Lord went out from the land of Egypt. And so our Sages say that the decree was for four hundred years from the day that the covenant was decreed upon them at the covenant between the parts, and the thirty years are an addition upon them due to the sin of that generation, etc., for there is no promise that sin will not cause the fulfillment to be delayed. And it is well known that Israel in Egypt were very wicked and sinful, etc., and therefore their exile was prolonged by thirty years, etc., and it was not fulfilled for them that "the fourth generation shall return here," etc., but the sins caused everything. Thus, according to some of its wording, see there. And this is what Rashi, of blessed memory, said: "Behold, I promised them and did not fulfill," that the time of the fulfillment of the promise was delayed and postponed due to the cause of their sin, as the Ramban, of blessed memory, states. And for the reason explained in the words of the Rabbi, of blessed memory, that the Holy One, blessed be He, rolled with them until the generation worthy of inheriting the land arrives. And all this was a response of comfort to Moshe Rabbeinu, who was distressed and troubled by the suffering of Israel in the difficulty of the servitude and found it hard to say why He was doing evil to them. And the Holy One, blessed be He, answered him that all this is necessary for the good of Israel, so that they may merit the inheritance of the land. And for this reason, "And I also heard the groaning of the children of Israel whom the Egyptians are enslaving, and I will remember My covenant," meaning the promise of the inheritance of the land that I promised them, for when the Egyptians are oppressing them with servitude, they will merit the fulfillment of the promise and it will not be delayed any longer.
summary: The passage discusses the hardships of the Israelites in Egypt as a necessary means for their ultimate benefit and redemption. It emphasizes that their suffering was essential to prepare them for inheriting the Promised Land, as only a righteous generation could achieve this. The delay in fulfilling God's promise was attributed to the sins of the people, but their cries for help prompted God to remember His covenant and ensure their eventual liberation. Thus, the struggles they faced were ultimately a divine strategy to elevate them to a deserving status for receiving the land.

passage_content: ונקדיםעוד דבריהב"ח(בשו"עאו"חסי' קי"ח) ע"ד ששאלוהו על מנהג האשכנזים שאומרים בברכת בונה ירושלים, ובנה אותה בקרוב בימינו בנין עולםוכסאדוד מהרה בתוכה תכין בא"י בונה ירושלים, דלאהוהכדקיי"לכשמואל (בפ' ערבי פסחים)דצריךמעין חתימה סמוך לחתימה, והשיבדשאלתוכסאדוד וכו' הוא שאלת בנין ירושלים ממש, כי בקשתנו על בנין ירושלים שתהי' בה השראת שכינה וראוי' לכונן בהכסאדוד עכת"ד, וע"דדאיתאבזוה"ק(ויקהלקצ"א ע"א)אר"אכתיב מן היום אשר הוצאתי את עמי את ישראל ממצרים, לא בחרתי בעיר מכל שבטי ישראל ואבחר בדוד וגו' לבנות בית להיות שמי שם, האי קרא לאו רישי' סיפי'וכו',דכתיבלא בחרתי בעיר ואבחר בדוד מאי האי עם האי ואבחר בירושלים מבעי' לי', אלא כדקוב"האיתרעותאקמי'למיבניקרתא אסתכלבקדמייתאבההוארישאדנהיגעמאדקרתא, ולבתר בני קרתאוכו',הה"דלא בחרתי בעיר עדדאסתכלנאבדודלמהוירעי' על ישראל וכו' עיי"ש, נמצא מבוארדמאמרוכסאדוד בתוכה תכין הוא בקשת בנין ירושלים ממש.
translation: And we will precede with the words of the Baḥ (in Shulchan Aruch Orach Chaim, Siman 118) regarding the question they asked him about the custom of the Ashkenazim who say in the blessing of "Builder of Jerusalem," "and build it soon in our days, the building of the world and the throne of David quickly within it," that it is not like we have established as Samuel (in the chapter of Arvei Pesachim) that there needs to be a similar conclusion close to the conclusion. And he answered that your question about the throne of David, etc., is indeed a question about the building of Jerusalem itself, for our request regarding the building of Jerusalem is that the Divine Presence should dwell there, and it is fitting to establish there the throne of David, thus far his words. And regarding what is written in the Zohar (Vayakhel 61a) in the name of Rabbi Elazar, it is written, "From the day that I brought out My people, the children of Israel, from Egypt, I did not choose a city from all the tribes of Israel, but I chose David, etc., to build a house for My name there." This verse does not mean that He did not choose a city and chose David; what does this mean with this? Shouldn't it have said, "I chose Jerusalem"? Rather, as the Holy One, blessed be He, looked to build a city, He looked at the first one, which was the city of David, and afterwards the children of the city, etc. This is what is meant by "I did not choose a city" until I looked at the greatness of what would be revealed upon Israel, etc. Therefore, it is clear that the statement "the throne of David quickly within it" is indeed a request for the building of Jerusalem itself.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Ashkenazi custom of including the phrase about the rebuilding of Jerusalem in the blessing, emphasizing that this request is intrinsically linked to the divine presence and the establishment of the Davidic throne within the city. It references the Zohar, highlighting that God's choice of Jerusalem and David is not arbitrary but reflects a deeper divine intention for a sacred space where His presence can dwell. The text underscores the connection between the physical rebuilding of Jerusalem and the spiritual aspiration for divine revelation and connection to the Jewish people. Ultimately, the request for the restoration of Jerusalem is seen as a plea for the fulfillment of God's promise and the establishment of His kingdom on earth.

passage_content: ובזהיתבאר קישור דרשתם ז"ל עה"פ וגםהקימותיאת בריתי אתם לתת להם את ארץ כנען, לכם לא נאמר אלא להם מכאן לתחיית המתיםמה"ת, ולדרכינוהיתהכוונת הרמז בזהלמשרע"הלהרגיע רוחו על שהתמרמר בצרתן של ישראל בקושי השעבוד, לזה הודיעו לוהבוית"שכי כ"ז הי' הכרח לתועלתן של ישראל שיזכו לירושת הארץ, שהרי הבטחתילאבוה"קלתת להם את ארץ כנען, לכם לא נאמר אלא להם מכאן לתחיית המתיםוכו',שהאבוה"קיקומובתחי'וינתןלהם בעצמם ירושת הארץ, ולזה צריך להכין דור כזה ובחי' א"י כזה ראויים לכך שיבואוהאבוה"קעמהם ביחד לקבל ירושת הארץ, היינו דור זכאי שיהי' להם התקשרות אלהאבוה"קוא"י מקודשת ומטוהרת ע"דהאבוה"קוע"דמ"שהב"חשבקשתנו על בנין ירושלים הראוי' לדוד, והיינו הראוי'לאבוה"קכי בחי' א' להם,ולז"אלו הקב"ה שהרי הבטחתי ולא קיימתי, שלסיבה זו נתאחר ההבטחה עד שתהי' א"י ראוי' בקדושתה ויספיק קדושת הדור לתת "להם"וז"פרש"י ז"לואראאל האבות, שהתגלות הזה בהבטחת ירושת הארץ הי' על תנאי שיהי' לישראל התקשרות עםהאבוה"קומתנהגים בדרכם עד שיקראו אבות להם וזה טעם הבטחתי ולא קיימתי,וה"זתשובה על דברימשרע"הלמההרעותהוהבן.
translation: And in this it is explained the connection of their teaching, may their memory be blessed, on the verse "And I will establish My covenant with you to give them the land of Canaan," it is not said to you but to them. From here, it is derived to the resurrection of the dead from the Torah. And our way is that the intention of the hint in this is to Moshe Rabbeinu, to calm his spirit regarding the suffering of Israel in the hardship of servitude. Therefore, it was made known to him, blessed be He, that all this was necessary for the benefit of Israel so that they would merit the inheritance of the land, for the promise to the Patriarchs, blessed be He, was to give them the land of Canaan; it is not said to you but to them. From here, it is derived to the resurrection of the dead, etc., that the Patriarchs will arise in the resurrection and the inheritance of the land will be given to them themselves. And for this, it is necessary to prepare such a generation and such a quality of the land of Israel that are worthy of receiving the inheritance of the land together with the Patriarchs, meaning a deserving generation that will have a connection to the Patriarchs and the Holy Land, and through the Patriarchs, as it is written, "that the Holy One, blessed be He, has taken an oath regarding the building of Jerusalem, which is worthy for David." And this is worthy for the Patriarchs, for in one aspect they are for them, and to these, may the Holy One, blessed be He, for I have promised and not fulfilled, for this reason the promise was delayed until the land of Israel would be worthy in its holiness, and the holiness of the generation would suffice to give "to them." And this is the explanation of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, "And I will appear to the Patriarchs," that this revelation in the promise of the inheritance of the land was on the condition that Israel would have a connection with the Patriarchs and would conduct themselves in their way until they would be called Patriarchs to them. And this is the reason for my promise and not fulfilling it, and this is the answer to what Moshe Rabbeinu asked, "Why have You done evil to this people?"
summary: The passage discusses the connection between the promise of the Land of Canaan to the Jewish people and the concept of resurrection. It emphasizes that the fulfillment of this promise is contingent upon the spiritual readiness of the generation, which must be worthy and connected to the patriarchs. The delay in the promise's realization is attributed to the need for a generation that embodies the sanctity required to inherit the land, highlighting the importance of maintaining a relationship with the ancestors and adhering to their ways. Ultimately, it reflects a deep theological insight into the interplay between divine promises, human actions, and the sanctity of the land.

passage_content: ובדורותהקודמים מנהיגי ישראל הקדושים שבא"י שמרו על קדושת הארץ, וגדרו גדרים ותקנות לשמור חומת הקדושה לבל יפרצו בה פרצות, (הבאתי מקצתם בספרי ויואל משה עמוד שכ"ח ש"נ עיי"ש) ועל דעת כן קראוה מיסדי' לכולל הזה בשם שומרי החומות, אף שבימיהם לא הי' לירושלים חומה סביב לה וכבר נחרבה, אולם כוונת השם הזה לציין מטרת הכוללשנתייסדהע"ד כן לשמור חומת הקדושה וחומת הדת לבל יבואו בה פריצים ויחללוה,דבמקוםשאין חומה שכיחי מתפרצים וע"דשאמה"כ(משלי כ"ה כ"ח) עיר פרוצה אין חומה, וצריך כ"א להתאמץ שיהי' לו חלק בהחזקת המוסד הקדוש הזה שיהי' לו קיום, וזהו הכנה לביאת הגואל וירושת הארץ שא"א כ"אלהמתנהגיםבדרכיהאבוה"ק, כמו שהבטיח הקב"ה לתת להם ארץ כנען, ונזכה לקבל פני משיחצדקינו בנחת ובשמחה, ולראות בישועת ישראל ושמחתן בהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו במהרה בימינו אמן.
translation: In previous generations, the holy leaders of Israel in the Land of Israel maintained the sanctity of the land, establishing fences and regulations to safeguard the wall of holiness so that breaches would not occur within it. (I have brought some of them in my book Vayoeil Moshe, page 268, see there.) With this understanding, the founders of this community called it "Guardians of the Walls," even though in their time Jerusalem did not have a wall surrounding it and had already been destroyed. However, the intention of this name is to signify the purpose of the community that was established to safeguard the wall of holiness and the wall of religion, so that intruders would not come and desecrate it. For in a place where there is no wall, breaches are common, as it is stated (Proverbs 25:28), "A city broken through has no wall." Each person must strive to have a share in the support of this holy institution so that it may endure. This is a preparation for the coming of the Redeemer and the inheritance of the land, which cannot be for those who conduct themselves in the ways of our holy forefathers, as the Holy One, blessed be He, promised to give them the land of Canaan. May we merit to greet the Messiah, our righteous one, with ease and joy, and to witness the salvation of Israel and their joy in the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us speedily in our days, Amen.
summary: In this passage, the author emphasizes the importance of maintaining the sanctity of the Land of Israel through communal efforts and regulations, likening it to a protective wall against spiritual breaches. The term "Shomrei Chomos" reflects the mission of safeguarding religious and moral boundaries, especially in a time when Jerusalem lacks physical walls. This commitment is seen as a preparation for the coming of the Messiah and the inheritance of the land, aligning with the divine promise of the Holy Land to the forefathers. Ultimately, the passage expresses hope for the redemption of Israel and the revelation of divine glory in the world.

passage_content: ואראאל אברהם וגו' באל שדי ושמי ד' לא נודעתי להם,פרש"ילא נכרתי להםבמדתאמיתית שלי וכו' שהרי הבטחתים ולא קיימתי, ולכאורה מהנפק"מבאיזה שם משמותיוית' נתוודע להם, ודיבורוית' לא ישוב ריקם בכל אופן ואופן, גם הרי לא הגיע עדיין הזמן שיתקיים ההבטחה, ואין סיבת המניעה מפני שלא נתוודע להם בשם הוי'ית'.
translation: "And I appeared to Abraham, etc., as El Shaddai, and My name YHWH was not made known to them. This means that I did not make Myself known to them in My true essence, etc., for I had promised them and did not fulfill it. And seemingly, what is the practical difference in which of My names they were made aware of? And His word will not return empty in any case, and indeed the time for the fulfillment of the promise has not yet arrived, and the reason for the delay is not because they were not made aware of the name YHWH."
summary: In this passage, the author discusses the revelation of God to Abraham through the name El Shaddai, contrasting it with the name YHWH, which had not yet been revealed. The text emphasizes that God's promises to Abraham were not fulfilled at that time, suggesting that the lack of revelation of the name YHWH did not hinder the eventual realization of those promises. It highlights the idea that God's word is always effective and will ultimately come to fruition, regardless of the timing or the names used in divine communication. This reflects a deep theological insight into the nature of God's relationship with humanity and the unfolding of divine promises.

passage_content: ויתבארבהקדםקושיתק"ז הישמח משהזלה"ה(פ'וארא)דבגמ' (ב"ב קי"ז ע"א)יליףמקרא ונתתי אותה לכם מורשה,דליוצאימצריםנתחלקההארץ עיי"ש, ולהלן (קי"ט ע"א) מסיקדמוחזקתהיא ליוצאי מצרים ובניהם נטלו חלק בכורה עיי"ש, ולכאורה קשהממנ"פאי זכו משעת הבטחה, א"כ כבר זכו בה האבות והי' ראוי שיתחלק א"י לי"ב חלקים שווין שהם בני יעקב, וכל א' מוריש לבניו כפי הבנים ולא כפי הבני בנים, ואי לא זכו עד שעת ביאתן א"כ הי' ראוי להתחלק לבאי הארץ ולא ליוצאי מצרים ע"כקושיתו.
translation: And it will be explained in advance the question of K"Z, that Moses was happy with the Divine Presence (in Parashat Va'era) that in the Gemara (Baba Batra 117a) it derives from the verse "And I have given it to you as an inheritance," that the land was divided to the ones who went out of Egypt, as stated there. And further (119a) it concludes that the stronghold is for the ones who went out of Egypt and their children received the firstborn portion, as stated there. And at first glance, it is difficult from the perspective of "if they merited from the time of the promise," then the forefathers already merited it, and it would have been appropriate for the Land of Israel to be divided into twelve equal parts, which are the sons of Jacob, and each one bequeaths to his sons according to the sons and not according to the grandsons. And if they did not merit until the time of their coming, then it would have been appropriate to divide it among those who entered the land and not to the ones who went out of Egypt; thus is his question.
summary: The passage discusses the theological question of why the land of Israel was divided among the Israelites who left Egypt rather than being equally divided among the twelve tribes, as descendants of Jacob. It raises the issue of whether the patriarchs had already secured a claim to the land at the time of the promise, suggesting that if so, the land should have been divided among their descendants. The text emphasizes the significance of the Exodus and the unique status of the Israelites who left Egypt, highlighting the Hasidic concept of divine promise and inheritance. Ultimately, it reflects on the complexities of spiritual legacy and the relationship between the ancestors and their descendants in the context of divine providence.

passage_content: ויתורץכ"ז עפ"י דרכנו הנ"ל,דהנהירושת הארץתליאג"כ בזה, אם נחשבים להתייחס ע"ש אבותיהם ולא נטמעו באומות, ורק אז זוכים בארץמכחירושת אבותיהם,וק"זהיש"מזלה"הפי' בזה קישור הפסוקים והייתי לכםלאלקיםוגו' והבאתי אתכם אל הארץ וגו' ונתתי אותה לכם מורשה, והנה יש לתמוה אם מורשה הוא. אף אם לא יתייחדו לעם לוית' לייחדאלקותועליהם, מ"מ שלהם היא כמו בשאר אומות בארץ ירושתם, ואיך תולה זה בזה, ותוכן תירוצועפי"דהמהרי"ט(בתשו'ח"בס"ו)דהגםדעשוישראל מומר הוידיורשאת אביו.עכ"זאין לו זרעלירשאותו, כיון שנשא נשיםנכריותקרוי בנה וממילא אין להם חלק בארץ, אבל אנחנובנ"יאברהם יצחק ויעקב זוכים בארץמכחירושת אבותינו, כי שםי"העדות לישראל שלא נטמעו אף בהיותם במצרים,וז"שולקחתי אתכם לי לעם והייתי לכםלאלקיםלייחד שמי עליכם, והיינו מפני שמתייחסים אחר האבות, ולכך והבאתי אתכם וגו' ונתתי אותה לכם מורשהעכלה"ק, נמצאדבזכותשלא נטמעו באומות זכו ישראל לירושת הארץ, ואפשרדמה"טליוצאי מצרייםדייקאנתחלקההארץ,דטרםשיצאו ממצרים עדיין לא הי' מוחזקת להם וקיום ההבטחה עדייןהיתהתלוי' ועומדת אם יהיו נחשבים ע"ש אבותיהם ולאיטמעוח"ו, ולטעם זה לא נתייחד שםי"הלהעיד עליהם כ"א אחר יציאתם ממצרים,דעדאז הי'תליאבבחירתם ואין הקב"ה מייחד שמוית' להעיד בדבר התלוי בבחירה כידוע, וע"כ מוחזקת היא ליוצאי מצרים ולא משעת ההבטחה ומתורץ קושיא הנ"ל.
translation: And it will be explained according to our aforementioned approach, that the inheritance of the land is also dependent on this, if they are considered to be related to their forefathers and have not been assimilated among the nations, and only then do they merit the land by virtue of the inheritance of their forefathers. And this is what is meant by "the fortune of the nation." The explanation here connects the verses "And I will be your God" and "And I brought you to the land" and "And I gave it to you as an inheritance." And behold, one might wonder if it is indeed an inheritance. Even if they do not identify as a nation to sanctify the Divine upon them, nevertheless, it belongs to them like it does to other nations in their inheritance of the land. And how does this depend on that? The content of the explanation is according to the Maharitz (in his responsa, part 2, section 6) that even if an Israelite is a heretic, he inherits from his father. Nevertheless, he has no right to inherit it, since he married foreign women, his son is called by his name, and consequently, they have no share in the land. But we, the children of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, merit the land by virtue of the inheritance of our forefathers, for there is a testimony to Israel that they were not assimilated even while they were in Egypt. And this is what is meant by "And I took you to be a people for Me" and "And I will be your God" to sanctify My name upon you, and this is because they are related to the forefathers. Therefore, "And I brought you" and "I gave it to you as an inheritance" is all the more so. It turns out that due to the fact that they did not assimilate among the nations, Israel merited the inheritance of the land. And it is possible that for this reason, the land was specifically divided to the descendants of those who left Egypt, for before they left Egypt, it was not yet held for them, and the fulfillment of the promise was still dependent and standing on whether they would be considered by their forefathers or assimilated, etc. And for this reason, the Divine name was not sanctified to testify about them until after their departure from Egypt, for until then it was dependent on their choice, and the Holy One, blessed be He, does not sanctify His name to testify about something that is dependent on choice, as is known. And therefore, it is held for those who left Egypt and not from the time of the promise, and the aforementioned question is resolved.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of inheritance of the land of Israel, emphasizing that this inheritance is contingent upon the Jewish people's connection to their patriarchs and their separation from the nations. It asserts that the Israelites, by not assimilating during their time in Egypt, merit the land as a legacy from their ancestors. The text highlights that God's name is uniquely associated with the Israelites after their exodus from Egypt, signifying their chosen status and the fulfillment of the promise of the land, which was contingent upon their identity as descendants of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. Thus, the inheritance of the land is a divine reward for maintaining their distinct identity.

passage_content: ובזהיתבארו דברי רש"י ז"לואראאל האבות, ר"ל שהבטחתי להםבבחי' אבות לקיים לזרעם הנחשבים ע"ש אבותיהם ולא נטמעו באומות, ושמי ד' לא נודעתי להם. שעדיין לא נודע להם עדות שםי"העל זרעם כ"זדתליאבבחירה,ומה"טהבטחתי ולא קיימתי ר"ל שאינה מוחזקת ירושת הארץ כ"א ליוצאי מצרים ולא משעת הבטחה, לכן אמורלבנ"יאני ד' והוצאתי אתכם מתחת סבלות מצרים, שבשעת יציאתם אייחד שמי להעיד עליחוסיהםשלא נטמעו,ועי"זיתקיים הבטחתי והבאתי אתכם אל הארץ וגו' ונתתי אותה לכם מורשה וגו'.
translation: And in this, the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, are clarified: I will reveal to the Patriarchs, meaning that I promised them in the aspect of the Patriarchs to fulfill for their descendants who are considered in the name of their forefathers and did not become mixed with the nations, and My name, the Lord, was not made known to them. For it was still not known to them the testimony of My name regarding their descendants, as this depends on choice. And what I promised and did not fulfill, meaning that the inheritance of the land is not established except for those who came out of Egypt and not from the time of the promise. Therefore, say to the children of Israel: I am the Lord, and I have taken you out from under the burdens of Egypt, that at the time of their departure I will sanctify My name to testify to their lineage that they did not become mixed, and through this, My promise will be fulfilled, and I brought you to the land, etc., and I gave it to you as an inheritance, etc.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author emphasizes the significance of the patriarchs and the divine promise made to them regarding their descendants, who are distinguished by their lineage and not assimilated among the nations. The text highlights that God's name was not fully revealed to the patriarchs, indicating a deeper connection to the concept of divine choice and the importance of the Israelites' identity. The assurance of land inheritance is specifically tied to the descendants of those who left Egypt, reinforcing the idea that their liberation and subsequent entry into the Promised Land fulfill God's covenant and demonstrate His commitment to their unique status as His chosen people.

passage_content: וגםהקמתי את בריתי אתם לתת להם את ארץ כנען וגו', בגמ' (סנהדרין צ' ע"ב) דרשו רז"ל לכם לא נאמר אלא להם מכאן לתחיית המתים מן התורה עכ"דהגמ', ראוי להבין קישור דרשתם ז"ללהכא, ומדוע רמז הכתוב להבטחתתה"מבפרשה זודייקא, וכבר ביארנו בזה ועודלאלקימלין.
translation: "And I also established My covenant with them to give them the land of Canaan, etc. In the Gemara (Sanhedrin 90b), our Sages expounded: 'To you' is not stated, but 'to them'—from here is a hint to the resurrection of the dead from the Torah, thus says the Gemara. It is fitting to understand the connection of their teaching here, and why the verse hints at this promise specifically in this section. And we have already explained this and more in the context of the Divine."
summary: הפסוק מתאר את הקמת הברית עם עם ישראל והבטחת הארץ, כאשר חז"ל דרשו את המילה "להם" כדי לרמוז לתחיית המתים. הקישור בין הברית לאמונה בתחיית המתים מדגיש את הקשר העמוק בין הגאולה הרוחנית והגאולה הפיזית. ההבטחה לארץ כנען משקפת את ההבטחה הנצחית של ה' לעם ישראל, תוך חיבור בין ההיסטוריה לבין העתיד המובטח.

passage_content: ויתבארבהקדם דברי המדרש פ' ואתחנן (פר' ב' סי' ט') א"ל הקב"ה למשה אם אתה נקבר כאן אצלן בזכותך הן באין עמך,אר"ללמה"ד דומהלאחדשנתפזרומעותיו במקום אפילה, אמר אם אומר אני האירו לי שאקבץמעותיאין ברי' משגחת עלי, מה עשה נטל זהב א' והשליך בתוכם, והתחיל צווח ואומר האירו לי זהב א' הי' לי ונפל ממני כאן והאירו לו, מה עשה משנטל את הזהוב אמר להן בחייהם המתינו לי שאלקט את המעות, בזכות הזהבנתלקטוהמעות, כך אמר לו הקב"ה למשה אם נקבר את אצלם במדבר הן באים בזכותך ואתה בא בראשם שנא' וירא ראשית לו וגו'ויתאראשי עם עכ"ד המדרש, ולכאורה יהי' מזה סתירהלמ"שבמד"ר(סו"פשמות) ויאמר ד' אל משה עתה תראה אשר אעשה לפרעה, במלחמת פרעה אתה רואה, ואין אתה רואה במלחמת ל"א מלכיםוכו', מכאן אתה למד שנטל משה עכשיו את הדין שלא יכנס לארץ הרי מבואר שנגזר עליו שלא יכנס לארץ בשביל שאמר למההרעותה,ולפי"דהמדרש הנ"ל הי' מוכרח כן מטעם אחר,דע"ישנקברמשרע"הבמדבר יבואו עמו מתי מדבר לעתיד בעתהתחי', וא"כ לאע"צהעונש הי' כ"א לטובתן של ישראל, גם צ"ב מדברי רז"ל (סנהדרין ק"י ע"ב) שהכריחודדורהמדבר יש להם חלק לעוה"ב, ממה שנאמר (ירמי' ב') הלוך וקראת באזני ירושליםלאמרוגו' זכרתי לך חסד נעוריך אהבת כלולותיך לכתך אחרי במדבר בארץ לא זרועה, ומה אחרים באים בזכותם הם עצמם לא כל שכן עכ"דהגמ', הרי מבואר שדור המדבר עצמה זכותם להביא גם אחרים,והבוי"תיזכור זכותם לכל ישראלשיהנובזכותם לעוה"ב,ומכ"ששיספיק זכותם לעצמם, כמ"ש בגמ' הם עצמם לאכש"כ,וה"זסתירה לדברי המדרש הנ"ל (בפ' ואתחנן) שרק ע"י שנקברמשרע"הבמדבר הן באים בזכותו, ואם לא יספיק זכותם לעצמם, איך יבואו אחרים בזכותם, גם צ"בדלפי"דהמדרש הנ"לדדורדיעהשל מתי מדבר לא יזכולתחי' רק ע"י שנקברמשרע"העמהם, א"כ איך יהי' תקנתן של דורות אחרים האובדים בארץ אשור והנדחים בארץ מצרים וכל מתי חו"ל שלא נקברמשרע"העמהם,ובל"סשכולן יזכולתחי' כמבואר בפסוקים ובאו האובדים בארץ אשור וגו',וצ"באיך יגרע זכותם של דור המדבר דורדיעהשלא יבואו רק אם נקברמשרע"העמהם, וכללית ישראל הבאים רק בזכותם יזכולתחי' אףבל"ז.
translation:
And it will be explained in advance the words of the Midrash in Parashat Va'etchanan (Parashat Be'ah, Siman 9): The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "If you are buried here among them, they will come with you because of your merit." This is similar to the saying that if one scatters his coins in a dark place, he says, "If I say, 'Illuminate for me so that I may gather the coins,' who will watch over me?" What did he do? He took one gold coin and threw it among them, and he began to cry out, saying, "Illuminate for me, one gold coin that I had and fell from me here," and they illuminated for him. What did he do? When he took the gold, he said to them, "In their lifetime, wait for me until I collect the coins." Because of the gold, the coins were gathered. Thus, the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "If you are buried among them in the desert, they will come because of you, and you will come at their head," as it is said, "And he saw the beginning of it," etc., and it describes the head with this. 

And at first glance, this will be a contradiction to what is said in the Midrash (Sifrei Shemot) that the Lord said to Moses, "Now you will see what I will do to Pharaoh," in the war against Pharaoh you see, and you do not see in the war of thirty-one kings, etc. From here you learn that Moses took the judgment now that he would not enter the land; it is clear that it was decreed upon him that he would not enter the land because he said, "Why have You done evil to this people?" And according to the aforementioned Midrash, it was necessary for another reason, that if he is buried with the Israelites in the desert, the dead of the desert will come with him in the future at the time of the resurrection. And if so, the punishment was only for the benefit of Israel. 

It is also questioned from the words of our Sages (Sanhedrin 110b) that they forced the generation of the desert to have a share in the World to Come, from what is said (Jeremiah 2), "Go and proclaim in the ears of Jerusalem, saying, 'I remember for you the kindness of your youth, the love of your betrothals, your following Me in the desert, in a land not sown.'" And what others come because of them, they themselves, all the more so. Thus, it is clear that the generation of the desert itself has the merit to bring others as well, and certainly they will remember their merit for all of Israel so that they will benefit because of them in the World to Come, and certainly their merit will suffice for themselves, as it is said in the Gemara, "They themselves." 

And this is a contradiction to the words of the aforementioned Midrash (in Parashat Va'etchanan) that only by being buried with Moses in the desert will they come because of him, and if their merit is not sufficient for themselves, how will others come because of them? It is also questioned that according to the aforementioned Midrash, the generation of the desert will not be able to resurrect except by being buried with Moses among them. If so, how will the remedy of other generations who are lost in the land of Assyria and the exiles in the land of Egypt and all the dead of the diaspora who were not buried with Moses among them be? And certainly all of them will be able to resurrect, as is explained in the verses, "And the lost ones of the land of Assyria will come," etc. 

It is also questioned how the merit of the generation of the desert will be diminished, that they will not come unless Moses is buried with them, and all of Israel who come only because of them will be able to resurrect even without this.
summary: The passage discusses the theological implications of Moses' burial in the desert, suggesting that his merit allows the souls of the Israelites to be gathered and resurrected in the future. It contrasts this idea with the notion that the generation of the desert possesses their own merit for the World to Come, raising questions about the relationship between individual and collective merit. The text emphasizes that Moses' burial serves as a catalyst for the redemption of others, while also affirming the inherent value of the generation that wandered in the desert. Ultimately, it highlights the interconnectedness of their spiritual legacies and the divine plan for redemption.

passage_content: ולבארהעניןנקדים דבריהגמ' כתובות (קי"א ע"א)א"ראליעזר מתים שבחו"ל אינם חיים שנא' (ישעי' כ"ו) ונתתי צבי בארץ חיים, ארץ שצביוני בהמיתיהחיים, שאין צביוני בה איןמיתיהחיים וכו' והקשו בגמ'ולר' אלעזר צדיקים שבחו"ל אינם חיים (בתמי' ותירצו)א"ראילעאע"י גלגול, מתקיף לה ר' אבאסלארבא גלגול לצדיקים צער הוא, אמראביימחילות נעשית להם בקרקע, ונשאתני ממצרים וקברתני בקבורתם אמרקרנאדברים בגו יודע הי' יעקב אבינו שצדיק גמור הי', ואם מתים שבחו"ל חיים למה הטריח את בניו, ותירצו שמא לא יזכה למחילות, (ובעין יעקבהגירסאשלא קבל עליו צער מחילות) כיוצא בדבר אתה אומר וישבע יוסף את בני ישראל וגו',א"רחנינאדבריםבגו יודע הי' יוסף בעצמו שצדיק גמור הי', ואם מתים שבחו"ל חיים למה הטריח את אחיו ד' מאות פרסה, ותירצו שמא לא יזכה למחילות, (ובע"יהגירסאשלא קבל עליו צער מחילות) עכ"דהגמ'לענינינוולכאורה עדיין צ"בדלפי"דר"א רק הצדיקים שבחו"ל יזכולתחי' ע"י גלגול מחילות, ומה יהי' תקנתן של כל מתי חו"ל והאובדים בארץ אשור והנדחיםבאמ"צ,ובל"סשכל ישראל יזכולתחי' ולאידחממנונדחכמבואר בפסוקיםוצ"ב.
translation: To explain the matter, we will precede with the words of the Gemara in Ketubot (111a): "Rabbi Eliezer said, the dead in the Diaspora are not alive, as it is stated (Isaiah 26), 'And I will give beauty in the land of the living,' a land where the living are beautiful, where there are no living beings, etc." The Gemara asks, and according to Rabbi Eliezer, the righteous in the Diaspora are not alive (with wonder, and they answered) "Rabbi Eliezer said, through reincarnation, Rabbi Abba challenges this, for reincarnation is a suffering for the righteous. Rabbi Abba said, they are made into pits in the ground, and 'You brought me up from Egypt and buried me in their burial place,' said Rabbi Kahana. Jacob our father knew that he was a complete righteous person, and if the dead in the Diaspora are alive, why did he trouble his sons? They answered, perhaps he would not merit the pits (and in the version of the eye of Jacob, it is stated that he did not accept the suffering of the pits). Similarly, you say, 'And Joseph made the sons of Israel swear,' etc. Rabbi Hanina said, Joseph himself knew that he was a complete righteous person, and if the dead in the Diaspora are alive, why did he trouble his brothers four hundred parasangs? They answered, perhaps he would not merit the pits (and in the version of the eye, it is stated that he did not accept the suffering of the pits). Thus, the Gemara concludes regarding our matter, and seemingly, according to Rabbi Eliezer, only the righteous in the Diaspora can merit life through the reincarnation of the pits, and what will be the remedy for all the dead in the Diaspora and those lost in the land of Assyria and the exiles in the land of Israel? And certainly, all of Israel will merit life, and as it is explained in the verses, etc.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of the afterlife for the righteous who die outside of the Land of Israel, referencing a Talmudic discussion about whether they are considered alive. It highlights the belief that while righteous individuals may experience a form of reincarnation or resurrection through "gilgul," there is a concern for their suffering in the afterlife. The text emphasizes the importance of burial in the Land of Israel, as it is seen as a means for the righteous to attain a higher spiritual status. Ultimately, it suggests that all of Israel will merit resurrection, reflecting a deep theological commitment to the sanctity of the Land and the fate of the Jewish soul.

passage_content: ויתבארכ"זעפימ"שהיפה תואר (בב"רפר' כ"ו סי' ג')דזמןהתחי' מתי יהי' נמצא מימרות חלוקות בדברי רז"ל,שממ"שבמס' יומא מצנפת ואבנט איזה מהן קודם. ותירצו לכשיבנהביהמ"קמשה ואהרן עמהםוכו', נראה שיהי'התחי' בזמןביהמ"קלימות משיחנו,וממ"שאין בין עוה"ז לימות משיחנו אלא שעבודמלכיותאינו נראה כן,דא"כשינוי גדול בין העוה"ז לזמן ההוא שיקומו כל המתים ויהפכו שפה ברורהוכו', עיי"ש שאסף איש טהור הרבה מאמרי רז"ל שמבוארבמקצתםשיתקייםהתחי' בעת ביאת משיחנו בב"א,ובמקו"אנראה שיהי' ליום הדין הגדול, וסוף דבר הביא דעת בעל העקריםמ"ש(במ"דפ"א) שבימות המשיח תהי' תחייה לצדיקים גמורים, כדי להקנותם שלימות גדול שלא יכלו לקבל תחלה, ולפרסם בעולם יכולתו הגדול, וליום הדין תהי'תחי' כוללת, וקרוב לזה כתבהראב"עז"לבפ' רביםמישיניאדמת עפר,ולפי"זיצדקו יחד המדרשים האומריםבתחי' לימות המשיח והאומרים אחר ימות המשיח עכ"דהיפ"תוכן כתבהרדב"ז(בתשו'ח"בסי' תתל"ט) בשםהריטב"אשהביא כן בשם רבותיו, וכ"כ הרבה מהראשונים עיין בספרי ויואל משה (מאמר א' סי' נ') העתקתי מקצת דבריהם ועוד ראיות מדברי הש"ס עיי"ש.
translation: And it will be explained that the beautiful form (in Bereishit Rabbah, chapter 26, section 3) is the time of the resurrection, when there will be differing statements in the words of our Sages, regarding what is mentioned in Tractate Yoma about the headgear and the belt, which of them comes first. And they answered that when the Holy Temple is built, Moses and Aaron will be with them, etc. It seems that the resurrection will occur at the time of the Holy Temple in the days of our Messiah. And from what is stated that there is no difference between this world and the days of our Messiah except for the subjugation of kingdoms, it does not appear so, for there is a great difference between this world and that time when all the dead will rise and a clear language will be transformed, etc. There, a pure man gathered many sayings of our Sages, which are explained in some of them that the resurrection will take place at the coming of our Messiah, may it be speedily in our days. And in another place, it seems that it will be on the Day of Judgment. In conclusion, he brought the opinion of the author of the "Ikkarim" who wrote (in the first part, chapter 1) that in the days of the Messiah there will be a resurrection for the completely righteous, in order to grant them a great completeness that they could not receive initially, and to publicize His great power in the world. And on the Day of Judgment, there will be a general resurrection. And closely related to this, the Rabbi said in the section "Rabbim" that the dust will awaken. According to this, the midrashim that say the resurrection will be in the days of the Messiah and those that say after the days of the Messiah will be reconciled. Thus, the content is written in the responsa of the Radbaz (in responsa, part 2, section 579) in the name of the Ritva, who brought it in the name of his teachers, and many of the early authorities wrote similarly. See in the books "Vayoeil Moshe" (Article 1, section 50) where I copied some of their words and additional proofs from the Talmud, see there.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of resurrection (techiyat hameitim) in relation to the Messianic era, highlighting differing opinions among the sages regarding its timing. It suggests that the resurrection will occur during the Messianic age, with a distinction made between the resurrection of the righteous and a more universal resurrection at the Day of Judgment. The text emphasizes that this resurrection serves to grant the righteous a completeness they could not attain previously and to showcase God's greatness to the world. Ultimately, it reconciles various interpretations by indicating that both views on the timing of resurrection—before and after the Messianic era—can coexist.

passage_content: ועפ"יהקדמתדבה"קאפ"לדמ"שרז"ל בגמ' כתובות הנ"ל, מתים שבחו"ל אינם חיים, ורק הצדיקים שבחו"ל יזכולתחי', שע"י גלגול מחילות יבואו לא"י ושם נפשם חוזרת אליהן, כ"ז נאמר רק עלהתחי' ראשונה לימות המשיח, ומפורש כן בירושלמי (פ"טדכלאים) אתהלך לפני ד' בארצות החיים,רשב"לבשם ברקפראארץשמיתיהחיין תחלה לימות המשיח וכו' אלא מעתה רבותינו שבגולה הפסידו,א"רסימאי מחליד הקב"ה לפניהן את הארץ והןמתגלגליןוכו' וכיון שהןמגיעיןלא"י נפשן חוזרות עליהן, ומ"ט (דכתיביחזקאל ל"ז) הנה אני פותח את קברותיכםוהעלתיאתכם וגו' והבאתי אתכם אל אדמת ישראל, ואח"כ ונתתי בכם רוחי וחייתם עכ"ד הירושלמי, הרי מבואר בפירושדתנאיזה שיצרכו לגלגול מחילות ולהחיות על אדמת ישראל, יהי'בתחי' דימות המשיח ולא יזכו לזה כ"א הצדיקים כמבואר שם, אמנםבתחי' השני' שלעתיד כל העולם יהי'בבחי' ארץ ישראל, וכמ"ש ק"זזלה"ה(בתפלה למשה תהלים פ"ב) לפרש הפסוק קומהאלקיםשפטה הארץ וגו' כי ע'קטדראותהם לע' שרי מעלה, אבל לעתידהכלתחת יד השי"ת לבדו, וכל עולםבבחי' ארץ ישראל, והיינו קומהאלקיםדייקא, כי אתה תנחל ר"ל כי כל העולם יהי'בבחי' נחלה זו ירושלים והבןעכלה"ק, נמצא דאז לאיצויירמתי חו"ל כלל, וכל מקום שבעולם יהי'בבחי' א"י תחת יד השי"ת לבדו בלי ממשלת שרי מעלה, ע"כ לא יהי' צורך לגלגול מחילות שיעלו לא"י וכל ישראל יזכובתחי' במקומם.
translation: And according to what our sages, of blessed memory, said in the Gemara in Ketubot mentioned above, the dead who are outside the land (of Israel) are not alive, and only the righteous who are outside will merit to live, for through the reincarnation of their souls they will come to the land of Israel, and there their souls will return to them. This is said only regarding the first resurrection in the days of the Messiah, and it is explicitly stated in the Jerusalem Talmud (Pe'ah 9) "I will walk before God in the lands of the living," Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said in the name of Bar Kappara that the land of Israel will revive first in the days of the Messiah, etc. However, from now on, our sages in exile have lost, as it is stated, "The Holy One, blessed be He, will revive the land before them, and they will be reincarnated," and when they arrive in the land of Israel, their souls will return to them. And the reason is (as it is written in Ezekiel 37) "Behold, I open your graves and raise you up," etc., "and I brought you to the land of Israel," and afterwards "and I put My spirit in you, and you shall live," thus concludes the Jerusalem Talmud. It is clearly explained that they will need reincarnation to be revived on the land of Israel, which will be at the beginning of the days of the Messiah, and only the righteous will merit this, as is explained there. However, in the second resurrection of the future, the entire world will be in the state of the land of Israel, as it is written in Psalms 82 (in the prayer of Moses) to explain the verse "Arise, O God, judge the earth," etc., for there are seventy nations corresponding to seventy ministering angels, but in the future, everything will be under the hand of the Holy One, blessed be He alone, and the entire world will be in the state of the land of Israel. This is the meaning of "Arise, O God," specifically, for You will inherit, meaning that the entire world will be in this inheritance, Jerusalem, and understand this well. It follows that then there will be no need for the resurrection of the dead from outside the land at all, and every place in the world will be in the state of the land of Israel under the hand of the Holy One, blessed be He alone, without the governance of ministering angels, therefore there will be no need for reincarnation to ascend to the land of Israel, and all of Israel will merit to live in their place.
summary: The passage discusses the resurrection of the dead, emphasizing that only the righteous from the diaspora will experience revival through reincarnation in the Land of Israel during the initial resurrection of the Messianic era. It highlights that this process is necessary for the righteous to return to their souls, as stated in the Jerusalem Talmud. In contrast, during the ultimate future redemption, the entire world will embody the qualities of the Land of Israel, with God's direct sovereignty over all, eliminating the need for reincarnation. Thus, all of Israel will attain revival in their respective places without the necessity of returning to Israel.

passage_content: ובזהיתורצו כל הקושיות הנ"ל,דאה"נדור המדבר עצמה זכותם מאוד, עד שאף אחרים יבואו בזכותם לעתידבתחי' הכללית והם עצמם לאכש"כשיזכו לעוה"ב כמבואר בגמ' (סנהדרין ק"י ע"ב) אמנם אעפ"כ הי' ההכרח שיקברמשרע"הבמדבר,דעי"זניתוסף זכותם ומעלתם והם באים עמו בזכותובתחי' הראשונה, גם ודאי שלא יצרכו לצער גלגול מחילות, כיון שיבואו עמו ובזכותו, ואף צדיקים גדולים הנקברים בחו"ל זולתם ג"כ יקומובתחי' הראשונה, אלא שיצטרכו לגלגול מחילות כמבוארבגמ', ושאר מתי חו"ל שלא הגיעו למעלת הצדיקים יקומו רקבתחי' הכללית כמבואר בדברי הראשונים הנ"ל מבואר מכל זה דמה שלא נכנסמשרע"הלארץ לא הי' לצד העונש, כ"א להצלת ישראל דור המדבר,ומ"שרז"ל כאן נטל משה את הדין שלא יכנס לארץ כבר ביארנו בדברנו לעיל שהי'בבחי' נורא עלילה, על שהי' הגזירה מוכרחת לטובתן של ישראל, ולא עבידקוב"הדינאבלאדינא, ע"כנסתבבלידו מעשה זה, שבאמת לא הי' חטא שלטובתן של ישראלנתכוין, אלא שלגודל קדושתו שלמשרע"הנחשב לפגם ע"דוסביביונשערה מאוד, וכ"ז הי' סיבה כדי שיקבר במדבר ויבואו עמו דור המדבר, וא"ש דשני הטעמים שנתנו רז"ל על שלא נכנסמשרע"הלארץתרווייהואיתנייהווצריכאלתרווייהו,דלולאהטעם של דור המדבר שיבואו עמו, לא הי' ראוישיסתבבמעשה זה לידו, ולולאשנסתבבלידומ"שלמההרעותהלא הי' נמנע מלכנס לא"י דלא עבידקוב"הדינאבלאדינאע"כ הי' הצורך בשניהם והבן.
translation: And with this, all the aforementioned questions are resolved, for the generation of the desert itself has great merit, to the extent that even others will come in their merit in the future resurrection of the general resurrection, and they themselves will merit the World to Come, as explained in the Gemara (Sanhedrin 110b). However, despite this, it was necessary for Moshe to be buried in the desert, for by this, their merit and stature are added, and they come with him in merit and in the first resurrection. Also, certainly, they will not need to suffer the reincarnation of graves, since they will come with him and in his merit. Even great righteous ones who are buried abroad will also rise in the first resurrection, but they will need to undergo the reincarnation of graves, as explained in the Gemara. And other deceased from abroad who did not reach the level of the righteous will only rise in the general resurrection, as explained in the words of the earlier authorities. From all this, it is clear that Moshe's not entering the land was not due to punishment, but rather for the salvation of the Jewish people of the generation of the desert. And as our sages said here, Moshe took the judgment that he would not enter the land; we have already explained above that this was a terrible accusation, as the decree was necessary for the benefit of Israel, and the Holy One, blessed be He, does not act according to strict judgment. Therefore, this act was necessary, for in truth, there was no sin intended for the benefit of Israel, but rather due to the great sanctity of Moshe, which was considered a flaw in the eyes of the surrounding nations. And all this was a reason for him to be buried in the desert and for the generation of the desert to come with him. And it is understood that the two reasons given by our sages for why Moshe did not enter the land are both necessary; without the reason of the generation of the desert coming with him, it would not have been fitting for this act to be done by him, and without the necessity of the decree, he would have refrained from entering the land, for the Holy One, blessed be He, does not act according to strict judgment. Therefore, the need for both was essential, and understand this.
summary: The passage discusses the unique merit of the generation of the desert, emphasizing that their righteousness allows them to be resurrected in the future alongside Moses, who was buried in the desert to enhance their merit. It asserts that Moses' exclusion from entering the Promised Land was not a punishment but rather a necessary act for the benefit of the Israelites, highlighting the profound sanctity of Moses and the divine plan that intertwines justice and mercy. The text illustrates that even great righteous individuals buried outside the land will eventually be resurrected, albeit with the need for a process of reincarnation, while the generation of the desert will rise directly due to their special status. Ultimately, it conveys the idea that divine actions, even when seemingly punitive, serve a greater purpose for the collective good of the Jewish people.

passage_content: ובזהיתבאר דבריהגמ'דסנהדריןהנ"ל, שדרשו רז"ל וגםהקימותיאת בריתי אתם לתת להם את ארץ כנען, לכם לא נאמר אלא להם מכאןלתה"ממן התורה,פרש"יז"ל לכם לא נאמר אלא להםדמשמעשהבטיח הקב"ה לאבותינו אברהם יצחק ויעקבשיתןלהם ארץ ישראל, וכי להם ניתנה והלא לבניהם ניתנה, אלא מלמדשעתידיןלחיות ועתיד הקב"ה ליתן להם את ארץ כנען עכ"ל רש"י ז"ל, וע"כ הכוונה כאן עלתחי' הראשונה לפני ביאת המשיח שאז יקומו האבות הקדושיםמדקאמרלתת להם את ארץ כנען,דבתחי' הכללית לא יהי' עוד במציאות ארץ כנען. שהמלך המשיח יכבוש את כל העולם ולעתיד יהי'הכלתחת יד הקב"ה וכל העולם יהי'בבחי' א"י וירושלים כנ"ל,ועכ"חלימוד זה עלתחי'הראשונה שיקומוהאבוה"קאז, ועלתחי' הכללית ישנם שם בגמ' הרבה לימודים עיי"ש, ורמז הקב"הלמשרע"ההבטחה זולהפיסדעתו על שנגזר עליו שלא יכנס לארץ,כאמרז"לכאן נטל משה את הדין שלא יכנס לארץ,דכלזה הכרח לטובתן של ישראל כדי שיבואו עמו דור המדברבתחי' הראשונה כשיקומומשרע"הוהאבוה"ק, וע"כ הודיעוית' כאן הבטחתתחה"מוא"ש.
translation: And in explaining the words of the Gemara in Sanhedrin mentioned above, that our Sages of blessed memory also interpreted, "And I will establish My covenant with you to give them the land of Canaan," it was not said to you but to them, from here we learn that it is from the Torah. Rashi of blessed memory explains, "It was not said to you but to them," which implies that the Holy One, blessed be He, promised our forefathers Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob to give them the land of Israel, and indeed it was given to them, but it was given to their children. Rather, it teaches that they will live in the future, and the Holy One, blessed be He, will give them the land of Canaan. Thus, the intention here is regarding the first resurrection before the coming of the Messiah, at which time the holy forefathers will arise, as it says, "to give them the land of Canaan," for in the general resurrection there will no longer be the reality of the land of Canaan. The Messiah will conquer the entire world, and in the future, everything will be under the hand of the Holy One, blessed be He, and the entire world will be like the land of Israel and Jerusalem, as mentioned above. Therefore, this teaching pertains to the first resurrection when the holy forefathers will arise, and regarding the general resurrection, there are many teachings on this in the Gemara, as you can see there. And the Holy One, blessed be He, hinted to Moshe Rabbeinu the promise except to appease his mind regarding the decree that he would not enter the land, as our Sages of blessed memory said, "Here Moshe took the judgment that he would not enter the land," for all this is necessary for the benefit of Israel so that they would come with him, the generation of the desert, in the first resurrection when Moshe Rabbeinu and the holy forefathers will arise. Therefore, He informed him here of the promise of the resurrection of the dead.
summary: The passage discusses the promise of the Land of Israel to the patriarchs Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, emphasizing that it is ultimately intended for their descendants. It highlights the concept of resurrection in the Messianic era, where the patriarchs will rise and receive the land, signifying a transformation of the world into a state akin to the holiness of the Land of Israel. Additionally, it reflects on Moses' exclusion from entering the land as a necessary measure for the benefit of the Israelites, ensuring their connection to the patriarchs during the initial resurrection. This underscores the deep theological belief in divine promise and redemption for the Jewish people.

passage_content: ולדרכינויתורץקושיתהאוהחה"קעה"פ והבאתי אתכם אל הארץ, וז"ל קשה כי דברי ק"ל עליון דברו טהור הוא כי יוצאי מצרים הם הנכנסים לארץדכתיבוהבאתי אתכם אל הארץ. ולא מצינו שכן הי' אלא ואת בניהם הביא שמה, אבל כל דור יוצאי מצרים מבן כ' ולמעלה נפלו פגריהם במדבר, ותגדלהקושיאלמה שאמרנו שנשבע ד' על כל הדברים, באמרו לכן ואמרו ז"ל אין לכן אלא לשון שבועה ע"כקושיתו, ותירץשהבוי"תהבטיח ע"ד תנאי והקדים לומר וידעתם כי אני ד' המוציא אתכם וגו' ובזה והבאתי אתכםיעיי"ש, ולדרכנו א"ש שיתקיים ההבטחה ליוצאי מצרים והם דור המדבר, והם בעצמם יבואו לארץ לעתידבתחי' הראשונה עםמשרע"הוהאבוה"ק, וז"א והבאתי אתכם אל הארץ אשר נשאתי את ידי לתת אותה לאברהם ליצחק וליעקב, והיינו ארץ כנען שהובטח להםבתחי' הראשונה, ויזכו עמהם גם דור המדבר לכנס לארץ,ולפי"זמאמר והבאתי הבטחה על זמן גאולה העתידה, והנהאמרז"ל(בירושלמי ע"פ ה"ה)דארבעכוסות תיקנו חז"ל כנגד ד' לשונות של גאולה והוצאתי והצלתי וגאלתי ולקחתי, ויתכןדכוסהחמישישמוזגיןלכבודו של אלי'זל"ט, הוא כנגד והבאתי שהוא הבטחה על גאולה העתידה בב"א.
translation:
And according to our way, the question is resolved: "And I brought you to the land," as it is written, "It is difficult because the words of the Holy One, Blessed be He, are pure, for those who went out of Egypt are the ones who enter the land." It is written, "And I brought you to the land." And we do not find that it was so, except that He brought their children there, but every generation of those who went out of Egypt from the age of twenty and above fell dead in the desert. And the question is great regarding what we said that the Holy One, Blessed be He, swore on all matters, as it is said, "Therefore," and our sages said that "therefore" is only a term of an oath. Thus, the question is, and it was answered that the coming is a promise based on a condition, and He preceded it by saying, "And you shall know that I am the Lord who brought you out," etc., and with this, "And I brought you," as you can see there. 

And according to our way, it is clear that the promise to those who went out of Egypt, who are the generation of the desert, will be fulfilled, and they themselves will enter the land in the future, in the first redemption with Moshe Rabbeinu, the Holy One, Blessed be He. And it is said, "And I brought you to the land which I swore to give to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob," and this refers to the land of Canaan that was promised to them in the first redemption, and they will merit with them also the generation of the desert to enter the land. 

And according to this, the statement "And I brought" is a promise regarding the time of the future redemption. And behold, our sages have said (in the Jerusalem Talmud, based on Exodus 6:6) that the four cups were established by the sages corresponding to the four expressions of redemption: "And I took you out," "And I saved you," "And I redeemed you," and "And I took you." It is possible that the fifth cup, which is poured for the honor of Eliyahu, may his merit protect us, corresponds to "And I brought," which is a promise regarding the future redemption, speedily in our days.
summary: The passage discusses the promise of entering the Land of Israel, emphasizing that while the generation that left Egypt did not enter, their descendants would ultimately inherit the land. It highlights the concept of divine assurance, where God's oath guarantees the fulfillment of His promises, particularly regarding the future redemption. The text connects the four expressions of redemption mentioned in the Haggadah to the fifth, "and I brought you," which symbolizes the future redemption and the eventual arrival of the generation of the desert alongside Moses. This reflects a deep theological insight into the continuity of God's covenant with the Jewish people across generations.

passage_content: (אמור וגו' והוצאתי אתכם מתחת סבלות מצריםופירש"יכאשר הבטחתי ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול והקשה ק"זזלה"הבייטבלב למה מביא רש"י ז"ל סיום הקרא ברכוש גדול לכאן, ואפשר לומרדהנהרש"י ז"ל פירש מתחת סבלות מצרים מטורח משא מצרים, ולכאורה צריך להבין אריכות הזה בפסוק,דאלוהי' נשארים ח"ו במצרים, הי' מקום לומר שהוציאם הקב"המסבלותםמטורח משאם שניצולו מזה, אבל הקב"ה הוציאם לגמרי ממדינתם, מובן ממילא שניצולו מעבודתם ומטורח משאם, והי' די לומר והוצאתי אתכם ממצרים, ובזה נכללהכלואין מהצורך להזכיר עודמסבלותםומשאם, גם ענין הד' לשונות של גאולה שנזכרובכאןצריך להביןלפי"ז, כיוןדהכלנכלל ביציאתם משם א"כבוהוצאתידי.
translation: "Say, and I will take you out from under the burdens of Egypt," and it is explained, "as I promised," and afterwards they went out with great wealth. And the question arises, why does Rashi, of blessed memory, bring the conclusion of the verse with 'great wealth' here? It can be said that Rashi, of blessed memory, explained 'from under the burdens of Egypt' as from the toil of the burden of Egypt. And at first glance, one must understand this elaboration in the verse, for it could be said that the Holy One, blessed be He, did not leave them, Heaven forbid, in Egypt; it would have been appropriate to say that He took them out from their burdens, from the toil of their burden, that they were saved from this. But the Holy One, blessed be He, took them completely out of their land, which implies that they were saved from their work and from the toil of their burden. It would have sufficed to say, 'And I will take you out from Egypt,' and in this, it would include all that is necessary to mention further about their burdens and their toil. Also, the matter of the four expressions of redemption that are mentioned here needs to be understood according to this, since all is included in their leaving from there, as it is written, 'And I will take you out.'"
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author explores the significance of God's promise to liberate the Israelites from the burdens of Egypt, emphasizing that the redemption encompasses not only their physical departure but also a complete release from their suffering and labor. The mention of "great wealth" at the end of the verse serves to highlight the transformative nature of this redemption, suggesting that it is not merely an escape from oppression but a profound elevation of their state. The discussion of the four expressions of redemption further underscores the comprehensive nature of God's salvation, indicating that the liberation is holistic and encompasses all aspects of their existence.

passage_content: אמנםביאורהעניןנראהלפענ"ד, כי הנה ענין גלות מצרים ויציאתם משם, מלבד שיעבוד הגוף יותר מזה סבלו גלות הנפש, שהיו משוקעים שם במ"ט שערי טומאה ר"ל, והקב"ה הוציאם משםליכנסתחת כנפי השכינה, והנה נודע כאשר האדם יושב במקום קדושת בתי כנסיות ובתי מדרשותובכנופיאשל ת"ח ועובדי ה', אף בבואו לביתו אח"כ ונפרד משם מועלת לו הקדושה הזאת, וכמאמרם ז"ל משל לנכנסלחנונישל בושם ריח טוב קלט עמו, וכמו כן להיפך ח"ו בשבתו במקומות הטומאה ועוברי עבירה ר"ל, וע"ז נאמר אשרי האיש אשר לא הלך וגו' ובמושב לצים לא ישב וגו', ולא נאמר לשון הווה אינו עומד ואינו יושב, כי גם אם אינו עומד ואינו יושב כעת בדרך חטאים ובמושב לצים, כ"א עמד וישב מכבר, מזיק לו ריח הטומאה שקלט משם גם אח"כ בבואו לביתו, כיהכחהזה אשר נדבק עמומלוהאותו לביתו, וחז"ל אמרו לנכנסלחנונישל בושם ריח טוב קולט עמו, ובהיפך ח"ו קולט עמו ריח רע, הנה אמרו זה על הנכנס לחנותם ולא עשה שם מאומה, רק מחמת הכניסה לבדו קלט עמו ריח עכ"פ, אבל אם עוד פעל ועשה שם מעשה במקומות האלו, הנהנתלוהעמוכחממש בין לטוב בין להיפך ח"ו.
translation: Indeed, the explanation of the matter seems to me to be as follows: the issue of the Egyptian exile and their departure from there, aside from the physical servitude, they suffered even more from the exile of the soul, as they were sunk in the forty-nine gates of impurity, so to speak. And the Holy One, blessed be He, took them out from there to bring them under the wings of the Shechinah. It is known that when a person sits in the sanctity of synagogues and study halls and in the company of Torah scholars and servants of God, even when he later returns home and separates from there, this sanctity benefits him. As our sages of blessed memory said, it is like a person who enters a spice shop; the good fragrance accompanies him. Likewise, the opposite is true, Heaven forbid, when sitting in places of impurity and among transgressors, and concerning this it is said, "Blessed is the man who has not walked..." and "In the seat of scoffers, he has not sat..." It does not say in the present tense, "he does not stand and does not sit," because even if he is not currently standing or sitting in the way of sinners and in the seat of scoffers, he has already stood and sat there previously, and the scent of impurity that he absorbed from there harms him even later when he comes home, as this is the nature of the impression that clings to him and follows him home. And our sages said, "A person who enters a spice shop, the good fragrance accompanies him," and conversely, Heaven forbid, he absorbs a bad scent. They said this about one who enters their shop and does nothing there; just by entering alone, he absorbs at least the scent. But if he also acted and did something in those places, then the impression clings to him strongly, whether for good or, Heaven forbid, the opposite.
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual implications of the Jewish exile in Egypt, emphasizing that their suffering was not only physical but also a profound spiritual degradation, as they were immersed in impurity. It highlights the transformative power of holiness found in sacred spaces, such as synagogues and study halls, which can positively influence a person's spiritual state even after leaving those environments. Conversely, exposure to places of impurity and sin can leave a lasting negative impact, suggesting that one's spiritual condition is affected by both the environments they inhabit and their actions within those spaces. Ultimately, the text underscores the importance of maintaining spiritual integrity and the lasting effects of one's surroundings on the soul.

passage_content: ומעתההנה ישראל אשר היו משוקעים במצרים כ"כ בכוחות הטומאה, אין ספק כי ביציאתם ממצרים,נתלוהעמםכחהטומאה הזה, אשר ירשו להם במקום המזוהם ההוא, וא"כ לא די להם הבטחה זו שיצאו ממצרים, כי גם אחר יציאתם משם לא נפטרועי"זמהזוהמאשגרמו לנפשם ע"י ישיבתםביניהם, והנה נודע כי העונותוכחהטומאה הוא כמשא כבידה על האדם,כמשאה"ככיעונותיעברו ראשי כמשא כבד יכבדו ממנו, ומכביד על האדם כל דרכי עבודתוית"ש, ובזה מובןמשאה"כוהוצאתי אתכם מתחת סבלות מצרים, כי לא סגי ביציאתם ממצרים אם עדיין נשאר אצלם משא כובד העונות וארס הטומאה שהכניסו בהם המצרייםבזוהמתםהגדולה, לכן אמר שהוציא אותם מתחת סבלות מצריםכפירש"יז"ל מטורח משא מצרים, ר"ל מהמשא הגדולה שהטילו עליהם המצריםבכחטומאתם, אשר אין לך משא כבידה מזה, וממילא לא סגי ביציאתם ממצרים לחוד, כ"א בהצלתנפשותםמזוהמת וטומאת מצריםלעניניפגם הנפש בהרבה בחינות, וא"כ אין קושי' מה שהוצרך לזה די לשונות של גאולה, לאשר בהם נרמז גאולת הנפש בהרבה בחינות.
translation: And from now on, behold, Israel, who were so deeply immersed in Egypt in the forces of impurity, there is no doubt that upon their departure from Egypt, this force of impurity accompanied them, which they inherited from that defiled place. Therefore, it is not enough for them to have this promise of leaving Egypt, for even after their departure from there, they were not freed from the defilement that had affected their souls due to their dwelling among them. And it is known that sin and the force of impurity are like a heavy burden on a person, as it is written, "The iniquities of my youth and my transgressions, remember not," as a heavy burden weighs upon him, and it burdens a person in all his ways of service to the Holy One, Blessed be He. In this, it is understood what is written, "And I have taken you out from under the burdens of Egypt," for it is not sufficient for them to leave Egypt if the heavy burden of sins and the poison of impurity that the Egyptians instilled in them through their great defilement still remains with them. Therefore, it is said that He took them out from under the burdens of Egypt, as our sages, may their memory be blessed, explained, from the toil of the burden of Egypt, meaning from the great burden that the Egyptians imposed upon them through their impurity, for there is no heavier burden than this. Consequently, it is not enough for them to leave Egypt alone, but rather to save their souls from the defilement and impurity of Egypt, concerning the blemish of the soul in many aspects. Therefore, there is no difficulty in understanding why it was necessary for this to be expressed in many terms of redemption, in which the redemption of the soul is hinted at in many aspects.
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual burden that the Israelites carried even after their physical liberation from Egypt, emphasizing that their time in the land of impurity left them with a lasting taint of sin and spiritual heaviness. It highlights that true redemption involves not only the escape from physical oppression but also the cleansing of the soul from the impurities acquired during their enslavement. The text underscores the necessity of multiple forms of redemption language to convey the comprehensive nature of their liberation, which includes the healing of the soul from the profound effects of Egyptian defilement. Ultimately, it illustrates the Hasidic belief in the interconnectedness of physical and spiritual freedom.

passage_content: והנההובאבספה"קמדרש פליאה הים ראה וינוס מה ראה ישראל באים ורכוש מצרים בידם וכבר פירשתי בכמה אופנים, וכעת נ"ל גם לבאר המדרשבפ' בשלח עה"פ אז ישיר משה,הה"דואני אשירעזךוארנן לבוקר חסדך, ואני אשירעזךאימתי בשעה שעמדו ישראל על היםוכו', וארנן לבוקר חסדך אותו הבוקר של מתן תורה וכו' גם להביןהפ'בפ' שמות והכיתי את מצרים בכלנפלאותי, וגו', ואחרי כן ישלח אתכם וגו' והי' כי תלכון לא תלכו ריקם,וצ"ביתור הלשון והי' כי תלכון כיון שכבר הזכיר ואח"כ ישלח אתכם,הולל"מתיכף ולא תלכו ריקם, גם צריך להבין למה אומר לשון שלילה לא תלכו ריקםהול"לבפי' תלכו מלא, ובאמת הי' כולל אז יותרממ"שלא תלכו ריקם, כיאם יהי' להם אף מעט לא יהי' ריקם עכ"פ, אבל באמת הי' ממולאים הרבה מביזת מצרים, כמבואר בגמ' (בכורות ה' ע"ב) אין לך כאו"א מישראל שלא הי' עמו צ' חמורים וכו' מכספה וזהבה של מצרים.
translation: And behold, in the holy book of Midrash, it is wondrous that the sea saw and fled. What did Israel see? They saw that the Egyptians were coming and that they had the wealth of Egypt in their hands. I have already explained this in several ways, and now it seems to me that I should also elucidate the Midrash in Parashat Beshalach on the verse "Then Moses sang," as it is stated, "And I will sing to You, O Lord, and I will sing in the morning of Your kindness." And I will sing to You, when? At the time when Israel stood by the sea, etc. "And I will sing in the morning of Your kindness," that morning of the giving of the Torah, etc. Also to understand the verse in Parashat Shemot, "And I will strike Egypt with all My wonders," etc., and afterwards He will send you, etc. "And it will be that when you go, you will not go empty." There is a need to clarify the wording "And it will be that when you go," since it has already mentioned "and afterwards He will send you." It should have said immediately "and you will not go empty." Also, it is necessary to understand why it uses the negative expression "you will not go empty," it could have said "you will go full." And indeed, it would have included more than what is stated "you will not go empty," for if they would have even a little, they would not be empty at all. But in truth, they were filled greatly with the spoils of Egypt, as it is explained in the Gemara (Baba Batra 5b) that there was not one of Israel who did not have with him sixty donkeys, etc., from the silver and gold of Egypt.
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous events surrounding the Exodus, emphasizing the significance of Israel's departure from Egypt with great wealth, which symbolizes divine favor and redemption. It highlights the connection between Israel's song at the sea and the future revelation at Mount Sinai, illustrating a continuity of divine grace. The phrase "לא תלכו ריקם" (you shall not go empty) underscores the idea that God's blessings are abundant, ensuring that each Israelite left with substantial riches, reflecting the fulfillment of divine promises. This serves as a reminder of the transformative power of faith and the importance of recognizing God's providence in the journey of the Jewish people.

passage_content: ואפשרלומר עפ"י מה שכתבהגה"קמהרא"למפלאצקזצלה"הבספרו ברכת השיר על הגדה, במה שאמרו חז"ל דבר נא באזני העם, אמר הקב"ה למשה בבקשה ממך הזהירם על כך שלא יאמר אותו צדיק וכו' ואחרי כן יצאו ברכוש גדול לא קיים בהם, וקשה למה הוצרך הזהרה כ"כ על לקיחת הרכוש, דברים שנפשו של אדם מחמדתן, גם קשה הלא איתאבפ' חלק שדנו אנשי מצרים על הרכוש שהוציאו,והיתההתשובה תנו לנו שכר ד' מאות שנהששיעבדו, א"כ מגיע להם הרכושמדינא, ולמה הוצרך לטעם שלא יאמר אותו צדיק, גם הוא פלא גדול למה הוצרך לתחבולה זושיקחוהרכוש בשאלה ולא יחזרו אח"כ, הלא אין מעצור לה' להושיע לתת להם חן בעיני המצריים שיתנו להם בפה מלא וכמו שהוציאם משם ביד חזקה, ופי' הג'זלה"הדודאי כיון שנגזר עליהם ת' שנה, אין להם תביעה על הרכוש בשכר עבודתם, מאחר שלא השלימו זמנם ושכירות אינו משתלמת אלא לבסוף, אלא מחמת שהקב"ה יעד להם נתינת התורה, כמ"ש תעבדון אתאלקיםעל ההר הזה,אתקדשובקדושת הגוף כמאמרינו אשר קדשנו במצותיו, והקדש מפקיע מידי שיעבוד, וממילא אין להם עוד שיעבוד עליהם, וצריך ליתן להם שכר שיעבוד השנים שעברו, אמנם קודם שקיבלוהתוה"קלאנפקעשעבודם עדיין, ואין מגיע להם הרכוש, לכן עצת ה' היא תקוםשיקחובהלואהעד חג השבועות זמן מתן תורה, וכיון שהי' אצלם הרכוש בשאלה בשעת מתן תורה, זכו בי'מדינאכיוןשנפקעהשיעבודוהגיע זמןהפרעון, ולכן בשעת הליכתן ממצרים שלא זכו עדייןבהרכושאלא לקחוהו בשאלה הוצרכו לאזהרה ללקיחת הרכוש, כי הי' בעיניהםטירחאשלא לצורךלישאעל הדרך רכוש שלא להם עיי"ש.
translation:
And it is possible to say according to what the holy Rabbi of Płock, may his merit protect us, wrote in his book Berakhat HaShir on the Haggadah, regarding what our sages said, "Speak now in the ears of the people," that the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses, "Please warn them not to say that righteous one, etc." And afterwards they went out with great wealth, which was not fulfilled in them. It is difficult to understand why such a warning was necessary regarding taking the wealth, things that a person's soul desires. It is also difficult, for the Egyptians had already claimed a portion regarding the wealth they took out, and the response was, "Give us payment for four hundred years of servitude." Therefore, they are entitled to the wealth by law, and why was it necessary to give a reason that the righteous one should not say? It is also a great wonder why it was necessary to use this trick to take the wealth as a loan and not return it afterwards. After all, there is no barrier for the Holy One, blessed be He, to save them and grant them favor in the eyes of the Egyptians so that they would give them freely, just as He took them out from there with a strong hand. 

And the explanation is certainly that since it was decreed upon them for four hundred years, they have no claim to the wealth as payment for their labor, since they did not complete their time, and wages are only paid at the end. However, because the Holy One, blessed be He, destined for them the giving of the Torah, as it is said, "And you shall serve God on this mountain," to sanctify and sanctify the body as we say, "Who has sanctified us with His commandments," and holiness exempts from servitude, and consequently they no longer have servitude over them. They need to be given payment for the years of servitude that have passed. However, before they received the Holy Torah, their servitude had not yet been nullified, and they are not entitled to the wealth. Therefore, the counsel of the Holy One, blessed be He, will stand that they should take it as a loan until the festival of Shavuot, the time of the giving of the Torah. And since the wealth was with them as a loan at the time of the giving of the Torah, they were entitled to it by law, since their servitude was nullified and the time for repayment had arrived. Therefore, at the time of their leaving Egypt, since they had not yet been entitled to the wealth, but only took it as a loan, they needed a warning regarding taking the wealth, for it seemed to them a burden to carry wealth that did not belong to them.
summary: The passage discusses the divine instruction given to Moses to warn the Israelites about taking the Egyptians' possessions, emphasizing that their enslavement had not yet been fully compensated due to the incomplete duration of their servitude. It highlights the theological concept that the giving of the Torah would release them from their bondage, thus necessitating a divine strategy to ensure they would receive their due compensation at the appropriate time. The act of borrowing the possessions before receiving the Torah was essential, as it allowed for the eventual rightful claim to the wealth once their servitude was nullified. This reflects the intricate relationship between divine justice, human actions, and the timing of spiritual redemption.

passage_content: וא"כלפי"זמובן היטב מה שלא אמר הכתוב שילכו מלאים, כי יען שלא להם עדיין הרכוש הזה, לא שייך לומר שהיו מלאים, כי אז לא הי' נקנה להם מזה מאומה, אמנם יען כי הי' אצלם עכ"פ בשאלה, להנות מהרכוש הזהלאח"זלא הי' ריקנים עכ"פ, אבל זו הי' רק בשעת הליכה ע"כ אמר לא תלכו ריקם, שבשעת הליכה א"א באופן אחר אלא שלא הי'ריקניןעכ"פ, אבל לבסוף ישתלשל מזה שהיו מלאים ממש.
translation: "And regarding this, it is well understood why the scripture did not say that they should go full, for since they did not yet possess this wealth, it is not appropriate to say that they were full, as then they would not have acquired anything from it. However, since it was at least in question for them, to benefit from this wealth later, they were not empty at least. But this was only at the time of walking; therefore, it said, 'Do not go empty,' for at the time of walking, it is impossible otherwise than that they were not empty at least. But ultimately, it will result in them being truly full."
summary: The passage emphasizes that the Israelites were not yet in possession of the wealth they sought, hence they could not be described as "full" in a literal sense. However, during their journey, they were not empty either, as they had a potential claim to the riches that would come later. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of spiritual readiness and anticipation, suggesting that even in a state of waiting, one can possess a form of fulfillment. Ultimately, this journey leads to a true state of abundance, illustrating the transformative power of faith and expectation.
