passage_content: והנהנודע דברי חז"ל ששר של ים טען מה בין אלו לאלו הללועע"זוהללועע"ז, ונודע כי גם בעת שהיו עוברים בים סוף עבר עמהם ערב רב ופסל מיכה כמאמר חז"לעה"ככי עבר בים צרה, אמנם טענה זו מה בין אלו לאלו לא הי' לו מקום רק עדקבלתהתוה"ק, כי בשעת קבלת התורה פסקהזוהמתםונתקדשובקדושת הגוף, וגם אם חוטאים אח"כ יש להם תקוה ע"יהתוה"קבהקרבתהקרבןוהתשובה,דזהוההבדל בין ישראללאוה"עשמועלת לנו התשובה ע"יהתוה"קכנודעבספה"ק, וא"כ אין מקום לטענת הים מה בין אלו לאלו. כי ישראל המה עתידים לקבלהתוה"ק, ולא עשה כן לכל גוי, והנה מאין הי' הדין זהשבודאיישראל יקבלוהתוה"ק, וזה מובן מרכוש מצרים אשר בידם, וקשה מאוד למה עשה ה' ככה להזהירם על כך,ליקחהרכוש שאינו מגיע להם, ולהטריחם בטורח משא הדרך בדבר שאינו שלהם, לולא שיקבלוהתוה"קאח"כ, ויתקדשו קדושת הגוף ויגיע להם הרכושמדינא, לזה הוצרכו להטריח שיהי' בידם שיזכו בו אח"כ, ובזה מובן היטב דברי המדרש מה ראהראהישראל באים ורכוש מצרים בידם, שמזה מוכרחשבודאייקבלוהתוה"קאח"כ,ונתבטלהטענתו מה בין אלו לאלו.
translation: And behold, it is known from the words of our Sages that the minister of the sea claimed, "What is the difference between these and those?" And it is known that even at the time they were crossing the Sea of Reeds, a mixed multitude accompanied them, and the idol of Micah was with them, as our Sages have said, "When they crossed the sea, there was trouble." However, this claim of "What is the difference between these and those?" had no place except until the giving of the Torah, for at the time of the giving of the Torah, their impurity ceased and they were sanctified with the sanctity of the body. And even if they sin afterwards, they have hope through the Torah by bringing a sacrifice and through repentance, for this is the difference between Israel and the other nations: repentance is effective for us through the Torah, as is known in the holy books. Therefore, there is no place for the claim of the sea, "What is the difference between these and those?" For Israel is destined to receive the Torah, and He did not do so for any other nation. And behold, from where did this judgment arise that Israel would receive the Torah? This is understood from the wealth of Egypt that was in their hands, and it is very difficult to understand why the Holy One, blessed be He, did this to warn them about this, to take wealth that does not belong to them, and to burden them with the toil of the journey regarding something that is not theirs, unless it is that they would receive the Torah afterwards, and they would be sanctified with the sanctity of the body, and the wealth would rightfully belong to them. For this reason, they needed to be burdened so that it would be in their hands to merit it afterwards. And thus, the words of the Midrash are well understood: what did Israel see that they were coming with the wealth of Egypt in their hands? From this, it is evident that they would receive the Torah afterwards, and his claim of "What is the difference between these and those?" was nullified.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between the Jewish people and the mixed multitude (Erev Rav) during the crossing of the Red Sea, emphasizing that the latter's claim of equality was invalidated at the time of receiving the Torah. It highlights that the acceptance of the Torah sanctified the Jewish people, granting them hope for repentance even after sinning, unlike the Erev Rav. The text also reflects on the significance of the wealth acquired from Egypt, suggesting that it was intended for the Israelites to receive as a reward for their future acceptance of the Torah, thus reinforcing their unique covenant with God. Ultimately, this illustrates the theological concept that the Jewish people are destined for a special relationship with the Divine, marked by the gift of the Torah.

passage_content: ומובןגם דברי המדרש, ואני אשירעוזיךבשעה שעמדו ישראל על הים וארנן לבוקר חסדך זה בוקרו של מתן תורה, כי אלו השנים שייכו להדדי, שע"י של בוקרו שלמ"ת, נעשה עוזו של יםשנתבטלהטענתו, ומעתה מובן היטב מה שמביא רש"יעה"כוהוצאתי אתכם וכו' כאשר הבטחתי ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול, שכבר ביארתי שההוצאה מתחת סבלות מצרים, מורה על טורח משא וכובדהזוהמאשלהם, והנה נודע כי לא נפטרו לגמרימזוהמתןשל מצרים עד שעתמ"ת, שאזנתקדשובקדושת הגוף ממש,ונטהרומטומאתן הראשונה, ולזה הביא ראי' לכאן מהכתובדאח"כיצאו ברכוש גדול,דלקיחתהרכוש א"א כי אם ע"י קבלתהתוה"קשנתקדשובקדושת הגוף, וזה הצלתם מטורח משאזוהמתןשל מצרים.
translation: And the words of the Midrash are also understood, and I will sing of Your strength at the time when Israel stood by the sea and sang to the morning of Your kindness; this is the morning of the giving of the Torah, for these two are connected to each other. Through the morning of the giving of the Torah, the strength of the sea was nullified. And now it is well understood what Rashi brings, "And I took you out, etc. as I promised," and afterwards they went out with great wealth, for I have already explained that the exodus from under the burdens of Egypt indicates the toil of their heavy yoke. And behold, it is known that they were not completely freed from the burden of Egypt until the time of the giving of the Torah, at which point they were sanctified with the sanctity of the body itself, and they were purified from their first impurity. And for this, he brought a proof here from the verse, "And afterwards they went out with great wealth," for the taking of the wealth could only be through the acceptance of the Torah, which sanctified them with the sanctity of the body, and this is their salvation from the toil of the burden of Egypt.
summary: The passage discusses the connection between the Israelites' redemption from Egypt and the giving of the Torah at Mount Sinai, emphasizing that the morning of the Torah's giving represents a profound spiritual awakening. It highlights that the liberation from the burdens of Egypt was not complete until the moment of receiving the Torah, which sanctified both the people and their physical existence. The text underscores that true freedom and the acquisition of spiritual wealth are intrinsically linked to the acceptance of the Torah, marking a transformative moment in the relationship between the Divine and the Jewish people.

passage_content: לכןאמורלבנ"יאני ד' והוצאתי אתכם מתחת סבלות מצרים וגו'פרש"יכי כן הבטחתיו ואחרי כן יצאו ברכוש גדול,וק"זהייטב לבזלה"הדקדק מדוע הביא רש"י סיפאדקראברכוש גדול עיי"ש תירוצו ועודלאלקימילין.
translation: Therefore, say to the children of Israel, "I am the Lord, and I have taken you out from under the burdens of Egypt," etc. Rashi explains that this is indeed what He promised them, and afterwards they left with great wealth. And it is good to ponder why Rashi brought the end of the verse regarding "great wealth," as you can see there his explanation, and also not to overlook the words of G-d.
summary: The passage emphasizes God's promise to liberate the Israelites from the burdens of Egypt, highlighting the divine assurance of their eventual redemption and prosperity. It reflects the Hasidic belief in the importance of faith in God's promises, as well as the idea that spiritual and material blessings are intertwined. The mention of "great wealth" upon their departure signifies not only physical abundance but also the spiritual elevation that comes from divine intervention. This underscores the theological insight that true liberation encompasses both the body and the soul, affirming God's active role in the lives of His people.

passage_content: ונל"פבהקדם דברי ק"זהיש"מזלה"ה(בפ' בא) דיש להביןמ"שלאאע"הכי גר יהי' זרעך וגו' ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול מה החשיבות של הרכוש גדול בעיני אברהם, ומה לו בבצע כסף, ותוכן תירוצו,דזהלהורות שלאיטמעובאומות ויהיונחשביןע"ש אבותיהם, שלא יחשוש אברהםדאלושיצאו יהיו אחרים ולא בניו,דידועדזההי' שכר העבודה,דאל"כהאיךיצוההקב"ה לגזול, ואם נטמעו א"כ אין לו ליטול שכר בשביל אביווכו',דמבוארבריש בכורות שאין לך א' מישראל שאין לו תשעים חמורים טעונים מכספם וזהבם של מצרים,ובודאישכר עבודתו של כל א' לבד לא יעלה להון רב כזה, אם לא בהצטרף שכר עבודת אבותיו ג"כ, והיינו דבר נא וישאלו וגו',הכללהורותזה לבני העולם שהם מתייחסים אחר אבותיהם ולא נטמעו ח"ו, וזהו כדי שלא יאמר אותו צדיק ועבדום ועינו אותם קיים בהם, היינו בזרעו שנא' כי גר יהי' זרעך ואח"כ יצאו וגו' לא קיים בהםדאלואינם זרעווכו', וע"כ ביקש מהם שישאלו וגו' ואז ידע אותו צדיק שגם אלו הם זרעו,עייש"דבאריכות.
translation: And it is explained in the beginning of the words of K"Z that one should understand what is meant by "your seed will be a stranger" (in Parashat Bo) and afterwards they will go out with great wealth. What is the significance of the great wealth in the eyes of Abraham, and what does he have to do with silver? The content of your explanation is that this is to teach that they will be assimilated among the nations and will be considered according to their ancestors, so that Abraham should not be concerned that those who go out will be others and not his children. For this was the reward for the work, as it is not possible for the Holy One, Blessed be He, to command to steal, and if they are assimilated, then he has no right to take reward for his father, etc. It is explained in the beginning of Bekhorot that there is no one from Israel who does not have ninety donkeys loaded with the silver and gold of Egypt, and certainly the reward for the work of each one alone would not amount to such great wealth, unless it is combined with the reward for the work of his ancestors as well. And this is the meaning of "they will ask" etc., all to teach this to the children of the world that they are related to their ancestors and have not been assimilated, Heaven forbid. And this is so that that righteous one should not say "and they will enslave them and oppress them" is fulfilled in them, meaning in his seed, as it is said "for your seed will be a stranger" and afterwards they will go out, etc., it is not fulfilled in them because they are not his seed, etc. Therefore, he asked them to "ask" etc., and then that righteous one will know that these too are his seed, as explained at length.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Abraham's concern for his descendants' identity and their eventual wealth when they leave Egypt. It emphasizes that despite their potential assimilation among the nations, Abraham's lineage will remain distinct and connected to their ancestors, ensuring they are recognized as his true descendants. The wealth they acquire is seen as a reward for the labor of both themselves and their forefathers, reinforcing the idea that their identity and merit are intertwined with their heritage. Ultimately, this serves to affirm the continuity of the Jewish people's connection to their patriarchs, even in the face of potential assimilation.

passage_content: והנהדרשו רז"ל במדרש (הובא ברש"י ז"ל פ' פנחס) עה"פ משפחת החנכי לפי שהיו האומותמבזיןאותם ואומרים מה אלומתייחסיןעל שבטיהם, סבורים הם שלא שלטו המצריים באמותיהם, אם בגופם היו מושלים ק"ו בנשותיהם, לפיכך הטיל הקב"ה שמו עליהם ה"א מצד זה ויו"ד מצד זה, לומר מעיד אני עליהם שהם בני אבותיהם וזה הוא שמפורש ע"י דוד (תהלים קכ"ב) שבטי יה עדות לישראל, השם הזה מעיד עליהם לשבטיהם עכ"ל, ובזה יתבארו דברירשיז"לוקישור הכתובשא"להקב"הלמשרע"הואראאל האבות, ר"לדהבטחתילהםבבחי' אבות, שיתקיים הבטחתי בזרעם הנחשבים ע"ש אבותיהם ולאיטמעובאומות, ושמי ד' לא נודעתי להם, ר"ל שםי"ההמעיד על ישראל כי עדיין לא נודע להם עדות זה, א"כ עדיין בצער זה שרויים שלאיטמעוזרעם באומות ח"ו, לכן אמור לבני ישראל אני ד', ששמי מעיד עליהם שלא נטמעו והוצאתי אתכם מתחת סבלות מצרים שכן הבטחתיו ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול, שגם הרכוש יהי' עדות שלא נטמעוובנ"יעאלוובנ"ינפקו כנ"ל.
translation: And the sages have expounded in the Midrash (brought by Rashi, of blessed memory, in Parashat Pinchas) on the verse "the family of the Hanchani," because the nations were belittling them and saying, "What does this family have to do with their tribes?" They thought that the Egyptians did not rule over their mothers; if they ruled over their bodies, certainly over their wives. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, placed His Name upon them, the letter "He" from this side and the letter "Yud" from that side, to testify that they are the children of their forefathers. This is what is explicitly stated by David (Psalms 122) "the tribes of Yehudah are a testimony for Israel." This Name testifies for them regarding their tribes. Thus, the words of Rashi, of blessed memory, will be clarified in connection with the verse that the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moshe, "I am the God of the forefathers," meaning to assure them in the merit of the forefathers, that My promise will be fulfilled in their offspring, who are considered in the name of their forefathers and not to be assimilated among the nations. And My Name, the Lord, was not made known to them, meaning that My Name, which testifies for Israel, was still not known to them as a testimony. Therefore, they are still in this sorrow, that they should not be assimilated among the nations, Heaven forbid. Thus, say to the children of Israel, "I am the Lord," that My Name testifies for them that they have not been assimilated, and I have taken you out from under the burdens of Egypt, as I promised, and afterwards they will go out with great wealth, which will also be a testimony that they have not been assimilated, and they will rise and they will be redeemed as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the divine assurance given to the Jewish people regarding their identity and connection to their ancestors, despite the scorn of other nations. It emphasizes that God's name serves as a testimony to their lineage and distinctiveness, ensuring that they will not be assimilated among the nations. The reference to the promise made to the patriarchs highlights the continuity of this covenant through their descendants, culminating in their liberation from Egypt and the acquisition of wealth as a sign of their enduring identity. Ultimately, it reassures the Israelites of their unique status and God's commitment to their survival as a distinct people.

passage_content: במסורהלכן אמור לבני ישראל אני ה', לכן אמור הנני נותן לו את בריתי שלום, פי'החיד"אז"ל בס' חומת אנךוזל"ק: אפשר לפרש כמ"ש רז"לדבזכותשהיו גדורים בעריות יצאו ממצרים, וזה רמז לכן אמור לבני ישראל אני ה' והוצאתי אתכם. והטעם בזכות שתשמרו אות ברית קודש על דרך שזכה פנחס לכל המעלות' לפי שקנא על ברית,כמש"הלכן אמור הנני נותן לו את בריתי שלום,מכחשקנא על ברית זכה לברית שלום, כן ישראל יצאו בזכות ששמרו את בריתי, ששמרו וגדרו עצמם מעריות, לכן אמור לבני ישראל שכולם בני ישראל ולא נמצא בם פסול בני ישראלעאלוובני ישראל נפקו אני ה' והוצאתי אתכםעכל"ק, ובדרכו אלך גם אני לבאר הפסוק הסמוכה אליווהיתהלו ולזרעו אחריו ברית כהונת עולם וגו',עפי"דהתרגום יונתן בן עוזיאלבשבועאאימרלי' מן שמיהאנאגזר לי'יתקימישלםואעבדיני' מלאך קיים ויחי לעלמאלמבשראגאולתאבסוףיומיאומכווןלמ"שחז"ל פנחס זה אלי', ומשום שקנא קנאת ה' במסירת נפש על קדושת הברית לכן זה שכרו שיבא לבשר הגאולה באחרית הימים, ויתבאר עפ"י דבריהחיד"אז"ל הנ"ל שגאולת מצרים הי' בזכות שמירת הברית. אמנם מה יהי' הזכות בדורות האחרוניםבעיקבאדמשיחאשגבר הצרהיצה"רלהיצרלישראל ולהכשילם ח"ו בפגם הברית, וגדלה הפריצותבמדהנוראה ומבהילה, ואף האנשים השלמים והיראים נכשלים בהרהורים רעים ומחשבות זרות, ואמרו חז"ל ונשמרת מכל דבר רע שלא יהרהר אדם ביוםוכו', ופשוטי עם נתקלים יותרבעוה"ר, ולמותר להאריך כמה יגיעות צריך ליגע ולעמול שלאלהכשל, ובאיזה זכות נזכה לגאולה, אלא שאלי' הנביא יזריח רוח טהרה וקדושה בלבבות בני ישראל ויעשה משמרת לגדר עריות ושמירת הברית, וזה שאמרתיב"עויחי לעלמאלמבשראגאולתאבסוףיומיא,וקאיעל פסוק הקודם הנני נותן לו את בריתי שלום שהוא שכרו בשביל שקינא על הברית ובזההכחיוושעובני ישראל ובזכותו תהי' הגאולה העתידה באחרית הימים.
translation: In the tradition, therefore say to the children of Israel, I am the Lord, therefore say, behold, I am giving him My covenant of peace. The Chida said in the book Chomat Anach: It is possible to interpret as our sages have said, that due to the merit of being guarded from immorality, they left Egypt. This is hinted at in the phrase, therefore say to the children of Israel, I am the Lord, and I have taken you out. The reason is in the merit that you will guard the sign of the holy covenant, in the way that Pinchas merited all the virtues, for he was zealous for the covenant, as it is written, therefore say, behold, I am giving him My covenant of peace. Because he was zealous for the covenant, he merited the covenant of peace; so too, Israel left in the merit that they guarded My covenant, that they guarded and fenced themselves from immorality. Therefore say to the children of Israel that they are all children of Israel and there is no disqualification among them. The children of Israel went out, I am the Lord, and I have taken you out. And in His way, I will also explain the adjacent verse, and it shall be to him and to his seed after him a covenant of priesthood forever, etc. According to the translation of Jonathan ben Uziel, in the week, I will say from Heaven, the decree will be established, and a lasting angel will be sent, and he will announce the redemption at the end of days. This is directed to what our sages have said, Pinchas is Eliyahu. And because he was zealous for the zeal of the Lord, risking his life for the sanctity of the covenant, therefore his reward is that he will come to announce the redemption in the end of days. It will be explained according to the words of the Chida mentioned above that the redemption from Egypt was in the merit of guarding the covenant. However, what will be the merit in the last generations, in the footsteps of the Messiah, when the distress will increase, the evil inclination will rise to ensnare Israel and to cause them to stumble, Heaven forbid, in the blemish of the covenant, and the immorality will grow to a terrible and frightening degree. Even the righteous and God-fearing people stumble in bad thoughts and foreign thoughts. And our sages said, and you shall guard yourself from any bad thing, that a person should not think during the day, etc. The simple folk stumble more in bad thoughts, and it is unnecessary to elaborate on how much effort one must exert and toil to avoid these failures, and by what merit will we merit redemption. Rather, the prophet will shine a spirit of purity and holiness in the hearts of the children of Israel and will create a guard for the fence of immorality and the guarding of the covenant. This is what is said, and he will announce the redemption at the end of days, and it connects to the previous verse, behold, I am giving him My covenant of peace, which is his reward for being zealous for the covenant, and through this, the children of Israel and in his merit, the future redemption will be in the end of days.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of maintaining the sanctity of the covenant, particularly in relation to sexual morality, as a key factor in the redemption of the Jewish people. It highlights that the Israelites' adherence to this covenant was instrumental in their liberation from Egypt, paralleling the zeal of Pinchas, who was rewarded for his commitment to the covenant. In the context of contemporary challenges, it calls for a divine infusion of purity and holiness to help the Jewish people uphold these values amidst increasing moral decay. Ultimately, it asserts that the future redemption will be achieved through the merit of those who guard the covenant.

passage_content: ולקחתיאתכם לו לעם וידעתם כי אני ה'אלקיכםהמוציא אתכם וגו' והבאתי אתכם אל הארץ וגו' ונתתי אותה לכם מורשה אני ה',יל"דעל אומרו מורשה ולא לשון ירושה, ומשמעות מורשה שיהיו מורישים לאחרים, עיין בגמ' (ב"ב קי"ט ע"ב) וע' פנים לתורה, גם צ"ב אומרו אני ה' שתי פעמים ודרשו רז"ל נאמן לשלם שכר, ונאמן בהבטחתי ומדוע הכפילעוה"פ.
translation: "And I took you to be My people, and you shall know that I am the Lord your God who brought you out, etc., and I brought you to the land, etc., and I gave it to you as a heritage; I am the Lord." The term "heritage" is used instead of "inheritance," and the meaning of "heritage" is that you shall pass it on to others. See in the Gemara (Baba Batra 119b) and also in the "Faces of the Torah." It is also to be understood why it says "I am the Lord" twice, and our Sages interpreted that He is faithful to pay the reward and faithful in His promise, and why it is repeated twice.
summary: The passage emphasizes the concept of "morasha" (heritage) rather than "yerusha" (inheritance), indicating that the land is meant to be passed down to future generations, reflecting a communal responsibility. The repetition of "I am the Lord" underscores God's faithfulness in fulfilling promises and rewarding those who adhere to His commandments. This dual emphasis serves to reinforce the covenantal relationship between God and the Jewish people, highlighting both divine assurance and the obligation to transmit spiritual values.

passage_content: ב)כי אני ה' המוציא וגו', בגמ' ברכות (ל"ח ע"א) ורבנן הכיקאמרלהוקוב"הלישראל, כדאפיקנאלכועבידנאלכו מילתא כי היכידידעיתו,דאנאהואדאפיקתיתכון ממצריםדכתיבוידעתם כי אני ה'אלקיכםהמוציא, ראוי להבין מה הוא הדבר אשר על ידויתודעלישראל כי השי"ת הוציא אותם ממצרים, ורז"ל סתמו דבריהם ולא ביארו מהו, גם היכן רמיזא בכתוב.
translation: B) For I am the Lord who brings you out, etc. In the Gemara Berakhot (38a), the Rabbis say that it is said to the Jewish people, as it is written, "And you shall know that I am the Lord your God who brought you out of Egypt," it is fitting to understand what is the matter by which the Jewish people will know that the Holy One, Blessed be He, took them out of Egypt. And our Sages have left their words sealed and did not explain what it is, nor where it is hinted at in the text.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the divine revelation of God as the one who took the Israelites out of Egypt, emphasizing the importance of knowledge and awareness of this act. It highlights that understanding this liberation is essential for the Jewish people, as it forms the foundation of their relationship with God. The text notes that the sages left this concept somewhat ambiguous, prompting deeper reflection on the nature of divine intervention and the recognition of God's presence in their history. Ultimately, it underscores the theological insight that true knowledge of God is intertwined with the experience of redemption.

passage_content: ואפ"לעפי"משפי'בספה"קאגראדכלהבפ' שופטיםוזלה"ק, כיהגויםהאלה אשר אתה יורש אותם אל מעוננים וכו' ישמעו ואתה לא כן נתן ה'אלקיך. והנראה להבין הדבר עפ"י קבלתינו מרבותינוכחהפועל בנפעל, ממילא ממונו ורכושו של אדם שהאדם מסגלו ע"י מעשיו, הנה יש בממון ורכוש ההואכחהפועל, ע"כ נאסר לנו לפרוט מתיבתהמוכסיןכיון שכח הפועל ישבהממוןההוא, והאדם הכשריקחנולעצמו הנה יגרום לנפשו פעולות זרות כפיכחהפועלהנפשיימבעלים הראשוניםוכו', והנהבכאןהשי"ת נתן לישראל את כל טוב ארצותהגויםהאלה ממונםורכושם המה יירשום, הנה יש לחוש כיכחהפועל בנפעל ובכל הרכוש האלה טמון מדות רעות שלהגוים, הנה כאשריהנוישראל ממנו יש לחוש שיקנו קנין בנפשם לעשות כמעשיהם, אבל לא כן הוא כי ישראל יירשום ירושה ונתונה מאת השי"ת,והשי"תהוא הבעלים של הרכוש, וזה שהתחיל כי אתה בא אל הארץ אשר ה'אלקיךנותן לך. ואין זה בהשתדלותךליקחמיד הרשעים האלה רק השי"ת נותן לך, ע"כ אני מבטיחךשעי"זלא תלמד לעשות כתועבותהגויםההםעכל"קבקיצור.
translation: And I will explain according to our tradition from our teachers, regarding the action in the passive, that a person's wealth and possessions are acquired through his deeds. Therefore, in that wealth and possessions, there is the action in the passive. Thus, it is forbidden for us to take from the toll collectors, since the power of the action resides in that wealth. And a righteous person who takes for himself will cause his soul to perform foreign actions, as the action of the soul is influenced by the original owners, etc. Here, the Holy One, blessed be He, has given Israel all the good of the lands of these nations; their wealth and possessions they will inherit. One must be cautious that in the action in the passive and in all that wealth, there are hidden bad traits of the nations. Therefore, when Israel benefits from it, one must be concerned that they will acquire a possession in their souls to act like their deeds. But it is not so, for Israel will inherit an inheritance given by the Holy One, blessed be He, and the Holy One is the owner of that wealth. This is what it begins with: "For you are coming to the land which the Lord your God is giving you." And this is not through your efforts to take from these wicked ones, but the Holy One, blessed be He, is giving it to you. Therefore, I assure you that through this, you will not learn to do according to the abominations of those nations, etc. in brief.
summary: The passage emphasizes the distinction between the inheritance of the Israelites and that of the nations, highlighting that while the nations' wealth is tainted by their negative traits, the Israelites' inheritance is a divine gift from God. This divine bestowal ensures that the Israelites will not adopt the corrupt practices of the nations, as their wealth is rooted in a higher spiritual source. The text underscores the concept of "keichah hapoel benifal," suggesting that one's actions can influence their spiritual state, but in this case, the divine origin of the inheritance protects the Israelites from moral degradation. Ultimately, it reassures that God's providence safeguards the spiritual integrity of His people.

passage_content: ועפי"זביארתיבמאמה"ככי תצא למלחמה על אויביך ונתנו ה'אלקיךבידך וגו',דאוליתחשוש למנוע לבוז בז ולשלול שלל למען לא יוליד בך הממון הבא מידי רשעים תכונה רעה, לזה אמר ונתנו ה'אלקיךבידךדייקאדע כי מתת ה' הוא, ע"כ ושבית שביו ואין לךליפחדשיגרום לך ירידה רוחניות, אדרבה על כי השי"ת הוא הנותן,יפעולכחהפועל שבו להמשיך לך מדות טובות, ולהביאך לידי קיום מצותומע"ט, כנודע שתכלית ביאתם לא"י הי' כדי לקיים מצות התליות בארץ, ודיןגרמאתוספות זהירות ופרישות ולא יוסיף עצב עמה.
translation: And according to this, I will explain the verse, "When you go out to battle against your enemies and the Lord your God delivers them into your hand," etc. One might be concerned about preventing the disgrace of plunder and the taking of spoils, so that wealth coming from the hands of the wicked does not engender a negative trait within you. Therefore, it says, "and the Lord your God delivers them into your hand," specifically to indicate that it is a gift from God. Thus, you will take captives, and you should not renew any thoughts that would cause you a spiritual decline. On the contrary, since the Holy One, Blessed be He, is the giver, He will cause you to continue in good traits and bring you to fulfill the commandments and good deeds, as it is known that the ultimate purpose of their coming to the Land of Israel was to fulfill the commandments that are dependent on the land. And the law requires additional caution and separation, and it will not add sorrow to it.
summary: The passage emphasizes that when engaging in battle against enemies, one must recognize that victory is a divine gift from God, as indicated by the phrase "וּנְתָנוּ ה' אֱלֹקיךָ בְּיָדֶךָ." It warns against the negative spiritual consequences of acquiring wealth from the wicked, suggesting that such gains can lead to moral decline. Instead, the focus should be on the divine assistance that enables the fulfillment of commandments and the cultivation of positive traits. Ultimately, the goal of entering the Land of Israel is to observe the commandments tied to the land, which requires heightened vigilance and spiritual purity.

passage_content: וזהאומרו ולקחתי אתכם לי לעם וגו' וידעתם כי אני ה'אלקיכםהמוציא אתכם מארץ מצרים והבאתי אתכם אל הארץ וגו' שתדעו ותשכילו שלאבכחהשתדלותיכםזכיתם לירושת הארץ, והראי' ע"ז ונתתי אותה לכם מורשה אני ה' היינו שביאתכם לארץ יוריש אתכם מדות טובות וידיעת ה' אשר מזה תשכילו ותבחינו כי מתת השי"ת הוא, וזה כוונתחכז"לעבידנאלכו מילתא כי היכידידעותודאנאהואדאפיקתיתכון ממצרים, והכוונה גם על נתינת א"י להם, כי כאשר יראו שזאת לא גרם להם להרע מעשיהם, ואדרבה יהי' סיבה להיטיב מעשיהם, מזה יוכלו לשפוט בצדק כי לא ע"י השתדלותם ירשו את הארץ, דאז הי'כחהפועל שבו מוליד בהם מדות רעות ומגונות, רק מתת השי"ת הוא וע"י יוסיף קדושה על קדושתכם.
translation: And this is what it means when it says, "And I took you to be My people..." and "You shall know that I am the Lord your God who brought you out of the land of Egypt and brought you to the land..." so that you should know and understand that it is not through your efforts that you have merited the inheritance of the land. The proof of this is, "And I gave it to you as a heritage, I am the Lord," meaning that your coming to the land will endow you with good traits and knowledge of the Lord, from which you will understand and discern that it is a gift from the Holy One, Blessed be He. This is the intention of the phrase "to serve Me," for in order that you should know and understand that it is He who took you out of Egypt. The intention also pertains to the giving of the Land of Israel to them, for when they see that this does not cause them to worsen their deeds, but rather will be a reason to improve their actions, from this they will be able to judge justly that it is not through their efforts that they inherited the land, for then the power of action would generate within them bad and disgraceful traits, but rather it is a gift from the Holy One, Blessed be He, and through this He will add holiness to your holiness.
summary: The passage emphasizes that the Israelites' inheritance of the land is not a result of their own efforts but a divine gift from God, highlighting the importance of recognizing God's role in their achievements. It teaches that true understanding and spiritual growth come from acknowledging this divine providence, which should inspire them to improve their character and actions. The text suggests that the experience of receiving the land should lead to greater holiness and moral refinement, reinforcing the idea that their relationship with God is central to their identity as a people. Ultimately, it underscores the concept that spiritual elevation and ethical behavior stem from recognizing and appreciating God's benevolence.

passage_content: עודירמוז הכתוב כי ע"י ביאתם לא"י ניתוסף להם הרבה מצות התלויים בארץ ולא הי' בידם לקיימם עד הנה, וזהו ונתתי אותה לכם מורשה, כי נתינת א"י יהי' מוריש לכם הרבה מצות ומעשים טובים, ולכך חזר ואמר אני ה' פי' נאמן לשלם שכר טוב למתהלכים לפני ע"דשפירש"ילעיל בריש הפרשה, ועל כי הובטחו שיתוסף להם מצות בביאת הארץ, לכן הובטחועוה"פגם עלתוס' שכר והבן.
translation: The text hints that through their coming to the Land of Israel, many commandments dependent on the land were added to them, which they had not been able to fulfill until now. This is the meaning of "and I gave it to you as an inheritance," for the giving of the Land of Israel will bequeath to you many commandments and good deeds. Therefore, it is repeated, "I am the Lord," meaning that He is faithful to pay good reward to those who walk before Him, as explained above at the beginning of the section. And because they were promised that commandments would be added to them upon entering the land, they were also assured that there would be an increase in reward, and understand this.
summary: The passage emphasizes that the entry into the Land of Israel brings with it an increase in commandments that are tied to the land, which were previously unattainable. This is reflected in the phrase "ונתתי אותה לכם מורשה," indicating that the gift of the land is a legacy that enables the fulfillment of many mitzvot and good deeds. Additionally, it reassures that God is faithful to reward those who walk in His ways, highlighting the connection between the land, the commandments, and divine reward. The promise of additional commandments upon entering the land underscores the spiritual significance of Israel in Jewish life and practice.

passage_content: פתיחהמשה לפני ה'לאמרהןבנ"ילא שמעו אלי ואיך ישמעני פרעה וגו'פירש"יזה א' מעשרה ק"ו שבתורה (ב"ר), הקשו המפורשיםדק"ופריכאהוא, דמהשבנ"ילא שמעו אליו מפורש הטעם בפסוק מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה, וטעם זה לא שייך לפרעה.
translation: Opening: Moses before the Lord said, "Behold, the children of Israel have not listened to me; how then shall Pharaoh listen to me?" (Exodus 6:12). This is one of the ten logical deductions in the Torah (B'reishit Rabbah). The commentators have posed a question: "But what is the reasoning here?" For it is explicitly stated that the children of Israel did not listen to him due to shortness of spirit and hard work, and this reason does not apply to Pharaoh.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the challenge Moses faced in conveying God's message to Pharaoh, emphasizing that the Israelites' inability to listen was due to their suffering and oppression, which does not apply to Pharaoh. This highlights a key Hasidic concept of divine communication, where the state of the soul and external circumstances profoundly affect one's receptivity to spiritual truths. The text underscores the importance of understanding the context of suffering in relation to divine will and the human experience, illustrating the complexities of faith amidst hardship.

passage_content: ב)ה' אל משה ואל אהרן ויצום אל בני ישראל ואל פרעה מלך מצרים וגו',וצ"בדלא נתבאר ענין הציווי מה הוא, (ועייןפירש"י) גם איך יהי' בזה תשובהלמ"שמשרע"ההןבנ"ילא שמעו אלי ואיך ישמעני פרעה.
translation: And the Lord spoke to Moses and to Aaron and commanded them to the children of Israel and to Pharaoh, king of Egypt, etc. And it is not explained what the matter of the command is, (and see Rashi's commentary) also how there will be a response to what Moshe said, "Behold, the children of Israel have not listened to me, and how will Pharaoh listen to me?"
summary: הפסוק מתאר את הציווי של ה' למשה ואהרן להעביר מסר לבני ישראל ולפרעה, אך לא מפרט את מהות הציווי. יש כאן עיסוק בשאלה כיצד ייתכן שהעם לא שמע את דברי משה, וכיצד יוכל פרעה לשמוע אותם. התובנה המרכזית היא שהקב"ה מצפה מהנביאים לפעול למרות הקשיים והספקות, והאמונה בכוחו של ה' לשנות מציאות היא יסוד חשוב בהבנת תהליך הגאולה.

passage_content: והנ"לדהנהמנהג ישראל כשאומרים דברי מוסר ותוכחה לעם, מפרשים איזה פסוק בתוה"ק ומלבישים בזה דברי מוסר הראויים לאומרם לפי מקומן ושעתן,וק"זהייטב לבזלה"הכתבבפ' דברים רמז נאה ע"ז, אלה הדברים אשר דבר משה וגו' הואיל משה באר את התורה הזאת עיי"ש, ולכאורה טעמא בעי מה צורך להלבישן בביאור המקראות, ולא סגי שיאמר המוכיח תוכחותיו בפירוש,ואפ"לעפימ"שהה"קבעל נועם אלימלךזלה"הבתפלה אשר תיקן, שנראה כ"א מעלת חברינו ולא חסרונם, והמידה הזאת מצוי באיש אשר השליםא"עביר"ש ומדות טובות, וכמו שפירשו מאמר חז"ל כל הנגעים אדם רואה חוץ מנגעי עצמו, דמה שרואה האדם נגעי חוץ באחרים זולתו, הסיבה הוא מנגעי עצמו שלא נשלם עדיין במידה זו, כי אם הוא בתכלית השלימות, אינו רואה חסרונות אחרים, והנה ידוע מאמר חז"ל דברים היוצאים מן הלב נכנסים ללב, דייקו לומר יוצאים מן הלב בה' הידוע, הכוונה על לב מלא חכמה ויר"ש, כי רק דברי מוסר היוצאים מלב כזה, יש להםכחלעורר לב השומע, ולעומת זה צריך ג"כ שהמקבל יהי' לו לב טהור וכלי מוכשר לקבל הדיבורים.
translation: And behold, the custom of Israel when saying words of moral instruction and rebuke to the people, is to interpret some verse from the Holy Torah and to clothe in it words of moral instruction that are appropriate to be said according to their place and time. And this is hinted at in the verse in Parshat Devarim, "These are the words which Moshe spoke," since Moshe explained this Torah, as it is written there. And at first glance, one might ask what is the need to clothe them in the explanation of the verses, and it would suffice for the rebuker to state his rebukes explicitly. And even according to what is stated by the holy Baal Noam Elimelech, that in the prayer he established, it appears as if he is highlighting the virtues of our friends and not their shortcomings. And this quality is found in a person who has completed his character traits, as it is explained by our Sages, that a person sees the blemishes of others except for his own. The reason is that what a person sees as external blemishes in others, is due to his own blemishes that he has not yet rectified in this quality, for if he is at the pinnacle of perfection, he does not see the shortcomings of others. And it is known from our Sages that "words that come from the heart enter the heart," they were precise to say "come from the heart" with the known letter, referring to a heart filled with wisdom and fear of Heaven, for only words of moral instruction that come from such a heart have the power to awaken the heart of the listener. Conversely, it is also necessary that the recipient has a pure heart and a suitable vessel to receive the words.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of delivering moral teachings and rebukes through the lens of Torah verses, suggesting that this method enhances their effectiveness. It highlights the idea that a person who has achieved personal perfection and good character is less likely to see faults in others, as true completeness leads to a focus on one's own shortcomings. Additionally, it underscores the principle that words of rebuke must come from a heart filled with wisdom and reverence, as only such heartfelt messages can truly resonate with the listener, who must also possess a pure heart to receive them.

passage_content: ועד"זיבוארלענינינושכאשר דיברמשרע"האלבנ"יבמצרים דברי מוסר ותוכחה להפרישם מע"זולעוררם אל התשובה, לא נכנסו דבריובלבםכמ"ש הכתוב ולא שמעו אל משה, והטעם מבואר בכתוב מקוצר רוח וגו', כמו שפי'בספה"קשכח הטומאה החזקה אשר במצרים התגבר עליהם, עד שלא נכנסבלבםדיבורי קודש שלמשרע"האף שהי' בתכלית השלימות, אמנםמשרע"הבראותו שאין דבריו מתקבלים, תלההחסרוןבעצמו כדרך הצדיקים, וחשב שהסיבה מפני שאין הדברים יוצאים מן "הלב" השלם בחכמה ויראה, אמנם הי' קשה לו על הנחה זו, הלאבנ"ימורה על מדריגה גדולה, ואיך ראו חסרונותיו אשר מסיבה זו לא שמעו אליו, וע"כ החליט שמצבו כ"כ בשפלות ח"ו שא"א בשום אופן לקבל ממנו, וא"כ איך ישמעני פרעה שהוא רשע בתכלית וה"ה רואה חסרונות אחרים ובוודאי לא ישמע לדברי, וא"שדיפהכחהק"ו.
translation: And similarly, regarding the matter, when Moshe Rabbeinu spoke in Egypt words of moral instruction and rebuke to separate them from idolatry and to awaken them to repentance, his words did not enter their hearts, as the verse states, "and they did not listen to Moshe," and the reason is explained in the verse, "from shortness of spirit," etc. As it is explained in the holy books, the strong impurity that prevailed in Egypt overpowered them, to the extent that the holy words of Moshe Rabbeinu did not enter their hearts, even though he was at the pinnacle of perfection. However, Moshe Rabbeinu, seeing that his words were not accepted, attributed the shortcoming to himself, as is the way of the righteous, and thought that the reason was because the words did not come from a "heart" complete in wisdom and fear. Yet, it was difficult for him to accept this assumption, for he was a great leader, and how could they see his shortcomings, which were the reason they did not listen to him? Therefore, he concluded that his state was so lowly, Heaven forbid, that it was impossible for them to accept anything from him. And if so, how would Pharaoh, who is wicked to the utmost, listen to me, as he sees other shortcomings and certainly will not listen to my words? And thus, it is a strong a fortiori argument.
summary: In this passage, the author reflects on the challenges faced by Moses in conveying divine messages to the Israelites in Egypt, emphasizing that their spiritual impurity and lack of receptiveness stemmed from their suffering and despair. Despite Moses' ultimate righteousness and wisdom, he attributed the people's inability to hear him to his own perceived shortcomings, illustrating a deep humility characteristic of the righteous. The text highlights the struggle between the spiritual state of the people and the messenger, suggesting that even the most elevated figures can feel inadequate in their mission. Ultimately, it underscores the profound impact of external circumstances on spiritual receptivity and the complexities of divine communication.

passage_content: וע"זבא תשובתוית' אלמשרע"הבפסוק וידבר ה' אל משה ואל אהרן ויצום אל בני ישראל ואל פרעה מלך מצרים וגו', שיאמר להם הציווי בלשון הנאמרה אליו מפי הגבורה, ולא שייך בזה האיכללאדדבריםהיוצאים מן הלבדייקאנכנסים אל הלב, דאין אלו דברי המוכיח כ"א דברי ה',ולהפיסדעתו נתן לו הקב"ה עצה הוגנת לפי מדתשפלותושהחזיקא"עכאינו ראוי להוכיח, ואפשר שזהו טעם המנהג להלביש דברי תוכחה בביאור הפסוקים כי מי יאמר זכיתי לבי שיהיו הדברים ראויים להתקבל על הלב, והם יוצאים מלב טהור, אמנם כשמלבישים אותם בפסוקי התורה, אין אלו דברי המוכיח כ"אד"ת(וע"דשמצינובה' כיבוד אב, שאין לומר תוכחה לאביו מצד חיוב כיבוד אב, אבל יאמר לו אבא כתוב בתורה כך וכך עיי"ש)ועד"זראויים שיכנסו בלב השומעים אף אם לא הגיע מדריגת המוכיח לשלימות הראוי'.
translation: And regarding this, his response to the verse "And the Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron and commanded them to the children of Israel and to Pharaoh, king of Egypt, etc.," is that he should convey the command in the language that was said to him from the mouth of the Almighty, and it is not relevant here to the inclusion of words that come from the individual and enter the heart, for these are not the words of the reprover but rather the words of the Holy One, Blessed be He. And to calm his mind, the Holy One, Blessed be He, gave him a fitting counsel according to the measure of his humility, and that he should hold back from reproving, and perhaps this is the reason for the custom to dress words of rebuke in the explanation of the verses, for who can say that he is worthy that the words should be accepted in the heart, and they come from a pure heart. However, when they are dressed in the verses of the Torah, these are not the words of the reprover but rather the words of the Torah (and similarly, as it is stated in the matter of honoring one's father, that one should not give rebuke to his father due to the obligation of honoring one's father, but he should say to him, "Father, it is written in the Torah such and such," see there), and likewise, they are worthy to enter the hearts of the listeners even if the level of the reprover has not reached the appropriate completeness.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author emphasizes the importance of delivering divine commandments in a manner that resonates with the heart, highlighting that words from God carry a unique authority that transcends mere human admonition. The text suggests that when teachings are framed within the context of Torah verses, they become more acceptable and impactful, even if the speaker does not possess the ideal level of spiritual perfection. This approach reflects a Hasidic understanding of the transformative power of divine words and the necessity of humility in the act of teaching. Ultimately, it underscores the belief that true communication of spiritual truths can bridge the gap between the speaker and the listener, fostering a deeper connection to the divine.

passage_content: וידברמשה לפני ה'לאמרהןבנ"ילא שמעו אלי ואיך ישמעני פרעה ואני ערל שפתים,פירש"יזה אחד מעשרה ק"ו שבתורה, הקשו המפורשיםדק"ופריכאהוא, דמה שלא שמעו אליובנ"ימבואר בפסוק טעמו מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה, וטעם זה לא שייך בפרעה א"כ אין כאן ק"ו.
translation: And Moses spoke before the Lord, saying: "They did not listen to me; how then will Pharaoh listen to me, for I am of uncircumcised lips?" This is one of the ten interpretations of the Torah. The commentators ask: "What is the difficulty here?" For it is explained in the verse that they did not listen to me due to shortness of spirit and hard work, and this reason does not apply to Pharaoh; therefore, there is no comparison here.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the dialogue between Moses and God highlights the struggle of communication and the challenges of leadership. Moses expresses his doubts about being heard by Pharaoh due to his speech impediment, which raises questions about the nature of divine communication and human limitations. The text emphasizes the concept of faith in the face of adversity, suggesting that even when external circumstances seem insurmountable, one must trust in God's plan. This reflects a deeper Hasidic insight into the relationship between human effort and divine assistance, illustrating that true strength comes from reliance on God amidst personal shortcomings.

passage_content: ב)קשה איך מקושר סיפאדקראואני ערל שפתיםלק"וזה שלא ישמע אליו פרעה, גם הרי כבר השיב לו הקב"ה על טענה זו מי שם פה לאדם וגו' הלא אנכי ה', וצירף אליו את אהרן שיהי' לו לפה ולמליץ, ומה זה שטעןעוה"פואני ערל שפתים.
translation: B) It is difficult how it is connected to the end of the verse, "I am of uncircumcised lips," and that Pharaoh would not listen to him. Indeed, the Holy One, Blessed be He, already responded to this claim, "Who made man's mouth... is it not I, the Lord?" and He added Aaron to him to be his mouth and spokesperson. And what is this that he claimed, "I am of uncircumcised lips."
summary: הקטע עוסק בקושי של משה רבנו בדיבורו ובתחושתו שהוא "ערל שפתים", כלומר חסר יכולת לבטא את עצמו. הקב"ה משיב לו בכך שהוא זה שברא את הפה ויכול להעניק לו את הכוח לדבר, ומוסיף את אהרן כשותף שיסייע לו. זה מדגיש את הרעיון שהקב"ה מספק את הכלים הנדרשים למי שנבחר למלא שליחות, גם כאשר יש לו תחושות של חוסר יכולת. המסר המרכזי הוא שהאמונה והביטחון בה' יכולים להתגבר על כל מגבלה אנושית.

passage_content: ג)יל"דבפירש"ישמפרש מקודם סיפאדקראואני ערל שפתים שפירושו אטום שפתים והביא ראיות לדבר, ואח"כ מפרשתחלתהמקרא ואיך ישמעני פרעה זה אחד מעשרה ק"ו שבתורה,וצ"במדוע שינה רש"י ז"ל את הסדרדהי' לו לפרש מקודםתחלתהקרא כדרכובכ"מ.
translation: 3) In the commentary "Yishmar" it is explained that the end of the verse is interpreted first, and I am uncircumcised of lips, which means sealed lips, and he brought proofs for this. Afterwards, he explains the beginning of the verse and how Pharaoh will hear me. This is one of the ten a fortiori arguments in the Torah, and it is puzzling why Rashi, may his memory be blessed, changed the order, as it would have been fitting for him to explain the beginning of the verse first, as is his custom everywhere.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the interpretation of the phrase "I am of uncircumcised lips," emphasizing the concept of spiritual barriers in communication with the Divine. The text highlights the significance of understanding the sequence of interpretations, particularly why Rashi chose to explain the end of the verse before the beginning, suggesting a deeper theological insight into the nature of divine revelation and human receptivity. This reflects a Hasidic perspective on the transformative power of faith and the importance of overcoming one's limitations to engage with God. Ultimately, it underscores the interplay between human humility and divine grace in the process of spiritual awakening.

passage_content: ד)הקשו המפורשים על אומרולאמרכי למי יאמר ה' דברי משה, ובמדרש ילקוט (רמז קע"ז) הקשו כן וז"ל וידבר משה לפני ה'לאמרהן בני ישראל לא שמעו אלי, ר"א בן עזרי' אומר בארבע מקומות בקש משה לפני המקום והשיבו על שאלותיו שנאמר וידבר משה לפני ה'לאמרשאין ת"ללאמר, אלא שאמר לו השיבני אם גואלן אתה אם לאו, עד שהשיבו המקום ויאמר ה' אל משה עתה תראה עכ"ד המדרש,וצ"בענין שאלה זו, וכבר אמר לו הקב"ה הרבה פעמים שיגאל את ישראל, ומדוע חזר ושאל אם גואלן אתה אם לאו, גם צ"ב מה שאמרו במדרש שהקב"ה השיב לו על שאלתו עתה תראה, ותשובה זו כבר נאמרה אליו בשליחות ראשונה, כשאמר למההרעותהאז השיב לו הקב"ה עתה תראה וגו', ואין לתרץ דאין מוקדם ומאוחר בתורה, ופסוק עתה תראה צריך להיות כתוב כאן, דהרי בחדענינאלאאמרינןאין מוקדם ומאוחר בתורה וזההכלענין אחד הוא, וא"כ דברי המדרש צ"ב.
translation:
The interpreters questioned the saying, "To whom will the Lord say the words of Moses?" And in the Midrash Yalkut (Remez 197), they posed the same question, and it is written: "And Moses spoke before the Lord, saying, 'The children of Israel have not listened to me.'" Rabbi Eliezer ben Azariah says that in four places Moses asked before the Holy One, Blessed be He, and He answered his questions, as it is said, "And Moses spoke before the Lord, saying." There is no need to say "saying," but rather he asked Him, "Answer me, are You going to redeem them or not?" until the Holy One, Blessed be He, answered him, "And the Lord said to Moses, 'Now you will see.'" Thus concludes the Midrash. 

And this question is puzzling, for the Holy One, Blessed be He, had already told him many times that He would redeem Israel. Why then did he return to ask, "Are You going to redeem them or not?" It is also puzzling what they said in the Midrash, that the Holy One, Blessed be He, answered him to his question, "Now you will see," and this answer had already been given to him in the first mission when he said, "Why have You harmed this people?" Then the Holy One, Blessed be He, answered him, "Now you will see," etc. One cannot explain that there is no early or late in the Torah, and the verse "Now you will see" must be written here, for in one matter we say there is no early or late in the Torah, and this is all one matter. Therefore, the words of the Midrash are puzzling.
summary: The passage discusses a dialogue between Moses and God regarding the redemption of the Israelites, highlighting the tension in Moses' repeated questioning about their salvation despite previous assurances from God. It references a Midrash that emphasizes the significance of Moses' inquiry and God's response, "Now you will see," suggesting a deeper understanding of divine timing and revelation. The text raises questions about the nature of God's promises and the human struggle to grasp them, reflecting key Hasidic themes of faith, trust in divine providence, and the complexities of spiritual communication.

passage_content: ונל"פעפי"מדאיתאבמד"ר(פ' ו' סי' ה') עה"פ וידבר משה כן אל בני ישראל ולא שמעו אל משה וגו' שהי' קשה בעיניהם לפרוש מעבודת כוכביםוכו', והנהמרע"התלההחסרוןבעצמו שאין דבריו יוצאים מאמיתיות הלב,דאל"כהיו ראויים דבריו להתקבלדדבריםהיוצאים מן הלב נכנסים אל הלב ואמרי' בגמ' (ברכות ו' ע"ב)וא"רחלבו אמר רבהונאכל אדם שיש בו יראת שמים דבריונשמעיןשנאמר סוף דברהכלנשמע אתהאלקיםירא וגו' עכ"דהגמ', וע"כ כשראהמשרע"השלא שמעו אליובנ"יולא פעל אצלם לפרוש מע"ז, חשבבענותנותושהחסרוןממנו, וזה שנשאמרע"הק"ו ואמר הןבנ"ילא שמעו אלי, שלא הי'בכחדיבורי להפריש אותם מע"ז ולהכניס בהםכחהקדושה, ק"ו שפרעה לא ישמע אלי שהוא משוקע בטומאתו יותר.
translation: And it is said in the "Divrei Yoel" (Parashat Va'era, Siman 5) on the verse "And Moses spoke thus to the children of Israel, but they did not listen to Moses," that it was difficult in their eyes to separate from idol worship, etc. And behold, Moshe Rabbeinu lamented the deficiency within himself, that his words did not come from the truth of the heart, for indeed, the words that come from the heart enter the heart. And it is stated in the Gemara (Berakhot 6b) that "Rav Huna said: A person who has the fear of Heaven, his words are heard," as it is said at the end of the verse, "For God hears the one who fears Him," etc., thus says the Gemara. Therefore, when Moshe Rabbeinu saw that they did not listen to him and did not act to separate from idol worship, he thought that the deficiency was from him. And this is what was said, "Certainly, the children of Israel did not listen to me," that it was not in the power of his words to separate them from idol worship and to instill within them the power of holiness; certainly Pharaoh would not listen to me, for he is sunk in his impurity even more.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author reflects on Moses' struggle to persuade the Israelites to abandon idol worship, attributing their resistance to a lack of genuine connection to his words. He emphasizes that true communication comes from the heart, as teachings that resonate deeply are more likely to be accepted. The text highlights Moses' humility in recognizing that the failure to inspire the people stemmed from his own shortcomings, suggesting that if the Israelites did not heed his call, it would be even less likely for Pharaoh, who was entrenched in impurity, to listen. This underscores the Hasidic belief in the power of heartfelt expression and the importance of spiritual authenticity in leadership.

passage_content: ומהשמסיים ואני ערל שפתים יובןעפי"מדאיתאבמד"רפ' דברים (פ"א סי' א') אלה הדברים וכו' אמר הקב"ה ראה לשונה של תורה מה חביבה שמרפא את הלשון. מנין שכן כתיב מרפא לשון עץ חיים, ואין עץ חיים אלא תורה שנא' עץ חיים הוא למחזיקים בהוכו', ר"ל אמר מה לנו ללמוד ממקום אחרנלמודממקומו. הרי משה עד שלא זכה לתורה כתיב בו לא איש דברים אנכי, כיון שזכה לתורה נתרפא לשונו והתחיל לדבר דברים, מנין ממה שקרינובעניןאלה הדברים אשר דבר משה עכ"ד המדרש, ולכאורה הרימשרע"העסק בתורה מנעוריו, ואף טרם שנתנה תורה לא פסקה ישיבה מהםכאמרז"ל(יומא כ"ח ע"ב), ואיך אמר ואני ערל שפתים והי' ראוי שע"י התורה יתרפא לשונו מיד, אמנם נראהדכ"זשלמד תורה לעצמו לא הי' צורך להסיר ממנו כבדות הפה ולא רצה הקב"ה להסירה ממנו, גםמשרע"הלא התפלל ולא חפץ ברפואתו כמ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל (בפ' שמות) לפי שהי' בו ממעשה הנסדעי"זניצול מחרב פרעהכאמרז"ל, אמנם כשהוצרך ללמד תורה לישראל ולהשפיע בלבבם אור האמת ודרכי עבודת השי"ת, אז הוצרך להסיר ממנו כבדות הפה כדי שיהיו דבריו נשמעים, וע"כ למדו חז"ל שנתרפא לשונו מאלה הדברים אשר דיבר משה אל כל ישראל,דזההי' סיבה להסיר ממנו כבדות הפה.
translation: And from the conclusion, I am of uncircumcised lips, it is understood according to the words of the Midrash in Parshat Devarim (1:1) "These are the words..." The Holy One, Blessed be He, said: "Look at the language of the Torah, how beloved it is, for it heals the tongue." Whence do we know this? For it is written, "The tongue of the healer is a tree of life," and there is no tree of life except the Torah, as it is said, "It is a tree of life to those who hold fast to it." In other words, He said, "What do we need to learn from another place? Let us learn from its own place." Behold, Moses, before he merited the Torah, it is written of him, "I am not a man of words." Once he merited the Torah, his tongue was healed, and he began to speak words. Whence do we know this? From what is written, "These are the words that Moses spoke to all Israel," thus concludes the Midrash. And at first glance, it seems that Moses was engaged in the Torah from his youth, and even before the Torah was given, he did not cease from his study, as our Sages have said (Yoma 28b). How then did he say, "And I am of uncircumcised lips," and it would have been fitting that through the Torah his tongue would be healed immediately? However, it appears that all the Torah he learned was for himself, and there was no need to remove from him the heaviness of the mouth, and the Holy One, Blessed be He, did not want to remove it from him. Also, Moses did not pray nor desire his healing, as the Ramban, of blessed memory, writes (in Parshat Shemot), for he was saved from the sword of Pharaoh due to this. However, when he needed to teach the Torah to Israel and to impart to their hearts the light of truth and the ways of serving the Holy One, Blessed be He, then he needed to remove from him the heaviness of the mouth so that his words would be heard. Therefore, our Sages taught that his tongue was healed from "These are the words that Moses spoke to all Israel," for this was the reason to remove from him the heaviness of the mouth.
summary: The passage discusses the transformative power of the Torah, emphasizing that it serves as a remedy for the tongue, as indicated by the phrase "a tree of life." It highlights that Moses, despite his initial speech impediment, was healed only when he was tasked with teaching the Torah to the Israelites, illustrating that the purpose of learning is not merely for oneself but to share divine wisdom with others. This reflects a key Hasidic concept that true spiritual elevation and healing come through the act of teaching and guiding others in their relationship with God. Ultimately, the text underscores the importance of communal responsibility in the transmission of Torah and spiritual truths.

passage_content: והנהמרע"התלההחסרוןבעצמו שהוא אינו ראוי שיהי' דבריו נשמעים לבני ישראל, והביא ראי' לזה ממה שלא הוסר ממנו כבדות הפה ולא נתרפא לשונו עדיין, ואלמלי הי' ראוי להשפיע עלבנ"יבדיבורו הי' ראוי שיתרפא לשונו מיד, אמנם הקב"ה השיב לו ויצום אלבנ"יוגו' להוציא את בני ישראל ממצרים, לא כמו שאתה סובר שאין דיבורך מועילים אצלם כלום, שאין הדבר יכוללהעשותבפעם אחת, אבל מעט מעט יתקרבו אל הקדושה, ולבסוף עשו ישראל תשובה שלימה ויצאו ממצרים וזכו לקבלת התורה הקדושה, נמצאלפי"זאומרו ואני ערל שפתים הוא טעםעלתחלתטענתו שאמר הן בני ישראל לא שמעו אלי,ועכ"חשאיני ראוי לכך והראי' שעדיין אני ערל שפתיםוק"ושלא ישמע אלי פרעה, ולזהפירש"יתחלה סיפאדקראואני ערל שפתים, להורות שמאמר זה מקושרלתחלתהפ' הן בני ישראל לא שמעו אלי, אלא שהפסוק מסיים אתהק"וואח"כ מביא את הראי',וז"פהפסוק וידבר משה לפני ה' "לאמר" פירוש שהתפלל להקב"ה עלכחהאמירה שיוכל לדבר דברים נכונים שיתקבלו בלבבותבנ"י, לא כמו שהי' עד עכשיו שלא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה, ולזה חזר משה לשאול מהקב"ה אם אתה גואלן אם לאו, מפני שראה שלא פעל בדיבוריו אצל ישראל להפרישם מןהע"ז, ע"כ אף שכבר הובטח על הגאולה עדיין חששמרע"הפן לא יזכו ח"ולהגאלגאולת עולם ושמא סופם לחזור למצרים.
translation: And behold, Moshe Rabbeinu was troubled by the deficiency within himself, that he was not worthy for his words to be heard by the Children of Israel. He brought proof for this from the fact that the heaviness of the mouth had not been removed from him and his tongue had not yet been healed. Had he been worthy to influence the Children of Israel with his speech, his tongue would have been healed immediately. However, the Holy One, Blessed be He, responded to him and commanded him to go to the Children of Israel to take them out of Egypt, not as you think that your words are of no benefit to them, for this matter cannot be accomplished all at once, but little by little they will draw closer to holiness. In the end, the Children of Israel repented completely and left Egypt, meriting to receive the Holy Torah. Therefore, when he said, "And I am of uncircumcised lips," it is a reason for the beginning of his claim when he said, "Behold, the Children of Israel did not listen to me," and therefore I am not worthy of this, and the proof is that I am still of uncircumcised lips, and that Pharaoh will not listen to me. For this reason, it explains that the beginning of the verse is connected to the end, "And I am of uncircumcised lips," to indicate that this statement is linked to the beginning of the verse, "Behold, the Children of Israel did not listen to me," but the verse concludes with the Holy One, Blessed be He, and then brings the proof. Thus, the verse "And Moshe spoke before the Lord, saying" means that he prayed to the Holy One, Blessed be He, for the ability to speak words that would be accepted in the hearts of the Children of Israel, not as it had been until now, when they did not listen to Moshe due to shortness of spirit and hard work. For this reason, Moshe returned to ask the Holy One, Blessed be He, if You are indeed our Redeemer or not, because he saw that his words had not had an effect on Israel to separate them from idolatry. Therefore, even though he had already been promised redemption, he still feared that perhaps they would not merit the ultimate redemption and that perhaps their end would be to return to Egypt.
summary: In this passage, the author discusses Moses' feelings of inadequacy and his belief that his speech is unworthy to be heard by the Israelites, as evidenced by his ongoing speech impediment. Despite this, God commands him to speak to the Israelites, indicating that their spiritual elevation will occur gradually rather than instantaneously. The text emphasizes the importance of prayer and divine assistance in enabling Moses to communicate effectively, as well as the concern that the Israelites may not merit redemption despite the promise of salvation. Ultimately, it reflects the Hasidic themes of humility, the gradual process of spiritual growth, and the reliance on divine grace.

passage_content: ובזהיובן דברי המדרש ילקוט שאמרמשרע"הלפני הקב"ה השיבני אם אתה גואלן אם לאו, עד שהשיבו המקום ויאמר ה' אל משה עתה תראה, ואין הכוונה שהקב"ה אמר לו תשובה זו עכשיו, שכבר נאמרה לו על טענת למההרעותה, אלא שנתןהבוי"תבדעתו שיתבונןעוה"פעתה תראה וגו', ובו ימצא תשובה גם על שאלתו של עכשיו, שנאמר עתה תראה כי ביד חזקה "ישלחם",ועפי"משדרשוחכז"ל(יבמות קי"ג ע"ב) ושלחה מביתו מי שמשלחה ואינה חוזרתיצתהזו שמשלחה וחוזרת, וע"כ כיון שהי' הבטחתהבוי"תבלשון ישלחם, מרומז בה שלא יהיובבחי' משלחים וחוזרים, ואז השיגמרע"ההנרמז בהבטחתוית' והרגיעה דעתו.
translation: And in this is understood the words of the Midrash Yalkut, which states that Moshe Rabbeinu asked before the Holy One, Blessed be He, whether He would redeem them or not, until the Holy One responded and said to Moshe, "Now you will see." And the intention is not that the Holy One said this answer to him now, for it had already been said to him regarding the claim of "Why have You done evil," but rather that the Holy One placed in his mind to contemplate, "Now you will see," and in this he would find an answer also to his current question, as it is said, "Now you will see that with a strong hand He will send them." And according to what our Sages of blessed memory have taught (Yevamot 113b), "And he shall send her from his house," one who sends her and she does not return, this is a case where she is sent and returns. Therefore, since there was a promise from the Holy One in the language of "He will send them," it is hinted that there will not be a case of sending and returning. And then Moshe Rabbeinu grasped the hint in His promise and calmed his mind.
summary: The passage discusses a dialogue between Moses and God, emphasizing that God's response to Moses' concerns about redemption is not merely a present answer but a deeper understanding that Moses must attain. It highlights the concept of divine assurance, where God's promise of liberation is irrevocable, symbolized by the phrase "He will send them." This assurance alleviates Moses' doubts, illustrating the Hasidic idea that faith and trust in God's promises can bring inner peace and clarity in times of uncertainty. Ultimately, it reflects the belief that divine guidance leads to a profound understanding of one's mission and purpose.

passage_content: וידברמשה כן אל בני ישראל ולא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה, במדרש (ילקוטרמז קע"ח) וכי יש לך אדם שמתבשר בשורה ואינו שמח, א"כ מה ת"ל ולא שמעו אל משה, אלא שהי' קשה בעיניהם לפרוש מע"ז עכ"ד המדרש,ויל"דדעדייןלא נתיישב נתינת טעםשאמה"כמקוצר רוח.דלטעםזה הי' ראוי שישמחו על בשורת הגאולה.
translation: And Moses spoke thus to the children of Israel, but they did not listen to Moses because of shortness of spirit and hard work. In the Midrash (Yalkut Reuveni 218), it is said: Is there a person who receives good tidings and is not happy? Therefore, what does it mean, "but they did not listen to Moses"? Rather, it was difficult in their eyes to separate from idolatry, thus concludes the Midrash. And it seems that the reason for their shortness of spirit has not yet been clarified. For this reason, they should have rejoiced at the tidings of redemption.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, it is highlighted that the Israelites did not listen to Moses due to their shortness of spirit and hard labor, as noted in the Midrash. The text questions why they would not rejoice at the news of redemption, suggesting that their attachment to idolatry made it difficult for them to embrace the message of salvation. This reflects a key Hasidic concept that spiritual bondage can hinder one's ability to perceive and accept divine promises. Ultimately, it emphasizes the struggle between physical suffering and the yearning for spiritual liberation.

passage_content: ונראהלבאר בדרך רמז מוסר, ידועמספה"קדימיהשובבי"םהמה מסוגלים לתקון חטא הידוע, על שם שבהם קוראים בתורה פרשיות גלות מצרים וזה הי' עבודתם של בני ישראל במצרים להעלותניצה"קולתקן חטא זה ובזה הי'תליאגאולתם, וע"כ הקריאה מעורר הזמן, ואף כי בכל יומא ויומא זמני', אבל הימים האלה מסוגלים יותר וקרוב ד' לכל קוראיו לכל אשר יקראוהו באמת, והנה כתבבספה"קדברי חיים (פ' נח) על מהשאמחז"לדבקושיגדול מועיל תשובה על חטא הנורא הזה, וטעם הדבר מבואר בספריםדבהחטאפוגם האדםבמדותיו,ובמדהשחוטא מסיר עצמו משרשי הקדושה וכו' ומקלקלצנורהמשכתו מלמעלה מלקבל קדושה וברכה באותו אבר שפגם וכו' ולכן בעשותו תשובה מביא חיות חדש משורשו אל האברוהצנורשנחלשוכו', אך בחטא חמור הנ"ל ר"ל הוא כמסיר שרשו לגמרי כמבוארבספה"ק, ולכן כמעט אין לו רפואה,ובמקו"אכתב דלפי שחטא זה הואבכחכל האיברים, וכל האיברים נעשו פגומים ר"ל, ע"כ קשה התשובה בזה, והעצההיעוצהלעבוד השי"תבמסנ"פאמיתית, וזהו תקנה לכולם עכת"ד ז"ל, עוד אפשר להמציא תקנה לזהשיאנחהאדם אנחהתקיפאעל עונותיו ועל חורבןביהמ"קוגלות השכינה,ואמרז"ל(כתובות ס"ב ע"א) אנחה שוברת כל גופו של אדם, ואף למ"דדס"לחצי גופו לבדו מודה באנחהתקיפאדשוברתכל גופו עיי"שבגמ',ועד"זיהי'התקוןבכחכל הגוף וכל האיברים.
translation: And it is seen to explain in a hint of moral teaching, it is known from the book "Kedimah" that the "Shovavim" are capable of rectifying the known sin, because in them we read in the Torah the sections of the exile of Egypt, and this was the work of the Children of Israel in Egypt to elevate the sparks to rectify this sin, and in this their redemption was dependent. Therefore, the reading arouses the time, and although every day has its times, these days are more capable and close to G-d for all who call upon Him in truth. And behold, it is written in the book "Divrei Chaim" (Parashat Noach) regarding what our sages say that a great sigh is beneficial for repentance for this terrible sin, and the reason for this is explained in the books that the sin affects a person in his character traits, and in the trait that the sinner removes himself from the roots of holiness, etc., and disrupts the channel of his flow from above to receive holiness and blessing in that limb which he has blemished, etc. Therefore, by doing repentance, he brings new life from his root to the limb and the channel that has weakened. However, in the aforementioned grave sin, it is as if he completely removes his root, as explained in the holy books, and therefore he has almost no remedy. And in another place, it is written that since this sin is in the power of all the limbs, and all the limbs have become blemished, it is difficult to repent for this. And the advised counsel is to serve the Holy One, blessed be He, with a true sigh, and this is a rectification for all, as stated by him. Furthermore, it is possible to establish a remedy for this by sighing a strong sigh for his sins and for the destruction of the Holy Temple and the exile of the Shechinah. And our sages said (Ketubot 62a) that a sigh breaks the entire body of a person, and even according to the opinion that holds that half of his body alone acknowledges a strong sigh that breaks his entire body, as stated there in the Gemara. And similarly, this will be the rectification in the power of the whole body and all the limbs.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the "Shovavim" period, emphasizing its potential for rectifying the grave sin associated with the disconnection from holiness. It highlights that the reading of the Torah during this time evokes a spiritual awakening, enabling individuals to reconnect with their divine source and repair their spiritual flaws. The text also notes that true repentance, particularly through heartfelt anguish over one's sins and the destruction of the Holy Temple, can restore one's connection to holiness, as even a powerful sigh can break through spiritual barriers. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of sincere service to God as a remedy for collective and individual spiritual ailments.

passage_content: והנהבני ישראל במצרים אף שהיו שמורים ונקיים מעריות כמו שהעיד עליהם הכתוב,ואמרז"ל(ויקרא רבה פ' ל"ב סי' ה') אחתהיתהופירסמההכתוב. מכל מקום להיותם בארץ טמאה ערות הארץ, ומשועבדים למזוהמים ומושחתים אומה של מצרים, לא נמלטו מקצתם מהרהור עבירה וחטא הנורא הידוע ר"ל והיוצריכיןבהכרח לתקן ולהעלותניצה"קשנתפזרובסיבת החטאים, ולא היויכוליןלהיגאלבלא"ה, וע"י קושי השעבוד שעבדו בעבודה קשה המפרכת את כל הגוףומשברתו, נתקן פגם החטא בתשובת המשקל נגד פגם העבירה שהואבכחכל הגוף. גם ע"ו אנחהכמשה"כויאנחובנ"יוגו' ותעלשועתםאלהאלקיםשנאנחו בשביל גלות השכינה,עי"זתיקנו פגם החטא מידה כנגד מידה.
translation: And behold, the children of Israel in Egypt, even though they were guarded and clean from immorality, as the scripture testifies, and our sages of blessed memory said (Vayikra Rabbah, Parashah 32, Section 5) that it was one and the scripture publicized it. Nevertheless, due to being in a defiled land, the nakedness of the land, and being enslaved to the polluted and corrupt nation of Egypt, they could not escape from some of them from thoughts of sin and the terrible sin known, may it be erased. And they were necessarily compelled to rectify and elevate the sparks that were scattered because of the sins, and they could not be redeemed without this. And through the difficulty of the servitude, which worked them with hard labor that crushed the entire body and broke it, the flaw of the sin was rectified through a response of balance against the flaw of the transgression, which is in the power of the whole body. Also, through their groaning, as it is written, "And the children of Israel sighed" (Exodus 2:23), and their cry ascended to God, they groaned because of the exile of the Shechinah; through this, they rectified the flaw of the sin measure for measure.
summary: בפסקה זו מדגיש המחבר את מצב בני ישראל במצרים, אף שהיו שמורים ונקיים מעריות, הם לא נמלטו מהרהורי עבירה בשל היותם בארץ טמאה ובשיעבודם למצריים. הוא מציין כי קושי השעבוד והעבודה הקשה שעמדו בפניהן תרמו לתיקון פגם החטא, כאשר התשובה נדרשה כדי להעלות את הניצוצות שנפלו. בנוסף, הוא מתאר את אנחת בני ישראל כתגובה לגלות השכינה, אשר גם היא סייעה בתיקון הפגם, במידה כנגד מידה.

passage_content: ואוליירמזו ד' לשונות של גאולה הכתובים בפרשה, על ד' בחי'מדריגות, והוצאתי אתכם מתחת סבלות מצרים ירמוז על החלק שבישראל שלא פגמו ולא נכשלו בחטא זה כלל,עכ"זהי' להם לטורח משא לסבול שעבודם של מצרים ושר של מצרים שהתגברו עליהם להכשילם, והבטיחם השי"ת והוצאתי אתכם מתחת סבלות מצריםוכפרש"ימטורח משא מצרים, והצלתי אתכם מעבודתם ירמוז על החלק שנכשלו ופגמו בחטא הנורא, וזה נקרא עבודתם שהקריבו עבודהלסט"אר"ל כמבוארבספה"קשהמוציא זרע במקום קדושה ובמקום מצוה נקרא עבד נאמן לד', ולהיפך ח"ו ה"ה בחי' ע"ז שמקריב דורןלסט"א, ועל אלו ירמוז הבטחת והצלתי אתכם מעבודתם, שניצולו מעבודה זו ע"י שהוציאם השי"ת משם, אמנם לא סגי בזה שלא יפגמו עוד, אבל צריך לתקן ולהוציא משם בחי' הקדושהניצה"קשנתפזרובסיבת החטאים, וזה נקרא גאולה כנודע, וזה ירמוז וגאלתי אתכם וגו', ואח"כ ולקחתי אתכם לי לעם,דאיתאבספה"קשע"י פגם חטא זה נעשה מסך המבדיל בין ישראל לאביהם שבשמים,ועי"כאנו מרוחקים כ"כבעוה"רמבחי' הקדושה, אבל לאחר שתתקיים והוצאתי והצלתי שלא יפגמו עוד, ומהשפגמו יתוקן כנרמז בהבטחת וגאלתי כנ"ל, אז יהי' ולקחתי אתכם לי לעם וגו' שיתבטלו כל המסכים המבדילים ויקרב אותנוהבוי"שלו לעם.
translation: And I will explain the four expressions of redemption written in the parsha, corresponding to the four levels of ascent. "And I took you out from under the burdens of Egypt" hints at the part of Israel that did not blemish or fail in this sin at all. Therefore, it is a burden for them to endure the servitude of Egypt and the minister of Egypt who overpowered them to cause them to stumble. And the Holy One, blessed be He, promised them, "And I took you out from under the burdens of Egypt," as explained, "from the burden of Egypt," and "I saved you from their work" hints at the part that stumbled and blemished in this terrible sin, and this is called their work, which they offered to the minister of impurity, as explained in the holy book that one who sows seed in a place of holiness and in a place of commandment is called a faithful servant to the Holy One, blessed be He, and conversely, God forbid, he is in the category of idolatry, who offers to the minister of impurity. And these are hinted at in the promise, "And I saved you from their work," that they were saved from this service by the Holy One, blessed be He, taking them out from there. However, it is not sufficient that they will not blemish further, but they need to rectify and extract from there the aspect of holiness, as it is known that due to the sins, this is called redemption, as hinted in "And I redeemed you," and afterwards "And I took you to Me as a people." For it is known in the holy book that due to the blemish of this sin, a screen is created that separates between Israel and their Father in Heaven, and thus we are so distant in this world from the aspect of holiness. But after it is fulfilled, "And I took you out" and "I saved you" so that they will not blemish further, and what they have blemished will be rectified as hinted in the promise "And I redeemed you," then it will be "And I took you to Me as a people," that all the screens that separate will be nullified, and He will bring us close to Him as a people.
summary: The passage discusses the four expressions of redemption in the context of the Jewish experience in Egypt, highlighting different spiritual states among the Israelites. It emphasizes that those who did not sin are promised liberation from the burdens of Egypt, while those who did sin must undergo a process of rectification to achieve true redemption. The text underscores the importance of overcoming spiritual barriers that separate the Jewish people from their divine connection, ultimately leading to their status as a chosen nation. The process of redemption involves both liberation from physical oppression and spiritual restoration.

passage_content: ועפי"זאפ"לבטעם שתקנו חז"ל ד' כוסות יין ע"ש ד' לשונות של גאולה, כיאמרז"ל(ברכותדף ס"ג ע"א, נזיר דף ב' ע"א) הרואה סוטה בקלקולהיזירעצמו מן היין, כי היין עלול להביא לידי קלקול בפגם הברית, אמנם הזוכה לתקן פגמי חטאו ועובד עבודתו להוציאניצה"קולהעלותם, מותר לו לשתות ייןלמצוהובבחי' קדושה,דנכנסיין יצא סוד היינוהניצה"קהנקראים כן, כמו שרמזו ז"ל בסודם אל תבוא נפשי זה מעשה זמרי שהי' החטאבעניןזה כנודע, וע"כ תקנו חז"ל ד' כוסות יין כנגד והוצאתי והצלתי וגאלתי ולקחתי להוציא בחי' הסוד ולהעלותו, וצריך ג"כלהזהרולהשגיח על הפה והלשון שיהיו זכים וטהורים, כי ברית הלשון והמעור מכוונים ותלייןזב"ז, וע"זאמרז"ל(שבת דף ס"ז ע"ב) חמרא וחיי לפום רבנןותלמידיהון, ולא אמרולרבנןרק לפום רבנן, כי כשמתקנים הפה אז גם בחי' היסוד יתוקן ע"י היין ולא זולת.
translation: And according to this, it can be said regarding the reason that the Sages established four cups of wine in the name of the four expressions of redemption, as our Sages have said (Berakhot 63a, Nazir 2a), "One who sees a Sotah in her disgrace should distance himself from wine, for wine can lead to corruption in the breach of the covenant." However, one who merits to rectify the flaws of his sin and works to elevate the sparks of holiness, it is permitted for him to drink wine for a mitzvah and in a state of holiness, for wine enters into the secret of the wine of the sparks, which are called so, as our Sages hinted in their secret, "Let not my soul come into their counsel," referring to the act of Zimri, who was the sinner in this matter, as is known. Therefore, the Sages established four cups of wine corresponding to "And I took you out," "And I saved you," "And I redeemed you," and "And I took you," to draw out the aspect of the secret and to elevate it. One must be very careful to watch over the mouth and tongue to ensure they are pure and clean, for the covenant of the tongue and the essence are aligned and dependent on one another. And regarding this, our Sages said (Shabbat 67b), "Wine and life according to the Rabbis and their students," and they did not say "according to the Rabbis" but "according to the Rabbis," for when the mouth is rectified, then also the aspect of the foundation will be rectified through the wine and not otherwise.
summary: המעבר בין היין לבין פגמי הברית מדגיש את הקשר בין תיקון הנפש לבין השימוש ביין, כאשר חז"ל קבעו ארבע כוסות יין כנגד ארבעה לשונות של גאולה. היין, כאשר הוא נצרך במצווה ובקדושה, יכול לשמש כאמצעי לתיקון ולעלייה רוחנית, אך יש להיזהר שהפה והלשון יהיו זכים וטהורים. תיקון הלשון משפיע גם על תיקון היסוד, מה שמצביע על הקשר העמוק בין המילים למעשים.

passage_content: ועד"זיתבארבמאמה"כולא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח וגו',דלכאורהאיך יתכן שלא שמעו ישראל אלמשרע"השהי' שכינה מדברת מתוך גרונו וכל דבריו דברי השי"ת, ע"ז נתן הכתוב טעם מקוצר רוח ורוח היינו מחשבה כמ"ש רז"ל (ויק"רפר' ז' ס"ג) עולה מכפרת על הרהור הלב שנא' (יחזקאל כ') והעולה על רוחכם היו לא תהי'וכשזוכיןלמחשבות טהורות זה נקרא הרחבת הדעתדקדושה, ולהיפוך ח"ו הוא בחי' קוצר רוח,ולז"אולא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח, על שנכשלו ר"ל בפגם ההרהור, ובעבודה קשה שהי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז היינו מפגם הברית שהוא בחי' ע"ז כנ"ל, על שהניצוץ הקדוש נשבה ביד זריםנוקבאדס"מוכתדילה, וכי יש מקום זר ועבודה זרה מזה, וע"י החטא הנורא הזה נעשה מסך המבדיל בין ישראל לאביהם שבשמים, וע"כ לא שמעו אל משה דיבורי השי"ת שהי' מדבר אליהם.
translation: And similarly, it is explained in the verse "All the people heard Moses because of their shortness of spirit, etc." How is it possible that Israel did not listen to Moshe Rabbeinu, who had the Shechinah speaking from his throat and all his words were the words of the Holy One, Blessed be He? For this, the verse gives the reason of "shortness of spirit," and "spirit" refers to thought, as our Sages of blessed memory said (Vayikra Rabbah, Parashah 7, Section 63) that the ascent of the offering atones for the thoughts of the heart, as it is said (Ezekiel 20) "and the thoughts that come into your mind shall not be." When one merits pure thoughts, this is called the expansion of the mind of holiness; conversely, God forbid, it is a state of shortness of spirit. Therefore, it says, "And they did not listen to Moses because of their shortness of spirit," for they stumbled, so to speak, in the blemish of thought, and in the hard work that was difficult for them to separate from idolatry, which is the blemish of the covenant, which is a form of idolatry, as mentioned above, because the holy spark was captured by foreign forces, the female aspect of the Sitra Achra. And is there a foreign place and idolatry beyond this? And through this terrible sin, a partition was created that separates Israel from their Father in Heaven, and therefore they did not listen to Moses, the words of the Holy One, Blessed be He, who was speaking to them.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of "Katzar Ruach" (shortness of spirit) as a reason for the Israelites' failure to listen to Moses, despite his divine communication. It emphasizes that this shortness of spirit stems from impure thoughts and a failure to achieve pure intentions, which creates a barrier between them and God. The text links this spiritual deficiency to the struggle against idolatry and the consequences of succumbing to foreign influences, ultimately highlighting the importance of maintaining a connection to the divine through pure thought and intention.
