passage_content: ולתרץדברי המדרש הנ"ל (בקושיאב')אפ"לבהקדם דברי ק"ז הישמח משהזלה"ה(בפ' מקץ) לפרש הכתוב (תהלים ק"ד) הכפירים שואגים לטרף ולבקש מאל אכלם וגו', כיהפוגמיןבהוצאת ז"ל ר"למושכיןניצוצות הקדושות מנשמתו לתוך הטומאה, ונבראים מאלו הטפות משחיתים ומזיקים, והמה צועקים לפני הזן ומפרנסית"ששיטולמאביהם אשר בראם הפרנסה הנקצבה לווכו',וז"פהכתוב לדעתי הכפירים היינו אלו הנבראים מהוצאת ז"ל, ונקראו כפירים כי המה משורשהסט"א,והסט"אדעריותנקרא כפיר וארי', כמבואר בגמ' (יומא ס"ט ע"ב) נפקכגוריאדנוראמבית ק"ק עיי"ש, והם שואגים לטרףשיתןלהם פרנסתם, ולבקש מאל אכלם של אותן בנ"א שבראםעכלה"קבקיצור, והנה המצריים היו מושחתים ומזוהמים מאודביצראדעריותכנודע, ואוליס"ללהךמ"ד שהערוב בא מלמעלה, שהי' בריאה חדשה היינו חיות הטורפות שבאו במכת הערוב, המה היוהמזיקיןוהמשחיתים שנבראו ממעשיהם הרעים, ואידך מ"דס"לדבעכו"םלא שייך בחי' זודזרמתסוסים זרמתם, ואין בחי' קדושה בטיפי זרע שלהם וע"כ איןהחצוניםמתדבקיםבהם, כידועשהחצוניםתאבים ומשתוקקיםלהתדבקבקדושהדייקא, ולזהס"לשהערוב בא עליהם מלמטה, חיות טורפות של מדבריות והבן.
translation: To explain the words of the aforementioned Midrash (in response to the question), it can be said that in advance of the words of K"Z, "May Moshe rejoice" (in Parshat Miketz), he interprets the verse (Psalms 104) "The young lions roar for their prey and seek their food from God," for as the sparks are drawn out from his holy soul into the impurity, and from those drops are created destroyers and harmers, and they cry out before the Sustainer and Provider, "to take from their father who created them the sustenance that is apportioned to them." And this is what the verse means, in my opinion, "the young lions" refers to those created from the outpouring, and they are called young lions because they stem from the Sitra Achra, and the Sitra Achra is called a young lion and a lion, as explained in the Gemara (Yoma 69b) "It emerged like a lion from the den," see there. And they roar for their prey to be given their sustenance, and seek from the food of those human beings that they were created from, as it is written, in short. And behold, the Egyptians were very corrupt and defiled, as is known regarding the Sitra Achra. And perhaps it can be said according to the opinion that the mixture came from above, that it was a new creation, meaning the predatory animals that came in the plague of the mixture, they were the harmers and destroyers created from their evil deeds. And the other opinion holds that the idol worshippers do not have this quality, as their seed flows like the flow of horses, and there is no holiness in their seed drops, and therefore the external forces do not cling to them, as is known that the external forces crave and desire to cling specifically to holiness. And for this reason, it is said that the mixture came upon them from below, predatory animals of the deserts, and understand.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of "nitzotzot kedushah" (holy sparks) being drawn into impurity, leading to the creation of destructive entities that cry out for sustenance from their Creator. It highlights the connection between these entities, referred to as "kephirim" (young lions), and their origins in the realm of impurity, particularly in the context of the Egyptians' moral corruption. The text contrasts two interpretations of the origin of these destructive forces, one suggesting they were created from the Egyptians' evil deeds and the other asserting that they lack any divine connection, emphasizing the longing of the impure to attach themselves to holiness.

passage_content: עודאפ"לבמאה"כולא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח וגו' בהקדם דבריהמד"רפ' שמות (פ"ג סי' ד') ויאמר משה אלהאלקיםמי אנכי וגו' מהו שאמר לו כי אנכי שלחתיך אמרו רז"ל סימן לגאולה הראשונה שבאנכי ירדו ישראל למצרים שנא' אנכי ארד עמך מצרימה, ובאנכי אני מעלה אותם, וסימן לגאולה האחרונה שבאנכי הןמתרפאיןוהם עתידיםלהגאלשנא' הנה אנכי שולח לכם את אלי' הנביא עכ"ד המדרש, והקשההיפ"תהלא סימן גאולה הראשונה הי' פקד פקדתי ומה צורך לסימן עוד עיי"ש תירוצו,ואפ"לעוד בהקדם דברי ק"ז הישמח משהזלה"ה(בפ' בשלח) לפרש כפל הלשון בפקידה כפולה שאמר יוסף פקוד יפקוד וגו',עפימ"שרש"י ז"ל (בפ' קרח) עה"פ ואם בריאה יברא עיי"ש הכא נמי או פקוד היינו הפקידה שמכבר שהוקצב לסוף ד' מאות שנה, או יפקוד למהר הקץוכו', עכת"ד ז"ל, נמצא לדעת שהי' מסורת ביד יורדי מצרים מיוסף הצדיק כי הגאולה אפשר שתהי' בשני אופנים, וע"ד שדרשו רז"ל על גאולה העתידה זכואחישנהלא זכו בעתה,ותליאבזכות המעשים.
translation:
Furthermore, it is said in the Midrash (Parashat Shemot, Chapter 3, Section 4) that when Moses said, "Who am I?" it was because the people heard the voice of God due to their shortness of spirit, etc. It is stated that the sign of the first redemption is that "I will surely visit you," as Israel descended to Egypt, as it is written, "I will go down with you to Egypt," and "I will bring them up." And the sign of the final redemption is that "I am sending you Elijah the prophet," thus concludes the Midrash. 

It is asked, however, why the first redemption had the sign of "I have surely visited," what need is there for another sign? There is an answer there. Additionally, it is worth noting the earlier words of the Zohar (in Parashat Beshalach) explaining the double language in the visitation that Joseph said, "I will surely visit you," according to the explanation of Rashi (in Parashat Korach) on the verse "If a new creation, He will create," etc. Here too, "or surely visit" refers to the visitation that was already decreed for the end of four hundred years, or "He will visit" to hasten the end, etc. Thus, it is found that there was a tradition among those who descended to Egypt from Joseph the Righteous that the redemption could come in two ways, and according to what our Sages have taught regarding the future redemption, if they are worthy, it will come quickly; if they are not worthy, it will come in its time, and it depends on the merit of their deeds.
summary: The passage discusses the dual nature of redemption as reflected in the phrase "אנכי" (I) in the context of both the first and final redemptions of the Jewish people. It highlights that the Israelites' descent into Egypt and their eventual redemption are interconnected, with the potential for redemption occurring in two ways: either at the predetermined time or hastened through merit. This reflects a Hasidic understanding of divine providence and the importance of human actions in shaping the timing of redemption. Ultimately, it emphasizes the belief that redemption is contingent upon the spiritual state and deeds of the people.

passage_content: והנהאמרו רז"לבמד"ר(פר' ג' סי' ד') עה"פ בהוציאך את העם ממצרים תעבדון אתהאלקיםעל ההר הזה, מה שאמרת באיזה זכות אוציאם ממצרים הוי יודע שבזכות התורה שהן עתידים לקבל על ידך בהר הזה הם יוצאים משם עכ"ד המדרש, ובזה פי'היפ"תדברי המדרש הנ"ל סימן לגאולה הראשונה שבאנכי ירדו ישראל למצריםוכו',עפי"משנודע כי תכלית גלות מצריםהיתהכדי שיקבלו עליהם עול תורה בצאתם ולא יקשה עליהם אחרי שכבר הורגלו בעבודה קשה,וכו',וז"ששבסבת אנכי כדי לקבל התורה ירדו למצרים, ובאנכי בשביל קבלת התורה אני מעלה אתכם עכ"ד, וכתב ק"ז הייטב לבזלה"הדלאצריכנאלטעמאדע"שהעתיד נגאלו ישראל ממצרים. בזכות שעתידים לקבל את התורה בהר סיני, אלאמכיוןשקבלו עליהם לקבל את התורה ולקיימה ופירשו מע"ז מיד, נחשב להם הקבלה כאלו כבר עשו, ובזכות זה נגאלו ממצרים עכ"ד,וז"פדברי המדרש סימן לגאולה הראשונהשבאנכי אני מעלה אתכם, היינו אנכי שבעשרת הדברות וזה להם לסימן שא"א שיגאלו כ"א ע"י שיקבלו עליהם עול התורה ויפרשו מדרכי ע"ז,ואה"נבקץ של בעתה שנקצב לסוף ד' מאות שנה היו נגאלים בכל אופן ואופן, ולא יאוחר בשום פנים, וכמ"ש רז"ל בגאולה העתידה אם תהי' בעתה אפי' בדור שכולו חייב מוכרח להיות הגאולה ולא ידחה ח"ו, אבל להקדים הקץבבחי'אחישנהא"א כ"אבזכו, ולזה הי' צורך להם זכות קבלת התורה, ויתורץ לדרכנוקושיתהיפ"תדאעפ"ישכבר הי' מסורת בידם הסימן של פקד פקדתי, הי' צורך גם לסימן של אנכי,דהבטחתפקד פקדתיתליאבזכו, ולזה צורך לסימן של אנכי והבן.
translation: And behold, our Sages said in the Midrash (Parashat Shemot, Section 4) regarding the verse "When you bring the people out of Egypt, you shall serve God on this mountain," that what you asked, "By what merit will I bring them out of Egypt?" know that it is by the merit of the Torah that they are destined to receive through you on this mountain that they will be redeemed from there, thus concludes the Midrash. And in this, the words of the aforementioned Midrash serve as a sign for the first redemption, that "I am the Lord your God" when Israel descended to Egypt, etc. According to what is known, the ultimate purpose of the Egyptian exile was so that they would accept upon themselves the yoke of the Torah upon their exit, and it would not be difficult for them after they had already been accustomed to hard labor, etc. Therefore, it is said that because of "I am the Lord your God" they descended to Egypt in order to receive the Torah, and "I am the Lord your God" for the sake of receiving the Torah, I will elevate you, thus concludes the text. And it is written that it is good to clarify that the reason for the future redemption of Israel from Egypt is by the merit that they are destined to receive the Torah at Mount Sinai. However, since they accepted upon themselves to receive the Torah and to fulfill it and immediately distanced themselves from idolatry, their acceptance is considered as if they had already done it, and by this merit they were redeemed from Egypt, thus concludes the text. And this is the meaning of the words of the Midrash as a sign for the first redemption, that "I am elevating you," meaning "I am" from the Ten Commandments, and this is a sign for them that they cannot be redeemed except by accepting upon themselves the yoke of the Torah and distancing themselves from the ways of idolatry. And indeed, at the end of the appointed time of four hundred years, they would have been redeemed in any case, and not delayed in any way, as our Sages said regarding the future redemption, if it will be in its time, even in a generation that is entirely guilty, the redemption must occur and will not be delayed, Heaven forbid. But to hasten the end in the aspect of "I will hasten it," it can only be by merit, and for this reason, they needed the merit of accepting the Torah. It will be resolved to the question of why, even though they already had the tradition of the sign of "I have surely remembered," there was also a need for the sign of "I am," for the promise of "I have surely remembered" is dependent on merit, and for this reason, there was a need for the sign of "I am," and understand.
summary: The passage discusses the connection between the Israelites' redemption from Egypt and their future acceptance of the Torah at Mount Sinai. It emphasizes that the purpose of their enslavement was to prepare them for the acceptance of the Torah, which would serve as a foundation for their spiritual identity. The text highlights that their commitment to the Torah and rejection of idolatry were essential for their redemption, indicating that true liberation is intrinsically linked to the acceptance of divine commandments. Ultimately, it asserts that while redemption was assured, the manner and timing of it depended on their willingness to embrace the Torah.

passage_content: ונקדיםדברי ק"ז הישמח משהזלה"ה(בפי' על איכה) לפרש הכתוב צדו צעדינו מלכת ברחובותינו קרב קצנו מלאו ימינו כי בא קצנו,עפימ"שהרב המגידמקרעמניץלפרש הפסוק כל רודפי' השיגוה בין המצריםוזל"קשעניןהמיצר הוא גבול שבין השדות, וזה משל על הזמנים שהיוגבוליםוסיום להשלמת הקץונתבטלובעוה"ר, וכתב בזוהר שזמן הגאולה אם יתבטלבעוןישראליהפךלאבל וצרה ר"ל ודבר זה נודע ומפורסם,וז"שכל רודפי' השיגוה לישראל בין המצרים, היינו בין הזמנים וסיומם שהיומעותדיםלגאול אז נהפך לרועץ עכ"ד,וז"שכאן צדו צעדינו מלכת ברחובותינו, שהם אורבים את פסיעותינו שלא ללכת לרחובותינוכפרש"י, והיינו שלא יגיע הקץ, ואימתי הוא כן כאשר קרב קצנו, שמתקרב הקץ שהוא עת רצוןוכו',ולפי"זאף שידענו שיש עת רצון, מ"מ יש לחוש שלא יהי' קטרוג ח"ו, וא"כלפי"זאין אנו יודעים מתי ימלאו ימינו אם לא כאשר יבא משיחנו ויבנהביהמ"ק, אז יתוודע לנו שמלאו ימינו כמ"ש הרמב"ם ז"לוז"שאימתי מלאו ימינו, כי בא קצנו שכבר בא, אז יתוודע לנו שמלאו ימינועכתדה"ק, השי"ת ירחם עלינו ויזכנו לראות בישועת ישראל, כי כבר ראינו התעוררת הגאולה, אךבעוה"רנדחה ונתעכבבעוננוונתקיים בנו כל רודפי' השיגוה בין המצרים, וע"ד הרמז פירשתי בזה אמרם ז"ל (שבת קי"ח ע"ב) כל המענג את השבתנותניןלו נחלה בלי מצרים, עפ"י אמרם ז"ל שם אלמלימשמריןישראל ב' שבתות כהלכתן מיד נגאלים, ובמדרש אמרו שבת א', ופירשתיעפימ"דבזוה"קדשבתדלילאושבתדיממאהוא בחי' ב' שבתות,ולפי"זשניהם צדקו יחדיו ולא פליגי, והנה דרשו רז"ל בספרי נחלה זו ירושלים,וז"שכל המענג את השבתנותניןלו נחלה בלי מצרים, שע"י זכות השבת יזכו ישראל לנחלה זו ירושלים ולגאולה שלימה במהרה ולא ידחו לבין המצרים.
translation: And we will precede the words of K"Z, may Moshe be joyful, to explain the verse "Our steps are closely followed as we walk in our streets; our end has come, our days are full, for our end has come." According to what the Maggid from Chernobyl explained the verse "All who pursue her have overtaken her between the straits," and the matter of the strait is a boundary between the fields, and this is a metaphor for the times that are the boundaries and the completion of the end, which will be nullified due to our sins. And it is written in the Zohar that the time of redemption, if it is nullified due to the sins of Israel, will turn into mourning and trouble, Heaven forbid, and this matter is known and publicized. And this is what is meant by "All who pursue her have overtaken Israel between the straits," meaning between the times and their completion, that the days of waiting for redemption then turn into a burden. Thus, it is said here, "Our steps are closely followed as we walk in our streets," meaning they are lying in wait for our steps so that we do not walk in our streets, as Rashi explained, and this means that the end will not come. And when is this so? When our end is near, as the end approaches, which is a time of favor, etc. Therefore, even though we know there is a time of favor, we must be concerned that there will not be a prosecution, Heaven forbid. And according to this, we do not know when our days will be fulfilled, except when our Messiah comes and builds the Holy Temple, then it will be made known to us that our days have been fulfilled, as the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, wrote. And this is what is meant by "When will our days be fulfilled? For our end has come," that it has already come, then it will be made known to us that our days have been fulfilled, and the Holy One, blessed be He, should have mercy on us and grant us to see the salvation of Israel, for we have already seen the awakening of redemption, but due to our sins, it has been delayed and postponed, and "All who pursue her have overtaken us between the straits" is fulfilled in us. And according to the hint, I explained here what they said, may their memory be blessed (Shabbat 118b), "Whoever delights in the Sabbath is given a heritage without boundaries," according to what they said there, that if Israel would keep two Sabbaths properly, they would be redeemed immediately. And in the Midrash, they said one Sabbath, and I explained according to the words in the Zohar that the Sabbath of the night and the Sabbath of the day are like two Sabbaths. And according to this, both are correct together and do not disagree. And behold, our sages have expounded in the Sifrei that this heritage is Jerusalem. And this is what is meant by "Whoever delights in the Sabbath is given a heritage without boundaries," that through the merit of the Sabbath, Israel will merit this heritage, Jerusalem, and complete redemption speedily, and they will not be delayed between the straits.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of redemption and the significance of time in relation to the coming of the Messiah. It emphasizes that the period of suffering, referred to as "between the straits," is a boundary that can be transcended through righteous actions, particularly the observance of Shabbat. The text highlights that the fulfillment of redemption is contingent upon Israel's merit and adherence to divine commandments, suggesting that true salvation will be realized when the Messiah arrives and the Holy Temple is rebuilt. Ultimately, it conveys hope for the imminent redemption while acknowledging the challenges faced due to Israel's sins.

passage_content: ובזהיתבאר לנו ליישב תמיהת המפרשים ז"ל (הובא לעיל)דמתחלהכשבאו משה ואהרן לבשר לישראל בשורת הגאולה כתיב ויאמן העם וישמעו כי פקד ה' את בני ישראל וכי ראה את ענים ויקדו וישתחוו, ואיך נשתנה בחי' מדריגתם בזמן קצר ולא שמעו אל משה, והטעם שנתן הכתוב שלא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה, ודרשו רז"ל שהי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז, לכאורה צ"ב ועדיין התמי' במקומה עומדת, שהרי גם מאז ומקדם היו משוקעים בע"ז ועבדו עבודה קשה, ואעפ"כ שמחו לקראת הבשורה ואיך נשתנה בחי' מצבם כ"כ, אמנם יתבאר עפ"י דרכנו הנ"ל, כי מתחלה כשבאו משה ואהרן אל זקני ישראל ודברו אליהם כל הדבריםאשר דבר ד' פקד פקדתי אתכם וגו', השיגו ישראל שימהר השי"ת ויחיש גאולתם, כנרמז בפקידה כפולה כנזכר לעיל בשם ק"זזלה"ה, ופי' פקד שיש פקידה מכבר לסוף ד' מאות שנה, אך פקדתי אתכםדייקאשאין אתם יכולים להתמהמה, והיו ישראל מייחלים ומצפים שיתקיים אצלם גם הסימן של אנכי ויפרשו מע"ז ויקבלו עליהם עול התורהועי"זיזכולבחי'אחישנה,וז"שויאמן העם וישמעו כי פקד ה' אתבנ"יוגו' ויקדו וישתחוו ושמחו לקראת הבשורה, אמנם עכשיו ראו שתי סתירות בדבר שהי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז ולקבל עליהם עול התורה. מעתה חששו שאינם ראויים לגאולתאחישנהדתליאבזכו, גם ראו שניתוסף להם צרה על צרתם והכבידו מצרים שעבודם ולחצם עליהם, ע"כ אף שהאמינו בבשורת הגאולה וידעו שיש התעוררת מן השמים להחיש גאולתם, אבל כאשר ראושנתגברוהצרות חששו שהפקידה נהפכה מששון לאבל כנ"ל, וזה שנתן הכתוב טעם ולא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה, ועפ"י דרשתם ז"ל שהי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז,ומה"טלא שמעו אל משה בבשורת הגאולה, שא"א שיזכולבחי'אחישנהכל זמן שלא פירשו מע"ז, ועפ"י פשוטו מעבודה קשה שהכבידו המצרים עול שעבודם עליהם ולזהנתייראושנדחה ונתבטל הפקידה.
translation:
And this will clarify for us to resolve the wonder of the commentators, may their memory be blessed (as mentioned above), that at first, when Moses and Aaron came to announce to Israel the tidings of redemption, it is written, "And the people believed, and they heard that the Lord had visited the children of Israel and that He had seen their affliction, and they bowed down and worshipped." How did their level change so quickly, and they did not listen to Moses? The reason given in the text is that they did not listen to Moses because of shortness of spirit and hard work. The sages expounded that it was difficult for them to separate from idolatry. It seems, however, that the question still stands, for even before and earlier they were immersed in idolatry and worked hard, and nevertheless, they rejoiced at the tidings. How then did their situation change so drastically? 

However, it can be explained according to our earlier approach, that initially, when Moses and Aaron came to the elders of Israel and spoke to them all the words that the Lord had spoken, "I have surely visited you," etc., the Israelites understood that the Holy One, blessed be He, would hasten and expedite their redemption, as hinted at in the double mention of "visitation," as mentioned above in the name of Kabbalistic teachings. The term "visited" implies that there has been a visitation from long ago, after four hundred years, but "I have surely visited you" is precise, as you cannot delay. The Israelites were hoping and expecting that the sign of "I am the Lord your God" would also be fulfilled for them, that they would separate from idolatry and accept upon themselves the yoke of the Torah, and thereby merit the aspect of "I will hasten it." 

And this is what is meant by "And the people believed, and they heard that the Lord had visited the children of Israel," and they bowed down and worshipped and rejoiced at the tidings. However, now they saw two contradictions in the matter: that it was difficult for them to separate from idolatry and to accept upon themselves the yoke of the Torah. From now on, they feared that they were not worthy of the redemption of "I will hasten it," and they saw that additional troubles were added to their troubles, and the Egyptians intensified their labor and pressed upon them. Therefore, even though they believed in the tidings of redemption and knew that there was a stirring from above to hasten their redemption, when the troubles intensified, they feared that the visitation had turned from joy to mourning, as mentioned above. 

And this is why the text gives the reason that they did not listen to Moses because of shortness of spirit and hard work, and according to their interpretation, that it was difficult for them to separate from idolatry. For this reason, they did not listen to Moses regarding the tidings of redemption, as it is impossible for them to merit the aspect of "I will hasten it" as long as they had not separated from idolatry. And according to the simple meaning, it was due to the hard work that the Egyptians intensified their burden of servitude upon them, and therefore they were afraid, and the visitation was delayed and nullified.
summary: The passage discusses the initial faith of the Israelites in Moses and Aaron's announcement of redemption, highlighting their joy and willingness to embrace the message of liberation. However, their subsequent inability to listen to Moses is attributed to their overwhelming burdens and the difficulty of abandoning idolatry. The text emphasizes that despite their initial hope for swift redemption, the intensification of their suffering led them to doubt their worthiness for immediate salvation, illustrating the tension between divine promise and human experience. Ultimately, it reflects on the complexities of faith amidst hardship and the necessity of spiritual readiness for redemption.

passage_content: גםאפ"לדהפשטוהדרש על קוטב א' יסובבו, והא בהא תליין, דלפי שהכבידו המצריים עולם עליהם בעבודה קשה, הי' לבם בל עמם מלהתבונן על מצבם הרוחני ולחפש דרך תשובה, כאשר מבשרינו נחזהבעוה"רבגלות המר הזה, שכ"א טרוד בעבודה ובמו"מ כל היום וכל הלילה, ולא נשאר עת פנוי ודעת צלולה לדבר שבקדושה ולתורה ולתפלה כדבעי, וזה יסובב שפלות הרוחני שאנו נתונים בו, ופירשו המפרשים הפסוק (שמואל א' ב') מדוע לא בא בן ישי גם תמול גם היום, כלומר מדוע נתארך הגלות כ"כ, ועדיין לא בא בן ישי גם תמול גם היום, וע"ז בא הכתוב כמשיב אל הלחם, שכל איש ישראל עיניו ולבו נשואות רק אל הלחם, ומחשבותיוורעיוניוטרודים על המחי' ועל הכלכלה, ואין משימין על הלב להתפלל על ישועת ישראל ועל הגאולה, וע"כ נתארך הגלות ועדיין בן דוד לא בא,ועד"זבמצרים ע"י שהיו טרודים בעבודה קשה הי' רוחם ודעתם קצרה מלהתבונןבעניניהנפש,ומה"טהי' קשה בעיניהם להתגבר עליצראדע"זולפרוש ממנה.
translation: Even though the simple meaning and the interpretation regarding the first pole are intertwined, it is because the Egyptians burdened them with hard labor, their hearts were not with them to contemplate their spiritual state and seek a path of repentance. As we see in our time during this bitter exile, each person is preoccupied with work and business all day and all night, and there is no time left or clear mind to engage in matters of holiness, Torah, and prayer as is necessary. This leads to the spiritual lowliness in which we find ourselves. The commentators explain the verse (1 Samuel 2) "Why has the son of Jesse not come, neither yesterday nor today?" meaning why has the exile been prolonged so much, and still the son of Jesse has not come, neither yesterday nor today. To this, the scripture responds as if answering to the bread, that every Jew's eyes and heart are directed only towards bread, and their thoughts and concerns are preoccupied with sustenance and livelihood, and they do not turn their hearts to pray for the salvation of Israel and for redemption. Therefore, the exile has been prolonged, and still the Messiah has not come. Similarly, in Egypt, because they were preoccupied with hard labor, their spirit and understanding were too short to contemplate matters of the soul, and it was difficult for them to overcome their inclination to idolatry and to separate from it.
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual plight of the Jewish people during their enslavement in Egypt, emphasizing how their burdensome labor prevented them from contemplating their spiritual state and seeking repentance. It draws a parallel to the current exile, where individuals are preoccupied with daily struggles and material concerns, leading to a neglect of prayer and spiritual connection. This distraction is seen as a reason for the prolonged exile and the delay in the coming of the Messiah, as people's focus remains on survival rather than on divine redemption. Ultimately, the text highlights the need for spiritual awareness and the importance of prioritizing faith and prayer amidst life's challenges.

passage_content: ויובןבזההק"ושאמרמשרע"ההןבנ"ילא שמעו אלי ואיך ישמעני פרעה,וקושיתהמפרשים ידוע דהרי ק"ופריכאהוא,דבנ"ילא שמעו מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה, וטעם זה לא שייך אצל פרעה, ולדרכנו טעם א' לשניהם, דגם פרעה טען טענה זו שלא נשלם עדיין זמן גלותם של ת' שנה, וא"א שתהי' גאולתם מיד ולא האמין לשלוחי ד',וז"שהןבנ"ילא שמעו אלי, אף שהם מאמינים בני מאמינים, והאמינו לקראת הבשורה של פקד פקדתי, מ"מ חוששים שנדחה הגאולה שלאחישנהכנ"ל, ואיך ישמע אלי פרעה שהוא עומד ומצפה על זה שידחה גאולתם,ובודאייסמוך על סימנים הנ"ל להחזיק בטענתו שאין זה גאולה, וא"שכחהק"ו, ולזה בא תשובתוית' אליהם בפסוק של אחריו, ויצום אלבנ"יוגו' להוציא את בני ישראל מארץ מצרים,שעשאוית' שליח לקרב את ישראל לעבודתוית' ולהחזירם בתשובה,ועי"זיזכו לגאולתאחישנה, להוציא אתבנ"ימיד, ובזה הרגיעה רוחו,שבכחשליחותוית' יהי' בידו להפרישם מע"ז וינצחו התגברות הנורא של כוחותהסט"אאשר רצו למנוע גאולתםעי"ז, וכן הי' שפירשו ישראל מע"ז לפני גאולתם וקבלו עליהם עול התורה ובזכות זה נגאלו.
translation: And it is understood in this that Moshe said, "Behold, the children of Israel did not listen to me, and how will Pharaoh listen to me?" And the commentators' question is known, for it is a difficulty, that the children of Israel did not listen due to shortness of spirit and hard work, and this reason does not apply to Pharaoh. According to our way, there is one reason for both, that Pharaoh also claimed this argument, that the time of their exile of 400 years has not yet been completed, and it is impossible for their redemption to be immediate, and he did not believe the messengers of G-d. And this is what he meant when he said, "The children of Israel did not listen to me," even though they are believers, the children of believers, and they believed in the announcement of "I have surely remembered you." Nevertheless, they are concerned that the redemption might be delayed, as mentioned above, and how will Pharaoh listen to me, as he stands and expects that their redemption will be delayed? And certainly, he relies on the aforementioned signs to support his claim that this is not redemption. And it is understood by way of a fortiori reasoning. And to this, G-d's response came to them in the verse that follows, "And I will command the children of Israel to go out to bring the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt," that He made him a messenger to bring Israel closer to His service and to return them in repentance, and through this they will merit the redemption of "I will redeem you soon," to bring out the children of Israel immediately. And in this, he calmed his spirit, that through his mission it would be in his power to separate them from idolatry and they would overcome the terrible onslaught of the forces of the Other Side that sought to prevent their redemption through this. And so it was that Israel distanced themselves from idolatry before their redemption and accepted upon themselves the yoke of the Torah, and by virtue of this, they were redeemed.
summary: The passage discusses the reluctance of the Israelites to believe in their imminent redemption from Egypt, as they were burdened by their suffering and the oppressive rule of Pharaoh. It highlights that even Pharaoh doubted the timing of their liberation, believing it was not yet due. The text emphasizes that despite their faith, the Israelites feared a delay in their redemption, which led to their hesitance. Ultimately, it conveys that through the mission of Moses as a messenger of God, the Israelites were called to return to their faith and reject idolatry, which would enable their eventual redemption.

passage_content: ואיתאבירושלמי (ר"ה פ"ג ה"ה) אמרר"שבר"יויצום אל בני ישראל על מהציוםעל פרשת שלוח עבדים וכו' עיי"ש.וצ"במדועדוקאבמצוהזו נצטוו ישראל סמוך לגאולתם, ומה ענין תשובה זו על דברימשרע"ההןבנ"ילא שמעו אלי וגו' ויתבאר לדרכנועפימ"שבס' נחלת יעקב (הובאבישמחמשה פ' משפטים)עמ"שבגמ'ב"מ(י' ע"א) פועל יכול לחזור בו אף בחצי יום וכו' מ"ט כי לי בני ישראל עבדים ולא עבדים לעבדים, והקשוהתוס' א"כ יהי' אסור להשכיר עצמו בפועל, ותירצו כיוןדיכוללחזור בו אימת שירצה לאו עבדות היא כלל ע"כ, והנה קשה על צדקתוית"ששמתנהג בדרך התורההאיךמכר אותנו לעבדים, והא אמר ולא עבדיםלעבדים, אך התירוץ הוא כיון שבכל יום ויום זמן גאולה הוא א"כ לאו עבדות הוא כלל עיי"ש לדרכו, נמצא כי במצות שילוח עבדים שנתן הכתוב טעם כי עבדי הם וגו' לא ימכרו ממכרת עבד, נרמז בו סוד הגאולה שלאחישנה, ובכל יומא ויומא זמני',דאל"הלאיצויירכלל עבדות וגלות,דהבוי"תשומר משמרתה של תורה,ולז"אבירושלמי ויצום אלבנ"יציוםעל פרשת שילוח עבדים, שבזכות שיקבלו עליהם מצוה זו יזכו לגאולהבבחי'אחישנה, ועפ"י אמרם ז"ל ה' צלךשהבוי"תמתנהג עם האדם כצל, כדרך שהצל עושה מה שהאדם עושה, כךהבוי"תבמידה שמתנהג האדם מודד לו.
translation: And it is stated in the Jerusalem Talmud (Rosh Hashanah, Chapter 3, Halacha 5) that Rabbi Shimon ben Yochai said: "They commanded the children of Israel regarding the matter of the commandment of sending away slaves," etc. See there. And it is clear that in this commandment, Israel was commanded close to their redemption, and what is the connection of this repentance to the words of Moshe Rabbeinu, who said, "They did not listen to me," etc. It will be explained according to the path of the teachings in the book Nachalat Yaakov (as brought in the joy of Moshe, Parashat Mishpatim) where it is mentioned in the Gemara (Baba Metzia, 10a) that a worker can retract even halfway through the day, etc. The reason is that "for to Me, the children of Israel are servants, and not servants to servants." And Tosafot asks, if so, it should be forbidden for one to hire himself as a worker, and they answered that since he can retract whenever he wants, it is not considered servitude at all. Therefore, it is difficult regarding the righteousness of the Holy One, blessed be He, who conducts Himself according to the way of the Torah: how could He sell us as servants, when it is said, "and not servants to servants"? However, the answer is that since every day is a time of redemption, it is not considered servitude at all, as seen there according to his path. It turns out that in the commandment of sending away slaves, the Torah gave a reason: "For they are My servants," etc., "they shall not be sold as a sale of a slave," hinting at the secret of redemption that will come quickly, and every day is a time for it. For otherwise, it would be conceivable to have complete servitude and exile, as the Holy One, blessed be He, guards the guardianship of the Torah. And thus, it is stated in the Jerusalem Talmud: "And He commanded the children of Israel regarding the commandment of sending away slaves," that in the merit of accepting this commandment upon themselves, they will merit redemption in the aspect of "quickly." And according to what our sages, of blessed memory, said: "The Holy One, blessed be He, conducts with man like a shadow; just as the shadow does what the person does, so the Holy One, blessed be He, measures to him according to the way the person conducts himself."
summary: The passage discusses the commandment of releasing slaves, emphasizing its connection to the theme of redemption and the idea that the Jewish people are ultimately servants of God, not of other humans. It highlights that the observance of this mitzvah is linked to the anticipation of redemption, suggesting that by fulfilling this commandment, the Jewish people can merit a quicker redemption ("אחישנה"). Additionally, it reflects on the relationship between human actions and divine response, illustrating that God's treatment of individuals mirrors their own behavior, akin to the relationship between a person and their shadow.

passage_content: וראיתיבספה"קלפרש אמרם ז"ל (יומא פ"ו ע"א) עבר עלמ"עושב אינו זז משם עדשמוחליןלו, ובעבר על מצות ל"תתליאכפרתו בזמן, דאף שעשה תשובהתשובהתולהויוכ"פמכפר וכןבאידךחלוקי כפרה עיי"ש, וטעם הדבר עפ"י הנודע כי שורש מצות ל"ת הוא משםאלקים,ומ"עשרשו משם הוי' ב"ה, והנה כל השמותהק' המהתואריםע"ש פעולותיוית' כמ"ש רז"לבמד"ר(פ' שמות), וא"כ המה תארים מחודשים בבריאה ונופלים תחת הזמןמשא"כשם הוי' שמורה על מהותו הי' הו' ויהי' הוא למעלה מן הזמן ועברוהו' ועתיד יחד, (עיין ישמח משה ר"פואראד"ה והנ"ל) ובזה נבין שבגאולת מצרים על כי הי'תליאבתשובה שאם יזכו ישראל יקדים הקב"ה גאולתםבבחי'אחישנה, לזה בישרו הקב"הלמשרע"הלכן אמור לבני ישראל אני ד' והוצאתי אתכם וגו', שהיציאה יהי'בכחשם הוי' ב"ה למעלה מן הזמןותליארק בתשובה,ועד"זיתבאר קישור המסורה לכן אמר הנני נותן לו את בריתי שלו',עפי"דהתרגוםיוב"עשקאיעל אלי' שיבשר את הגאולה בסוףיומיא, וגאולה העתידה תהי' ג"כבבחי' זודתליאבתשובה ולא בזמן. שאם יזכו ישראל לעשות תשובה תהי' הגאולהבבחי'אחישנה, ובכל יומא ויומא זמני'.
translation: And you will see in the commentary of the holy Rabbi, may his memory be blessed (Yoma 86a), that if one transgresses a positive commandment, he does not move from there until he is forgiven, and if he transgresses a negative commandment, his atonement is dependent on time, for even though he has repented, the repentance is suspended, and Yom Kippur atones, and similarly in other aspects of atonement, as stated there. The reason for this is according to the known principle that the root of the positive commandments is from the name Elokim, while the root of the negative commandments is from the name Havayah, blessed be He. Now, all the holy names that are described according to His actions, as our sages of blessed memory said in Midrash Rabbah (Parashat Shemot), are therefore new attributes in creation and fall under time, whereas the name Havayah signifies His essence, which was, is, and will be, and is above time, past, present, and future together (see Yismach Moshe, Rabbi P. on the words above). In this, we understand that in the redemption from Egypt, since it was dependent on repentance, if the Jewish people merit, the Holy One, blessed be He, will hasten their redemption in the aspect of "Achishena." For this, the Holy One, blessed be He, announced to Moshe, saying, "I am the Lord, and I have taken you out," etc., that the exodus will be in the aspect of the name Havayah, blessed be He, which is above time, only dependent on repentance. And similarly, the connection of the tradition is explained; therefore, it is said, "Behold, I give him my covenant," according to the translation, "He will announce to him the redemption at the end of days," and the future redemption will be in the aspect of "Zot," dependent on repentance and not on time. For if the Jewish people merit to repent, the redemption will be in the aspect of "Achishena," and every day and every day is a time.
summary: The passage discusses the relationship between repentance (teshuva) and divine redemption, emphasizing that the fulfillment of commandments (mitzvot) is rooted in the divine names associated with God's essence. It highlights that while transgressions can delay atonement, sincere repentance can lead to immediate redemption, as seen in the context of the Exodus from Egypt. The text asserts that God's essence transcends time, allowing for the possibility of redemption to occur outside of temporal constraints, particularly if the Jewish people merit it through their repentance. Ultimately, it conveys the hope that through genuine teshuva, the future redemption will manifest swiftly.

passage_content: וידברמשה כן אלבנ"יולא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה וכו' וידבר משה לפני ה'לאמרהןבנ"ילא שמעו אלי ואיך ישמעני פרעה ואני ערל שפתים, וידבר ה' אל משה ואל אהרן ויצום אלבנ"יואל פרעה וכו' להוציא אתבנ"ימארץ מצרים,יל"דטובאבמקראי קודש אלו,דלכאורההדעת נותן להיפך דלפי שהי' רוחם קצרה מעבודה קשה, הי' להם להטות אוזן קשבתולהמלאשמחה וגיללהבשורהטובה אשר יגאלם ה' ולא יוסיפו לדאבה עוד, ולא שעבודה הקשה תהא סיבה לבל יאבו לשמוע לקול מבשר טוב, גםיל"דבמאמה"כולא שמעו "אל משה" כי תיבות אל משה נראה כמיותרדהאבי'עסיקוקאי.
translation: And Moses spoke thus to the children of Israel, but they did not listen to Moses because of shortness of spirit and hard work, etc. And Moses spoke before the Lord, saying: "The children of Israel did not listen to me, and how will Pharaoh listen to me, for I am of uncircumcised lips?" And the Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron and commanded them to speak to the children of Israel and to Pharaoh, etc., to bring the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt. It is good to ponder these holy scriptures, for it seems that the understanding would suggest the opposite: that since their spirit was short from hard work, they should have inclined their ear to listen and to be filled with joy and gladness at the good tidings that the Lord would redeem them and they would no longer suffer. And that hard work should not be a reason for them not to want to hear the voice of good tidings. Also, it is said, "They did not listen to Moses," for the words "to Moses" seem superfluous, as if to say that they were preoccupied.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author reflects on the paradox of the Israelites' inability to listen to Moses due to their shortness of spirit and hard labor. Despite their suffering, they should have been more receptive to the joyful news of redemption. The text emphasizes that hardship should not diminish one's capacity to hear and embrace hope, highlighting a key Hasidic belief in the transformative power of faith and divine promise amidst adversity. The mention of "אל משה" suggests a deeper connection to the messenger of God, indicating that the message of salvation transcends the immediate struggles of the people.

passage_content: ב)הקשו המפורשים בפסוק הןבנ"ילא שמעו אלי וגו', דהרי ק"ופריכאהואדאצלישראל מבואר הטעם שלא שמעו אליו מקוצר רוח וגו' וזה לא שייך אצל פרעה ויוכל להיות שישמע אליו.
translation: B) The commentators have difficulty with the verse "Behold, they did not listen to me," for it is explained that the reason they did not listen to Him was due to their shortness of spirit, etc. This does not apply to Pharaoh, and it is possible that he will listen to him.
summary: The passage discusses the reasons why the Israelites did not listen to God, attributing their lack of response to their shortness of spirit and suffering. In contrast, it suggests that Pharaoh, despite his hardened heart, might still be able to hear and respond. This highlights a key Hasidic concept that spiritual receptivity is influenced by one's emotional and psychological state, emphasizing the importance of inner freedom and openness to divine communication. The text reflects on the differing capacities for listening and responding to divine calls between the oppressed and the oppressor.

passage_content: ג)צ"בבמאמה"כויצום אלבנ"יואל פרעה וגו' להוציא אתבנ"יוגו' דאינו מבואר מהיצוהאלבנ"יועיין בפי' רש"י ז"ל, אמנם מלשון הפסוק משמע שיצוום להוציא אתבנ"יוזה אין בידם שיוציאו את עצמם.
translation: 3) It is written in the holy text, "And he commanded the children of Israel" (Exodus 5:1) to take out the children of Israel, and it is not clear from the command to the children of Israel. One should examine the commentary of Rashi, may his memory be blessed. However, from the language of the verse, it seems that he commanded them to take out the children of Israel, and this is not in their hands to take themselves out.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author reflects on the command given to Moses to lead the Israelites out of Egypt, emphasizing that the directive implies a divine intervention rather than a human capability. The text suggests that the Israelites, in their state of bondage, lack the ability to liberate themselves, highlighting the necessity of divine assistance in their redemption. This underscores a key Hasidic concept of reliance on God’s will and power for salvation, illustrating the belief that true freedom comes through divine grace. The passage invites contemplation on the relationship between human effort and divine providence in the process of redemption.

passage_content: ד)(בפ' בא) בא אל פרעה כי אני הכבדתי את לבו וגו' למעןשיתיאותותיאלה בקרבו, משמעדמ"שכי אני הכבדתי הוא נתינת טעם לשליחותו לילך אל פרעה,ולכאו' איפכא מסתברא דאם השי"ת הכביד את לבו מה יועיל הליכתו ובוודאי לא ישמע אליו, ורש"י ז"ל פי'שיתישימי שאשית אני, צ"ב מה שדייק לומר אשית אנידייקא.
translation: (d) (In Parashat Bo) "Go to Pharaoh, for I have hardened his heart, etc." in order that I may place these signs in his midst. Since it is stated, "for I have hardened," this gives a reason for his mission to go to Pharaoh. However, it seems the opposite is more logical; if the Holy One, Blessed be He, has hardened his heart, what benefit will his going be, and surely he will not listen to him? And Rashi, of blessed memory, explains that "I have placed" means "I have made." It is puzzling why he specifically chose to say "I have made."
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the divine intention behind God hardening Pharaoh's heart, suggesting that this act serves to fulfill God's purpose in sending Moses to confront him. The apparent contradiction of sending Moses to a ruler whose heart is hardened is addressed, emphasizing that God's actions are ultimately aimed at demonstrating His power and sovereignty. The reference to "שיתיש" indicates a deeper theological insight into the nature of divine intervention and the necessity of human agency in the face of divine will. This reflects key Hasidic concepts of the interplay between divine providence and human responsibility.

passage_content: וכלאלה יתבארו בהקדם דברינו (בפ' שמות) לפרש דברי המדרש למה משה ואהרן תפריעו את העם ממעשיו, אתם למה ודבריכם למה, גם צ"ב ענין טענתו שלמשרע"הלמההרעותהלעם הזה למה זה שלחתני, איך יתכן טענה זו לגבימשרע"העבד נאמןלהשי"תלקבול על שליחותו ולהתרעם עלמדותיוית"ש, ב) גם צ"ב אומרו למה זה שלחתני משמעדכלעיקרהקפידאעל שהוא הי' השליח, וכי בלתי זאת לא יחשוש להרעה אשר ימצא את ישראל,ג) רש"י ז"ל פי' וא"ת מה איכפת לך קובל אני על אשר שלחתני, והוא תמוה לכאורהדאיךיעלה על הדעת לומר מה איכפת לך, הלא זה משה האיש ידענו מה הי' לו שהי' מיצר בצערן של ישראל ובכל צרתם לו צר. ד) תשובת השי"ת עתה תראה וגו' צ"ב עייןפירש"יז"ל.
translation: And all of these will be clarified in advance of our words (in Parashat Shemot) to explain the words of the Midrash regarding why Moshe and Aharon disturbed the people from their actions, you why and your words why. It is also necessary to understand the matter of his claim to Moshe Rabbeinu, "Why have You harmed this people? Why have You sent me?" How can this claim be made regarding Moshe Rabbeinu, the faithful servant of the Holy One, Blessed be He, to complain about his mission and to be upset with His attributes? Additionally, it is necessary to understand his statement, "Why have You sent me?" since he was the messenger, and without this, would he not be concerned about the harm that would befall Israel? Rashi, may his memory be blessed, explains, "And you might say, 'What do you care? I complain about the one who sent me.'" This seems puzzling at first glance, how could it enter one's mind to say, "What do you care?" After all, this is Moshe the man; we know what he had, that he was pained by the suffering of Israel, and in all their affliction, he was afflicted. The response of the Holy One, Blessed be He, is, "Now you will see..." It is necessary to examine the explanation of the holy Rishonim.
summary: The passage discusses the perplexity surrounding Moses' complaints to God about his mission to free the Israelites, questioning why he would express dissatisfaction as a faithful servant. It highlights the tension between Moses' role as a leader and his concern for the suffering of the people, emphasizing the deep emotional connection he has with their plight. The text also reflects on God's response to Moses, suggesting a divine reassurance that will reveal the greater purpose behind the hardships faced by the Israelites. This interaction underscores key Hasidic themes of faith, the struggle with divine will, and the profound bond between a leader and their community.

passage_content: וביארתיעפי"משהקשו רז"ל קושיאלאלקינושהבטיח וגם את הגוי אשריעבודודן "אנכי" וכתיב "ואנכי" אעלך גם עלה, ומדוע נעשה כ"ז ע"י שליחמשרע"ה, ותירצודהבטחתדן אנכי לאהיתהרק אחרי שישלמו ימי השעבוד ארבע מאות שנקצבו בגזירת ברית בין הבתרים, ובאמת לא עברו רקרד"ושנים, ע"כהיתההגאולה ע"י משה עכת"ד. והנה בישובהקושיאדאיךיצאו ישראל קודם זמנם תירצו המפורשיםדקושיהשעבוד השלים, ולכאורהלפי"זנסתר מחמתו תירוץ הנ"ל עלקושיתהבטחת דן אנכי ואנכי אעלך,דמפנישיצאו קודם זמנם ע"כ הי' ע"י שליח, דהרי כבר נשלם זמנם ע"י קושי השעבוד וא"כ הי' ראוי להיות הגאולה ע"י השי"ת בכבודו ובעצמו, ויתכן לומרדזההיתהטענת פרעה אתם למה, הלא הגאולה צריך להיות ע"י השי"ת בעצמו לא על ידי שליח, וכעת אשר שלח אתכם מוכרח לומר כתירוץ הנזכר משום שהוא קודם זמנו, וא"כ דבריכם למה, כי טרם נשלם זמנם איננו מוכרח לשחררם, ואוליעד"זהי' ג"כ טענת אדון הנביאיםמשרע"הלפני השי"ת למההרעותהלעם הזה בקושי השעבוד,ואת"לשעי"זנשלם זמן שעבודם לסוףרד"ושנה, א"כ למה זה שלחתני ומדוע לא גאלתם בכבודך ובעצמך, ובזה יתבארו דברי רש"י ז"ל וא"ת מה איכפת לך ר"ל בקושי השעבוד, שה"ה באמת לטובתן של ישראלשעי"זיושלם זמן שעבודם ויצאו מהר, ע"ז אמר קובל אני על מה ששלחתני, דאם נשלם זמנם הי' לך להוציאם בכבודך ובעצמך.
translation: And you will explain, according to what our sages have asked, a question on the verse "And I will also bring the nation that they will serve," and it is written "And I will also bring you up," and why was all this done through the messenger Moshe Rabbeinu? The answer is that the promise of "And I will also bring you up" was only after the four hundred years of servitude that were decreed in the covenant between the parts, and indeed, not even two hundred years had passed, therefore the redemption was through Moshe, as stated. And behold, in answering the question of how Israel went out before their time, the commentators answered that the servitude was completed, and seemingly according to this, the previous answer regarding the promise of "And I will also bring you up" is contradicted, for since they went out before their time, it should have been through the Holy One, blessed be He, in His glory and essence, and it could be said that this was Pharaoh's argument against them: why, after all, should the redemption be through the Holy One Himself and not through a messenger? And now that He has sent you, it must be said as an answer mentioned, because it is before their time, and therefore your words are why, for since their time has not yet been completed, He is not obligated to free them. And perhaps this was also the argument of the Master of the Prophets, Moshe Rabbeinu, before the Holy One, blessed be He: why have You afflicted this nation with the hardship of servitude? And if you say that their time of servitude was completed after two hundred years, then why have You sent me, and why did You not redeem them in Your glory and essence? And with this, the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, will be clarified: and you may ask, what does it matter to you, regarding the hardship of servitude, for it is indeed for the benefit of Israel that through this their time of servitude will be completed and they will go out quickly. To this, he said, I complain about what You have sent me, for if their time had been completed, it would have been fitting for You to take them out in Your glory and essence.
summary: The passage discusses the tension between God's promise of redemption and the timing of the Israelites' liberation from Egypt, emphasizing that their suffering was necessary to fulfill the predetermined duration of their bondage. It raises the question of why Moses, as a messenger, was chosen for the redemption instead of God Himself intervening directly, especially since the suffering had already completed the designated time. The text reflects on the theological implications of divine timing and the role of human agency in the process of redemption, suggesting that the hardships endured were ultimately for the benefit of the Israelites. It concludes with a critique of the notion that their suffering was merely a means to an end, highlighting the complexity of divine justice and mercy.

passage_content: ועתהנבאר תשובת השי"ת אליו במאמר עתה תראה וגו',דהנהאפ"לעוד בישוב קושיא הנ"ל עה"פ ואנכי אעלך גם עלה,דבאמתעיקר הגאולה הי' ע"י השי"ת בעצמו, ומפורש בכתוב כחצות הלילה אני יוצא בתוך מצרים, והכיתי כל בכור וגו', וכהנה פסוקים רבים, ודרשו רז"ל אני ולא מלאך אני ולא שרף ולא השליח, אמנם שליחותמשרע"ההי' רק לעשות פועל דמיוניואתערותאדלתתא, ולעורר לבבנ"ישיאמינו ויצפו לגאולתם ופדות נפשם, אשר ע"י אמונתם יוכלו לעשותאתערותאדלעילאלהמשיךכחהגאולה, וכמה פסוקים יתנועידיהםע"ז, וכמ"ש להלן אתה תדבר את כל אשראצוךוגו' ואני אקשה את לב פרעה וגו' ולא ישמע אליכם פרעה ונתתי את ידי במצרים ופי' רש"י יד ממשוכו', והוצאתי אתצבאותיוגו' וכדי לחזקהעניןכפל דבריו ואמר וידעו מצרים כי אני ה' בנטותי את ידידייקא, שעיקר הגאולה תהי' ע"יהבוית"שכביכול בכבודו ובעצמו: ושליחות משה הוא רקבבחי' הכנה לעצם הגאולה.
translation: And now we will explain the response of the Blessed Holy One to him in the statement "Now you will see," etc. Behold, the essence of the redemption was indeed through the Blessed Holy One Himself, as it is explicitly written, "At midnight I will go out into the midst of Egypt, and I will strike every firstborn," etc., and there are many such verses. The sages have interpreted, "I [will do it] and not an angel, I [will do it] and not a seraph, and not a messenger." However, the mission of Moses was only to create a figurative action and an awakening from below, to stir the hearts of the children of Israel to believe and to hope for their redemption and the salvation of their souls, which through their faith they could create an awakening from below to draw down the power of redemption, as many verses testify to this. And as it is said later, "You shall speak all that I command you," etc., "and I will harden Pharaoh's heart," etc., "and Pharaoh will not listen to you," and "I will stretch out My hand in Egypt," and Rashi explains, "a hand that is extended," and "I will bring out My hosts," etc. And to strengthen the matter, He repeated His words and said, "And the Egyptians shall know that I am the Lord when I stretch out My hand," precisely, that the essence of the redemption will be through the Blessed Holy One, as it were, in His glory and essence: and the mission of Moses is only a preparation for the essence of the redemption.
summary: The passage emphasizes that the essence of redemption is directly orchestrated by God Himself, as illustrated by the biblical verses that highlight His personal involvement in the Exodus from Egypt. While Moses' role is significant, it is primarily preparatory, aimed at awakening the people's faith and anticipation for their salvation. This underscores the Hasidic belief in the direct relationship between divine action and human faith, where the latter serves to facilitate the former. Ultimately, the text affirms that true redemption is a manifestation of God's glory and presence.

passage_content: ובזהיתבארו לנכון הפסוקים הוא אהרן ומשה אשר אמר ה' להם הוציאו אתבנ"ימארץ מצרים עלצבאותם,דלכאו' תיבת עלצבאותםצ"ב (עיין פי' רש"י ז"ל), גם צ"ב שהכפיל הכתוב עוד הפעם הם המדברים אל פרעה וכו' הוא משה ואהרן,ולפימ"שבא הכתוב להורות ולשלול שלא נטעה לחשובדעצםהגאולההיתהע"י משה, ע"כ אמר הוא אהרן ומשה אשר אמר ה' להם הוציאו אתבנ"ימארץ מצרים עלצבאותםדייקא, היינו לעורר צבאות ופעולת ישראל, וע"י שיחזקובטחונםבדבר יציאתם, דיןגרמאלעורראתערותאדלעילא, וכדי לחזקהעניןכפל הכתוב לומר הם המדברים אל פרעהדייקא, וזה יסובבאתערותאדלעילאלהוציא את ישראל ע"י הקב"ה ממצרים, הוא משה ואהרן רק זאתהיתהפעולת משה ואהרן, אבל עצם הגאולה הי' ע"י השי"ת בעצמו, אמנםמשרע"החשב בנפשו כי רצון השי"ת שתהי' גם עצם הגאולה בשליחותו, ע"כ סירב ומיאןבהשליחותונשמט מלילך, ובאבקובלנאלפני הקב"ה בטענת למההרעותהכנזכר.
translation: And in this it is clarified correctly the verses, it is Aaron and Moses whom the Lord said to them, "Take out the children of Israel from the land of Egypt according to their hosts," and the term "according to their hosts" is to be examined (see Rashi's commentary). It is also to be examined why the text repeats that they are the ones speaking to Pharaoh, etc., it is Moses and Aaron. According to what is explained, the text comes to teach and to negate that we should not think that the essence of the redemption was through Moses; therefore, it says, "It is Aaron and Moses whom the Lord said to them, 'Take out the children of Israel from the land of Egypt according to their hosts'" specifically, meaning to awaken the hosts and the action of Israel, and by strengthening their trust in the matter of their departure, it will draw down an awakening from above. And to strengthen the matter, the text repeats to say, "They are the ones speaking to Pharaoh" specifically, and this will cause an awakening from above to take out Israel through the Holy One, Blessed be He, from Egypt. It is Moses and Aaron, but this was the action of Moses and Aaron; however, the essence of the redemption was by the Blessed One Himself. Nevertheless, Moses thought in his heart that it was the will of the Blessed One that the essence of the redemption should also be through his agency, therefore he refused and declined the mission and was hesitant to go, and he argued before the Holy One, Blessed be He, with the claim of "Why have You done evil to this people," as mentioned.
summary: The passage emphasizes that the redemption of the Israelites from Egypt was ultimately orchestrated by God Himself, despite the roles played by Moses and Aaron as His messengers. It highlights the importance of their actions in strengthening the faith and resolve of the Israelites, which in turn facilitated divine intervention. The repetition of their names serves to clarify that while they were instrumental, the essence of the redemption was a direct act of God. Moses' initial reluctance to accept the mission reflects his deep understanding of the divine will and the significance of the redemption process.

passage_content: וע"זבא תשובת השי"ת אליו לא כמו שאתה סובר שעצם הגאולה יהי' על ידך, כי באמת יושלם הזמן ע"י קושי השעבוד ואקיים הבטחת ואנכי אעלך, והשליחות שלך הוא רקבבחי' הכנה לעשותאתערותאדלעילא, וזהו אומרו עתה תראה אשר אעשה לפרעה, ר"ל אחר שכבר התחלת לעשות איזה פעולה במקצת, למען יתעוררהעניןבאתערותאדלתתא, מעתה תראה את אשר אעשהדייקאבכבודי ובעצמי כי ביד חזקה ישלחם וכו' כוונתו על מכת בכורות, דאז ישלחם ביד חזקה כמ"ש ותחזק מצרים על העם, ובמכה זאת התרה לו ראשונה כפי' רש"י בפסוק הנה אנכי הורג את בנך בכורך, וזאת המכה אעשה בעצמי, ומכות האחרות הם רק למען יתעורר לבבנ"ישלא יתייאשו עצמם מן הגאולה ח"ו ע"י שהיו משוקעים בכור הברזל במ"ט שערי טומאה.
translation: And in response to this, the answer of the Holy One, Blessed be He, to him is not as you suppose that the essence of the redemption will be through you, for in truth the time will be completed through the severity of the servitude, and I will fulfill the promise, and I will elevate you. Your mission is only in the aspect of preparation to create an awakening from below. This is what is meant by the saying, "Now you will see what I will do to Pharaoh," meaning after you have already begun to perform some action to a certain extent, so that the matter will be awakened through an awakening from below. From now on, you will see what I will do, specifically with My honor and My self, for with a strong hand I will send them out, etc. His intention is regarding the plague of the firstborn, for then He will send them out with a strong hand, as it is said, "And Egypt was strengthened against the people," and with this plague, He will act Himself, as Rashi explains in the verse, "Behold, I will kill your firstborn son." And this plague I will do Myself, while the other plagues are only so that the hearts of the children of Israel will be stirred, so that they do not despair of the redemption, Heaven forbid, due to being immersed in the iron furnace in the forty-nine gates of impurity.
summary: The passage emphasizes that the ultimate redemption is not solely dependent on human efforts but is fulfilled by divine intervention, particularly through the suffering of exile. The role of individuals is to prepare for this divine awakening, as indicated by their initial actions that prompt a higher spiritual response. The text highlights that while the plagues serve to awaken the people, the final act of redemption, specifically the death of the firstborn, is executed directly by God, underscoring His sovereignty and the necessity of divine action in the process of salvation.

passage_content: ויתכןדזאתהיתההסיבה אשרבנ"ילא שמעו אל משה, דלפי שראו את קושי השעבוד שהוא להשלים הזמן, אותה נפשם שיקיים השי"ת הבטחת ואנכי אעלך ויוציאם בעצמו לא ע"י משה, וזהו אומרו ולא שמעו אל משהדייקא, שהוא יהי' השליח, והטעם מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה,דלולאקושי השעבוד היו תוליםדמחמתשלא נשלם הזמן עדיין מוכרח להיות הגאולה ע"ימשרע"הוכתירוץ הנ"ל, אמנם כיון שקצרה רוחם מכובד השעבוד שהוא כדי להשלים הזמן, ע"כ לא שמעו אל משהדייקא,ומשרע"הפירש שיחתו לפני השי"ת ואמר הןבנ"ילא שמעו "אלי"דייקאמחמתקושיתממנ"פהנ"ל, ואיך ישמעני פרעה להוציאם קודם זמנם, כי פרעה כבר טען טענה זו, דאם הגאולה ע"י שליח בשר ודם הרי זה מורה שעדיין לא נשלם זמנם לצאת כנ"ל.
translation: And it is possible that this was the reason why they did not listen to Moses, for since they saw the difficulty of the servitude, which was to complete the time, their souls were hoping that the Holy One, Blessed be He, would fulfill the promise "And I will bring you up" and take them out Himself, not through Moses. And this is what it means when it says "and they did not listen to Moses" specifically, that he would be the messenger. The reason was due to shortness of spirit and hard work, for were it not for the difficulty of the servitude, they would have been relying on the fact that since the time had not yet been completed, the redemption must come through Moses. However, since their spirit was short because of the heaviness of the servitude, which was to complete the time, therefore they did not listen to Moses specifically. And Moses expressed his concern before the Holy One, Blessed be He, and said, "Behold, the children of Israel did not listen to me," specifically because of the difficulty from the aforementioned, and how will Pharaoh listen to me to take them out before their time, for Pharaoh had already claimed this argument, that if the redemption is through a mortal messenger, it indicates that their time to leave has not yet been completed, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the Israelites' reluctance to listen to Moses due to their intense suffering and the belief that their redemption would come directly from God rather than through a human intermediary. Their shortness of spirit, caused by the harshness of their bondage, led them to doubt the timing of their liberation, as they felt it was not yet the appointed time for redemption. Moses, in turn, expresses his concern to God about Pharaoh's refusal to release them, highlighting the theological tension between divine timing and human agency in the process of redemption. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the struggle between faith in divine promise and the harsh realities of earthly suffering.

passage_content: וע"זבא תשובת השי"ת להודיע למשה אשר יגלה אוזן ישראל, כי באמת עיקר הגאולה תהי' ע"י השי"ת בעצמו, ושליחות משה הוא רק לעשותאתערותאדלתתאשיעוררו את לבבם ויתנו אומן בישועת השי"ת, וזאת ימשוךאתערותאדלעילאשיגמור השי"ת בעצמו את הגאולה, וזהו אומרו וידבר ה' אל משה ואל אהרן ויצום אלבנ"יאין צואלא לשון זירוז כוונתו ששליחות משה הוא רק לזרזם כדי שיהי'אתערותאדלתתא,וכחזה יהי' סיבה להוציא אתבנ"ימאמ"צ, היינושעי"זיוציא השי"ת כביכול בכבודו ובעצמו את בני ישראל מארץ מצרים ותיבת להוציאקאיעל השי"ת.
translation: And this is the answer of the Holy One, Blessed be He, to inform Moses that he will reveal to the ears of Israel, for indeed the essence of the redemption will be through the Holy One Himself, and the mission of Moses is only to awaken them to give their hearts to the salvation of the Holy One, and this will draw the awakening from above to complete the redemption by the Holy One Himself. And this is what it means when it says, "And the Lord spoke to Moses and to Aaron and commanded them to the children of Israel," for the term "command" implies a sense of urgency; his intention is that the mission of Moses is only to urge them so that there will be an awakening from below, and as it is seen, it will be a reason to bring the children of Israel out of Egypt. That is, the Holy One, Blessed be He, will, as it were, with His honor and His essence, take the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt, and the initiative to take them out will be attributed to the Holy One.
summary: The passage emphasizes that the ultimate redemption of the Jewish people will be accomplished by God Himself, while Moses' role is to inspire and awaken the hearts of the Israelites to trust in God's salvation. This "at'arat d'letata" (awakening from below) serves as a catalyst for the "at'arat d'le'ela" (awakening from above), leading to divine intervention. The text highlights that Moses' mission is to encourage the people, making them receptive to God's imminent redemption, which will be executed with divine honor and presence.

passage_content: היוצאמדברינו שכל עיקר שמיאןמשרע"הבשליחותו והקביל לפני השי"ת על שנתן המשרה הזאת על שכמו, הי' לאשר נכספה וגם כלתה נפשו שיהי' הגאולה ע"י השי"ת בעצמו, אמנם כאשר ראה כי הולך אל פרעה פעם אחר פעם ואולי הכיר בפרעה כי מעט נתרכך לבבו, עלה מורא על ראשו אולי בין כך יתרצה פרעה לשלחם ע"י שליחותו, ולא יהי' הגאולה ע"יהבוית"שבעצמו, ע"כ הי' בדעתו להשמיט עצמו מן השליחות, ולזה בא מאמר השי"ת אליו בא אל פרעה והתרה בו, ואין לך לחוש אולי יאבה ויסכים פרעה לשלחם, כי אני הכבדתי את לבו וכו' ובוודאי לא ישלח אותם, ושלא תאמר א"כ השליחות למה, ע"ז אמר למעןשיתיוכו' כי עיקר השליחות הוא למען לעשות פועל דמיוניואתערותאדלתתאשיזכועי"זשאשים "אני" אתאותותיאלה בקרבו, כוונתו למכות בכורות ויהי' הגאולה ע"י השי"ת בכבודו ובעצמו, וזהו שפי' רש"י למעןשיתישימי שאשית "אני"דייקאבכבודי ובעצמי, וכימי צאתנו מארץ מצרים יראנו נפלאות.
translation: The essence of our discussion is that the main purpose of Moshe Rabbeinu's mission was to plead before the Holy One, Blessed be He, regarding the fact that He placed this burden upon him. He yearned and his soul longed for the redemption to come through the Holy One Himself. However, when he saw that he was going to Pharaoh time and again, and perhaps he recognized that Pharaoh's heart had softened a little, fear arose in his mind that perhaps Pharaoh would agree to send them away through his agency, and the redemption would not be through the Holy One Himself. Therefore, he intended to exempt himself from the mission. To this, the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him, "Go to Pharaoh and warn him," and you need not worry that perhaps Pharaoh will agree to send them away, for I have hardened his heart, etc., and he will certainly not send them. And so you should not ask, "What is the purpose of the mission then?" To this, it was said, "In order that I may set My signs among them," for the essence of the mission is to create a spiritual awakening and to ignite the fire of the Divine Presence within them, with the intention of the plagues of the firstborn, and the redemption will be through the Holy One, Blessed be He, in His glory and essence. This is what Rashi explains, "In order that I may set My signs," meaning "I" with My honor and My essence, and "As on the day we left the land of Egypt, He will show us wonders."
summary: The passage discusses the divine mission of Moses as a messenger to Pharaoh, emphasizing his deep desire for redemption to come directly from God. Despite his initial hesitations, God reassures Moses that Pharaoh's heart is hardened intentionally, ensuring that the redemption will be a miraculous act of divine intervention. The ultimate purpose of Moses' mission is to evoke a spiritual awakening within the people, leading to their liberation through God's direct involvement, as highlighted by the reference to the plagues and the miraculous nature of the Exodus. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the importance of divine presence and intervention in the process of redemption.

passage_content: ועפ"יפשוטואפ"לבמאמה"כולא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה,שהתוה"קמלמדת זכות על ישראל,דלכאורהיקשהקושיתהמדרש וכי יש לך אדם שמתבשר בשורה טובה ואינו שמח, ומה שתירצו במדרש ומ"ט לומר לא שמעו אל משה, אלא שהי' קשה בעיניהם לפרוש מע"ז, לכאורה גם זה אינו מושג, הלא באמת הוא הבל הבלים, וכבר הי' מושרש בישראל דרך האמיתי בעבודת השי"תמהאבוה"ק, והיו ביניהם שבט לוי כולם צדיקים עובדי ה', ומשה ואהרן הוכיחו אותם לפרוש מדרכיהע"ז, ומה גם שידעו שבזהתליאגאולתםכאמרז"ל, ומדוע הי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז שאין בו ממש ומועיל, אמנם התירוץ על זה מבואר בפשוטו של מקרא באמרו מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה,ועפימ"דבילקוט פ' בשלח (רמז רל"ד בשם מדרשאבכיר) והמים להם חומה חמה כתיב, שירד ס"מ ואמר רבש"ע לא עבדו ישראל ע"ז במצרים ואתה עושה להם נסיםוכו', מיד השיב לו הקב"ה שוטה שבעולם וכי לדעתם עבדוה, והלא לא עבדו אלא מתוך שעבוד ומתוך טירוף דעת, ואתה דן שוגג כמזידואונס כרצון וכו' עכ"ד המדרש, עיין בדברנו (לעילבפ' שמות) שפירשנודבחי' האונס הי' ע"י כוחות הטומאה שהתגברו על ישראל בדרך כפי' עד שכאונס נחשבו עיי"ש, ועפ"י פשוטו מבואר האונס בכתוב מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה, שע"י כובד השעבוד קצרה רוחם ודעתם ולא יכלו להתבונן בשפלות מצבם ולעשות תשובה ראוי', ולטעם זה לא שמעו אל משה, ובזה יאותכחהק"ושדןמשרע"ההןבנ"ילא שמעו אלי ואיך ישמעני פרעה, וכבר הקשודק"ופריכאהוא. דהרי אצל פרעה לא יצדק טעם הכתוב מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה אמנם מה שהי' לגבי ישראל באונס, הי' לגבי פרעה ברצון, שברצון נפשו התנגד לדברי ה' וא"שכחהק"ו.
translation: And according to the simple interpretation, it is said that all heard Moses due to shortness of spirit and hard work, for the Torah teaches merit for Israel. At first glance, the Midrash's question is difficult: is there a person who receives good news and is not happy? And what the Midrash answers, that they did not listen to Moses, but it was hard for them to separate from idolatry, at first glance, this too is incomprehensible. For it is truly vanity of vanities, and the true path of serving the Holy One, blessed be He, was already rooted in Israel, and among them was the tribe of Levi, all righteous servants of the Lord. And Moses and Aaron rebuked them to separate from the ways of idolatry, especially since they knew that their redemption depended on this, as our Sages have said. And why was it hard for them to separate from idolatry, which has no substance and is not beneficial? However, the answer to this is explained in the simple meaning of the verse, saying, "due to shortness of spirit and hard work." And according to the Midrash in Likkutei Parashat Beshalach (Remez 234 in the name of Midrash Abkir), it is written, "And the waters were a wall for them," that the Satan descended and said to the Holy One, blessed be He, "Did Israel not serve idolatry in Egypt, and You are performing miracles for them?" Immediately, the Holy One, blessed be He, replied to him, "Fool of the world! Do they think they served it? They did not serve it except out of servitude and madness, and you judge a mistake as if it were intentional and coercion as if it were willful," etc. Thus concludes the Midrash. Refer to our words (above in Parashat Shemot) where we explained that the coercion was by the forces of impurity that overpowered Israel in such a way that they were considered as if coerced. And according to its simple meaning, the coercion is explained in the verse "due to shortness of spirit and hard work," that due to the heaviness of the servitude, their spirit and understanding were shortened, and they could not contemplate the lowliness of their state and make proper repentance. And for this reason, they did not listen to Moses. And in this, it is fitting to refute the question of the Holy One, blessed be He, who said to Moses, "They did not listen to me, and how will Pharaoh listen to me?" And the question is already established, for with Pharaoh, the reason of the verse "due to shortness of spirit and hard work" does not apply. However, what was regarding Israel as coercion was for Pharaoh a matter of will, for he willingly opposed the words of the Lord, and it is clear.
summary: The passage discusses the difficulty the Israelites faced in heeding Moses due to their "shortness of spirit" and the burdens of hard labor, which clouded their ability to recognize their dire situation and repent. It emphasizes that their inability to respond was not a reflection of willful disobedience but rather a consequence of their oppression, likening their state to that of being forced into idolatry under duress. The text also contrasts the Israelites' plight with Pharaoh's deliberate rejection of God's message, highlighting the distinction between coerced actions and intentional defiance. Ultimately, it illustrates the profound impact of external oppression on spiritual awareness and responsiveness.

passage_content: וידברה' אל משה ואל אהרן ויצום אלבנ"יואל פרעה מלך מצרים,ופירש"יז"לצוהעליהם להנהיגם בנחת ולסבול אותם, ואל פרעה מלך מצרים צום עליו לחלוק לו כבוד בדבריהם, וקשהדציוויזה הי' צ"ל כשהלכו בפעם הראשונה בשליחותם אל ישראל ואל פרעה, אז הי' ראוי לצוות להם על ככה להנהיגם בנחת ולחלוק כבוד לפרעה, ומדוע נצטוו ע"זדייקאבעת ההוא, ובספר חנוכת התורה מהגאוןהר"רהעשילזצ"למקראקאהקשה על מה שכתב רש"י ז"ל צום לחלוק לו כבוד בדבריהם, ממהדאיתאבגמרא (זבחים ק"ב ע"א) כל חרון אף שבתורה נאמר בו רושם וכו' ופריך והכתיב ויצא מעם פרעה בחרי אף ולא א"ל ולא מידי, ומשני אמר ר"ל סטרו ויצא, ופריך ומי אמר ר"ל הכי והכתיב ונצבת לקראתו וגו', אמר ר"ל מלך הוא והסביר לו פנים,ור"יאמר רשע הואוהעיזפניך בו, ומשניאיפוךדר"ילר"ל, והנה רש"י ז"ל פי' לעיל (בפ' שמות) עה"פויחראף ה' וגו'דכלחרון אף שבתורה עושה רושם שניטלה הכהונהוכו', א"כ קשהכקושיתהגמרא מהאדכתיבויצא מעם פרעה בחרי אף מאי רושם הי' שם,ועכצ"לכר"לדסטרוויצא, וגם האדכתיבונצבת לקראתו צריך לפרשהעיזפניך כנגדו כנ"ל, והרי כאןפירש"יצום לחלוק כבוד למלכות א"כ דברי רש"י ז"לסותריןאהדדי ע"כקושיתו, ולכאורה קושיא זו הי' יכול להקשות מפסוק זה ויצא מעם פרעה בחרי אףדבאותוהפסוק כתיב וירדו כל עבדיך אלה אלי,ופירש"יחלק כבוד למלכות שהרי בסוף ירד פרעה בעצמו אליו בלילהוכו',ולפי"דרש"י ז"ל יש סתירה בפסוק גופי' מרישי' לסיפי' ומדוע הוצרך להביא ממרחק לחמו.
translation: And Hashem spoke to Moses and Aaron and commanded them to speak to the children of Israel and to Pharaoh, king of Egypt. And it is explained that He commanded them to lead them gently and to bear with them, and to Pharaoh, king of Egypt, to show him honor in their words. It is difficult to understand why this command was necessary when they first went on their mission to Israel and to Pharaoh; it would have been appropriate to command them to lead them gently and to show honor to Pharaoh then. Why were they specifically commanded about this at that time? In the book of the dedication of the Torah, the great Rabbi HaRashash, zt"l, from Krakow, questions what Rashi, zt"l, wrote about showing him honor in their words, based on what is stated in the Gemara (Zevachim 102a) that every anger mentioned in the Torah leaves a mark, etc. And it asks, but it is written, "And he went out from Pharaoh in anger," and he did not say anything to him. And it answers that R' Levi said he struck him and went out. And it asks, "Did R' Levi really say this?" and it is written, "And you shall stand to meet him," etc. R' Levi said he is a king and he showed him a pleasant face, and R' Yochanan said he is wicked and you should not show him a pleasant face. And it answers that R' Levi's interpretation is reversed. And behold, Rashi, zt"l, explained above (in Parshat Shemot) on the verse "And the anger of Hashem burned," that every anger in the Torah makes a mark that the priesthood was taken away, etc. Therefore, it is difficult as the Gemara's question is based on the verse "And he went out from Pharaoh in anger," what mark was there? And it must be according to R' Levi that he struck him and went out. Also, the verse "And you shall stand to meet him" needs to be interpreted as not showing him a pleasant face, as mentioned. And here Rashi, zt"l, explained to show honor to the monarchy, so the words of Rashi, zt"l, contradict each other, hence his question. At first glance, this question could have been raised from this verse "And he went out from Pharaoh in anger," for in that same verse it is written, "And all your servants shall come down to me," and Rashi explained to show honor to the monarchy, since in the end Pharaoh himself came down to him at night, etc. According to Rashi's interpretation, there is a contradiction in the verse itself from the beginning to the end, and why was it necessary to bring him from afar to feed him?
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the divine command to Moses and Aaron to lead the Israelites gently and to show respect to Pharaoh, emphasizing the importance of honoring authority even in the face of oppression. The text raises questions about the timing and necessity of this command, particularly in light of the tension between showing respect and the anger directed at Pharaoh. Theological insights highlight the complexity of leadership, the need for humility, and the balance between reverence for authority and the pursuit of justice. Ultimately, it reflects on the nature of divine instruction and the moral responsibilities of leaders in challenging circumstances.
