passage_content: והנ"לליישבדהנהבגמרא שם איתאא"רינאי לעולם תהא אימת מלכות עליךדכתיבוירדו כל עבדיך אלה אלי, ואילו לדידי' לאקאמרלי', ר' יוחנן אמר מהכא (מלכים א' י"ח) ויד ה'היתהאל אלי' וישנס מתניווירץלפני אחאב, וכתבהרלב"ג(מלכים א' כ"ב) וז"ל: ואמנם חלק לו כבוד עתה לא קודם זה, כי ידמה שגם הוא סר מאחרי הבעלים והאמיןבהשי"תולזה הסכים לאלי' בהריגת נביאי הבעל, אך קודם זה שהי' בתכלית הרוע לא חלק לו כבוד, וכן לא חלק לו כבוד כשחטא בדבר נבות עכ"ל, ומבוארלהדיאכדבריו בילקוט פ' משפטים עה"פ ונשיא בעמך לאתאורועי' ויואל משה ח"א סי' קל"ג שהארכנו בזה) אמנם כל זה רק במלכי ישראל שהם משועבדים למצות התורה, גם יש אצלם מצות מיוחדות כמבואר בפסוק, ע"כ כל מלך הפונה מדרך התורה אינו בכלל מלך שצריך לחלוק לו כבוד,משא"כבמלכיאוה"עמחוייביםאנו לחלוק להם כבוד בכל אופן, שהרי הם עובדי ע"זבלא"הואעפי"כצותההתוה"קלחלוק להם כבוד כ"ז שגזירת השי"ת עלינו להיות בגלות בין האומות, ורק כשנתמלא סאתם והגיע זמן איבודם אז איןמחוייביםעוד לחלוק להם כבוד. ודבר זה א"א לשקול בדעת בנ"א אם הגיע קיצם ונתמלא סאתם, ושיקול זה רק בדעתו של א"לדיעותה', כי באמת תלוי זה גם במעשה ישראל ובזכותם, וכמו שפי'האוה"חהק' (פ' לך)עה"כודור רביעי ישובו הנה כי לא שלםעוןהאמורי עד הנה,וזל"קמכאן מוכח שעון האמורי מעכב הכניסה, ובמעשה אשר סידר ה' בתורתו הנעימה יגיד, כיעוןהמרגלים הוא אשר סבב עכבת דור היוצא ממצריםוכו', וזולת המרגלים שהרשיעו היו נכנסים הדור היוצא וכו' והלא לא שלםעוןהאמורי עדיין, אכן כוונתהכ' הוא ע"ד אומרם ז"ל במס' (ברכות דף ז' ע"ב) בפסוק כבלע רשע צדיק ממנו,צדיק ממנו בולע צדיק גמור אינו בולע ע"כ, פי' כי אם יהי' הרשע עדיין יש בידו קצת זכות, ויבוא צדיק שרובו זכיות להתגרות בו, איןכחבצדיק לאבדו, כי עדיין יש לרשע להשתלם זכות הנשאר לו בעוה"ז, והרשע יתנקם מהצדיק להיות שיש ביד הצדיק מהתיעוב שאינו צדיק גמור, אבלכשיהי' צדיק גמור הגםשישארלרשע חלק מהטוב יפקע כלילתו, וכן אם יהי' הרשע מוחלט ונגמר דינו למות, בכל עושה ה' שליחותו לאבדו וכל הקודם בו זכה ואפילו אינו צדיק גמור יוכלו לאבדו מן העולם וכו' עיי"ש באריכות, מבואר מזה שהשגת קיצם של הרשעיםליאבדמן העולם תלוי גם במעשה וזכותם של ישראל, ואיןבדעתינולשקול ולהכריע בזה רק הקב"ה א"ל דעות ה' לו נתכנו עלילות, וכל עוד שלאנתבררשכבר הגיע קצםליאבדמן העולםמחוייביםלחלוק כבוד למלכי עכו"ם.
translation: And the above is to be settled, for in the Gemara there it is stated: Rabbi Inai said, "The fear of the kingdom should always be upon you," as it is written, "And all your servants shall come down to me." And if it were up to me, I would not say this. Rabbi Yochanan said from here (Kings I 18), "And the hand of the Lord was upon me," and I girded up my loins and ran before Achav. And Rabbeinu Bachya wrote (Kings I 22) as follows: "And indeed, he was honored now, not before this, for it seems that he also turned away from the Baalim and believed in the Holy One, Blessed be He, and for this he agreed with Eliyahu in the killing of the prophets of Baal. However, before this, when he was in the utmost wickedness, he was not honored, and he was not honored when he sinned regarding the matter of Navot." Thus far his words, and it is explicitly explained according to his words in the Yalkut, Parashat Mishpatim, on the verse "And a prince among your people shall not come to harm," and in Yoel Moshe, Part I, Siman 133, where we elaborated on this. However, all this is only regarding the kings of Israel, who are subservient to the commandments of the Torah. They also have special commandments, as explained in the verse. Therefore, any king who turns away from the path of the Torah is not included in the category of a king to whom honor should be given. Whereas, in the case of the kings of the nations, we are obligated to give them honor in any case, for they are idol worshippers, and yet, according to the Torah, we must give them honor as long as the decree of the Holy One, Blessed be He, is upon us to be in exile among the nations. Only when their measure is full and the time of their destruction arrives, then we are no longer obligated to give them honor. And this matter cannot be weighed in the minds of men whether their time has come and their measure is full; this consideration is only in the mind of the Holy One, Blessed be He, for indeed, it depends also on the actions of Israel and their merit. And as it is said in the Torah (Parashat Lech), "For the iniquity of the Amorite is not yet complete," and it is clear from here that the iniquity of the Amorite delays the entry. And in the matter that the Holy One, Blessed be He, arranged in His pleasant Torah, it will be said, as the sin of the spies is what caused the delay of the generation that went out of Egypt, etc. And except for the spies who sinned, the generation that went out would have entered, etc., and yet the iniquity of the Amorite was not yet complete. However, the intention of the verse is in accordance with what our sages, of blessed memory, say in Tractate Berakhot (7b) on the verse "The wicked swallow the righteous," that the righteous swallow the completely righteous, but not the completely righteous. The explanation is that if the wicked still have some merit, and a righteous person who has mostly merits comes to provoke him, the righteous does not have the power to destroy him, for the wicked still has the merit that remains to him in this world. And the wicked will take revenge on the righteous because the righteous has some deficiency that he is not completely righteous. But when the righteous is completely righteous, even if the wicked has a portion of good remaining, it will be completely nullified. And likewise, if the wicked is absolute and his judgment is sealed for death, in all that the Holy One, Blessed be He, does, His mission is to destroy him, and whoever is first in this matter is successful, even if he is not completely righteous, he can destroy him from the world, etc. It is explained at length there. From this, it is clear that the reaching of the end of the wicked to be destroyed from the world also depends on the actions and merits of Israel, and we do not have the ability to weigh and decide on this; only the Holy One, Blessed be He, knows His thoughts, for it is said, "For the plots are prepared for the wicked." And as long as it is not clarified that their time has indeed come to be destroyed from the world, we are obligated to give honor to the kings of the nations.
summary: The passage discusses the obligation to show respect to non-Jewish kings, emphasizing that this duty persists as long as the Jewish people are in exile and under divine decree. It highlights that the status of these kings is contingent upon their adherence to the Torah, and that their eventual downfall is linked to the actions and merits of the Jewish people. The text underscores the belief that the timing of the downfall of the wicked is determined by God alone, and that human judgment cannot ascertain when this will occur. Ultimately, the respect owed to these rulers is a reflection of the broader relationship between divine justice and the moral conduct of Israel.

passage_content: והנהכשהי'מרע"האצל פרעה בפעם האחרון כשאמר לו פרעה לך מעלי השמר לך אל תוסף ראות פני וגו', השיגמרע"השכבר הגיע פרעה לתכלית הרשעות וכבר הוחלט ונגמר דינו למיתה, ומעתה לא הי' צריך עוד לחלוק לו כבוד וע"כ סטרו על פניו ויצא כדרשת ר"ל, ומה שאמר לו וירדו כל עבדיך אלה אלי וחלק כבוד למלכות, סובב על אותו הזמן שבא פרעה אלמרע"הוהכניע עצמו לפניו ואמר לו קומו צאו מתוך עמו וגו' וברכתם גם אותי, שעשה קצת תשובה לפי ערכו ולא הי' כ"כ מוחלט ברע באותה שעה ע"כ חלק לו כבוד בדבריו, ולא קשהקושיתהגאון ז"לדהחיובלחלוק כבוד למלכותתליאבאיכות בחינתו שהוא עומד באותה שעה.
translation: And behold, when Moshe Rabbeinu was with Pharaoh for the last time, when Pharaoh said to him, "Get away from me; take heed to yourself; do not add to see my face," Moshe Rabbeinu understood that Pharaoh had already reached the pinnacle of wickedness, and his judgment had been decided and sealed for death. From now on, there was no need to show him honor, and therefore he struck him on the face and left, as the interpretation of R. Levi states. And what Pharaoh said, "And all your servants will come down to me," and he showed honor to the monarchy, refers to the time when Pharaoh came to Moshe Rabbeinu, humbled himself before him, and said, "Get up, go out from among my people," and "Bless me also," for he had done a bit of repentance according to his level, and at that moment he was not so completely wicked. Therefore, he showed him honor in his words. And the question of the Gaon, may his memory be blessed, is not difficult, for the obligation to show honor to the monarchy depends on the quality of his standing at that moment.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the moment when Moses confronts Pharaoh, highlighting the transition of Pharaoh's character from a state of potential repentance to one of complete wickedness. The text emphasizes that Pharaoh's initial humility and acknowledgment of Moses' authority allowed for a temporary respect, but ultimately, his fate was sealed due to his persistent evil. The Hasidic insight reflects on the nature of repentance and the divine judgment that follows, illustrating the tension between human agency and the predetermined outcomes of one's moral choices.

passage_content: ואיתאבמד"רפ' בא (פט"זסי' ג') משכו וקחו לכם צאןהה"ד(תהלים צ"ז) יבושו כל עובדי פסל. בשעה שאמר הקב"ה למשה לשחוט הפסח א"ל משהרבוןהעולם הדבר הזההאיךאני יכול לעשות, אי אתה יודע שהצאןאלהיהןשל מצרים הן וכו' א"ל הקב"ה חייך אין ישראליוצאיןמכאן עד שישחטואלהימצרים לעיניהן שאודיע להן שאיןאלהיהעכו"םכלום, גם איתאבמד"רפ' זו (פ' ו' סי' ה') ולא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה שהי' קשה בעיניהם לפרוש מע"ז, וזה שטעןמרע"האל השי"ת הלא הגאולה א"א שתהי' כ"א שתקדים הכנעת ע"ז ע"י ישראל כמבואר במדרש הנ"ל,ובנ"יעדיין דבוקים בע"ז ולא ירצו לשחוטאלהימצרים,וז"שהןבנ"ילא שמעו אלי מפני שקשה בעיניהם לפרוש מע"ז וא"כ לא ירצו לבטלהע"ז, ואיך ישמעני פרעה לשלוח את ישראל כיון שמוכרח להיות ביטול ע"ז תחלה, ואמר לו הקב"ה ויצום אלבנ"ילהנהיגם בנחת ולסבול אותם, היינו שמעט מעט בנחת יראה להחזירם בתשובה ולהפריש אותם מע"ז, ואל פרעה מלך מצרים צום לחלוק לו כבוד,דכלזמן שלא הופרשו ישראל מע"ז לא הגיע עדיין זמן איבודו של פרעהוצריכיןלחלוק לו כבוד כמ"שהאוה"חהק' כי לא שלםעוןהאמורי עדיין לצד שאין ישראל בשלימות המעלה, ולזה שפיר שייך כאן הציווי לחלוק לו כבוד,דחלוקתכבוד לפרעהתליאבמעשיהם וזכותן של ישראל כנ"ל.
translation: And it is stated in Midrash Rabbah, Parashat Bo (17:3) that they were drawn and took for themselves sheep, as it is said (Psalms 97:7), "Let all those who serve idols be ashamed." When the Holy One, Blessed be He, told Moses to slaughter the Passover, Moses said to the Master of the Universe, "How can I do this? Do You not know that these sheep belong to the Egyptians?" The Holy One, Blessed be He, replied, "I swear, Israel will not leave here until they slaughter these sheep before the Egyptians, so that I will inform them that these are not gods at all." It is also stated in Midrash Rabbah, Parashat Va'eira (6:5), "And they did not listen to Moses because of shortness of spirit and hard work," for it was difficult in their eyes to separate from idolatry. This is what Moses argued before the Holy One, Blessed be He: "Surely redemption cannot happen unless the subjugation of idolatry by Israel precedes it," as explained in the aforementioned Midrash. And in truth, they were still attached to idolatry and did not want to slaughter the sheep before the Egyptians. This is why they did not listen to Me, because it was difficult in their eyes to separate from idolatry, and therefore they would not want to nullify idolatry. How would Pharaoh listen to me to send Israel, since it is necessary for the nullification of idolatry to happen first? The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him, "Command the children of Israel to lead them gently and to bear with them," meaning that little by little, gently, he should see to return them in repentance and separate them from idolatry. And to Pharaoh, king of Egypt, he should command to give him honor, for as long as Israel had not been separated from idolatry, the time for Pharaoh's downfall had not yet arrived, and they need to give him honor, as it is written, "For the iniquity of the Amorites is not yet complete," since Israel is not yet complete in their elevation. Therefore, it is fitting that here there is a command to give him honor, for the giving of honor to Pharaoh depends on their deeds and the merit of Israel, as mentioned above.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the divine command to Moses to sacrifice the Passover lamb, emphasizing the challenge posed by the Israelites' attachment to Egyptian idolatry. The text highlights that true redemption cannot occur until the Israelites renounce their idolatrous practices, which is a prerequisite for their liberation. God instructs Moses to lead the people gently towards repentance, indicating that their spiritual state directly impacts their relationship with Pharaoh and the timing of their redemption. The passage underscores the interconnectedness of Israel's spiritual integrity and the fate of their oppressor, illustrating a profound theological principle of divine justice and mercy.

passage_content: (משה ואהרן כאשרצוהד' אותם כן עשו, וצריך להבין מהדכפלהכתוב לומר כן עשו שהוא מיותר לכאורה,ובפ' בא אחר פרשת קרבן פסח כתיב ג"כ כן עשו ושם ביאר רש"י ז"ל הכוונה וכאן לא פי' מאומה, ואפשר לומר דלעיל כתיב הוא אהרן ומשה אשר אמר ה' להם וגו' הם המדברים אל פרעה וגו' הוא משה ואהרןדלכאורהכל הפסוק השני מיותר,דבמהשאמר הוא אהרן ומשה אשר אמר ד' להם הוציאו וגו', כברידעינןהכל, ומה חידש לנו באמרו הם המדברים בפרט מה שסיים עוד הפעם הוא משה ואהרן אין לו הבנה, וברש"י ז"ל פי' הם המדברים הם שנצטוו הם שקיימו הוא משה ואהרן הם בשליחותם ובצדקתם מתחלה ועד סוף, וגם זה צ"ב מה הוצרך לומרדהםשנצטוו הם קיימו וכי ס"דדאחריםקיימו הלא מפורש בפרשהדהםקיימו אחר שנצטוו ולא הוצרךבכאןאלא לייחסםדהםהנולדים מיוכבד לעמרם ולא יותר, גם מה שאמר הם בשליחותם ובצדקתם מתחלה ועד סוף צ"במה"תלומר שנפלו ח"וממדריגתצדקתם עד שהוצרך לומר כי היו בצדקתם מתחלה ועד סוף.
translation: (Moses and Aaron, as Hashem commanded them, so they did. And it is necessary to understand why the text emphasizes "so they did," which seems superfluous at first glance. In Parashat Bo, after the section on the Passover offering, it is also written "so they did," and there Rashi explains the intention, while here he did not explain anything. It can be said that above it is written, "It is Aaron and Moses whom Hashem said to them," etc., they are the ones speaking to Pharaoh, etc. It is Moses and Aaron. At first glance, the entire second verse seems superfluous, for in what was said, "It is Aaron and Moses whom Hashem said to them, 'Take out...'" we already know everything. What new information does He bring us by saying "they are the ones speaking," especially since it concludes again with "It is Moses and Aaron"? This does not have understanding. And Rashi explains, "They are the ones speaking; they were commanded, they fulfilled," it is Moses and Aaron, they are in their mission and their righteousness from beginning to end. And this also requires explanation: why is it necessary to say that they who were commanded fulfilled? Is it possible to think that others fulfilled? It is already explicit in the section that they fulfilled after they were commanded, and it is not necessary here except to attribute to them that they are the offspring of Yocheved to Amram and nothing more. Also, what he said, "they are in their mission and their righteousness from beginning to end," requires explanation: what is the need to say that they fell from their level of righteousness to the point that it was necessary to say that they were in their righteousness from beginning to end?)
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the repetition in the biblical text regarding Moses and Aaron's obedience to God's command. It raises questions about the necessity of emphasizing their role as the ones who were commanded and who fulfilled the command, suggesting a deeper understanding of their righteousness and mission. The text highlights the importance of their lineage and the continuity of their faithfulness from beginning to end, reflecting key Hasidic themes of divine purpose and the sanctity of fulfilling one's spiritual duties. Ultimately, it underscores the idea that true leadership and obedience stem from a profound connection to divine will and moral integrity.

passage_content: ואפשרלומר עפ"י מה שפי' ק"זזצוקלה"הבפתיחת ספרו ישמח משהעה"תדברי המדרש (ויק"רפ"ח) ר"י אומר חביבקרבנםשל נשיאים לפני הקב"ה כשירה שאמרו ישראל בים, ורבנן אמרו חביב קרבנו של אהרן לפני הקב"הכקרבנםשל נשיאים,דהנהאין חסידות כחסידותבתחלתוואין לך אדם בישראל שאין לו שעה שחושק לעשות רצון קונו. רק אחר עבור שעה נתקרר וחוזר לקדמותו, אבל הבני עלי' כל שעה ושעה כשעה הראשונה, שבכל עת נדמהלו שעתה מתחיל לעבוד השי"ת ואין אצלו אמצע וסוף רק תמיד התחלה, וזהו דברי המדרשדהשירהשבים הי' חביב מאוד לפי שהי'בתחלתכניסתן לקדושה והי' בהתלהבות גדולוכו', וכן נתינת הלוחות שזה התחלת קבלת התורה הי'בחשקותגדול עד שהזהירה התורה בכל יום יהיו בעיניך כחדשים, וכן קרבן נשיאים שהוא לחנוכת המזבח שהי' חנוכה הראשונה הי' בהתלהבות גדול והי' חביב מאוד בערך הדביקות והתלהבות שלהם, ובאו רבנן ואמרו שקרבן אהרן אף שהי' בכל יום פעמיים חביב לפני הקב"ה כקרבן נשיאים, שכן דרך בני עלי' שכל שעה ושעה אצלם כשעה ראשונהיעיי"ששהאריך בזה, וא"א מו"רהגה"קזלה"הפי' בזה דברי רש"י ז"ל (בפ' בהעלותך) להגיד שבחו של אהרן שלא שינה,דר"לשכמו שהתחיל לעשות עבודתו אחרשנצטוהמהשי"תכן לא בא לידו שינוי וגרעון לעולם, ולא נתקרר כלל כי בכל שעה ושעה הי' אצלו התחלה מחדש.
translation: And it is possible to say according to what is explained in the opening of his book, "Moshe will rejoice in the Torah," that the Midrash (Vayikra Rabbah 28) states: Rabbi Yochanan says that the offerings of the leaders are beloved before the Holy One, Blessed be He, like the song that Israel sang at the sea, and the Rabbis say that the offering of Aaron is beloved before the Holy One, Blessed be He, like the offerings of the leaders. Behold, there is no piety like the piety at the beginning, and there is no person in Israel who does not have a moment when he desires to do the will of his Creator. Only after a moment does he cool down and return to his previous state, but the sons of Eli are like this at every moment, as at the first hour, for at all times it seems to them that they are just beginning to serve the Holy One, Blessed be He, and there is no middle or end for them, only always a beginning. And this is the meaning of the Midrash that the song was very beloved because it was at the beginning of their entry into holiness and it was with great enthusiasm, etc. Likewise, the giving of the tablets, which was the beginning of the acceptance of the Torah, was with great desire, to the extent that the Torah warns that every day they should be in your eyes as new. And so the offering of the leaders, which was for the dedication of the altar, which was the first dedication, was with great enthusiasm and was very beloved in relation to their attachment and fervor. And the Rabbis came and said that the offering of Aaron, even though it was every day twice, was beloved before the Holy One, Blessed be He, like the offering of the leaders, for this is the way of the sons of Eli that every hour is for them like the first hour, as it is written there that he elaborated on this. And it is impossible to explain the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed (in Parshat Beha'alotecha), to indicate the praise of Aaron that he did not change, meaning that just as he began to do his service after being commanded by the Holy One, Blessed be He, so he never experienced change or decline at all, and he was never cooled down, for at every hour it was for him a new beginning.
summary: The passage emphasizes the concept of constant renewal in one's service to God, likening the devotion of the righteous to that of the initial fervor experienced at the beginning of a spiritual endeavor. It highlights that while most individuals may experience fluctuations in their commitment, the truly elevated souls, like Aaron, maintain a continuous and passionate connection to the Divine, treating each moment as a fresh opportunity for worship. This idea is illustrated through the comparison of the offerings of the leaders and Aaron, both cherished by God, reflecting the importance of enthusiasm and dedication in spiritual practice. The text underscores that true Hasidic devotion is characterized by an ongoing, unchanging zeal for serving God.

passage_content: וזהאפשרלכויןבדברי רש"י ז"לדבוודאיבעת שנצטוו משה ואהרן מפי הקב"ה לעשות שליחותם הי' אצלם התלהבות גדול והשתוקקות רב לקיים רצון קונם, ועד שבאו לידי עשי' הי' אפשר לומר שנתקררו קצת כדרך כל אדם אשר אין חסידותכבתחלתוואחר עבור שעה אינו זה האיש שהי'בתחלתו, ע"כ אמר הוא אהרן ומשה אשר אמר ד' להם וגו' הם המדברים וגו'דהםשנצטוו הם שקיימו ממש בלי שום שינוידכמושהיו בהתלהבות גדול בעת שנצטוו, כן היו ממש בעת שקיימו דגם בעת שקיימו הי' אצלם התחלתהעניןכמו בעת שנצטוו כדרך הבני עלי' אשר בכל שעה ושעה הוא בעיניהם כחדשים, ואח"כ הוסיף עוד לומר הוא אהרן ומשהכפירש"יז"ל הם בצדקתם מתחלה ועד סוףדאלתאמר דאך טרם שעשו איזה דבר לא נתקררו מהתלהבות שלהם אבל אחר שעשו איזה דבר משליחותו של הקב"ה נתקרר דעתם בזה ונשקע אש ההתלהבות מקרבם קצת כדרך שאר בני אדם, ע"כ אמר הם בצדקתם מתחלה ועד סוף שגם בסוף עשייתם אשתוקדבקרבם כאילו לא עשו עדיין מאומה, והתחילו אז לעשות מחדש ולא נגרע מצדקתם ועבודתם מאומה,וז"שויעש משה ואהרן כאשרצוהד' אותם שקיימוהמצוהכמאמרה כאשר נצטוו מפי השי"ת בחשק רב ובהתלהבות עצום, וכדי שלא תאמר שהן אמת שהי' הדבר בחסידות רבבתחלתוסמוך לציווי של הקב"ה, אבל אחר עשייתם קצת נתקררו ולא עשו כן כמובתחלהלכן סיים כן עשו שבכל פעם ופעם עשו ממש כן כמו שהי'בתחלה.
translation: And it is possible to focus on the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, that at the time when Moses and Aaron were commanded by the Holy One, Blessed be He, to fulfill their mission, there was a great enthusiasm and a strong yearning within them to fulfill the will of their Creator. However, by the time they came to action, it could be said that they had cooled down a bit, like all people, for there is no piety like at the beginning, and after an hour, he is not the same person he was at the beginning. Therefore, it says, "He is Aaron and Moses," who the Lord spoke to them, etc. They are the speakers, etc., for they were commanded, and they fulfilled it truly without any change, just as they were in great enthusiasm at the time they were commanded. So they were truly at the time they fulfilled it, that even at the time of fulfillment, the beginning of the matter was with them as it was at the time they were commanded, like the sons of Eli, who at every moment it is new in their eyes. And then he added to say, "He is Aaron and Moses," as Rashi, may his memory be blessed, explains, they are in their righteousness from beginning to end, so that you should not say that only before they did anything did they not cool down from their enthusiasm, but after they did something of the Holy One's mission, their minds cooled down regarding this, and the fire of enthusiasm within them somewhat sank, like other people. Therefore, he said, "They are in their righteousness from beginning to end," that even at the end of their action, their enthusiasm was as if they had not yet done anything, and they then began to do anew, and their righteousness and service were not diminished at all. And this is what is meant by "And Moses and Aaron did as the Lord commanded them," that they fulfilled the commandment as it was said, just as they were commanded by the Blessed One with great desire and immense enthusiasm. And so that you should not say that it is true that the matter was with great piety at the beginning, close to the command of the Holy One, but after their action, they somewhat cooled down and did not do so as they did at the beginning, therefore it concludes, "So they did," that each and every time they did indeed do so just as it was at the beginning.
summary: The passage emphasizes the unwavering enthusiasm and dedication of Moses and Aaron in fulfilling God's commandments, highlighting that their fervor remained constant from the moment of receiving the command to its execution. It contrasts their steadfastness with the common human tendency to lose zeal over time, asserting that they maintained their initial passion and righteousness throughout their actions. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of continuous spiritual elevation, where true devotion is characterized by a persistent renewal of commitment, akin to experiencing each commandment as new and significant. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of maintaining a deep, heartfelt connection to divine service at all times.

passage_content: עוי"לדהנהנודעבספה"קאשר שני בחינות בעושי מצוה, דיש מי שעושה מצוה שמכריח את יצרו לעשות אבל לבו בל עמו ולא הגיע למדרגה זו שיהי'נכסוףומשתוקקלהמצוהבאמת ויהי' צמאה נפשו לאלוקיםבהרגשעריבות נעימות מתיקותהמצוה, והן אמת כי גם זה חשוב לפני השי"ת אם מכריח את יצרו עכ"פ לעשות באיזה אופן שיהי', אבל זה אין בידו כ"א בשעה שעושההמצוהשאז מכריח את איבריולהעשי', אבל אחר גמרעשותוכיון שהדבר הי' עליו לעול ויגיעה רבה, ממילא בשעה שהולךמהמצוההואכההולךונפטר מעול ושיעבוד גדול ואין לו שייכות עוד עםהמצוה, וכן קודם עשייתו בעת שלא הכריח עדיין את איבריולהמעשהאין בידו מאומה, אבל הבני עלי' וקדושי ה' הנכספים ומשתוקקים באמת, אשר מרוב התשוקה לא נחשב בעיניהם לעמל ויגיעה, וכמו שפי'זקיניהגה"קזלה"הבישמחמשה (כיתשא)דאצלהחסידים ובני עלי' הפי' של וחי בהם ולא שימות בהם הוא בהיפך, ואין להם לבטל שום מצוה מחשש סכנהדכלחיותם הוא רקבהמצוהואם לאו יפסק חיותם ח"ו מרוב השתוקקותלהמצוהעיי"ש,ולפי"זהמה מקושרים ודבוקים במצותהבוית"שגם לפני עשייתה ואף לאחרי' מרוב השתוקקותם לעשותה ולקיים רצוןהבוית"ש.
translation: There are two aspects in those who perform a mitzvah: there are some who perform a mitzvah by forcing their yetzer (evil inclination) to act, but their heart is not with them, and they have not reached the level where they truly yearn and long for the mitzvah, and their soul is thirsty for God with the pleasant and sweet sensations of the mitzvah. It is true that this is also significant before the Holy One, Blessed be He, if they at least force their yetzer to do so in some manner, but this is only in their hands at the moment they are performing the mitzvah, when they force their limbs to act. However, after they have completed the act, since it was a burden and great toil upon them, it follows that at the time they walk away from the mitzvah, they are as if they are walking away and freed from a great burden and servitude, and they no longer have any connection to the mitzvah. Similarly, before performing it, when they have not yet forced their limbs to act, they have no power at all. But the elevated and holy ones, who truly yearn and long, who, due to their great desire, do not consider it toil and effort, as explained by the elders of the holy community, that the meaning of "and they shall live by them" (Vayikra 18:5) for the righteous and the elevated ones is the opposite, and they have no reason to nullify any mitzvah out of fear of danger, for their very life is only in the mitzvah, and if not, their life would cease, Heaven forbid, due to their overwhelming longing for the mitzvah. According to this, how are they connected and attached to the mitzvah of the Blessed One, even before performing it and even after, due to their great longing to do it and fulfill the will of the Blessed One.
summary: The passage discusses two types of individuals who perform mitzvot: those who do so out of obligation, struggling against their desires, and those who are genuinely passionate and yearn for the mitzvah. While the former's actions are still valued by God, their connection to the mitzvah is limited and often feels burdensome. In contrast, the truly devoted individuals experience a deep longing for the mitzvah, viewing it not as a burden but as a source of life and joy, which keeps them spiritually connected to God both before and after the act. This highlights the importance of inner desire and spiritual attachment in fulfilling divine commandments.

passage_content: ובבחינהזו אמרתי לפרש מה שאמרדהע"השש אנכי על אמרתך כמוצא שלל רבדקשהלכאורה הלא כתיב טוב לי תורת פיך מאלפי זהב וכסף וכל חפציך לא ישוו בה, ומה דמיון וערוךלהתוה"קעם מציאת שלל רבוהול"ליותר ממוצא שלל רב, ועפ"י הנ"ל אפשר לומר דלא בא לדמותהתוה"קלמציאת שלל רבבעניןיקרת הערך, ואך באלהבינינובזההאיךהי' שש ושמחבהתוה"קאף שהוא באמת עבודה קשה ויגיעה רבה ואין התורה מתקיימת אלא במי שממית עצמו עלי' ולשמחה מה זו עושה, אמנם הדבר יובן לסתם בני אדם בעת שמוצא שלל רב ויוכל למלאות את ביתו בכסף וזהב ואבנים טובים ומרגליות, הנה אף שהוא עבודה קשה לילך כל היום וכל הלילהלישאמשא הכסף והזהב עלכתיפואל תוך ביתו,עכ"זתקטן בעיניו כל היגיעה ולא ירגיש שום צער בעמלווליאותו, לרוב הרצון והחשק למלא את ביתו בכל טוב, ואדרבה כבד הוא בעיניו להניח רגע אחתמלישאמשא ההואשעי"זיחסר לו מהטובה שיוכל להביא לביתו בזמן ההוא, ובזה מובן שהצדיקים הגדולים אשר כל טוב שבעוה"ז אפי' שבעוה"ב לא נחשב אצלם נגד תענוג קיום התורה והמצות, וכמו שפי' ביערות דבש דברי חז"ל יפה שעה אחת בתשובהומע"טמכל חיי העוה"ב,דמדקאמריפה שעה אחת וכו' ש"מ דהוא גם יפה בתענוגים ומתוק יותר מכל חיי העוה"ב עכ"ד, א"כ לא נחשב אצלם שום צער ויגיעה לרוב המתיקות ואדרבה קשה בעיניהם לעזוב רגע, אף כי רחוקים אנחנו ממדה זו אבל כן העידו רבותינוזלה"הבספה"קעל הצדיקיםהאמיתים,וז"ששש אנכי על אמרתיךוכ"תלרוב הצער והיגיעה לשמחה מה זו עושה ע"ז אמר לראי' כמוצא שלל רב שאין נחשב ליגיעה בדבר שיש בו רצון אמיתי.
translation: In this regard, I said to explain what the verse states, "I rejoice at Your word, as one who finds great spoil." It is difficult, for it is written, "The law of Your mouth is better to me than thousands of gold and silver," and all Your desires cannot be compared to it. What similarity and comparison can there be between the Torah and finding great spoil? It would seem more than finding great spoil. According to the above, one could say that it does not come to compare the Torah to finding great spoil in terms of its precious value, but rather in this matter, how it was that he was joyful and happy with the Torah, for it is indeed hard work and much toil, and the Torah is only sustained by one who gives himself over to it, and what joy does this bring? However, this can be understood by ordinary people at the time when they find great spoil and can fill their homes with silver and gold and precious stones and pearls. Behold, even though it is hard work to go all day and all night carrying the burden of silver and gold on their shoulders and into their homes, nevertheless, all the toil seems small in their eyes, and they do not feel any sorrow in their labor and effort, due to the great desire and eagerness to fill their homes with all good things. On the contrary, it is heavy in their eyes to leave off even for a moment from carrying that burden, for thereby they would miss out on the good they could bring to their homes at that time. In this, it is understood that the great righteous ones, for whom all the good of this world, even of the World to Come, is not considered against the pleasure of fulfilling the Torah and the commandments, as explained in Yaarot Devash, the words of our Sages, that "one hour of repentance and good deeds is better than all the life of the World to Come," for since it says "one hour," it implies that it is also good in pleasures and sweeter than all the life of the World to Come. Therefore, no sorrow or toil is considered by them due to the great sweetness, and on the contrary, it is hard for them to leave off even for a moment. Although we are far from this measure, our teachers have testified in the holy books about the true righteous ones. And this is what is meant by "I rejoice at Your word," for due to the great sorrow and toil, what joy does this bring? To this, it is said, "as one who finds great spoil," for there is no toil considered in something that has true desire.
summary: The passage discusses the profound joy and value that the righteous find in the study of Torah, comparing it to the exhilaration of discovering great treasures. It emphasizes that, despite the hard work and effort required to engage with Torah, the immense pleasure derived from it far outweighs any toil, akin to how a person feels when acquiring wealth. The text highlights that for the truly righteous, the spiritual rewards of Torah and mitzvot surpass all worldly pleasures, making their struggles seem insignificant in light of their genuine desire for divine connection. Ultimately, the joy in fulfilling God's commandments transforms their labor into a source of happiness, illustrating the deep spiritual fulfillment found in devotion to Torah.

passage_content: ובזהיתבארו דברי קודש רש"י ז"ל הוא משה ואהרן, הם בשליחותם ובצדקתם מתחלה ועד סוףדלגודלתשוקתם לעשות רצון קונם היו שווים בשליחותם וצדקתם מתחלה ועד סוף ואף לפני העשי' ואף לאחר שהשלימו שליחותם לא יעפו ולא יגעו ונכספה וכלתה נפשם לקראתהמצוהונחשב להם כל שעה כאלו עשוהו,וז"שויעש משה ואהרן כאשרצוהד' אותם כן עשו, שנחשב להם עשי' זו בהוה כאלו כן עשו תמידי לרוב הרצון והחפץ בה, והבן.
translation: And in this it is explained the words of the holy Rashi, may his memory be blessed, that he is Moses and Aaron; they, in their mission and righteousness, were equal from beginning to end due to their great desire to fulfill the will of their Creator. They were equal in their mission and righteousness from beginning to end, even before the action and even after they completed their mission, they did not cease nor falter, and their souls longed and yearned for the commandment, and every hour was considered for them as if they had fulfilled it. And this is what is meant by "And Moses and Aaron did as the Lord commanded them; so they did," for this action was considered for them in the present as if they had always done it, due to their great will and desire for it. Understand this.
summary: The passage emphasizes the unwavering dedication of Moses and Aaron in fulfilling God's will, highlighting their equal commitment and righteousness from beginning to end. Their intense desire to perform God's commandments is so profound that every moment of their longing is considered as if they had already accomplished the task. This reflects a key Hasidic concept that the intention and yearning to serve God hold significant value, equating their spiritual state to actual fulfillment of the commandments. Ultimately, their actions are viewed as continuous and eternal due to their deep devotion.

passage_content: ויאמרה' אל משה ואל אהרןלאמרכי ידבר אליכם פרעהלאמרתנו לכם מופת ואמרת אל אהרן קח את מטך והשלך לפני פרעה יהי לתנין וגו' ויקרא גם פרעה לחכמים ולמכשפים ויעשו גם הם וגו' ויבלע מטה אהרן אתמטותם,במד"ר(פר' ט' סי' ז')הה"ד(משלי כ"ט) כל רוחו יוציא כסיל וחכם באחורישבחנה, כל רוחו יוציא כסיל זה פרעה שהי' מלעיג על הקב"ה, שהי' סבור שמעשה כשפים הן מה שעשו משה ואהרן, וקרא לכל בני ביתו לעשות כמותם, הוי כל רוחו יוציא כסיל זה פרעה, וחכם באחורישבחנהזה הקב"ה שנאמר חכם לבב ואמיץכחוכו', אר"יב"רחנינאנס גדול נעשה במטה שאע"פ שבלע כל אותן המטות שהשליכו, שהיו רבים לעשות מהן עשרהעומריןולא הועבה, וכל מי שרואה אותה אומר זה מטה אהרן, מכאן שהי' מטה אהרן סימן טוב לעשות בו נסים ונפלאות לדורות וכו' עכ"ד המדרש, ראוי להבין הלא לא עבידקוב"הניסאלמגנא, ומה הי' צורך לנס זה שלא הועבה המטה ממה שהי' ואיך הוא סימן טוב לעשות בו נסים ונפלאות לדורות.
translation: And Hashem said to Moses and Aaron, saying, "When Pharaoh speaks to you, saying, 'Show me a miracle,' you shall say to Aaron, 'Take your staff and throw it before Pharaoh, and it shall become a serpent,' etc. And Pharaoh also called for the wise men and the sorcerers, and they did the same, etc. And Aaron's staff swallowed their staffs." In the Midrash (Parashat Va'era, Section 7), it is stated: "This is the meaning of (Proverbs 29) 'Every fool utters all his mind, but a wise man keeps it in until afterwards.' Every fool utters all his mind—this refers to Pharaoh, who mocked the Holy One, Blessed be He, thinking that the acts of sorcery performed by Moses and Aaron were mere magic. He called all his household to do likewise. Thus, 'Every fool utters all his mind' refers to Pharaoh, and 'a wise man keeps it in until afterwards' refers to the Holy One, Blessed be He, as it is said, 'A wise heart and strong in counsel.' A great miracle was performed with the staff, for even though it swallowed all those staffs that were thrown down, which were many enough to make ten measures, it was not thickened. And anyone who sees it says, 'This is Aaron's staff.' From here, it is evident that Aaron's staff was a good sign to perform miracles and wonders for generations, etc." Thus concludes the Midrash. It is appropriate to understand that the Holy One, Blessed be He, does not perform miracles for mere protection, and what was the need for this miracle that the staff was not thickened from what it was, and how is it a good sign to perform miracles and wonders for generations?
summary: In this passage, the confrontation between Moses, Aaron, and Pharaoh illustrates the folly of Pharaoh's skepticism towards God's power, as he mistakenly equates the miracles performed by Moses and Aaron with mere sorcery. The swallowing of the magicians' staffs by Aaron's staff signifies God's supremacy and the futility of human wisdom against divine authority. The text emphasizes that despite the miraculous act, Aaron's staff remains unchanged, symbolizing its enduring power as a vessel for miracles throughout generations. This highlights the concept that true miracles stem from divine will, not human capability, reinforcing the belief in God's omnipotence and the significance of faith in His signs.

passage_content: ב)ילקוט (רמז קפ"א) כי ידבר אליכם פרעהלאמרתנו לכם מופת, א"ל למחר אני מוציאם ממצרים ואני נותן להם את התורה שנאמר בה כי יקום בקרבך נביא וגו' ונתן אליך אות או מופת,וצ"באיךשייכאמצות הנביא שעתידה להינתןבמ"תאל מה שיאמר פרעה תנו לכם מופת.
translation: In the Yalkut (Remez 151), it is said that Pharaoh will speak to you, saying, "We have given you a sign." He said, "Tomorrow I will take them out of Egypt and I will give them the Torah, as it is stated, 'When a prophet arises among you...' and He will give you a sign or a wonder." And how does this relate to the commandments of the prophet that will be given at Mount Sinai to what Pharaoh says, "Give you a sign"?
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the prophetic promise made by Pharaoh regarding the Israelites' liberation from Egypt and the subsequent giving of the Torah. The text emphasizes the connection between the miracles performed by Pharaoh and the future signs that will accompany the revelation of the Torah at Mount Sinai. This highlights the Hasidic belief in the significance of divine signs and the role of prophecy in affirming the covenant between God and the Jewish people. Ultimately, it underscores the transformative power of the Torah as a guiding force in the spiritual journey of the Israelites.

passage_content: ונראהביאורהעניןדהנהאיתא במדרש ילקוט (שם) כיון שהלכו משה ואהרן אצל פרעה אמר להם תנו לכם מופת מיד וישלך אהרן את מטהו, באותה שעה שחק פרעה אליהם, א"ל למה אתם סבורים שבאתם לשחק עלי, איני מתיירא מן הדברים האלווכו', שקרא לאשתו וא"ל ראוהאיךבאו היהודים לשחק ביוכו', ולכאורה הוא פליאה עצומה למהעשה ה' ככה לצוות את משה ואהרן לעשות מופת זה לפני פרעה, הלא קמי שמיאגליאשפרעה יתלוצץ ממופת זה, ובפרט שמשה ואהרן באו לעורר את ישראל על התשובה לפרוש מדרכי ע"ז ושיאמינו בהקב"ה ובנפלאותיו, וכאן ראו שאותם האותות שעשו משה ואהרן בשליחות הקב"ה עשו גם פרעה והחרטומים, הגם שאח"כנתבררבמה שבלע מטה אהרן אתמטותםשמעשה אהרן לא הי' ח"ו מעשה כשפים. אבל עדשנתבררהדבר היו יכולים ישראל לבוא ח"ו לידי ספיקות באמונת השי"ת, והי' העדר כבוד שמים באותו שעה שהתלוצץ פרעה עליהם והכל גלוי לפניוית' ומדועציוםית' לעשות מופת זה
translation: And it is seen in the explanation of the matter that behold, it is in the Midrash Yalkut (there) that when Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh, he said to them, "Give yourselves a sign immediately," and Aaron threw down his staff. At that moment, Pharaoh laughed at them, saying, "Why do you think you have come to mock me? I am not afraid of these things," etc. He called to his wife and said, "Look how the Jews have come to mock me," etc. And seemingly, it is a tremendous wonder why the Holy One, blessed be He, would command Moses and Aaron to perform this sign before Pharaoh, for it is known from Heaven that Pharaoh would scoff at this sign, especially since Moses and Aaron came to awaken Israel to repentance, to turn away from the ways of idolatry and to believe in the Holy One, blessed be He, and His wonders. And here they saw that the same signs that Moses and Aaron performed at the command of the Holy One, blessed be He, Pharaoh and the magicians also did, even though it was later clarified that what Aaron's staff swallowed were their staffs, and Aaron's act was not, Heaven forbid, an act of sorcery. But until the matter was clarified, the Israelites could, Heaven forbid, have come to doubts in their faith in the Holy One, blessed be He, and there would have been a lack of the honor of Heaven at that moment when Pharaoh mocked them, and everything is revealed before Him, blessed be He. And why did He see fit to perform this sign?
summary: The passage discusses the perplexity of why God commanded Moses and Aaron to perform miracles before Pharaoh, knowing that Pharaoh would mock them and their signs. It highlights the potential for doubt among the Israelites regarding their faith in God, especially since Pharaoh and his magicians could replicate these signs. The text emphasizes the importance of faith and the honor of God's name, suggesting that even in the face of mockery, the ultimate truth of God's power would be revealed. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of unwavering belief in divine providence despite apparent challenges.

passage_content: אמנםעניינו הוא שהי' גלוי וידוע לפני מי שאמר והי' העולם שיהי' זמן שיבואו ישראל לידינסיוןכזה כמ"ש כי יקום בקרבך נביא או חולם חלום ונתן אליך אות או מופת וגו', ויעמדו נביאי שקר בישראל ויבררו ע"י אותות ומופתים שמצות ה' לעבוד ע"ז או להתחבר לעובדי ע"ז ח"ו, וניתן מן השמיםכחלשטן לעשות אותות ומופתים, וכמושמצינובחטא העגל שהשטן הי' מראה לפניהם שמשה רבינו מת ומוטל במטה, ובזה הטעה את ישראל לע"ז, וכדומהמנסיונותאחרים שמביא השטן ע"י אותות ומופתים, והנה איתא במדרש (פ' אחרי) אחרי מות שני בני אהרן,מלה"דלרופא שנכנס אצל החולה א"ל אל תשתה צונן ואל תשכב בטחב, בא אחר וא"ל אל תשתה צונן ואל תשכב בטחב שמא תמות כדרך שמת פלוני, זה זרזו יותר מן הראשון וכו' לכך נאמר אחרי מות שני בני אהרן עכ"ד המדרש, וענין המשל הזהדטבעבני האדם כן שאם מזהירים בו ומראים לו דוגמא שכבר הי' כמוהו נתפעל יותר ונחקק האזהרהבלבויותרלהשמרממנו וכמו"כלעניננושהתוה"קמזהיר אותנו שלא נתפעל מאותות ומופתים שהם לעבור עלהתוה"קבאיזה אופן שיהיו א"כ יקשו קושיא גדולה מדוע לא הסיר ה'הכחמנביא השקר לעשות האות והמופת לבל יטעו ישראל מאחרי ה', ולמה ניתןכחויכולת לכוחות הטומאה שיעשו אות זה, אמנם נתן הכתוב טעם כי מנסה ה'אלקיכםאתכם וגו' ולזה הראה לנוהתוה"קדוגמא שכבר נהי' כמוהו שפרעה וכת דילי' עשו אותן המופתים ממש מה שעשו משה ואהרן בשליחות הקב"ה, ונתגלה אח"כ שהמופתים שלהם אין בהם ממש, וכן הוא בכל המופתים שבאים מכוחות הטומאה, יתברר לאחר זמן שאין בהם ממש ויתבטלו כחרס הנשבר.
translation:
Indeed, the matter is that it was revealed and known before Him who said, "Let there be a world," that there would be a time when Israel would come to such a trial, as it is written, "If a prophet arises among you or a dreamer of dreams and gives you a sign or a wonder," etc. False prophets will stand in Israel and will prove, through signs and wonders, that it is a command of the Lord to serve idols or to join with idol worshippers, Heaven forbid. And it is given from Heaven to the forces of evil to perform signs and wonders, as we see in the sin of the Golden Calf, where the evil one showed them that Moses our teacher had died and was lying in the grave, and by this he misled Israel to idol worship, and similarly with other trials that the evil one brings through signs and wonders. 

And behold, it is stated in the Midrash (Parashat Acharei Mot) after the death of the two sons of Aaron, like a doctor who enters to see a patient and says to him, "Do not drink cold water and do not lie in dampness," another comes and says to him, "Do not drink cold water and do not lie in dampness, lest you die as so-and-so died." This second warning has a greater effect than the first, etc. Therefore, it is said, "After the death of the two sons of Aaron," thus concludes the Midrash. 

And the matter of this parable is that it is human nature that if one is warned and shown an example of something that has already happened, he is more affected and the warning is engraved more deeply in his heart to guard himself from it. And just as the Torah warns us not to be swayed by signs and wonders that lead to transgressing the Torah in any way, therefore a great question arises: why did the Holy One not remove the power from the false prophet to perform signs and wonders so that Israel would not be misled after the Lord? And why was the power given to the forces of impurity to perform this sign? 

However, the scripture gives a reason: "For the Lord your God is testing you," etc. And for this, the Torah shows us an example that has already occurred, that Pharaoh and his ilk performed the very same signs that Moses and Aaron did by the command of the Holy One, and it was later revealed that their signs were without substance. And so it is with all the signs that come from the forces of impurity; it will be clarified after a time that they are without substance and will be nullified like a broken shard.
summary: The passage discusses the divine foresight of Israel facing trials, particularly through false prophets who perform signs and wonders to lead them astray from God's commandments. It emphasizes that these tests are allowed by God to discern the faithful, drawing parallels to past events like the sin of the Golden Calf. The text highlights that, ultimately, the miracles of false prophets lack substance and will be proven false over time, reinforcing the importance of adhering to the Torah and remaining vigilant against deception.

passage_content: ובזהיתבאר דברי המדרש כי ידבר אליכם פרעהלאמרתנו לכם מופת ואמרת אל אהרן קח את מטך וגו'.דקשהע"ז קושיא גדולה למהצוהה' לעשות מופת זה, וקמי שמיאגליאשיתלוצץ פרעה עליו, ע"ז מתרץ המדרש א"ל למחר אני מוציאם ממצרים ואני נותן להם את התורה שנאמר בה כי יקום בקרבך נביא וגו' ונתן אליך אות או מופת ולטעם זהצוהה' לעשות אות זה, כדי ללמוד לישראל שלא יתפעלו מאותות ומופתים, והראה להם דוגמתו שפרעה הרשע עשה זה המופת עצמו שעשה משה ואהרןונתבררזיופו לבסוף.
translation: And in this, the words of the Midrash are clarified, for Pharaoh will speak to you saying, "We will give you a sign," and he said to Aaron, "Take your staff, etc." This raises a great question regarding the Holy One, blessed be He, why He commanded to perform this sign. And before Heaven, it is revealed that Pharaoh will rise against him. To this, the Midrash answers: He said to them, "Tomorrow I will take them out of Egypt and I will give them the Torah, as it is said, 'When a prophet arises among you,' etc., and He will give you a sign or a wonder." And for this reason, the Holy One, blessed be He, commanded to perform this sign, in order to teach Israel not to be swayed by signs and wonders, and He showed them an example that the wicked Pharaoh performed the very same sign that Moses and Aaron did, and in the end, his deception was clarified.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the miracles performed by Moses and Aaron in the context of Pharaoh's challenge. It emphasizes that God commanded these signs to teach the Israelites not to be swayed by wonders and miracles, as even Pharaoh, a wicked ruler, could replicate them. This serves to highlight the ultimate truth of God's message and the importance of discernment in faith, reinforcing the idea that true belief should not rely solely on miraculous signs. The teaching underscores the distinction between divine authenticity and deceptive displays of power.

passage_content: והנהמדרךהסט"אלטשטשהגבוליןולהראות על אותות ומופתים של שקר שהוא אמת, ולהיפוך על מופת אמיתי מהקב"ה מסית לומר שמעשה כשפים הוא וכדרך שאמרו המצריים, ובזה יובן למה הוצרך לנס זה שלא הועבה המטה,דאמרז"לשמטה אהרן הוא המטה שעתיד מלך המשיח לעשות בו נסים ונפלאות, ולזה אלמלי הועבה אחר שבלע מעות החרטומים: הי'להרשעיםמקום לומר, שנכנס בומכחמטותם,ובכחהזה נעשו בו נסים ונפלאות ואינם מצד הקדושה ח"ו, ע"כ עשה הקב"ה נס שלא הועבה מטה אהרן כלל למען יתברר שאין לצדהסט"אשום אחיזה בו, ומטה הזה שהוא כולו מצד הקדושה יהי' ביד מלך המשיח, ובו יעשה נסים ונפלאות, גם במה שבלעמטה אהרןמטותםולא הועבה,נתבררשאין קיוםלהניסיםוהמופתים שנעשו ע"י כוחות הטומאה וסופם שיתבטלו מן העולם,וז"פדברי המדרש כל רוחו יוציא כסיל זה פרעה שהוא מרכבהלסט"אהנקרא זקן וכסיל, והתגבר בכל כוחותיו להטעות את ישראל ע"י אותות ומופתים המדומים, אבל חכם באחורישבחנהזה הקב"ה שנאמר חכם לבב ואמיץכח. ולבסוף נתגדלעי"זכבוד שמיםונתבררשאיןבאותותםממש, והמאמין בהקב"הצריך להמתין על ישועת השי"ת הבא באחרונה ולא להתפתות מנסים המדומים של כוחותהסט"אשסופם כלה ונאבד כעפרא דארעא, ורק ישועה הבא מצד הקדושה בדרךהתוה"קהוא ישועה אמיתית ונצחי,הבוכ"עיעזור שנזכה להיות דבוק בהקב"ה ובתורתוהק' ולראות בישועה שלימה ולא נהי' מן הנדחים ח"ו, וכאשר ראינו כל הצרות והשפלות כך נזכה לראות בשמחתן של ישראל כשיתרומם קרן התורה וישראל, השי"ת יעזורשנוושעבמהרה בישועה שלימה ולראות בישועת ישראל ושמחתן ובהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו במהרה בימינו אמן.
translation: And behold, the way of the Sitra Achra is to blur the boundaries and to show signs and wonders of falsehood that appear as truth, and conversely, to twist a true miracle from the Holy One, Blessed be He, to claim that it is sorcery, as the Egyptians said. And this explains why this miracle was necessary, that the staff was not thickened, for our Sages have said that the staff of Aaron is the staff with which the King Messiah will perform miracles and wonders. Therefore, had it been thickened after it swallowed the coins of the magicians, the wicked would have had grounds to say that it entered by virtue of their magic, and through that power, miracles and wonders were performed that are not from holiness, Heaven forbid. Thus, the Holy One, Blessed be He, performed a miracle that the staff of Aaron was not thickened at all, so that it would be clear that the Sitra Achra has no hold on it, and this staff, which is entirely from holiness, will be in the hand of the King Messiah, and with it, he will perform miracles and wonders. Also, in that the staff of Aaron swallowed their staffs and was not thickened, it was made clear that there is no permanence to the miracles and wonders that were performed by the forces of impurity, and their end will be that they will be nullified from the world. And this is the meaning of the words of the Midrash: "Every spirit will expel this fool, Pharaoh, who is the chariot of the Sitra Achra, called old and foolish," and he strengthened himself with all his powers to deceive Israel through the false signs and wonders. But the wise one, in the end, will praise the Holy One, Blessed be He, as it is said, "A wise heart and strong power." And in the end, the honor of Heaven will be magnified through this, and it will be made clear that there is no truth in their signs. And the one who believes in the Holy One, Blessed be He, must wait for the salvation of the Blessed One that will come in the end and not be tempted by the false signs of the forces of the Sitra Achra, whose end is to perish and be lost like dust of the earth. And only the salvation that comes from holiness, through the path of the Torah, is true and eternal salvation. May the Blessed One help us merit to be attached to the Holy One, Blessed be He, and to His holy Torah, and to see complete salvation and not to be among the castaways, Heaven forbid. And as we have seen all the troubles and humiliations, so may we merit to see the joy of Israel when the horn of the Torah and Israel is uplifted. May the Blessed One help us to be saved quickly with complete salvation and to see the salvation of Israel and their joy, and the revelation of the honor of Heaven upon us speedily in our days. Amen.
summary: The passage emphasizes the distinction between true miracles from God and false signs produced by forces of impurity, highlighting that the staff of Aaron, which remains unaltered, symbolizes divine holiness and the future miracles of the Messiah. It warns against being misled by deceptive wonders, asserting that only the salvation that comes from holiness is genuine and eternal. The text calls for faith in God's ultimate redemption, encouraging believers to remain steadfast and connected to divine teachings amidst trials, with the hope of witnessing the true joy and glory of Israel's salvation.

passage_content: ויחפרוכל מצרים סביבות היאור מים לשתות וגו' כתב האבן עזרא ז"ל רבים אומרים כי המים היו ביד המצרי אדומים כדםונתלבנוביד הישראלי, א"כ למה לא נכתב אות זה בתורה,ומכחקושיא זו הכריח לומר כי מכת הדם והצפרדעים והכניסהיתהכוללת המצריים והעבריים, וכן בשאר מכות חוץ מג' שמפורש בכתוב שהובדלו מהם ישראל, והם ערובדכתיבוהפלתי וגו', ובמכת דבר כתיב והפלה ה' בין מקנה מצרים וגו', ובברד כתיב רק בארץ גושן אשר שםבנ"ילא הי' ברד עכת"ד, וכתב האבי עזרי על דבריהראב"עהנ"ל, אנו אין לנו אלא דברי רז"ל כי ממכת דםנתעשרוישראל, ואפי'נכריוישראלשותיןבספל א', הי' חציו דם וחציו מים, ולפי דעתי תלמיד טועה ועני בדעת כתב הדברים האלהוכו'. וכן דעת כל המפרשים ז"ל, אמנם לדבריהם יקשהקושיתהראב"עז"ל מדוע העלים הכתוב נס נפלא כזה שהי' במכת דם, שהובדלו ישראל כ"כ, עד שאפי' מצרי וישראלשותיןבספל א' הי' חציו מים וחציו דם, ולא מצינו דוגמתו בכל המכות, וטעמא בעי שהעלימו הכתוב.
translation: And all of Egypt dug around the Nile for water to drink, etc. The Ibn Ezra, may his memory be blessed, writes that many say the water was in the hands of the Egyptians red as blood and in the hands of the Israelites it was clear. If so, why is this not written in the Torah? And from this difficulty, one is compelled to say that the plague of blood and the frogs and the inclusion was for both the Egyptians and the Hebrews, and so it is with the other plagues, except for the three that are explicitly stated in the text that Israel was separated from them, which are the mixture of beasts, as it is written, "And I will make a distinction," etc., and in the plague of pestilence it is written, "And the Lord will make a distinction between the livestock of Egypt," etc., and in the hail it is written, "Only in the land of Goshen, where the children of Israel were, there was no hail," thus far. And the Avi Ezer wrote on the words of the aforementioned Rabbi that we have only the words of our sages, for from the plague of blood, Israel became wealthy, and even if a non-Jew and an Israelite drink from one cup, half of it was blood and half of it was water. And in my opinion, a mistaken and poor student wrote these words, etc. And so is the opinion of all the commentators, may their memory be blessed. However, according to their words, the question of the Rabbi is difficult: why did the text conceal such a wondrous miracle that was in the plague of blood, that Israel was so separated, that even if an Egyptian and an Israelite drink from one cup, half of it was water and half of it was blood, and we do not find its like in all the plagues, and a reason is needed for why the text concealed it.
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous distinction between the Israelites and Egyptians during the plague of blood, where the Egyptians' water turned to blood while the Israelites' remained drinkable. It highlights the theological insight that this separation signifies God's protection and favor towards the Israelites, even in shared circumstances. The author questions why such a significant miracle is not explicitly mentioned in the Torah, suggesting that it reflects a deeper understanding of divine intervention and the unique relationship between God and His chosen people. Ultimately, it emphasizes the theme of divine providence and the special status of Israel amidst the plagues.

passage_content: והרמב"ןז"ל כתב במכת ערוב עה"פ והפלתי ביום ההוא את ארץ גושן וגו', בעבור היות המכות הראשונות עומדות, איננו פלא שיהיו בארץ מצרים ולא בארץ גושן, אבל זו מכה משולחת וכאשר יעלו החיות מהררי נמרים וכו' ראוי הי' בטבעם שיבואו גם בארץ גושן אשר היא מכלל ארץ מצרים, לכך הוצרך והפלתי את ארץ גושן שתנצל כולה וכו' וכמו"כ נתן הרמב"ן ז"ל טעם במכת דבר וברד שהוצרך הכתוב לפרש שלא שלטו בישראל לצד הפלא שבהם עיי"ש,משא"כבשאר המכות לא הי' פלא שהובדלו ישראל מהם, ע"כ לא הוצרך הכתוב לפרשאת"דז"ל, הנה גם לדבריו יקשה ממכת דם, שהי' נס ההבדלה בו מופלג יותרמבערובודבר וברד, ומ"ט לא הודיע הכתוב נס ההבדלה בו כדרך שנתפרש בהם.
translation: And the Ramban, of blessed memory, wrote regarding the plague of frogs on the verse "And I will separate on that day the land of Goshen," that since the first plagues were standing, it is not surprising that they were in the land of Egypt and not in the land of Goshen. However, this plague is sent forth, and when the beasts rise from the mountains of leopards, it would be natural for them to also come into the land of Goshen, which is part of the land of Egypt. Therefore, it was necessary to say, "And I will separate the land of Goshen so that it will be entirely saved." Similarly, the Ramban, of blessed memory, gave a reason for the plagues of pestilence and hail, that the scripture needed to explain that they did not prevail over Israel due to the wonder in them, as opposed to the other plagues, where it was not surprising that Israel was separated from them; therefore, the scripture did not need to explain this. According to his words, it is also difficult regarding the plague of blood, where the miracle of separation was even more pronounced than in the plagues of frogs, pestilence, and hail. Why then did the scripture not inform us of the miracle of separation in that case as it was explained in the others?
summary: הרמב"ן ז"ל מסביר שהמכות במצרים היוו ניסים שמפרידים בין ישראל למצרים, כאשר מכות מסוימות, כמו מכת ערוב, דרשו הבהרה מיוחדת על ההגנה על ארץ גושן. הוא מציין שהמכות הראשונות לא היו פלא שהתרחשו במצרים, אך מכות משולחות כמו ערוב היו צריכות להדגיש את ההגנה על ישראל. בנוסף, הוא מתייחס למכת דם, ושואל מדוע לא הובהר הנס בהבדלה בו כמו במכות אחרות, מה שמעיד על עומק הנס וההגנה האלוהית על עם ישראל.

passage_content: ואפ"לבדרך פשטותעפי"משנתנו חז"ל (במד"רפר' ט' סי' ט') טעם למכת דם, מפני שמצרים עבדו לנילוס לפיכך הלקה את יראתם ואח"כ הלקה אותם ולהראות ביטולה של ע"ז שאין בו ממשאת"דז"ל, והנה היו רביםמבנ"ישנתפסו גם לע"ז במצרים כמבוארבדרז"ל, ואפשרדלאותןשעבדו ע"ז לא נעשה להם נס ההבדלה, ואף המים שבידם הי' לדם, להראות להם ביטולה של ע"ז שאין בו ממש,ומ"שרז"ל שהיו המים נעשו לדם ביד המצריונתהפכולמים ביד הישראל, זה הי' רקבבנ"יהכשרים שהובדלו מכל בחי' ע"ז. ע"כ לא הי' צורך אצלם להראות ביטולה של ע"ז ע"י שיתהפכו לדם,דמידשבא לידם נתבטל כל בחי' ע"ז שבו,וארז"לבגמ' (ע"ז נ"ג ע"א) בעכו"ם שמכר או משכן ע"ז לצורף ישראל ד"ה ביטל,דמידעידעדהאיתברלה, וכתבוהתוס' לאודוקאצורף,דכלישראל לגבי ע"זכצורפיןעיי"ש,ולפי"זאפשר שלא הובדלו כל ישראל ממכת הדם, כי אלו שהיו מודים בע"ז גם בידם נעשו המים לדם, לפי שהיו המיםמבחי' ע"ז, ואולידמ"שהראב"עששלטה מכת הדם גם בישראל, הכוונה ששלטהבמקצתן, ואינו סתירהלמ"שרז"ל שהי' ביד מצרי דם וביד ישראל מים, כי זה הי' רקבבנ"יהכשרים שכפרו בע"ז, ואולי לטעם זה לא פי' הכתוב נס ההבדלה במכת דם, מפני שלא הי' בכל ישראלשוה, ולעשות הפרש בין ישראל לא רצתההתוה"קלדבר בגנותן של ישראל, ע"כ לא גילה הכתוב נס ההבדלה בו כלל, ואוליעד"זבשאר המכות שלא פירש הכתוב נס ההבדלה בהם, היו שולטים גםבבנ"יבמקצתםבאותן שלא פירשו מע"ז, רק בערוב דבר וברד ביאר הכתובשלא שלטובבנ"יכללולפי"זיתיישבו דבריהראב"עז"ל להסיר ממנו הסתירהמדרז"ל.
translation: And even though, simply put, according to our Mishnah, the Sages (in Midrash Rabbah, Parashat Va'era, Section 9) gave a reason for the plague of blood, because Egypt worshipped the Nile, therefore their fear was struck, and afterwards they were punished, to demonstrate the nullification of idolatry, which has no substance, as it is said. And behold, many of the children of Israel were also caught up in idolatry in Egypt, as explained in the Sages. It is possible that for those who served idolatry, a miracle of separation was not performed for them, and even the water in their hands turned to blood, to show them the nullification of idolatry, which has no substance. And from what the Sages said that the water turned to blood in the hands of the Egyptians, while it was transformed to water in the hands of the Israelites, this was only for the children of Israel who were separated from all aspects of idolatry. Therefore, there was no need for them to demonstrate the nullification of idolatry by turning to blood, for as soon as it came into their hands, all aspects of idolatry within them were nullified. And the Sages said in the Gemara (Avodah Zarah 53a) regarding a non-Jew who sold or mortgaged an idol to a Jewish silversmith, it is nullified, for immediately it is considered nullified. And the Tosafot wrote that this is specifically regarding a silversmith, for all Jews regarding idolatry are like silversmiths, as explained there. According to this, it is possible that not all of Israel were separated from the plague of blood, because those who acknowledged idolatry also had their water turned to blood, since the water was from the aspect of idolatry. And according to what the Rabbi said, the plague of blood also affected Israel, meaning it affected some of them, and this does not contradict what the Sages said that in the hands of the Egyptian there was blood and in the hands of the Israelite there was water, for this was only for the children of Israel who denied idolatry. And perhaps for this reason the text did not explain the miracle of separation in the plague of blood, because it was not uniform among all of Israel, and to make a distinction between Israel, the Torah did not want to speak negatively about Israel. Therefore, the text did not reveal the miracle of separation in it at all. And perhaps for the same reason in the other plagues, where the text did not explain the miracle of separation in them, they also ruled over some of the children of Israel in those who did not separate from idolatry, only in the plague of swarms and hail did the text clarify that it did not rule over all the children of Israel. According to this, the words of the Rabbi can be reconciled to remove the contradiction from the Sages.
summary: The passage discusses the theological implications of the plagues in Egypt, particularly the plague of blood, emphasizing that it served to demonstrate the futility of idolatry. It suggests that those Israelites who were not fully separated from idolatrous practices experienced the plague as well, as their water turned to blood. The text highlights the distinction between the righteous Israelites, who were spared from this plague, and those who still held onto idolatry, illustrating the concept of divine separation and the necessity of true faith. Ultimately, it reflects on the broader theme of God's power over false gods and the importance of spiritual purity among the Jewish people.

passage_content: ואפ"ללאידךגיסאעפימ"שהאוהחה"קעה"פ ויעשו כן חרטומי מצרים וגו', לפי דבריהם ז"ל שהיו כל מימי מצרים לדם, א"כ מנין מצאו מים להפכו לדםוכו', ותירץעפימ"שרז"ל כי ישראלנתעשרוממכת היאור שהיו מוכרים מים למצריםוכו', כפי זה עשו החרטומים מהנמכר להם עכ"ד ז"ל, והנהכחהזה שניתןלהחרטומיםלעשות מופת הדם בכשפים, הי'בכחהסט"אוע"צהנסיוןוע"ד שביארנו בנס המטה עיי"ש, ואפשרדאלושהיושותיןבספל א' עם המצרי היו קרובים לדעתם ושיטתם, ומכרו להם מים לכוונה זו להראות מופת הדם בכשפים ולהטעות את ישראל אחריהם ולהחליש בהם האמונה בנסי משה ואהרןדע"ישיראו שגם החרטומים עושים כן בכשפים, יחשבו גם בניסיהם שהוא מעשה כשפים ח"ו, ומן הראוי הי' שלא יזמין ד' להם הנס ההוא שיהי' חלקם מים, אך נעשה להםהנס ג"כ ע"דהנסיוןוע"כ העלימה הכתוב ולא גילהו, וע"ד שפירשנו באמירת הנחש אל חוה, שלא סיפר הכתוב בנס של פתיחת פי הנחש, כמ"ש בנס פתיחת פי האתון,דשםאמרז"למלאך של רחמים הי' ובא למנעומלחטוא, נמצא הי' בחי' הנסמסיטראדקדושהע"כ גילהו הכתוב, אמנם בנסדנחששהי' ע"ד הסתה ומצדהסט"אע"כ העלימו הכתוב (עיי"דבעה"גסי' כ'), וכמו"כ בנס זה של מים לאלו ששתו בספל א' עם המצרים הי' כולוע"צהנסיוןלכך העלימו הכתוב.
translation: And even though on the other hand, as it is written, "And the magicians of Egypt did so," according to their words, may their memory be blessed, that all the waters of Egypt were turned to blood, how then did they find water to turn to blood, etc.? And it was explained according to the words of our Sages that the Israelites became wealthy from the plague of the Nile, as they were selling water to the Egyptians, etc. Based on this, the magicians did what was sold to them. Thus far their words. And behold, this power that was given to the magicians to perform the miracle of blood through sorcery was through the power of the Other Side and a test, as we explained regarding the miracle of the staff, see there. And it is possible that those who were drinking from one cup with the Egyptian were close to their opinion and method, and sold them water for this purpose, to show the miracle of blood through sorcery and to deceive Israel after them, and to weaken their faith in the miracles of Moses and Aaron, for they would see that the magicians also do so through sorcery, they might think that their miracles are also acts of sorcery, Heaven forbid. And it would have been appropriate that the Holy One, blessed be He, would not have prepared that miracle for them, that their portion would be water, but the miracle was also done for them as a test, and therefore the scripture concealed it and did not reveal it, and according to what we explained regarding the serpent's speech to Eve, that the scripture did not mention the miracle of the opening of the serpent's mouth, as it is written regarding the miracle of the opening of the donkey's mouth, where it is said that it was an angel of mercy who came to prevent her from sinning. Thus, it was in the category of a miracle from the Side of Holiness, therefore the scripture revealed it. However, in the miracle of the serpent, which was for the purpose of temptation and from the Other Side, therefore the scripture concealed it (see there in the section of the Great Book, section 20). Similarly, in this miracle of water for those who drank from one cup with the Egyptians, it was all for the purpose of a test, therefore the scripture concealed it.
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous transformation of water into blood by the Egyptian magicians, emphasizing that this act was rooted in the power of the "Sitra Achra" (the Other Side) and served as a test for the Israelites. It suggests that the magicians obtained water from the Israelites, intending to deceive them and weaken their faith in the miracles performed by Moses and Aaron. The text highlights the divine wisdom in allowing such a miracle to occur, as it served as a trial for the Israelites, while also noting the distinction between miracles of holiness and those of deception. Ultimately, the concealment of this miracle in the text reflects the nature of the spiritual struggle between divine truth and falsehood.

passage_content: ויאמרמשה לפרעה התפאר עלי למתי אעתיר לך וגו' להכרית הצפרדעים וגו' ויאמר למחר, ותמהו המפורשים כי מנהג כל אדם לבקשלהסררעתו מיד, ומדוע ביקש פרעה שיסורו רק למחר ויתמהמה בצרתו שלא לצורך.
translation: And Moses said to Pharaoh, "Glorify yourself over me; when shall I entreat for you..." to remove the frogs, etc. And he said, "Tomorrow." And the commentators were astonished, for it is the custom of every person to request the removal of their affliction immediately, so why did Pharaoh ask that they should only be removed tomorrow, and delay his suffering unnecessarily?
summary: בקטע זה, משה רבנו פונה לפרעה ומציע לו להפסיק את מכה הצפרדעים מיד, אך פרעה בוחר לדחות את הבקשה למחר. המפרשים תוהים על כך, שכן טבע האדם הוא לבקש להפסיק את הסבל מיד. התנהגות זו של פרעה משקפת את הקונפליקט הפנימי בין הרצון להימנע מכאב לבין ההבנה שהשינוי דורש זמן ומאמץ. בכך, הקטע מדגיש את המאבק בין חירות רוחנית לבין עבדות פנימית, ואת הצורך בתשובה אמיתית כדי לחוות גאולה.

passage_content: ב)כדבריך למען תדע כי אין כד'אלקינו, ראוי להבין איך יתברר לו ידיעה זו מהסרת הצפרדעים יותר מהסרת שאר המכות, ולא מצינושא"למשרע"הכן במכות אחרות כ"א במכת הצפרדעים בלבד וטעמא בעי.
translation: In accordance with your words, so that you may know that there is none like our God, it is fitting to understand how this knowledge is clarified to him through the removal of the frogs more than through the removal of the other plagues, and it is not possible to say that it was so for Moshe in the other plagues, but only in the plague of the frogs, and the reason is needed.
summary: The passage emphasizes the unique significance of the plague of frogs in demonstrating God's unparalleled nature. It suggests that the removal of the frogs serves as a specific revelation of divine knowledge, distinct from the other plagues. This highlights a deeper understanding of God's relationship with humanity and the particular lessons that can be drawn from each miraculous event. The inquiry into why this specific plague is chosen for such a demonstration reflects a broader theological exploration of divine intervention and awareness.

passage_content: ונל"פבהקדם דבריהגמ' (פסחים נ"ג ע"ב) מה ראו חנני'מישאלועזרי' שמסרו עצמן על קדושת השם לתוך כבשן האש נשאו ק"ו בעצמם מצפרדעים, ומה צפרדעים שאין מצווים עלקדה"שכתיב בהו ועלו ובאו בביתך וגו' ובתנוריך וכו' אנושמצוויןעלקדה"שעאכו"כ, וכתבוהתוס'ור"ימפרש מה ראו שלא ברחו, שהרי קודם המעשה היו יכולים לברוח עכ"ל, והקשו המפרשיםדלפי"דר"י אין כאן ק"ו,דשאניצפרדעים שנגזר עליהם בגזירת השם שיבואו באש,משא"כחנני'מישאלועזרי' לא נצטוו על זה כיון שהי' אפשר להם לברוח, (עיין בדברנו לעיל ביאורהעניןבאריכות) ועודלאלקימילין.
translation: And it is explained in advance by the words of the Gemara (Pesachim 53b) what Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah saw that they gave themselves over for the sanctification of the Name into the fiery furnace, they carried a fortiori within themselves from the frogs. And just as the frogs, who are not commanded regarding the sanctification of the Name, as it is written about them, "and they shall come into your house" etc., and into your ovens, etc., how much more so are humans commanded regarding the sanctification of the Name! And the Tosafot and Rashi wrote to explain what they saw that they did not flee, for before the act they could have escaped. Thus far the text. And the commentators questioned that according to the opinion of Rabbi Yochanan there is no a fortiori here, for the frogs were decreed by the decree of the Holy One Blessed be He to come into the fire, whereas Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah were not commanded regarding this since it was possible for them to flee (see our discussion above regarding this matter at length) and furthermore, it is not fitting to say.
summary: The passage discusses the profound commitment of Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah to sanctify God's name by willingly entering the fiery furnace, drawing a comparison to the frogs that were compelled by divine decree to enter the fire. It highlights the idea that while the frogs had no choice due to God's command, Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah chose to face death rather than abandon their faith, emphasizing the significance of free will in serving God. This act of self-sacrifice illustrates the ultimate devotion to divine principles, even in the face of mortal danger, showcasing a key Hasidic theme of the sanctity of God's name and the power of human agency in spiritual matters.

passage_content: ואפ"לדהנהתכלית ותועלת כל המכות היו להכניע ערפו הקשה ולבבו הערל עד שיאבה לשלח את ישראל, אלא שלא נשלמה פעולה זו בשלימות עד שעברו עליו כל המכות, כי נמדד עליו כאו"א כפי מדת רעתו והי' ראוי שיעברו עליו כולם, ועכ"פ בכל א' מהמכות נשלמה פעולה זו במקצת וחלק ממנה, וא"כלפי"זכיון שאמר פרעה העתירו אל ד' וגו' ואשלחה את העם ויזבחו לד', כבר נשלמה תכליתה של מכה זו והגיע עת הסרתה מיד,ולז"אמשרע"הלמתי אעתיר לך וגו' כי יתכן שיסורו מיד אם תרצה, אמנם פרעה התחכםברשעתווחשבשבלא"היסורו מיד, אחרי שאמר ואשלחה את העם וכנ"ל ולזה ביקשממשרע"השיתפלל שיסורו רק למחר, ולא יתקיימו דבריו כן, כי באמת כבר הגיע עת הסרתם היום,ועי"זיעשה דברימשרע"הפלסתר ח"ו, אמנם הצפרדעים אף שלא היו מצווים עוד שכבר הגיע עת הסרתם כנ"ל, מ"מ הוסיפו עוד יום א' לקדשש"ש, וא"שהק"ושלמדוחמ"ומהצפרדעים, שלא היו מצווים עוד בגזירת השםליכנסבתנורים. אעפ"כ מסרו עצמם לקדשש"ש, אנו על אחת כמה וכמה, ודבר זה לא עלה בדעתו של פרעה שהצפרדעים יתעכבו עד למחר כדי לקדשש"ש, וע"כ ביקש על למחר וכשיסורו היום יתמעטכבוד שמים ח"ו, והשיב לומשרע"הכדבריך שיסורו רק למחר למען תדע כי אין כד'אלקינושיתקדשש"שעל ידם.
translation: And behold, the ultimate purpose and benefit of all the plagues was to subdue his stiff neck and his uncircumcised heart until he would be willing to send Israel away. However, this action was not completed in full until all the plagues had passed over him, for each one was measured according to the degree of his wickedness, and it was fitting that all of them should pass over him. Nevertheless, in each of the plagues, this action was completed to some extent and part of it. And regarding this, Pharaoh said, "Entreat the Lord for me... and I will send the people and they will sacrifice to the Lord," the purpose of this plague was already fulfilled, and the time for its removal had arrived immediately. Therefore, when he said, "Entreat the Lord for me," it was possible that they would be removed immediately if he wished. However, Pharaoh cunningly thought that they would not be removed immediately, after he said, "I will send the people," as mentioned above. For this reason, he asked Moshe to pray that they be removed only tomorrow, and his words would not be fulfilled, for in truth, the time for their removal had already arrived today. And thus, Moshe would do something that would be a disgrace, Heaven forbid. However, the frogs, even though they were no longer commanded since the time for their removal had arrived, nevertheless added another day to sanctify the Sabbath. And regarding the frogs, they were no longer commanded by the decree of the Holy One, blessed be He, to enter the ovens. Nevertheless, they dedicated themselves to sanctifying the Sabbath. We, all the more so, and this thought did not enter Pharaoh's mind that the frogs would delay until tomorrow to sanctify the Sabbath. Therefore, he requested for tomorrow, for if they were to be removed today, the honor of Heaven would be diminished, Heaven forbid. And Moshe responded to him, "As you have said, they will be removed only tomorrow, so that you may know that there is no one like the Lord our God to sanctify the Sabbath through them.
summary: The passage discusses the purpose of the plagues in Egypt, emphasizing that they were intended to soften Pharaoh's hardened heart and compel him to release the Israelites. Each plague contributed to this goal, but Pharaoh's resistance delayed the complete fulfillment of this divine plan. When Pharaoh requested that the plagues be removed the next day, it highlighted his misunderstanding of God's sovereignty, as the frogs, despite no longer being commanded, chose to delay their removal to sanctify the Sabbath. This act demonstrated the importance of divine timing and the sanctification of God's name, contrasting Pharaoh's intentions with the higher purpose of glorifying God.

passage_content: ואפ"לעוד מדוע ביקש פרעה שיסורו רק למחרעפימ"דבמד"ר(פר' י' ס"ה) ויאמר למחר מכאן אתה למד שאותו היום הי' לו להשלים ז' ימים לכך א"ל משה למתי אעתיר לך למחר אעתיר לך ולא לאותו יום, ונקדים עוד מ"דבמד"ר(פר' ע' סי' י"ב) עה"פ וימלא שבעת ימים אחריהכותה' את היאור, ר' יהודה ור' נחמי', אחד מהם אומר כ"ד ימים הי' מתרה בהם עד שלא בא המכה, וז' ימים המכה משמשת בהם, וא' מהם אומר ז' ימים מתרה בהם וכ"ד ימיםהיתההמכה משמשת בהם, והנה כלל גדול בכל פלוגתת חז"לדאלוואלו דבריאלקיםחייםכאמרםז"ל (עירובין י"ג ע"א) וכתבהריטב"אשם וז"ל שאלו רבני צרפת ז"להאיךאפשר שיהי' שניהםדא"חוזה אוסר וזה מתיר, ותירצו כי כשעלה משה למרום לקבל תורה, הראו לו על כל דבר ודבר מ"ט פנים לאיסור ומ"ט פנים להיתר ושאל להקב"ה ע"ז, ואמר שיהא זה מסור לחכמי ישראל שבכל דור ודור ויהי' ההכרעה כמותן עכ"ל, מבואר שכלאו"אמדיעותהחולקים יש לה שורש בגבהי מרומיםוכחההכרעה נמסרה לחכמי הדור, והנהבעניןהמכות על המצריים פליגי חז"ל כמה ימים שימשה כל מכה, ח"א ז' ימים וח"א כ"ד יום, ובאותו הדור נמסרה ההכרעהלמרע"ה, וע"כ אמר לפרעה שיכול לברור א' משניהם או שיכרתו למחר שהוא יוםהז' להתחלת המכה כמבואר במדרש, או שתשמש המכה עד כ"ד יום, וכפי רצונו של פרעה יכריעמרע"ה, והשיב לו פרעה למחר כדרך בנ"א שאין רוצים לסבול צרתם כל שיש אפשרות להסירה, ולפי שנתן לומשרע"ההבחירה לברור על יום מחר או לסוף כ"ד יום, בחר בזמן המוקדם ואמר למחר.
translation: And furthermore, why did Pharaoh request that they only go tomorrow? From here you learn that on that day he was to complete seven days. Therefore, Moses said to him, "When shall I pray for you? Tomorrow I will pray for you, but not for that day." And we will also bring another source from the Midrash (Parashat Va'era, section 12) regarding the verse "And it filled the seven days after that" (Exodus 7:25). Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Nehemiah, one of them says that there were twenty-four days of warning before the plague came, and seven days the plague served them, and one of them says that there were seven days of warning and twenty-four days the plague served them. And behold, there is a great principle in all the disputes of our Sages, that if it were not for the words of the living God, as they said (Eruvin 13a), and as the Ritva wrote there, that the Rabbis of France asked how it is possible that one says it is forbidden and another permits it. They answered that when Moses ascended to the heavens to receive the Torah, he was shown each matter with forty-nine faces for prohibition and forty-nine faces for permission, and he asked the Holy One, Blessed be He, about this, and He said that it should be entrusted to the sages of Israel in every generation, and the decision would be like them. Thus, it is clear that each of the disputants has its root in the heights above, and the decision was entrusted to the sages of the generation. And behold, regarding the plagues upon the Egyptians, our Sages disagree on how many days each plague served: one says seven days and one says twenty-four days. And in that generation, the decision was given to Moses. Therefore, he said to Pharaoh that he could choose one of the two: either to cut it off tomorrow, which is the seventh day for the beginning of the plague, as explained in the Midrash, or that the plague would serve for twenty-four days. According to Pharaoh's desire, Moses would decide. And Pharaoh replied, "Tomorrow," in the manner of human beings who do not wish to endure their suffering as long as there is a possibility to remove it. And since Moses gave Pharaoh the choice to select either for tomorrow or for the end of twenty-four days, he chose the earlier time and said, "Tomorrow."
summary: In the passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the discussion revolves around Pharaoh's request to delay the plagues, highlighting the tension between divine judgment and human agency. The text emphasizes the concept that the resolution of disputes among the sages is rooted in a higher divine wisdom, with the authority to decide resting with the leaders of each generation. The differing opinions on the duration of the plagues illustrate the complexity of divine justice, where Pharaoh's choice reflects a common human desire to avoid immediate suffering. Ultimately, the passage underscores the interplay between free will and divine decree in the unfolding of events.
