passage_content: עודאפ"לבזה בהעיר עוד בשינוי הלשון מדברי פרעה לדברימרע"ה,דכתיבויקרא פרעה למשה ולאהרן ויאמר העתירו אל ה' ויסר הצפרדעים ממני ומעמי וגו' ולא ביקש על עבדיו, ובדברימרע"הכתיב למתי אעתיר לך ולעבדיךולעמך להכרית הצפרדעים וגו' וכן להלן וסרו הצפרדעים ממך ומבתיך ומעבדיך ומעמך וגו',ובודאינרמז איזה ענין בשינוי הזה ואין לומר שבדברי פרעה נכללו העבדים בתיבת עמו,דא"כלמה הוצרך משה רבינו להזכירם בפ"ע, ואין תיבה ואות מיותר בתוה"ק, עוד יש שינוי אחד במכת הצפרדעים מה שאינו כן בשאר המכות, והואמ"שמשרע"הבהתראתו לפרעה למען תדע כי אין כה'אלקינו, ובמכת ערוב כתיב למען תדע כי אני ה' בקרב הארץ, ובמכת ברד למען תדע כי לה' הארץ ולא אמר כי אין כה'אלקינו. ובאמת חילוק גדול יש בין הני תרי לישני, דאין כה'אלקנומורה על היחוד האמיתי שהואית"שאחד יחיד ומיוחד ואין עוד מלבדו,משא"כבמאמר אני ה' בקרב הארץ אינו מבורר יחודו ואחדותוית"ש, והי' פרעה יכול לטעות במאמר הזה כי אני ה' בקרב הארץ,שהאמנםשיש מציאות הבורא אבל ח"ו ב' רשויות הן,משא"כבמאמר אין כה'אלקינואין בו מקום לטעות, וא"כ צריך להבין מדוע במכת הצפרדעים בלבד אמרמרע"הלשון זה: ואיךנתבררלפרעה ידיעה זו מהסרת הצפרדעים יותר מבשאר המכות.
translation:
Furthermore, it can be said regarding this in the city, also with a change in the language from the words of Pharaoh to the words of Moshe Rabbeinu, as it is written: "And Pharaoh called for Moshe and Aharon and said, 'Entreat the Lord that He remove the frogs from me and my people,' etc., and he did not ask for his servants. And in the words of Moshe Rabbeinu it is written: 'For when shall I entreat for you and for your servants and for your people to exterminate the frogs,' etc., and similarly later: 'And the frogs shall depart from you and from your houses and from your servants and from your people,' etc. And indeed, there is a hint to some matter in this change, and one cannot say that in Pharaoh's words his servants were included in the term 'my people,' for why did Moshe Rabbeinu need to mention them separately? And there is no superfluous word or letter in the Holy Torah. 

There is also one more difference in the plague of frogs that is not the same as in the other plagues, which is that Moshe Rabbeinu, in his entreaty to Pharaoh, said: 'In order that you shall know that there is none like the Lord our God,' and in the plague of wild beasts it is written: 'In order that you shall know that I am the Lord in the midst of the land,' and in the plague of hail: 'In order that you shall know that the land is the Lord's,' and it does not say 'that there is none like the Lord our God.' 

And indeed, there is a great distinction between these two phrases, for 'there is none like the Lord our God' refers to the true uniqueness that He is One, Unique, and Singular, and there is none other besides Him, whereas in the phrase 'I am the Lord in the midst of the land' His uniqueness and oneness are not clarified, and Pharaoh could have erred in this statement 'I am the Lord in the midst of the land,' for indeed there is the existence of the Creator, but Heaven forbid, there are two authorities. However, in the phrase 'there is none like the Lord our God' there is no room for error. Therefore, one must understand why in the plague of frogs alone did Moshe Rabbeinu use this language: and how was this knowledge clarified to Pharaoh regarding the removal of the frogs more than in the other plagues.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between Pharaoh's request to Moses regarding the frogs and Moses' response, highlighting the theological implications of their language. It emphasizes that Pharaoh did not include his servants in his plea, suggesting a lack of concern for their suffering, while Moses explicitly mentions them, indicating a deeper compassion. Furthermore, the text contrasts the phrases used in the plagues, noting that the declaration "there is none like our God" emphasizes God's unique oneness, while "I am the Lord in the midst of the earth" could lead to misconceptions about the nature of divinity. This distinction underscores the importance of recognizing God's singularity and the clarity needed in understanding His true essence.

passage_content: ונל"פדהנהבמכה זו כתיב ויעשו כן החרטומים בלהטיהם ויעלו את הצפרדעים על ארץ מצרים אמנם במכת כנים לא יכלו להוציא את הכניםופרש"יהטעם שאין השד שולט על ברי' פחותהמכשעורהובעכ"חהודו שאצבעאלקיםהוא, ומאז גם בשאר המכות שאח"כ לא מצינו שניסו החרטומים לעשות כמעשה משה ואהרן, אף שאין שייך בהם טעם זה שאין השד שולטוכו',עכ"זכיוןשבעכ"חהודו במעשה משה ואהרן שאצבעאלקיםהמה לא ניסו עוד לעשות כמעשיהם, והנה במכת הצפרדעים הוסיפו גם החרטומים על המכה והעלו צפרדעים ע"י כישוף נוסף על הצפרדעים שהעלו משה ואהרן, ולא מצינו שהחרטומים הסירו אלו הצפרדעים שהביאובכחכשפיהם להכרית אותם,דזהלא הי' בכוחם לעשות וכ"כהראב"עז"ל עיי"ש, נמצא שהוצרך פרעה לסבול גם מהצפרדעים שהוסיפו חרטומיו ולא יכלו להכריתם, וע"כ כעס פרעה על חרטומיו שיודעיםרק להרע ולהטיב לא ידעו, ולזה אמרלמרע"ההעתירו אל ה' ויסר הצפרדעים ממני ומעמידייקא, ולא ביקש על עבדיו שהם החרטומים, כי רצה שיסבלו המכה אשר הביאו בעצמם כיון שאין בהםכחלהכריתם ורק להוסיף ידעו, אבלמרע"ההשיב לו אני אבקשמהשי"תיותר משאלתך וגם מעבדיך יסיר המכה, ע"ז ענה לו פרעה שעכ"פ לא יסיר מהם עד למחר, וממני ומעמי תסירם מיד, ומן החרטומים לא תסירם עד למחר, שעכ"פ יסבלו יום א' יותר, ויאמר לו משה רבינו כדבריך. ר"ל אעשה כדבריך שלא יסורו עד למחר, אךעי"זיהי' הכרחשתשארהמכה בכל ארץ מצרים עד למחר למען תדע כי אין כה'אלקינו.
translation: And it is explained that in this plague it is written, "And the magicians did so with their enchantments, and brought up frogs upon the land of Egypt." However, in the plague of lice, they could not bring forth the lice, and the reason is explained that the demon does not have power over a creation that is less than a barley grain. And afterwards, they acknowledged that it is the finger of God. And since then, in the other plagues that followed, we do not find that the magicians tried to do as Moses and Aaron did, even though this reason does not apply to them, that the demon does not have power, nevertheless, since they acknowledged afterwards in the act of Moses and Aaron that it is the finger of God, they did not try to do as their deeds. And behold, in the plague of frogs, the magicians also added to the plague and brought up frogs through sorcery in addition to the frogs that Moses and Aaron brought up, and we do not find that the magicians removed these frogs that they brought forth by the power of their sorcery to destroy them, for this was not within their power to do, as the Rabbi said there. It is found that Pharaoh had to endure also the frogs that his magicians added, and they could not destroy them. Therefore, Pharaoh was angry with his magicians, saying that they only knew how to do harm and not good. And for this, he said to Moses, "Entreat the Lord that He may take away the frogs from me and from my people," and he did not ask for his servants, who are the magicians, because he wanted them to endure the plague that they brought upon themselves, since they had no power to destroy them, only to add. But Moses replied to him, "I will ask from the Holy One, Blessed be He, more than your request, and He will also remove the plague from your servants." To this, Pharaoh answered him that at least He would not remove it from them until tomorrow, and from me and my people, remove them immediately, and from the magicians, He will not remove them until tomorrow, so that at least they will suffer one more day. And Moses our teacher said to him, "As you have said," meaning, "I will do as you have said, that they will not be removed until tomorrow," but through this, it will be necessary that the rest of the plague remain throughout the land of Egypt until tomorrow, so that you may know that there is none like our God.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the limitations of the Egyptian magicians in their attempts to replicate the plagues, particularly highlighting their inability to remove the frogs, which signifies the supremacy of God's power over sorcery. The text emphasizes that while the magicians could add to the plagues, they could not alleviate them, illustrating the theme that true divine authority cannot be challenged by human means. Pharaoh's request for the magicians to suffer the consequences of their actions reflects a deeper understanding of justice and accountability, while Moses' response underscores the notion of God's mercy and the ultimate purpose of demonstrating His unparalleled sovereignty. The passage concludes with the assertion that the persistence of the plagues serves to reveal the uniqueness of God in contrast to the impotence of false powers.

passage_content: וביאורהעניןעפי"מדאיתאבגמרא (סנהדרין ס"ז ע"ב)א"ריוחנן למה נקרא שמן כשפיםשמכחישיןפמליאשל מעלה, אין עוד מלבדוא"רחנינאאפילו לדבר כשפים, (פירש"יאין בהםכחלפני גזירתו שאיןכחמלבדו) ההיאאיתתאדהותקאמהדראלמשקלעפראמתותי כרעי' דר'חנינא, אמר לה אי מסתייעתזילעביד אין עוד מלבדו כתיב עכ"דהגמ', והנה אם הי'מרע"העושה כדברי פרעה להכרית הצפרדעים מכל ארץ מצרים היום ורק אצל החרטומיםישארועד למחר, מסתמא היו נשארו אותן הצפרדעים שהוסיפו החרטומים ע"י כישוף,דכלדבר נמשך אחרי שורשו ואותן הצפרדעים שהביאו היו נשאריםליסרםע"ד תיסרך רעתך, אמנם כי כן יהי' להםלהמכשפיםפתחון פה לומר שכח הכישוף חזק הוא ח"ו יותרמכחהשמים, והראי' שמשה לא הי' יכול להכרית הצפרדעים שהעלובכחהכישוף, ונמצא היומכחישיןאמונת אין עוד מלבדו ואפי' כשפים, לזה הי' הכרחשישארוכל הצפרדעים עד למחר ולא יהי' להם פתחון פה, ויתברר להם שאין עוד מלבדו אפילו לדבר כשפים, וזה שאמרמרע"הלפרעה אחר שביקש מאתו להשאיר הצפרדעים על החרטומים עד למחר, א"ל כדבריך פי' שלפי דבריך מוכרחשישארוכל הצפרדעים עד למחר למען תדע כי אין כה'אלקינוולא יוכלו החרטומים לעשות דבר להקדים הסרתם או למנוע ובעל כרחם יודו שאין כה'אלקינואפילו לדבר כשפים.
translation: And the explanation of the matter according to what is stated in the Gemara (Sanhedrin 67b) is that Rabbi Yochanan said: Why is it called the oil of sorcery? Because it denies the heavenly entourage. There is none other than Him, and Rabbi Chanina said that even to speak of sorcery (he explained that there is no power other than His). That woman who was coming to draw water from the well of the dead, said to her: If you are able, go and do, for it is written, "There is none other than Him." Thus the Gemara states. And behold, if Moshe Rabbeinu had acted according to Pharaoh's words to eradicate the frogs from all the land of Egypt today, and only with the magicians would they remain until tomorrow, surely those frogs that the magicians added through sorcery would have remained, for everything follows its root, and those frogs that they brought would remain to punish them according to "I will punish you for your evil." However, thus it would be for the sorcerers to have a mouth to say that the power of sorcery is strong, Heaven forbid, more than the power of Heaven. And the proof is that Moshe was unable to eradicate the frogs that were brought by the power of sorcery. And thus today they deny the belief in "There is none other than Him," and even regarding sorcery. Therefore, it would have been fitting for the frogs to remain until tomorrow, and they would have no mouth to speak, and it would be clarified to them that there is none other than Him, even to speak of sorcery. And this is what Moshe said to Pharaoh after he requested from him to leave the frogs with the magicians until tomorrow: He said to him, "According to your words," meaning that according to your words, it is fitting that all the frogs remain until tomorrow, so that you may know that there is none like our God, and the magicians will not be able to do anything to hasten their removal or to prevent it, and against their will they will admit that there is none like our God, even to speak of sorcery.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of "Ein Od Milvado" (There is none besides Him) in the context of the power of sorcery and its limitations compared to divine authority. It illustrates that even the magicians of Pharaoh could not truly replicate the miracles performed by Moses, as their powers are ultimately subordinate to God's will. The text emphasizes that the existence of sorcery serves to highlight God's supremacy, as any semblance of power from the magicians is merely an illusion. Thus, the persistence of the frogs until the next day serves as a testament to the truth that there is no power greater than that of the Almighty.

passage_content: ויאמרד' אל משה השכם בבקר וגו' כי אם אינך משלח את עמי הנני משליח בך ובעבדיך ובעמך ובבתיך את הערוב וגו', והפליתי ביום ההוא את ארץ גושן וגו' ושמתי פדות בין עמי ובין עמך למחר יהי' האות הזה,פרש"יז"ל והפליתי והפרשתיוכו', ושמתי פדות שיבדיל בין עמי ובין עמך עכ"ל, ולפי פירושו שניהם מלשון הבדלה והפרשה, וראוי להבין מה צורך לכפול הלשון במלות שונות, גם צ"ב מדוע הוצרך הכתוב לפרט במכות הערובדייקא, שהפריש הקב"ה את ישראל ולא שלטה בהם המכה, וכמו"כ הופרשוונצולובני ישראל מכל המכות שלא שלטו בהן, ובאבן עזרא כתב(בפ' דם)דכלהמכות היו כוללת המצריים והעבריים חוץ מערוב דבר וברד, שפירש בהם הכתוב שהיו ישראל מופרשים ממנה, וכתב עליו האבי עזרי אנו אין לנו אלא דברי רז"ל, כי ממכת דםנתעשרוישראל, ואפי'נכריוישראלשותיןבספל א' הי' חציו דם וחציו מים, ולפי דעתי תלמיד טועה ועני בדעת כתב הדברים האלה עכ"ל, ולפי דברי רז"ל צריך ליתן טעם מדוע הוצרך הכתוב לפרט במכת הערוב שהופרשו ישראל ממנה, וכן הי' בכל המכות, ולא עוד אלא שכפלו הכתוב והפליתי וגו' ושמתי פדותוצ"ב.
translation: And G-d said to Moses, "Get up early in the morning, etc. For if you do not send out My people, behold, I will send upon you and your servants and your people and your houses the swarms of insects, etc., and I will make a distinction on that day in the land of Goshen, etc., and I will set a redemption between My people and your people; tomorrow this sign will be." The explanation of the holy Rabbi is that "I will make a distinction" and "I will separate," etc., and "I will set a redemption" means that it will distinguish between My people and your people. Thus far the text. According to his explanation, both terms are from the language of distinction and separation, and it is appropriate to understand why the language is doubled with different words. It is also necessary to clarify why the text needed to specify regarding the plague of the swarms, that the Holy One, Blessed be He, separated Israel and the plague did not prevail over them. Likewise, the children of Israel were separated and saved from all the plagues that did not prevail over them. And Ibn Ezra wrote (in the section of Blood) that all the plagues included the Egyptians and the Hebrews, except for the swarms, pestilence, and hail, where the text specifies that Israel was separated from them. And the father of the helper wrote, "We have only the words of our sages," for from the plague of blood, Israel became wealthy, and even the Egyptians who drank from one cup had half blood and half water. In my opinion, a mistaken and poor student wrote these words. Thus far the text. According to the words of our sages, it is necessary to provide a reason why the text needed to specify regarding the plague of the swarms that Israel was separated from it, and so it was with all the plagues. Moreover, the text doubled the phrases "I will make a distinction" and "I will set a redemption," etc.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the divine distinction made by God between the Israelites and the Egyptians during the plagues, particularly emphasizing the concept of "p'dut" (redemption) and separation. The repetition of terms related to separation highlights the importance of this distinction, suggesting a deeper theological insight into God's protective relationship with His people. The text also questions the necessity of detailing the specific plagues from which the Israelites were spared, indicating a profound understanding of divine intervention and the nature of suffering. Ultimately, it reflects on the significance of spiritual separation and redemption in the context of divine justice and mercy.

passage_content: ב)אונקלספי' פדות מלשון פדיון,ואשויפורקן לעמי ועל עמך איתי מחא, וכן דרשו רז"לבמד"ר(י"א ב') ושמתי פדות בין עמי, מלמד שהיו ישראלראוייןללקות בזו המכה, ונתן הקב"ה פדיונם המצרים, ואףלע"להקב"ה מביא עכו"ם הקדמונים ומשליכן לתוךגהינםתחת ישראל שנא' כי אני ד'אלקיךוגו' נתתי כפרך מצרים כוש וסבא תחתיך עכ"ד המדרש, וראוי להבין מה נשתנה מכת הערוב שהיו ישראל ראויים ללקות בזו יותר משאר המכות, גם אם ישראל ראויים ללקות איך יהיו המצריםוהאומה"עפדיונם, ולא עבידקוב"הדינאבלאדינא, גם צ"ב בלשוןהמדרששלע"להקב"ה מביא עכו"ם הקדמונים ומשליכן לתוךגהינםתחת ישראל, ומדוע עכו"ם הקדמוניםדייקא, והאחרונים ג"כ רשעים וראויים לזה.
translation:
In the translation of the Hebrew text from Sefer Divrey Yoel:

"Regarding the term 'redemption' from the word 'pidyon,' and I will redeem them for My people, and for Your people, I will be with you, as our Sages expounded in Midrash Rabbah (11:2), 'And I will place redemption between My people,' teaching that the Israelites were deserving of suffering from this plague, and the Holy One, blessed be He, gave them their redemption from the Egyptians. Furthermore, the Holy One, blessed be He, brings the ancient nations and casts them into Gehenna in place of Israel, as it is stated, 'For I am the Lord your God... I have given your ransom, Egypt, Cush, and Seba in your stead.' Thus says the Midrash. It is appropriate to understand what distinguishes the plague of the swarms, that the Israelites were more deserving of suffering from this than from the other plagues. Even if the Israelites were deserving of suffering, how could the Egyptians and the nations of the world be their redemption? And does the Holy One, blessed be He, not act according to the law? Additionally, it is puzzling in the language of the Midrash that the Holy One, blessed be He, brings the ancient nations and casts them into Gehenna in place of Israel, and why specifically the ancient nations, when the latter ones are also wicked and deserving of this."
summary: The passage discusses the concept of redemption (פדות) in the context of the plagues in Egypt, emphasizing that the Israelites were deserving of punishment but were spared through divine intervention. It highlights the idea that God provided a "redemption" for the Israelites by punishing the Egyptians instead, raising questions about the justice of this divine action. The text also queries why specifically ancient nations are mentioned as being cast into Gehenna for the sake of Israel, suggesting a deeper theological reflection on the nature of divine justice and mercy. Ultimately, it underscores the unique relationship between God and Israel, where redemption is intricately linked to the fate of other nations.

passage_content: ג)פדות וגו' למחר יהי' האות הזה, צ"בדא"אלומר מחר ממש,דזמןהתראת המכה הי' יותר מיום א' לד"ה, למר ז' ימים ולמר כ"א יום, ואם הכוונה על מחר שהוא לאחר זמן. צ"ב מדוע הזכירו הכתוב ואיננו מוגבל ומבורר הזמןבלא"ה, גם לא נמצא כן בשאר המכות ומדוע במכת ערובדייקאאמר כן.
translation: 3) Redemption, etc. Tomorrow this sign will be, as it is said, "Tomorrow" specifically, for the time of warning of the plague was more than one day according to the calendar, for some it was seven days and for others twenty-one days. And if the intention is for tomorrow which is after a certain time. It is puzzling why the scripture mentioned it and it is not limited and clarified in time otherwise, and it is also not found in the other plagues, and why specifically in the plague of swarms is it stated this way.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine timing in the context of the plagues, specifically the plague of swarms (ערוב). It highlights that the announcement of the plague includes a specific timeframe, indicating a deeper significance in God's communication. The text questions why this particular plague is marked with a precise time reference, unlike the others, suggesting a unique theological insight into the nature of divine intervention and the importance of timing in the unfolding of events. This reflects a Hasidic understanding of the interplay between divine will and the human experience of time.

translation: "And I brought a tradition and I placed redemption between My people and between your people, a redemption sent to the world for His covenant, for with G-d is kindness and much with Him is redemption."
summary: The passage emphasizes the concept of redemption (פדות) as a divine promise between God and His people, highlighting the significance of this covenant in the context of Hasidic thought. It underscores the idea that God's relationship with humanity is rooted in kindness (חסד), suggesting that redemption is not only a physical deliverance but also a spiritual connection. The text reflects the belief that through this covenant, God's grace and mercy are continually bestowed upon His people, reinforcing their identity and purpose in the world.

passage_content: ונל"פדהנהכל המכות באו על המצריים מידה כנגד מידה כמבואר בדברי רז"ל, ובמכת ערוב נתנו רז"ל טעםבמד"ר(פי"בס"ג) אמררשב"לאמר להם הקב"ה אתם עשיתם המונים על עמי, אף אני אעשה עליכם עוף השמים וחית הארץ המוניםהמונים, שנאמר הנני משליח בך את הערוב חיות ועופותמעורבבין, ופי'ביפ"תשקבוץ החיות זו עם זו וכן העופות זו עם זו אע"פ שהם מינים שונים אינו כ"כ חידוש, לכן צ"ל כי החידוש כאן הי' קיבוץ החיות עם העופות דלאדבקיןדנא עם דנא עכ"ל, והנה אין לך דבר בעולם מזיק לנפש מהתערבות והתדמות לגוים,כמשה"כויתערבו בגוים וילמדו מעשיהם, וזה גרם הירידה הנוראה לישראל במצרים, כמ"ש רז"ל במדרש ילקוט ובפסיקתא עה"פ וימת יוסף וכל אחיו וגו' ותמלא הארץ אותם,א"ריוחנן שמלאו את מצרים, דבר אחר שנתמלאו בתיטרטיאותובתיקרקסיאותמהם, וע"י התערובת והתבוללות התחילו לדמות למעשה ארץ מצריםואמרז"לבמד"רללמדך כשמת יוסף הפרו ברית מילה אמרו נהי' כמצרים ואפשרדע"כהי' קטרוג גדול על ישראל שגם המה ראויים ללקות במכת ערוב מידה כנגד מידה עבור חטא ההתערבות טהור בטמא דלאדבקיןדנא עם דנא, ועוד ישמבחי' התערובת בישראל מה שאינו נוהגבאומה"עכלל, היינו שאם מכניסים במעשה עבודת המצותוהתוה"קמחשבה זרה לשם פני' או מחשבה פסולה ר"ל,עי"זמערבים קודש בחול וטומאה בטהרה, ולא יתכן בחי' תערובת זובאוה"עשהם משורש הטומאה לגמרי ומשוקעים בה, ולזה הי' קטרוג על ישראל שגם הם ראויים ללקות במכה זו מידה כנגד מידה, אמנם ריחם הקב"ה עליהם ונתן פדיונם המצריים, כי הם היו הגורמים להחטיא את ישראל ועל ידם באו ישראל לירידה זו, וע"כ מגיע מדת העונש עליהם, וע"ד שפי' ק"ז הישמח משהזלה"הדברי המדרש ילקוט פ' בשלח (רמז רל"ד) והמים להם חומה חמה כתיב שנתמלא עליהם הים חמה להטביעןוכו', מיד אותה חמה שנתמלא על ישראל החזירו על מצרים, והטעם על כי הם היו הגורמים להחטיאם, ע"כ גם מדת עונשם של ישראל יחולו על ראשיהם (עיין בדברנו לעיל).
translation: And all the plagues came upon the Egyptians measure for measure, as explained in the words of our Sages. And regarding the plague of swarms, our Sages gave a reason in Midrash Rabbah (Chapter 12, Section 3), Rabbi Shimon said: "To tell them that the Holy One, blessed be He, said: You have made multitudes upon My people, so I will also bring upon you the birds of the sky and the beasts of the earth in multitudes, as it is said, 'Behold, I am sending upon you the swarms of beasts and birds mixed together.' And the explanation is that the gathering of the beasts with one another and the birds with one another, even though they are different species, is not such a novelty; therefore, it must be that the novelty here was the gathering of the beasts with the birds, that they do not adhere to one another. Thus, there is nothing in the world more harmful to the soul than the mixing and resembling of the nations, as it is written, 'And they mixed with the nations and learned their deeds.' This caused the terrible downfall of Israel in Egypt, as our Sages said in the Midrash Yalkut and in Pesikta on the verse, 'And Joseph died, and all his brothers, and so on, and the land was filled with them.' Rabbi Yochanan said that they filled Egypt, another explanation is that they were filled with filth and abominations from them. And through the mixing and assimilation, they began to resemble the deeds of the land of Egypt, and our Sages said in the Midrash to teach you that when Joseph died, they nullified the covenant of circumcision, saying, 'Let us be like the Egyptians.' And it is possible that there was a great accusation against Israel, that they too were worthy of being struck by the plague of swarms measure for measure for the sin of mixing the pure with the impure, that they do not adhere to one another. Furthermore, there is a type of mixing among Israel that does not occur among the nations at all, which is that if they introduce a foreign thought into the service of the commandments and the Torah, or a flawed thought, through this they mix the holy with the mundane and impurity with purity, and it is not possible for a type of mixture to arise from the root of impurity entirely and to be submerged in it. And for this reason, there was an accusation against Israel that they too were worthy of being struck by this plague measure for measure. However, the Holy One, blessed be He, had mercy on them and gave their redemption to the Egyptians, for they were the ones who caused Israel to sin, and through them Israel came to this downfall. Therefore, the measure of punishment comes upon them, and as explained in the Midrash Yalkut Parashat Beshalach (Remez 234), 'And the waters were a wall for them,' it is written that the sea was filled with heat to drown them, and immediately that heat that was filled upon Israel was returned upon the Egyptians, and the reason is that they were the ones who caused them to sin. Therefore, the measure of their punishment will also fall upon their heads (see our discussion above).
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine justice, emphasizing that the plagues inflicted upon Egypt were a measure-for-measure response to their actions against the Israelites. It highlights the dangers of assimilation and the spiritual consequences of the Israelites adopting Egyptian practices, which led to their moral decline. Despite their shortcomings, God showed mercy to the Israelites by allowing the Egyptians to bear the brunt of the punishment, as they were the instigators of Israel's downfall. This reflects the Hasidic belief in the interconnectedness of actions and the importance of maintaining spiritual purity.

passage_content: ואפ"לעוד בהקדם דברי הכלי יקר עה"פ הנה אנכי מכה במטך וגו' שנתן טעם על כל המכות עפ"י דרכו עיי"ש, ובמכת הערוב פי' ערוב באו עליהם לפישנשתעבדובישראל שנמשלו לחיות כמושפירש"יעל פסוק כי חיות הנה עכ"דלעניננו, ואפשר להמתיק טעם זהבתוס' נופך עלדבה"ק, בהקדם שפירשנו לעילבפ' שמות עה"פ כי לא כנשים המצריות העבריות כי חיות הנה,דהנההאומה"ענמשלו לחיות טורפות על בחי' הרע שבהם, כמ"שבזוה"ק(ר"פ שמות) ממעונות אריות אלין בני שעיר וכו' מהררי נמרים אלו בני ישמעאל עכ"ד, אבל ישראל נמשלו לחיותע"צהטובה,כאמרז"להוי עז כנמרוגבורכארי וכו' לעשות רצון אביך שבשמים,ואמרז"לבמד"רפ' בשלח (כ"א ס"ה) אמר הקב"ה לישראלוכו', אצלי הם כיונה פותה, כל מה שאני גוזר עליהם עושים ושומעים לי, אבל אצל עכו"ם הם קשים כחיות שנא' גור ארי' יהודה בנימן זאביטרףוכו',וז"פכי לא כנשים המצריות העבריות כי חיות הנהע"צהקדושה, ולא כנשים המצריות שנמשלולמדותהגרועים שבחיות, ואדרבה לזה הם משולים לחיות שיתגברובעזותןאפי' כנגד גזירת המלך ולא יתדמו לנשים המצריות לעולם, ולא תוכל להם להחטיאם בעריותעייש"דבאריכות.
translation: And I will add, in advance, the words of the Kli Yakar on the verse "Behold, I strike with my staff," etc., who gives an explanation for all the plagues according to his way, see there. And regarding the plague of the mixture, he explains that the mixture came upon them because they were enslaved to Israel, who are compared to animals, as it is explained in the verse "for they are animals." Thus far his words. And it is possible to sweeten this explanation with an additional nuance on the holy words, in advance of what we explained above in Parashat Shemot on the verse "for they are not like the Egyptian women, the Hebrew women, for they are animals," for behold, the nation is compared to predatory animals in the aspect of the evil within them, as it is written in the Zohar (Parashat Shemot) from the dwellings of lions, these are the sons of Seir, etc., from the mountains of leopards, these are the sons of Ishmael. Thus far his words. But Israel are compared to good animals, as it is said, "to be strong as a leopard, courageous as a lion," etc., to do the will of your Father in heaven. And our sages say in Midrash Rabbah, Parashat Beshalach (21:65), the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Israel, etc., "With Me, they are like a gentle dove; whatever I decree upon them, they do and listen to Me," but with the nations of the world, they are as fierce as animals, as it is said, "The lion's cub is Judah; Benjamin is a wolf that tears," etc. And this is the meaning of "for they are not like the Egyptian women, the Hebrew women, for they are animals of holiness," and not like the Egyptian women who are compared to the worst of animals. On the contrary, they are compared to animals that are strong in their boldness even against the king's decree and will not be compared to the Egyptian women ever, and they will not be able to lead them to sin with immorality, as I have explained at length.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between the spiritual nature of the Jewish people and that of the Egyptians, emphasizing that Jews are likened to noble animals, embodying strength and righteousness, while Egyptians are compared to predatory beasts, representing their moral degradation. It highlights that the Jewish people, as "good animals," are obedient to God's will, contrasting with the stubbornness of the Egyptians, who are likened to wild beasts. This reflects a broader Hasidic theme of the inherent holiness and potential for elevation within the Jewish soul, as well as the importance of aligning oneself with divine purpose. Ultimately, the text underscores the unique spiritual identity of the Jewish people in relation to their oppressors.

passage_content: ועפ"ידרכנו מצינו טעם למכת הערוב שהי' מדה כנגד מידה, על שהשתמשו המצרים במידת חיות טורפות עם ישראל באכזריות נורא בלי חמלה,ע"כ מידהכ"מהביא הקב"ה עליהם חיות טורפות, והנה בהתחלת ימי השעבוד עדיין היו ישראלבבחי' הקדושה להיותן משולים לחיותע"צהטובה,לעזותושל נמר וגבורתו של ארי להתגבר נגד כוחות הטומאה והמסיתים, אמנם אחר זמן ועידנים ירדוממדריגתםוהשקעו בכובד הגלותוהנסיונותעד שהגיעו למ"ט שערי טומאהכאמרז"ל, ונדבק בהםממדותהרעות של מצרים עד שנמשלולעזותןשל חיותע"צהרעה,כאמרז"לג'עזיןהן ישראל באומותוכו', ואלמלא ניתנה תורה לישראל לא הי' כל ברי' יכולה לעמוד בפניהם מפניעזותן,ולז"אבמדרש שהיו ישראלראוייןללקות במכה זו לפי שהשתמשו ג"כ במידות חיות הטורפותוקיטרגהמידת הדין עליהם שגם הם ראויים ללקות, אלא שריחם הקב"ה עליהם ונתן פדיונם המצריים, שהם היו הגורמים והביאו אותם לזה, ע"כנלקוהמצריים תחתיהם.
translation: And according to our way, we find a reason for the plague of the wild beasts, which was measure for measure, because the Egyptians used the trait of wild beasts against the Jewish people with terrible cruelty and without mercy. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, brought upon them wild beasts. And behold, at the beginning of the days of servitude, the Jews were still in a state of holiness, being compared to good wild beasts, to the audacity of the leopard and the strength of the lion to overcome the forces of impurity and the instigators. However, after a time and ages, they descended from their level and became immersed in the heaviness of the exile and the trials until they reached the forty-nine gates of impurity, as our sages have said. They became attached to the evil traits of Egypt until they were drawn to the audacity of the bad wild beasts, as our sages have said, "The audacious ones are Israel among the nations," etc. And if the Torah had not been given to Israel, no creature would have been able to stand before them because of their audacity. And thus it is said in the Midrash that the Jews were worthy of being struck by this plague because they also used the traits of wild beasts, and the attribute of judgment was invoked against them, for they too were deserving of punishment. However, the Holy One, blessed be He, had mercy on them and gave them redemption from the Egyptians, for they were the ones who caused and brought them to this, as it is written that the Egyptians were drawn under them.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine retribution, illustrating how the Egyptians' cruel treatment of the Israelites, likened to predatory animals, led to their punishment through the plagues. Initially, the Israelites embodied holiness and strength, akin to noble beasts, but over time, they succumbed to the impurities of exile, adopting the negative traits of their oppressors. Despite their shortcomings, God showed mercy by redeeming them from the Egyptians, who were ultimately responsible for their suffering. This reflects the Hasidic belief in the interplay of divine justice and compassion, emphasizing the transformative power of the Torah in elevating the Jewish people.

passage_content: ולדרכינויתבאר סיום דברי המדרש ואףלע"להקב"ה מביא עכו"ם הקדמונים ומשליכן לתוךגהינםתחת ישראל,דהנהבעוה"רבדראבתראההע"רנעשו למושלים בישראל, ואחת מטרתם לעשות כל תועבות אשר שנא ד', וחוקקים חקי זימה אשר לא נשמע אף בגרועים שבאומות, וכבר פירשתיבמאמה"כאיעצךאשר יעשה העם לעמך באחרית הימים. שהתנבא בלעם הרשעדעצהזו של זימה יעשה העם הזה לעמך באחרית הימים, ע"י שימשלו בםרשעיםואומה"עילמדו מהם דרכי הזימה, ולזה יהי' פתחון פהלאומה"עלע"ל, מדוע מגיע להם עונשגיהנםיותר מישראל, וע"כ הקב"ה מביא עכו"ם הקדמונים ומשליכןלגיהנםתחת ישראל, כי בימיהם היו ישראל מתנהגים בגדרי הקדושה והצניעות, והם אשר גרמו להחטיאם וכמו שהתגברו המצריים ובלעם הרשע לעשותם רעים וחטאים, וע"כ גם מדת עונשם של ישראל יחולו על ראשם.
translation: And it will be explained according to our way the conclusion of the words of the Midrash, and even to the Holy One, blessed be He, He brings the ancient idolaters and casts them into Gehenna beneath Israel. Behold, in this present time, the wicked have become rulers over Israel, and one of their goals is to do all the abominations which the Holy One, blessed be He, hates, and to enact laws of immorality which have not been heard even among the worst of nations. And you have already explained in the verse, "I will counsel you what this people will do to your people in the end of days," that Balaam the wicked prophesied that this people will do this immorality to your people in the end of days, by having the wicked rule over them, and the nations will learn from them the ways of immorality. And thus there will be a justification for the nations to say, why they deserve the punishment of Gehenna more than Israel. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, brings the ancient idolaters and casts them into Gehenna beneath Israel, for in their days Israel conducted themselves within the bounds of holiness and modesty, and they are the ones who caused them to sin, just as the Egyptians and the wicked Balaam prevailed to make them evil and sinful. Therefore, the measure of punishment of Israel will also fall upon their heads.
summary: The passage discusses the theological concept that in the end of days, the actions of the nations will lead to the downfall of Israel, as they will adopt immoral practices. It emphasizes that the ancient nations, who caused Israel to stray from holiness and modesty, will be punished in Gehenna beneath Israel, as their influence led to Israel's sins. This reflects the idea that the sins of Israel, influenced by these nations, will result in a shared consequence, highlighting the interconnectedness of moral behavior and divine justice. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of maintaining sanctity to avoid the repercussions of external corrupting influences.

passage_content: ובזהיתבאר המסורה ושמתי פדות בין עמי וגו' שהיו ישראלראוייןללקות בזו המכה ונתן הקב"ה פדיונם המצריים, ואףלע"ליהי' כן, וזהו פדות שלח לעמוצוהלעולם בריתו שיהי' פדות הזאת בחי' נצחית נוהג לעולם, והטעם כי עם ד' החסד והרבה עמו פדות, כיהבוי"תיודע כל תעלומות חוקר כליות ולב, והוא יודע ועד כי לא בבחירתם עשו ישראל את כל הרעה, אלאהעכו"םהיו הגורמים להחטיא אותם, וע"כ והרבה עמו פדות ליתןהאומה"עפדיונם של ישראל.
translation: And in this, it is explained in the tradition, "And I have placed redemption between My people," etc. that the Israelites were deserving of being struck by this plague, and the Holy One, blessed be He, gave them their redemption from the Egyptians. And so it will be in the future. This is the redemption that He sent to His people, to be an eternal covenant, that this redemption should be a perpetual state forever. The reason is that with God is mercy, and much with Him is redemption, for He knows all secrets, and He searches the kidneys and the heart, and He knows and sees that it was not by their choice that the Israelites did all the evil, but rather the idolaters were the ones who caused them to sin. Therefore, "and much with Him is redemption" to give the nations of the world the redemption of Israel.
summary: The passage emphasizes the concept of redemption (פדות) as a divine gift to the Jewish people, highlighting that they were deserving of punishment yet received salvation from God. This redemption is portrayed as an eternal covenant, reflecting God's enduring kindness and mercy. It underscores the belief that the sins of Israel were not solely due to their own choices, but rather influenced by external forces, thus reinforcing the idea of divine compassion and the perpetual nature of God's relationship with His people.

passage_content: ונקדיםמ"דבתנחומאויצום אלבנ"יואל פרעה מלך מצרים, אמר להם הקב"ה היונוהגיןבו כבוד וחלקו כבוד למלך שאני צריך לו לעשות בו את הדיןוצ"ב,ובמד"ר(פר' ז' ס"ג) אל פרעה מלך מצריםא"רלוי משל למלך שהי' לו פרדס ונטע בו אילני סרק ואילני מאכל, אמרו לו עבדיו מה הנאה יש לך באילני סרק הללו, אמר להם כשם שאני צריך לאילני מאכל כך אני צריך לאילני סרק שאילולא אילני סרק מהיכן הייתי עושה לי מרחצאות וכבשונות, לכך נאמר אל בני ישראל ואל פרעה שכשם שקילוסו של הקב"ה עולה מג"ע מפי הצדיקים, כך עולהמגיהנםמפי הרשעיםוכו', מה הם אומרים, אמר ר"י יפה אמרת יפה דנתוצ"בכוונת המשל ולכאורה אינו דומה לגמרי אל הנמשל,דמאילניסרק יש הנאה למלך שעושה על ידן כבשונות, אבל הרשעים מה צורך להן ולקילוסן, אמנם יתבאר לדרכנו שיש צורך ברשעים לעשות בהם כבשונותכהמשלשל אילני סרק, שעתיד הקב"ה להשליכןלגיהנםתחת ישראל לפי שהם היו הגורמים להחטיא את ישראל, והם מצדיקים עליהם הדין ואומרים יפה דנת, ואף פרעה הי' צורך בו לעשות בו את הדין אף בשביל ישראל.
translation: And we will precede with the explanation of the Midrash in Tanchuma: "And He said to the children of Israel, 'I need to do justice with Pharaoh, king of Egypt.'" The Holy One, blessed be He, said to them, "Just as you honor Me, so too should you honor the king, for I need to execute justice upon him." And in the Midrash Rabbah (Parashat Va'eira 7:63), it is said: "A parable of a king who had an orchard and planted in it both barren trees and fruit-bearing trees. His servants said to him, 'What benefit do you have from these barren trees?' He replied, 'Just as I need the fruit-bearing trees, so too do I need the barren trees, for without the barren trees, how would I have places for my baths and kilns?'" Therefore, it is said to the children of Israel and to Pharaoh that just as the praise of the Holy One, blessed be He, rises from the Garden of Eden from the mouths of the righteous, so too does it rise from Gehenna from the mouths of the wicked, etc. What do they say? Rabbi Yochanan said, "You have spoken well, you have judged well." And the intention of the parable is, at first glance, not entirely similar to the lesson, for from the barren trees there is benefit to the king who uses them for his kilns, but what need do the wicked have for their praise? However, it can be explained in our way that there is a need for the wicked to serve as kilns, just like the parable of the barren trees, for the Holy One, blessed be He, will cast them into Gehenna under Israel because they were the ones who caused Israel to sin, and they justify the judgment against them and say, "You have judged well." And even Pharaoh was necessary for the execution of justice upon him, even for the sake of Israel.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author draws a parallel between the necessity of both righteous and wicked individuals in the divine plan, likening the wicked to "trees of waste" that, despite their lack of inherent value, serve a purpose in God's justice. Just as a king requires both fruit-bearing and non-fruit-bearing trees for his needs, God uses the wicked to fulfill His judgment, ultimately leading to the elevation of the righteous. The passage emphasizes that even the presence of evil serves a divine purpose, as it allows for the justification of God's actions and the eventual redemption of Israel. Thus, the wicked, like the trees of waste, play a crucial role in the unfolding of divine justice and the sanctification of God's name.

passage_content: ובזהיתבאר דברי המדרש הנ"ל א"ל הקב"ה למשה חייך יש לך לידע שנא' טוב אחרית דבר מראשיתו, טובה אחריתן של ישראל מראשית שנתתי להם במצרים,דע"יקישוי השעבוד שסבלו ישראל, ניצולו אח"כ מןהחימה, על כי אנוסים היו בידיהם נמצא הם הגורמים לכל מעשיהם, ואף לעתידינתנוהעכו"םפדיונם בטענה זו, ויצמח הצלה לישראל מראשית שסבלו בימי גלותם, וזהו טוב אחרית דבר מראשיתו והבן.
translation: And in this, the words of the aforementioned Midrash are clarified: The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "By your life, you should know that it is said, 'Good is the end of a matter from its beginning.' The goodness of the end of Israel began from the moment I gave it to them in Egypt. Know that the suffering of the servitude that Israel endured led them afterwards to be saved from the wrath, for they were forced in their hands, thus they are the cause of all their actions. And even in the future, the nations will redeem them with this claim, and salvation will sprout for Israel from the beginning of their suffering in the days of their exile. And this is the good of the end of a matter from its beginning; understand this.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the concept of divine providence is emphasized, illustrating that the suffering of the Israelites in Egypt ultimately leads to their redemption. The phrase "טוב אחרית דבר מראשיתו" highlights that the end is inherently good, rooted in the beginning of their trials. The text suggests that the hardships endured by the Israelites serve as a catalyst for their future salvation, reinforcing the idea that their suffering is not in vain but part of a divine plan that ensures their eventual liberation.

passage_content: ולבאריתר הדקדוקיםאפ"לכשראו ישראל המצרים לוקים במכת ערוב והצילם הקב"ה ממנה,התבוננו שגם המה ראויים ללקות במכה זו מידה כנגד מידה כנ"ל, ע"כ עשו הבדלה והפרשה גמורה מדרכיהגויםוקבלו עליהם לילך בדרכי השי"ת בלי שום תערובות, וע"ד שאמר הנביא (צפני' ג' ו') הכרתי גוים נשמופנותםהחרבתיחוצותםוגו' אמרתי אך תראו אותיתקחומוסר וגו', שאם ישראלזוכיןלוקחים מוסר מעונש הבא עלאומה"עועושים תשובה, ובזה מקדמים פני הרעה שלא יגיע אליהם ומעתהאפ"לששני הפירושיםבמאמה"כושמתי פדות,לפרש"ילשון הבדלה והפרשה ולפי' הת"א והמדרשים הוא מלשון פדיון והצלה, שניהם הא בהא תליין, שהביא הקב"ה על המצרים מכת ערוב ופדה והציל את ישראל,ועי"זעשו הבדלה והפרשה גמורה מדרכי המצריים, וא"ש מה שחזר ושנה הכתוב לומר ושמתי פדות וגו', וכבר הזכירשנצולוישראל מערוב שנא' והפליתי ביום ההוא את ארץ גושן וגו', אמנם כאן הודיע לנו הכתוב דבר חדש שע"י הצלה זו עשו ישראל הבדלה והפרשה מדרכי המצריים, וז"א ושמתי פדות בין עמי ובין עמך ונכלל בו ג"כ לשון הצלה ופדיון דשניהם אחד הם, אולם אף שקבלו עליהם במכת ערוב לעשות הבדלה והפרשה מדרכי המצריים, לא זכו למעשה זו בשלימות עד אחר שיצאו ממצרים ואחר קבלת התורה, שאז השיגו בחי' הפרשה זו בשלימותה ואולי זה ירמוז הכתוב ושמתי פדות בין עמי ובין עמך למחר יהי' האות הזה יש מחר שהוא לאחר זמן, דהיינוביצ"מואחר קבלת התורה ישתלם אצלם בחי' הזאת, אלא שמיד קבלו עליהם לעשות הבדלה והפרשה וזה נחשב להם כמעשה.
translation: And to explain the nuances of the words, when the Israelites saw the Egyptians struck by the plague of swarms and that the Holy One, blessed be He, saved them from it, they reflected that they too were deserving of being struck by this plague, measure for measure, as mentioned above. Therefore, they made a complete distinction and separation from the ways of the nations and accepted upon themselves to walk in the ways of the Holy One, blessed be He, without any mixture. And as the prophet said (Zephaniah 3:6), "I have cut off nations; their towers are desolate," I said, "Only you will see my punishment," etc. For if Israel merits, they take reproof from the punishment that comes upon the nations of the world and repent, and through this, they avert the evil from reaching them. And from now on, it can be said that both interpretations in the verse "And I will set redemption" can be explained: the language of distinction and separation, and according to the Targum and the Midrashim, it is from the language of redemption and salvation. Both are interconnected, for the Holy One, blessed be He, brought upon the Egyptians the plague of swarms and redeemed and saved Israel. And through this, they made a complete distinction and separation from the ways of the Egyptians. And it is understood why the verse repeats and says, "And I will set redemption," etc. It has already been mentioned that Israel was saved from the swarms, as it is said, "And I will make a distinction on that day in the land of Goshen," etc. However, here the verse informs us of a new matter: that through this salvation, Israel made a distinction and separation from the ways of the Egyptians. And this means, "And I will set redemption between My people and your people," which also includes the language of salvation and redemption, for both are one. However, even though they accepted upon themselves during the plague of swarms to make a distinction and separation from the ways of the Egyptians, they did not merit to complete this act until after they left Egypt and after receiving the Torah. For then they achieved this level of separation in its completeness, and perhaps this is hinted at in the verse, "And I will set redemption between My people and your people," for tomorrow this sign will be; tomorrow refers to a later time, meaning after leaving Egypt and after receiving the Torah, this quality will be completed among them. Yet, immediately they accepted upon themselves to make a distinction and separation, and this was considered for them as an act.
summary: The passage discusses how the Israelites, upon witnessing the plagues inflicted upon the Egyptians, recognized their own potential for punishment and chose to separate themselves from the ways of the Egyptians. This act of distinction is seen as a form of repentance that allows them to avert further calamity. The text emphasizes that true separation and redemption were fully realized only after the Exodus and the giving of the Torah, highlighting the connection between divine salvation and the commitment to follow God's path. Ultimately, the concepts of redemption and separation are intertwined, illustrating the transformative power of faith and adherence to divine commandments.

passage_content: ואפ"לעוד בדרך רמז מוסר עפ"י המבוארבספה"קדעיקרעבודת בני ישראל בגלות, לברר ולקבץהניצה"קחלקי הנפש ולהעלותם מעומק הקליפות, וזהו ענין קיבוץ נידחים וגאולת הנפשות, ובזהתליאגם גאולת הגופים,דכשישלםבירור כלהניצה"קלהעלותם מעמקי הקליפות אז יגאלו ישראל גאולת עולם בגאולת הנפשות והגופים יחדיו, נמצא כי יסוד הגאולה וסודותליאבשמירת הברית, דאם ח"ו פוגמים בקדושת הברית ר"ל, מפזריםניצה"קבשבי' אל כוחותהסט"אזוגו של הס"מ שמשם מקורו של חטא זה וכמ"שבספה"קרמז מהפסוק וקרבה אשת האחד והחזיקה במבושיו זהו זוגו של הס"מ וכתדילההמחטיאיםלבנ"אבפגם הברית ר"ל, וזהו בחי' הגלות, שחלקי הנפש היינוהניצה"קנשבים ביד הקליפות, וא"א להיגאל גאולת הגוף מביןהגויםזולתי אם תקדים אלי' גאולת הנפש כנ"ל.
translation: And I will add, also in a hint of moral teaching according to what is explained in the holy book, the main work of the Children of Israel in exile is to clarify and gather the sparks of the soul and elevate them from the depths of the klipot. This is the matter of gathering the exiles and the redemption of the souls, and this is also connected to the redemption of the bodies. When the clarification of all the sparks is completed and they are elevated from the depths of the klipot, then Israel will be redeemed with an eternal redemption, with the redemption of the souls and the bodies together. It is found that the foundation of redemption and its secrets depend on the preservation of the covenant. For if, Heaven forbid, they blemish the sanctity of the covenant, they scatter the sparks into the forces of the other side, which is the counterpart of the Sitra Achra, from where the source of this sin comes, as it is written in the holy book, hinted at in the verse, "And the wife of one approached and held onto his garments," this is the counterpart of the Sitra Achra, and it is a great sin that causes people to stumble in the blemish of the covenant, Heaven forbid. This is the aspect of exile, where the parts of the soul are the sparks that are trapped in the hands of the klipot, and it is impossible to achieve the redemption of the body from among the nations unless the redemption of the soul precedes it, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage emphasizes that the primary task of the Jewish people in exile is to refine and gather the sparks of the soul (nitzotzot) trapped in the forces of impurity (klipot) and to elevate them. This process of redeeming the souls is intrinsically linked to the redemption of the body, as the complete elevation of these sparks will lead to a holistic redemption for Israel. It highlights the importance of maintaining the sanctity of the covenant, warning that any transgression can scatter these divine sparks into the hands of the forces of evil, thus prolonging the state of exile. Ultimately, the redemption of the soul must precede the redemption of the body.

passage_content: ואפשרלרמוז זהבמאמה"כפדות שלח לעמוצוהלעולם בריתו,עפי"דהגמ' (נדרים ל"ב ע"ב) גדולה מילה שאלמלא מילה לא נתקיימו שמים וארץ שנאמר (ירמי' ל"ג) אם לא בריתי יומם ולילהחקותשמים וארץ לא שמתי,ופליגאדרבאלעזרדא"ראלעזר גדולה תורה שאלמלא תורה לא נתקיימו שמים וארץ שנא' אם לא בריתי יומם ולילה וגו' עכ"דהגמ' וכתבהמהרש"אז"לדר"אמשמע לי'דהאיברית היינו תורה, דהיינו ברית של יומם ולילהדכתיבובתורתו יהגה יומם ולילה עכ"ל, אמנם צ"בלאידךמ"דדמוקילהאיקרא אם לא בריתי יומם ולילה במצות מילה, ומילה אינה נוהגת אלא ביום ולא בלילה,דנפק"לבגמ' מביום השמיני ימול וגו' ביום ולא בלילה, אולם כברביארנובמקו"אדשלימותמצוה זו של מילה נשלם רק ע"י שמירת הברית, והרמב"ם ז"ל כתב בטעם מצוה זו שהוא להחלישכחהתאוה,ואמרז"לבגמ'דהפוגםבריתו נמשכהערלתוונראה כאינו מהול, עד שאאע"ה אינו מכיר לי' אם מהול ואינו מוציאומגיהנםעיי"ש נמצא שרק ע"י שמירת הברית נתקייםהמצוהבשלימותה, ודבר זה נוהגת ביום ובלילה שצריך שמירה בכל רגע בלי הפסק, ורז"ל אמרו שלא יהרהר אדם ביום ויבוא לידי טומאה בלילה ר"ל, ותלוי בזה קיום כל העולם וגאולתן של ישראל, גם מקושר עם ברית של תורה, שאם יזכה האדםלהתדבקבתוה"ק דביקות אמיתי ולא יתפרד מחשבתו הימנה, אז ינצלבודאימהרהורים רעים ופגם הברית, וכמ"ש הרמב"ם ז"ל דאין ההרהור מצוי אלא בלב פנוי מן החכמה היינו חכמתהתוה"ק,וז"שרז"ל אלמלא מילה ואלמלא תורה לא נתקיימו שמים וארץ. שנא' אם לא בריתי יומם ולילהחקותשמים וארץ לא שמתי,דקיוםכל העולמות תלויים בהם,וז"פהפסוק פדות שלח לעמוצוהלעולם בריתו,שהבוי"תהכיןכחהפדות והגאולה לישראל,ע"ישצוהלעולם בריתו, היינו ברית המילה וברית התורה הנוהגים לעולם יומם ולילה, ואם ישמרו בריתות אלו יזכו להחיש ולמהר גאולתם בב"א.
translation: And it is possible to hint at this in the verse "He sent redemption to His people; He commanded His covenant forever." According to the Gemara (Nedarim 32b), a great word is that if not for the covenant of circumcision, the heavens and the earth would not have been established, as it is said (Jeremiah 33:25), "If My covenant with day and night is not established, and the statutes of heaven and earth I have not set." And there is a dispute with Rabbi Eliezer, who says that the greatness of the Torah is such that if not for the Torah, the heavens and the earth would not have been established, as it is said, "If My covenant with day and night is not established," etc. Thus says the Gemara, and the Maharsha wrote that Rabbi Eliezer means that the Hebrew refers to the Torah, which is the covenant of day and night, as it is written, "And in His Torah he shall meditate day and night." However, it is difficult according to the other opinion that interprets the verse "If My covenant with day and night is not established" in the context of the commandment of circumcision, and circumcision is only practiced during the day and not at night, as it is derived from the Gemara, "On the eighth day, he shall be circumcised," etc., during the day and not at night. However, it has already been explained in various places that the completeness of this commandment of circumcision is fulfilled only through the observance of the covenant, and the Rambam wrote that the reason for this commandment is to weaken the desire. And our sages said in the Gemara that one who damages his covenant has his foreskin extended and appears as if he is uncircumcised, to the extent that even if he is a righteous person, he does not recognize him if he is circumcised and does not save him from Gehenna, as found there. Thus, it is evident that only through the observance of the covenant is the commandment fulfilled in its completeness, and this matter is practiced both day and night, as there must be vigilance at every moment without interruption. And our sages said that a person should not contemplate during the day and come to impurity at night, Heaven forbid. The existence of the entire world and the redemption of Israel depend on this, and it is also connected with the covenant of the Torah, that if a person merits to cling to the Holy Torah with true attachment and does not separate his thoughts from it, then he will be saved from evil thoughts and the blemish of the covenant. As the Rambam wrote, that contemplation is only found in a heart free from wisdom, meaning the wisdom of the Holy Torah. And this is what our sages said, "If not for circumcision and if not for the Torah, the heavens and the earth would not have been established," as it is said, "If My covenant with day and night is not established, and the statutes of heaven and earth I have not set," for the existence of all worlds depends on them. And this is the verse "He sent redemption to His people; He commanded His covenant forever," that the essence of the redemption and the salvation for Israel is prepared through the commandment of His covenant, which is the covenant of circumcision and the covenant of the Torah, which are practiced forever, day and night. And if they keep these covenants, they will merit to hasten and expedite their redemption, may it be soon.
summary: The passage emphasizes the critical importance of the covenants of circumcision (Brit Milah) and Torah in sustaining the existence of the heavens and the earth, as articulated in the Talmud. It highlights that the fulfillment of these commandments requires constant vigilance and dedication, both day and night, to prevent spiritual lapses that could lead to moral decay. The text asserts that true adherence to these covenants is essential for the redemption of Israel and the maintenance of the world, linking the observance of these mitzvot to the ultimate salvation and spiritual elevation of the Jewish people.

passage_content: ויתבארבזה דברי המסורה ושמתי פדות בין עמי ובין עמך, היינו הבדלה והפרשה מןהעכו"םלברר חלקי הנפשהניצה"קהשבויים אצלם, גם יתפרש פדות מלשון פדיון וגאולה כפי' המדרש כי בזהתליאגאולתם של ישראל, וזהו פדות שלח לעמוצוהלעולם בריתו ע"י הברית של תורה וברית של מילה יגאלו ישראל, אמנםבעוה"רהנסיונותוהתגברות כוחות הטומאה גדולים וחזקים עלינו מאוד. ואם כבר נכשל האדם ר"ל בפגם הברית, נבראו ממעשיו מזיקים ומלאכים רעים הגורמים לולחטואעוד ולהביאו לידי הרהורים רעים, ואיןבכחהאדם להתגבר נגדם כ"א בסייעתא דשמיא,ולז"אכי עם ד' החסד והרבה עמו פדותשהבוי"תרב החסד ומרבה להטיב יסייע בידנו להשלים נפשותינו ולהרבות בחי' הפדות ע"י שמירת שני הבריתות שבהםתליאגאולתם של ישראל.
translation: And it will be clarified in these words of the Masorah: "And I have placed redemption between My people and your people," meaning the distinction and separation from the idolaters to clarify the parts of the soul that are captured among them. Also, redemption is explained from the language of redemption and salvation, as the Midrash interprets, for their redemption is dependent on the redemption of Israel. And this is the redemption sent to the people to the world, His covenant through the covenant of the Torah and the covenant of circumcision; through these, Israel will be redeemed. However, in our times, the trials and the strengthening of the forces of impurity are very great and strong against us. And if a person has already stumbled, God forbid, in the breach of the covenant, harmful spirits and evil angels are created from his actions, causing him to sin further and bringing him to evil thoughts. And a person does not have the strength to overcome them except with the help of Heaven. Therefore, it is said that with the Lord, the God of kindness, and much with Him, redemption is abundant; He who increases kindness and does good will assist us in completing our souls and increasing the aspect of redemption through the observance of the two covenants, upon which the redemption of Israel depends.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of redemption (פדות) as a means of distinguishing between the Jewish people and the nations, emphasizing the importance of the Torah and the covenant of circumcision in achieving this redemption. It highlights the challenges posed by the forces of impurity and the consequences of failing to uphold the covenant, which can lead to negative spiritual influences. The text asserts that divine assistance (סייעתא דשמיא) is essential for overcoming these challenges, and that through acts of kindness and adherence to the two covenants, the Jewish people can attain spiritual completeness and redemption.

passage_content: באופןאחראפ"לדברי המסורה, שירמזו הפסוקים על ג' זמני גאולה שהי' בחינתם שונה זה מזה, ושמתי פדות בין עמו ובין עמך ירמוז על גאולת מצרים שנגאלו ישראל מהם לעולם ונפטרו משעבודם לגמרי וז"א ושמתי פדות בין עמי ובין עמך שיהי' הבדלה והפרשה גמורה כמ"ש כי כאשר ראיתם את מצרים היום לא תוסיפו לראותם עוד עד עולם, אמנם בגאולת בבל לא הי' רק בחי' פקידה ועדיין היו ישראל משועבדים תחת יד פרס והרומיים, ולא זכולבחי' הפרשה זו שהי' בגאולת מצרים שנאמר לקחת לו גוי מקרב גוי, אלא שהי' צורך בו להקים עולה של תורה שבע"פ,שנתייסדהבזמן בית שני ע"י אנשיכנה"גוחכמי המשנה כמו שביארנובמקו"א, וזהו ירמוז פדות שלח לעמו, שהי' גאולה ע"י שליח ולא גאולה נצחית רק בחי' פקידה, למען הקים יסוד תושבע"פ,וז"שפדות שלח לעמוצוהלעולם בריתו לקיים ברית התורה, שלא כרת ד' ברית כ"א על תושבע"פכאמרז"לולא אמר בין עמי ובין עמך שלא הי' הפרשה גמורה ועדיין היו משועבדים למלכי פרס כנ"ל ובגלות האחרון הזה שאין לנוכחהתורהוכחשמירת הברית ואיך נזכה להיגאל, אמנם כבר הבטיחנו הנבואה (ישעי' ס"ג) שיאמר הקב"ה ואביט כי אין עוזר ואשתומם כי אין סומךותושעלי זרועי וגו', ואמר למענילמעניאעשה והגאולה העתידה יהי' למען שמוית', וזהו ירמוז כי עם ד' החסד והרבה "עמו" פדות, כביכולהבוי"תנגאל עמנו כמ"ש רז"ל (מגילה כ"ט ע"א) ושב ד'אלקיךאת שבותך והשיב לא נאמר אלא ושב מלמד שהקב"ה שב עמהן מבין הגליות ואז יהי' גאולת עולםוז"שוהרבה עמו פדות שבחי' הגאולה יהי' יתירה וגדולה על כל הגאולות שקדמו אלי',הבוי"תיזכנו לזה בב"א.
translation: According to the words of the Masorah, the verses hint at three times of redemption that were of different natures from one another. "And I will put a redemption between My people and your people" hints at the redemption from Egypt, from which Israel was redeemed forever and completely freed from their servitude. This means that "I will put a redemption between My people and your people" will be a complete distinction and separation, as it is said, "For as you have seen Egypt today, you shall see them no more forever." However, in the redemption from Babylon, it was only a matter of visitation, and Israel was still subjugated under the hands of Persia and the Romans. There was no such separation as there was in the redemption from Egypt, which is stated as taking a nation from the midst of a nation, but there was a need to establish the foundation of the Oral Torah, which was established during the Second Temple by the Men of the Great Assembly and the sages of the Mishnah, as we have explained in various places. This hints at "He sent redemption to His people," which was a redemption through a messenger and not an eternal redemption, only a matter of visitation, in order to establish the foundation of the Oral Torah. This is what is meant by "He sent redemption to His people" to establish His covenant forever, to uphold the covenant of the Torah, for He did not make four covenants except concerning the Oral Torah, as our sages have said. If it were not for the phrase "between My people and your people," there would not have been a complete separation, and they would still have been subjugated to the kings of Persia, as mentioned above. In this last exile, there is no longer the presence of the Torah and the observance of the covenant, and how will we merit to be redeemed? However, the prophecy has already assured us (Isaiah 63) that the Holy One, blessed be He, will say, "And I looked, and there was no helper; and I was astonished, for there was no supporter; therefore, My own arm brought salvation for Me," and He said, "For My sake, for My sake I will act," and the future redemption will be for the sake of His name. This hints that with the Holy One, blessed be He, the kindness and much "with His people" is redemption, as it were, "He will redeem with us," as our sages have said (Megillah 29a), "And the Lord your God will restore your captivity," and it does not say "and He will return," but "and He will return" teaches that the Holy One, blessed be He, returns with them from among the exiles, and then there will be an eternal redemption. This is what is meant by "and much with His people is redemption," that the nature of the redemption will be greater and more significant than all the redemptions that preceded it. May we be worthy of this speedily in our days.
summary: The passage discusses three distinct phases of redemption in Jewish history, emphasizing the complete and eternal nature of the Exodus from Egypt compared to the partial redemption from Babylon. It highlights the necessity of establishing the Oral Torah during the Second Temple period, indicating that this redemption was not absolute but rather a preparation for future spiritual foundations. The text reassures that in the final redemption, God will actively return with His people, leading to a greater and more profound redemption than any previous ones, ultimately fulfilling His covenant with Israel.

passage_content: כיבפעם הזאת אני שולח את כל מגפתי אללבךוגו'פרש"יז"ל למדנו שמכת בכורות שקולה כנגד כל המכות עכ"ל, הקשההרא"םז"ל מכת בכורות מאןדכרשמי', ולמה לא יתפרש על מכת ברד שמדבר בה הכתוב, ותירץ בשם ר"תמאורליינוששהגירסאצ"ל ביכורות, והוא הברד שנלקה בו האביב הממהרלהתבכרוכו', שהוא שקולה נגד כל המכות, אמנם הקשה עליוהגו"אזלה"הממ"שרש"י (בפ' שמות) עה"פ הנה אנכי הורג את בנך בכורך, שמכת בכורות קשה מכולם, ואם נפרש כאן דברי רש"י על מכת ברד, א"כ יהיו דבריו סותרותזא"ז.
translation: As I have said this time, I send all my plagues to you, and we learned that the plague of the firstborn is equivalent to all the plagues. The Ra'ah"m asked why the plague of the firstborn is mentioned specifically, and why it should not be interpreted as referring to the plague of hail that the scripture speaks of. He answered in the name of R"T that the correct version is "firstborn," and it is the hail with which the spring was struck, hastening to be born, which is equivalent to all the plagues. However, he challenged this based on the words of Rashi (in Parshat Shemot) regarding the verse "Behold, I am killing your firstborn," that the plague of the firstborn is more severe than all. If we interpret Rashi's words here as referring to the plague of hail, then his statements would contradict each other.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the significance of the Plague of the Firstborn, emphasizing its weight as being equivalent to all the other plagues combined. The text addresses a question raised by the Ra'ah regarding why the Firstborn plague is not interpreted in relation to the plague of hail, suggesting that it represents a deeper spiritual reality. The commentary highlights the unique severity of the Firstborn plague, as noted by Rashi, indicating that it holds a distinct place in the narrative of the plagues, reflecting profound theological insights into divine judgment and redemption.

passage_content: ב)ממ"שרז"ל עה"פ והנה לא שמעת עד כה, עד שתשמע ממני מכת בכורות שאפתח בכה, שנא' כה אמר ד' בחצות לילה וגו' ואםנימאשמכת ברד שקולה נגד כל המכות, איך יתכן שסבל מכת ברד הקשה שבכולם ולאיכנעלבבו, ואח"כ נכנע ע"י מכת בכורות שאינו קשה כמוהו.
translation: B) From the words of our Sages, regarding the verse "And behold, you have not heard until now," until you hear from me about the plague of the firstborn, which I will open with this, as it is said, "Thus says the Lord, at midnight..." And if we consider the plague of hail, which is equal to all the plagues, how is it possible that he endured the severe plague of hail, the hardest of them all, and was not humbled, and afterwards he was subdued by the plague of the firstborn, which is not as severe as it?
summary: The passage discusses the paradox of Pharaoh's hardened heart, which remained unyielding even in the face of the severe plague of hail, yet ultimately succumbed to the seemingly lesser plague of the firstborn. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of divine intervention and the nature of repentance, suggesting that the spiritual resistance of the heart can be overcome by a more profound, personal revelation of God's will. The text emphasizes the idea that true submission to God often comes through a deeper understanding and recognition of His power, rather than through the severity of punishment alone.

passage_content: ג)את העיר אפרוש את כפי אל ד' וגו'פרש"י(בשם מד"ר) אבל בתוך העיר לא התפלל לפישהיתהמלאה גלולים והקשו המפרשיםדלטעםזה הי' צריך להיות כן בכל המכות, ולא מצינושהזכיר כן אלא במכת ברד בלבד, ובמכת הצפרדעים כתיב ויצא משה ואהרן מעם פרעה ויצעק משה אל ד' וגו', וכן במכת ערוב הנה אנכי יוצא מעמך והעתרתי אל ד', ובמכת הארבה ויצא מעם פרעהויעתרלד' ואינו מבואר שיצא מן העיר כ"א במכת ברד בלבד וטעמא בעי. והרמב"ן ז"ל כתב על דרך הפשט יתכן לומר שהי' משה מתפלל בביתו, רק בפעם הזאת ראה להיות כפיו פרושות השמים ויחדלו הקולות והמטר מיד, ולא יתכן לעשות כן בעיר ע"כ אמר כצאתי את העיר עכ"ל ואינו מבואר כוונתו מדוע הי' צורך במכה זודייקאפרישת כפים, ומ"ט לא יתכן לעשות כן בעיר.
translation: 3) "I will spread my hands to the Lord" (Exodus 9:29) - Rashi (in the name of Midrash Rabbah) explains that he did not pray within the city because it was full of idols. The commentators question why, for this reason, it should have been so for all the plagues, and we find that it is only mentioned in the plague of hail. In the plague of frogs, it is written, "And Moses and Aaron went out from Pharaoh, and Moses cried out to the Lord," and similarly in the plague of wild beasts, "Behold, I am going out from you, and I will entreat the Lord," and in the plague of locusts, "He went out from Pharaoh and entreated the Lord," and it is not clarified that he went out of the city except in the plague of hail alone, and the reason is needed. Nachmanides, may his memory be blessed, wrote that according to the simple interpretation, it is possible to say that Moses was praying in his house, but this time he saw fit to have his hands spread to the heavens, and the sounds and the rain ceased immediately, and it is not possible to do so in the city; therefore, he said, "As I go out of the city." However, his intention is not clear as to why it was necessary in this specific plague to spread his hands, and why it is not possible to do so in the city.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the unique nature of Moses' prayer during the plague of hail, emphasizing that he needed to step outside the city to raise his hands to God. This act symbolizes a deeper spiritual connection that cannot be achieved within the confines of a city filled with idolatry. The text raises questions about the necessity of this specific action and highlights the importance of purity and intention in prayer, suggesting that certain divine interactions require a separation from impure environments. Ultimately, it reflects on the significance of physical posture in prayer as a means to invoke divine intervention.

passage_content: ואפ"לעפי"דהרבינו בחייזלה"השכתב ע"ד הקבלה, שהוצרךמשרע"הבמכה זו להתפלל בנשיאת כפיםמשא"כבכל השאר, מטעם שהיו בנ"א מתים בה לפחד הקולות ולמכת הברדשהיתהבהסכמת הוא ובית דינווכו', ולכך הוצרך בביטולםלישאאת כפיו כדי שיתקדשו כל העשרוכו',וז"שמשה אפרוש כפי אל ד' כלומר אפרוש כפי כנגד העשר ויתקדשוואכויןבהם אל ד' ומיד הקולותיחדלוןעכ"ל, ואולי גם הרמב"ן ז"ל הלביש בדבריו בחי' הסוד הזה כדרכובכ"מ,וז"שכי רק בפעם הזאת ראה להיות כפיו פרושות השמים וכו'והתכויןלבחי' נשיאות כפים והנה לזה צריך טהרה גדולה כמ"שהמט"אדלטעםזה איןנוהגיןלישאכפים בכל יום מפני שאין לנוכחהטהרה הצורךלנ"כעייש"ד, ואולי לטעם זה יצאמשרע"המן העיר לצדשהיתהמלאה גילולים ולא יתכן לעשות עבודה חשובה זו במקום טומאה, אבל בשאר המכות אולי הי' מתפלל בביתו כמ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל, כי מצד הדין סגי בהרחקה זו, ולא נאסר כל העיר בשבילהע"זאשר בו, אלא לפי שהוצרך לנשיאת כפים יצא מן העיר ונרמז סוד זה בלשונוהק' של הרמב"ן ז"ל.
translation: And according to what our Rabbi, may his memory be blessed, wrote in the manner of Kabbalah, that Moshe Rabbeinu needed to pray with raised hands during this plague, unlike in all the others, because there were people dying from the fear of the sounds, and the plague of hail was with his consent and that of his court, etc. Therefore, he needed to raise his hands so that all the ten would be sanctified, etc. This is what is meant by "Moshe will stretch out his hands to God," meaning he will stretch out his hands against the ten and they will be sanctified, and he will direct them towards God, and immediately the sounds will cease, etc. Perhaps also the Ramban, may his memory be blessed, clothed his words with this aspect of the secret as is his way everywhere. This is what is meant by "only this time he saw to have his hands stretched towards the heavens," etc., and he intended the aspect of the raising of hands, and behold, for this a great purity is needed, as it is known that for this reason it is not customary to raise hands every day because there is no need for purity in the presence of the Divine. And perhaps for this reason Moshe Rabbeinu went out of the city, which was full of idols, and it was not fitting to perform this important service in a place of impurity. But regarding the other plagues, perhaps he would pray in his house, as the Ramban, may his memory be blessed, wrote, for according to the law, this distance is sufficient, and the entire city was not forbidden because of the idol worship therein, but since he needed to raise his hands, he went out of the city, and this secret is hinted at in the language of the holy Ramban, may his memory be blessed.
summary: The passage discusses the necessity for Moses to pray with raised hands during the plague of hail, emphasizing the importance of spiritual purity and intention in prayer. It suggests that this act of raising hands serves to sanctify the ten plagues and connect them to the Divine. The text also highlights the significance of performing such a sacred act in a state of purity, indicating that Moses had to leave the city filled with idols to maintain this sanctity. Additionally, it reflects on the deeper mystical insights of the Ramban regarding the conditions under which prayer and divine intervention occur.

passage_content: ואפ"לעוד בהקדם לבאר דברי רש"י ז"ל למדנו שמכת בכורות שקולה כנגד כל המכות, ולכאורה לפי משמעות הפסוק מכת ברד שקולה נגד כולןדכתיבכי בפעם הזאת אני שולח את כל מגפתי וגו' וכתב רבינו בחיי ז"ל שבמכת ברד נכללו בו מגיפות הרבה וזהו כל מגפתי עיי"ש גם הי' בו שינוי מנהגו של עולם שנא' ויהי ברד ואש מתלקחת בתוך הברד,ואמרז"לבמד"ר(פ' י"ב סי' ד') שהי' נס בתוך נס האש והברדמעורביןוהברד מים הוא ולעשות רצון קונם עשו שלו' ביניהם, וע"כ נתרכך לב פרעה ולא הכביד את לבו כבראשונים, ואמר חטאתי הפעם ד' הצדיק ואני ועמי הרשעים, אלא שהחזיק ד' את לבבו כמ"ש ויחזק לב פרעה ולא שלח אתבנ"י, כי עדיין לא הגיע זמן גאולתם של ישראל, ובסודן של דברים הי' צורך עוד להביא עליו עוד מכת ארבה חושך מכת בכורות, ע"כ נתן לו השי"ת אבירת הלב ואחר שחדל הברד הכביד לבו הוא ועבדיו.
translation: And furthermore, to clarify the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, we learned that the plague of the firstborn is equivalent to all the plagues. And seemingly, according to the meaning of the verse, the plague of hail is equivalent to all of them, as it is written, "For this time I will send all My plagues..." And Rabbi Bechaye, may his memory be blessed, wrote that in the plague of hail many afflictions were included, and this is "all My plagues." Also, there was a change in the order of the world, as it is said, "And there was hail, and fire mingled with the hail." And our sages of blessed memory said in the Midrash (Parashat 12, section 4) that there was a miracle within a miracle, the fire and the hail were mixed, and the hail is water, and to do the will of their Creator, they made peace between them. Therefore, Pharaoh's heart softened, and he did not harden his heart as he had before, and he said, "I have sinned this time; the Lord is righteous, and I and my people are wicked." However, the Holy One, blessed be He, strengthened his heart, as it is written, "And the Lord hardened Pharaoh's heart," and he did not send the Children of Israel, for the time of Israel's redemption had not yet arrived. And in the secret of the matter, there was still a need to bring upon him another plague of locusts, darkness, and the plague of the firstborn. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, gave him a strong heart, and after the hail ceased, he and his servants hardened their hearts.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Plague of the Firstborn, which is considered equivalent to all the plagues, highlighting its theological weight. It contrasts this with the Plague of Hail, which included multiple afflictions and demonstrated a miraculous intertwining of fire and hail, symbolizing divine intervention. The text emphasizes that Pharaoh's heart was softened temporarily, acknowledging his wrongdoing, yet God ultimately hardened his heart to fulfill the necessary sequence of plagues leading to Israel's redemption. This reflects the Hasidic concept of divine timing and the unfolding of redemption through a series of divinely orchestrated events.

passage_content: וז"פהפסוק כי בפעם הזאת אני שולח את כל מגפתי, אללבךשיהי' לפי מדתלבךוינתןלך אומץ הלב שתוכל לסבלו, אף שהוא שקולה כנגד כל המכות כאומרו את כל מגפתי, אמנם במכת בכורות הי' רצוןהבוי"תשישלח את ישראל מיד, כמ"ש עוד נגע א' אביא על פרעה ועל מצרים אח"כ ישלח אתכם, וע"כ לא חיזק ד' את לבבו במכה זו, ולא הי' בכוחו לסבול עוד והוכרח לשלחם,ולפי"זאפשרדמצדהאיכותהיתהמכת הברד קשה מכולן, אבל לפי שנתן לו הקב"ה אבירת הלב הי' יכול לסבלו ופג צערו מיד אחר שחדל הברד, וזהו כלל גדול דאם יש לאדם אבירת לב יכול לסבול הרבה יותר מכוחו, ואם אין לו אומץ הלב אינו יכול לעמוד אפי' ברכות ולצד זה הי' מכת בכורות קשה מכולן לפי שניטל ממנו חוזק הלב.
translation: And in this verse, "For this time I will send all My plagues upon your heart," it will be according to the measure of your heart, and He will give you courage of heart so that you can endure it, even though it is equivalent to all the plagues, as it says, "all My plagues." However, in the plague of the firstborn, it was the will of the Holy One, blessed be He, to send Israel out immediately, as it is written, "I will bring one more plague upon Pharaoh and upon Egypt; afterward, he will send you out." Therefore, God did not strengthen his heart in this plague, and he was no longer able to endure and was compelled to send them out. According to this, it is possible that the quality of the plague of hail was the hardest of all, but since the Holy One, blessed be He, gave him courage of heart, he was able to endure it, and his pain ceased immediately after the hail stopped. And this is a great principle: if a person has courage of heart, he can endure much more than his natural strength; but if he lacks courage of heart, he cannot withstand even blessings. And on the other hand, the plague of the firstborn was the hardest of all because the strength of the heart was taken from him.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the concept of divine providence and the nature of suffering, emphasizing that God tailors afflictions to an individual's capacity to endure them. The text highlights that during the plague of the firstborn, God did not strengthen Pharaoh's heart, leading to his inability to withstand the suffering, while the plague of hail was bearable for him due to the divine gift of courage. This illustrates a fundamental Hasidic idea that one's inner strength and courage can significantly influence their ability to endure hardships, and that the severity of suffering is often linked to the state of one's heart. Ultimately, the passage underscores the importance of divine assistance in facing trials and the varying degrees of suffering based on one's spiritual resilience.
